Draught at the brewpub. Clear golden. Light grapefruity hop aroma. Dry with light body and clean mouthfeel.A very straightforward, drinkable IPA with medium bitterness.

This is a great IPA. This is not thoe tyes that just kick you in the head and leave you NOT wanting more. This has a great flavor and the hops where just right for a good IPA. A nice dark amber color with a great haed. Loved the flavors and you could actually tatse a bit of the malts.

This starts out great, and you tink it will be a great IPA, but then it just disappears off the radar completely. This one leaves you really thirsty. A rich almost amber hue, with a nice aroma, that tingles your nose but leaves your tastebuds hanging.

column1: Lucky Labrador Open Bridge Brown Ale
column5: On tap. Brown with a thin off white head. Light scent of toasted malt. Taste is toasted malts, coffee and chocolate.

column1: Lucky Labrador Open Bridge Brown Ale
column5: brown ale with a good malt and hops backing. Nice aroma and flavor this was a very nice easy drinking beer. I liked the flavors and could drink this all day.

column1: Lucky Labrador Open Bridge Brown Ale
column5: Draught. Poured brown with thin head. Faint but pleasant malt aroma. Flavour is hoppy and sweet with a medium body and a thin finish

column1: Lucky Labrador Open Bridge Brown Ale
column5: More of a salmon-amber color than the brown one would expect of the style. Topped with a resilient head. Mild roasty malt and crystal nose. Dusky, somewhat old shoe flavor along with some off malt notes. Essence of spoiled walnuts. Possibly oxidated and overly walnutty finish.

column1: Lucky Labrador Open Bridge Brown Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. This was the cask-conditioned version. Pours a chestnut brown with a big bubbled ecru head. This is super mild and flat beer, served at room temperature. Very candy sweet. Almonds! The beer is a bit too sweet and almost green tasting.

column1: Lucky Labrador Open Bridge Brown Ale
column5: Date: September 19, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear brown with ruby edges, fine beige head, drippy lace Aroma: swwet chocolate and caramel aroma Flavor: sweet chocolate flavor, dark caramel swetness, balancing earthyness Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4

column1: Lucky Labrador Open Bridge Brown Ale
column5: Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a malty caramel aroma with some roasted hints. Roasted malty caramel flavor with some hints of licorice and hops. Has a roasted malty caramel finish with some hoppy hints .

column1: Lucky Labrador Open Bridge Brown Ale
column5: A nice and darker brown, anise quality, but mostly a malt body, thicker than many.

column1: Lucky Labrador Open Bridge Brown Ale
column5: On tap at BrewPub Portland OR, Pours out a dark brown topped with a tan head. Aroma of roast malt. Tast some sweetness of black licorish (or how ever you spell it) and a nice nut tast.

column1: Lucky Labrador Open Bridge Brown Ale
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Dark brown. Lightly roasty. Medium sweet with fairly soft mouthfeel. Lightly salty with some licorice-like hoppy bitterness. An oridinary but hoppy aroma.

column1: Lucky Labrador Top Dog Extra Special Pale Ale
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Slightly hazy orange pour. White head. Soft citrus meat on the nose. Also soft texture. Slight hop bite late. Okay.

column1: Lucky Labrador Top Dog Extra Special Pale Ale
column5: Slightly hazy pale golden colour. Nose is sort of apricot-like but without the sweetness that I sometimes get from beers with this flavour in it. Moderate bitterness with some nice fruitiness.

column1: Lucky Labrador Top Dog Extra Special Pale Ale
column5: Iâ€™ve drunk my share of lucky labs, and this is one of their best. Well balanced hop flavors of resin, lemon & a peppery spice. the aroma sticks more with the resin, plus caramel and alcohol. Clear amber with minima lwhite head (all the beers here lightly carbonated.) light and refreshing in the mouth. clean finish. Today they just called it Top Dog with 6% alcohol.

column1: Lucky Labrador Top Dog Extra Special Pale Ale
column5: Name: Top Dog Pale Ale Date: 10/14/1996 Source: Brewpub clear light amber, everlasting whispy head, mild flowery hop aroma with a touch of sweetness, medium dry hop flavor with continous underlying bitterness lasting through the finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column1: Lucky Labrador Top Dog Extra Special Pale Ale
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Clear deep golden. Aroma of apricot and orange. Dryish with clen, crisp mouthfeel. Nicely hoppy, yet easy going and very drinkable. Medium bitterness.

column1: Lucky Labrador Top Dog Extra Special Pale Ale
column5: on tap at lucky labrador. light amber appearance with a persistent head. some pine and school desk in the aroma, plenty of butterscotch flavour and a hint of menthol. just lacking a bit of bitterness

column1: Lucky Labrador Top Dog Extra Special Pale Ale
column5: Tap@Lucky Labrador. Spicy US hops, lightly aromatic. Caramelly/toffee, but not overdone at all, a tad bit dull compared to there other beers, but it was still OK.

column1: Lucky Labrador Top Dog Extra Special Pale Ale
column5: This one rocks. Orange with a nice head. Yummy yummy in my tummy sweet citrus burst. Floral and fruity with exceptional balance.

column1: Lucky Labrador Top Dog Extra Special Pale Ale
column5: Draft: mild malt nose some carmel. Orange copper color. Good malt hop mix. Carmel comes to mind. Clean, kinda creamy. Not bad. Didn't wow me either though.

column1: Lucky Labrador Top Dog Extra Special Pale Ale
column5: Tap. Hoppy floral aroma. Quick bite. Slightly malty. Was that the smell of dog in this beer? Oh, that was the 50 dogs that were hanging our outside the bar. They even had a band playing.
3rd Brewery 07-08 Brew Trip with Bikesandbeer. Pours orange with a half finger tan head. Nose is sweet malts and its prickly bitter, was listed as Best Bitter.
Tap. Copper to amber color. Somewhat sweet, bitter, malty, and a medium body.
Tasty and rich stout, but pretty smooth and drinkable. Basically like many of their beers - really solid, but nothing spectacular. Good.
Draft at the source as Black Mo, 5.1%. Dark maroon, tan nitro head. Aroma of dark chocolate. Taste is fruity coffee, dry finish.
Draft at the brewery. Very dark with off white head and lacing. some coffee, chocolate and toffee notes... Needs some more body. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Transfer from BA reviewed 1-19-12 - Had on tap at the brew pub served in a pint glass. Appearance â€“ The black as night nitro driven beer forms a beautiful white head which cascades through the dark brew giving a nice, just off white, foam head with very nice retention. A thing of beauty in a beer. Smell â€“ Roasted malts and dark chocolate are the first to be encountered. While the two dominate the nose, a faint bit of sweetness works its way at the end. Taste â€“ The flavor of roasted malts give a nice very nutty-toasty taste. The cocoa flavor then develops shortly after, complementing the roasted notes very nicely. The nutty, toasty malt with chocolate overtones then sweetens ever so slightly toward the end of the tasting, with hints of vanilla swirled into the other more dominant flavors. A very nice balance. Nothing overpowers too much, but the important flavors shine at just the right time. Mouthfeel â€“ Creamy to say the least. The perfectly formulated nitro driven body combined with the wonderfully balanced and non overpowering lighter malt body makes for a very smooth drinking experience. So wonderfully smooth, light and refreshing; the silk of the beer world. Overall â€“ This is one great beer. I have tasted this many times before and every time I have it I am surprised at how wonderfully creamy, tasty, light and satisfying it is. For anyone out there this is a must try.
Pours a beautiful dark opaque black with a creamy nitro head. Nose is malty, roasty and chocolate, Taste is chocolate and a bit light. Finish is dry without any carbonation. Quaff Scote 7 / 10

Draft. Pours deep, dark brown with thick, creamy beige head; good retention and lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and dark fruit. Flavor is heavy roasted and caramel malt, light dark fruit esters, light earthy hops, and some smoke; creamy taste with dry finish. Full body, medium carbonation, and low warmth.

Tap. Pours black with a large, creamy light tan head, medium retention with excellent lacing. Aroma is toast, chocolate and coffee malt, leather yeast with dark fruity esters. Flavor is malt dominant with light hops and medium bitterness, dark fruity esters, leather and faint peat notes with a dry finish. Light body and warmth with medium carbonation.
on nitro-pours a retaining tight tan head that sheets and black color. Aroma is dark malt-roasty. Taste is dark malt-chocolate/roasty, some hops balance.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a black color with a longlasting creamy off-white head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and caramel aroma. Sweetish roasted malty chocolate flavor with weak hints of coffee and caramel. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish.
On tap at brewpub. Black with very thick tan head. Aroma is faint roastiness. Very creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is roasted malts. Solid but not great stout.

A solid well-balanced Octoberfest - clear orange color, malt sweetness just barely balanced out by some faint European hop backbone. Easy to drink, but not one I'd return to all that frequently given my style preferences.

Draft at Ottoâ€™s. Pours clear ambrt with small, lacing white head. Brown sugar and bread, some light grain. Octoberfest goodness, biscuit and caramel, clean and crisp, mild hoppy notes, but light. Solid festbier.

Transfer from BA review on 9-30-12- Served on tap in a pint glass Appearance â€“ Served an amber colored beer with a slight orange-red hint. Upon serving there was almost no head at all. With almost no head, there was really no lacing at all either. Smell â€“ The aroma of the beer was a nice blend of sweet caramel and toffee mixed with roasted malt and a very light fruit aroma. With these aromas, is a very light spice aroma which rounds out the aroma of the brew quite nicely. Taste - The taste begins with a flavor of caramel and some roasted malt. As the taste advances through the middle to the end it dries then sweetens up again. In the middle the taste dries as more roasted, light spice, and a very light nuttiness comes to the tongue. While these dry out the beer, it is only temporary. At the end of the taste the sweet strikes back; a caramel and toffee flavor come to the tongue and when combined with the roast leave a very pleasantly sweet roasted flavor on the tongue. Mouthfeel â€“ The body and the carbonation of the beer were both rather average. Both were nice for the style as they made for an easy drinking and refreshing beer without compromising any of the flavors by being over carbonated and light. Overall â€“ This beer, in my opinion, is a very nice example of a Oktoberfest. It has great flavors, is very drinkable and smells wonderful. Besides its lack of a great look (due to lack of head) it is a fantastic brew.

The beer appears average with a clear orange hue, a one finger white head, and decent lacing on the glass. The beer smells average as it has a mild malty/caramel blended nose. The beer tastes great as you get a decent malty flavor that is followed by a toffee/caramel finish, very strong flavors as opposed to the nose. The mouthfeel is decent as the beer is well carbonated and leaves you somewhat dry. Overall, the smell lacked and the taste didnâ€™t...not a bad marzen.
One of the better marzens Iâ€™ve had over the years. Nice amount of sweet caramel malts. A lager that I would order more than one of is saying something, and this is one of them.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a crystal clear, copper-gold colored body with a finger-width, frothy, off-white head that dissipates quickly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is a light malt sweetness with some grains and a bit of a bland fruit. Flavor is better. Somewhat grainy, lightly toasted malts with a touch of toffee-bread sweetness. Very light earthy hopping comes in to balance with a light fruit as well. Finishes clean and mostly dry with a very light bitterness before leaving a medium length aftertaste. Medium-light body and a soft, moderate carbonation. Overall, an alright Oktoberfest. Nothing special, but easy drinking and well balanced.

Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a bright orange color with a huge foamy orange-white head that lingered and left great lacing. The aroma was tangy faint vague fruits. The flavor was dryish and nutty with a bit of perfume. Medium finish and body. Eh.

Re-rated. Last month (first batch) was undrinkable. This is their second batch of the season. On tap at brewpub. Light orange with thin white head that disappears. Aroma is very faint straw. Flavor is straw and a little caramel. Dry for an Oktoberfest. Solid marzen
Draft. Pours brownish copper wirh ruby edges and an off-white head. Nose is Wheaties, nuts, caramel malt. Tastes of grainy cereally malt, mild brown sugar, nuts, hops, and tannins. A decent marzen.

Bought a growler of this and drank it while tailgating at the Penn State vs. Temple football game. It retained itâ€™s carbonation for about 24 hours. Nice, thick, tan head with reddish orange body. Slightly sweet, and I agree not a whole lot of flavor, very little bitterness.
Apricot and wheat aroma. Go figure. Not a beer I'd want to drink all the time. Pours hazy orange with ok head. Tangy finish. Can.

Bottle from the Wegmans in State College (after finding the brewpub was out). Nose flush with seemingly artificial apricot extract. Pour clear golden with a touch of brass, sudsy off-white head. Taste half-smooth and half-crisp, medium-full body not overly malty but nicely struck with a bit of bread in the finish. The apricot experience is much nicer in the mouth that at times it more resembles bramble berries than stone fruit. Clean and quenching, maybe a touch too sweet for two or three, but possibly correctable by mixing with seltzer. Absolutely worth going out and getting. [2018.07.10: 3.2]

Poured into a nonic pint glass, the appearance was a semi-hazy copper/amber color with a little white head that swiftly dissipated. No lace. The aroma had sweet apricots up front, light grassy hops at the end, not much else. The flavor was the sweet apricots with a sweet apricot aftertaste and finish. The feel was light bodied with a decent carbonation and ABV. Overall, I think I got enough words in for this so called review, but I didnâ€™t get any wheat. Decent for what Ottoâ€™s wanted to do. But I will have to disagree and say this is more of Spring/Summer beer, I wouldnâ€™t want this in the dead of Winter. Iâ€™ll stick to my big stouts in the Winter.
Aroma and taste is very much apricot. Unfortunately, thatâ€™s not a taste I enjoy.
Draft at Zenoâ€™s. Poured a hazy yellow with off-white head. Aroma was strong on apricot. Fruit notes, hazy sweet malt notes.
Nice light wheat malt body with a sweet backbone and dry finish. Crisp apple and citrus notes and definite apricot feeling overall.
Bottle. Hazy golden amber color. Huge aroma of apricot jam. Taste is jammy and fruity. Very tasty.
12 oz bottle at the DC Local Tasting. Slightly hazy yellow with off-white head. Aromas of big apricots, Tastes of big apricots, stone fruit. Medium-light body with a dry finish.

12oz bottle pours a clear orange with some cloudy, white head. Nose has tons of apricots, tons of orange, a lot of bubblegum too. Flavor is sweet and then just tons of fruit, apricots, peaches, canned fruit. Clean finish.
Apricot aroma. Hazy amber, thin head. Apricot dominated flavor. Light body. Tasty, but singularly fruited. Should be re-classed as a fruit beer.
Draft at KClingers. Bronze color makes me wonder if I got the right beer. Light hoppy aroma; drinks with an even malt keel. Drinkable. (#3911, 5/23/2010)
Rated 9/15/07 - Draft Sample at brewpub. Light golden color with small white head. Sweet, normal malty lager taste. A bit muddled finish, hoppy and lingering. not bad.

On tap at the brewpub. Aroma, what aroma? A plain weak malt falters into the room, barely noticed. Pours a polished bronze, golden in hue, rimmed in white. Flavor is even less descriptive than the aroma, thereâ€™s a palatable seltzer water quality and a particular derision of light corn, but mostly a bland malt figure, with nips of old lemon, salty grain and sweet honey. Body runs somewhere between thin and full. Maybe satisfying, but somehow not thirst quenching. Finishes dry with maybe a little bit of grain crispness. Totally forgettable. Seems a shame to waste this style as the BMC look a like.

On tap at the brewpub on 4/9/07: Pours a transparent bright golden with a thin, frothy white head. Aroma of slightly sweet pale grainy malt and a touch of floral noble hops. Body starts lightly malty turning more bitter and thinner toward a crisp finish. True to style and drinkable.
On draft at Zenoâ€™s, Penn State. Poured clear gold with minimal head. Flavor is sweet and light. Very crisp finish.

Re-Rate. Tap at the brewpub. Poured into an imperial pint glass- nice clear gold with lively carbonation, a nice lasting fluffy head and some nice lacing. Aroma is grainy, fresh pils malt, bready, lightly sweet and very light herbal german hops. Nice slightly sweet, with a dryish grainy flavor with more bready fresh pils malt, and a nice crisp quenching finish. This was a lot better than the first time I had sampled this at the brewpub a couple years ago.

Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a medium golden color with a small white head. The aroma is light sour malts with a hint of floral hops. The flavor is your typical sour tangy lager with a hint of dry nut on the finish. Fairly basic.

Draught at the brewery. Clear solid yellow color, a bit darker than most, with light trails of bubbles rising quickly through the body, with a thin white head. Light, syrupy flavors of corn and hay, with a moderately peppery nose. Simple tasting overall, crisp and refreshing, but still simply made.

Clear yellow-straw body with moderate visible carbonation and a loose, sudsy white head. Aroma is fresh with pleasantly buttery malt qualities plus floral and honey notes. Good malt character in the flavor with light residual sweetness and some lightly crisp, developing bitterness. A nice, clean helles after a long drive.

Draft. Decent aroma, light hoppy appeal. Light lager color with minimal head. Flavor is smooth with very little bitterness. Very drinkable and one that goes well with all of the food at Ottoâ€™s especially the hadok.

column1: Middle Ages White Knight Light Ale
column5: From old tasting notes. Hazy amber orange color topped by a rocky beige head. Spicy malt nose. Crisp dry malt flavor balanced by a bitter hop finish. Lacks depth.

column1: Middle Ages White Knight Light Ale
column5: You know... Iâ€™m not sure if this beer is labeled right based on other reviews. It definitely is called this... but this review will be a lot different than a few Iâ€™ve read. First of all... MY GOD. The cap was capped so tightly that the bottle FREAKING BROKE. This brewery has already killed one of my openers, and luckily this one wasnâ€™t gonna break. After I carefully poured it and avoided glass shards it gave a cloudy dark amber body with a small head. Didnâ€™t seem much like a light ale to me. The beer itself was fairly one dimensional, but certainly enjoyable. Big vanilla aroma. Flavor was the same. Maybe some hints of lighter fruits in there. Really... Iâ€™m totally baffled by this one. It wasnâ€™t that light bodied. It certainly wasnâ€™t golden or blonde in color. Perhaps they changed what they put in this because most of the previous reviews say this beer sucks. In this case Iâ€™m more confident itâ€™s a different beer than me losing my mind. Usually itâ€™s the other way around.

column1: Middle Ages White Knight Light Ale
column5: Clear golden colour with a thinnish white head. Aroma of subtle American hops with some rice & sugar and nothing else. Light-bodied (as expected); Mild hop flavour with some sweetness & not much else. Aftertaste bland and not pleasant at all. Overall, horrible-but I wanted to try another inferior beer from this brewery, because I was leaving from New York a week later. I sampled this 12 ounce bottle purchased from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York on 30-July-2004 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia.

column1: Middle Ages White Knight Light Ale
column5: Golden ale with a maple syrup aroma. Dry in mouth. Fresh malt and maple sweet tatse. Lighter bodied.

column1: Middle Ages White Knight Light Ale
column5: Cask: Had this at the Old Toad, Rochester. Mostly clear, blonde yellow color with a minimal white head that disappears. Thereâ€™s almost no aroma coming from this beer albeit some light malt and floral notes. As much as I love ales on cask, it just doesnâ€™t do anything for this beer. Simply put, itâ€™s bland. Thereâ€™s nothing offensive in the taste whatsoever, but thereâ€™s nothing really great there either. Some very mild hops, light malt characteristics, light carbonation, and a watery mouth feel. Inoffensive is about all I can say. Why would they bother putting a light ale on cask? Hmm.

column1: Middle Ages White Knight Light Ale
column5: On tap at Middle Ages Brewery, Syracuse NY: This tastes like a cream ale/blond ale hybrid with no redeeming quality of either.; cabbage/corn aroma, weak flavor, and generally unappealing.

column1: Middle Ages White Knight Light Ale
column5: Pours a hazy blonde color with little to no head, and what head there is is gone fast. I can't really smell anything. High carbonation, mild hoppiness, maybe a little fruitiness from the hops. A decent light beer, I mean there is a little flavor at least.

column1: Middle Ages White Knight Light Ale
column5: Pours slightly hazy blonde with a minimal quickly dissipating white head. Aroma is very faint--maybe some mild maltiness. Start and middle are massively carbonated to the point where you have trouble tasting anything. Finish has a nice little hop kick to it. Pretty good for a light beer. Was much better than I expected.

column1: Middle Ages White Knight Light Ale
column5: This one looks like some kind of old-person fiber-boosting drink to keep you "regular". The aroma was slightly malty with a light malty taste.

column1: Middle Ages White Knight Light Ale
column5: Orange in color with a small white head.Hoppy,floral,yeasty aroma with a bitter finish.

Interesting that the description says malty as I am not a fan of malty IPA's. Does not have that strong of a malt aroma or taste. Very smooth. Will definitely get again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Orange pour with creamy off white head and lace. Caramel malt and citrus hops on the nose. Flavor is sweet caramel malt with a good resiny bitter finish with a bit of floral as well. A touch of cough medicine on the back end. Medium bodied but a touch foamy. ok
Draft. Milky orange-caramel malt and orange peel aroma. Golden amber with moderate head. Sweet orange-caramel malt and moderately bitter herbal orange peel flavor. Solid.
3oz draft sampler pours amber with a off white head. Aroma of citrus, floral and caramel. Taste is sweet malts and citrus. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

tap at the brewpub - Grapefruit hop character dominates the aroma of this IPA. The flavor is of sweet malt with a hint of caramel up front and some good citrus accented bitterness. Itâ€™s medium bodied and pretty tasty.

Got some dinner at Turoniâ€™s staying at a nearby hotel on our roadtrip. IPA was served in a pint glass, copper-amber color with off-white head. Aroma of floral/earthy hops and caramel malt. Taste leans more light citrus hops balancing well with the caramel malt. Medium body, average carbonation, light hoppiness with slight bitter aftertaste. I wish it has been a little more hoppy but very drinkable and enjoyable.

Actually, this is a pretty good IPA. I really prefer more of a citrus hoppiness but all things considered, itâ€™s very drinkable. I always make sure I have a growler on hand to get filled when I pass by the Newburgh, IN location.

Draught. Pours dark amber with a good sized soapy off-white head that leaves a sheath of lacing down the glass. Sweet floral aroma with a crystal malt extract xharacter. Flavor is quite sweet and malty with less bitterness than would be expected.
Draught at brewpub/pizza place. Slight malt build. Some ok hops and aroma. Drinkable if not very impressive.

Tap and served too cold: Coppery hue with a fading frothy head. The aroma has notes of citric and grassy hops, caramel and toasty malts, some grainy pale malts, and mineral water. The taste is a bit twangy and mild sweet malts with lead to a nutty and house yeast characteristic. There is a medicinal note that is a bit off putting. The mouth feel is soft yet biting. A okay beer with pizza but not as hoppy as I would have liked, the hops did appear a bit more as it warmed.
Not the best. Sticky artificial sweetness. Light and crisp bitterness. Tried with Laurens, Paul, and Dave before the Rye-union in 2019.

Moutig met een licht zoetje en een redelijke bitter. Ruikt moutig, drinkt lekker door en ziet er gewoon goed uit voor een pilsje. Doorzichtig geel met genoeg schuim. Eerlijk gezegd had ik met zo'n foute naam en vreselijk lelijk logo een slechter biertje verwacht. Maar deze is gewoon oke voor pils Proefglas
Fles 30cl op een camping. Marginaal, zoetig . (8-2011).---------------------.
50cl can. Thin white head. Clear golden pour. Chemical cheap aftertaste. Not great.
From a 0,33 cl bottle. Clear yellow without Smallingerland head. Easy to drink beer. Exactly what you would expect from a cheap supermarket beer, but not bad.
Straight from the can. Some sweet malts, bread, light fake honey. Weird light bitter finish. Cheap macro lager but drinkable just like the rest.
Can. This really, really is not the best bier, actually more like some of the worst beers. Sweet and malty, nothing else. They even used maltose, which is a very bad sign. Yak.
Lichtgeel bier met schuim. Smaak is vlak en weinig bijzonder. Gewoon supermarkt bier.

Can: Served in a shaker: Medium sized fluffy white foamy head on top of a clear lighter yellow colored beer. Aromas of malts, pils malts, light wood, some oat, some cardboard and herbs. Flavours are quite low: some malts, herbs, mineral, bitters, grains, pils malts, light cardboard and some very light woody tones. Aftertaste is even lighter, some malts, light bitter, some herbs... Low carbo, creamy mouthfeel, low bodied and a watery to light creamy mouthfeel. Meh...

Some supermarket in Rotterdam: Pours golden yellow with a fizzy white head. Aroma is grainy, grassy, and cheap. Taste is slightly sweet, a tad hoppy, but mostly cheap and grainy. For a cheap-o beer with a funny label, this isnâ€™t bad.
(2008)This was a very tasty pilsner. It was light and refreshing. This would be a great beer on a nice hot summer day. I would definitely buy this beer again.
On tap at Bristol, Colorado Springs. Bowl of pretzels. While reading a good book. Easy to drink pilsner is very refreshing after a stressful day. Light yellow color. Small medium bubble head.

Draft at SBR. Tasted on 7/11/09. Pours a pale yellow (SRM 3) ovr a clear body....nose light hop, mild malt, no spice from hop, no bite....taste is grass, corn and ?lime....very light mouth feel. Not enough hop nose or spice taste to be really good.
(on tap at the brewery). Pours a yellow color. Medium size white head. Light lemon aroma. Light wheat flavor that is lasting. Smooth finish. Soft to moderate carbonation.
Crushed at the Pumphouse Spring Beer Festival. Very yeasty pilsener. Some malt on the nose with a bit of poop. Flavor is yeasty and a bit sour but itâ€™s aight.

Had this beer on 7/9/2005. Aroma is a sweet bright malt scent. Color is a bright yellow/gold with good carbonation and thin head. Taste is clean and bitter. Starting with a light body it goes down with a crisp feel. Finish comes on with a smooth malt flavor backed by a faint hop flavor and a bold bitter end. This may be one of the best and most well rounded Pilsners I have ever had.
On tap at Bristol Brewsing. A light yellow color with foamy white head. Slightly bitter hoppy nose. Grainy body. Surprisingly good for a pils.
Great micro pilsner - very refreshing taste and worth the trip to the brewery. Also served at Sky Sox games.

The whole collection of Bristol brews that are only available (and drinkable) at the Bristol brewpub is the biggest secret in Colorado Springs, second only to NORAD, and everybody at least knows NORAD is there. So I like to pop in to the brewery every once and awhile and see whatâ€™s on tap. Last time it was Skull & Bones, and making the typical naÃ¯ve college assumption I expected it this time around too. No such luck Iâ€™m afraid, but they did have two others of mild interest: Edge City Wit and Edge City Pilsner. The Pilsner was actually purchased by my friend, but we had something of a sampler session. I continue to stand by my love for Winter Warlock - and little else of Bristolâ€™s. The Pilsner was a fairly regular pilsner and lacked the charm that instills most of Bristolâ€™s beverages, even though they may not be the most complex or spirited. It sat upright in its glass like a bubbly column of neon yellow; an inch thick cap of alpine white crested on the top making a foam moustache free sip impossible. A thorough search with all two of my nostrils yielded no discernible scent. I may attribute this to the open, sterile and crowded nature of the bar. I may also attribute it to the veritable foam cork that plugged the top of the beer. The taste was pretty clear â€“ not watery. It bubbled and trickled with a very feint pilsner taste, tinged with a light skunkiness and left bereft of anything that could make it a strong pils. While not burdensome, itâ€™s not enlightening and lacked any character that would make it a beer eminent in my memory. If you ever visit the Brewpub Iâ€™d recommend having something else poured â€“ especially as this winter gives us such a wonderful sweet stout benison poured under the guise of a green-faced magician.

Bomber {Thanks to BeerandBlues2} poured a hazy gold with a small quickly dissapating white head. Aromas of breadlike malt and a touch of citrus. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of cereal, fruitiness and and a hint of lemon with a smooth lingering bitter finish.
Tasted several times. Clear golden with a small white head. Aroma is malty and grainy. Taste is corn, malts and soft caramel. Flat, metallic and low bodied. Next one please!

33cl Bottle from a SPAR in Maspalomas. Clear deep golden colour, white head. Aroma of some light sour grain, aspartame, hint of iron, light toast. Flavour is light to medium sweet, malty, light grainy, light sourness, metallic bitterness. Light bodied. Not so good.
Cerveza de estilo pilsner industrial de sabor casi neutro olor difuso a cereal y amargor medio
Sweet lager smell, clear color. Sweet taste that goes easlily without being water. Exactly what you look for when having a lager. Cool
Yet anonther summerbeer. Nice honeycoloured beer with a white foam. Some notes of citrus and flower. The taste dissapears nearly at onces.
Es una cerveza ligera y de carbonataciÃ³n media. Aroma a cereales. En boca es ligera y dulce pero poco agradable al paladar con un final corto y olvidable.
330ml bottle. Drank from bottle. Stone fruit, syrup, bit of acidity. Pretty clean. Not too bad.
Aroma: Sweet malt and grain. Flavour: Very fruity and malty sweet. Colour: Amber with a white head. From: Bottle @ Grocery Fanabe Tenerife Jul. 2018.

Can 0.33l at Seville, Spain. 30.05.2017. Pour it golden color with small white head. Aroma cardboard, honey, corn. Taste funky, soapy, egg, rotten eggs, skunky, light body, thin feel, soft carbonation, meh.
330ml bottle. Pours dark gold with a small white head. Aroma is wort, cardboard, corn, cooked vegetables. Taste is light sweet, cereal. Pointless.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy gold with medium frothy off white head that lasts. The aroma is tropical fruit and dank. Thin mouth, juicy hop, grapefruit, nice light bitterness, very good.

Appearance: very slight haze, average golden color, pours with a large off white head Aroma: pale malt grain, some pine, Taste: grass, dank, pine, strong bitterness, very pale backbone Palate: average carbonation, light mouthfeel, bitter aftertaste Overall: delicious ipa, very floral and lots of hop flavors over the bitterness, minimal sweetness, very drinkable ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap @ hood river brewery. Best of their beers Iâ€™ve had. Piney hops are solid, tolerable bitter finish. Good IPA example. Solid transparent blonde color. 8.8 bd

Draught at the brewpub; 6.2% ABV Hazy golden color with compact head. Delicate pale malts perfectly support this ale loaded with citrusy hops, a real hop explosion. Easy to drink. Very good. More expressive than the Strictly Rude #15.
Draught. For the west coast this is a flimsy IPA. I was hoping for more bite and grassyness.
Bitter to the point of being one-dimensional. Citrus and floral, citrus and floral, etc.

A dry and very Columbus oriented green-tea/marijuana nose. Crisp with a tight and light carbonation. A light kiwi flavour and acidity with a slow bitterness. The carbonation reminds me Kronenburg 1664 and I donâ€™t mean that as an insult, it just does. I think itâ€™s nice, the bitterness builds a little too intensely and that weedy flavour could become too much if I bought more than a glass.
Tap at the brewpub. Light amber pour with a thin white head. Big citrus hop aroma. Nice smooth malt body, caramel and a big citrus hop bitterness. Good brew.
Big Horse Brewing â€“ January 2010 Nice hops aroma with a good malt backing this was a very good IPA.

Date: September 24, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy copper, fine off white head, drippy lace Aroma: sweet resinous orange and tangerine aroma Flavor: sweet and fruity flavor, sweet crystal malt, lots of orange, light balancing bitter citrus rind, light bitter finish Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.6/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *** /4

column1: Big Horse Horse Tail Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery. Nice pale with a doughy malt character and grassy and lightly citrusy hop finish. Pours golden with a medium white head. Good sessionable pale.

column1: Big Horse Horse Tail Pale Ale
column5: On Tap at the Brewpub pours out a clear gold topped with a nice off white head. Some malt and grain with a little hops.

column1: Big Horse Horse Tail Pale Ale
column5: On Tap at the brewpub. Slightly hazy golden orange with a dense creamy off white head. Odd sweet DME aroma with some citrusy aroma. Mild light malt flavor.. Mildy hoppped. Drinkable and plain.

column1: Big Horse Horse Tail Pale Ale
column5: Light bronze colour. Slightly fruity nose. Moderate bitterness. Light pale malts and a hint of tropical fruit esters.

column1: Big Horse Horse Tail Pale Ale
column5: A very boring pale ale, like most of the beers I tried at this brewery. Well balanced, but that is about it, very little malt background, light, bodied, with some crispy hoppiness.

column1: Big Horse Horse Tail Pale Ale
column5: (Draft: Big Horse Brew Pub in Hood River, OR) On my brewery tour of Oregon, itâ€™s been awhile since Iâ€™ve had a quality American Pale Ale, but this is a very fine one. Mild, lightly sweet, and slightly grain malt base allows the tasty, lightly citrusy, moderately bitter hops to shine without stomping the taste buds. The subdued, but balanced nose is lightly malty and pleasantly hoppy. Golden color is fairly cloudy in appearance. Light-to-medium bodied, clean, with a crisp finish. The off-white head rises to half an inch, and as it slowly settles to a film, it leaves a few streaks of lace on the glass. A well-crafted, perfectly balanced APA that doesnâ€™t try to be an IPA, but would make a great session beer for me. Solid.

column1: Big Horse Horse Tail Pale Ale
column5: Tap. LIghtly opaque, medium amber in color. Fair sized white head fades to a film and leaves excellent lacing. Nice earthy and citric hop aroma. Goes a bit skunky towards the end of the glass, a bit lightstruck from sitting in the sun. Light to medium bodied. Well balanced with lingering bitterness. Pleasant.

column1: Big Horse Horse Tail Pale Ale
column5: Faint misty amber, very light head & lacing. Aroma is dusty & sulfuric like fireworks & hops. Light caramel, sweaty flavor. Balanced tail, not that great. Next!

column1: Big Horse Horse Tail Pale Ale
column5: Flaxen, little head and sparse lacing. Woody and earthy aromas. Some malts. Flavors are of light, earthy hops and some bitter notes. Bland, boring pale.

column1: Big Horse Horse Tail Pale Ale
column5: Yellow-orange with no head whatsoever. Pungently moldy, like an old apple. Not good.
Bottle. Dark brown color with beige head. Aroma is chocolate, raisins, vanilla, quite intense. Taste is chocolate, not too vintage, cocoa. Silky mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Nice enough!
RBESG 2019, Plzen. Dark brown color. Oxidation, dark malt, alcohol in aroma and taste.

Bottle from De Bierwinkel. Cloudy orange brown with tan foamy head. Moderate malty aroma. Med carb. Burnt start mellowing into caramel, coffee and a little apple fruitiness. A little out of season though still wearing a jacket today. Solid
2015 vintage on tap in 2018 at Arendsnest. Creamy beige head. Chunky, thick, brown body. A rather massive creature. Heavy, beastly beer, not unlike an Old Ale. A pinch oxidize with the age.
Bottle at home, darker almost black beer, small head. Aroma is dark fruit, malt, alcohol, chocolate. Taste is the same, sweet, bitter, long chocolatebitter aftertaste. not bad.

Bottle on sale from Nettorama supermarket Gorinchem, The Netherlands. The beer is dark brown colored and has a unstable cream foam, with good carbonation. The aroma is malty with notes of caramel, roasted malts, dried fruits, chocolate, coffee and spices. The taste is full bodied and sweet with caramel and roasted malts, and goes to bitter with coffee, cacao and spices. The finish is light dry and pretty bitter with a hint of alcohol. Very nice!
Bier met een donkere kleur en bruine schuimkraag. Smaken van chocolade, koriander, speculaas. Daarnaast is de smaak van zwarte peper en rook heel licht aanwezig. -backlog de BierApp-

Bottle shared at formerly 100%NL THT. Hazy reddish brown with lots of floaters and beige head. Lots of caramel and toffee, sugary, light wood, light grassy, bready, dried apricot and soft alcohol. Quite sweet and medium bitter. Over medium bodied.

Solid powerful and tasty stuff. Dangerously easy drinkable beer at 9%. Balanced in any way. Nice opaque dark color and a fine tan head. Ok lacing down the sides of the glass. Pleasant intensity in the aroma. Full body and a mellow fine carbonation level. Pleasant to drink. Oily texture and a balanced sweetness. Definitely better with some temperature. Dried fruits, toffee, brown sugar, bready and oak in the flavor. Ok complexity. Absolutely a beer to recommend if you like this stuff. [Bottle from a trade with Grima] Rating #9000 Brewery #1900

Uiterlijk: Donkerbruin met een creme kleurige schuimkraag. Geur: Moutig, curacaoschil, koriander, speculaasjes en cacao. Smaak: Vol en romig, chocolademout, sinaasappel, aangename bitter, koriander. Mond, weinig koolzuur, volle smaak die erg aantrekkelijk is. Dit is een rating van een aantal jaren geleden, Ik heb het bier afgelopen winter ook nog een keer gedronken toen het in 37,5 cl. fles zat en deze vond ik een nasmaak hebben van gebrande suiker en plastic, maar over het algemeen goed te doen. Prima bewaarbier trouwens.

Bottle from Mitra in Gorinchem, The Netherlands. The beer is very dark brown to black colored and has a nice creamy head. Carbonation is very good. The aroma is malty with caramel malts, dried fruits, roasted malts, tropical notes and light chocolate and coffee. The taste is full bodied and sweet with caramel and raisins and goes to pretty bitter with coffee and chocolate. The finish is dry and pretty bitter with chocolate notes.
Zwart bier met een dikke crÃ¨mekleurige schuimkraag. Ruikt naar mokka en koffie. Smaakt wat bitter, donkere chocolade, koffie en een beetje kruidig met de nasmaak van gebrande mout.
Smaak van veel donkere mouten van onder andere chocolade, koffie, karamel en iets rokerigs. -backlog de BierApp-

Een vrijwel zwarte substantie dat op het eerste gezicht wel wat meer boby mocht hebben. Geur en smaak doen allebei ongeveer hetzelfde aan: koffie, mokka, chocolade, in de smaak zit ook nog iets van rozijnen en karamel, maar ik had er op Ã©Ã©n of andere manier toch meer van verwacht. Motorolie.
Fles 33cl thuis. Zoetig, rood fruit. Licht bitter, koffie. (11-2014).------.

15-04-2018; bottle; at home (bought somewhere in The Netherlands). The looks of the beer are good. They are the looks of a great Russian Imperial Stout. It is only a tin lighter than most RIS. The beer is a very dark ruby red/brown, approaching black, but it is clearly that it isn't black whereas most RIS look black. In the light there is a nice ruby red glow. On top of the beer a nice layer of greyish brown, soft, fast collapsing foam is formed. After while hardly a drape is left. The smell isn't like I expected...it isn't a bad smell, but it isn't a RIS smell. I smell sweet malts, with only in a far, far away distance some coffee and chocolate. Way to less for a RIS. Hops give a slight herbal note. Yeast gives a creamy sensation, with some spicy notes and a little fruity banana note...reminding me a lot of Belgian Ale yeast. I expected more. The same can be said about the taste. It is rather weak and more of a Belgian Strong Ale taste than that of a RIS. There are sweet malts, with bitter herbal hops and creamy, spicy and fruity sweet yeast. The yeast profile is typical for a Belgian Strong Ale. I hardly taste the chocolate of the roasted malts. Alcohol is clearly present though. Flavour is balanced, but a bit weak and not style specific at all. The palate is fine. Medium body, smooth and high carbonation. The finish of the beer is filled with alcohol and some malty notes with a herbal hop edge. It is a bit dry and not very long. I expected a lot more from this beer. This is hardly a Russian Imperial Stout...it is a mediocre Belgian Strong Ale at best. Disappointing.

Bottle received in trade with tricksta_p, cheers! Pours dark brown with an average sized lasting off-white head. Aroma of malt, roasting, liquorice, chocolate, vanilla and caramel. Milky chocolate medium sweetness, moderate roasted bitterness. Medium to light body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation.

33cl bottle at home. Appearance: black with medium, beige head. Aroma: blue grapes / grape juice, fruits, bread, metal, fruits, some tartness and dark malts. Taste: pretty high sweetness and medium bitterness. Notes of grapes, plums, light coffee. Palate: medium to full bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. Easily drinkable. I miss the roasted character and heavy bitterness.

Bottle. Dark brown, almost black. Very malty (roast/burnt malts, toffee, burnt sugar, chocolate, hint of coffee). Fruity (dark fruits, berries). Spicy and yeasty. Sweet throughout. Alcohol quite noticeable. Drying roast malty finish. More Belgian than Imperial? (2008)
Deze Russian imperial stout is wat eentonig. Mooie donkere kleur met beige schuimlaag. Smaak: lichte koffie en chocolade. Geen echte zoete laag. Er zit weinig diepte in de smaak, noch in het aroma.

Bottle. From Bottles, London. No date. Foams up hugely in a manner to suggest this is bottle conditioned. Marmite aroma. Cloudy amber colour. Marmite, cardboard and metal flavours with sweet dark malts and a hint of roasty bits. This tastes like an old bottle, though it certainly has plenty of life in it. Enjoyable and interesting. I don't know what style it is, but it certainly aint a Kolsch!

Big frothy head, dark copper color. Citric aroma with a hint of caramel. Full bodied. Hopbitter citric flavor. Slight tartness. Hints of caramel and butter. Hopbitter aftertaste. Excellent beer, although I doubt it's a KÃ¶lsch.

on tap @ Red Rooster / Jacksonville FL --- Clear medium amber with a beige rim head and light streaks of lace. Taste is woody malt that shows tiny hints of chocolate and earth, followed by carbonation on the swallow. The finish turns only a little hoppy. A very light brew with little complexity.
at the brewpub .. . pours a dark tan .. . light low foam .. . light molasses drops .. . almost no body .. . never an altbier .. . . dogs that love cats..
5/29/12. On tap at the brewpub. Clear light amber pour with a small khaki head. Light aroma with some chocolate. Bolder flavor with chocolate, roasted malts, sweet tea, and a touch of metal. Eh.

Draft @ brewpub. Pours amber with a trace of off-white head; short retention and no lacing. Aroma is caramel and bread malts. Flavor is malt forward, but was quickly overtaken by vinegar and soap flavors (Had this problem with 3 of the 5 samples). Medium body with low carbonation and warmth.

Tap at River City Brewing in downtown Jacksonville. Not sure what is up with this place, but it doesnâ€™t look like their brewhouse has been used in years (mold and cobwebs in the mashtun and brew kettle room). No fermentation vessels to be found anywhere unless they are upstairs and this place has some sort of insanely reinforced roof. Anyway, every beer here I tried was the same. No head formation. No lace. Force carbonated. And all were severely lactic infected so that everything tasted like tart soda. Not gross by any means, but certainly not to style and certainly not to the "German Reinheitsgebot" as is mentioned in the brewpub/restaurant. Red Rooster pours a clear reddish amber. Darker SRM than the pale ale (a good sign). No head/no lace. Soda carbonation. Caramel and maple nose but wildly weak. Taste up front is like straight caramel syrup and caramel candies. Sweet and thick feeling. Soon, though, the lactic tartness takes over to turn this into some sort of lemon tea cream soda. Interesting. Could be served to children as "cream soda lemonade" and no one would ever even consider the possibility that it was an alcoholic beverage and much less beer. Altbier? Holy Moses.
Amber pour with off white head and lace. Wheaty maltiness on the nose. Caramel malty flavor with a light bitter finish. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Decent beer.

On tap at the River City brewpub. Pours deep copper with off white head. The mild aroma has faint crystal malt notes at a just noticeable level and nothing else. The taste is as mild as the aroma with a touch of roast, crystal maltiness and a sense of faint vague hop bitterness. I get moments of dryness from the wafer thin layer of roastiness in this brew.

Tap @ brewpub. Just like the rest of their offerings. Nasty, tasteless, boring. pours copper, white head. Aroma light malt, some faint roast and yeast. Flavor light roasted malts, caramel, with some weak hoppy notes. I feel bad for their brewer.
Amber color. Aroma of lightly toasted malts. Flavor is chestnuts and cara malts. Light bodied. Nice balance. 25 July 09
Reddish-copper. Malty aroma. Sweet and syrupy with some bread character redeeming it from hell but overall is like something made at a Hops.
Had this from draft as part of a flight at Newport Beach Brewing Co. funky banana and tropical creamy taste. Weird but not bad
(En fÃ»t Ã  la brasserie): Biscuit sablÃ© mouillÃ©, ramolli dans un jus dâ€™agrumes. Plus sucrÃ© quâ€™houblonnÃ©, plus vers le miel que le caramel, finale molle sans attrait mÃ©morable.

Draft at the brewpub The APA poured a clear light gold color with a small off white head and lacing. The aroma was more citrus than malt. The overall taste was good but could have more hop flavor. The ale had a light body and average carbonation. In the back, hop bitterness takes hold, inducing a lasting dry swallow. This a special place with above average beer.
Draft. Pours golden orange with a white head. Pale malts, light sweetness, moderate fruity hops, and mild bitterness. Not bad.

Beer number two on my flight at the brewpub on 11th March 2014. Comes a clear and good looking amber, white head. The aroma was leaning towards a citrus base with some toasted maltiness, as was the taste. Easy to drink and my second favourite of the eight beers I sampled while sitting in the sun outside the place with my wife and daughter.

6 oct 2013, tap. Orange and a bit hazy. Nose is orange juice and grapefruit rind. Med body and moderately fizzy. Grapefruit rind bitterness and finish. Some caramel malt. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at the brewery, decent pale ale, hoppy, citrus, piney, overall pretty decent pale.

On tap at the brewpub. It pours golden with a small head. The aroma has some berry fruit, caramel and light diacetyl. The flavor also has some off notes of cooked vegetables. Other than that, theres some caramel and a decent earthy bitter finish. Not great.

Slightly orange coloured blonde body with a little white head. Aroma of fresh hops, light malt and a good citrus and grapefruit scent. Medium-bodied; Potent fresh hops show well, with a good malt backbone and some other light herbal tastes. Aftertaste shows a bit of grass, some light yeast and a good dose of citrus and grapefruit hops, all with a good malt backbone. Overall, a nice pale that shows well and leaves the mouth slightly puckered from the bitterness. I sampled this pint on draught at the brewpub with haddon90 in Newport Beach, California on 27-August-2011.

On tap @ Newport Beach Brewing Co. Clear amber brew with a decent amount of white head. Lots of floral hop aroma with some bready malt. Taste is very balanced with not too much bitterness or sweetness. Flavors of caramel and pine hops.
Sweet banana malt aroma is well accented on the palate. Clean clove and bubble gum aromas, very light roast. Slight sourness in the finish works well. Best of the beers on the night.
yellow with fair and good head. high corn syrup/industrial nose. very sweet. very bad, haven't had a good french beer yet.

Into a tulip, chilled. Bright, medium gold and ceding of a loose, sudsy fluff of white. Eggy fart nose. Sulphury DMS, sweet creamed corn and dowdy boiled cabbage - not good. But this wanes a good five minutes after. There is light herbal and metallic notes and a relinquishing spicy, peppery note that saves it. Drabby, moderately dry and sulphury palate. DMS is high. Medial, swift lick of sweet candi upfront. Mildly chemical; just has that pizazz. Cereal-like malt lingers. Carbonation is light, spritzy. Flat finish; no crispness. But then the sweetness builds as it warms. Slight of herbal, grassy notes. A bit of a wash. Not hard to drink, but not quite a long quaffer!! (50cL can, Aldi Cannington)
Botella 0,33l Dorada,espuma blanca,moderada,poco resistente.Aroma malta,maiz,cereales,caramelo,galletas.Sabor dulce,malta,maiz,caramelo,galletas,frutal
El ver que viene en botella verde me echo para atrÃ¡s pero al abrirla sorprendentemente olÃ­a a muchÃ­simo a cereal y su sabor tambiÃ©n era muy marcado a cereal

I drank this beer the last week in Geneva with Alex, in one Portuguese restaurant in Geneva. In my own opinion, it is not a piece of Art or not like Proust looking for the lost time but looking for the eternal quality that this beer doesnâ€™t have. It is a basical lager, nothing more, any pleasure to drink it, even from the tap. The body is yellow and gold, unpleasant metalic side, watery, not really malty and the hop is coming from the lost paradise and the malt from Tchernobyl, barely drinkable.
Bottle. Very pale golden color, white foam. Sad aroma: corn, swamp, ooze, sweetness, a bit malt. Taste: malt, candy, light sweetness. Bored.
light sweet biscuits aroma,golden, clear, off white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light metallich dry finish

Can 0,50L. Clear golden color with medium big, frothy white head. Mostly malty aroma of cookies, grain, toasted malts, there is a note of grassy hops, too. Unpleasant light bitter metallic taste with some lemon acidity and moderate bitter finish. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation and metallic finish.
Yellow coloured and clear. Has a white head, diminishing. Light malty aroma, light bread, faint caramel. Artificial.
A golden yeallow beer with a small bubbly head. Aroma is sweet and malty. Taste is slightly malty with some fruitness. Watery

Part of a seasonal voyage platter at the Heartland Brewery and Chophouse, 43rd St, NYC. Pours clear bright chestnut brown with a small lasting off-white head. Aroma is roasted, syrupy, and chocolaty. Medium to heavy sweetness, light bitterness. Medium body, oily texture, average carbonation. Aroma was its highlight.
Holziger Antrunk, Karamell, in Vordergrund steht ein dumpfes Aroma, das mir Ã¼berhaupt nicht gefÃ¤llt. Kaum herb, dennoch unsÃ¼ffig in meinem Augen. 8/7/6/8//8

Tap at Heartland, Union Square, 24/11/13. Dark mahogony brown with a good sized light beige head. Nose is cardboard, light toffee, fruity notes, toasted malt. Taste comprises toffee, light cocoa, straw, berry fruit light. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, dry finale - crisp and clean. Ok - a little overly sweet though.
Draft. Pours reddish brown with off white head. Nose and taste of toast, candied black malt, light fruit and touch of smoky chocolate. Lighter medium body.
Aroma of citrus, marshmallow, roasted malt. Thin, watery palate. High carbonation. Medicinal aftertase. Meh.
Draught sample. Pours dark brown with a white head. Smells roasty with some citrussy hints. Tastes of watery chocolate, some earthy hints, some peppery hints on the finish.
On tap in USA. Black color, little head. Malty aroma. Malty mess. Palate is malty and coco. This is the typical Ice Cream flavored brewery stuff. Not good at all.
Draft at the midtown location. Dark brown with a beige head. Lightly sweet aroma with some roasty notes. The flavor is roasty as well, with a light caramel sweetness. Pretty good.
Tap: pours dark red/brown. Arouma of chocolate and prunes. Disappointingly thin mouthfeel. Nice chocolate and caramel malts. Finishes with an alcohol and bitter kick.

Sweet molasses nose, ruby-black colour with tan head. Flavour is a mix of molasses, coffee and some malt sweetness. The palate on this is quite full and the finish is a long mix of the molasses and bitterness. Well made beer
From what I remember, this was a mellow IPA, and not really hoppy. Notes of pine, but more ESB-ish.

Pretty standard west coast IPA. Amber color, thin head, light citrus hoppy aroma. Not much bitterness to match the hoppy flavor. Fairly light bodied, refreshing. Could use a bit more malt and a bit more alcohol.
Draft. Coppery beer with a thin white head. Not as hoppy of an aroma as many IPAâ€™s. Summer fruit flavors with some malt backing. Good balance and a nice creamy mouthfeel.

Poured a coppery gold with a creamy white head. Hoppy aroma with overtones of malty sweetness. Light bitter beginning with a malty explosion that hits you like a ton of... well... malt. Finishes quickly with a strong bitter that fades into the faintest sensation at the back of your tongue. A fine IPA.

Medium gold color. Medium head. Aroma is grassy and floral. A medium bodied IPA. Malts are fruity and slightly sweet. Hops are fairly bitter, grapefruity and floral. Leans a little toward the malt sweetness. Smooth taste. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Arrived in Sunnyvale on the 17th, and headed straight to Stoddards based on a recommendation from the kind peeps in the Ratebeer forum. This was my second selection after I cleansed my palate. I enjoyed a superb veggie quesadia (sp?) with this. This brew pours from the tap a clear medium copper. The average tight off white head is fully lasting with decent lacing. The nose is pine and flowers. The taste is very well balanced for the style. Toasty start followed by a sweetish middle and a long toasted bitter finish. Not super complex but the refreshing balance makes up for it. Could use some more spice and acidity. The palate is medium to full, soft and creamy and finishes clean. I'm not sure what "American Style" means, but if it is in reference to the "Bigger is Better" philosophy, than it would be a misnomer in this case. Though a solid offering, this is a small IPA.
Tap. Dark golden color with a nice white head. Lots of hops makes it quite bitter. I found this beer sort of odd in how quickly it dies. A little too watery.
Golden yellow coloured beer, sweet and delicious. Not that reminiscent of the Belgian beers I prefer, but a nice pint in its own right none the less.
Clear golden with a fizzy white head. Bubble gum sugar and bread aroma. Banana pear bubble gum and sugar taste. Decent.
Tap. Slightly hazy golden color. Strong coriander aroma and flavor. Great spice. Sharp. Light body.

Clear golden coloured body with a thinnish pure white head. Aroma of biscuits, grain, alcohol, pungent toffee and alcohol and a dose of nuts and very little else. Light grainy bite with some toffee, earth, nuts and light apples and a dose of pine noticeable on the end with some softer flavours towards the finish. Aftertaste shows only the grain, light nuts, earth and a dose of caramel, toffee and caster sugar with a touch of biscuits, yeast and some more harsh herbal lager characteristics at the very end. Overall, a pretty standard lager with a big and heavy malt and toffee hit showing bunches of more assertive and slightly astringent and medicinal lager flavours with the yeast, biscuits, grain and nuts all very strong, especially at the end. What starts as an easy drink finishes a lot stronger with only a touch of the sweetness coming through to finish it off. I sampled this I sampled this 50 cL can purchased from the Costco Advent Calendar, purchased from Costco in Arlington (Pentagon City), Virginia on 29-September-2018 for US$59,99/24 pack/days, sampled on the 23rd Day of December, 2018 at my parent's house in Manassas, Virginia.
Clear light yellow with a fizzy white head. Faint malty aroma and a sweet grainy taste.

Bottle 50cl. @ home. Clear medium yellow color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, grain, hay, straw, fruity notes, light to moderate hoppy, grass notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090609]

Bottle: Golden, slowly collapsing average white head; moderate grainy-dusty nose; moderate to robust sweet-bitter flavour, astonishingly medium bodied for a beer of 11Â° Balling; solid dry grainy finish. A robust thirst quencher, good............
bottle, Danke MoritzF! Clear golden yellow, large white head. Malty character with a spicy citrusy touch. Well-balanced and very quaffable.

(bottle, purchased at the bryggeriet, yesterday) Clear, golden colour with a big and bubbling, eggshell-coloured foamy head. Fresh citrus-fruity (grape-fruit, mandarin) and moderately sweet malty aroma with a light hoppy touch. Moderately sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a crispy mouthfeel. Malt-accented and citrus fruity taste; sweet and faint bitter malt-accented and subtle fruity finish. Clean and easy-going brew (05.X.08).
Bottle. Golden clear colour with a little head. Malty and grainy aroma also flavour of maltness with a bitter and dry finish.
Clear yellow colour with a white head. Malty, grainy aroma with a light hay note. Sweet grainy flavor with a light dry finish.
Bottle. Clear yellow coloured with a white head. Aroma of malts, fruits and cardboard. Flavour of malts, fruits and cardboard.

(Bottle 50 cl) Comes as: "Schaffer Schnaittacher Lager". Clear, fully golden with a creamy, white head leaving laces. Soft, sweetish malty aroma. Medium body with sweet malts. Very soft mouthfeel. No bitterness. 291206
On tap at the Struglers, Lincoln. Amber colour with an off white head. Pithy orange caramel aroma. Taste starts sweet with a long bitter finish. Warming body.
On cask at Boathouse, Wylam. Pours amber with white head. Some alcohol sour, hint of caramel, hop finish. Drinks lighter than ABV. Decent.
6.2% cloudy pale amber colour with a poor head, malt aroma, fruity caramel taste, very nice.
500ml bottle conditioned - a deep amber colour, thin white head, a bit fizzy. Nice caramel nose, similar taste, The fizz gives a refreshing edge to an old ale taste. Not the best, but not bad.
18th October 2010 Light haze on this gold - amber beer. No real head. Light dry malt with a whisper of spice. Softish dry finish, trace of banana. Mild hop aftertaste. Okay.

Clear gold with a thin white lacy head. Oily. Smells of malt, roast spice and alcohol. Frothy oily medium body. Strong taste of alcohol. sweet malt and straw and a dry hay finish. Stong hops with huge grass alcohol finish. Its not very good and overly alcoholic.

I think I can best sum this up by suggesting a basic Belgian strong ale. 500 ml bottle served in a trappist glass cellar cool. Clear golden colour, not much head, little hop flavour, but a fairly pleasant malt, alcohol and mild spice flavour. Notworld beating, but well wort the Â£1 I paid.

500ml bottle. Pours an off-golden colour with no head. Barely any carbonation. Aroma is of alcohol and resin. Taste is of apples and some sourness. Light body and watery, probably due to a lack of carbonation. Some bitter in the finish. Hides its alcohol. Could be a good beer.
Bottle. Orange with a small head.Low carbonation and fairly lifeless. Bitter with some hops. To be honest I expected better.
Bottle conditioned, 500ml from B&M, Southport. Cloudy orange gold with no head. Sweet, bready, yeasty with bottling issues, some apple tartness and a rawish malt note. Few hop notes.
Cask conditioned at The Wellington, Birmingham. Dark brown with cream head. Malty, roasty beer, full with a hint of fruitiness, some liquorice and a hint of fruity sweetness. A pretty decent beer.

Cask-conditioned at the Bag Oâ€™Nails, Bristol 9/1/08. Dark reddish-brown with a decent off-white head that left rings down the glass. Aroma of dark chocolate, fruit and some roasted notes. The flavour had plenty of tasty chocolate, with a smooth mouth feel and a long dry finish. Excellent.

Cask handpump at The Wellington, Birmingham. Brown with a short off-white head. Hint of chocolate in the scent. Quite watery, a bit sweet, with a creamy mouthfeel and a dry end. Very unusual milky taste with some roast hop. Quite good, but I thought it was lacking interest.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Swan & Rushes, Leicester. An almost black beer with no head. The aroma is dry and a little smoky. The taste is dry and fishy wih smoke and roast malts. Some fruit also. In spite of all these flavor characteristics, itâ€™s actually quite mild. Pretty good.
Cask Handpump at the Borough Arms, Crewe 08/12/2002 Dark red porter with some alcohol present. Nice bitter finish.
The commercial description is a little over the top! Nevermind, this is a good example of a porter with roast malts and a light sweetness. Be afraid, a bit afraid...

column1: Original Saratoga Springs Length and a Half Lite
column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Pale golden color with a medium head and lasting lace. Slightly sweet malty aroma with hoppy undertones, smells like freshly mashed malt. Sweet malt flavor with a bitter hoppy background. Good depth of flavor, with a bitter, hoppy finish. Light bodied and smooth.

Tap@brewpub. Itâ€™s golden with a creamy, white and lasting head. The aroma has notes of malt, bread and flower. The flavor has a light sweetness and notes of flower, bread, malt and the finish is slightly dry.
The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass also. Starts mild, but very sourish. Becomes woody to the end, still sourish and fermented. Not a good beer!

bottle. Clear golden yellow, medium-sized head. Malty-fruity nose, reminding me of some Bhoemian Pilseners. Medium-bodied, solid malty base with lovely aromtaic hops. Well-matured carbonation, hints of grain. The flavour also reminds me of Bohemian Pilsners. Good stuff.

Bottle: Traces of carbonation visible, slowly collapsing fluffy white head, golden coloured; sweet-malty, only a bit grainy nose with almost Pilsner-like hoppy traces; soft MF, robust sweet-bitter flavour, nearly medium-bodied; distinctive, but mild sweet-bitter finish with a tinge of aromatic hops. Very well crafted, spicy and pleasant Helles.......

(bottle) Clear, pale golden colour with a medium-sized foamy white head with lace. Light-sweet malty aroma with hay, subtle citrus-fruity and herbal hoppy notes. Moderately sweet flavour with a bitter edge, light to medium bodied with a smooth and pleasant carbonation. Good balance between the initial malty, slightly grainy sweetness and herbal hops towards the dry-ish, moderately bitter finish. Aromatic and rounded Helles with little Pilsener-character.
Herbal hops aroma. Amber color, beige head, very nice lace. Very malty, sweet, hint of sourness at the beginning, little smoked character, herbal hopbitterness, soft.
Malty aroma and flavor. Slight hoppiness. Just a hint of metal and a bit of orange. Clean palate.

Tap@brewpub. Itâ€™s unclear golden with a creamy, white head. The aroma has mild notes of banana, yeast and wheat. the sweet flavor is mild all the way through, it has notes of yeast, banana, wheat, and the finish is slightly dry and mildly spicy. Itâ€™s harmonic and charming.
The bottle looks not so good (unprinted top label), the beer in the glass is okay. The beer starts mild, modest fruity like banana, a bit dry finish. Not bad!

bottle, DankeschÃ¶n Frankenland! Cloudy golden yellow, large white head. Fruity nose. Yeasty and wheaty with a nice fruity touch, not too intensive. Banana and peach, rounded off with some spicy hops in the finish.

Bottle 8purchased at the brewery): Cloudy golden with a loose off-white head, that quickly diminishes to a stable foamy layer; the aroma is dominated by citrus-fruity and wheaty-grainy notes; moderate sweetish-sourish flavour, light bodied; in the finish - again - lemons and wheat, the sweet-sourish finale ends with an mild, but tart aftertaste. A very good and refreshing weizen.......

(bottle) Hazy, pale golden colour with a thick and dense foamy white head. Dusty and chalky, moderately sweet wheat-malty and sourish-fruity aroma with banana, citrus and pears. Light-sweet, slightly sour flavour, light to medium bodied with a velvety, pleasantly carbonated mouthfeel. Good wheat-character with a rising fruit-accentuation towards the refreshing finish with restrained phenols. Rounded and pleasant Weizen.

Wheat aroma with a little banana and a hint of vegetables. Cloudy, dark yellow, white head, good lace. Sweet, hint of sourness, wheat, light banana, smooth. If it only was a little fuller and didn't have the vegetable in the aroma it would be a great german hefeweizen.
Citrus and banana in the aroma. Well laced. Yeasty flavor with citrus and grapes.

Millennium Madness Lager--2000 12 oz. Bottle. 8.00% ABV. (4.25 / 5.0) Clear light amber rich golden color. Spiced coriander front with fruit hop aroma. Big Bock smooth malty sweet rich body. Finishes with hint of lingering spice, light alcohol bitter, and earthy hops. Sampled 5/17/2000.

Purchased in Jackson Hole, Wyoming as singles in May 2002 One time brew made for the Millennium Y2K Madness - not sure when it was released -12 oz bottle - States right on the bottle that it can be cellared, so I did. Opening this was exciting, even though its a lager I was hoping for perhaps a Bigfoot quality. Unfortunately it wasn't what I was expecting but good non the less. Color is a deep golden bronze/coppery yellow with just a bit of fizzy head and bubbles. Smells of sweet malt and floral hops and spice, very clean and soft with caramel and sweetbread notes. Taste is good, mostly roasted malt thats sweet and robust with a caramel stickyness and smoothness that leads right into the spicy floral hop thats quickly biting and dry. Nothing overpowering, its balanced well. Surprising for having it sit for so long. I wish I new what the % was cuz it seems strong and makes its presence in the end. Its sneaky.

Bottle #80/240 signed by Brewer Darron Welch. I bought this at the brewery in Pacific City, OR in mid-October 2002. There could not be a better location for a brewpub. Imagine drinking fantastic beers on a beautiful beach. I only wish I could have stayed until sunset. The bottle says to cellar this as you would a fine vintage. An Imperial Pilsner! What a fantastic brew. Deep amber color with a nice head. Dense, sweet, malty, caramel, reminds me of a barley wine. It''s rich and beautiful.

And so we come to the third and last in DB Breweriesâ€™ unholy trinity of â€™Hopperâ€™ fruit beers, now thankfully consigned to the dustbin of history. Iâ€™d love to think the copy-writer had his/her tongue firmly in cheek when writing the delightfully ambiguous marketing pitch on the bottle: "If you canâ€™t quite believe the taste, flavour and sheer schmaltz of this berry hopper, donâ€™t worry - nor can we". But I fear not. This comes in a 330ml bottle wrapped from tip to toe in cherry-coloured plastic, which is perhaps why they didnâ€™t add a colouring along with the flavourings and food acid 330. Consequently, it pours a hazy burnt gold colour that gives no clue to its character. No head, no lace, not a hint of life in the murky depths. Raise it to the nose and you may experience a rush of â€™sense memoriesâ€™ of when you were four or five years old and lived on a diet of Ribena and iced lollies. The aroma screams sugar. I could almost feel my teeth disintegrating under the smell: raspberry cordial, lemonade, strawberry bonbons. This bottle is months past its â€™best byâ€™ date, which might explain the flat, under-carbonated palate. But looking at the other ratings, perhaps not. As in the other Hoppers, the sweet, fruity flavourings mask any trace of malt or hops. The flavouring is an anonymous berry mix - raspberries, strawberries, cherries, etc, with nothing in particular dominant. If you donâ€™t mind cordials, this is drinkable. However, as the bottle says, "This is not beer as we know it". Amen to that. (BTW, anyone who enjoys quality writing should read SilkTorkâ€™s review of this - itâ€™s a classic.) (330ml bottle, Amatos, bb 21/2/05)
This is awful, omg what did they do to the beer? My flatmate got given heaps for free and had so much trouble trying to get through it all.

Not much to be said for this one. The berry taste is "nice"...then again I have virtually no experience of fruit beers. A strength of 5% ABV is usually my minimum requirement so this one passes that particular test. I, if offered one or left with no other decent choice, would have another.

Bottled raspberry ice lolly with alcohol. My name is SilkTork; I'm a kitchen designer living in Kent - and I'm addicted to fruit beers. I'll drink anything that's a combination of fruit and beer. I started with the standard krieks, moved quickly onto the Chapeau range of pear, apricot and apple flavoured beers, and was soon mainlining on Floris Gaardenbeers. It wasn't long before I was waiting for my man. I was jeered, abused, spat on - but I had to get my fix. He was always late. But then he would turn up and thrust a St Louis Peche in my hand and I had to do it right there. No self-control. No shame. No idea of the mess I was getting into. I would sit on the park benches with the meths drinkers. They'd gather round sympathetically. "What you got in the brown bag?" they'd ask. "Floris Chocolat," I'd reply. And they'd all move away from me on the bench. I thought I couldn't sink any lower. But then, in a dark Soho alley, late at night when all respectable people were in bed dreaming of decent, hearty stouts and the manly power of a high alcohol IPA, I scored a bottle of Berry Hopper from a slimy pimp in pink jodpers. The bottle was covered in indecent shades of scarlet. I couldn't help myself! "This is not beer as we know!" screamed the label. "Drink me! Drink me now you bad boy!" it urged. I couldn't help myself. Believe me. Cheap, stale beer enfused with Food Acid Flavouring 330 - how could I resist! There is no lower than this. I have truly consumed the world's worse fruit beer and enjoyed it! Mother of God, is this the end of SilkTork?

close your eyes and it's raspberry cordial. look at the glass and it's a lager. i wish they'd put some red food colouring in it so I wouldn't get so confused. definitely the worst framboise i've ever had.
quite amazing. looks like a standard lager but smells and tastes a vodka cruiser or something, mixed with leftover stale beer. lots of lemonade ice block in there. why not make a proper fruit beer?
Bright golden colour with small spritzy head, disapates quickley. Heavy rasberry aroma sweet flavour but unpleasant smokey aftertatse. New product launched in July 2002 to the female drinkers
Tastes like cordial. Very sweet, lolly like flavour, they must use a very week lager, coz you can't even taste any hops, malt etc. Couldn't get into it at all.
Piwo brunatne, klarowne. Piana beÅ¼owa, wysoka, lekko siÄ™ lepi. Aromat chlebowy, sÅ‚odÃ³w palonych z nutÄ… palonego karmelu. W smaku podobnie, Å¼ytnie pieczywo, palonoÅ›Ä‡ I lekki karmel.

Bottle now at 5.7%, dark brown with a fast-settling fine foam, malty-sweet and lightly toasty-plummy nose, palate is dry-burnt caramel sweetness, a little dark plummy fruit and winter spice. Finishes sweet with a burnt and herbal bitter edge.

deres Julebryg er en nÃ¸ddebrun lager med et frodigt skum. duften prÃ¦ges af karamel, alkohol og humle. dens store fylde opnÃ¥s ved brug af mÃ¸rk karamelmalt, som sÃ¦tter sit aftryk pÃ¥ smagen sammen med krokant og lettere ristede nuancer. Diskret sÃ¸dme balancerer med humlen i eftersmagen. GÃ¥r godt til julens arrangementer samt til mÃ¸rkt kÃ¸d, stuvninger og salte retter.

50cl Bottle @ Boxbeers.com, Copenhagen, Denmark. Hazy brown colour with a medium size white head. Aroma is malt, sweet, straw, nuts. Taste is malt, sweet, nuts, hints of chocolate. Medium body, average carbonation.
Dark brown with huge brown head. Aroma ryebread. Taste ryemalt nice. Some sweetness.
Hazy amber color with beige head. Aroma of caramel, plum. Taste is medium bitter with sweet notes. Caramelly finish. Decent christmasbeer.

hazy reddish-brown colour, one inch of quite stable and dense beige-ish head; aroma of toasted rye bread, some roasted nuts, burnt honey and slight licorice; taste has the same notes with minimal herbal liqueur notes; good one

0,5 flaske (5,7%) fra Rema 1000 NÃ¸rrebro, delt med Kitty i lejligheden: klar mÃ¸rk brunrÃ¸d rav med fint skum som varer helt ned. Karamelliserte juletoner med hint av krydder, svisker, tÃ¸rkede frukter og brente mandler. Fin bitterhed i afslutningen. Mersmag, og julestemningen begynner Ã¥ vise seg.
Bottle, 5.7%. Nearly clear brown, lasting beige froth. Malty, bready aroma. Caramely, malty flavour. Faint licorice notes. Light hoppy bitterness and a little metal in the finish.

Tap @ diner after fad & foredrag w friends/don. Appearance: pours clear nut brown with good off-white soapy head and lacing. aroma/taste: caramel, bread, chocolate, dried fruits and some alcohol and floral notes. palette: medium somewhat roasted malty aroma, average carbonation, medium body, average to notable sweetness, somewhat balanced by a medium bitterness, average duration and a watery texture. Overall: nice medium roasted Christmas lager
Bottle. Pours clear copper with a white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, dusty. Watery feel, light fruity charater, sugary feel.
A copper "Classic" lager with white head. Aroma is light yeasty, malty, caramel. Taste is bitter, light sweet. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Ikke det store sus. Bitter og meget flad i smagen. Let syrlig i det ogsÃ¥. Billig men dÃ¥rlig Ã¸l.
Can @ Home. Pours light golden with a white head. Aroma of light malt, grain, corn. Flavor is sweet, grain, corn, plastic. Thin watery body, lively carbonation. 090615

Copenhagen 26/4 2015. 33 cl bottle from Meny. Label is advertisement for the Spar supermarkets recently taken over by Meny. Pours golden yellow with white head. Slowly subsiding. Aroma is weak malts and not much else. Strong prickly carbonation. Taste is grainy and weak malts. Pretty bland. Classic discount brand.
Aroma: Sweet fruits and corn. Flavour: Sweet corn and a watery mouthfeel. Colour: Dark amber with a white head.

Boks 330ml anskaffet av djoeye og delt med ham og Rune pÃ¥ pauserommet 27 Aug 14. Gylden. OK skum som daler sakte. SÃ¸t maltaroma. Smaken vassen. En aner litt malt i det fjerne. Svakt tÃ¸rr avslutning.

330ml can shared by djoeye. Clear dark golden body, fading pearl white head. Mild smell of pale and brown malts. Mixed taste of grain and apples. Mid-sweet ending. Clean in the mouth. Little to offer, possible to drink though (Bokhuset, TromsÃ¸ 10.09.2014).
Fawn foam, deep golden clear body. Caramel malts and synthetic grass to the nose. Caramel malts, bread, grassy mild hops to the tongue. Semi dry on palate. Not too bad. [33cl can 4.6%abv BB271014]
Can 330ml @ home Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, corn and cardboard. Taste is light sweet. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

Aroma mellow and of bread dough with a light tang---different...Color a cloudy straw hue---wispy but busy head that leaves thin patches of lace---looks like some of my early homebrews... Flavor features a light sweetness up front, joined by a subtle yeastiness and mild hop top...the finish is a foggy blend of all elements, slightly dry...The body is quite full for this style...carbonation held nicely in-check---good mouthfeel...Overall, this is an interesting taste, but the blend of elements aren''t quite simpatico...It has an unrefined quality that borders on greenness...I''ll have to sample again to see if this impression holds...

Draft: Ruby black. Jagged ring of light-tan bubbles. Roasted wood and unsweetened chocolate aromas, with a touch of caramel. Both prickly and slick on the palate. Promisingly flavorful, initially, with a tangy salami expression intertwined with juicy plum esters. Fairly firm, as well, with a roasted-wood dryness and a hint of char. Chewy notes of chocolate are able to withstand the dryness, but the malts are fuzzy and lacking vividness. Ensuing plumlike acidity also hinders the malt girth and it becomes much grainier and wetter as things progress. Finishes wet, soggy and acidic with waning malt flavors echoing the faintest whisper of velvety smoke. Way too fizzy and light in body, which disallows the malts to latch onto the palate. Disappointing.

Dark black in color, nice lasting creamy tan head, roasty smokey aroma. Roasted smokey burnt coffee flavors, nice dry burnt bitternes in the finish. Light-medium body light creamy mouthfeel, this is decent porter, maybe just a bit lighter than I like.
Delicious and dark. Very smokey taste with a chocolate nose................
