28.11.2003, 0,5l Can. Brunt Ã¸l med fin farge. Ã˜let er litt bittert og surt. Synes kanskje at juleÃ¸l skal vÃ¦re litt sÃ¸tere. Ã˜let er godt humlet og minner kanskje litt for mye om pils.
Bottle. Red / golden colour with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, caramel, malt. Flavour is sweet, caramel, malt. Too thin to be a full bodied norwegian christmasbeer.

330 ml bottle. Clear, golden reddish body with a short, small beige head. Aroma has some pleasant caramel malt notes. Flavor is more disappointing, a watery caramel flavor with some malt and not much more. Itâ€™s a rather fresh and light beer with a big lack of flavors. Just to one-dimensional to get exited over. No Christmas feeling whatsoever.

Bottle, 33 cl. Nice brown color, some burned sugar, but generally just another watery version of Norwegian Christmas beer. This only has local distribution in the Stavanger area, and I think they generally aim for the nostalgia market!

Medium creamy offwhite head. Light brown body. Light, fruity caramelly aroma with cinnamon notes. Taste is again light caramel with strong cinnamon notes and a touch of paper. Slightly watery mouthfeel. Some floral hops and bitterness in the aftertaste. Not bad, but could have more taste. (0.33l bottle.)

(Bottle 33 cl) Beautiful, clear amber with a small, creamy, off-white head. Distinct (Norwegian - whatever that means) malt character in the aroma. Rather light body with some fine malts and a lightly caramelish sweetness. Some dry bitter hops in the finish. Thereâ€™s an indefinable, not so pleasant and lightly cloying edge to this beer that I have dificulties explaining. 271205

Bottled. Golden-orange with a nice off-white head. Weak malty and hoppy aroma. After a long day of Christmas-preparations, and no beer, it felt good to drink, but when I really tasted it, well thereâ€™s not much taste in it. I probably rated it too cold, but it felt mostly like a Norwegian Christmas-sodapop with a hoppy finish. Feel some metal too, pity itâ€™s in the taste of the beer, and not music from my stereo. There is some boiled vegetables in the aroma too. That made the aroma change from 4 to 3 in my opinion. Thin body. Afterall this is not a too bad beer, just not interesting, but as far as I remember, it tasted better some years ago, before Ringnes took over, but on the other hand, it might be my preferences that have changed. (051222)
Well, this is totally waste. Bad pilsner with some colour added. It was slightly better some years ago, when it was still bottled, but not by much.

Copper coloured Christmas beer, brewed for the Norwegian grocery store market when the traditional "klasse F" Christmas beers could be sold only through the government owned Vinmonopolet stores. This beer is an example of the fact that the JuleÃ¸l style NEEDS an ABV of 6,2% - 7% to be decent. The beer looks good, but that''s all. Bland metallic flavour, just a hint of caramel. It''s stunning how little taste they have managed to put into this beer. Low score in all Xmas beer ratings in Norwegian newspapers - well deserved. BTW, like (nearly) all Norwegians, I believed that Norwegian JuleÃ¸l was a style in its own right - I actually learned from RateBeer that they could be classified as Vienna. (I don''t know if people living in Vienna would agree.) Fortunately, the best "klasse F" beers are a lot better than this.
On tap 0,4l. Pours a dark red/brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma Of malts and hops. Malty flavour with a hoppy finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Can. Light brown colour with a small white head. Mild caramel nose. Light roasted barley flavour with some fruity notes, a bit waterish.
01.02.2004, 0,5l Can. MÃ¸rkt rÃ¸dbrunt Ã¸l uten nevneverdig skum. Smaker litt "plastalina". Mangler kanskje litt alkohol styrke til Ã¥ matce smaksrikdommen. Typisk smak pÃ¥ fyldige juleÃ¸ltyper.

50 cL can. Pours clear and golden hazzlenut brown with a lacing white head. Light spiced and mild caramel aroma. Flavour is mild spiced, light orange citric and with a caramel malt note. Ends bitter and mildly spiced.

330ml bottle. Golden, dark reddish body with a beige head. Slightly roasted malt and caramel aroma, nice. Flavor is also slightly roasted malt, sweet, malty and some bitterness. A bit thin body, but quite descent bitterness in the finish.
Bottle. Red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is roasted, caramel. .Flavour is roasted , caramel, fruit, hop, apple.
Bottle 0,33l. Dark red brown coloured. A creamy brown coloured head. Lasting. Quite pretty. Sweet malt in the nose. Soft mouthfeel. Sweet caramellish flavour with a touch of bitterness in the finish.

330ml bottle enjoyed at home. Dark reddish body with nice clarity and some brownish foam. Slightly roasted malty to the nose. Taste of dried apricot and dark friuts. A sweet yeasty touch at the end. Moderate carbonated. Better than most of the low-alcohol xmas beers I have tried so far this year (though that does not say much) (24.11.2006).
Bottle. 2006 Christmas seasonal. Dark amber, tiny head. Hardly no aroma... Slight caramel and malt flavors. Thin body. Sourish finish. Average all over.

This beer has a color that mostly reminds me of a red fruitsyrup and water mix for kids, though it has a beige head. The aroma is dusty hoppy combined with notes of berries. The flavor is dry dusty hoppy again with notes of berries - the flavor also reminds me of a kids soft drink - besides the alcohol content.

0,75 flaske med champagnekork delt pÃ¥ (alltid like) hyggelig RBHD-treff hos Odd Gunnar mars-18: blek strÃ¥gul med kort skum. Pussig aroma av kunstige sÃ¸tstoffer og umodne pÃ¦rer. Barnebrus for voksne.

Shared bottle at RB/HD at GunnarÂ´s 08.03.19. Very, very and pale clear yellow. Small, white head. First a quick shock of ammoniac in aroma, but this dissapears almost immediately. Then amoderate aroma of pears. Taste is of neutral perry with some bitterness.

Shared 750 ml clear bottle (caged & corked), from British Corner Shop. ABV is 5.5%. Very pale yellow colour. Bad aroma, desinfectant and only a hint of pears. The flavour is better, notes of pear and sugar. Not something I'll buy again though.
Shared bottle at local tasting. Pours clear straw no head. Aroma of chemical substances, air fresheners. Taste is mild pear with a weak fizzy body,, nice taste, awful aroma

200 ml bottle bought at The magstore on Nathan Road, Yau Ma Tei. Clear pale blonde colour; Near zero head with residual soapy white form which fades in 5 seconds; No lacing with barely notable slight carbonation; Sweet aroma of pear wine, with sulphur, floral and sugar; Very light sweet taste of white wine, with tartness and hint of sugar; Light body, watery palate; Mouth feel is thin white wine in very runny background with virtually no pear taste. Quite tart with only traces of sweetness. No barrel nor tannin. Blah!... Fairly dry after taste. Tart and easy to mouth. Comments: This so-called historical brand is a yawner, with taste pretty much like a watered down white wine and almost no character to speak of, not even a hint of carbo. Bland and useless just like the Bulmer Pear Cider. Glad it's only a baby bottle.

Bottle from ASDA online. Chemical pear aroma with added saccharine. Pale gold. A steady rise of bubbles. White head just clings to the inside rim. Light-medium sweet which then develops sourness. Reminds me of sour jelly sweets. Light-medium bodied. Slick. Soft carbonation. Dry finish. The palate's probably the best thing about it. Mass produced factory Perry.
Bottle (gift) bought at Tesco. Pours very pale gold with no head. Aroma of pear and citrus. Heavy sweetness, light bitterness, touch of sour. Light body, oily texture, fizzy carbonation.
200ml bottle from Reading Food & Wine, Reading. Funny label. Light gold colour with small white head. Synthetic pear juice, synthetic honeydew melon, sulphites, bottom-shelf Prosecco. Blegh.

The poor man's champagne, now taking on a camp chic status. Has typical perry taste consisting of pear and melons, has a slightly sugary, slightly dry and bitter aftertaste reminiscent to a cheap white wine.

20cl bottle. Chilled. Very pale yellow colour, white foam head that dissipates away and aroma of pear with a hint of sulphur. Taste is pear, sugary, sweet, fruity, melon-like and white wine. Thin mouthfeel, light bodied, spritzy carbonation, dry and residual sweet at the finish. OK.
Shared 0,75l bottle @ One Pint Pub, Christmas tasting. Pours clear deep red with a low head. Aroma is sweet fruity and spicy malts. Flavor is sweet malts with berries and spices. Quite tasty.

Bottle, thanks anstei! Served at 45Â°C. Brown color with no head. Aroma is chocolate, anis, cinnamon, Lebkuchen. Taste is sweet, anis, Lebkuchen, cinnamon. Flat. Very interesting, and fun. Quite intense though.

Bottle, heated to 45Â°C, from the brewery shop. Aroma is like a mulled wine: wintery spices, herbs, ginger, cardamom, gingerbread man. Body is warming, a little boozy, strong. Quite nice, actually, but the spice mix is clearly a matter of taste.

donâ€™t let yourself be fooled, this is a fairly weird one. You might actually have to follow the label on preparation steps. Placing this beer in the "Spice/Herb/Vegetable" really doesnâ€™t do it justice as it is a GlÃ¼hbier, meaning that it is supposed to be consumed hot. Compared to other examples of the style such as Liefmans GlÃ¼hkriek or Locher GlÃ¼hbier the BFM La Dragonne does not try to overwhelm you with sugary sweetness. Instead it finishes with a surprising amount of hop bitterness for a warm beverage while the aroma is mostly lead by the added spices (cinnamon, gingerbread, cardamon, maybe juniper), hiding any typical BFM flavors or most beerness for that matter. The only disappointment comes from the lack of mouthfeel on the palate. Its lack of sugar and tannins, which typically provide GlÃ¼hbier and GlÃ¼hwein with their mouthfeel leaves you with a watered down sensation between an interesting nose and a pleasant finish...
Served warm: Tobacco, fig,, walnut aroma. Mahogany, headless. Tobacco, allspice, cardamom, blueberry. Full body, soft, tannic.
Bue en bouteille de 75cl. Froide, tiÃ¨de puis chaude. Nez cannelle, pain d'Ã©pices au palais. Alcool trop prÃ©sent. Trop sucrÃ©e. Pas terrible.

Bue en bouteille en 75cl chez Renobob biÃ¨re achetÃ©e Ã  la brasserie. Bue sous trois tempÃ©rature. A froid, nez cannelle, en bouche cannelle vin chaud, spÃ©culos. TiÃ¨de, cannelle moins prÃ©sente attaque sur lâ€™alcool, continuitÃ© sur le vin chaud. Chaude, vraie attaque sur le vin chaud et encore plus sur lâ€™alcool. Assez forte en goÃ»t pas de houblon Ã©pice. Epice. Trop forte
Bottle. Pours black. No head. Nose/taste of molasses, dirt, nutmeg, cinnamon, spice bag and shoe leather. Medium body.

Not sure of the age on this one. It as unintentionally aged way past when I planned to drink it. Pours deep brown with a mahogany hue and tiny head. The aroma has lots of spices, caramel, brown sugar, toffee and dark fruits. It has a medium smooth body with very little carbonation. The taste has plum, prune, figs, dates, caramel, light cinnamon and sourness. The finish is astringent and fruity. Not my fave at all for being as old as it was it was decent and interesting.
Rated in 2010 (Backlog) - Brown in color with no head. Aroma is very spicy with ginger, licorice root and cinnamon. Taste is of malt and cinnamon.

DAA; Can 0, 5 L. Pours large, hazy cobber, frothy with a long lived and lacing, tan head. Aroma moderate to heavy malt and dark fruit, light nutts, grass and spice. Taste is moderate to heavy sweet and light bitter with a somewhat lasting finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

0,5 boks delt med Hans etter juleforestillingen: brunlig mahogny med beige skum som varer. God aroma av ristet brÃ¸d, mÃ¸rk karamell, nÃ¸tter og litt sjokolade. Fin karbonering gir god munnfylde, og smaken er nÃ¸tteaktig mÃ¸rk og god. Fint balansert bitterhet. En riktig god juleÃ¸l i det %lette segment.

Appearance Clear light amber, with a small off-white head. Aroma Corn, malts, bread, skunk, butterscotch, raisins Taste Sweet, unbalanced, lacking in bitterness Palate Thin, highly carbonated, short aftertaste Overall The recipe must have been changed between 2014 and 2015, as I remembered this beer as being more assertively hopped, and with herbal notes and a more balanced taste

Bottle @ Scooper Tasting in Ulfborg. Pours clear copper brown with airy off-white head. Dusty aroma with notes of malt and fruit. Sweetish, fruity flavour, with sour and hoppy notes. Bitter, dusty finish. Not off but weird.
Bottle, 4.5%. Clear dark amber with small tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel and bread. Flavour is malt, caramel, bread, medium sweet and a little toasted.

Ulfborg weekend celebration of nothing in particular. Dark amber with a small off-white head. Malty aroma with caramel, toffee and a hint of fruit. Dry malty flavour with toffee and a hint of cardboard
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are rich caramel, malt, little nuts and hops.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Clear golden with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and a little rye bread. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 231113
Duft av malt og rosin. fin gyllen mÃ¸rk nÃ¸ttefarge. Lite skum. Smak av rosin og frukter, frisk og godt.
Bottle. Deep brown, small creamy beige head. Heavy malt aroma with roast and prunes. Sweet malty taste with spice notes. Thin body.
An amber lager that has a nice taste to it, still a little watery. An ok christmas brew with a good meal.

Aroma sÃ¸t malt, grÃ¸nne epler, humle. Utseende klar gyldenbrun med lyst beige skum. Smak karamell, eple, humle, malt. Lett til middels fylde, frukt, lite jul i denne. Flaske kjÃ¸pt pÃ¥ Eurospar Langnes, 33cl 4,6% BF041019
Et ganske godt Ã¸l, passer til det meste av mat. OgsÃ¥ behagelig som tÃ¸rstedrikk. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma of caramel, malt and nuts.Brown with a red tint, off-white head. Medium sweet and medium bitter. Medium body with a average to soft carbonation. Overall an OK Amber Lager, but a bit on the boring side.
0,5 litre Can at a Christmas Eve party. Dark brown with big offwhite head. Malty, Caramel aroma and taste.
Can, 500 ml. Caramel, metal, spruce - these smells hit you after it is poured. Brown and orange in colour. Flat carmel taste, fizzy, short. Unsuccessful even as cheap macro christmas brew.
Burk 50 cl. Klar bÃ¤rnstensfÃ¤rgad med ett rikligt smutsvitt skum. Dofter och smaker av karamell, nÃ¶t och malt. LÃ¤tt beska, urvattnad kropp, nÃ¶tig avslutning.

Appearance Pours a reddish amber, with a medium-sized sand coloured head, some lacing. Aroma Malty butterscotch, dried fruit, raisins, bread and biscuits, hints of herbal hops Taste Mildly sweet, with a distinct bitterness that serves as a very nice counterbalance to the sweetness Palate Mildly carbonated, with a slightly watery mouthfeel
0,5l can. Amber of color with a beige head. A flavor of malt, caramel and sweets. A flavor of malt and sweets. No hops at all.
Red with white head. Caramel, red frut and light floral. Sweet, cherries and cardboard. Overall: okay. Good with food.

500ml can pours a pale golden color with a huge white head that settles quite quickly leaving very little lacing behind. Aroma is light grains and hops. Taste is light malt sweetness with mild hop bitterness. Nothing special about this one.

not very "honey." Straw color, huge head of large bubbles, high carbonation of tiny bubbles. Tangy, a little sweet, minimal hops, corn, slight malt. slightly thick texture with a light body. Skunky aftertaste. Not good on itâ€™s own, BUT................................................... STRANGE FACTOR:itâ€™s weird, but if you blend this with the "CHAMPPS WILD RED" 1 part to 2, it ends up quite drinkable. Weird. Either 2 parts honey to make a honey brown, or 2 parts red to make a honey nut. It works, it tastes great, and I recomend trying this blend. Cheers
Straw color with a large white head with small tiny bubbles. High carbonation,light bodied,tangy,whereâ€™s the honey?
Bottle: Looks fizzy and yellow, tastes fizzy and yellow, the bubbles burn my tongue. Eh!
(Bottle) Pours a medium, frothy, white head and a golden body. Head quickly dissipates. Thin taste of honey and malt. Not very good...

Pleasant lite aroma of honey perhaps and a lite yeast. Very bubbly. Moderate foamy head. Weak finish. Watery honey taste. Honey flavoured beverage to wash down pizza and wings but enjoyable on its own.
Pale gold colour with a mostly diminishing white fizzy head. Faint honey aroma. Faint honey and canned apple juice flavour, slight bitter finish. Watery palate.
Its a strange beer, it isn't really good. I got it in a can. It tasted honey a little ... :/
Aroma and taste of some grainy malt and grassy hops. Bitterness is a bit rough.
[Ancient rating, bottled] Clear yellow Czechish style pilsener with evident saaz hops. Slightly hard mouthfeel. Medium bitterness.

Bottle 330ml (tnx Edo, bierkoning! BB 03/2016) Dark ruby color, decent beige head. Aroma is berryish, sweetish and cellary. Light to medium-bodied. Red berries and cellar dominate the flavor. Harsh, tartish, bitter aftertaste. Tastes infected with few faulty off-flavors. Meh. Drain pour.
Medium mokka brown head, pitch dark colour, malty some coffee smell, sour sweet smokey taste a bit to much sourness sticky body
Sweet bock beer, quite yeasty as well, I understand why itâ€™s labelled a belgian ale here.
Had this over a year ago, didnâ€™t write down any notes. Only remember that it was a little sour and that after a half glass I threw it away.
Bottle at 30e PINT bokbierfestival. Dark creamy brown. Nice carbonation. Caramel and toffee flavours. Dry. Ends very smoothly. My favourite of the 25 I tried.
Bottle: Poured a dark black brown with a thin creamy light brown head. The aroma is a sweet malt. Taste is a dark roasted to burnt malt, sweet with a dry caramel finish.
(Bottle 30 cl) Only 6% ABV in my version. Muddy dark brown without much head. Another Bock being more sour than malty sweet. Discreet, bitter finish. Quite light in body and very refreshing. 110105
PINT Bokbierfestival 2004. Great appearance. Pretty dry, but full-flavoured.

PINT bokbierfestival 2004. Hazy redbrown color, medium off-white head. Aroma is lightly sour, bit yeasty. Sweet and bitter taste, bit yeasty. Creamy texture. Earlier Rating: 2/21/2004 Total Score: 1.6 Bottled, BB oct 2003. Cloudy brown color, short head. Aroma is lactic, bit chocolat indeed, yeasty. Taste is very sour, lactic milky, some honey sweetness. Quite disgusting.
Bottle. Muddy dark brown with small head. Yeasty sourness dominates. Low carbonation and pleasent mouthfeel. If only it tasted better...
Standard Pils, with its flavors tending more towards a rather hoppy, bitter variant, but still within the boundaries of a mainstream Pils.

Flasche (â€žSturmâ€™s Pilsener", 50 cl) aus einem GetrÃ¤nkemarkt in Neustadt bei Coburg. Das Etikett nennt einen â€žCoburger Biervertriebâ€œ (tatsÃ¤chlich werden Coburger Biere lÃ¤ngst in Kulmbach gebraut). - Hellgelb, klar. - Antrunk schlank, blaÃŸ fruchtig und zart sÃ¤uerlich; zitroniger Hopfen. Ohne jegliche Finesse, weder beim Hopfen noch beim Malz. Nachtrunk von strenger Bittere. - Nichts besonderes aber immerhin gut hopfenherb. (Alte Bewertung, 27.7.2013.)
Pours a golden color. Grassy and hayish hoppy even from a distance. Dry bitter, grassy and hayish.
0,5 l bottle BB07. May 14 bread, cereal, herbs, golden, clear, minimal head, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, average carbonation,
Clear, pale golden color. Intensive hoppy aroma. Correct bitterness. Good pilsener.

Bottle, courtesy of fonefan. Itâ€™s a clear, golden beer with a small, off-white head. Quite grainy on the nose but with a pleasant grassy and piney hop impact. Dry, medium bodied and pleasantly carbonated, slightly metallic in the bitter and grainy finish. Bitterness, grass, some generic fruits as well as pale malts in the flavor. A decent pilsener indeed. 110128

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium yellow color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, toasted, light hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, malty, light sweet malt. Body is medium to light, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20110128]
Bottle 500ml @ fonefan Pours clear pale yellow with a white head. Aroma has notes of hay, malt and grain. Taste is light sweet. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.
Bottle @ Ulfborg Weekend, Jan 2011. Pours clear pale yellow with a small white head. Grain, hay and grass, Dry and bitter flavor. Medium bodied. Dry and bitter end.

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours a clear yellow with a white head. The nose mainly has some perfumy hops. Medium body, very clean yet dry mats with dusty and dry hops leaving quite a bitter finish. 280111

Draught at the brewpub in Everett Golden color, hazy, with small head. Easy beer, but a bit more balanced than the Premium Lager, with mild malt flavor, the aroma is too weak, the bitterness is correct with a light grassy touch. Pleasant.
Dark golden colour With an off-white head. Aroma is fruit, malt, hop, grass. Flavour is fruit, malt, hop, grass. Medium body. Ordinary beer.

[ As Fish Brewing Friesian Pilsener ]. Clear medium yellow orange color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, light toffee. Flavour is moderate sweet with a long duration, pale malt, hoppy bitter, hay. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20140118]

Draught in a flight at the brewpub. Pours a clear amber color. Nose has some corn elements to it, and actually appears to be slightly sour. Taste was slightly bitter, and smacked of the average lager. Not a big fan of the style.
Bottle. Pours hazy golden with a small white head. Perfume, bready malts and grass. A bit of dust. Medium bodied.

Bottle. A clear, dark golden beer with a small, off-white head. Rather malty aroma with some grass and piney notes. Peppery hints too. Itâ€™s full to medium bodied, quite dry and with a tad too hard carbonation. The flavor has some pale malts, a nice bitterness and some fruityness and a touch of pine cones. Bitter, fruity finish. A pretty decent one, although I donâ€™t think itâ€™s very Friesian. 140118
Clear golden with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and light hoppy - straw. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 180114
Cloudy orange with a tiny white head. Weak malty aroma with a touch of citrus. Bready malt flavour with some citrus hops and a rather bitter finish
Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, grain and grass. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.
Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, grass, straw and hops.
This is actually the White Bock, with extra spice. Still a very high % beer. A great experience.

33cl flaske 7,6 %. Ganske udmÃ¦rket juleÃ¸l med en dejlig smag. FÃ¸rst med lidt noter af alkohol, men denne forsvinder hurtigt efter et par minutter i glasset. Der er ikke nogen eftersmag og derfor rater jeg den kun til 2.8
Bottle shared by Anders. Clear golden body with a small white head. Malt, alcohol notes. Nothing special.
Strong in alcohol pretty low in taste.clear amber beer with a pilsner flavour and slight bitterness to finish
A fine pilsener, that tastes of more than the mainstream. But too much alcohol and not much Christmas.

Denne julebryg har et klart gyldent udseende med et medium hvidt skum. Ã˜llen har en maltet aroma og smager deraf med en kraftig sprit smag. Alkoholsmagen overskygger Ã¸llen og smager ikke af andet. Medium karbonering.
StÃ¦rk smag af alkohol og ikke nogle krydderier, en god smag af dansk guldÃ¸l. MÃ¥ske lidt for lidt maltsmag

Bottle @ DÃ˜E. Appearance: pours clear yellow with ok white soapy head and lacing. aroma/taste: alcohol, barley and light bread notes. palette: light malty aroma, average carbonation, light to medium body, average sweetness, unbalanced by a light bitterness, average duration and a watery texture. Overall: uninspiring strong lager. .
Flaske. farven er rav med hvid skumkrone. Aromaen er frugt og humle medens smagen er sÃ¸dlig malt og humlebitterhed. En gennemsnitlig juleÃ¸l.
Clear amber color with white head. Aroma of hops and fruits. Taste is sweetish with light bitter finish. Actually very enjoyable beer.
Orangebrun klar med lavt beige skum. Lukter malt og karamell. Smaker sÃ¸tt, litt formue vannete, men en god smak.
Can 0,5l. Pours a colour of dark brown. Arom and taste is of malty, sweet and some bitternes. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Dark ruby colour with an off white head. Caramel and and a bit fruity nose. Caramel and and an ok fruity flavour, light hoppy. From an old notebook. The only grocery store "christmas" beer I used too buy regulary. Retired as usual when I fancy a product from Ringnes.

Bottle. 1996 vintage. Thx to Yngwie. Dark golden golour with a small off-white head. Aroma is oxidation, malt, caramel, alcohol, dried fruit. Flavour is sweet, oxidation, malt, alcohol, dried fruit, caramel. Interesting what cellaring had done to this beer. As i can remember i think the beer had been better with aging.

Bottle, 1996 vintage. I opened up this one by curiosity, wondering how well a low ABV beer could stand the years when stored properly. It really surprised me, especially considering this is from the biggest swill-producer in the country. 13 years in the bottle hadnâ€™t cleared out all the co2, and there was a small, off-white head forming on top of the clear, dark amber body. Smell was delicious, with carmel, a light earthy touch, a pleasant oxidation, dried fruits and maybe a hint of alcohol. The flavor wasnâ€™t at the same level as the aroma, still it was nice. Caramel, cola, raisins and some generic dried fruits got company of some weak alcohol and bitterness. Medium body, feeling a bit watery maybe. Quite oily and low on co2. The finish also had some alcohol, as well as bitterness. Overall still surprisingly good, in a way maybe better than it was fresh, leading my thoughts to a watered down English-style barley wine. 090910
20.12.2003, 0,33l Bottle. The colour is dark brown. aroma and taste is nice. Malty, sweet and some bitternes.
Yeah, Sigmund is right. This is the Ringnes to look for in the "D"class. Good sweetness, some spicy aroma, and no weak points, really. Well balanced. Above average.

Probably the best of the "klasse D" Norwegian Christmas beers (doesn''t take much, really). The stronger "klasse F" beers are the way to go! But this is at least a nice try. Golden brown colour. Toffee sweetness, fruity, mild spices. Low bitterness. Good with food.

Knew I would find my notes on this one, albeit it does look like an early rating. Dark golden color with a thick, small off-white head. Quite like the few bitters I know. Some minerals, and floral hops. Iâ€™m not sold on the Maris Otter. Some floor flavors. Still a change of pace.

slightly hazy, dark straw body. small white head. Tart, dry and hoppy. fruity, namely apples. relatively alcoholic, slick. fresh hop finish, a little grassy and fresh hop character. appley and resinous. Too well dry hopped for me. greamy and smooth. feels nice

New Glarus is legit. Good job dan, the use of imported hops really makes this a class act bitter brew. I've never been to england to enjoy a brew, but if its anything like this one then I want one. I didn't even get this one off of the cask or off the tap.
TAP at Titletown: Pour is clear pale yellow/gold. Floral hops and malt on the nose. Taste is light with a bit of fruit like pear/apple.
A nice example of a geman pilsner. Maybe closer to its cousin a czech pils. It has a medium body with some hoppy characters and clean malty taste.

If this is what the pilsners used to taste like, I think i would have enjoyed many of them back in the day. Pours a bright, vibrant yellow colour with a large white top. Aroma is of corn, grain and lemon peel. Mouthfeel is full and slightly creamy with an inital corn taste, but it quickly mellows into in a comfortable soothing firm malted texture. Strong abv, something like 8%- and alcohol taste is evident, but balanced. Spalt hops evident in the finish.

Draft at the brewpub. Not much in the way of aroma other than watered-down pale malt. Poured a clear gold color with a thin white head. Light bodied and on the dry side with very mild hop bitterness. Very grassy flavor with a hint of pine cleaner/clove. Eh.

On draught at the brewpub in Green Bay, Wisconsin. Pours a clear pale apple juice golden brew with a creamy off-white head that quickly dissipates to a thick white ring with spotty lacing. Aroma of multi-grain malt, flowery hops with a touch of apple and pear character. Taste is light to medium bodied, well carbonated with flavors of multi-grain malt, apples with a touch of mild bitterness. Finish has a good balance of bitterness and semi-sweet malt that even has some light fruit in the background. Pilseners are difficult to make, Dave did an excellent job preparing this one.

This is a great pilsener! Not normally a big fan of the style, but this is a very tasty offering from Titletown. Golden, crisp with just the right bitterness - no skunky odor or taste as with some of the Euro style pilsners. A fine beer from a brewpub that continues to improve its offerings.

On tap at Titletown. Pours a clear golden color with thin wispy white had that leaves an abundant amount of lacing. Aroma is grassy hops, light malt, and a sourdough bread like nose. Taste is grassy, light hop spice. light toasted malt. This beer finishes sharp and to the point. Very drinkable. Good job Dave.

On draught at the Titletown brewpub in downtown Green Bay, WI. Pours a semi-clear dark copper colored brew with a creamy off-white head that has some nice retention and spotty lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, a hint of toffee and floral hops. Taste is medium bodied, a touch of extra carbonation with flavors of caramel malt, a hint of peat, floral hops and some chocolate. Finish has a light metallic texture with some caramel and chocolate aftertaste. Nice to see Dave bring this one back after two years.

Iâ€™ve been wanting to try this beer for years. It first came out before I was of age I think, so itâ€™s been quite a while since Dave or anybody in the brewery brewed this one up. Bright amber, decent off white head. Aroma is slightly peaty but noticeably caramel-y. Light fruits mid palate, decent hoppage all throughout and semi sweet, soft desert like flavours near the finish. Another nice beer.

Thanks to murrayswine for the samples! Poured a clear, deep cola brown with little head going on. Aroma was of rich, smoky molasses and peat with ample doses of dark chocolate.. very nice! Damn tasty, too! Smoky oak and molasses at the forefront along with dark chocolate and some coffee bitterness.. could drink a lot of this! Lower carbonation allowed the flavors to deliberately make their way to the proper tastebuds.. long, smoky-sweet finish. Excellent brew!

On tap at the Tittletown Brew Pub. On the beer board as the "Helter Skelter Scottish Ale" (I didnâ€™t want to put in another entry). Poured a medium brown color with a small sized off white head. Aromas and tastes of light peat, earthy, caramel and toffee.
Quite impressive. I hope it doesn''t disappear too soon!....................
*Old rating. Best before 10.04.03. Fresh but a bit grainy sweetish beer. Not too distinctive, malty-grainy, moderate bitter in the aftertaste.

Older bottle. Looks good. Like it better than the actual HasserÃ¶der design. Beer in the glass surprisingly zippy, small head. Starts strong and spicy, more and more grasy-sourish, a bit moldy. Finish milder, still a bit sourish, spicy aftertaste. Better than exspected.
a beer that is good for what it is not rather than what it is. not salty or sticky or sweet. nice rich amber. but very unremarkable

On tap poured apale yellow with a small white head, Aromas of bread and noble hops. Palate was crisp and clean. Flavors of bread and noble hops. Im not much for lagers, but this was one of the better ones in my opinion, unfortunatly most of thier ales were terrible.

Light golden with a slight haze and a thin white head. Light malts emitted faint notes of sweet grains and cereal. Light-bodied with a mild carbonation level. Very, very mild hop profile, and only a hint of bitterness. No off-flavors to complain about, but the light sweetness seemed to overpower the beer, and the weak hops just couldnâ€™t keep up -- relatively speaking, of course.
Very very thin. One of the beers closest to water. Actually I would say it is water, if I did not knew better. Horrible

Draught. Body is light yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (cereal), lightly hoppy (herbs). Flavor is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.
On tap poured a clear brown with an amber head. Aromas of toasted malt and toffee. Palate wasslightly watery. Flavors of bread, toasted malt and a hint of nuttiness.

Creamy head; clear and deep brown with bugundy highlights. Lightish body; smooth carbonation. Had a little roast and a little toast. Mild sweetness (nuts, caramel) complemented by a mild bitterness, and just a hint of sourness. Not bad, but uneventful.

Draught. Body is medium brown. Aroma is moderately malty (cookie, caramel, nutty), with a note of toffee. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

On tap @ 5280 [now the Mill] poured a clear copper with a minimal ivory head. Aromas of earthy hops, light carmel and a hint of pine. Palate was medium bodied. Flavors of carmel, earthiness, a hint of citrus and light spice with a lingering lightly bitter finish.

dark yellow brown with a nice head. aroma is caramel and a bit of grass. taste is caramel and a bit of grass too. very subdued ipa(definitely not an american ipa) some metal in the finish. this went well with the fish and chips.
Barrel Draught from the jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 30/09/2005 Golden coloured and hoppy with a slightly hazy appearance. Crisp on the palate with a dry malt finish.

Clear and medium gold with orange shadows; nice lace patterns. Medium carbonation; had a nice creaminess / rich malt base to it -- cookie, caramel. Hop flavors were nice: grapefruit and a little pine. Hop aromas (flowers, pine) were nice as well, though not as pronounced. Quite a bit of bitterness in the finish and aftertaste. Had a little sourness and a slight amount of acidity, which kind of gave it a sharp edge, but it wasnâ€™t too bad. Overall, I enjoyed the beer.

Draught. Body is light amber. Aroma is lightly malty (caramel), lightly hoppy (grapefruit, resin). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Finish is moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

tap. dark near black with a gray head. aroma is weak, some chocolate, thatâ€™s about it/ taste is thin, water & chocolate. a touch of cream in there. finishes straightforward cocoa. one dimensional and non offensive.

On tap poured a translucent brownish black with a small brown head. Aromas of roasted malt, coffee, and cocoa. Palate was smooth and creamy. Flavors of roasted malt, coffee, and a hint of cocoa with a slightly astringent dry finish.

Clear and very dark brown, almost black. Mouthfeel was nice and very drinkable (i.e., not too thick and sticky, and not too watery), but on the light-bodied side of the scale. Chewy-sweet and very roasted, with great notes of chocolate and coffee. Hint of sourness kept things interesting. Healthy amount of hop bitterness came up in the end, balancing things out well. Surprisingly tasty.

Draught. Body is dark brown. Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, dark chocolate), with a note of vanilla. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Clear light amber with a creamy thin white head, very laceful. Aroma of toffee and mineral water with a thinly veiled English noble hop presence. Taste is pretty toffee malty but not terribly sweet. Almost like its balanced itself with mineral water or something. Kinda butterscotch tone on the middle with a creamy malty biscuit tone on the finish.

Cask at Pints Pub. Pours clear amber with a small, fizzy white head, somewhat diminishing with fair lacing. Aroma is average malt (bread, hay, straw, cereal, meal), heavy hop (herbs, grass), average yeast (sweat, earth) with notes of raisin, pear, and cherry. Medium bodied, slick texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish. Average duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and bitterness.

On tap @ Pints Pub poured a clear reddish copper with a lasting amber head. Aromas of vinegar, carmel and a hint of fruittiness. Palate was light to medcium bodied and crisp wioth a smooth finish. Flavors of carmel, vinegar, diacytel and a hint of fruittiness with a smooth lingering finish.
Pint. Clear orange beer. Some butterscotch that seems to be a trend at the pub. A mildly bitter finish. Very light drinking, low carbonation

Husky malty aroma and flavor, with some butterscotch, caramel and cookie dough, that leans more towards a biscuity flavor. LIght fragrant hoppiness, with some tangy fruit flavors coming through in the finish.
On Tap at the Pints Pub Brewery & Freehouse, Denver 30/09/2005 Amber coloured and hoppy with a fruit aroma. Some dryness and bitterness in a full malt finish.
light rouge color with a whitehead. fruity aroma(strawberry) taste is lime and cherry jollyrancher with a butterscotch finish also a blackberry with a weird bitter. not bad, not great.

Tap. Gues what-BUTTER! None of the flavors one would expect in an amber ale. What is up with this freaking butterscotch thing these guys have? Is it an infection? Are they putting drwan butter into their beers?

A clear dark orange beer with a small white head. The aroma is very light - what is there is malty combined with notes of oranges. The flavor is very flowery combined with notes of oranges leading to a dry hoppy end.

Thin head, but nice lace. Vegetable-like, yeasty aroma. Very smooth with low carbonation. Herbal/flowery hop flavors. Decent bitterness in the finish. Maltier than your typical "amber." Didn''t do much for me.
Old rating. Cask pour. Brown color. Nutty, dry, toast, hints of fruit. Really thin for a cask conditioned brown. Meh.

Cask at Pints Pub Brewery & Freehouse in Denver, on April 9, 2014. Clear dark reddish brown color, teal head. Fruity, tart, berry taste, some alcohol. Berry aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitternes. Finishes very dry. Sweet, malty scent.

10 oz from cask at the brewpub. Pours near still and dark brown in color. Aroma is malty and a little nutty. There are hints at berries and cacao and leather. Palate is pretty decent. Itâ€™s a good beer for a cold day. The flavor is warming with hints at earth, leather and dark fruit. Thereâ€™s an occasional tartness that seems a little out of place. Decent.
Draft. Pours brown with off white head. Nose and taste of malt, dry toast, light dry fruit and grain. Lighter body.

Draft at source. Deep brown. Nose is of lightly roasted and toasted malt, fruity and tart. Some nice fruity "live" ester character with a even roast and mild hop finish. Low carbonation and serving temperature really made this one pop.

Hazy brilliant burnt copper, but with no head. Aroma is kinda dank with some chewy dark toffee, a bit of dark vinegar, a touch of apple, and a subtle hoppy bitteness. Body a little too thin and lacking carbonation, though it is a cask ale...roasted toffee malty start, a little burnt malt, with a slightly dry hopped finish, slightly bitter.

If this beer was brewed in Britain and sold in pubs it would become a classic. All the features of a British â€™real aleâ€™ in a single mug, good and bad. Intense caramel nose supports the idea of a brown ale, the dryness in north of England but the English hopping is more assertive than most in its spiitual homeland.

Cask at the brewpub - brown ale? - I would have guessed english strong - fairly strong roast, some woody/barrel character, light bits of treacle, some plum and fig, a touch of tartness - a light bit of diacetyl - I quite enjoyed it.

I bet I drank 20 pints of this beer in three nights. You think Iâ€™m joking but not a chance in hell. This beer has it all, sweet malty caramel nuttiness with hint of citrus and fruit underlining the yeasty after taste. You drink this beer and you drink it often...thereâ€™s no reason not to!

Draught at Pints Pub. Pours brown with an average, rocky off-white head, mostly lasting with fair lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (bread, toasted grain, nutty), light hop (herbs), average yeast (earth, musty) with notes of cask and cola. Light bodied, thin texture, soft carbonation, and a bitter finish. Long duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and bitterness.

Cloudy woody copper with an overall sorta â€™brownâ€™ hue. Creamy medium white head, almost like it was a nitro pour. Nose of dusty earthy toffee and a bit of grassy hop acidity. Flavor is like toasted cracker and dusty toffee malt, with an old-world hoppy nip at the finish. Overall really dusty and malty.

Draft at source. Deep red almost brown. Toasted malt and almost a weird vanilla-like oak aroma? Flavor is a deeply toasted malt with mild caramel and a nice dry, English hop finish. Nice English character.

Tap at Pints Pub. Pours clear copper with a medium, fizzy light tan head, somewhat lasting with fair lacing. Aroma is caramel and lightly toasted malt, fruit and ester yeast, citrus and pine hop. Flavor is malt and hop balance, medium hop bitterness. Medium-light body, medium carbonation.
On Tap at Pints Pub Brewery & Freehouse, Denver 14/10/2008 Some malt aroma. Bronze coloured smooth on the palate and fruity with a crisp bitter and slightly dry malt finish.

On tap @ Pints Pub poured a clear dark copper with a lasting amber head. Aromas of earthiness, carmel and light fruitiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, earthiness and light fruitiness with a smooth dry lingering moderatly bitter finish. A very British pale ale.
Tap. Yellow/orange with a white head. Some butterscotch, the finish has a citrus taste. Not anything amazing
Pretty solid pale ale here. Got some caramel and butterscotch flavors. Pretty hoppy for an English pale ale, but euro hops, definitely not any American hops in here.
The only thing that makes this an English style pale ale, is the fact that it denotes some butterscotch flavors, other than that the malt and hop profile are just like every other APA.
light yellow tan with a thin white head. lemon bitter nose with a flavor like strawberries with a strong bitter finish of citrus. not bad.
Tap. Hmmm. Butterscotch? Check. Nothing about this reminds me of a pale ale. This tastes like all the rest. I am done with their frakn beers. Some apple notes. Wow. BFD.
Draught at the brewery on October 12, 2012 Clear dark brown color, tan head. Butterscotch, sweet taste. Roasted and berry aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness. Sweet and butterscotch scent.
Tap at Pints Pub. Pours a deep black with a decent cream white head. Aroma is vegetable and earthy malt. Flavor is trashy vegetable refuse and malt. Watery mouthfeel. Frigginâ€™ GROSS.

On tap at Pints Pub, dark rubby color, with a beige head, sweet caramel malty, fruity nose of dried raisins, plums, with a light winey accent, some faint dark chocolate, black coffee notes in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a watery, malty, grainiy, fruity winey character, with a soapy, flowery hop leafy accent, with some hints of caramel and chocolate, leading towards a dertegent, malty, hop bittering finish.

On tap@ pints Pub poured a clear deep brown with garnet highlights and a lasting tan head. Aromas of carmel, peat, brown sugar, milk chocolate and coffee. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, peat, cocoa and coffee with a smooth sweet malty finish.

Tap. Dark brown beer with a light brown head. Chocolate and coffee were present in the pint I had. Too sweet of a finish for my taste, will definitely try again to see if the taste varies from batch to batch

Nice light brown pour. Thin light brown head left no lacing on the glass. Simple caramel malt flavors with some notes of fruit, caramel, nutty, roasted grain. Slightly sour. Moderately sweet especially up front. Body is thin, although I must confess I have enjoyed this beer at times. The pint I had today had too much sour fruit, which was off-putting. Will rerate.

On tap at the Pints Brew Pub [1/2 pint glass]. Poured a dark, dark brown with red edges and a small sized off white head. Aromas of caramel and lightly earthy. Tastes of caramel, toffee, and light earth. Lacing left on the glass. Thinner body.

Cookie dough maltiness, with just ahint of acrid smoke pervading in the aroma, but disappears in the flavor. Has a bit of a saddle drawn vinous fruit note, along with some caramel maltiness. Simple texture, with just a bit of roastiness in the finish.
On Tap at the Pints Pub Brewery & Freehouse, Denver 30/09/2005 Dark coloured and slightly rich on the palate. Fruity aroma. Slightly dry roast finish.

Draught at Pints Pub Brewery & Freehouse. Pours dark brown molasses with a small edgy tan head and spotty lacing. Sweet caramel malt and yeast (horse blanket) aroma. Sour yeast leather caramel malt flavor with a bitter hop finish. Medium bodied, thin and dry palate.

Clear rich amber poured on nitro that retains a smooth sticky creamy ivory head. Nutty slightly toasty English malt aroma. Smooth palate with a nice fluffy roundness thatâ€™s a touch light. Classic pub ale flavors of gentle toast and gentle earthy biscuit malt with a very subtle creamy ale-fruity ester. Light-ish and bland, but a classic offering thatâ€™s so completely British and pub-oriented.
Old rating. One of my first room temperature nitro English style beers. Brown Amber with creamy head. Biscuit maltiness with earth and slight toffee sweetness. Creamy body of course.

First rating Draught at the brewery on October 12, 2012 Clear dark copper color, creamy tan head. Sweet, malty, cream, some butterscotch scent. Sweet, smooth, berry, grainy taste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness. 7/5/7/4/15=3.8 Rerate Draught at Pints Pub Brewery & Freehouse in Denver, on April 9, 2014. Hazy dark copper color, dense tan head. Malty, toasty, grainy taste. Grainy, toasty aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, dry, medium bitterness. Sweet, malty scent. 8/4/8/3/16=3.9

Nitro at the pub - served way too effing cold - a decent, sessionable esb - clean and light-bodied, with some bready maltiness through the middle - malts become drier and more crackery as the earthy bitterness sets in for the finish - finish is lingering toasted bread and bitterness - decent.

Very creamy with a nice full body, nice thick malt flavor with the beloved hefe flavor just lurking around the after taste. I wasnâ€™t sure where the Extra Bitter comes into play but this beer is so freaking wonderful I donâ€™t give a shit if itâ€™s not per the nomenclature. Great frigen beer!

Tap at Pints Pub. Pours with an average amber body and a thick, creamy white head. Aroma is apricot malt and English biscuit. Flavor is bitter bread and yeasty fruit. Average mouthfeel. A typical and approachable English bitter. Not bad.
On Tap at Pints Pub Brewery & Freehouse, Denver 14/10/2008 Malt aroma. Thick white head. Mid brown coloured and smooth on the palate with a crisp and bitter lasting malt finish.

On tap at the Pints Pub, tawny brown color, with a creamy beige head, grainy, toasty, caramelized malt nose, with a cookie dough accent, mild toffeeish note, hint of nuttiness, with a faint floral hop aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a light toasty, faint roasted malt character, with a nice flowery hop citrusy, leafiness, and lemon grassiness, leading towards a lemony hop grassy bittering finish.

On tap @ Pints Pub poured a clear dark amber with a creamy lasting ivory head. Aromas of carmel, toasted malt, earthiness and a hint of coffee. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of earthiness, carmel and light toffee with a smooth dry lingering bitter finish.
Pint, on nitro. Great carbonation display that settles in a cream colored head. Good consistency, some malts and caramel present. A pretty good beer.

Draught. Body is hazy medium yellow. Aroma is trace malt (grain). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic. Finish is moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

On tap at Ironworks poured a clear reddish amber with a lasting off white head. Aromas of carmel, earthiness and light citrus. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, earthiness and light citrus with a smooth dry finish. Ironworks has a new owner and new brewer since the last rating so this is probably a completely different beer.

Draught. Body is hazy medium amber. Aroma is trace malt (grain), lightly hoppy (grapefruit). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Finish is moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Draught. Body is hazy medium amber. Aroma is lightly malty (caramel), lightly hoppy (grapefruit). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Draught. Body is hazy dark orange-brown. Aroma is lightly malty (cookie, caramel), lightly hoppy (grapefruit). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Draught. Body is hazy dark brown. Aroma is lightly malty (nutty, caramel). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Draught. Body is medium yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (cookie), moderately hoppy (flowers), with notes of bubble gum, sugar, orange, and coriander. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Sample at the Gaylord location: Pale orange color with a continuous string of rising bubbles. Thin white head and spotty lacing. Medium-bodied with roasted malt and hops flavor. The finish is lightly hoppy and rather short. Alright as far as Oktoberfests go, pretty much on par with what you would find at most brewpubs right off the interstate.

A very hoppy Oktoberfest, much more than I expected from its 22 IBUs (more hoppy bitterness than the brewery''s 33 IBU steam beer). Malty, a bit sticky actually. Bitterness has a slightly metallic edge. Slightly yellow on the the edge of its cream soda brown color. (on tap at the Grapevine, TX location)
Awwww, I'm telling Anchor........ Light bodied, sweet malts are faint, but a nice hop presence makes it enjoyable.
Good white head and decent lacing. Strong hop flavor without being too overwhelming, but highter than I personally like. Nice bubbles.
MIBG Fest: Clear red-amber with lots of bubbles. Crisp carbonated body that worked well with the balanced flavour. A middle-of-the-road refresher.
Golden yellow, very fizzy. Very crisp and dry and it had more hops than you normally see from the style. The finish had a lingering bitterness to it. Not bad.

Incredibly curious and off-putting aroma--like that strange smell you get from the edge of a hunk of processed cheddar cheese after it has sat against the plastic packaging for too long, not exactly moldy, but soured milk and chemicals. Hints of floral, too, but not enough to make up for the smell. The flavor was much better--a pretty normal West Coast hop profile, with mild bitterness. (More mild at its listed 33 IBUs than the brewery''s Bucktoberfest at 22 IBUs.) Pale-ish dull amber. It would have been rather enjoyable if not for the aroma. (on tap at the Grapevine, TX location)

Cask-conditioned beauty! Pitch dark in color with a lasting caramel foam. Aroma is intensely like a coffee brewing in a small room at 7 a.m. It drinks smooth and rich, nicely mellow (so refreshing when a brewpub is able to do a cask, so that at least one beer isn''t carbonated to the hilt.) A solid helping of chocolate makes this taste like a chocolate-covered coffee bean, although this didn''t strike me as a particularly sweet concoction. Easy drinking, with the only criticism being that the flavor may get slightly annoying over time. Very interesting and enjoyable. (on tap at the Grapevine, TX location)

4.6%ABV. Hefeweizen Tapped out light gold. 5Â°SRM. Nose has aromas of bubblegum, and clove. This nose is more centered around sweet and spicy, and less rounded fruit. Mouthfeel is light, carbonated. Palate has flavors of pale wheat toast, biscuits, crackers. Clean grain flavors come through. Hop flavors are grassy. Finish is dry and light. Overall, a true to style, highly approachable, refreshing and â€œlightâ€ ale choice. I really liked this one. Goes on Favorites List!
Tap. Pours clear golden yellow, medium white head, great lacing. Aroma is wheat, clove, banana, bubblegum. Flavors is light sweet, very light bitter. Medium body. A bit muted, perhaps, and dense

On draught. Really bright aroma and flavor, with banana and slight spice. Very creamy mouthfeel. Hazy yellow with full white head. Really tasty and enjoyable. Maybe a little generous on the score, but it was tasty and easy drinking!
A really refreshing hefe. Found at camber in Montclair. Like a cool class of lemonade with a light hefe spice.

355ml bottle at House of Belgium, Xiamen. Pours slightly hazy golden yellow with a thin white head. Aroma of malt with a little banana. Sweet taste and finish. Refreshing on a hot evening but nothing special.
Aroma: wheat malt, banana. Taste: wheat malt, banana, citrus and apples. Citrus like aftertaste.
250ml on tap @ Parallel universe. Thin white head. Cloudy golden pour. Refreshing.

@SFO layover. Hazy, thin head. Light tan colour. Nose is heavy on the banana. Sweet, with a lot of banana. A little bit fizzier than most beers, so that there's sort of a thin, acidic quality to the finish. Ok hefe - fairly authentic just not hitting high.
Aroma is honey, banana , citrus and slight pears. Taste is light sweet grains, clove and citrus. Very refreshing and sessionable.

San Francisco, CA - Woodhouse Fish Company - 12 oz bottle. Hazy, medium orange pour, light off-white head. Pleasant aroma of clove and coriander, Flavor has some banana flavoring, some yeasty accents, a touch of coriander some bubble gum. thick enough mouthfeel, Rating #54 of my 2017 Northern California vacation.
Pours a deep dark amber color. Aromas of roast malts, fruit, and a hint of nuts. Flavor is Roast malt, with hoppy bite in the finish and aftertaste.
Bottle. Reddish brown with long lasting thin head. Slightly artificial aroma, touch of vanilla. Wood, vanilla and nut flavour. Finish is a little chemically. Overall effect is a little uneven.

The beer after extricating itself from the 12 ounce brown bottle sets in the class a clear brown with a modest light tan head, the lace a thin sheet to cover the glass. Nose is malt sweet, fresh and pleasing to the senses, start is sweet, the top thin. Finish has a benign acidity, the hops quite mild an unassuming, dry aftertaste, a bit weak for my liking, but drinkable especially now as the temperature has climbed into the 100â€™s.

syrupy nutty nose with some roast on top. some pine and bark flavors as well. cloudy, copper brown in color. taste flows well from the nose, thin in body, low bitterness. hops are mellowy piney, not very assertive
Really a weird aroma to it. Sweet musky. Very little hop flavor, but nice roast that open up after it comes to temp. Finishes very clean.
12oz bottle 90â€™s Pours a medium golden with a small white head. Aroma of sweetness, malt, and honey. Taste of the same. This light to medium bodied brew is pretty well balanced. Not bad.

On tap at the brewpub bar after the conclusion of the 12th Annual Drunk Monk Competition. Pint served with a hazed, light golden hue, a modest, white foam to the head, and average streaks and spots of lacing. The aroma was honey/candy sweetness, with light malt and fruit notes, maybe a hint of orange zest. The flavor was malt, light hop, and some mealy wheat or dank grain taste. Food complimentary, and sessionable.

Bottle. Pours a golden that darkens and gets deeper towards the center of the glass and is very slightly hazy. Aroma is very mild, a touch of lemon and honey. Flavor is light with a touch of honey and a light floral bitterness. Thin and light bodied.
Tried this one out on tap while up judging the Drunk Monk Challenge but didnâ€™t have time for good notes.

12 ounce bottle purchased by my parents for me from the brewpub in Aurora, IL. Poured a light golden color with a half finger width white bubbly head that disappeared quickly. It had a decent amount of carbonation also. The aroma was very bland for a wheat ale. It consisted of very light malt and some very subtle fruit hints (possibly cherry). The taste was a bit sour for my liking. It had a strange cherry tang to it with a bit very light taste of sour wheat. Overall, a very strange beer. I would not seek this out again...

Light golden color with a small lid of white bubbles. LIght blueberry and hint of malt aromas. Seems too sweet for a honey brew. Some mild glue scents as well. Flavors of marzipan and stale almonds. Some old wheat and oat flavors as well. Iâ€™m going to finish this, but it is going to be a challenge. Some light acidity in the finish and linger. I continue to dislike this style even more after this one.
Golden with thin white head. Honey, citrus, and mild hop aroma. Wheat, citrus, and mild honey flavour notes. Very light.

Straw colored body with a medium white head. Aroma is sweet and a bit skunky. I can smell the honey, but thereâ€™s almost a spoiled scent to it. Medium, oily palate up front leads to to higher carbonation and bite towards the end. The flavor is pretty bland. Honey and malt with a touch of hoppy bitterness. Not impressed.
12oz bottle. Poured a medium and clear golden color wtih a small sized white head. Aromas of grains, some honey, wheat, and light citrus. Tastes of wheat, lighter honey, and citrus.

12 oz. bottle, no freshness date, the breweryâ€™s website currently lists the ABV as 5.4%, sampled in a pint glass. L: Unfiltered hazy, orangey straw golden with a billowy white head that slowly settled into a sudsy skim. The head retention on this wheat ale is quite good. Minimal amount of splotchy lace at the top of the glass. S: Raw barley grains and wheat malts, flowery, namely orange blossoms, touches of lemon and honey, notes of herbal hops as well. Mellow, but pleasantly flavorful smelling nose on this APWA, the aroma of a hot summer afternoon quaffer. F&T: Soft carbonation gives the light body a mildly firm and slightly creamy feel in the mouth, Americaâ€™s Honey Wheat Ale is a smooth and easy drinker. Mellifluously sweet tastes of orange, lemon and honey, backed by pale malts and a gentle wheat twang. A delicate hop spiciness comes out in the finish. Finishes softly clean with just a briefly lingering lemon honey aftertaste. Honey Wheat Ale is a pretty decent American Pale Wheat Ale, fills the bill while watching baseball on this sunny and humid summer day.
hazed copper color, off white head. nose of piney hops. flavor is evergreen and some caramel. medium bodied, light bitter finish. quite an enjoyable brew.

Poured a clear amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of carmel, butterscotch, earthiness, light citrus and light pine. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, butterscotch, earthiness, light orange and a hint of pine with a smooth moderatly bitter finish.

Had on tap in Elgin at the BREWFEST 2006. Wow, this is a very very solid IPA. Nose is strong with lots of hops. The taste is just about the same with a huge kick of sweetness. Pretty clean and full in the mouth. So bitter it is almost gritty. Wow great stuff.
Had this on draught in Aurora, Illinois. One of the best beers I've tried. Beautiful rich reddish color, wonderfully hopped, fresh tasting. Nose of cloves.
Had on tap at the brewpub in a pint glass. I didnâ€™t take good notes beyond the numbers, but it was just fine.

Draught. Pours an orange amber with a whispy off-white head. Aroma is mild. Mild dry and nutty with sweet caramel notes spice notes. Faintly bitter finish. Medium bodied with little carbonation. Okay.

Right off the bat I notice an overwhelming aroma of buttered popcorn. It was not a good thing. mixed with the caramelly malts it got a bit better, but then showed up in a big way while consuming too and that was a big big turn off. Too powerful to overcome. Wasnâ€™t horrible as I went along, but didnâ€™t reach my "good beer" standard either.

Tap: This pours a deep amber body with a sustained, good lacing head. The aroma and flavor are sweet caramel, toast, toffee, and some apples and pears. The light hop presence keeps the sweetness from getting overwhelming. Sessionable. Americaâ€™s Brewpub, Aurora, IL

column1: RJ Le Cheval Blanc Sainte Paix MÃ»res
column5: (660ml Bottle) I was very intrigued by this beer since I did not know that it exists - I had tried the apple and cherry. Pour a cloudy, strawberry body and virtually no head. Aroma of berries but I wouldn't be able to tell without the picture of the blackberries on the label and because it is partially masked by its highly carbonated, soda pop style. Tastes of more of a tart, young red wine with a medium sour finish as opposed to a seasonal beer. No comparison to a lambic but nice for a spring day like today.

column1: RJ Le Cheval Blanc Sainte Paix MÃ»res
column5: Originally brewed in apple and cherry versions, this is a blackberry (mÃ»res) varation on Cheval Blanc's Sainte-Paix. I haven't tried either of the others, but I wasn't too impressed with this one. The first pouring from the bottle was overly bubbly, and lacked in flavour or complexity. It just tasted like a light lager cut with a little bit of blackberry juice. The second half of the bottle started out a little more interesting, as I stirred up the yeast and poured it along with the beer, giving it more flavour - but the yeast and blackberry soon combined into an unpleasant medicine flavour. Bleah.

"Bauriedl Eslarner Festbier", 5,8 %, Flasche (MHD: 4.12.19) aus dem brauereieigenen GetrÃ¤nkemarkt. - Kupfergold, blank. - In der Nase breites herbsÃ¼ÃŸliches Karamelmalz, Holzleim und DMS, unschÃ¶n dumpf und matt. - Antrunk nussig-karamelmalzig mit schaler Frucht und vager, schwach krautiger Herbe. SÃ¼ÃŸ aber nicht malztief. Bizzelig rezent. Im Abgang derb ranzige Bittere. - Stark miÃŸlungenes Festbier, unrund, abgestanden, muffig und ranzig, als hÃ¤tte die Flasche ein paar Jahre in der Sonne gestanden. Kaum genieÃŸbar. (14.9.2019.)
50cl bottle. A clear deep golden beer with a small white head. Aroma of light caramelish malt and soft floral hops. Taste of mild spicy bitter hops, caramel, herbs.

Bottle [from trade with beerhunter111] @ home. Clear light amber color, average sized white to off-white head. Smell and taste malts, lightly caramel, lightly bitter, moderately malty sweet-bitter. Very flavorful malt forward, easy drinkable beer.

The color is red copper and the head is creamy, not very big. The aroma has notes of caramel, malt and a little sweet fruit. The flavor is rather sweet with the same notes as the aroma, Iâ€™m glad I shared this one with my husband, it would have been too sweet in the long run, Iâ€™m afraid...
Light amber color. Strange aroma, dusty, with hazelnuts and freshly cut wood. Light caramel flavor, light residual sweetness, quite low bitterness; light nutty touch. Weird.

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, earth, wood - damp staind - musty. Flavor is moderate sweet and light light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20091130]
Bottle at PapsÃ¸. Clear amber coloured with a small off white head. Sweet aroma of caramel, grass, earth and mould. Flavour of caramel, earth and mould. Mouldy and hoppy finish.
Clear amber with a tiny off white head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel and hoppy notes. Sweet flavour with roasted malt, caramel and hoppy notes. Finished bitter.
50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white had. Aroma is mouldy and malty, light roasted. Roasted malt flavoured. Roasted and slight bitter flavoured finish.

Bottled. An amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of dust with hints of mold and caramel. The flavor is sweet iwth notes of mold, caramel, and malt, leading to a bitter finish. Thanks Papsoe for sharing and Timo for bringing it to Denmark.

F: medium, tan, not long lasting. C: dark brown, clear against the light. A: chocolate, dark fruits, malty, toffee, caramel, dried fruits. T: caramel malty, toffee, bit buttery, dried fruits, bit sweet cherries, bit chocolate, medium to full body, medium carbonation, vintage but not too much oxidized, good, enjoyed, sample from 0,75l bottle vintage 2012 @ second day ZBF 2018.
En sÃ¸dlig Ã¸l, som ikke smager af de sÃ¦dvanlige belgiske juleÃ¸ltyper, men helt sikker en god fyldig og kompleks Ã¸l.
Vintage 2012. Interessanter Lebkuchenkracher mit gutem GestopfterSchweinebratencharme. Cellarstinky&schwallernd durchgereift ðŸŒš . 0,1 aus der Flasche, beim ZYHTOS BEER FESTIVAL 2017.

Helder donkerbruin bier met mooie beige schuimkraag. Aroma: Karamel, kandij. Smaak: zoete karamel mout, gedroogde vruchten, kruiden en een hint van chocolade. Mondgevoel: rijk met zoetige afdronk en matig koolzuur.
@ Stordirren 16-1-26: ingen stÃ¶rre doft men tydlig kolasmak och knÃ¤ck, lite vanilj. Ok, men inget mer.

Aroma: Smelling of bread, apple, brown sugar and vanilla. Appearance: A amber colored beer. A off-white head with some lacing and good curtains. Taste: Tasting toffee, bread, brown sugar, raisins and hay. Palate: Low carbonation, a soft and oily texture. A big body. Overall: Sweet, warm. Good winter stuff. Note: Bottle 750 ml at home. Reviewed 2015-12-21.

750 ml unfiltered bottle sampled just at best before date. Clear (at least for the first 2/3 part of the bottle) amber body with a nice creamy beige head that disappears quite fast. Nice aroma of caramel malt, dry fruit, brown sugar and spicy Belgium yeast. Flavor is sweet caramel malt that balanced nice with the alcohol, brown sugar, dry fruit, spices and a hint of chocolate. Nice balanced body and good, long lasting aftertaste with sweet caramel and dry fruit. Really nice and the cellaring has probably done some good thing here.

bottle shared during xmas beer festival. poured a poured a clear dark amber colour with a off tanned head on top. belgian yeast, and overriped fruits upfront. caramal, liqorice, deep dried fruits, sweet malts. more spices as it warms. not good

DWFADSJT; Bottle, small. Poured clear brown with a moderate lasting, frothy, off-white head. Nose is moderate, malt and caramel, yeast, rasin, spice and alchole wood. Taste is moderate sweet and bitter with a warming, spice, dried fruit, lasting finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to avarage.
@ Agards vÃ¤g 5/9-15. Bottle from Belgoklubben. Fruity with spicy notes also sweet. Body is medium, the finish is spicy.
Bottle shared. Light hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of grain, malt and cardboard, pretty dull. Flavour is light sweet and bitter. Light bodied with light carbonation.
25cl bottle shared with kermis. Very thin white head. Clear golden pour. Drinkable but nothing special.
Pours clear blonde, Small white head. Smell is intense grainy. Taste is bit bitter, crispy maltyness. Bit metallic. Easy drinkable. Rather weak in body. No real aftertaste, besides metallic notes.

Tasted at ZBF 2008 in Sint-Niklaas. Pure â€™old goldâ€™ colour, clear with medium, sticky, snow white head; malt sweet character, â€™honestâ€™ and bready, toasted accent, some herbal hop bitterness in the finish. One of the better Belgian lagers, but, as is the case with all of Leroyâ€™s beers, hopelessly outdated...
Bottle from a gift. Blond colour, white foam. Medium carbonation. Rather sweet malty body with light bitter finish. Easy drinkable. Boring.
at my home golden blonde colored body with a white head and a spicy hop malt aroma a spicy sweet malt taste with a bitter finish
Clear golden colour, white head. Aroma of banana, malts, straw, light off notes. Sweet flavour, light bitter, hop extract. Bit too sweet for me. (from 25cL bottle shared by Benzai @ Oirschot)
Bottle @ home shared with Martinus. Clear golden color, small white head. Smell and taste light to moderately malty, lightly sweet, sweet grainy, slightly alcohol. Meh...
Bottle @home. Pours clear golden with a white creamy foam. Light malty aroma. Taste is lightly sweet, malt and in a very light way again this metal/copper taste. Dry finish. Nothing special.
@ZBF. Clear golden with a white head. Sweet malty aroma. Light body with sweet malty hints and very weak bitterness. Not a belgium speciality... :D
12/10/2017 - sample from a colleague's bottle. Orange colour, nice white head; Nose is sweet malty, toffee. Taste is sweet malts, caramel, missing some hops.

Cette ultrablonde de la brasserie ScÃ¥ssenes est une biÃ¨re plutÃ´t plaisante, sur une amertume agrÃ©able sans quâ€™elle en soit cependant particuliÃ¨rement intÃ©ressante. En bref, de quoi passer une bonne soirÃ©e avec des amis en Ã©tÃ©. En verre, lâ€™ultrablonde est blond dorÃ© (EBC aux environs de 21) avec une mousse blanche dâ€™un centimÃ¨tre environ. Le nez est frais, sur le houblon avec des arÃ´mes floraux, fruitÃ©s (pomme, poire et une pointe citronnÃ©e) et de miel. Lâ€™attaque, souple et sur un bon Ã©quilibre malt/houblon est avant tout floral, sur les cÃ©rÃ©ales mais avec une pointe dâ€™aciditÃ© citronnÃ©e. La deuxiÃ¨me bouche est lÃ©gÃ¨rement plus amÃ¨re, florale avec des arÃ´mes de pÃªche en complÃ©ment. Lâ€™arriÃ¨re bouche quant Ã  elle prÃ©sente une amertume plus saillante avec des notes de coriandre. La troisiÃ¨me bouche, linÃ©aire, prÃ©cÃ¨de un final relativement long sur une amertume saillante et agrÃ©able. Lâ€™alcool, progressif, est bien dosÃ© Ã  lâ€™instar du sucre, et la corpulence, quant Ã  elle est moyenne. Un bon moment tout de mÃªme. Il faut savoir se contenter des choses simples quelquefois.
Bottle shared. Hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is big herbal, yeast, light perfume, caramel and malt. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. [12/08/2016]
33cl bottle courtesy of and shared with Kermis. Medium creamy white head. Very hazy blond pour. An average blond.
Troebel donkergeel bier met weinig schuim. Smaak is krachtig, licht zoet en fruitig. Smaak blijft lang hangen.

27/XII/14 - 33cl bottle from Amon Tchiniss (MalmÃ©dy) @ holidays - BB: 7/V/15 (2014-1539) Clear blond to orange beer, creamy off-white head, little stable. Aroma: oxidized, orange peel, very spicy, coriander, nutmeg, overripe fruits. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: very spicy, quite some coriander, sweet, malty, dry, little bitter, some orange peel. Aftertaste: lots and lots of coriander, spicy, little sugary, nice bitterness, bit grassy, more spices.
33 cl bottle. Hazy golden with creamy head. Yeast aroma, apricot, apple, sweet caramel taste, yeast, dry finish
Bittle@home. Small head. Haze golden. Medium carbonation. Floral citrus yeast notes. Almond phenolic bitter medium mouthfeel. Dry finish. Fine brew.
2014.11 - fles 33cl - bij Cis, bier van Hans - bleek geel bier, zeer troebel, brokken, weinig schuim - neus/smaak : een gistbom

Tripel with yellowish white, moussy and somewhat rocky, stable head and deep â€™old goldâ€™ colour, clear but cloudy with deposit, including somewhat off-putting protein strings. Very estery aroma, apricot, banana, orange, coriander, white pepper, caramel, honey, floral hops. Fruity, pleasantly malt sweet palate, light spicy hints, yeasty, rounded and straightforward with light hoppiness in the end. Decent but nothing extraordinary, just another tripel - again.

Nog een boekje gevonden van de 24 uur van het belgische bier in de oude beurs in Antwerpen in 2002 waar ik dit bier geprobeerd heb. Ondertussen bestaat het bier blijkbaar niet meer, maar ik heb er toen bijgezet: kleur tussen donkerblond en amber, zeer lekkere geur en lekkere (iets zurige) smaak

One of the old Regenboog beers which went extinct when the brewery was closed down (and replaced by another one). A spicy, fruity, sweetish â€™edelbierâ€™ with warm orange blond colour, toasted bread, red berries, yeasty, smooth maltiness, supple and fruity, with grassy hops in the finish. A bit different.

pours a reddish amber with a thin white head amd a slight release of gasses. taste is sour/putrid, with a strange, slightly sickening metallic flavor. smells how it tastes. mouthfeel is smooth. i donâ€™t care for this beer much, and snuffels hostel in brugge deserves a better beer with itâ€™s name on it. go to snuffes!!!! itâ€™s awesome! brugge is wonderful! cheers
ZBF 2005. Pours dark golden, with a small white head. Aroma is sweet and spicy. Taste is slightly sour, with some malty sweetness.
Dark golden colour, small white head. Refreshing sourish and malty flavour.
Zythos Beer Festival, Sint-Niklaas, Belgium 2005. Amber colour with a white head. Light sweet spicy aroma and a sweet malty light sour taste. Medium body and a sweet sour finish.
Amber coloured. Very nice spicy peach aroma. The flavour is sour and fresh. The finish is dry. Complex and interesting.

Bottle conditioned, ZBF 2004. Amber gold, moderate white head and moderate condition. Low malt and high wild yeast notes (intentional?). Fruity tart in the mouth with more wild yeast that becomes chemical like. Tart fruity finish with traces of spice. Suspiciously like an infected beer.

An amber beer with not head. The aroma is sour as if it is infected - or is it just the spices, but also malt sweetness. The flavor is sweet in the beginning from malt and caramel, but then again sour as if it is infected.

Amber; white head, fast gone. Spicey nose (which I KNOW - not identify - to be paradise seed) on top of crystal malt. Bit over-burnt smell. Sourish taste, once more sloeberry-like, but quite clean & crisp. Extremely refreshing - perfect palate-cleaner. Rather light-bodied. Strange, but well worth looking for. Normally only at the YH in Brugge.

Obviously aged sample, +/- 4 yrs Initially frothing head, gone in seconds, leaving unclear yellow beer, resembling cider. Yeasty & estery nose, fresh-smelling, peppery, lemony or lemongrass, even some Brett! (a lot of aged Regenboog beers sport this), ironoxide (though not in the head, obviously), organic acids, fruity. Good deal of fruity acidity in the taste, bit lactic, much less spicey than the nose. Lemony or wild prunes ( quetches ), sweet (or rather sourish?) woodruff. Retronasal even more flowery notes. Thinnish MF, because of the acidity, but has kept oxydation at bay. Strange, but rather pleasant flavours. I get Michaelsâ€™ lemon, but not his tea. Thanks to the brewer himself for supply! This bottle is better than remembered on draught at the 24h.
Milky blond with a small head. Weak aroma. Tea and lemon flavour. Well balanced but a rather short taste.

A layered palate; interestingly so. Chalky, dusty but with some smooth elements too, this is an easy to drink beer. Earthy, muted coriander and surprisingly mellow caramel. Nice burnished brown. Natural. Hint of honey (or in all of Regenboog by default?). Lovely little beer.

Hazy orange. Lacy head. Nose of coriandre, spicey, herbal, lactic. Diacetyl just at identification level. coriandre, lots of malt and malt sugar. Dense mouthfeel, more than expected, but the palate is 'fade'. OK, but nothing to rave about.
Amber coloured beer with a sweet fruity aroma and a mild, slightly fruity taste.

0,33l bottle. Pours brown with beige head. Aroma of malt, loads of raisins, dark fruits/dried fruits, toffee, spices, christmas cake, star anise. Taste is sweet, malty, toffee, dark & dried fruit, spices, star anise, licorice, hint of christmas bread. Excellent.
Perhaps too heavy for a fordrink? The beer is more for a dessert or later in the meal. But once over the frist chock- very good!
15/20 pure liquorice, a sipping beer but no real hint of booze. really interesting belgium. stored for almost three years before drinking

Dark brown , slightly hazy, with a beige head. Aroma is chocolate muffin and some faint licorice. Taste is an immersion into licorice, very intense. Along with some spice, bread, malts. Beautiful mild malty and slightly sweet palate. Excellent.
Kruidig, krachtig en rond. Smaakvol en heerlijk op kamertemperatuur. Weet niet precies wat het geforceerde maturatieproces voor effect gaf

33cl bottle from Abeervinum, Rimini, Italy. Pours dark brown with andante and persistent cream foam, fine. Aroma is very rich of malt, caramel, liquor, wood, vanilla, figs. Body is dense and sticky with moderate carbonation. Taste is pretty intense with sweetness, of course. But very pleasant. Finish is fairly long, sticky and sweet
Dark color, middle foam size. Good beer, aroma and taste fit into the style.
A: Clear mahogany with a medium off-white head. N: Sweet malts and hints of spice. T: Malty, fruitcake. P: Full O: Quite enjoyable

Color marrÃ³n oscuro rojizo con espuma beige media de buena retenciÃ³n y residuo medio. Aroma a maltas tostadas, regaliz, especias y notas a levadura belga, frutas oscuras y polvo. Sabor similar, muy especiado y con notas a frutos secos, madera, vino dulce o cognac. Dulzor medio-alto con final afrutado y aÃ±ejo y regusto largo. Textura acuosa, cuerpo medio-ligero y carbonataciÃ³n baja. Una BiÃ¨re d'hiver muy especiada, ligera de tomar y con alcohol muy bien escondido. Perfecta para el frÃ­o, como postre o acompaÃ±amiento de dulces. Me hubiera gustado con algo mÃ¡s de cuerpo.

Of the several brews brought home from my recent The Netherlands/Belgium visit, Christmas/Noel will be the first opened and sampled. I tilt the 33 cl bottle into my Trappistes Rochefort glass to discover an amber-brown body completed by a determined egg brown top of finely-bubbled foam. The nose is apparent and delightful, toffee, brown sugar, malt and sour dough bread. I pause before drinking, but not too long. Delightful again, dates, caramel, wheat bread, cherries and a nice surrounding bitterness. Gouden Carolus does it again for me. Bravo.
Nice winter ale. Dark, with no end of spices, particularly cinnamon and clove. Backlog.
Fles 33cl thuis. Winter ale smaak maar wel vlak. Wel te drinken. Niet spannend. (1-2011).
En stor fylde, og en del sÃ¸dme. JuleÃ¸l uden at det smager af kanel og kardemomme det hele.
