column5: Bottled. Hazy golden. Honey aroma. Sweet with raw, mellow mouthfeel and sugary finish.

column1: St. Poloise La Cervoise des Sept VallÃ©es
column5: Golden syrupy beer with a fruity lightly hopped aroma. Slightly sweet flavour with a bitter finish. An above average French beer.

column1: St. Poloise La Cervoise des Sept VallÃ©es
column5: deep golden colour, beautiful head, honey and hazelnut aroma, sweet, malty, alcohol, long aftertaste

column1: St. Poloise La Cervoise des Sept VallÃ©es
column5: Blond, misty. Sweet aroma, honeyish, fruity (banana,...). Sweet, some malt, no character, poor hop.

On tap at JHâ€™s in Manchester CT. A wonderful light-bodied hoppy golden lager. Clean and refreshing. This one has a tad more hops than the classic German type, but is still quite drinkable an refreshing. Well made version of a very under-appreciated style.
i find the aroma and flavor of this brew to be rather bland and boring. nothing worth noting.

On tao at brew house. Poured a slightly hazy, light amber with a thin, off white collar. The aroma was mild citrus with a hint of breadiness. Flavor was weak toasted malts with a touch of citrus hops. Had a slight peppery bite in the finish. Medium bodied and a middle of the road beer.
on tap-pours a thin off white head and amber color. Aroma is light/medium malt, fruit/spice hops. Taste is sweet light/medium malt-caramel, fruit/spice hops. Towards medium body. OK/mild carbonation.
Assume this is what is called "Harvard Square Helles" in the Harvard Square location. Dull golden, with quickly receding head. Grassy aroma with sweet, malty flavor. Light carbonation, medium body.
On tap at the Wayne, PA location. Poured a medium golden color with a small sized white head. Aromas and tastes of grains, light citurs, and some grass. Thinner body.

Pretty sure this is the same....called Munich Gold at the DC location. Draft on 11-12-05. Gold bodied witha small white head. Nose is malty and bready with a light sulphur/egg note. Kind of unappetizing. Taste is better with chewy malts, light lemon notes and grass. SOme sourdough bread hints as well. Body is light with a mild carbonation feel. Finishes with more bread notes, malts, light grass and a hint of citrus. OK, I guess.

On draght at Framingham loc. on 9/22/2005 with OldGrowth. Freshly brewed on 9/20/2005, so it didnt have being old as an excuse. But an excuse it needed. Pours a ridiculously clear, filtered to all get out light yellow. No head or lacing, much resembling BMC, though not as much fizzy carbonation and perhaps not quite as light in color. Smells like a cheap, German knock off. You can smell the yeast biproduct and I know they used a German-style yeast strain, but itâ€™s just smells, powdery, dusty, corny, papery and altogether unpleasant. Yikes. Flavor is at least, somewhat better than the aroma would let on. Watered down German lager yeast has no bite left in it, with touches of light pale grains, corn-like notes and a watery, poor body which gets even worse after it warms. Barely perceptible hoppiness, maybe a touch of watered down grassiness. Iâ€™ve definitely had worse versions, but this is still pretty bad.
Tap in Framingham. Clear golden orange color, minimal head. Aroma of wet hay and pale malts, assorted grains. Mild flavor overall, has a pleasant malt finish. Not bad, but just average altogether.
Tap at Framingham location: Poured golden yellow with a medium white head. Mild aroma of vinegar and corn with a little fruit. More corn in the palate. Okay.

Notes from 2006 - Monroeville location. +++ Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a mahogany color with a small tan head. The aroma was faint sweet malts with a pleasant vague fruity presence. The flavor was sweet and tangy with a nice malty presence and faint fruity hops. Medium length hoppy finish. Pleasant.

Draft at Union Station, identified as an American ESB with 5.6% ABV. Beige head atop clear dark amber body. Aroma is medium sweet, orange/floral, some caramel/bread, light spicy, strawberry. Taste is medium sweet, orange/floral, spicy, some bread, caramel. Light-medium body, light stickiness.

Growler filled at the Lake Grove, NY location. Pours a clear dark reddish amber with a moderate off-white head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left just a bit of spotty lace. Pleasant aroma of malt and just a hint of chocolate. The flavor is exactly the same as the aroma with malt and just the barest hint of chocolate. Very lightly bitter at the finish. I am not sure what makes this a holiday ale, but it is a decent enough beer anyway.
Sweet with notes of caramel and maybe a drop of cherry. Light, not meduim bodied like in the Providence discription. A little bitter, a little watery wheat taste also.

Lake Grove listed as Holiday Red. Poured a dark red brown color with a beige head. Light chocolate and nutty malt aroma. The aroma was dry. The flavor was malty with nutty notes. Light sweetnes with a hint of fruit. Dry finish. Medium bodied.

Draft at Manchester, CT location. Light aroma, not much of a head, nice red color. A little earthiness and very little bit of hops in the nose. Rather watery and light in the mouth. Small amount of caramel maltiness balanced by an equally small amount of grassy hops. Not repugnant, but not mind-blowing either. Easy to drink and goes well with a full meal, which what theyâ€™re after.
Ok lighter weight style. Soem faint roasted notes lurk, adding complexity. Clean, filtered, fizzy notes detract from the flavour.
Hmmm. Was expecting more. I was a bit taken off by the watery texture of the beer. Yes there was malt and hopps present and a little candy like sweetness. A mellow and quafable beer but unremarkable.

Dark red in color, decent lacy head, not much by way of flavors as the beer seemed a bit bland, a bit of a sweet malty profile & aftertaste, certainly not one of the better holiday seasonal beers out there

Draft in Pittsburgh, PA. Clear coppery red. Barely an edge head. Light carbonation. Lightly sweet with a smack of Belgian yeast initially. Light malt base and a buried alcohol presence. Minimal hop aroma and flavor. Basically an Irish Red made with Belgian yeast. Decent seasonal.

Warm amber with an OK head. The aroma has notes of malt and sweetness, and the flavour is sweetish, malty and is slightly roasted. Itâ€™s mellow and rather well balanced. But a great experience - noooooo!

Bottle. Amberish colour with a short lasting bubbly head. Sweet maltish aroma, which also appears in the flavour though more sweet. Served too warm so it was a bit nasty. Though my thanks to Janne for getting this brew.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is amber. Aroma is sweet caramel and malt. Taste is sweet with caramel and notes of roast malt.
Beautiful dark amber color with fine head. Sweet aroma but the flavor isnÂ´t that sweet. An okay beer.

Bottle. Pours dark amber with an off-white head. Sweetish aroma, slightly hoppy. Lots of apple. â€“ I usually like the apple-thing, but this seems overdone â€“ as if the beer hadnâ€™t matured long enough. Flavour is sweetish with apple notes and cereals in the background. Dryish finish. 12-01-06.

(Bottle 33 cl) Nice, golden brown beer without much head. Not much immediate aroma, but lovely soft and pleasant flavours of some slightly roasted malt and caramel. Not much bitterness to speak of. Very harmonious and easy-to-drink Christmas-beer although perhaps not the most characterful. 311099
An amber beer with a caramel colored beutiful head. The aroma is sweet caramel with slight sour notes. And so is the flavor, which also contains notes of bread. An OK cheap christmas beer.
Dark colour. Malty aroma. The flavour is sweet with a bitter finish.........
From notes, tasted at Great American Beer Festival 2017. Will add more notes if I get to try this again. Good stuff.
At the source: pours light amber with a white head. Aroma is caramel and malts. Taste is sweet and malty. Not a bad marzen.
Sampled at GABF 2017 in Denver, CO. Numerical rating only - did not take detailed notes.

22 oxz bomber from Total Wine. How this beer could miss so many marks is beyond me. Funky, musty aroma bordering on sour. taste is overly sweet malt, cooked vegetables. Just off and nasty all the way around. I had hoped for much better.
On tap at the brewery. Clear yellow pour with a white head. Mild lager bouquet. Nice malty notes dominate. Light and and refreshing.

"Suckered into this premium price beer (for a marzen anyway 40 cents an ounce is a bit much) because Iâ€™m wanting to try EVERY new Oktoberfest beer I see this year. This was ok, but not a great traditional example of the style. Not very rich and a little too bitter. In the end, the toasted malts and caramel were pleasant, but it wasnâ€™t enough."
(bottle) clear orange amber colour with a medium tall white head; aroma of stewed fruit, then honey; somewhat unusual, intense flavour- bit chemical, with a long medium bitter finish

Pint on tap. Dark gold color, clear, light head. Aroma is disappointing, not what I was expecting for the style, kind of flat. Taste is confused, I think this beer has an identity crisis--itâ€™s simultaneously a not good example of the style and not good in general. I donâ€™t know what it is, frankly. Hoppy but not fresh really. Get a Paulaner Oktoberfest MÃ¤rzen instead.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has bread through out that grows in sweetness with a bit of cereal. Flavor is a combination of bread and cereal that are slightly sweet.

On tap at brewery poured a clear amber hue w/ med fully diminishing white head. Medium malty aromas. Initial flavor light sweet w/ a med bitter finish. Tastes are bread, caramel, and rye. Creamy mouthfeel and a dryness in the finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On the board as Lake Effect Stout. This a really sweet stout. The pour is a lighter dark brown, no real head, and no lacing to speak of. The smell is really sweet, with some hints of chocolate, and maybe a little coffee. The taste is even sweeter, with some of the coffee and chocolate coming in as an afterthought. Not very well executed, and it doesn't linger very well. Not a good beer ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Listed on the menu as Coletteâ€™s Stout and described as a sweet stout. however, it seems extremely dry to me with substantial chocolate malts -- no sweetness at all. decent, but not exactly what was described by the menu.

On tap at Harperâ€™s. Deep brown body, medium tan head. Chocolatey, roasty aroma with sweet notes. Rich, creamy, full body with roasted malts and chocolate opening up to a complex, deep sweetness characteristic of the best cream stouts. Appropriate depth of body to carry the array of flavors. Smooth, quaffable, and well-done.

Black body with small, quickly fading head. The aroma is sweet chocolate and roasted notes. The flavor was sweet cream, chocolate and coffee. Body was slightly on the thin side, but overall a nice milk stout.

Really pretty impressive. Brewpub stouts can be hit or miss and this one was a nice surprise, a direct hit, especially with the creaminess and soft roasted taste. I usually don''t like strongly roasty stouts and this one was tasteful, unlike Sean''s rating of it.

A sophisticated presentation - swirling deep browns and a lovely dark head and a gentle mouth feel, soft and full as a woman''s breast. OK, maybe that''s getting carried away, but it was a pleasant texture, and nice accents of licorice, roast, and well creamed coffee in the flavour. A good, lighter stout.

column4: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
column5: This beer is now made every now and again at the SUnnybrook ballroom. It is excellent if flavor, color, and aroma.

column4: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
column5: Excellent bock beer, light copper color, decent amount of lacy head, fruity aromas & flavors, very sweet aftertaste, excellent blond bock

column4: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
column5: A nice dark bock. I have seen this one a few times at Sunnybrook under Bill Moore. I'm not sure what recipe he is using.

column4: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
column5: Very nice dark brown appearance, lacy tan head, seemed a little thin & light in the body, fruity flavors & aftertaste, pretty decent dark bock

column4: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
column5: Try this recipe at the new Ortleibs Sunnybrook ballroom. Very dark pour, with excellent head and lacing. Super complex, with a great finish.

column4: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
column5: Excellent stout, I think this is the best beer they had (at least at the time of this writing), basically black in color with an off-white head, the soft & lacy head followed the stout all the way down the glass, very rich flavors, a bit on the dry side, a hint of roasted coffee in the flavors & the aftertaste, overall a very good stout

column2: Toms River, New Jersey, United States
column5: It's been a few years, but I just came across the notes on this stuff. Foul looking, flat Mug root beer appearance. Touch of hops and roast on nose. Sip: this is not beer. I ask the bartender for something else because this porter tastes completely awful. Has a pretty watery mouthfeel that won't go away...or is that my mouth trying to reject the bitter poison I just tasted?

column2: Toms River, New Jersey, United States
column5: I had never been to a brewpub that offered me standard American Lagers before offering their home brews... until now. And with good reason. Their porter is the thinnest, weakest excuse for a porter I have ever tasted. Pass this one by and hit Basil T''s instead.
Golden, small. Aroma is malt, fruit, sweet. Taste is the same, malty sweet, bit alcohol. Ok
Almost no aroma. Pour is golden color with very little head and carbonation. Taste is sweet, but well balanced.

â€œAlpirsbacher Kloster Starkbierâ€œ, Flasche von GetrÃ¤nkewelt, MeiÃŸen. - Orangegold, leicht trÃ¼b. â€“ In der Nase fÃ¼lliges, mild brotig-karamelliges helles Malz, dezente reife Frucht (AprikosenkonfitÃ¼re), feine KrÃ¤uter. â€“ Antrunk fett brotig-hellmalzig mit starker, leicht honigherber ZuckersÃ¼ÃŸe und Trockenobst. KrÃ¤ftige herbale Hopfenherbe. Milder rezent, Ã¶lig schwer, hefig weich; nicht restlos kaschierter Alkohol. Im Abgang etwas scharfe grasige Hopfenherbe, auch leicht ranzig. â€“ Breit malziger heller Bock, krÃ¤ftig aber etwas dumpf gehopft. Durchaus trinkbar.
0,5L bottle at home. Slightly cloudy golden pilsener, foamy white head. Firm pilsener, quite sweet and yeasty. Firm body, low carbonation.
0,5l Flasche. Dunkles klares Gelb, kaum Schaum. Aprikose, Malz, alkohol Duft. SÃ¼sser Antrunk. Hopfen, Aprikose, Honig.
Butelka 0,5l. Aromat sÅ‚odowy, z delikatnÄ… nutÄ… zioÅ‚owÄ…. W smaku doÅ›Ä‡ peÅ‚ne, sÅ‚odowe, z delikatnÄ… goryczkÄ….

Couleur lÃ©gÃ¨rement ambrÃ©e relativement limpide. Mousse lÃ©gÃ¨re et peu tenace. Au nez on est (hoho) sur un mÃ©lange de cÃ©rÃ©ales et de caramel. En tout cas on peut supposer que c'est sucrÃ©. Supposition qui se confirme en bouche. C'est rond, c'est sucrÃ©, c'est un peu maltÃ©, et l'amertume est trÃ¨s lÃ©gÃ¨re en toute fin de bouche. Ã‡a se boit facilement, c'est pas fonciÃ¨rement Ã©coeurant. Bref, j'ai bu bien plus bidon et inintÃ©ressant de la part d'une brasserie allemande traditionnelle du genre.
Bottle. Golden color. Canned peach, malt and floral notes in the aroma and flavor. Full bodied, sweet, tasty.

- goldfarben mit leichter, schnell zerfallender Schaumbildung - Aromen nach Stroh, Toffee, Honig, Sauerteig, KrÃ¤uter, Flieder und Harz - angenehm zurÃ¼ckhaltende Carbonisierung - der Antrunk hat etwas von einem Eisbonbon - die honigartige SÃ¼ÃŸe zeigt sich schnell von seiner dominierenden Art und Weise - danach kommt eine leichte, wÃ¼rzige Hopfennote zum Vorschein - in Verbindung mit einem nussigen Beerengeschmack klingt das Ganze aus Fazit: SchÃ¶ne Aromenvielfalt mit einer Idee zuviel SÃ¼ÃŸe
0.5l bottle from hieberâ€™s. pours a clear golden with a small white head. mild aroma of cereals and hay. flavour of grains, biscuit, honey, grass. oily mouthfeel. delicate bitter finish. nice.

Copper with a small head and no lacing. Rich and malty with toasted and caramel malts in the nose. Some nuts and a touch of bitter hops. The flavor mostly follows suit though bitter hops show a bit more and the malts are a touch softer. Nutty finish with a medium body.

Bright golden-amber. Huge caramel/brown sugar aroma. Sweet, slightly fruity palate. Heavy emphasis on brown sugar character. Some earthy notes from the yeast. Iâ€™m not a fan of the beer per se, but I can see what theyâ€™ve getting at.

Sampled draught at the Mill Creek Brewpub in Walla Walla, WABronze color, light head, no lacing. Nose of light PNW hops, sweet husky crystal malts and an earthy body. The flavor is very sweet with a touch of bitterness and lots of herbal hop qualities. Not traditional in any sense but itâ€™s managable. I donâ€™t know if I could drink a whole pint due to the sweetness.

Clear amber with a thick fine particle head. Aroma is split between european hops and caramel with a light earthiness and an even lighter bubble gum and roast. Bitterness throughout the semi-dry taste. Lingering bitterness.

Aroma is light and faintly malty-sweet...Color is a hazy copper-amber with a light head and speckled lace...Flavor is a mellow blend of lighty roasted and sweet malts, with compatibly mellow hopping...This has a nice combo of caramel and hop-dryness, which come especially into play in the finish...This has good body and balance...This does not have the most assertive flavor profile, but is well-constructed and quite pleasant.

Draught in a flight at the brewpub. Pours a clear amber color with a moderate white head on it. Nose has some nice floral hoppy elements to it. Taste is definitely bitter, but tastes like the hops are going bad, as I get some bits of isovaleric acid to it. Meh.

filtered caramel rust body. zingy hop bitterness with astoundingly awful tasting malt sweetness. it seems like nothing more than amber malt extract and hop pellets: chewy, sweet and buttery with caustic cheese rind hop bitterness. awful.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a rather dark hazy amber-orange, with a thin slick in white. Generic cascade aroma, quiet. Flavor is a bit ugly. Really sweet and riddled with old hop, wet dog, buttery, cheesy isovaleric character. Ugh. Iâ€™m not sure Iâ€™ll be able to handle this whole pint. Tongue-smacking bitterness is rough and chewy. Some high estery fruit coming of the yeast alcohols on the back end. This is tough.
Taster - Mill Creek Brew Pub - Walla Walla, WA - A lackluster batch of IPA. The beer was slightily light struck with a small infection. This was not the best from this area.

From a growler fill and a very new batch. Pours full-on amber witha small head and few lacings. Aroma is fruity hops with some caramel. Taste is fruity citrus-orange hops with enough sweet malt to give good support. Pretty close to an English IPA even has low carbonation. Nice bitter finish. Donâ€™t expect a West Coast US IPA and you wonâ€™t be dissapointed. Very nice beer.

Dark bronze with a light head and lace. Vegetable aromas with a small floral quality. A small malt backing. Caramel malts with herbal hops in the flavor. Sweet and candy like. Syrupy and a little too sweet.
Bright golden-copper. The aroma is earthy, lightly grapefruity. Palate is spicy, lightly citrusy with hints of brown sugar. Not a bad beer at all, just donâ€™t expect an IPA.

Sampled draught at the Mill Creek Brewpub in Walla Walla, WAClear bronze color, little head, little lacing. Nose of resionous hops, earthy columbus types with a hint of citrusy alpha acids. The flavor is more sweet but has a touch of bitterness in the finish. A bit too sweet but decent.

Golden with a fine white head. Floral hopp aroma with accents of caramel and light toast. Slight vinous and earthiness. Sweet with a medium body and a moderate bitter finish. A well made IPA but light compared to other west coast varieties. Similar to Sweetwater's IPA, not quite as complex though. Very enjoyable.

Aroma is a light, attractive combo of caramel, light yeastiness and hoppy tang...Color is a hazy apricot with a medium head and nice sheet lace---has an unfiltered look to it...Flavor is a good blend of caramelly malts and well-rounded hops that offer good bitterness and subtle floral tones...The finish is medium-dry but with a combination of flavors that seems lightly smoky to me---most curious but enjoyable...Overall, this is a mellow yet flavorful English-style IPA with a unique twist...well worth a taste...

Having one at CafÃ© LÃ¶we in Neunkirchen/Germany. Golden clear with a thin head. Malty smell. Got it served ice cold which comes good at the current weather conditions. As with most low alcohol beers, this one is maltier than its alcoholic counterpart. Low carbonation.

Bottle 33cl. @home poured into a shaker. Clear pale golden, good two finger frothy white head, good retention, light lacing; sweet malts, grain, straw; taste light sweet and bitter, malty, grainy, metallic; light sweetbitter finish, metallic and cardboard notes; light body, watery texture; acceptable but didn't like the aftertaste.
Bottle @ Saxo tasting. Clear pale yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and corn. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. Extremely watery. 040518
Bottle. Clear pale yellow with small white head. Aroma is malt, grainy and cardboard. Flavour is malt, grainy, thin, cardboard, little sweet and watery.
Bottle @ HÃ¸jbjerg tasting. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are bread, malt, grain and hops. Light bitter finish.
Bottle. Frothy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy bready aroma. Light bitter flavor. Short light bitter finish. Watery palate.
Fles geprobeerd bij de vogelshow in Neunkirchen Zoo Duitsland. Het is een goudgeel alcoholvrij pilsner bier. Prima smaak.
Couleur dorÃ©e claire, trÃ¨s lÃ©gÃ¨re mousse. Nez malt dâ€™orge bien doux. Gout malt dâ€™orge rapide et aqueux, avec fin trÃ¨s amere metallique. A peine des notes dâ€™herbes. Pas gÃ©niale

Thanks to Erzengel for that one! Bottle looks simple but okay. Beer in the glass zippy, huge head. Starts quite malty, moldy, soapy, some bready-sweet notes. Typical non alcohol taste. Finish could be more balanced. Okay.
Malzig-getreidiges Bier. Recht sÃ¼ÃŸlich alkoholfrei. Kaum Herbe, mild-brotig mit typisch alkoholfreiem aber nicht zu penetranten Nachgeschmack.

Aftertaste of burnt nutshells which is oddly not unpleasant. Super light mouthfeel with some herbalness and acidity masking the chocolate. Still, simple sweetness shines through. Leaves the mouth feeling dry. A transparent medium brown.
Regular Tap at the BP. Brown, slight tan head, clear. A little apple in the nose, fruit, malt. Light malt flavor, a little acidity. Slight chocolate malt flavor or roast. Good session brew.
A darker version of their ESB, nice and malty, residual sweetness...........

Sort of generally Belgian, a light golden ale with a persistent head. It was served a tad colder than I think it should have been, and as soon as it got warm enough for the flavor to really blossom out, my bacon cheeseburger arrived, which totally messed up my palate (they use good smoky bacon at the Brew Works restaurant.) Thus it gets lower flavor and palate marks than it probably should. All in all, though, it''s very good, and I agree with Setanta about the vague-tending-toward-saison style. There''s no way this could be mistaken for a non-Belgian style, but it''s be hard to really say which Belgian was intended.
Not sure what style... I would say close to a saison, but a moderately strong ale none the less

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Bagpipers Scotch Ale
column5: Brown color with a medium sized, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel malts, roast, some smoke, and dark fruits. Taste of caramel, nuts, roast, and dark fruits, with some light alcohol in the finish.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Bagpipers Scotch Ale
column5: 750 ml bottle. Pours a deep reddish hue with a large light beige head. A light nose of spices and big berries. A pretty similar flavor with an emphasis on berries, light caramel, sweet. Pretty light flavors. Earthy at times. Light spices. Decent. Tastes thin despite the high ABV.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Bagpipers Scotch Ale
column5: This bottles about ~ 2 yrs old. Gorgeous maroon body. Ok head. Deep, smooth, mellowed dark crystal malts noticeable in aroma and flavor--very consistent sensory experience.. Fruitiness is there, but muted. Mid-range dark fruits and blush wine and some marsala notes. Slide woodiness. Cherry syrup finish. Quite enjoyable.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Bagpipers Scotch Ale
column5: Location: 750 ml bottle from Buy Rite, 2/3/12 Aroma: The nose is sweet and malty, with some caramel, toffee, brown sugar, and molasses Appearance: This one pours a murky looking brown color with minimal head and no lacing Flavor: The taste is fairly sweet, lots of caramel and toffee, no real bitterness, unbalanced sweet Palate: The body is medium, it sticky and mildly cloying on the mouth, with a tingly finish on the tongue Overall Impression: I found some nice components to this beer, but in the end this one was just a little too sweet/cloying for my tastes. Despite that criticism, I still found it to be decent.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Bagpipers Scotch Ale
column5: THOUGHTS: Very nice. Very malty and fairly complex â€” especially in the aroma. It would go nice with some Christmas cookies. Hid alcohol very well. Got slightly cloying halfway through. TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark, reddish brown that was nearly black in the glass with bright, red highlights and a large, off-white head that mostly diminished. It also had tiny particles of average to thick density floating in the body. The aroma had heavy dark bread, molasses, caramel, chocolate and chocolate syrup; light roasted malt; cherry; toffee; butterscotch; brown sugar; maple syrup; cola and hints of vanilla. The initial flavor was light to mod sweet, ever so slightly sour and lightly acidic; while the finish was heavily sweet, ever so slightly sour and slightly bitter. There was cherry, caramel, maple syrup, molasses, cola, hints of vanilla, brown sugar, chocolate, toffee and butterscotch. The medium to full body was a bit syrupy and then a little dry with fairly soft carbonation and a light alcoholic finish.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Bagpipers Scotch Ale
column5: Bomber from New Jersey. Initial smokey malty was nice aroma and tasty, above average mouthfeel, caramel, brown colour and lots of lace. Some hop bitterness. However unbalanced sweet. So-so drinkability.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Bagpipers Scotch Ale
column5: Shared 750 ml. bottle at a recent group tasting. Poured a mahogany/brown color, with good clarity, modest, light tan head foam, and light, spots & streaks of lacing. The aroma was light roast, subtle smoke & peat, and some molasses & dark fruit sweetness. The flavor was similar, with low hop bitterness and a body that was just a bit fuller than medium. Subtle alcohol warmth showed up toward the finish. Tasty, but except for the posted abv, more in the 80/- Scottish range to me.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Bagpipers Scotch Ale
column5: This poured a semi murky medium brown color with a bieg head. Aroma was mainly caramel, light roast and some astringency. Flavor was a bit metallic and astringent, some roast, toffee and caramel. Ehh

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Bagpipers Scotch Ale
column5: From a bottle poured a brown color with a good amount of head. Sweet malty flavor with a quick finish.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Bagpipers Scotch Ale
column5: Poured from a 750 ML bottle. Pours a mahogany color with a finger or two of beige head. Aroma is some smoked peat and malts. Taste is fairly typical for the style...slightly sweet, slightly smokey, some dried fruits similar to a Belgian Dubbel
Draft sample at the source. The beer is a clear yellow with a white head of foam. Crisp, doughy, with a grassy finish. Lighter body and medium carbonation.

Nice find, bottle at kroger! $1.25 Hazy pale like a wit bier. Smell is of fresh cut hay. Very smooth refreshing and bubbly, much better than expected considering all those astringent beers out there that call themselves pilsner. Yes, so much carbonation, lovely, effervescence. One of the better beers in feel on my palate in a long time, so cutting. Taste is almost tart but never quite gets there, right on the threshold of tart and wheatie. This the kind of beer I wouldnâ€™t mind in a 24 can case. Yummy, civilized overall beer drinking experience, nice job Portsmouth. Lovely refreshing stuff fer sure! Does not possess any of that rude sharp astringent bitterness so common with contemporary pilsners. I think this just may be my highest rated pilsner above Erie Brewing Hard Cock Pilsner, Bavik Premium Pils, Carlsberg Pilsner, Warsteiner Premium Verum, New England Elm City Pilsner or even Brixton Michael Pilsener, pretty good stuff! Big thanks to kroger and portsmouth for this random encounter. No lie! This Pilsner ROCKS! Iâ€™m liking this bullshit! Not like most american or domestic wannah beez!
clear gold color; earthy, astringent, grassy, vegetal aroma; flavor is light malt and grassy hops with more strange vegetable notes; not a very good pilsner in my opinion

I wasnâ€™t looking to purchase this beer but it came with a free howler. Or I should say my howler came with this free beer. Pilsners arenâ€™t really my thing but I certainly wonâ€™t turn them down. Nothing special with this one. Typical American-style lgiht beer.
Bottle thanks to my cousins. Pours yellow white head. Nose/taste of old rye bread, stale peppercorn, grass and old malt - Lighter medium body.
Pour from a 12oz bottle. Slightly cloudy light amber brew. Not much aroma. Taste is light malts, slightly vegetal, not much hops.

12 ounce bottle from The Root Cellar. Medium gold hue, medium white head, medium bittersweet aroma with the trademark Portsmouth Brewing rotten vegetable smell in the backround, slightly astringent medium bittersweet flavor with some adjuncts. Iâ€™ve now given three of this placeâ€™s brews less than ringing endorsements but I have to admit, the brewery is still probably better than Portsmouth, Ohio deserves.

Tasted on tap at brewery. Pale yellow with nice white head and some good lacing. Taste is dry with mild sweetness and a medium to low malt and hippiness taste. Above average pilsner. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

3/05/2011: Portsmouth Pilsner... Aroma: Light and grassy with a hint of lemon. Appearance: Pale straw color with a chill haze; densely frothy off-white head that leaves scant lacing. Flavor: A bit funky at first, then biscuit, light grassy hops and some bitterness. Palate: Medium-light body; crisp, clean, and smooth. Overall: Decent, refreshing Pils. Draught sample at Portsmouth Brewing in Portsmouth, Ohio. Rating #16 for this beer.

This is a very crafted beer, but the malt/hops ratio is a bit high for style due to insufficient hopping. Itâ€™s also rather light in color, being a very pale gold. It does have a head with nice size, density and durability, and very fine lacing. Very good to excellent as a light pilsner.

3/05/2011: Portsmouth Heffeweisbier... Aroma: Faint aroma that only slightly grassy. Appearance: Transparent pale yellow color; thin, frothy crown. Flavor: Lemon zest, wheat malt, slightly soapy, spicy finish. Palate: Medium-light in body; calm and smooth texture. Overall: Okay; kind of like a "light" hefe. Draught sample at Portsmouth Brewing in Portsmouth, Ohio. Rating #5 for this beer.
on tap-pours a white head with bubbles and yellow color. Aroma is lemon/orange, vinegar. Taste is lemon/orange, vinegar, hay/spice.

Gold/orange pour with no head or lace. Aroma of sour oranges. Sour tart fruitiness that makes me think infection. A thin and fizzy beer. Something was wrong with this beer even the guy beside me said his beer was off and he was not a beer guy but he did know what a hefe was suppose to be like.
Pretty good for the style. Strong wheat tones with a nice sweet aroma, light on the flavor.

Tasted at the Barrelhouse Brewing Company Microbrew Fest on November 9. Portsmouth (OH, not NH) Brewing was definitely the smallest microbrewer at the festival. I thought this beer was okay for a Weiss, as it was light and wheaty. Pale yellow with a light citrus aroma. Wheat beers aren''t among my favorites but I can appreciate a craft brew like this.

column1: Portsmouth Brewing Maple Nut Brown Ale
column5: Creamy thick head that disintegrated fairly quickly. Good lacing and nice maple and nut tones.

column1: Portsmouth Brewing Maple Nut Brown Ale
column5: Tasted at the Barrelhouse Brewing Company Microbrew Fest on November 9. Portsmouth (OH, not NH) Brewing was definitely the smallest microbrewer at the festival. This beer got points for originality. Poured a dark brown color with a thin beige head and good lacing. It had a sweet maple aroma and flavor and I found it very easy to drink.
Sehr durchschnittliches Massenbier, wÃ¤ssrig und flau, ohne nennenswerte Charaktereigenschaften.
Beer with yellow color, soft bitterness, average carbonized, good volume of foam, (shared a 50cl bottle beer with PG, from Kaufland, Zwickau, DE #799)(#100 DE)(#5 Thuringia).
Jak na niemieckiego pilsa, caÅ‚kiem niezÅ‚e. Chmiel czuÄ‡, goryczka jest, pije siÄ™ ok.

Pours light golden colour with small head. Aroma of malts, grains and sulphur. Taste is rather dry, some malty and biscuits notes. Low to medium bitterness, low bodied. Refreshing and drinablek. Fine.

On tap. Light golden, almost cristal clear with medium but very solid white head and good lacing. Light hoppy aromas with little bit of butter in the nose. Pretty dry and light bidy but not watery, medium bitterness in the finish. Quite solid and very drinkable pils.
Bottle in a hotel room in Berlin. Clear golden coloured with a medium sized white head. Malty aroma of hay, hops and grain. Malty flavour of Hay and hops with notes of grain. Hoppy finish.
Pours a clean golden color with medium white head. Aroma and flavours have straw, sweet malts, grass, cooked vegetables, herbs and honey. Not bad, over the regular Pilener average.
Bottle - clear golden color, medium carbonation. Tastes dull, boring. Hints of straw and malt. Spicy. Only faint hops. Low to medium bitter finish.

Bottle @ Boys night out, at the hill of the dragon. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma of citrus grainy, touch of dms, cardboard. Taste is quite bitter with a touch of herbal hops, light earthy.
Bottle @ Boys night out at the Hill Of The Dragon. Clear yellow body with a small white head. Malt, straw.

Clear golden body with a big foamy and persistent white head. Aroma is grassy, crispy, a bit of honey. Taste is malty, bread crust, honey, some camomile. Dry, herbal finish. Medium body soft carbonation oily texture. From wooden barrel, gravity pour.

L: -pours a clear straw golden with a small to medium,foamy,white head -medium to high carbonation visible S: -spicy,herbal,sourdough,mineral,chalk-y T: -sweet upfront,vegetables,spicy,herbal,chalk-y -finishes dry -medium to high bitterniss for the style F: -medium carbonation -light body O: Pretty good , but somewhat dry and bitter for a Helles.
Smells of soft sweet grain, has a good old white foam on orangey brown body. Flavour is medium in all ways, okay grain, simple but drinkable in large quantities.
Semplice helles, chiara, malto, fieno, note erbacee, finale appena amaro. Poco interessante.
Gezapft in einer Bar in Berlin. Helles klares gelb, angemessener Schaum. Klassisches Helles in Aroma und Geschmack: Hopfen, etwas Zitrus, etwas getreidig, kaum bitter.
Jaune dorÃ©e, bonne mousse. Nez maltÃ© et houblonnÃ© sec, genre lager. Gout pareil un peu sucrÃ© et corps leger. Petite amertume. Bof
Bottle 50cl shared by calisky. A clear yelliw beer with medium head. Nose is on grain, aroma on grain and wet paper, poor lager, boring.

Bottled 500ml. -from Ecuga.com. Pale yellow coloured, medium sized white head, dusty grainy nose. Sweetish malty, caramel, grainy and touch of cardboard with short bitterish finish. Had better had worse.

getrunken im Sommer 2018 Das Helle aus Traunstein ist ein klassisches Helles nach ur-bayrischer Tradition. Man bekommt es inzwischen sogar recht oft vom Fass im Ausland. Dort erfreut es die Leute mit einer angenehmen Spitzigkeit. Es ist sicher ein ausgezeichnetes Bier, aber den Hype, den manche darum machen finde ich etwas Ã¼bertrieben.

Clear golden. Aroma is some grapes some smooth grassy hops some kind of berries. Taste is rather harsh metallic with some sweet almond type sweetness. Full bodied and quite drinkable. Yet too harsh. Not so great.

Frischer aber sehr milder Antrunk, nur sehr leicht getreidig, wÃ¤ssrig. Auch im Mittelteil ist es eher Wasser mit wenig KohlensÃ¤ure als Bier, minimal grasig, immerhin erfrischend. Im Abgang andeutungsweise malzig, herb im Hintergrund. Aromenarmes Bier. Test vom 14.8.2008, Gebinde: Fass Noten: 8,6,6,6,-,6 - 6,21
Draught. Foul beer, very watery and thin. Small amount of hops. The only distinctive aromas are that of lemon and vinegar. Clearly overrated.
draught at brewpub. better than the mass-produced balkan lagers, but not by much. pale, slightly hazy, malty. large long lasting head. not much evidence of hops

On draught at the brewpub. Pours a light gold color with 5cm of foam head. Medium-bodied, with a soft mouthfeel and nice body. Pale malty flavor with an early, slight hop bitterness leading to an even flavor balance with a mild hops flavor throughout. Easy-drinking.
pola voda, pola pivo. istog ukusa kao i crno. Nije za ozbiljniju upotrebu...
Sampled draught at Pivnica Kasina,Belgrade, Yugoslavia. -pale yellow coloured, light hoppy aroma, nice foamy head but too much watery
Sampled draught at Pivnica Kasina, Belgrade. Pale yellow and hazy with airy head. Nicely malt accented with filling mouthfeel, yet very light bodied. Very mild and soft with low bitterness.
Instead of putting your beer in a fancy bottle learn how to brew first, it is waaay over carbonated, perhaps infected. Also the color is waaay off.
Draft@Taps.. Nice orange colour, bitter hops aroma and some citrus, medium finish..
Moldy aroma, bright yellow color, whitish spongy head, moldy flavor, slightly sweet taste, mild carbonation, medium body, abrupt finish. Not great but fine.

Bottled. A golden beer with a lazing white head. The aroma has notes of straw and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and straw. It doesnâ€™t resemble a Vienna - it should be darker in color and more malty - a lot more like a Dortmunder.

Bottled@Monks Porterhouse, Stockholm. Amber colour, small off-white head. Aroma is fruits, wood, some notes of nettle as well. Flavour is wood, ruit, some mild metallic notes as well as some mild floral notes.
Fresh lager from the greatest butique brewery taps. Fresh but caracteristic, nice malty taste nice lager. We need more of these beautifull beers.

Sampled draught at Taps Istanbul, Istanbul, Turkey. They say you should just someone after how they act when they commit a mistake. If so, Taps Istanbul made the test as things went terribly wrong when two waiters collided and dropped three full glasses of beer into my friends head... He received a new shirt within minutes and the whole company got the full dinner for free (and a good laugh at my friends account...) Anyway, this vienna was deep golden, very malty and rather sweet with a fresh hop accent. It was well rounded and nearly buttery with low bitterness, and way better than any other lager I've found in Turkey.

Ã•lle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi vÃµi pudeli suule tÃµstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sÃµltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mÃµjutavad. Seega piirdun iga Ãµlle juures selle tekstiga.
Can from my in-laws, shared with explosivedog: pours pale gold with white head. Aroma is cheap macro cereal. Taste is not particularly offensive, not overly sweet or grainy. Still not very good.
Can, at RB bottle share. Pours pale gold brown. Sulfur, cereal, honey, booze. Medium body. Not good.

330ml bottle from SAQ in Gatineau, Quebec. Pours a clear golden colour with one finger of white head. Aromas of bread and honey. Taste matches the aroma. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Sweeter than the usual Euro lagers. Not bad.

23 September 2019. Can from a supermarket in Agia Pelagia, Crete. Balcony tasting in Pela Mare hotel. Shared with the lovely Anke! Pours clear pale golden with a lasting, small, foamy, white head; irregular lacing. Aroma of citrus, apple peel, wet grain, wort, cereals. Taste is light fruity sweet, some apple & sourish citrus over a yeast, wheaty, bit soapy body; dry, grainy, grassy & bready finish. Light body, slick texture, soft carbonation. Unconvincing Pale Lager, but not terrible.
My favorite lager , went perfectly with my Salmon dish and lemon potatoes.
Pours clear, pale golden with one finger, white head. Aroma is straw and metallic. Taste is corn syrup, moving to well...nothing. Finish is corn syrup.
Cheep and correct. In my opinion, the best "every day" beer for vacation in Greece.
An ok lager, kind of boring, metallic aroma in the after taste. So many other nicer lagers to choose from in Greece.
330ml can share. Pale golden and clear. Metallic aroma, with some corn and a little lager malt. Bready sweetness and soapy notes. Pretty grim pale lager.

Marginally better than the green chili beer. The nose isn't as overpowering of peppers, but still very strong. There is the faint traces of a decent amber brew under the pepper taste, but the peppers still overwhelm. Must be an acquired taste.

On tap at the brewpub. This basic recipe has been reformulated and is now being called the "Trappist Tripple Ale." Unfortunately, it does not look like a trippel. Darl amber in color with a quickly subsiding white head. Itâ€™s as rich as a quad. Smells like cream soda. Has a cherry-like flavor. Serious alcohol burn. This beer dehydrates the mouth. Serves as quite the dessert beer.
Not quite up there with a Trappist, but this is a decent beer. Very smooth, although maybe a little "thin" as compared to others in this category.
Clear golden appearance with a compact head. Banal beer, but very drinkable.
Sampled draft @ zum Bierjohann. Clear golden apple. Nose is cooked vegetable, corn, soap. Taste is vegetable oily weirdly sweet corn, plastic,â€¦ Unpleasant plastic, oil,â€¦ Poor.
Ein sehr gewÃ¶hnliches export der unteren Kategorie, kein Charakter recht sÃ¼ffig tut nicht weh
0,33l Flasche. Goldgelb, fester weisser Schaum. Typischer Exportgeruch. Getreide, leicht sÃ¼ss. Gras, Stroh, Hopfen Antrunk. Sanfte SÃ¤ure. Langweilig.
Bottle sample at a tasting at Tom L's place. Thanks Oren. Yellow. Graininess, bread, a bit of hay, sweetish, bitterish finish, quite light-bodied. Easy-drinking.
At Tom's Place, pours yellow with a small head, aroma of fruits malt, caramel, toffee, flavor of corn, rice, acidity, light bodied

On tap at Das Weinhaus Becker, Aschaffenburg, Bavaria, 10.10.17. Clear gold, white head. Crisp and malty aroma, some minerals. Malty taste but mostly hoppy and bitter - grassy. Medium body, light bitterness, lively fizz and long finish.

On tap, 33cL. @La Cervoiserie Poitiers. A golden pale clear beer with a big white head ; light retention ; few bubbles. Grain, cereal. Light sweet, light dry bitter refreshing. Light body, thin texture, average carbonation, cereal dry fresh finish. Overall, average.
33 cl bottle at Lohr am Main. Just a beer to quench the thirst and straight from the bottle.Malty with medium body and medium to high carbo.
Clear golden colour with white head. Malty aroma. Taste malty, hop and a bit herbal.
Amber, average head. Didn''t really taste like a bitter at all; the flavoring hops overrods the bittering ones. Nutty maltiness toward the clean finish; great brewpub beer.

Beautiful color and head.....transparent reddish orange color. Really just a hopped up version of the trophy bitter....balanced out rather nicely by the malts at sip''s end. The maltiness turned kinda funky as the beer warmed, notes of alcohol came out too....all in all, a good beer.

column1: Rock Bottom Portland Old School Ale
column5: Cask conditioned, and recently tapped at the Portland location. This came a dark amber, with an off-white head that lasted surprisingly long,and left nice lacing. Malty aroma, and sweetly malty up front, with a nice bitter finish, and a touch of alcohol burn at the end. Really nice.
A flavorful, robust beer with little after taste. Just discovered the 8.5% content. Never would have guessed it. I enjoyed several pints at Bostonâ€™s in Dayton, OH.
Pours orangish-brown wtih a white head. The aroma is malty with caramel and toffee. Flavor is full with maltiness, caramel, toffee, and the finish is full bodied.
Golden amber color with a creamy white head. This was a sweet beer with a caramel flavor and aroma. Pretty good overall.

Clearish orange-red body, thin off-white head. Big butterscotchy aroma that carries over into the flavor. Bready, caramely body with a touch of peat. The butterscotch component makes this beer taste like a Werthers candy. Medium-bodied, light carbonation. A pretty solid beer shared by John (JCW).

Bottle, from trade with JCW. Good nose, Little maple, molasses, toffee. Reminds me of a barley pop or the smell of mash. Clean orangy red color, nice head that faded. Sweet flavors, like the aromas little coffee in there, alot like mash. Little metallic bite in there. Medium body, oily creamy mouthfeel, sweet, some bitter bite, sticky finish. Man thatâ€™s a great beer. Unlike any Scotch ale Iâ€™ve had. None of that peaty earthy funk I associate with the catagory. Damn good. If this is 8.5% i canâ€™t notice. Thanks JCW
Mmmmm. This is a big ale in every way. Very nice. This one warms you up from deep down inside and has a nice kick. Great beer.

I agree with Dogbrick on this one. I go to Barrel House a fair amount and I've never been too impress. Scotchish Ales in general aren't my style, but I really liked this one. It was sweet with a heavy taste of barley. Big in alcohol, but I could in no why taste it. Excellent beer!
STRONG - wow. Thick consistency and flavor. A tough drink - high on the alcohol flavor.

Tasted at the Barrelhouse Brewing Company Microbrew Fest on November 9. Got this one out of the cask and it was excellent, one of the best BarrelHouse has to offer. Warm, flavorful presence. Rich and malty with a beautiful color.

Clear orange/amber body with a nice, foamy and persistent white head. Aroma is honey, mild herbal, rosemary. Taste is malty, caramel, mild grassy. Sweet finish. Medium body soft carbonation oily texture
Bottled, from Sagasser, Ilmenau. Clear amber, minimal head. Fruity piney nose. Sweet with medium body and clean mouthfeel. Fruity and caramelly with butter and spice. Resinous bitter finish.

500mml. bottle tasted on the 08/06/2018 at home. Light copper colour with a lasting white head. Aroma is grains, sweet malts, caramel and yeast. Taste is the same, leading to a medium straw bitter finish. Medium body and soft carbonation. Next one please!
Bottle. Pou clear golden with a white head. Aroma of marzipan, caramel, light fruity, grains. Taste is rather sweet, caramel, dust, grains, light nutty.
Bocken varer lige til pÃ¥ske. Dark golden with a lasting white head. Aroma of grain and cardboard. Sweet malty flavour with grain and straw
Bottle @ Dolles Bockstival â€” Bocken varer lige til pÃ¥ske, 5000 Odense C. Pours Clear amber with a small White head. Caramel, bread and grains. Medium bodied. Clean. Ordinary.

"Ur-Saalfelder - Das MÃ¤rzenbier" vom BÃ¼rgerlichen Brauhaus Saalfeld aus ThÃ¼ringen. 0,5L BÃ¼gelpulle, Etikett ist ansprechend mit einer Menge Beerstars drauf! Bernsteinfarben und klar filtriert mit kleiner kurzlebiger Schaumkrone. RÃ¶stmalzbetonter Antrunk, harmonisch kernige WÃ¼rze mit der RestsÃ¼sse gepaart, sehr weich im Trunk. Eine leichte Hopfenbittere stÃ¶sst hinzu und lÃ¤sst es gut ausklingen. Leider nicht so mein Geschmack. European Beer Star: Bronze (2010), Gold (2017,2016,2014,2012,2008,2006,2004).
Bottle. Copper colour, clear, head does not stay long. Aroma is malt, some caramel, a bit of cellar. Light bitterness. Medium carbonation. Decent.

0,5 l Flasche aus einem lokalen GetrÃ¤nkemarkt. Orangegold, klar mit grobporiger Schaumkrone, schwaches lacing. In der Nase habe ich Getreide, Kandiszucker. Im Geschmack Ã¤hnlich, mit leicht herbem Abgang

Bottle. Color: Reddish amber, fast disappearing frothy off-white head. Low carbonation, very small bubbles throughout the whole beer.Taste: Sweet malts, hints of caramel, very lightly roasted malts and hints of flowers / hay. Medium body. Gentle and mild taste.
Botella de 35 Cl. Cerveza inbebible, tambien he intentado probar alguna que resulto ser casera y falsificada.
Really bad. Adjuncts-a-plenty. Really sweet and fizzy, it reminded me a hell of a lot of cheap Aussie lagers, which made me homesick.
Sparkling lager with a lightly hopped aroma, and a sweet/dryly finished flavour. A reasonable lager.

Don't tell the State Department that I bought a bottle of this while in London, but I suppose I can always claim I did it under the "academic research" exemption. What I learned was that it was a lesson in the influence of adjuncts on beer. Fizzy white head. Corn flavors, characteristically sweet like many international lagers. In truth, while clearly bad beer, it had a flavor that I don't particularly mind and it went well enough with friends and dinner. And who are we kidding, this is a beer worth trying only to tick another country off the list.

Bottled. Gold, poor head and moderate condition. Foul aromas of crap, smoke and mothballs, soft and unsettlingly dissolving in the mouth. Slight chalkiness, although that may just be the enamel being stripped from your teeth. Justifies the US boycott of Cuba in a mouthful.

Smells sweet and malty and also a bit "off". This is a clear, golden beer that looks very still, amazing considering how fizzy and bloating it is. Flavours are..not evident. The slight sourness on the finish is the best aspect of this beer. Pretty hopeless. Castro probably forces this on his citizens.

Tinima is the largest of the six breweries in Cuba, and is undergoing modernisation to keep up with the demand in Europe for this slimey cheap cereal lager. Splashed on the label are the words "Cerveza de Cuba" over an evocative picture of palms trees against a blue sky. No doubt if they put a picture of Fidel Castro's beard on the back they would triple production. It started off well - a soft creamy first mouthful with hints of butter. But as the carbonation dies down so the flavour fizzles away leaving a taste of corn starch and a metallic tang of cheap hops.
Bottled. Pale golden. Corn aroma. Light bodied, very bready. Low bitterness. Drinkable, but certainly nothing special.

Hard to describe this one. At first it reminded me of liquid cardboard but after a while it started to taste a little nicer. Tastes like a pils that has gone wrong.There must be a lot of reasons to visit Cuba but this isn't one of them.
Phew - smells like canned corn. Hazy anemic gold color and a fizzy head. Cardboard aftertaste and water. Worthless.

Bottle, 2004 vintage, DÃ˜E Julefrokost @ Aarhus Bryghus. Pours dark golden with an offwhite head. Aroma of malt, caramel, wood, sherry, light oxidation. Flavor is light sweet, malty, caramel, woood, sweet dessert wine, sherry notes, some oxidation. Thin to medium body, soft carboantion, sweet finish. 161215
2003 edition opened 2015. Very good for a 12 year old ale but the taste are not what I expected.

22nd November 2009 ChrisOs Kook Tasting. 2004 Vintage. Clear amber beer, light biscuit coloured head. Moderate carbonation. Softish palate. Mild malts and fruits with a little minerals in the finish. All told has lasted well!
Vintage 2003. bread, caramel, cereal, golden, cloudy, minimal head, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, full body, sticky, average carbonation, bitter,
Bottle, 2005. Light red colour with a small white head. Delicious fruity aroma. good bitter and woody.

A Mes rate. 2004 bottle at Chris Oâ€™s Kook Fest tasting. Amber colour with a thin beige head. Amazingly fruity plus lots of caramel and slight oxidisation. A typical Sheps stamp on it and there are still some hops hanging around five years on giving a reasonable bitterness to the finish, balancing it out nicely. Decent stuff.

Bottle at chris_oâ€™s "smash kookâ€™s granny tasting". Alround rating: Pale sweeter malt, bit of cardboard, not of dry sherry, fairly thin body as youâ€™d expect after this time but the fruity richness keeps it tasty.
Taster at DÃ˜, Aarhus Syd. Bottled, 171208. Strong Vintage 2004. Amber with white head. Aroma and flavor of chocolate and dried fruit.
Bottle. 2005 version. Medium head with medium duration. Color is clear amber. Aroma and taste are fruits, malt and hops.

[i]Bottle (50 cl) from Systembolaget[/i]. Sampled in January 2006. Clear amber with a medium off-white head. Fruity and caramelly aroma with subtle notes of figs and prunes, and floral tropical fruits. Medium bodied with creamy mouthfeel. Niceley balanced with a bitter edge. A personal favourite but not really a Christmas Ale.
Aroma has butter and strawberry, but not very outspoken. Yeasty taste with butter, coffee and bitter chocolate. An a-typical bock beer.
Grain and nutty aroma. Dark brown/redish, off-white head, very good lace. Full, very smooth, caramel, hopbitter. Long lasting hoppy finish. Nice beer but not remarkable.
Very drinkable dark hoppy stout. You can taste the heightened alcohol content in the first taste. This would be an interesting stout to make Black & Tans with.
Black with a brown head. Aroma of dark bread, roasted malts, a bit of smoke and corn. The flavour is sweet and malty with notes of roasted malts and brown sugar.
caramel, smoke, brown foam, brown dark,light sweetness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, need more sweetness.
Light malty aroma with sweet notes of syrup. Huge frothy, light brown head. Good lacing. Mostly lasting longevity. Clear, dark brown body. Heavy syrup sweet initial flavor. Medium and creamy palate.

This hvidtÃ¸l er brown/black with a red hue and a nougat-colored head. The aroma is very sweet and malty, just like the flavour, that is a bit less sweet though. OK, but a bit too sweet, even for a hvidtÃ¸l....

33 cL bottle. Pours dark brown with a little hazzlenut brown hue, short lasting brown head. Mild aroma of malt and sugar. Carbonated mouthfeel. Mild breadish malt flavour, cane sugar - yet not overly sweet. Finish holds a undefineable orange fruity note. Classic hvidtÃ¸l, yet not as flavourful as others within the style.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with msotly diminishing beige head. Molasses and sweet malt in the aroma. Flavor likewise. A bit watery on the palate. Average finish.
Dark brown colour with beige fluffy head.Sweet taste with note of sugar and rosted malt.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a small light brown head. Sweet sweet malty aorms and taste. Too sweet for my taste.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma is malt and syrup. Taste is sweet with fruits and malt.

Bottle. Creamy lightbrown excellent mostly lasting head. Dark red amber colour. Light malty and light hoppy neutral aroma. Moderate sweet flavor. Average sweet finish. Watery palate. Not as sweet as most danish JulehvidtÃ¸l. This is allright.
Golden color. Pleasant hop aroma. Pretty good taste, some malt and hop, a light residual sweetness, an equilibrated and pretty aromatic palate. Enjoyable, but not impressive.
Not beefy as in cow. Beefy as in the legendary "beefy" cricketer. This has a great hops bite that drowns a thirst. Six!

Bottle. Flaky dark brown colour with a relatively large off-white head, nose is yeasty, malty and roasty with notes of banana, liquorice, bubble gum, toffee and chocolate, taste is sweet, spicy and roasty with a tart finish and a thick body.

"Unertl WeiÃŸbier Bock", Flasche aus dem Fastenzeit-Bierpaket vom Biershop Bayern. - Dunkles Mahagoni, Ã¼ppiger Schaum. - Frische Nase mit warmem dunklemn Malz, obergÃ¤rigen Weizenaromen und schlanker, zart herb-sÃ¤uerlicher Frucht: Zitronat, Johannisbeere. - Antrunk fÃ¼r einen Bock eher schlank hefig-dunkelweizenmalzig mit frischer Frucht: Ã„pfel, Zitrone, Weintrauben. AnklÃ¤nge an Vanille und Kakao, ein wenig Nelke. Milder rezent, hefig weich; erst allmÃ¤hlich macht sich wÃ¤rmender Alkohol bemerkbar. Im Abgang sehr dezente, mild orangenfruchtige Hopfenherbe. - FÃ¼r einen Bock eher schlank und frisch gehopft, ohne die fette bananige SÃ¼ÃŸe vieler Weizenbiere doch mit dezenter, runder Dunkelmalzigkeit, gekonnt abgerundet mit zart sÃ¤uerlicher Frucht. Angenehm!
Good weizenbock. Light citrus and potpourri - a hibiscus type vibe. Dark amber pour with decent head. Light sweet finish. Some orange peel here. Easy drinking. Bottle in Dublin.

Nun teste ich mal das WeiÃŸbier Bock von Unertl. Im Glas zeigt es sich fast schwarz, trÃ¼b mit schÃ¶ner feiner Schaumkrone. Dunkelmalzige Aromen steigen zur Nase. Der Antrunk ist sÃ¼sslich, schwach sÃ¤uerlich, weizig, dunkelmalzig und hefig. Dabei hat das Bier einen wÃ¼rzigen Charakter, bei dem im Laufe der Alkoholgehalt von 6.7% auffÃ¤llt. Das Bier sollte man, wie bei allen Weizenbockbieren, ans Ende einer Bierprobe setzen, da der Nachgeschmack, sehr lange anhÃ¤lt. Dieser ist hier recht dunkelmalzig und leicht herb anklingend. Ein ansprechendes Bier und als Weizenbock gut erkennbar. KÃ¶nnte im Mittelteil noch etwas ausgeprÃ¤gter sein.

[Munich 2018] Sampled draft @ Tap House Munich. Dark brown, tanned head. Nose is very unique, fish guts, hay, caramel, liquorice, black candy. Taste is medicinal, herbal, weird, liquorice, bitter spices, black liquorice, thick bodied, herbal, almost medicinal bitter. Almost off-putting at first but it grows very quickly on you, very unique beer.
Drat at Taphouse Munich. Black! Surprised me, anyway. Nice aroma of roasted coffee and light bubblegum. Taste has more roast, banana, citrus. Good stuff.
500ml Bottle - Hazy dark brown with red tinges and a foamy head. Chocolate, cherries and banana in the aroma. Banana split with chocolate sauce, berries and toffee in the taste.

500 ml bottle. Pours unclear chocolate brown with medium foamy head. Bubble gum in the nose. Roasted malt, brown sugar, raisins, vanilla, dark bread. More sweet than bitter, but overall balanced and far away from being too sweet. Light alcoholics warmth. Creamy texture, medium to full bodied, soft carbonated. Nice Weizenbock. Perfect on a winter day.

0.5 l bottle. Hazy black-copper colour. Huge low-lasting off-white foam. Strong banana aroma. Banana and wheat malty flavour, which end up with nutty and black fruits aftertaste. Medium-full body and medium-high carbonation which make the 6.7% Abv seem much lower. An interesting beer.

Black with little white head. Aroma is chocolate dried banana with some mealy stuff dandelion bubblegum. Taste is sweet chocolate with lots of bananna and some sour flour. Smooth and not mealy. Medium full body. Convincing.

Draft at Brouwerâ€™s in Seattle. Beautiful! Great clean appearance with perfect fresh floral nose. Body is just right, with slight citrus bite and huge flavor. Finishes a bit dry and thin, but otherwise this is textbook and tasty.
Sampled at WABL Oktoberfest. Holy hops! Love the mix of nugs and spicy hops coming through. Wonderful aroma and taste to match. A bit too light, and might benefit from a bit more body.

Taster â€“ Brewery â€“ Sunnyside, WA Aroma â€“ Good floral aroma from the hops with a good malt background. Appearance â€“ Amber color, Nice head and clear. Flavor â€“ Very nice fruity beer flavor this was fro the floral hops and the great malts. Palate â€“ Nice Mouthfeel, good texture with a dry finish. Overall â€“ A great beer for the day and the flavors where awesome. This beer had the stuff need to drink this again.
Orange gold color. Funky hop aroma. Super floral w some herbal pot flavor. Light in body with nice bitterness.

My favorite aspect of a harvest ale is the graininess that gives images of a fresh harvest - seems reasonable. It may be in part due to my Eastern Washington upbringing (land of wheat and barley). This was a tasty beer, but frighteningly sparse in respect to this Harvest Ale necessity as I see it. Fresh hops dominate, and although I respect the mentality that a harvest of hops is just as important as a grain harvest, I wish the malt was a touch stronger.
Starts off with a hoppy nose of cascade hops. In the body, malt starts to come into play and then a played out dry grainy malty finish. Waaaayyy too hoppy for the style.
Hazy light amber,lasting beige head.Great citrus nose. Musty citrus hop flavor. Rather thin

Very fine, intense hop aroma with mango tones...Color is a rich gold with a healthy white head--good patchy lace...Flavor has a hoppy countenance that is sharp but very light, with citrus-rind brightness...Subtle sweetness creeps into the scene towards the misty hop finish...Mouthfeel is a little thin, and although the balance is OK, clearly needs a little "oomph" to better showcase its fine ingredients...Overall, this brew "teases" the drinker a little in that it features excellent ingredients, but does not present them prominently enough to render full satisfaction...
On tap at Alehouse. Pours a copper color with white head. Grainy, earthy, malty flavors. Pretty decent.

11/10/02: Aroma is of sweet malt---caramel overtones...Color is whisky with medium head and light drizzly lace...Flavor is sweet up-front, followed by a two-pronged statement by lightly roastier malts and well-judged hoppiness. Finish is a reprise of initial sweetness and the hop-dryness coats the entire back half of the mouth...Body is medium; this has a nice layering of flavors...If there is something lacking, it is a degree of richness in the overall profile...but there is a good spectrum of elements featured here...Very drinkable...

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: 2009 bottle thanks to Sam from the Saucer. deep amber pour with a cream head and floaties. right toffee and caramel malts right off the bat. nice on the palate, sweet malts, caramel, figs, and an easy finish.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: on tap at NXNW. They call it a barley wine, it is listed here as english strong, I think both classifications would be accurate. Pours very nice ruby color with off white creamy head. Aroma includes of raisin, prune. Flavor includes dark fruit tones, molasses, and even some maple, burnt sugar. Very smooth and sippable for abv. Quite nice.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: On tap at the brewery. Listed as an English Barleywine. The beer pours a hazy dark reddish brown color with a tan head. The aroma is very heavy on the dark fruit and some very sweet malt. The flavor is similar with some added notes. I get a lot of brown sugar from the malt as well as some piney hops, dark fruit and some alcohol. The beer is fairly boozy, but less so than some other barleywines. The predominant flavor is brown sugar. Medium mouthfeel and low to medium carbonation.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: 22oz bottle-pours a slightly hazy amber with a big tight foamy light tan head. Aroma is slight medium fruit, musty, grain. Taste is medium malt-caramel, spice hops. Lots of effervescence. 3.2 Then 2nd Â½ of bottle is cloudy/murky and the effervescence has calmed. Nice. 3.5

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: 2009 bottle thanks to Jcwattsrugger. Pours cider brown. Nose of caramel malts, Fuggles, brown sugar. Taste of brown sugar, caramel malts and light plums.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Barrel aged version on tap at the pub. Clear copper orange pour with a foamy white head. Big sweet malt nose with ripe fruit. Taste is sweet bourbon sting right away. Very warming as it slinks down your throat. Lovely spice and light chocolate. Very good and very well done. Iâ€™m thinking this may need to be a new listing as itâ€™s barrel aged.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Date: February 22, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear copper, wispy beige head, streaks of lace Aroma: sweet caramel aroma Flavor: sweet caramel flavor, nice spicy character, balancing bitterness follows the spicyness, touch of candy caramel brings it back to sweet, nice bitter finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: *4

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Served in a tiny tulip, dirty beer clean glass. tan 1/2" head lasts 30 seconds. color is deep amber with red tint. Aroma of carmelized sugars and sourdough. Consistency is really nutty. Flavor is nutty fruity, sweet, and taste too much like alcohol. bite starts off strong but smoothens out to a slow burn on the way down. finish is tart and bready. a bit heavy overall.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: 750mL bottle courtesy of slimchill poured into a tulip. Pours a murky caramel orange with small floaties in the first pour underneath a small head of big bubbles that recedes to a small collar and left some delicate lacing. The aroma is musky but sweet with lots of apple and pear sweetness with a healthy dose of bready malts as well. There are hints of spices, maybe cinnamon and pepper. The taste has an interesting spicy kick up front before the big light fruit sweetness comes on with apples mainly and a hint of floral sweetness. The spices come back in the finish with a slight peppery dryness. The mouthfeel is very slick with low carbonation - drinks almost like a cask ale. This is a very interesting beer from NXNW with lots of fruity sweetness battling with an herbal spiciness throughout. Certainly worth a try and very original.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Bottle sample courtesy of bgburdman. Cloudy amber in color with a thin white head. Malty nose with cherry and raspberry character. Sweet flavor with some tart fruit influence and a sugary finish.
Mild artificial spiced pumpkin aroma. A bit soapy, like dish water, with a fruity shampoo flavor... ugh. Bland and sour describe this one well.

Yep, another entry from The Bitter End...I love using the form to the right and being the first! It''s another pumpkin ale, consumed a few days after Buffalo Bills, which was my first pumpkin ale ever. To tell the truth, I couldn''t taste too much difference between the two, except this one might have a slightly more prominent pumpkin flavor and maybe a bit more spiciness. Still a good novelty beer, I''ll drink one every October. Gets a bit minty toward the finish as it warms up.
A sweeter German style Pilsener. Pale yellow stable head, sweety aroma, body somewhat thin, sweet and spicy. Yeast accent in the spicy aftertaste. Quite fresh and drinkable composition.

Bottle. Dark red and brown. Nose resembles the typical Rogue Ale yeast, some scotch, plums, red oak and wine. Flavor is a lightly hoppy oak and cherry, some light abrasive yeast flavors as well. A nice one... scotch, wood, dark fruit.
Rogue never makes a bad beer, and i guess neither does any company they own. Very nice brown color. Very little head with nice hop aroma. Nice sweet roasted malt taste.
Brown, with tan head.Lightly roasted nose. Roasted palate with hints of chocolate. Medium hop finish. Medium body with rich mouthfeel

Brewed by Rogue. Medium brown color, small head. A medium bodied amber ale. Roasted malts and very hoppy. Big full flavor, complex taste. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is smooth. Aftertaste is bitter. Etched painted bottle. Proceeds benefit the Issaquah Valley Trolley

on tap @ Party Town (Friday Night Flights) --- Cloudy raspberry amber color, white head that drops to a thin rim, a few lace dots. Taste is malt with a light dose of slightly sour raspberry. Hardly any carbonation, very little change through a short finish. I expected better.

Sampler at brewery. Pours red with a white head. Definitely raspberry notes on the nose. Has a bit of the tartness you would expect with this fruit. Itâ€™s flavorful but it could be bolder. Still solid though.

reddish pinkish orange draft sampler...nice aroma of mild malt and lots and lots of raspberries. aromatic and fresh. the flavor is pretty much raspberry and mild malt rather like this one...but if you get the chance take 2/3 of the oarsman and 1/3 of the raspberry for a delicious mix..

Snifter at triangle wine. Ok aroma. Sweet. Fruity raspberry. Tad sour. Hazed red color. No head or lace. Tart flavor. Lighter body thin smooth mouthfeel tart finish. Ok. Nice in the fruit beer area. But not wowing me. Just ok.
A nice fruit beer. Great pinkish red color with pink head. Great raspberry jam aromas. tart raspberry flavors. A touch watery... But still good.
Tap. Red with minimal head. Lightly tart with mild raspberry. Light on flavor but raspberry is often overdone. More on the subtle side.
Not overly sweet but still tons of raspberry flavor and some cereal notes in the finish. Very clean and crisp. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle sample at Beoir Go Leoir. Earthy musty sweet raspberry malt aroma. Cloudy deep rose with a small white head. Earthy sweet raspberry malt flavor. Medium body, soft carbonation.

Draft to taster at the Eccentric Cafe. Looks good for the style; a transparent reddish-orange with white lacing. Smells of raspberries and wheat. Tastes like it smells with an average mouthfeel. Alright.

Batch K10357, Bottle 187 ; Pour is murky gold with pink highlights ; the bottle popped, revealing a bit of over carbonation here. The white head with slight pink highlighting is average initial, retains on the modest side, and there is some light lacing present. The nose is raspberry jam, seeds, caramel malts really ; I thought this one came across as a really nice drinker, and one of the better fruit beers I had, in spite of the fact that the base beer is on the boring side. Raspberry comes through in a natural , non artificial way here, and this brew drinks clean and bright, with more raspberry jam, mild tart, medium sweet, caramel, bread, and light bitter - I enjoyed it.

Bottled, 500ml from Asda, Leamington Spa. Deep amber with white head. Hacking away through some old and dusty bottles, this was a pleasant reminder of happy times with Ridleys brewery. I couldnâ€™t make out the BBE, but it had to be 4 or 5 years since I bought it. Decent caramel malt, some roasty then sweet notes, toffee. Little sign of the hop though, but there is a sharpness to the finish. Reasonable.

Nice head, quickly disappearing but leaves a good lace. I drink this one in April 2005, 8 months after the best before date. The color is amber and the aroma is malty. The flavour is initially sweet and malty but then comes floral notes and a moderate bitterness along. In the finish is has notes of roasted malt and a fairly OK bitterness.

A mid, golden amber beer with a thick white head. The nose is clean and distinctly malty in the beginning, this is then followed by a slightly sweet, floral hop aroma. The taste is dry on the palette, the hop element being the more predominant. This is underlined by a malty touch that leaves a balanced flavour in the aftertaste. (Bottle - purchased from the Beers of Europe, Setchey, Norfolk before the G.K. closure).
Clear and golden with a small white head. Floral hoppy aroma and malty taste with a medium bitter finish. Still on sale in Asda, but within a couple of weeks of best-by date.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Malty, florel, hay aroma and a sweet dry malty taste. Medium body and a sweet finish.
Bottled. Clear golden coloured with a small white head. Aroma of malts, grape fruit, pine needles and hops. Flavour of hops, fruits and pine needles.
Bottle. Amber beer with dry, hopped and fruity aroma. The flavour is well hopped and caramel. Overall a good beer.

(Bottle 50 cl) Fully golden or light amber, clear with a limited head. Focus in this beer is the amazing Challenger hops leaving a beautiful flowery aroma, but not much bitterness. Light sweetness in the palate. Another fine example of a light ale with lots of flavour. 101204
Bitter and hoppy with a trace of citrus.Very pleasant mouthfeel with a lingering bitter aftertaste.A pleasant beer.
Pasturised and/or filtered bottle from Asda, High Wycombe, Bucks. Average bottled bitter. Nothing special, seriously cheap (99p), though.

column1: Flossmoor Station Station Master Wheat Ale
column5: Wheat and other grain malts, light bitter. Slightly hazy gold, medium, creamy, white head. Light bitter. Intense grain and cereal malts, soft carbonation. Decent Wheat Ale, well-balanced. Keg at brewery, Flossmore, IL.

column1: Flossmoor Station Station Master Wheat Ale
column5: [Tap] Light orange in color with a light haze to it. Citrus and floral hop aroma. Not much wheat in the nose. Flavors of bready malts, citrus, grass and hops. Dry. Moderately bitter, but seems like the hop flavors were a little harsh in this beer.

column1: Flossmoor Station Station Master Wheat Ale
column5: Tap. Pours lightly hazy golden, small white creamy head, great lacing. Aroma is wheat, cardboard. Flavor is the same, light sweet, medium bitter, harsh bitter finish that is totally out of place for this beer. Light body. Meh 5, 6, 5, 3, 10

column1: Flossmoor Station Station Master Wheat Ale
column5: A light wheat beer. Pretty average with your typical aroma and flavor profile. Orange, citrus, lemon, wheat.

column1: Flossmoor Station Station Master Wheat Ale
column5: Sampled at the brewpub and took a bottle home. It poured a cloudy yellow color with a white head. The aroma was yeasty with hints of spices and a little banana. The taste was lots of banana and spices, but a little too watery to be great. On draft was better than the bottled version.

column1: Flossmoor Station Station Master Wheat Ale
column5: Aroma is yeast, light bubble gum, citrus and a hint of wheat malt. The flavor is citrus, an undercurrent of berries, malts, wheat notes and a mix of tart and mild bitterness in the finish.

column1: Flossmoor Station Station Master Wheat Ale
column5: A cloudy, yellow-orange pour with a frothy white head. The aroma has earthy wheat with a mild orange zest. It has a light, crisp texture with a sweet taste and lively carbonation.

column1: Flossmoor Station Station Master Wheat Ale
column5: A solid Ameican light pale wheat ale. Spicy hops, light yeastiness. Just an easy drinker.

column1: Flossmoor Station Station Master Wheat Ale
column5: 22 oz bottle pours a hazy golden/orange color with decent white head and clumps of lacing. Aroma is not very memorable: some honey, wheat, and cloves. Taste is slightly sweet and grainy with a little drier finish. Body is light to medium. I had higher hopes for this one, and wonâ€™t bother again.

column1: Flossmoor Station Station Master Wheat Ale
column5: 22oz bottle-thanks jtclockwork for sharing-thin offwhite-cloudy/murky gold/brown. A-spice, lt fruit, med malt. T-perfumy/spice hop, lt fruit, med malt.

column1: Flossmoor Station Gandy Dancer Honey Ale
column5: Grain bread malts, honey, caramel, molasses. Slightly hazy, dark gold. Light sweet. Citrus fruits, grain and bread malts, caramel, honey, soft carbonation. Very nice. Keg at brewery, Flossmore, IL.

column1: Flossmoor Station Gandy Dancer Honey Ale
column5: (bottle) hazy ruby-amber colour with a couple of tiny floaties and a frothy light-beige head. aroma of caramel and chestnut honey, heavily phenolic and leathery, with lots of vanilla and touch of cherry stones. flavour is mostly orange peel and pear, with some more caramel, clear honey, bubble gum and quite a bit of alcohol in the semi-tart finish. medium-bodied with lively carbonation.

column1: Flossmoor Station Gandy Dancer Honey Ale
column5: Sampled at GABF 2014. Pours a light body wiht white lacing. Aroma is spice, light sweet honey and malt. Mouthfeel is soft and carbonated with notes of honey, apple, lemon, malt, light grain and sweet vanilla.

column1: Flossmoor Station Gandy Dancer Honey Ale
column5: [Tap] Deep orange color without much head, but with nice looking lacing. Aroma of rye bread, honey and caramel malts. Tasting notes include honey malts, white pepper, mild resinous hops and dry grains. Average palate. Not bad.

column1: Flossmoor Station Gandy Dancer Honey Ale
column5: Golden orange appearance with a tan head. Pretty spicy, floral herbal, honey, orange citrus aroma. Carbonation is a bit dull. Caramel, toasted, sweet nectar, honey flavor. Not all that bad but kind of one dimensional.

column1: Flossmoor Station Gandy Dancer Honey Ale
column5: Pour is clear red pour with white head, aroma brought notes of honey, earth, lemon, caramel, sugar, hints of spice, rye, slight lemongrass notes in there as well. Taste is a mix of slight honey, earth, grain, spice, rye, yeast, some sugary notes into caramel, toffee, finishing fairly sweet, more honey.

column1: Flossmoor Station Gandy Dancer Honey Ale
column5: Tap. Pours clear amber, medium off white head, good lacing. Aroma is caramel, nutty, dark bread. Flavor is light sweet, very light bitter, a touch of rye spiciness. Uncomplex. Medium body.

column1: Flossmoor Station Gandy Dancer Honey Ale
column5: A lot of honey in this beer. A light body with a sweet flavor and good honey profile. Kind of interesting in that regard.

column1: Flossmoor Station Gandy Dancer Honey Ale
column5: Sampled at the brewpub. It poured a clear golden/orange color with an off-white head. The aroma was predominantly of flowery hops. The taste was similar. It had a medium body without much hop bitterness. Nicely done.

column1: Flossmoor Station Gandy Dancer Honey Ale
column5: Draft. Lemon and lactic malt aroma. Golden yellow with small head. Sweet light lemon and wheat malt flavor. Decent.

column1: Flossmoor Station Chessie Cherry Wheat Ale
column5: Taste: tart sour, raspberry, cherry, strawberry, white wine notes. tangy fermented fruit and yeast nose. Amber, mostly, clear, pinkish hue to large head with ring lace. Medium body.

column1: Flossmoor Station Chessie Cherry Wheat Ale
column5: Intense red fruits, raspberries, red currant, sweet grain and bread malts. Hazy, dark brown, small, creamy white head. Medium sweet. Very fruity, red fruits and raspberries again, soft carbonation. Very nice Fruit Beer, great raspberries in aroma and palate. Keg at brewery, Flossmoor, IL.

column1: Flossmoor Station Chessie Cherry Wheat Ale
column5: Tap at brewery. Very hazy deep amber. Lightly sweet with mild cherry. Needs more flavor.

column1: Flossmoor Station Chessie Cherry Wheat Ale
column5: Draft. Lactic sour cherry malt aroma. Golden yellow with small head. Sweet cherry and lactic malt flavor. Pretty good.

column1: Flossmoor Station Chessie Cherry Wheat Ale
column5: Draft @ brewery. LIght cherry aroma. Cloudy amber with a small off-white head. Sweet cherry and light wheat flavor. Medium, slightly sticky body, soft - almost flat - carbonation.

column1: Flossmoor Station Chessie Cherry Wheat Ale
