Nose involves toasted malt, woody hops, and some light roasted coffee. Lightly sweet, somewhat bitter. Light, airy body, creamy texture, soft carb, with a toasty toward dry finish. Another damn near perfect session brew that I wish was on draft in the north part of the state on occasion. Thanks Broad Ripple for having this as a guest tap.
Draft sampler pours cooper with a off white head. Aroma of malts and grains. Taste is malts, grain and some bitterness.
Brown pour. Smoky, but nothing else Not bad, but nothing to look for. Looking for 75 characters.
Not one of the better NABC beers. No aroma and tastes a little flat. Still drinkable at the flea.
Malty aroma with a little bit of cocoa. Malt forward flavor. Medium body. Not too complex but a decent beer.

5 oz sample draft at the New Albanian Pizzeria and Public House in New Albany, Indiana. The pour is a darker copper golden with a smallish off white head. The aroma is roast, nuttiness, grass and a bit pine. Nice soft, full, natural nose. The taste has all of the elements of the nose balanced and integrated nicely together. Lightly sweet, nutty, grassy pine, and soft roast to the finish. Fresh, a bunch of character for a mild. The palate has great body, light, easy drinking. Fresh, clean and really tasty. Great mild - highlight of the night.
Bottled. Reddish brown coloured. Quite spicy aroma and flavour. Very nice and rather sharp herbal bitterness in the flavour.

(Bottle 30 cl) Muddy, dark orangey golden. rather neat off-white head. Pronounced acidity as with otther strong Dutch beers. Diacetyl and a lot of yeasty esters, without being unpleasant. Dry bitterness and very warming alcohol. OK but not overly refined. 050405
Bitter special. Bitter. The first couples of zips are nice, but afterwards it gets sickening. Quite brutal beer.

The aroma is very spicy with noticable cowberries. The color is a hazy red and it has a beutiful beige head though collapsing. The flavor is lovely; spicy and sweet. A nice beer. I wonder what went wrong with the beers the first four samplers have had.

First of all: appearance. Let's have a look at the bottle instead of the beer. A copied label, which is hardly readible, because of being copy #345. The beer itself pours a cloudy orange brown color, with a short frothy head, not the nicest of appearances. The aroma is of metallic malts, yeast and alcohol. It resembles my first homebrew project, which did not turn out too well. I can taste sweet malts, alcohol is quite well hidden, nice biologic solution Joris. The palate is thick, sticky, alcoholic. If anyone sees this in stores, leave it there. It's not worth the try.
Lactic and spices aroma. Cloudy, orange/brown color, off-white head, fair lace. Lactic but this is covered by all the spices, light sweet, light bitter, alcohol well hidden, medium body.

Explosive gushing, spewing forth the meanest grey-brown blobs of yeast (I hope!) I ever saw in such a small bottle. Stupendous yellow-brown head, full of... I wish I knew what speckles - then again, maybe rather not... Dark red-brown beer. Nose: lactic acid, phenoles, spices, flowery notes, cidery. Taste: vinous, but with a cloying-sweetish taint under the aggressive tarty-spiced malts. God, this is UNBELIEVABLE. Palate: thick. Ruined. The alcohol is partly consumed by the pediococci, I presume, who are now having a ball. This is third-in-a-row, it's getting obvious: these guys are amateurs, and ought not to sell before they get their act right.
Aroma has glue. Yeasty taste with glue, cream, chewing gum and alcohol. Hints of roasted malt. Full bodied beer, but too amateuristic to make a real impression.
Troebele oranje bruine kleur met een goede kraag. Ruikt zoetig, fruitig, kruiden, mout. Smaakt fris, zoetig, suiker. Veel koolzuur.

@Burg bieren, wazig amber met schuimige witte kraag. aroma komt niet erg binnen, of het wordt overruled door de BBQ die ik net aangestoken had. wat wel te herkennen was waren tonen van citrus, bloemen, mout en zoetigheid. smaken zijn redelijk zoet, zwak bitter, zwak fruitig , aardse mouten, koriander, tarwe, zwakke body, dun en glad van textuur, lage co2, maar al met al krijg ik er niet een echt witbier ervaring bij.

Draught @ Burg bieren. Opaque orange color, small white head. Smell and taste malts, lightly sweet, some caramel surprisingly. Dry finish, a bit watery texture, low to average body and average carbonation.

From previous rating it appears this beer fluctuates a bit. I found the appearance does not resemble a classic wheat (wit) beer. It poured amber with good white head but very little wheat present. Scent is typical â€™earthyâ€™ Belgian wheat and similar to â€™t Ij Wit. Flavour is quite clean for a wit, not very citrussy but pleasant. Label mentions elderflower but struggle to detect that. Overall a pleasant witbeer, but not memorable.

Dark yellow/orange with an even head. Brew is interesting but not yet fully developed. The fruits give a good tart sourness to it, the aftertaste is yet somehow dissappointing. Bottle from Burg Bieren Ermelo.

Bottle, courtesy of fonefan. A clear, golden beer with some floaties and a small, off-white to white head. Not entirely clean aroma, some milky unpleasant notes blend with lemon, spice notes and cellar hints. The flavor isnâ€™t much better, worse actually. Medium body, dead and papery. It ends like the initial flavor, far from good. Wonâ€™t miss this one. 110128

bottle, kindly donated by Bierkoning - bedankt! Hazy golden yellow, fizzy white head. Rather full-bodied for the style, sweet malty base with spices and hints of lemon/lime zest. Very nice, a tasty example of the style. Refreshing and tasty!

Bottle 300ml. Unclear medium orange yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting to diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, wheat, moderate yeasty, leather, soap, coriander. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration,fruity, citrus, vegetables. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20110128]
Bottle 330ml @ fonefan Pours cloudy golden with a white head. Aroma and taste was kind of off.
Bottle @ Ulfborg Weekend, Jan 2011. Pours unclear golden with a small white head. Nose is yeasty and spicy. Coriander and wheat. Tart fruity. Medium to thin body. Dry and short end.

bottle. Deep amber brown with small head. Substantial malt body, caramel and toffee and huge amount of spicing. Slightly boozy. Super weird and hard to drink. This might be someone's cup of tea, but definitely not mine.

Pours a brown color with a thin white head. Aroma is dominated by spices, such as cinnamon, nutmeg, and clove, as well as yeasty bubblegum and caramel malts. Flavor is caramel and toffee, bubblegum, and the spices. Well-carbonated with a light body. Perhaps a touch heavy on the spices, but overall rather good.
On tap at Dragonmead. Pours clear amber with a white head. Ginger in the aroma. Flavors of ginger, spruce, and toasty malt. Nice.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 11/6/2014. Pours hazy deep ruby red/brown color with a 2 finger dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a light amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big caramel, brown sugar, toast, light chocolate, raisin, plum, cinnamon, nutmeg, clove, ginger, orange peel, wood, and herbal/spice earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/bready malt, spices, and fruity yeast notes; with good strength. Taste of big caramel, brown sugar, toast, light chocolate, raisin, plum, cinnamon, nutmeg, clove, ginger, orange peel, wood, and herbal/spice earthiness. Light spice bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, brown sugar, toast, light chocolate, raisin, plum, cinnamon, nutmeg, clove, ginger, orange peel, and herbal/spice earthiness on the finish for a while. Damn nice robustness and complexity of dark/bready malt, spices, and fruity yeast flavors; with a great malt/spice balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth and lightly creamy/bready/chalky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a damn nice spiced dark ale style. All around good balance, robustness, and complexity of dark/bready malt, spices, and fruity yeast flavors; and very smooth to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

An aroma of lemon peel, clove, and celery. An appearance is dark copper. Taste is Christmas spicy with orange peel, clove and some lightly roasted malt. Palate is very fizzy, almost "burns" your mouth. Overall, interesting, Christmasy, unique, and fun to drink when wanting to change things up.
On tap at brewery. No head. Dark redbrown. Smells and tastes like Scandinavia (a.k.a Ikea). Notes of orange peel, allspice? Maybe some nutmeg. Easy drinking. Nice!

On tap at the Dragonmead Brew Pub. Poured a deeper brown color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of lots of spices - nutmeg, ginger and cloves. Some cinnamon as well. Tastes of the same spices. This one was all about the spices which drowned out anything else.

I am a fan of Scandanavian style beers, a good variation onthe Belgians spiced and dark. This was brown with some lace. Like a barleywine and old ale. Didnâ€™t get that much of spice, but there is clove and ginger and cardommon thrown together. Enjoyed at the brewpub. Carbonation and mouthfeel they got right.

Tap at brewpub. Pours a clear rusty, coppery color with a small of white head. Aroma is spice, nutmeg, clove, ginger. Flavor is spicy too, pepper, cinnamon, ginger, cardamon, clove. Palate is smooth and medium bodied. Nice holiday brew. Worked for me!
Tap: dark red/mahogany in color. Nice spice aroma of nutmeg/clove/cinnamon. Strong spiced ale taste. Smooth crisp body. Very good winter drink, just canâ€™t drink more than one though.

Sampled from the tap at the brewery. Pours black with a dark brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has dark grains, roasted malts and a light vegetal note. Flavor has dark grains, roasted malts with a bit of bitter chocolate backing.

Keg @ Dragonmead. Deep brown with a small head. Sort of acrid burnt chocolate malt on the nose. Some general charred grain. Some pine. Big boned stuff. Oily and thick. Peppery hop. Some acidic char. Chocolate malt. Caramel. Full bodied, very oily.

Taps opaque coffee with a nice tan head. Aroma presents quality coffee, roast malt, molasses, and subtle chocolate and licorice tones. Flavor echoes the aroma while addinadding a note of woody hops. Mouthfeel features body that is thin for a RIS, but fizz is lively and finish is like a quality mocha. Hammer that sickle.

Majority of 6 oz. pour, on tap at the breweryâ€™s taproom in Warren, Michigan. Consumed on 9-26-16. Dark brown, light in color for style. Small amount of light tan head. Nice chocolate and lightly to moderately roasted malt aroma. Malty flavor. Chocolate start and roasted finish. Quite pleasant. Lively in the palate. Medium body, light for the style. Not a great imperial stout, but a good non-imperial stout, which, by contemporary standards, is what this is.
Notes from summer. Pours black. Aroma and taste roasted malts, coffee, and some licorice.

Pour on tap at the brewery, thick brownish black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of dark chocolate, roast, hints of chewy dark fruits into a bit of coffee, slight caramel into a bit of grassy hops. Taste is a mix of dark fruit, toffee, caramel, some roast, coffee, nice dark cocoa, finishing fairly sweet, slightly bitter.
Growler pour. Pours black with a brown head. Roasty cocoa aroma, creamy, with a touch of anise. Cocoa roasty coffee flavor, a bit smoky. Not all that complex, but pretty good.

Tap @ Dragonmead: Black-hole black with just about no head. Roasted malts, burnt coffee beans, mild licorice, bittersweet cocoa, and some residual sweetness in the aroma. Malty bomb with lots of coffee bean, anise, licorice, and chocolatey sweet flavors on the palate. Slight ashy and leafy in the finish, mildly bitter from the intense roast. Oily, not as thick as I want it to be. A "safe" RIS. Not bad, though.

On tap at Dragonmead Brewpub. Midnight brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and some sweet chocolate and licorice underneath. Taste of dark-roasted malts, chocolate, mild coffee and mild alcohol. Semi-chalky on the finish.

Sample at the brewpub. Pours brownish-black with a medium beige head that dissipates steadily to a film. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and molasses. Medium body with a roasty character of malt and coffee. Notes of mild hops and brown sugar in the background. The finish is charred malt and coffee. Decent, albeit lighter Imperial Stout overall.

Taps opaque dark chocolate with a nice tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma delivers roast malt, oatmeal, coffee and subtle chocolate notes. Flavor offers quality coffee, roast malt, oatmeal, molasses and chocolate for a very drinkable stout. Mouthfeel features good body and fair fizz. Revere it.

Pour on tap at the brewery, dark brownish black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of cocoa powder, dark fruit, hints of chocolate, coffee, some nice lactose into a bit of earthy spice. Taste is a mix of cocoa powder, roast, coffee, some lactose into a bit of oaty, grainy notes, touch of yeast, finishing bitter, dry. Nice.

From notes. Finally getting around to adding beers from the Ypsi Summer Beerfest! Enjoyed on July 25. The pour is a nice light black with a decent dark khaki head ans some light lacing as it recedes. The aroma is heavy on the roasted malt. There is a nice chocolate bit and itâ€™s definitely got some good oat qualities. The flavor is much of the same. Much more oaty than I was expecting. The roast on it is really good. I love the bitter chocolate, but this is definitely an oatmeal stout. The mouth feel is very creamy with a nice carbonation and a lingeringly dry roasty aftertaste. Definitely a solid brew.

Had on-tap at Dragonmead. Appearance: Well, what is there to say? Thick, creamy-as-hell tan head that stays on top of the beer. Thick wall of lacing. One of the best beers Iâ€™ve had, visually. Dat nitro-tap! Smell: Hm. Yeah, thatâ€™s nice. Light, but pleasant. Coffee and toffee/caramel sort of aromas are there though. Whatâ€™s there is really good. Taste/feel: Taste is much like the smell. Coffee, toffee/caramel. Basic. Light. Easy drinking. The obvious comparison is Foundersâ€™ Oatmeal Stout. Thatâ€™s a better beer, but not by too much. Simply put, that beer just has a bit more flavor. The look and feel of this one though are excellent. A well-made Oatmeal Stout. Iâ€™d like some more flavor, but what IS in here is tasty. Iâ€™d have it again for sure.

On nitrogen. A nice roast malt and cigar tobacco aroma. Appearance is nearly black dark brown with a thick and creamy milk chocolate head with thick, opulant curtains. Taste is roast malt, bitter leather, and sweet tobacco. palate is spot on for a stout, creamy, thick, not syrupy or fizzy, a rare perfect palate. Overall, an amazing stout when on nitro, donâ€™t miss this!

Nitro at brewery. Beautiful pour of dark black with great, lingering tan head. Mild aroma of burnt malt. Very creamy mouthfeel of charred malt, mild coffee, tobacco, light smoke. I donâ€™t generally like DMâ€™s stouts, but this is super solid.

Tap: Very black color, completely opaque with a fuzzy, dark-khaki colored head. Aroma consists of roasted malts with maybe a touch of smoked malt, too; oats and grains abound, along with a hint of woodiness and a slight mocha-java vibe. The taste has a good dose of roasted malts with a burnt and slightly smokey profile. Dark coffee beans, bitter chocolate, and heavy, heavy oats. The oat flavor is explosive. Dry, rustic oats coat the palate, also giving plenty of almost wheaty, grainy flavor. No much hoppage; bitterness comes from the roast. Very creamy, nice carbonation.

Draft at brewery, nitro. Aroma is mostly malt. Taste is smooth as most nitros are. The taste is kinda bland though. A little disappointed a I was looking forward to it. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft. Poured dark brown color with medium brown creamy head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Medium roasted coffee and chocolate aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Medium roasted flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

Sample at the brewpub. Pours flat black with a medium creamy beige head that diminishes slowly. Patchy lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Light to medium body with a roasty character and flavors of malt, coffee and dark chocolate. The finish is sweet with a toasted malt aftertaste, Decent overall.
Amber colored. Has a sweet aroma like brown sugar. The combination of spices gives this a mildly sweet flavor. Tasty, though I wish there was just a little more to it.

Had both on cask and standard. Cask is a opaque, milky brown with a more vegetable quality to the pumpkin flavor. Normal is an orangey-amber with a much brighter malt character, and pumpkin spice character shines through more.
On at at the Dragonmead Brewery. Poured a medium amber color with a small sized head. Aromas and tastes of pumpkins and spices. Not overly spiced nor not overly pumpkin.

medium brown large white head. moderate carbonation. a little bitterness up front followed by somewhat indiscernable spices, that arenâ€™t immediately identified as traditional pumpkin pie spices. the spice lies in the background, without much else to the beer. flawed recipe

On tap at Dragonmead. Mostly clear orange body, medium light tan head. Typical pumpkin pie spice aroma, with nutmeg, cinnamon, etc. slightly thin, cinnamon body with nutmeg and light bready notes and an earthy, rather chalky finish. Somewhat thin. Nothing special, Iâ€™m afraid.
Pours a medium amber with white head. good lacing. Tastes and smells a bit spicy with hints of pumpkin.decent brew

On tap at the brewery. Orange amber color with a foamy beige head and a big nose of pumpkin pie spice. The smell reminded me of momâ€™s pumpkin cookies. Taste of cininmon, clove, pie spice and a white sugar sweetness. Palate is so dry you can almost taste the powder of the spices. A little light in body, and not enough beer here to support the spices. But I still like this style for an Autumn treat.
Tap: Pours amber with little head. Aroma was spiced pumpkin pie almost like the yankee candle. Little pumpkin flavor and really strong spice. Overall very smooth pumpkin ale.

On tap: Spice and light pumpkin in the aroma. Transparent amber with a small white head. Light spice in the fron with light pumpkin. Spice reallh comes on in the finish and becomes the dominate flavor.
Wonderful smell... outside lambics, this is the best smelling beer I have had. The flavor, like most fruit beers, does not do it justice, but it is not bad.

En fÃ»t. Verre de dÃ©gustation directement Ã  la brasserie. ArÃ´me: LÃ©gÃ¨re odeur de cÃ©rÃ©ale. Apparence: La couleur est blonde avec une trÃ¨s faible densitÃ© de bulle. PrÃ©sence dâ€™un mince col mousseux et dâ€™une large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: LÃ©ger goÃ»t de cÃ©rÃ©ale avec une pointe fruitÃ©e. DurÃ©e moyenne de lâ€™arriÃ¨re goÃ»t. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture lÃ©gÃ¨rement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. ArriÃ¨re goÃ»t lÃ©gÃ¨rement fruitÃ©. (Rating #5161)
Pours straw/gold with a thin fizzy white head. Smells grassy and sweet with some perfumy hints. Tastes sweet and skunky with some earthiness on the finish.

bottle poured a light amber color with a thin white head. aroma has sweet malt, light grains, and faint spice. flavor is sweet, pale malts, and some lingering hops poking around. saw this on the shelf at a local store and had to buy the last bottle I would probably see from these guys.

Bottle... Cloudy golden lager with a small, creamy, white head. Decent retention. The aroma is a refreshing, down-home blend of cookie, biscuit, pale grain and warm mash notes. Medium-bodied with lively carbonation. Nice, toasty, biscuity flavor. A touch sweet, but refreshing nonetheless. Coarse, snappy, dry finish. Iâ€™m not much of a lager guy, but Iâ€™m digginâ€™ this one. Bottle courtesy of beer bill!
Pours gold into a shaker. Fluffy bright white head leaves spots lacing as it slowly recedes. Dusty plum and malt aromas. Sour, bitter and unpleasant.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a mostly clear gold with a thin white head that faded into a scummy looking film after the first sip and left no lace. Faint aroma of malt and grassy hops. The flavor is a little bit better with a bit of malt up front followed by some grassy hops. Mildly bitter at the finish. This is not an offensive beer, but it certainly is a boring one.
Pretty good lager. Smooth with a nice malty sweetness and perfectly balanced spicy hop bitterness. Appears to be unfiltered. Fairly straightforward stuff, but enjoyable nonetheless. 12oz. bottle.

12oz bottle. Poured a medium and hazy amber color with a small sized head. Aromas of toasted malts, grains, honey comb, and lightly bready. Tastes of toasted grains, bready, and had a grassy finish. Not bad for a pale lager.

(bottle - 12 oz) Straw gold in color with a fizzy white head. Aroma is a light and balanced mixture of sweet malts, dry grass, hops, and honey. Flavor has a strong hop presence that gives way to a smooth and malty middle and a crisp and slightly hoppy, bitter finish. Thin-bodied.

A Decent Lager. Pours with a good inch of head that becomes lathered. Aroma is balanced, if a little understated. Mouthfeel is good and flavor is a little bitter but overall balanced by the hops. Easy drinking and overall enjoyable.

Caramel, malt, brown sugar, dried fruits and a hint of spices in the aroma. Brown with a tan head. Medium sweet and light to medium bitter. Medium body with a average carbonation. Overall not to bad, but utterly boring
From bottle 03.02.15. Slightly hazy dark orange to brown. Beige head and lacing. Aroma of sour caramel and butterscotch. Similar taste, with a hint of prunes. Waterish mouthfeel.
Klart, mÃ¸rkt rÃ¸dbrunt med lysbrunt skum. Lukter svisker og julekrydder. Smak av rosiner og marsipan. Litt vannaktig ettersmak.
From bottle. Reddish brown colour. Aromas of malt and plastic. Sweet malty taste with nasty synthetic tang.

Flaske delt med Willy: klar mÃ¸rk rubin med flott skum som varer til bunns. Lite aroma, men myk og god smak preget av mÃ¸rk karamellsÃ¸dme og delikate kryddertoner. Slank naturligvis ettersom det er butikkÃ¸l, men allikevel en overraskende god juleÃ¸lopplevelse. Skal kjÃ¸pe noen av denne. Den beste jeg har smak fra Grans.
Klar mÃ¸rk brun farve med beige skum. Lukt av malt, karamell, frukt og krydder. Smak av malt, karamell, frukt og krydder. Lett bittersÃ¸t karamellavslutning. Lavt karbonert. Rema.

Bottle from my local Rema 1000. Pours almost clear deep ruby with a huge frothy off-white head. Sweet aroma of caramel and butterscotch. Taste is watery with a very strong sweet butterscotch, overwhelmingly so. Drainpour.
RÃ¸dbrun klar med beige skum. Malt og karamell. SÃ¸t og lett bitter smak. Kort ettersmak, medium kullsyre. Tick 1000
MÃ¸rk brun med lys beige skum. Aroma av karamell og moden stenfrukt. Medium karbonert. Smaker desverre litt lite, men helt ok juleÃ¸l.
Fin duft av rosiner og krydder. MÃ¸rk fin kastanjebrun farge. Lite skum, litt langs kant. Smak av rosin, krydder og en anelse appelsin.

Smell- weak, smoke, roast, weak hops. Foam-thin, soft, hops, medium biting bitterness. Roast. Medium size, gray, white foam. Appearance-Almost dark, brown color, clear, some carbonation. Taste- roast, bitterness in aftertaste, some caramel. Not really my style, but drinkable.

chocolate, coffee, nuts, toast, roasty, bread, hay, cereal, caramel, resin, floral, grass, spruce, barnyard, pale, golden, amber, orange, red, brown, black, cloudy, sparkling, minimal head, white foam, tan foam, brown foam,

Butelka pite w domu. Kolor ciemny klarowny, piana Å›rednipÄ™cherzykowata trzyma siÄ™ dzielnie. Aromat polone sÅ‚ody, karmel niezbyt mocny, trochÄ™ droÅ¼dÅ¼owe, raczej wytrawne i bez nachalnego karmelu, dobre piwo.

Aroma; roasted malts, dark fruit, raisin, prune in a toffee caramel dice. Look; beige film, clear black ruby'ish body. Taste; dark plum, malts, roasted malts, dark fruity malt, n rum - and finishes sweet fruity plummy rummy. Feel; soft n nice to palate. Overall; good soft sweet tasty schwarz. [swingtop-bt.50cl abv4.9% xp01.12.17 Tasted@Thanxbeeringparty @PivotekaH7] 6474'15

500ml swing-top bottle kindly shared by djoeye. Fawn-coloured head to a clear dark brown coloured body. Spotty lacing. Dark malty nose, slightly roasted. Blended taste profile of dark dough, liquorice and prunes. Mid-sweet, roasted malt-driven finish. Clean on the swallow. Like it. (Shared with Finn and djoeye, Thanxbeeringparty at PivotekaH7, TromsÃ¸ 23.11.2017).

Flaske 500ml spandert av djoeye. Delt med ham og Rune pÃ¥ Thanxbeeringparty 23 Nov 17. Svart. Lavt skum med litt farge. Litt lacing. Lett & god fruktaroma. Smaken plommer & svisker. Litt rom i avslutninga.
Swing top botella. Farbe: dark brÃºn. HÃ¶vd: media, short lasting. Sweet like soft roastish nÃ¶s. Sweet like sabor con malta birn toastada pero algo thin, Ewatery brew. Too thin. Poor Schwartz...

Bottled. 40cl sample. The aroma has light roast, caramel toffee, bit grass. Clear, dark coloured beer with a medium sized off-white head. The taste is light bitter and has toffee sweetness, light roast. Easy-going beer.

Copenhagen 16/5 2017. 50 cl bottle with swing cap from Kvickly. Very German label with a little Shield, lions and tools for Beer making and assurance that this is a "Feines Schwares". Pours Dark Reddish brown with white head. Settles as 0,5 cm thick layer of foam. No lacing. Aroma is a little metallic without being unpleasant. Sweet caramel and light roastiness. Soft carbonation and slightly thick palate. Flavor is sweet without being cloying. Followed by medium sweetness. Aftertaste is sweet caramel and burnt sugar. Indeed a "Fines Schwarzes" without being decadent or original.
Bottle @ home. Aroma of straw malt and light caramel. Clear brown with off-white head. Taste is light- sweet and light bitter. Light body, watery feel and light malt finish.

Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a black color with a large foamy dark tan head that lingered and left minimal lacing. The aroma was dryish with coffee, wood and smoke. The flavor was semi dry with wood, brewed coffee, a bit of roasty malts, cream and a hint of smoke. Long finish. Moderately full bodied and smooth. Fairly well made but not my style.

Bottle courtesy of Zach at Andyâ€™s New Yearâ€™s Par-tay! Pours a deep black with a fairly large dense mocha head. Roast and plum and sweet cocoa. Medium bodied, cocoa and chocolate. A bit of oxidization, cocoa and plum. Long roast and bitterness into the finish. Dusty bitter chocolate on the finish.

Opaque black pour with a tall, creamy, long lasting tan head. Coffee, cocoa, dark roast malts in the aroma. Sweet and roasty flavor. Some licorice in the finish. Bitterness is minimal. Smooth body, creamy.
I pronounce this a pretty good stout! Dense black and frothy head. Aromas of chocolate, dark fruit and roasted malt. The taste mirrors the nose. It is a meal unto itself!

22oz bottle pours a watery, opaque black with some clumping beige head. Nose is chalky, dark chocolate. Flavor of chocolate, malts, bread, more chalk. Medium bodied, chalky finish. Very heavy carbonation detracts from the experience as well.

pours black with a gigantic foamy tan head...excellent retention and lacing. aroma has some powdery cocoa, a wheaty, malty aroma like the aroma during sparging...faint hint of dark fruit...subtle milky sourness (the guy who rated this before me was spot on). flavor has coffee, dark fruit, and cocoa...roasty in the end. mouthfeel is super creamy and thick yet lively with a nice dry roasty finish...very nice beer!

22. Thanks, Mike! Pours jet black with a dense and rather fizzy burnt tan head. Not much lace. Big roasty dry nose, a little chalky and maybe a bit milk sour but not much. More on the dry english porter side of foreign stout and less on the hoppy side. Creamy medium body with soft carb. Roast, chalk, a bit of coffee, and some milky sourness on the mid palate. Mild chocolatey finish. Nice solid stout.

22 oz. bottle from Root Cellar in Cincinnati. I brought it to the Big Black Beer Bash 2011. Pours a deep, dark brown color with minimal visible carbonation and a tiny tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malts, some coffee, and earth- basic but really nice. Same goes for the flavor, featuring dark chocolate, roasted caramel malts, coffee, earth and some toast. Medium-bodied, with mild carbonation and a roasty mouthfeel. Nothing in particular stands out about this one, but thatâ€™s fine because itâ€™s just a well-done foreign stout.

Poured into a pint glass. 3.0 A: Black color. First pour was about 8-9 fingers of frothy head. This took forever to fill my glass up. Retention was reasonably good, but not any lacing. 4.0 S: Smells like thereâ€™s a lot of sourish lactose in here. Soft roastiness with even softer chocolate and molasses. Simple, but nice. 3.5 T: Again, seems like some lactose in here. Second strongest flavors are semi-sweet chocolate, roasted barley, and a touch of molasses. Relatively simple again, but not as nice as in the nose. 2.5 M: Lighter medium body. Way, way, way too much carbonation, but this doesnâ€™t surprise based on the pour. Itâ€™s BMC level carbonation and frankly distracted from my overall enjoyment of the beer. Too carbonated to be smooth. 3.0 D: Not a great beer, but not a bad one either...if the carbonation was fixed. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 06-26-2010 01:53:03

My Bottom Line: Roasted coffee beans and dark chocolate seem to be drowning in a picklish flavor which must be the result of a slowly developing infection. Further Personal Perceptions: -A creamy veil of foam tops the brownish black. -Expansive carbonation might also be a result of this rising infection. -The body was strangely thin. -This is the first time I get a bad Buckeye bottle. Their beers are so wonderful that this experience wonâ€™t stop me from getting more of their brews, if I can get some, that is... Bottle.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge Whiskey Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Sample at Extreme beer fest. 2002 version. Great nose, whiskey/coffee/prune/raisin. Clean black color, no light gets through. Bitter flavors, Same as nose. Thicker body, Oilt mouthfeel, Bitter roasted finish. This one lived up to the hype, a great brew.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge Whiskey Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: 1/5/05. Poured out of 12 oz. bottle, shared with TAR and cb on The Deluxe Tour 1/5/05. Deep brown in color with a silky appearance as it pours from the bottle. Definitely not black as it pours, but when it sits in the glass itâ€™s an opaque and oily black-brown with red glazes. Deep, dark golden brown head, almost crimson along the edges. Decent sized head with thin outline and solid, shimmering beady lacing-- a bit blotchy but sometimes cascading down the sides of the glass in a nice, slow crawl. Aroma has a deep and complex woody character and subtle, lovely dark maltiness that I really love, along with a touch of soy sauce that I really donâ€™t and a faint trace of sweet smoke. Flavor has big chocolate malt and dry roast, shades of vanilla bean with very little sweetness. Continues with excellent woody character and a surprisingly delicate (?!) whiskey undertone. Mostly the wood of whiskey barrel, not so much the forceful alcohol. Touches of dark mushroom, earthy black truffle, dark chocolate. Haunting oyster sauce traces in the aroma. A very delicious whiskey barrel stout, and an exceptionally rare treat from my generous friends. Thanks Emily and Jeff!

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge Whiskey Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: The beer as it emerges from the bottle a Jet Black color, the head is planetary in size, semi-creamy in texture, the color a toothsome light chocolate color as it evanesces the lace forms a satiny skirt to hide the glasses charms. â€œAh That Smellâ€, vanilla, sweet hints of bourbon, roasted grains, malt, molasses, a real compendium of the best â€œSmellsâ€ in â€œBeerdomâ€. Start is ambrosial, thick malt with the top chocolate fudge rich and thick, finish has a moderate acidity, and the hops are dynamic but pleasant, very dry and bittersweet aftertaste that lingers on the tongue. Nice belly warming sensation and a quite quaffable stout.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge Whiskey Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Thick edging of deep tan foam crowned the dark confection of slight bourbon goodness. I thought the hard liquor flavor was perfectly balanced with the malts. Not a palate-encasing, throat-drowning, explosion however. Noticed some caramel toasted almost to the burning point, along with some prune. Extremely smooth texture.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge Whiskey Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Dark plum with chestnut highlights. Creamy, mocha hued, tiny-bubbled foam. Luxurious aroma of fudge, cocoa, plum, black currant, dark rum, coconut, and butter. Rich caramel and lightly woody undertones. It's also estery and whiskey cask-ish, which collaborate to lend a vinous effect. Whiskey notes are subdued, thankfully, and enable its imperial stout components to shine. Velvety texture. Firm and toffeeish palate. Huge milk chocolate flavors followed by clean, minty alcohol and a late acidic burst. Whiskey notes remain in the background, but are clearly present. Touches of fruitcake and licorice, here and there. Finishes intensely fudge-like, with a coarse note of charcoal and afterthoughts whiskey casks, honeyed chocolate, and silky cappuccino. With a fuller body and aroma, this would precisely be what I seek in the style. Many thanks, Mitt!

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge Whiskey Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Chez Mittenstein - June 2003: Dark and slick in appearance with no carbonation. Smells burnt and sweet. Slow start to the taste which blossoms into a bitter whisky flavor. REALLY really nice. Get some if you can.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge Whiskey Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Wow, what a perfect mixed. Most barrel aged beers have too much of the barrel flavor and not enough of the beer flavor, not this one. This one is dark brown almost black with a moderate head for an Imperial stout. Thin bodied for an Imperial. Flavor is excellent. Vanilla, whiskey, coffee, burnt flavors they are all there, none so heavey as to edge out the others. This is what wood aging is all about and others should strive for. Finish is somewhat sweet, but delicous. Great Beer, Thanks go out to Mittenstein.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge Whiskey Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: This is some black liquid.Fizzy,head suprisingly leaves ring,and lace.My goodness,such a inticing aroma. Whiskey,vanilla,chocolate,wood,toffee,bread. Mouthfeel is so soft,creamy(as a oatmeal stout),and silky. Unbelievably,clean malt flavors,with roast,vanilla,and cookie/bread.The wood and whiskey were noticable before finish but this is masterfully balanced.Finish has some more vanilla,roast,and just slightly,noticable hop.Lingering coffee bean and whiskey.This could not be any better. It is just so clean,balanced and tasty itâ€™s hard to call others favorites.Iâ€™m blown away! On the other hand,I will never see this again. Many thanks MItt.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge Whiskey Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Strong notes of bourbon in the nose. Had a sizeable head on it. Flavor? Imagine some high-quality coffee, and then imagine pouring in a healthy dollop of (good) bourbon. It does complement the rest of the beer extremely well, setting off the sweeter chocolate and faint fruit flavors. Overall, a very good beer.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge Whiskey Barrel Imperial Stout
column5: Imperial Stout Blind Tasting (11-16-02): Visual: Small head. Aroma: nice bourbon, good dark malts. Flavor: more bourbon but not overpowering. The nicely balanced use of the bourbon creates perceived flavors of vanilla that blends nicely with the fruitiness and chocolate. Oh yeah.

On tap at Santorini in Eden Prairie. Pours dark amber/brown small head in plastic cup, classy. Not really any aroma hint of hops. Taste is bleak not much there really had to swish this around for any flavor, slight caramel and hops. Really a poor beer would get anything over this, although it might not be bad for getting drunk and hitting on suburban cougars.
On tap at Santorini Taverna and Grill in Eden Prairie. Dark copper in color. not much aroma. Lightly hopped with some malt. Odd taste that I could not quite put my finger on. Nothing special here.

Hopeful that this specially produced amber ale was a secret waiting to be discovered. Wrong. Over carbonation gives a feeling of champaign while the taste is off, either a weird barley or bad yeast. Wasnâ€™t going to enter it in here but saw an entry already exists. Not recommended.

Mildly surprised this beer had not been rated before. Santorini is contract brewed by Schell and, according to the bartender, has been in existence the entire 7+ years that the Minneapolis Greek restaurant from which it derives its name has been in business. The bartender felt that it tastes more like a Red Ale than an Amber, and although its reddish brown hue certainly is more characteristic of a Red, taste-wise I''m not sure I agree. Has a hint of hop bitterness with a pretty good dose of malt. There''s a little something off in the after-taste..perhaps yeast? Anyway, after giving it a try, I stuck with Redhook ESB the rest of the evening.
April, 2004. Golden ale with an off white head. Aroma of hops which was pleasant . Good balnce of hops and malts with grapÃªfruits. Good bodied.
(Draught) Nice head retention! Yellowish head with a golden body. Hi-C hopped notes in the nose. Highly hopped flavours with a slight tart finish. Very good!

Cascade grapefruitiness and diluted orange juice...Lasting citrusy bitterness which garnishes the totality of the back of the palate...As you have noticed, malt is not the story here, this is a comfortable American-style IPA, venerating the hop...
Big "C" hop aroma. Golden orane. Nice lacing. Lasting head. Strong bitterness without overwhelming. Some orange in the flavour. Decent body. On tap at TapNY festival.

Pours with an amber body topped by a thin white head that leaves decent lace. Sweet and citrusy hop aroma with a hint of berries and pretty good malt balance. Bitter sweet and citrusy hop flavor wtih a slight hint of beeries and an almost to bitter hoppy (is that possible?) finish. Medium bodied and relatively smooth.
very tasty IPA, somewhat bitter finish with hints of carmel and hops!.......
a very light kolsch, I believe this is a seasonal, somewhat plain, but not bad on a hot summer day.

01-Jan-14 (12-oz bottle: Obtained in trade with slob, thanks Bert!) Well, my last bottle of Pursuit of Happiness from this now-defunct brewery. The beer pours a hazy, dark-amber body with half an inch of off-white head that recedes to a ring. The nose is very malty like a Winter Warmer should be, with this one offering lots of caramel, toffee, dried fruit, and earth. On the palate, again, the malts are caramely, medium-sweet, and earthy, with toffee, decaying wood, some milk chocolate, dried apricot, and candied orange. Itâ€™s medium in weight, medium in carbonation, and very smooth and easy to drink. Overall, this has been a great beer over the years, and even at several years of age, itâ€™s still a great beer. Itâ€™s the kind of Winter Warmer I like most: no spices, no adjuncts, just straight up malty and delicious.
lots of barley but nothing too crazy, strong and smooth, goes down well, crystal malt, yum

Bottle, 2004, shared by ryan. Pours with little to no head, rusty light brown. Light citrus, spice, and raisins in the aroma. Bready, and a little cakey. Slight sweetness and some cinnamon. Lighter to medium body. Not bad.

Bottle, 2004, shared by ryan. Pours clear tawny with a small, fizzy beige head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (bread, caramel, toasted), average hops (floral, grassy), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of wood, alcohol, dates, and honey. Flavor is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toasted), average hops (floral, grassy, citrus), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of wood, alcohol, dates, and honey. Full body, medium warmth and carbonation, low creaminess with a dry finish.
2004 bottle courtesy of ryan, thank you sir! Murky dep amber color, lots of floaties. Aroma of scotch, caramel, light spice. Taste is very malty, on the sweet side, light spice. Decent.

Bottle. Pours an orange golden body with a white head and light lacing. Sweet with caramel and citrus malt tones. A bit sweet and light honey and citrus, candied sweetness and a light warming. A bit dull with a toasted malt undertone. Alright.

Wow. What a magnificent change from the norm of winter warmers! Pours a hazy particulate suspended burnt amber with fading khaki head. This one forgoes the nutmeg and spices in favor of a honey and citrus hop. Huge underlying caramel backbone lends excellent support. This is superbly well complemented, the hops and the malt, but not blended. Each side shines through. And the alcohol is hidden very well. Nice job guys. Iâ€™ll definitely pick this up next year!
bottle, pours light amber with a strong sweet hop nose. Super sweet bread, like sticky buns and light bitterness in the finish

Location: 12 oz bottle from Wine and Beer Westpark, 12/12/09 Aroma: The nose is rather hoppy and fruit, with some orange, apricot, and grapefruit along with toffee and caramel Appearance: Pours a somewhat clear copper-amber color with a thin white head that leaves a good amount of lace Flavor: Maltier then the nose, sweet citrus and malts dominate up-front, bitter backing leading to a good balance Palate: This beer is medium bodied with moderate carbonation, a nice, somewhat sticky mouthfeel, and a long finish Overall Impression: I live in MD, this beer is from MD, and I bought this one in VA? Well, sometimes it just works out that way. Iâ€™m pretty sure this isnâ€™t my first time drinking this one, but I didnâ€™t remember it well enough to know for sure. Smells almost like a nice IPA, doesnâ€™t really seem to have the spice components common in your usual winter warmer brew, but still a nice aroma. Taste is more balance, but still very nice. I canâ€™t say for sure how I would classify this, not really totally a winter warmer or an IPA, but somewhere in between, guess that is how it ended up in the ambiguous: "American Strong Ale." Also, Iâ€™m surprised to learn this one is over 8%, as it doesnâ€™t feel that way at all.

Lightly hoppy nose with a bit of spice and malt. Amber color with white head. Like a mildy hopped up amber with a touch of spice. The hops carry all the way through lingering at the end with an earthy/fruity finish. A decent winter warmer, Iâ€™d have another.
Light pale ale. Golden pour. Floral hops in the nose. Taste is grass and resin. Rated 8/17/04

Pale amber color with a fizzy white head. Light citrus and pine notes with some sweet malts. Some light citrus hops and malts in the flavor. Nothing really stands out, or makes this one stand out from the pack. Itâ€™s not bad but not something Iâ€™d search out again.
Pours a nice amber color with a thin head. Aroma is malt a little hops. Flavor is sweet caramel, a little hops bitterness. Passable session beer. Not great not terrible.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle. Appearance: Deep orange color with a large, frothy, off-white head. Good head retention and spotty lacing. Aroma: Citrus and spice on the hops side, a bit of caramel and bread from the malt. Flavor: Decent bready maltiness with a solid citrus and floral hop backbone. A decent spicy finish. Palate: Medium carbonation with a medium-light mouthfeel and a medium, spicy finish. Overall: Not a bad APA. It went well with the blue crabs I was eating. Take it or leave it.
Bottle, World Market, Charlottesville. Dead lead amber/brown with half inch of off-white head. Tangy aroma, some sourness, light caramel. Flavor is light citrus and nuts. OK, but nothing new here.
Pours a slightly hazy orange caramel with a small white head. Aroma of tangy citrus, hops and caramel. Taste of tangy citrus, bread dough and hops...it is what it is...
Nice pale ale that has lots of caramel to it. Easily as much malt character in this one as the hops, and it really tastes more like a hoppy brown than a pale. Very nice though, pleasantly surprised.

Draft at BWI. Pours a dark amber with an off white head. Faint caramel and fruity ester aroma. Light bodied, approaching medium with a British mouthfeel. Malty flavor of caramel, toffee, maple, and nuts countered by a moderate, but balancing spicy bitterness. Very simple and balanced, and much better than the rating reflects. This is an enjoyable pale ale, but is really more in the British vein.

Bottle from a small but respects me shop in Baldwin,MD. Crystal clear reddish amber under a thin khaki head. Aroma of toasted malt and mild caramel. Flavor reminds me of a cross between an English Pale and a domestic Amber with a slightly metalic aftertaste. Strong malt profile but could use a healthier dose of hops. Short and dry finish. Not a bad beer but far from special.

Very nice amber pour. Sweet, grassy aroma with noticeable yeast. Pretty sweet and hoppy for a pale ale, with a touch of caramel and yeasty astringency. I wouldnâ€™t mind washing down a crabcake with one of these.

A nice orange amber ale with a thin lacing off white head. A nice perfumey malt with light cinnamon, very pleasant. In mouth, a nice vienna with caramel malt, butterscotch, a bit short overall. On tap at brewpub, Oct. 12 2008.
OK oktoberfest. Fairly one-dimensional flavor, lightly sweet with a dry, lightly bitter hop finish.

Draught pint at the brewpub, 12/18/2005. Pours a lightly chill-hazed amber-auburn with some deep beige tones and a small beige head, moderate to low retention and spotty lacing. Aroma of honey, maple, light vanillin and a touch of earthy, lightly toasted grains. Flavor begins with light fruitiness (peaches, nectarines, tangerines) and touches on a sweeter note, with vanilla and light maple syrup-like notes. Toasted grains add a deep earthy feel to it and overall the breadiness usually present in the style is quite underdone here. Light, flowery, leafy hops bitterness and flavor, no alcohol apparency. Texture is rather loose, though the body is at least not thin. Carbonation is low, but lightly engaging at times.

Pours a medium amber, with a small head that leaves just a touch of lacing. Aroma is slightly bready, but mainly dominated with caramel and toffee, with a hint of hops. Flavor is caramel, toffee, some breadiness, and finishes with a small whiff of hops. Medium in body, quite nice.

Looks pretty much like a typical deep reddish amber brew. Not impressively malty either. Again, as seems the trend with many American brewers these days, they tend to junk up everything with TOO much hops. Dude, let the malts have a little more say in the matter! Fairly sweet and "flowery" finish. Overall though, this was one of the nicest brewpubs I have visited recently in the area, and I will definately go back!
Sweeter, milder and altogether less interesting than the original recipe. Better than most beers in Chile, still that''s hardly saying anything positive.

column1: Gahan Sir John A's Honey Wheat Ale
column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: 473ml can. (4.5% ABV) Pours a clear amber with a medium, creamy, long lasting, off-white head that laces nicely. Mild, semi-sweet aroma of honey, wheat malt and floral. Mild, sweet flavour of honey, faint wheat malt and herbal hops in a dry finish. Light body with a thin, watery texture and soft carbonation. Inoffensive and boring, almost a Blonde Ale.

column1: Gahan Sir John A's Honey Wheat Ale
column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: On tap at gahan house. Light wheat aroma - not much honey. Golden in colour with very little head. Fairly weak and watery with only a hint of honey. Thin bodied. Watery finish.

column1: Gahan Sir John A's Honey Wheat Ale
column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Tasting at Matt's, can Golden color, clean. Skunky malt juice, bread, more skunk in the final. Very bad.

column1: Gahan Sir John A's Honey Wheat Ale
column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Can - Wheat and honey sweetness. Clear gold with a small white head. Light cardboard and sweetness with a touch of malt.

column1: Gahan Sir John A's Honey Wheat Ale
column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: 473mL can, pours a clear golden with a small white head. Aroma is very subdued wheat notes - not much really. Flavour is dull, with cardboard, no honey notes, and light biscuit. Dull and washed out. Lame.

column1: Gahan Sir John A's Honey Wheat Ale
column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Where and how: big trip East Coast 2017 â€“ on tap at brewpub Aroma honey, grainy, hint of floral meadow and wheat malts. Appearance : Top: smaller top, some rings on glass. Base: golden Palate : medium bodied, somewhat softer carbonation and body. Average end. Taste: Honey soften the character of this beer, somewhat bland, easy going base with mild tartness on edges.

column1: Gahan Sir John A's Honey Wheat Ale
column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Well water notes with hint of calcium and metal mark this tepid honey wheat ale peed from the oldest, sickest, male member of an interbred family.

column1: Gahan Sir John A's Honey Wheat Ale
column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Appearance: Pours a light, slightly hazy golden body with a bit of carbonation racing in there (phew!). But again same story. Thin ring literally disappears in seconds and leaves nothing behind! Even worse that the Island Red (if thatâ€™s possible!). Not good and i dread whatâ€™s coming. Smell: Ok, not bad. Some grass (and wheat maybe?) with a mild bitterness and some grain. I think iâ€™m being generous on this score only because i expected worse and was surprised. Taste: Very hard to grasp on the flavors. A bit of sweetness and an aftertaste of honey but not much else. At least there are no off flavors but not terribly interesting. Again, i feel iâ€™m being to kind on this score but it exceeds my expectations (which were by this point pretty low). Reviewed on: 08-27-2009

column1: Gahan Sir John A's Honey Wheat Ale
column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Very drinkable, slight wet hay. Good use of the honey on the finish. Not a whole lot going on, but good enough.

column1: Gahan Sir John A's Honey Wheat Ale
column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: On tap at Sims. Pours a clear gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has sweet wheat and a good amount of honey supporting. Flavor combines sweet wheat and honey well but is a bit thin and sweet.

Draught (Post & Telegraph (JDW), Brighton) (7:4:6:3:12=3.2) Rich malty bready aroma. Pale amber, small persistent tight head. herbal nettly hopping, but somethigna bit vegetal about the malts, a bit pulsey. OK-ish bitter, but a disappointment after the aroma.

Cask (4.5%; quarterly ale), 1/2 pint by hand-pump at Sir John Moore, Glasgow on 5 Apr 2018: floral, grain aroma, golden amber, thin bubbly white head, sparse lacing, floral, aromatic, resiny, oily, grainy finish.
Cask @ Barum Top Inn, Halifax. Golden with a head. It's crisp with a hop-malt balance, but quite heavy tasting with this. Some fruitiness is to be found too.
Hoppy aroma golden colour with good lacing. Creamy flow that leaves slight bitter taste. Pleasant and inoffensive would order again
Settled slowly to a pale golden colour. Not a very strong aroma and the taste had a gentle bitterness which i found very pleasant. A nice, refreshing drink that's is well suited for session drinking.

Cask at The Green Dragon, Leek (JDW) A clear golden colour with a medium white head. Aroma of bready malts, maybe cereal, slight herb, a hint of apple and some spicy hops. Taste of bready malts, some crisp apple, slight herbs and subtle spicy hops. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A dryish, malt and spicy hop bitterness in the finish. A crisp, easy drinking golden bitter. Just a bit dull.
Cask at the Ralph Fitz Randal (JDW), Richmond. Medium white head. Clear gold body. Green apple, herbs, English hops and spice.
Cask @ 3 Judges. Golden colour, foamy white head. Aroma of citrus and soap. Flavour: citrus, soapy, sweet malts. Fairly bitter.

Cask at the Hope Pole, Aylesbury, Bucks 10-07-09 Pours amber with a slight haze, also has a thin white head. Some honey and hops on the nose. The taste is bitter sweet with honey there again, its fine but just a tiny bit tired A6 A3 F7 P3 Ov12 3.1

Cask conditioned at The Turf Tavern, Oxford. Brown amber with white head. Thin and a little tart on the palate, then with a sweet hop note, quite dull malt which tends to dominate. Just average really.

From old notes: Cask @ Booze on the Ouse fest, St. Ives, 2000. Black color. Aroma's: big roasted malt with light herbs and sweetness. Flavor was rather bitter. Short finish, only mildly bitter. Nice porter.

Cask at PoW, Farnborough, 16/08/17. Creamy chocolate aroma, with a sour edge. Dark and glossy. Frothy beige head. Sweet with an underlying bitterness. Chocolate and fruit. Medium bodied. On the thin side. Flat carbonation. Slightly astringent element to the finish. Any enjoyable porter.

Cask from Gatehouse Tavern, Coventry. Near black, with lots of streaky coffee coloured lacing. Aroma was subdued and primarily milky coffee. Maybe this was a bad pint, because I didnâ€™t get the expected range of porter flavours, just cheap chocolate. Lingering bitter finish, but not altogether pleasant.

30th June 2015: cask hand-pulled half pint in The Rocklands Club, Redditch. Black with a creamy textured off-white head. The aroma came across as fruity with a coffee and chocolate overtone. The taste was semi-sweet, losing the fruitiness from the nose but keeping the malts molasses nicely. Mild dry finish to a fairly smooth Porter: decent.

Cask at Rocklands Private Members Club 8th December. Poured black with small creamy off white head.Coffee and roast malt aromas with a little chocolate.Smooth drinking with flavours of roasted malts and coffee wth the chocolate again in the background.Head though smallish stayed till the end.Not up to the strength of porters how i prefer but nonetheless a very tasty drink all the same.

Cask-conditioned at the Hobgoblin, Reading 7/08/2011. Near black with a decent, creamy off-white head. aroma of dark fruits, coffee and milk chocolate. Flavour had a touch of caramel, more chocolate and a hint of spice, before a dryish finish. Very good.

Cask conditioned at Banbury Beer Fest â€™10. Black with tan head. Fruity deep porter with strong coffee, roasty notes and hints of tar and liquorice. Thick on the palate with a black wine gum note. Liked it.

Cask at NWAF 2009. A very dark brown beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has strong notes of roasted malt as well as lighter notes of soy sauce. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of hard roasted malt as well as lighter notes of chocolate and soy sauce, leading to a dry roasted finish.

Cask (gravity) @ National Winter Ales Festival 2009, Manchester, England. Clear medium brown color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, chocolate, cola. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20090122]
Cask at Manchester winter ale fetival 2009... Black ... roast malt little hop nose ... roast malt ... little bitterness ... little coffee.
Tap. Mahogany color with a light brown head. Malty aroma with a weak watered down toasted malt flavor.

Dark brown color with medium head. Fruity yeasty aroma with some malt present. Very sweet caramel flavor with light bitterness. Very fruity. Light body. Too sweet and too fruity. Tastes like slightly over-the-top American take on an English Bitter. Unbalanced.

getrunken ANfang 2018 Dieses Biobier gibt es schon lÃ¤nger und die Tatsache, dass das Etikett auf Deutsch, Italienisch und Slowenisch erinnert an eine Zeit, in der es noch kein Bio-Bier in Italien und Slowenien gab. Dieses Bier, hat offenbar durch seinen Geschmack Ã¼berzeugt und nicht nur deshalb, dass es Bio ist. Es ist unglaublich sÃ¼ffig und lÃ¤sst sich wunderbar trinken.
Bio cimbra bottle bb 22/5/19 dorata leggera velatura schiuma media buona nota maltata mielosa fine erbaceo amaro contenuto

Bottiglia. Il gusto al naso resta attratto dall'orzo. L'intensitÃ  olfattiva Ã¨ normale e la maniera in cui permane Ã¨ sufficiente. Il cappello di schiuma resiste abbastanza. La grandezza delle bollicine Ã¨ media. Il liquido Ã¨ di consistenza limpida. Poche bollicine fini costituiscono la forma della frizzantezza. Il colore Ã¨ giallo dorato brillante. Il corpo Ã¨ rotondo. L'amaro Ã¨ poco incisivo. L'intensitÃ  gustativa Ã¨ normale e la continuitÃ  Ã¨ sufficiente. Il gusto Ã¨ piacevole. Le sensazioni boccali finali risultano di pronta beva. Il finale Ã¨ semplice e dissetante. Il retrogusto Ã¨ di media intensitÃ . Al palato si fermano impressioni di cereali e pane cotto di recente.

50 cl bottle. Pale golden color, average white head quickly disappearing, clear, fizzy. Flavors of biscuity malts, lagery, mild grainy and biscuity with straw. Taste a bit tacky and starchy, typical of austrian lagers, clean, average carbonation. I think it's Hirter's Bio under different name.
This is a rather unspectacular brew, good thing it's organic. But I wish they could do their pils organic
Helder geel bier met schuim. Smaak is licht bitter hoppig en licht zoet met iets van gras en hooi. Best goed te drinken met een mooie zachte smaak..

Bottle at Erzbierschof MC. Pours clear pale yellow. Aroma is pleasantly malty but also with clear hops. Body is light, short, but also a tad sour, low carbonation and a bit oily. Rather thin. Okay, nothing really off.
Bottle clear golden body with white head. Aroma is malty grains herbs. Taste is malty with bisquits and hints of honey. Aftertaste is sweet with hints of bitterness.
0,5l bottle. Mild, easy drinkable, light bitter finish. Basically ok, but a bit boring
Bottle at work. Pours golden color, white head. Aroma and taste are malty, bit sweet, some corn, lightly bitter finish.

7/20/2007: Elevator Belgian Wit is a cloudy, pale yellow color with a foamy white head. Wheat, light citrus and some spice are in the aroma. The flavor is a bit sour and grassy with some lemon citrus. There is a mild amount of alcohol that seems to sneak into the flavor as well. This is not a typcial Witbier and definitely was not as expected. It was more like a poor attempt at a Farmhouse Ale or something. It was a bit disappointing to say the least... Draught at Luckyâ€™s in Athens, Ohio during the Ohio Brew Week 2007. Rating #9 for this beer...

Mid-hazed pale golden with a white halo when served. Clove, florals and... mystery spices in the aroma add allure and intrigue. Thin-bodied with a wheat base flavor smothered by flowers and spice. Interesting, yet seemingly incorrect. On draught at Elevator Brewing Co., Columbus, OH 43215

Nose of yeast & spice, pears & bananas and oddly enough - pickles. The brew is cloudy golden honey. The quick white frothy head leaves no lace. Well balanced, heavy acidity, with a very briney metallic finish that all but ruins the flavor. The light body is dry and soft. Canâ€™t help but wonder if there was something wrong mechanically with the tap system on this one. Thanks to Jana for the sample.
Hazy pale yellow color. Some citrus aroma, but could just be the lemon slice. Mild citrus and wheat flavor. Not much in the way of spice flavoring. Still, drinkable and thirst quenching.
Frosted lemondrop color, lacy head. Orangeblossom aroma. Esteric and phenols. Bubblegum and cereal flavors. Finishes out tart. Pleasant.

Draft at The Elevator. Cloudy pale color with an average fizzy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate citrus banana spice aroma. Light body with lively carbonation. Light sour citrus flavor with a light sweet finish of moderate duration. Refreshing summer beer.

Rerate 5/2/12: Sampled this beer under the updated name "Nit Wit" and had a better experience. Same color, but with more of a traditional body and spice and citrus flavor one would associate with a Wit. Still pretty average. 6/29/06: This is the June selection in Elevatorâ€™s "MBA" program. This is the first seasonal from the Elevator that has been poorly done. It is also the first time I have had the equivalent of a "drain pour" at a brewpub, being unable to come close to finishing it. Served with a slice of orange. The beer is cloudy yellow/gold with a thin white head that diminishes quickly. Slick lacing. Aroma of light spices and citrus. Light-bodied and crisp with a zesty spice and citrus flavor for a split second, then an immediate blast of soap and moldy yeast flavor that is wince-inducing. Moreover, this unpleasant flavor seems to coat the tongue and stay there. The finish is no better, as any of the good flavors are overpowered by the lingering moldy wet dish rag flavor. Maybe an off batch but I will be scared to ever try this again.
From notes: Pale and carbonated. Small sweetness combined with coriander. Floral. Pretty good for a wit.

This beer was a straw color with a small white head which left little lace. If had a faint aroma of hops and citrus. The flavor was of hops and citrus. The finish was light and tangy. A good session beer.
Bottle. light golden colour white head.dry malt and hay aroma. flavour is watery malt with notes of hay.

(Bottle 33 cl) Pilsener golden with a small, creamy, white head. Light-bodied with a decent, malty character. Some metallic accents appear to be this beerâ€™s main feature. Some hops in the finish. 160206

Bottled: Light yellow coloured. Clear. Fluffy off white head. Very vague aroma. Light grass, light stable and a vague and distanct sweetness. Flavour is very watery and thin. Sweetness is present, but dosnâ€™t have much to offer. Boring and uninspiring.

A yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is boring with primary notes of straw - I find it somewhat artificial. The flavor contains notes of straw as well as light notes of corn, leading to a dry end. A real light beer.
Bottled. Pale golden coloured. Weak aroma with notes of midding. Very weak and rather sweet flavour. Watery.

Bottle. Light golden, white head. Sulfury aroma that is in the taste too. Itâ€™s a pity to give such low score to my local lager-brewery, but it doesnâ€™t deserve a better rating. For this beer, there should be a 0 in the aroma-categoy. (050918)
Light (= low ABV) lager with some bitterness but otherwise little flavour. Like all light beers easily forgettable.

This is more like a hoppy APA versus an IPA. Fresh hopped though, which gives it a smoother mouthfeel, plus the fact that it just isn't that malty. Well balanced, but worth nowhere near the full price tag on this. Even at half off on clearance felt like was slightly pricey. I like Left Hand, but going to stick with their standard beers bottled in 6-packs from now on. Bottle is slightly old so that could have lowered the rating somewhat.

Draft at Bru Craft. Mostly clear deep gold with a thick off-white head. Bit of an odd bird. Grassy. Watery. Lagery clean finish. Rain-soaked grass clippings. Cracker malts. Hints of peach, pine, clove, and clementine. Different from the standard wet hop IPAs.

22floz bottle BBD 01.21.2017 (paid $4 because itâ€™s a little old). Consumed 04.03.2017. A copper colored IPA with a large head that falls to create a plateau. Orange zest and lavender combine to create a soap-like aroma. Body is full, and leathery taste has a harsh bitterness. Brewed to be drunk fresh, so it could be marginally better. I prefer a greater hop to malt balance, this beer lacked malt character.

Pours a dark golden with an ample eggshell colored head. Grassy and very spicy nose. Spicy, rye, cinnamon, clove, grass, and berry(?) flavors. Weird IPA. Not in a good way. I was waiting for a while on trying this one and Iâ€™m disappointed.

On tap. Pours a dark copper color with a nice head and good lacing. Aroma of grapefruit, bit of pine and grain. taste of grapefruit bit of malt sweetness and grain. Nice bitterness and a clean finish. Medium body, crisp clean with a nice subtle hop feel. Enjoyable beer.

Hazy, orange color, medium white head. Sweet fruit aromas, grapefruit and oranges. Pine and citrus hops. Taste is very mellow. Sweet flavors that are poorly balanced by the hops. Slight hop flavor of pine and grass. Short, light bitter finish. Maybe you should drink it fresh too.

Bouteille de 22 oz achetÃ©e chez Barkâ€™s Beer Cave (Plattsburgh, NY) au coÃ»t de 7,00$. ArÃ´me: Odeur de pamplemousse avec une pointe de pin. Apparence: La couleur est orangÃ©e avec une trÃ¨s faible densitÃ© de bulle. PrÃ©sence dâ€™un mince col mousseux et dâ€™une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: GoÃ»t de pamplemousse avec une pointe de pin et de caramel. DurÃ©e moyenne de lâ€™arriÃ¨re goÃ»t. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture lÃ©gÃ¨rement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. LÃ©gÃ¨re prÃ©sence dâ€™amertume dâ€™houblon en arriÃ¨re goÃ»t. (Rating #6835)

BBD 1/13/16. Clear amber pour with a dark ruby cast. Outstanding head volume, world class lacing and retention. Outstanding nose of orange and light pine over biscuit coupled with a bit of earthy spice. Light body with a texture similar to that of water but coupled with an outstanding oily slickness. Superb carbonation with a bit of effervescence in the middle and a nice burst in the finish. The flavor profile is very good. This is a hop flavor focused beer with moderate bitterness that is balanced with toasty biscuit and caramel. Like the nose, orange dominates with pine and spicy elements in the background. Along with moderate bitterness in the middle, caramel makes a strong appearance. The finish is semi-dry and a hint of alcohol astringency arrives over a lingering slightly sweet rind/pine bitterness.

Bomber. Pours copper with a big fluffy off-white head that has good retention. Aroma of wet pine needles and a trace of fresh grapefruit. The taste, likewise, is more piney that citrusy and set in a light caramel malt base that is slightly sweet. The palate is medium, finishes sweet. Overall: Very easy drinking IPA, good stuff.
22oz bottle pour from home with a best by date of 1/13/16 (one week from review). Pours a light reddish color with nice fluffy head. A solid beer...not bad...but not mind blowing either.
500ml bottle at The Spice Lounge, Watford in 2016. Clear golden. Fairly malty aroma with a slight dried fruit note. Not a lot of flavour, but better than others of its ilk.
Flaska. Klar ljusgul med ett medelstort vitt skum. Dofter av malt och papp. Smakinslag av malt, vÃ¥t papp och honung.
strÃ¥gul, klar, leskende, korn, fin fylde, godt balansert....................
Bottle: Poured a golden with huge white head. Aroma is skunky. Taste is soggy cardboard, lingering aftertaste.
Muted gold Buttery a little rich and off bottle picked up in booths carnforth

The following marketing is a triumph, the beer is an epic fail. The temples of Dinajpur; the tea gardens of Sylhet, the rain forests of Sundarban - Bangladesh contains a wealth of exotic sights, cultures and culinary delights. Inspired by this richness, Bangla premium lager beer is stronger brewed to complement strongly flavoured foods. Chamotkar - Enjoy.
Bottle at Restaurant Ultimate in Stockholm. Initial aroma of dirty wash cloth that then levars to a thin pale pilsner malt. Light malty with a small acidity. Low seetness and bitterness.
Bottle from beersofeurope.com. Clear golden appearance with medium sized white head. Aroma is sweet, malt and hops. Flavour is citrus, slight hops, bitter, sweet and metallic.

The bottle they give you when "The cobra is off tap". Chemical tasting bullshit. Don't accept this clear Imitator. Genuinely tastes like a non alcoholic interpretation of an Indian lager. But nowhere near and with more fake sweetener. Avoid at all costs.

Bottle at local Bangladeshi restaurant. Poured golden with a large, frothy white head. Aroma of malt, hop, corn, grass and veg. Medium sweetness, light bitterness. Towards medium body, oily texture, average carbonation. Supported the occasion, that's about all.
Pet 0,5l wypite w Rumunii ok.2006r.Niewiele mogÄ™ napisaÄ‡ ale piwo to nie zrobiÅ‚o Å¼adnego wraÅ¼enia, tylko pragnienie zaspokoiÅ‚o.
Little plastic bottle. Amber-brown color. Malty aroma. Full taste of caramel malts. Little bit strong for hot summer.

2l-PET bottle. Clear brown colour with an amber glow and a fluffy off-white head. Lovely aroma of chocolate and dark malts. Full-bodied, hopy, with a dry mouthfeel and pleasant flavours of liquorice, chocolate, caramel and roasetd malts. Slightly hoppy. Despite its high ABV the alcohol appears only in a warming shadow. Quite nice!

PET bottle 0,5 ltr, alc. 6,3 % Bottle bought from random grocery shop in Romania. Dark ruby red color, good creamy beige head, lace. Light papery aroma. Some caramel, light licorice, strong metallic flavor. Aftertaste is a bit sweet. Not too bad for being PET-bottled Romanian.

PET bottle shared by TBone. Deep rubyish amber colour, small beige head. Aroma is bready malts, caramel and some mild hops. Flavour is caramel, hops, dry wood and some mild licorice in the finish. Rather pleasant!

Bottle. 50cl PET, shared by larsga. It pours a blood-reddish black body, or maybe itâ€™s just copper ;-), anyway, itâ€™s topped by a small, beige head. The aroma has toffee, some grains and alcohol. Thereâ€™s toffee in the flavor too, some roasted malt, as well as a touch of fruits and alcohol. Medium boudy. Wee touch of alcohol in the finish as well as an even weaker burnt note, and toffee. Drinkable, but far from a great brew. (080216)
Pet bottle provided by larsga. Murky red beer. Sweet toffee and then some metallic bitterness. Oxidized? Hard to know how this is when fresh.

500 ml plastic bottle provided and shared by larsga, thanks. A thin greyish head over a reddish amber body. Sweet malts and toffe dominates the aroma. Scents of roast. Strong and sweet caramellish malt taste. Burnt sugar and roast underneath. Healthy body. Light sticky texture. Mild bitterness towards the finish. Unusual, but goes well down.

Medium offwhite head. Dark red body. Roasty toffee and caramel aroma with syrupy, grassy notes. Dryish-sweetish roasty caramelly grainy taste with papery rubbery notes. Decent, but not really good. (0.5l PET bottle bought outside Bran castle, Romania.)

Bottled- PET. Clear ruby, small head. Fruity coffee aroma. Medium sweet with clean mouthfeel and solid body. Quite potent with concentrated roasty malt character. Some dusty bitterness. Rough around the edges, but still a welcome break with the stream of pale lagers in Romania.
Draft. Amber beer with a dark cream head. Pumpkin and pie spice aroma. Spice and light malt flavor. Medium bodied. Spice and light malt lingers with light caramel and light vegetal notes.
Light pumpkin beer flavor. Well made but really if your not going to go exotic why go at all? Not bad at all but why bother. What they should do is add spices to their IPA.

Pours an amber-orange with loose-bubbled white head and decent retention. Unremarkable sweet malt aroma, light pumpkin spice. Sweet lightly astringent body with cinnamon and light nutmeg. Very carbonated, thin body. Unmemorable, but drinkable and decidedly pumpkin-like. Thanks to John for the trade!
Basically their amber ale and throw in some nutmeg and cinnamon. Donâ€™t taste any pumpkin but the spices are clearly present. Never been a big fan of pumpkin beers... still not a fan.
Village Tavern Bham -- draught. Real tangy and spicy. Good carbonation. Solid 3.

She settles into the glass, deep amber golden with a creamy head to call attnention to her. Pumpkin and nutmeg call out to you as you lift the glass. Bringing it to your lips the pumpkin is oh so understated with distinctively nutmeg overtones. Overall, drinks like a good lager--with pumpkin mixed in. One of the better pumpkin brews Iâ€™ve had, this time on tap at Cool Beans.
Tap. Spice pumpkin aroma. Dark amber color. Nice head. Cinnamon flavors. Nice spice beer.

Shaker pint draft at Jacks Brewing Company in Fremont, California. The pour is a hazed orange golden with a small white head. The aroma is faint honey, floral and a touch of cracker malt. The taste is clean with subdued flavors of the honey, floral and cracker malt. The palate is medium bodied with low carbonation and a clean mineral hop softly bitter finish.
pours golden Delight. not a lot of foam, lots of Taste, fruit, citrus and especially pine. not suitable for multiple drinks but very Nice to enjoy
On tap at the brewery Pours clear light golden with a small white head, some lacing. Aroma of citrus, fruity and grapefruit. Flavor of grapefruit, grassy and citrus peel Nice ipa

Growler pour thanks to Brian. Pours hazy orange amber with a medium beige head that lasts pretty well and laces well too. Aroma is standard IPA - pine forward, some citrus, leaves, caramel. Flavor is light sweet and light bitter, pine forward again. Finish is quite harshly bitter. Medium body, oily mouthfeel.
(Growler) Pours a clear yellow body with a small white head. Aroma of pine, earth, caramel, and some florals. Flavor of pine, caramel, orange, and earthiness with a dry, bitter finish.
Pretty respectable IPA. Decent head that lasts a while, good hoppy flavour, just enough carbonation.

Thanks to bu11zeye for sharing this growler. Golden-orange pour with a white head. The aroma is full of resin and pine notes, very similar to what I got in the Jacks Double IPA. The flavor is more like the aroma where I get some pine and orange character, as well as enough biscuit malt to keep the bitterness low. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Poured golden amber, complex hop flavors(citrus, earthy, piney), caramel malts.

Pours a nice clear copper with a thin cream colored head. Citrus and pine hop nose. The flavor in the front has a strange lemon citrus to it, the subsides to allow more traditional hop bitterness and dryness in the mid to finish, which are both very solid. Not crazy about that front, but beside that this is a nice IPA.

Draft from a sampler at the San Ramon brewpub. Deep orange in color, a bit hazy. Some orange and floral hops in the nose. Flavor of grapefruit, orange, perfume, and floral hops. Balanced bitterness that softly dissipates. Crisp and pleasant. Jackâ€™s pale ales stand head and shoulders above their others.

50 cl bottle bought from supermarket. Pours clear golden color with medium white head. Aroma of alcohol, light malts and hops. Taste is similar to aroma, alcohol, malt, hops, light corn. Light body, medium carbonation, medium bitter finish. Overall not a good beer, but ok if it's cold and you are thirsty.

Can, 500 ml. Absolutely not a bad beer, but totally forgettable. Deep folden with good 1 finger foam. The nose is funky, sour, no character at all. The palate sour and bitter (on the end), not unpleasent but somehow it's absolutely empty on the mid-palate. Cheap beer from Heineken in Romania.

50 cl. can. A clear gomden coloured beer with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, fruit, hops, straw and with a bitter finish.
Strong and bitter taste, very cheap beer ,but sadly not much more. It is drinkable if you are low on money but I would recommend to spend a few more cents and get a better beer.

Bottle in Cluj Napoca, Romania. Golden color, white head. Pretty common beer, refreshing but not special

Plastic bottle 50 cl. Pours an odd orangey golden with a tiny, white head. Odd cardboardish aroma. Medium body, strangely unclean with no real malt feel - just this cardboard note. Roughish bitterness. One of the poorest Pale Lagers I've had for a while. 170818
Kedvencem a weizenbock, Ã‰rte inni majd meghalok, Habja testes, teste habos,
Bottle at Hopa. Deep golden, white head. Nose is big banana, fruity-flowery yeasty touch, malty kick. So is the taste with a long, sweet finish. Perhaps a tad too light body, but nice nevertheless.

Der weiÃŸe Bock sieht im Glas bernsteinfarben aus und zeigt eine ordentliche Schaumkrone. Vollmundiger Geruch. Der Antrunk ist sehr sÃ¼sslich, karamellmalzig, fruchtig und wÃ¼rzig. hazy grey-ish orange colour, medium sized dense white head; aroma and taste of banana, clove, caramel, bready notes and maybe some basil (?); good weizen bock!

Bottle from Drankenhandel Leiden. Aroma is sweet ripe banana, bready wheat, spicy yeast, pear, and touch of ripe stone fruits. Flavour is rather sweet with a mild bitterness. Body is medium. Sweet with ripe fruits, lots of banana.

Bottle. Orangey brown color. Banana, herbs, floral hop aroma. Big malty wheaty beer, sticky, classic Bavarian weisse yeast flavors, slight booze. Bold weisse bock with good traditional approach, less fruity and more big malt than anything else. I like it.

Pours opaque brown with a white head that dilapidates quick for a Weizen. Rich malty aroma with a lot of roast (when opening the bottle). In the glass aroma is milder. Taste is mild, sweet, honey, but also some spice, grain. Complex, very good!

Bottle. Hazy amber color with creamy head. Aroma is spicy, banana. Taste is banana, pear, spicy yeasts, milky, maybe a bit too milky - but not phenolic. Oily mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Good Weizenbock!

50cl MHD06/2018 Maruhn. - Kurz: lean, all pearjuice and nutmeg Weizenbock with more (fresh) Weizen than Bock character. + fresh stonefruit and banana milkshake - watered down, on watery mf with added faint whiffs of Williams Christ fumes. Not the rich creamy wallop I expected & foodpaired this to be.

L: -pours a cloudy golden-amber with a big,creamy,white head -high carbonation visible S: -banana,white bread,clove,orange,wheaty,milky T: -Follows the nose + honey, caramel -medium to high bitterniss for the style F: -medium carbonation -medium body -alcohol noticeable O: Top Notch Weizenbock.Can absolutely keep up with Weihestephaner's Vitus.

Lys pilsner med lidt fint skum. Let bitterhed, fin fylde med god eftersmag.
can @ auchan (budapest) golden colour, normal body, average carbonated, white head, malty, sweet, metallic taste, easy to drink, nothing special
