Clear red brown, frothy off-white head, nice lacing, malty nose with some fruit and spice, caramel, bread, dark fruit, floral, bittersweet malty taste, light to medium body, crisp dry finish is slightly bitter, bit spicy

Grifo. Vaso Lager. Color Ã¡mbar oscuro y espuma blanca. corona tupida y persistente que deja anillos. Aromas de maltas tostadas y notas de hierba. La entrada chispeante se torna en refrescante y suave sensaciÃ³n. Sabores de maltas tostadas. Cuerpo ligero y carbonataciÃ³n moderada. Limpio amargor en el intermedio que permanece en el prolongado final floral y amargo. Muy buena para "ir de caÃ±as" !! On-tap. Lager glass. Dark amber color. White foam, close & lasting crown. Lacing rings on sides. Toasted malt aromas & grassy notes. Sparkling at first turns refreshing & smooth, Toasted flavor. Light body. Moderate carbonation. Clean bitterness in the middle lingers into a long floral bitter finish. Nice session beer !!!

On tap. Malt, caramel and herbal aromas. Pours light copper, with average white to tan head, some persistance and lacework. Malty flavours, along with sweet notes. Very light body and average carbonation. Really easy to drink, quite enjoyable.

Tap at the newer Oldenbur in Madrid. Dark amber, golden lace. Light honey roast, fruityness as it warms, grassy hops, good balance, not as much bitternes as in other Alts I think. Medium body, light sparkly mouthfeel.
On bottle in San Sebastian bar summer 2011 Dark golden Medium body and complexity A bit sour for an Alt bier Enjoyable

[ASPETTO] marrone castagna, velata [SCHIUMA] media presenza, beige, fine e media persistenza [ OLFATTO ] bassa intensitÃ , un leggero floreale, con un tocco di cerali che si combina con note tostate [GUSTO] media intensitÃ , con un inzio dolciastro, caramello. Una sensazione minerale verso il finale che si mescola con note amare, apparentemente dovute alla tostatura ma câ€™Ã¨ spazio anche per qualche nota luppolata, che ricorda una una pilsner tedesca [TEXTURE] corpo medio basso, mobida al palato, media carbonazione, alcohol non percettibile [COMMENTO FINALE] bevuta alla spina, in un locale in stile tedesco in Madrid (FASS). Premettendo che la mia conoscenza delle altbier Ã¨ piuttosto limitato, i due boccaloni sono stati piuttosto graditi. Una birra leggera, da bere in quantitÃ  nel piÃ¹ classico stile tedesco, accompagnando con wurstel e patate. caratterizzata da un iniziale equilibrio fra dolce ed amaro, una leggera tostatura accompagna verso un finale che tende verso note amare comunque contenute. si intravedono note fruttate -floreali che la distinguono da una lager classica e, lasciata scaldare un pochino, acquista maggiore complessitÃ . ideale per una serata conversando ... in stile birra e salsiccia.. mancava Bud Spencer seduto al mio fianco
As red as Autumn leaves, compliments over... This has light, fruity berries with a dry-ish finish. Er, it''s quite bland, actually.
Watery beer, a bit sweet. Itâ€™s not bad, but boring. I wouldnâ€™t recommend it.

Half pint, cask at Richard John Blackler. Clear golden brown coloured body. Creamy white head. Floral hops and pale malts on the nose. Flavoured with nuts, mild caramel and juicy malts. Bitter ending. Soft in the mouth. Paired well with my traditional English breakfast (Liverpool 01.02.2015).
Cask @ Fox & Goose, Hebden Bridge. Amber with a frothy head. Has light fruits and a light bitterness with a small sweet berry aroma.
Light brown colour. Quite a bland average beer that is a bit unrefined and weak. Has a mild fruitiness.

Cask (handpump) @ The Bankers Draft, 1-3 Market Place, Sheffield, South Yorkshire England S1 2GH. Clear medium amber orange color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, butter, butterscotch. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light light bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20100118]

[Cask at Back of Beyond, Reading] Pale amber, negligible white head. Smooth, pleasantly sweet, juicy fruits and caramel with a lemony finish, a little thin of body. A pleasant if inoffensive little beer.

Cask. Slightly hazy pale amber with an off-white head. Sweet toffeeish and lightly buttery nose. Light body, low carbonation with a very soft mouthfeel. Very sweet toffee notes - and basically nothing else. No bitterness. 180110
Cask @ 3 Judges. Dark golden colour, off-white head. Aroma: toffee and biscuit. Flavour: caramel, cookie, nutty, peanuts, roasted malts. Dry finish. Very drinkable.
Cask gravity at Ashford Rugby Club BF 2008. Bit of cheese on aroma, some caramel in flavour. Itâ€™s got that smooth creamy caramel that Iâ€™n not keen on. Eggy aroma.

Hazy orange, thin white head. Slight citrus malt with some hop balance. Touch of banana and strawberry. Mouth is sweet, smooth, clean hop. Malt, some tumeric. Finished hoppy, slightly brackish. Slight lemony lasting fruit. Quaffable.
Cask at Freebird, Newcastle under Lyme. Pours copper with a white head. If you like boozy sugar water then this is for you. Awful, far far too sweet and hard to drink.
Cask @ Fox & Goose, Hebden Bridge. Copper with a thin head. Has a berry sweet and sugary aroma and taste.
Cask at the Anchor; Clear amber pour soapy white head, malty aroma, sweet caramel, very English strong, ABV not that present.

Cask at the Anchor, Birmingham. Poured a clear medium amber with a thin white head. The aroma is malt, caramel hop. The flavour is medium bitter with a rich resin malt palate. Medium bodied with average carbonation.
Cask conditioned at The Anchor, Birmingham. Clouded brown with no head. Fruity raw alcohol flavour, very difficult drinking. Not particularly pleasant.

Reddish half hand-pulled at the brewtap. Lots of alcohol, faint caramel and wood flavours (hops?). Nose rubbery and slightly sickbowly/citric like strong industrial cider. Increasingly musty hop presence as it warms. Not enough malt, caramel, complexity or anything but alcohol to really make much of an impression. Dull strong ale awash with Bavaria Red almond ethanol notes 533311 (Re-rate, 2005 vintage, cask handpull at the brewtap, Xmas Eve) Clear red amber with an initial collar diminishing to nothing. Jammy faint peach and apricot aroma to begin with, blending into Strawberry Chewit once the headâ€™s gone. Tropical and stone fruit to fore; pineapple, peach and apricot. Wring of Warthog. Grass, almond and what tastes like oak creeping in, giving the alcohol away. Splash of mouthwashy harshness. Apricot and hop marmalade. Unsticky and still-bitter fruity sipper. Actually pretty very bloody good. All credit to Church for trying something like this.

Hand pulled at the Anchor, Birmingham, during Church End Weekend. Red gold, no head. Smell = clay, in a naan bread context, with some mulled berries also. Flavour is strong bricks, red berries + warm, mushy Xmas flavours hinted at too. Unbalanced. Random. Spins out on finish.

An unusual beer. Amber/gold colour. I can see why its described as a bitter as it doesnâ€™t really have the depth, fruit or power that you normally find in beers of this strength. But, whilst it has some hop, the levels are not that high and nor is the bitterness. Some residual sweetness. Perfectly pleasant but doesnâ€™t quite hit the spot. It just doesnâ€™t somehow have a big beer feel to it. On the other hand, its dangerously easy to drink for a beer of this strength. Cask (gravity dispense), White Cliffs Beer Festival, February 2005.

Feb 2005 Dover Fest. Sweet and pleasant. A mildly hoppy pale beer. OK. At this point I am settling into the festival and calming down. But Chris and Joe are starting to leave. [2.9] Feb 2009 Dover Beer Festival. Alcohol. Plastic. Some bittering hops. Sweet. Not impressed with this. [2.4]
Well, it looks like a malt licquor. This is actually a powwerful bitter (well the beer festival described it thus). This has a light fruity aroma and alcohol vapours throughout. Nothing special.

column1: Sarahs Hop House Black Mamba Mild
column5: Cask Handpump at the Railway Hotel, Golborne 13/06/2001 Dark coloured with a woody aroma. Slightly bitter in the finish.

column1: Sarahs Hop House Black Mamba Mild
column5: Dark with an impressive head. This is delicate on the palate. Smooth chocolate and a touch of coffee are present. This is an easy going beer that is always drinkable but quite characterless. Maybe that is the point of the humble mild?
Not as much flavour and complexity as for some reason I expected. Reddish appearance with a hint of fruit and bitterness.Not the real thing but not a bad attempt at replicating it.
Cask, Dog & Bone, Gillingham Copper coloured. Served slightly warm. Oak aroma. Strong flavour of juicy red apples. Flat watery finish with a nutty quality - no bitter hops at all. Not impressed.

Bottle conditioned. Chestnut red colour, good but thin white head and moderate condition. Aroma started with chocolate malt and caramel before an unusual earthy woodland note took over. Chocolate again in the mouth but with a sneaking suspicion that someone has dumped some tree bark in my beer. Mascerated twigs and moss in the aftertaste. Ooh look, a rabbit! Weird, highly drinkable and English, how bizarre.

Brewed to celebrate California''s craft brewers. This is a deep red beer with a light fruity aroma. Sweet malts are followed by pine needles (!). This beer doesn''t quite cross the "over bitterness line". Good.

On tap (cask) at Grant's Free House, Leicestershire on 1-Apr-2018. Clear brownish amber colour with a thin white head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Light to medium body and soft carbonation. Taste is toffee, malt and nuts. A decent local bitter.

Cask (gravity) @ NWAF 2015, National Winter Ales Festival (2015), The Roundhouse, Pride Park, Derby, Derbyshire, England, DE24 8JE. [ As Parish Special Bitter ]. Clear medium amber orange color with a small to average, open and frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, off-white - silver head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, pale malt. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, sweet malt, caramel. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20150213] 6-3-7-3-12

Gravicask (PBF2015, Saturday) Slightly eggy farty bitter aroma. A nice bitter in the mough - light malts and gentle bitter hops. Not "special" in any way, but probably sessionable. Just a middle-of-the-road English bitter.
Cask at Peterborough Beer Fest. Dark amber. Papery nose. Medium sweet and light bodied. Really fruity with resiny bitter finish.
Cask Conditioned @ The Bull. Running out of steam bitter that does nothing but stand and gawp.
This is OK. It would be mediocre if it wasn''t for the fantastic long, dry finish. I had the bottled version, which is quite rare. I must try the cask version one day.

SÃ¼ÃŸ-sÃ¤uerlich getreidiger Antrunk, etwas langweilig, das Bier scheint auf Massentauglichkeit getrimmt. Der etwas unstimmige Grundton weicht nicht, weiter sÃ¤uerlich, wÃ¤ssrig, etwas getreidig. Zum Ende harmlos und andeutungsweise malzig. Der Abgang ist etwas frischer. EntÃ¤uschend! Test vom 18.9.2008, Gebinde: Fass Noten: 12,7,8,7,-,6 - 7,26
From tap at Hopfenspeicher, Leipzig. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is crisp hoppy and slight citrusy. Crisp hoppy. Light yeasty and citrusy. Bitter and citrusy finish.

Medium white head doesnâ€™t last. Hazy pale yellow body with carbonation. Fruity sugary strawberry-like aroma with mealy grassy notes. Some yeast and herbs, too. Dry-sweetish alcoholic vodka taste with fruity notes. This is what I got initially. I then put the beer aside and finished my lunch, then returned to it. The fruit-vodka character was now mellowed out, and notes of yeast and grass had come in, but it was still not a nice beer. Dried out my mouth. No aftertaste. Just not a good beer. Way too much alcohol taste. (Which, at 5%, takes some doing. Anyway, 0.3l draft at Ratskeller, Leipzig.)
On tap at Hopfenspeicher in Leipzig. Not very zippy, not much foam. Sourish aroma. Tastes sourish and fruity, somehow like a lemon. weak finish. Very strange. Not so good!

Draft - Hazy corn golden body with a huge creamy head, beautiful very fine and elegant lacing; Very special nose, malty, grainy, bubblegum, ripe green fruits; A bit to thick body, slightly malty sweet balanced malty bitter and slightly fruity prickling fresh acidy; Quite long a little salty and acidy dry finish, grain, bubblegum and malty aromas lasting quite long. Good beer but a little to thick and not fresh enough.

on tap @ Snow Goose / Anchorage AK --- Clear dark caramel amber color, beige head cover, streamers of lace. Taste is fizzy sweet malt that grows substantially through a swallow that glides without incident to a finish that only suggests hops. A reasonable brew, even though it is pretty much "one-trick."
Clear copper color with ivory sheen. Toasted caramel, earthy, tea leaf aromas. medium body, average carbonation. Toasted, spicy caramel flavors with some earthy vegetal kelp---decent
Draft: Poured a burnt orange brown with a white to off white head. Aroma is sweet malts. Taste is toffee, caramel malt, and nice hoppy blend that feels sweet but balanced.
Reddish Amber in color, clear with a thin head. Nice balance light earth like qualities. Good balanced flavors with a light extra bittering from the hops. Sweet in taste with a dry finish.
Draft at GABBF 2012. Murky brownish amber. Aroma of caramel. Taste is butterscotch with a bitter finish. Not bad.

[Tap] Tried this at the brewpub in mid-September. Pours an even shade of amber with a small white head. Aroma of caramel and light brown sugar with fainter hints of peat and English hops. Toffee, sweet rolls and earthy hops are the main flavor contributers here. Fine carbonation leads to a hearty mouthfeel. One of the better beers I had at the brewpub.

Draft at brewery: Another one from Sleeping Lady that I thought was too sweet. Loaded with elements of caramel, honey, sweet peat and cereal. Hops were earthy, restrained and they only offered a mild amount of grass-like bitterness.
(tap) clear dark amber colour with small white head; faint vanilla aroma; silky palate; smooth balanced flavour

Draft at Humpyâ€™s in ANC. Deep, dark with a small film of bubbles that try. Nose is cocoa and orangey-caramel. Flavor is similar with maybe a hint of earthy smoke, but I may have just been wishing, Medium body is watery, drinkable and well-balanced.

Had this on tap at the brew pub in Anchorage in August 2009. Colour... dark amber with a thick head. Nose... sweetly malty with some hops and biscuit. Palate... gentle CO2, plenty of sweet malt, yet somewhat dry-ish, some biscuit flavour and light brown sugar with a medium finish.
Clean grapefruit/citrus nose. Golden color, mostly clear. Strong bitter taste, filtered quickly by grapefruit, ending as moderate bittering hops. Smooth, with just enough carbonation.

on tap @ Snow Goose / Anchorage AK --- Clear light golden copper color, white head cover, sprays of lace. Looks like it will taste great! Taste is caramel malt that is quickly invaded by assertive pine hops. Even though the hops are solid, the malt will not be denied, and hangs in through a medium finish. A keeper.
On tap at Snow Goose Clear golden with a medium sized white head, lots of lacing. Aroma of tropical fruit and floral. Taste is floral, fruity and grains Very nice IPA
Honey colored, no head, aroma lychee. Taste pineapple, spruce, grapefruit. Subdued carbonation. Finish bitter/clean.

On tap at the source... Aroma of citusy and ligty floral hop. a bit of malt on the backend. perfectly adequate and not a hop bomb....Crisp clean citrus flavor a bit of darker malt.medium bodied with just the right amount of carbonation. Solid if not average.

Draft at Tap Root Beer and Mead Social: Poured a copper color with off white head. Aroma is citrus fruit grapefruit, piney hops, and some floral. Very nice mixture of citrus fruit, piney hops, balancing malts, and floral bitterness. Finish is warm and spicy.
Amber in color, clear with a thin head. Nice hops aroma and flavor. Floral and earth like flavors. light crisp malt flavor biscuit and light citrus flavors. This is a nice dry IPA.
Draft at GABBF. Hazy golden yellow color, medium off white head. Aroma of pine. Taste is very bitter pine. Too bItter for my palate.

[Tap] Tried this at the brewpub in mid-September. Pours a bright orange color with a quickly receding head on top. Moderately strong nose of grapefruit, passionfruit and lighter amounts of pine sap. Herbal hoppy taste is strong, but not overpowering. Caramel and molasses notes also round out the flavor. The balance is OK, but there are some fusel alcohol notes in this brew as well. Dry and crisp finish. A decent IPA.

Draft at brewery: Good IPA. Nose is filled with juicy citrus. Bright hops in the olfactories. Effervescent and snappy. Malts are rich to boot. Hops are floral, citrusy, clean and piney. Not overly bitter like many IPAs out there. Just a decent, easy-to-drink IPA. Probably my favorite beer that Iâ€™ve tasted from Sleeping Lady. Also drank this one night at Humpyâ€™s.

column1: Sleeping Lady Urban Wilderness Pale Ale
column5: "a well balanced and fairly assertive flavor profile. this was one of the better pales, if not the best, at Canfest. liberally hopped but still balanced. nice beer. "

column1: Sleeping Lady Urban Wilderness Pale Ale
column5: Draft: Poured an orange white with copper edges, head was white. Aroma is light hops. Nice smooth malts with light hops finish.

column1: Sleeping Lady Urban Wilderness Pale Ale
column5: Draft @ Snow Goose. Clear amber with a small off white head. Aroma of citrus and floral hops with some light caramel and cereal malt. Flavor is firmly bitter hops throughout with some light caramel malt sweetness, fairly clean yeast profile. Medium to light body with average carbonation. Nice pale, leaning towards an American style pale now though.

column1: Sleeping Lady Urban Wilderness Pale Ale
column5: Can - I got this in a special can from the brewer. Nice amber color, clear with a thin head. Good malt forward flavor and light hops. Nice balance.

column1: Sleeping Lady Urban Wilderness Pale Ale
column5: Draft at GABBF. Deep clear golden color. Aroma of slightly burned caramel. Taste is toasted caramel. Plain.

column1: Sleeping Lady Urban Wilderness Pale Ale
column5: [Tap] Tried this at the brewpub in mid-September. Pours a shade of amber with a large foamy head. Nose is mainly of floral hops and grainy malty notes. Caramel, herbal astringency, bitter hops and mild soap in the taste. Slick mouthfeel. Average carbonation levels. Not a ton happening with this one.

column1: Sleeping Lady Urban Wilderness Pale Ale
column5: Draft at brewery: Amber-orange with a thin head. Medium body. Lots of caramel, toffee and toast, but only a mild sweetness. Moderate hops but subdued aromas. Sessionable, albeit unexciting.

column1: Sleeping Lady Urban Wilderness Pale Ale
column5: (tap) hazy medium amber, small white head; aromas of citrus, tea-with-lemon; flavour on the bitter side, with long medium bitter finish

column1: Sleeping Lady Urban Wilderness Pale Ale
column5: Draft at the pub. Amber-copper with a creamy cover of foam. Faint nose of caramel and citrus. Balanced flavor of caramel, citrus and light resin. Light-medium body is tingly, softly carbonated and very drinkable.

column1: Sleeping Lady Urban Wilderness Pale Ale
column5: Wow - be careful of this one! My can (brought back from Anchorage to Washington) exploded and leaked a bunch out of the malformed top, but luckily didnâ€™t fully explode - so I could sample it. As I cracked the top open (jammed something into the mouth hole), there was another explosion (pressure releasing) and the pour was very slow, since 90% of the beer was head. Crisp cola/iced tea coloured body with an obviously huge tan head thatâ€™s all soap bubbles. Aroma of funky soap, cardboard and stale malt - nothing pleasant at all in here. Medium to Light-bodied; Assertive funky malt and nutty flavours with a lot of peanuts and some soap mixed in. Aftertaste shows a very slight amount of stale hops with more stale malt and a touch of gross bitterness from soap here. Overall, not such a great beer and the whole experience was rather offputting. I enjoyed the can, but not when it explodes, even if its been a few months and came from ~5000 miles away. I sampled this twelve ounce can purchased from La Bodega (Formerly Yukon Spirits) in Anchorage, Alaska on 26-June-2010, sampled at home in Washington on 16-September-2010.

column1: Sleeping Lady Forty Niner Amber Ale
column5: (Tap) bright, clear Amber colour with a medium tall, beige head; aroma of sour candy; balanced flavour with a long, light bitter finish

column1: Sleeping Lady Forty Niner Amber Ale
column5: Clear dark amber color with ivory head. Mild spicy caramel, toast aromas. medium body, average carbonation. Lightly sweet nâ€™ spicy caramel flavors with toast; lightly bitter finish---not bad

column1: Sleeping Lady Forty Niner Amber Ale
column5: Draft: Poured a dark orange with copper edges. The head was white. The aroma is mixed malts. Nice smooth taste with malts and grains.

column1: Sleeping Lady Forty Niner Amber Ale
column5: Amber in color, clear with a thin head. Good malt and hops balance. Nice flavor easy drinking with a dry finish. Very good Amber.

column1: Sleeping Lady Forty Niner Amber Ale
column5: Draft at the source. Bright golden color, medium white head. Aroma of caramel. Taste is yeasty and lightly spiced caramel. Average.

column1: Sleeping Lady Forty Niner Amber Ale
column5: [Tap] Tried this at the brewpub in mid-September. Pours a light amber color with a nice cap of beige head. Sticky and sweet aroma of light brown sugar and caramel malts. Sweet malts, dinner rolls, mild nutty notes and toasted bread in the taste. Virtually no detectable hops here make it a tad too sweet. Low carbonation levels. OK, but not my favorite.

column1: Sleeping Lady Forty Niner Amber Ale
column5: Draft at brewery: Rich malts ... too sweet for me. Notes of caramel, maple syrup and molasses were too strong. Light toast, butterscotch and honey-covered nuts, too. Moderate hops with hints of grass and herbs, but not nearly enough to counteract all the sweetness. Too cloying as well.

column1: Sleeping Lady Forty Niner Amber Ale
column5: 6/09/2009: Sleeping Lady Forty-Niner Amber Ale has a deep, clear, amber to chesnut color that is "pretty" according to my wife. It is roasty with hints of coffee and has a soft, medium-light body. This is a good amber with a nice roasty quality. Sample (draught) at the Snow Goose Restaurant/Sleeping Lady Brewing Company in Anchorage, Alaska. Rating #6 for this beer.

column1: Sleeping Lady Forty Niner Amber Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub, July 10. Attractive color and decent flavor for an amber. I definitely tasted the hops and malt, and thought it was pretty well balanced, with just a touch of bitter and a hint of toffee. This could be a session beer if you wanted drink something safe.

column1: Sleeping Lady Forty Niner Amber Ale
column5: stopped by snow goose for some food, wasnâ€™t too impressed with the forty niner, not much flavor and didnâ€™t really compliment the steak... Iâ€™d go for the IPA or the bravehart first.....
From draft at Snow Goose in Anchorage. Looks like a porter. Minimal head. Mild aroma of chocolate grain. Taste is chocolate malts and sour. Somewhat cloying. Just ok.

on tap @ Snow Goose / Anchorage AK --- This review should be taken with a "grain of salt," because I suspect that either the lines werenâ€™t cleaned properly today, or the batch is beginning to turn. I looked over the other reviews and they have a consensus of impressions that donâ€™t sync with mine. For me, taste begins with semi-sweet malt that grows awkwardly into cedar and a bit of dark fruit, then abandons everything by completly shutting out hops in a finish that continually grows sweeter and more woody. Canâ€™t be what the brewer intentioned.
Pours dark brown with not much light beige head. Aroma is roasted, dark chocolate and coffee. Flavour is roasted, chocolate and light to medium sweet. Pretty thick body and soft carbonation.
On tap at Snow Goose Dark brown with a small beige head, some lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, bready and chocolate. Taste of roasted malts, grains and chocolate Ok, a little thin mouthfeel
Black, thin tan head. Aroma of cocoa, coffee, cola. Flavor: dark bread crusts, moderate roast, chocolate, bakerâ€™s chocolate, hint of toffee, grAiny finish.

Draft: Poured a deep brown with blackened center and reddish orange tint to the edges. The head was off white to tan color. Aroma was nice chocolate and light coffee. Taste is dark chocolate with soft coffee and roasted malts that is robust at first but drinks rather smooth. Iâ€™m sure I could see myself drinking this all day and not worrying with the lower abv.

Growler from LaBodega. Dark reddish brown with a small tan head. Aroma of chocolate roasted coffee and caramel. Flavor is rich semi-sweet chocolate, roasty bitterness with no alcohol taste. Medium to full body with a smooth mouth feel. This is a solid porter, lots of chocolate, some roast and goes down easy.
Dark brown in color, clear with a thin tan head. Nice roast and light chocolate aroma. Good flavor with a coffee chocolate balance and decent hops backing. Very tasty brew.
Draft at the source. Almost black, thin tan head. Aroma of brown bread and coffee. Tasty is roasty and toasty. Medium body. A proper porter.

[Tap] Tried this at the brewpub in mid-September. Pours a very dark brown color with a light brown colored head. Nose is of dark roasted malts, mild mocha notes and a general charred character. The taste is very similar, with some brown sugar, cold coffee and mild anise. Light sweet vanilla bean notes come out as this beer warms. Decent body. A pretty decent brew.
on tapâ€“pours gold with a thin white head. Aroma is pumpkin spice, some bready light/medium malt. Taste is perfumy, pumpkin spice, some bready light/medium malt.
(Draught) Pours a hazy amber-brown body with a medium cream head. Aroma of pumpkin, roasted malt, cinnamon, ginger, and nutmeg. Flavor of pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg, bread, and caramel malt.

Draft. Beige head atop clear amber body. Aroma is medium sweet, nutmeg, allspice, some cinnamon, light clove. Taste is medium sweet, nutmeg, allspice, some clove, light cinnamon. Soft, light-medium body. They got the spices right, but theyâ€™re a little more intense than Iâ€™d like.
On tap at Watch City, Waltham MA, 5 November 2009 @ 5.4%. Clear copper colour. Cookie dough, pie spice aroma. Not a lot else. Light mouthfeel. Standard pumpkin stuff. Not my thing.

Ontap @ brewpub. Good nose, sweet. Like pumpkin pie as it says. Pumpkin and brown sugar and some spice, ginger, cinnamon, nutmeg. Clean orangy brown color, no head. Bittersweet flavors, spice upfront then a grapefruity bitterness creeped in. Medium body, creamy smooth mouthfeel, spiced bitter finish. I was diggin the bitter spiced flavors. Went down easy. As I sat a the brew pub I thought about what it would be likr to live at the aprtments across the street.

2004 draught @ the Brewery. Dark orange brown, not altogether unlike DFH Punkin, but has less of a head on it, transluscent body. Aroma of light grains, some root-like spices (ginger perhaps???). Very odd. Flavor proves to be equally strange. Itâ€™s not overspiced, it just has the strangest mix of spices Iâ€™ve tasted. Itâ€™s slightly astringent, slightly metallic, very herbal. Medium to medium light bodied, little to no pumpkin flesh apparent. Low sweetness to start, some wateriness apparent through the body. Waxes sweet on the end. [2.9] Rerate January 2005. Much better than remembered. Bigger body, like a thick amber ale, with a lovely amount of allspice and cinnamon lingering on. Very flavorful, not nearly as watery. Though I donâ€™t know, Iâ€™d like to think that they improved on their first release. Kinda like what Ramstein did with its winter wheat this winter. Very cool of brewers to be always looking to improve and rerelease.[3.8]

Very nice! A medium-bodied brown ale with pumpkin flavor. Not too spicy, like other pumpkin ales can be. VERY well balanced. I even had two to confirm. October 2010 update: Still wonderful stuff, even after all these years! - Glad I caught some this year. (Bump up rating)

Pours a deep orange-brown, with a nice white head that floats on top until the last sip, lacing well on the way down. Aroma is bready, sweet (pumpkin), and a bit spicy (nutmeg and cinnamon). Flavor is a bit bready to start, sweet with the squash coming through strong in the middle, the spice comes through w/the pumpkin as well, finish is a little spicy. Medium bodied, quite drinkable, although the sweetness might get to be too much after a few mug fulls.

Bottle given to me by rciesla, because he didnâ€™t want it. I donâ€™t blame him. Iâ€™m only rating this for the scavenger hunt. Itâ€™s terrible. Completely flat, dull, spent yeast, overwhelmingly oxidized. A note of celery, bandaid, and... 7up. Dumping this down the drain, which will get me more points.
My favorite of all the winter ale series. One of my favorite beers of all time.

Name: Winter Date: November 06, 2002 Mode: Draft Source: Twains, Decator, GA Vintage: 2002 Appearance: Opaque orange, thin white head Aroma: robust aroma with lots of spices, citrus, and hints of sweetness Flavor: light malt flavor, deceptive, very complex, lots of wheat chahacter upon warming, cloudy but not yeasty, the hefe yeast character does not show until the very end with only the slightest hint of banana or clove Name: Winter Date: November 24, 2002 Mode: draft Source: summits Vintage: 2002 Score: iii Appearance: fine frothy head Aroma: light sweet citrus aroma Flavor: much richer malt flavor, good dose of belgian character Name: Winter Date: December 11, 2005 Vintage: 2002 still sweet, not too much oxidation, complexity fading Name: Winter Date: November 22, 2006 Vintage: 2002 Appearance: clear dark amber, scant head Aroma: big sweet caramel and fruit aroma Flavor: lots of sweet flavor, nice over ripe banana character, touch of earthy bitterness comes in to add balance, actually quite nice especially for a four year old weizenbock Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.7/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **4

12oz bottle via trade with goldtwins - thanks Larry! - Poured cloudy light brown with a short tan head and some lace. Aromas of lots of yeast, some bubblegum and a little clove and bannana. Flavor is fruity with bannana, raisin, clove, and some plum. Palate is rather smooth with medium body and a good amount of balance. This is drinking pretty well almost 5 years later.

Dark, cloudy gold with a yeasty aroma with hints of bubble gum. Lots of complex flavors on parade here from dark fruits to grains to chocolate to caramel. A fair amount of alcohol in the finish, but pretty balanced overall.

Deep brown in color, with nice tan head and light lace. Sweet malts upfront on the nose and slightly phenolic. Rich, sweet malts than a nice chocolaty lingering. slightly spicy on the finish and very clean.
Poured a clear light copper color. Aroma of golden raisins and plums. Sweet and fruity flavor with some more plum and a light citrus fruitness. Medium body.
I enjoyed this fine brew at kpâ€™s tasting. Had an orangish tint upon a base of brown. Bananas were present and some spices, very smooth and well done.

Many thanks to KP for letting me sample this from the cellar. An orange appearance with a moderate head. The flavor had some citrus and a doughy presence was there. Some bananas in the finish. It was complex but well balanced.

Bottle at Heavyweight... Poured a prunish red color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of plums, cloves, yeast and alcohol. Taste of dried fruit, roast, bananas and alcohol as well.
Pepin bÃ¡csi tÃ­zese. KrÃ©mes habvilÃ¡gÃº Ã©s testÅ±, Ã©deskÃ©s malÃ¡taszirup, keser lecsengÃ©ssel.
the aroma is malty and herbal with hints of straw, grain and grasses... the taste is clear and refreshening, malty with notes of grain, hay and some herbs... bitter and dry aftertaste...

Tap at nervosa, bratislava. Pours golden with white head. Aroma is sweet, malt, hops, some caramel. Flavor is sweet and bitter, caramel, malt, hops. Finish has caramel and slight dry hoppiness. Overall: ok, too sweet and not enough hops.
Prakticky tady pÅ™idÃ¡vÃ¡m tento komentÃ¡Å™, jen aby tady nÄ›co bylo, protoÅ¾e zpÄ›tnÄ› dopisuji 900 piv z mÃ©ho seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zblÃ¡znit.

0.5l can thanks to Cristobal37. Deep golden body with an immediately collapsing white head. Aroma and taste of bread, grains, hay and spicy hops. The hoppy character is quite pronounced. Its crisp bitterness, weak body and low alcohol content makes it ideal for the summer heat. Decent session beer for sure.

Can. Rich honey gold color, good carbonation and soapy white head. Malty aroma with some faint floral hops. Crisp beer, light pils, malty and even a little bit watery. The palate is faint hop. Overall a nice session pils. The fact itâ€™s watery makes it great for hot ass summers.
PohodovÃ© normÃ¡lnÃ­ ÄeskÃ© pivo, jeÅ¾ rozhodnÄ› niÄÃ­m neurazÃ­. Na tyto ÄeskÃ© klasiky si vÅ¾dycky rÃ¡d zajdu.. :)

Aroma: diacetyl, light, malty. Nothing special, smells like a classical "DesÃ­tka". Dark, golden colour. Medium head, without lacing. Clarified. Taste is dry, some diacetyl and malty hints. Maybe a bit of caramel. Watery, light body. Bitterness is medium and astringent. Also medium carbonation. A great example of Czech 10. Such a nice, drinkable beer.
Clear gold3n colour, medium sized correct head; aroma and taste of a typical 10Â° Czech pilsner with some sourish and cardboard notes; very easy to drink

Bottle. Golden colour, clear, decent head. Nose is faint, mostly honey. Mouth is clear malty, with a bit of hops. Light bitterness, but itâ€™s enough in this case. Light body, but not watery. Nothing spectacular, but itâ€™s a good simple light beer.
amazingly soft. like drinking a pillow. just a shame itÂ´s pretty flavourless

Bottle (500ml, BBE 2/20) from Marks & Spencer, Bristol as â€œNorfolk Bitter.â€ Copper-amber pour, translucent, good sized tan-coloured head that hangs around. Aroma and taste is caramel malts, mild citrus, subtle dark fruits and a little earthiness. Easy drinking palate with soft carbonation and a lightish body. A solid English Bitter.
Bottle from Mark. Medium, clear amber, small foamy head subsides. Caramel malts in the aroma and taste, light bitterness trails. This is the M&S version, labelled as Norfolk Bitter.

Pint at Carnival Inn, Bridgwater (JDW). Pours clear amber small white head. Aroma: biscuit malts, earthy hops. Taste: light to moderate bitter, light fruity citrus. Low to moderate carbonation, smooth texture, light body, semi dry, bitter finish.
Cloudy pint at ye olde rose and crown Walthamstow. Sweet nose nice rich fruitcake taste, almost no bittering hop presence
Malt and hop aroma, clean tasting session bitter, with some sweetness on the finish

500ml bottle [from a trade with Grumbo, thanks a lot for the ship-themed label!]. Wonderful clear, reddish, dark amber colour with average, thick, fluffy, moderately lasting minimally lacing, off-white head. Floral hoppy and mellow malty aroma, somehow inseparable honey-pollen-orange-butter-cake-christmas stollen (fruit loaf) flavours. Taste is slightly dry, floral and slightly fruity hoppy, hints of raisin and orange zest with a minimally soapy touch, candied orange zest, malty basis with minimal residual sweetness, hints of panettone, stollen or the like (I never had Dundee cake.as possibility of comparison). Paradigmatic for the possible richness of a Bitter.

500ml bottle from M&S. Pours amber with a fluffy tan head. Aromas of caramel, dried fruit, fruit cake and citrus rind. Quite a rich taste and slightly sticky mouthfeel. Taste is caramel, sultana cake, toast, earthy and hoppy in the finish. Decent beer, but not a beer Iâ€™d want to desperately have again.
Caramel, dark fruits, light amber color, watery, empty, a bit acidic, estery, fruity.
2016 catch up - Bottle at home after it was doscovered going cheap at M&S. A reasonable bitter. Nothing spectacular, but a very good pint for Â£1.25.

Sharp dry hops with a metalic taste lovely head and dry fruit stickyness. Its okay but not a huge fan. Its lifted by a lovely silky texture the sprt that is rarely found in a 4.5% beer. On gravity: this is a different beast. Heavy toffee notes with a a dry finish. Lovely kept
Cask conditioned at The Old Chapel Inn, St Annes Chapel, Devon. Brown amber with no head. Unfortunate tart, tainted beer, a standard malty bitter but well past its best. Poor stuff.
Tawny red in colour. This is malty and dry on the palate. Finish hangs around for some time. Slightly smokey, but doesn''t set the world on fire.
Pieczony razowiec choc nie bardzo intensywny. Faktycznie poczÄ…tkowa slodycz ktora przechodzi w wytrawnosc. Barwa miedziana.
Bel colore ambrato, schiuma persistente. Molto rotonda al palato. Ottima la nota caramellata. Si sentono molto le note dei lieviti aiutate anche dal fatto che non Ã¨ filtrata.

Flasche 0,5l: Dunkles Mahagoni, dezente TrÃ¼bung, krÃ¤ftiger stabiler mittelporiger Schaum; sehr wÃ¼rzige Nase, RÃ¶staromen, eher trocken, RÃ¶stmalz, Getreide, dunkles Karamell, trockene Hopfennoten, leichte trockene SÃ¤ure, Haselnussschalen, dezente Rauchnoten; frischer + sehr wÃ¼rziger KÃ¶rper, eher trocken, RÃ¶stmalz, Getreide, dunkles Karamell, cremig, krÃ¤ftige KohlensÃ¤ure, dezente trockene Hopfennoten, leichte SÃ¤ure, dunkle Brutkruste, getrocknete FrÃ¼chte, dezente Rauchnoten; angenehmer malzig-trockener Nachgang
A really nice caramel body to this one. Lots of depth to the flavour, complex and clean. Not perfect, but very good. Fristo dresden

0,5 l swing top bottle. Unclear dark red brown in the glass with a more than two finger beige frothy head. looks really good. Smells sweet malty. Taste starts malty, increasing toasted with some sweetness.Thins out in the second part.
0,5 l bottle NÃ¼rnberg - muddy like brown with small head - aromas of fruit grapes malts - tastes sweet bitter
Im Aroma feuchtes Moos, Rasen, Brot, Malz. Im Geschmack zeigt sich das Bier sÃ¼ffig, wenig bitter, stark malzig, mit vielen Ester-Aromen.
Bottle as Kellerbier unfiltriert. Dark Amber colour, frothy head that stays for a while. Aroma is caramel, cellar. Light sweetness. Feels too heavy and not drinkable.

Pours auburn from the bottle. A creamy head lingers. Typical Kellerbier aroma: musty and dank with nuts, caramel and dark fruits in the background. Taste is sweet up front, finishes with a lingering mild bitterness. Medium body. Smooth. High drinkability. Not usually a favorite style of mine but this one is good!

0.5l bottle from a Getrankemarkt in Bayern. Brown body with ruby hint. Beige head vanishing with medium speed. Moderate aromas of cocoa, coffee and caramel. Quite nice. Typical Bavarian sweet taste, sweets coming from caramel and chocolate. Some spices also detectable. Aftertaste is mild, neutral, with a bit of bread-like sourness. Carbonation moderate, palate is silky, seducing. Easy drinking, refreshing. Nothing special, but very harmonic. My first ever dark kellerbier.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Dark brown with solid tan head and good lacing. The aroma hinted of burnt malts, hazelnut, aromatic fuggles hops, dusty yeast esters. The taste starts nutty and sweet with a mild bitter and smoky finish. The mouthfeel left me wanting more, thin and lively. An okay porter, worth a try.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Clear dark dark brown color and a low tight head. Burnt, roasted malt with tobacco tones. High dry finish. Thin-ish. Bold flavor but overall not so successful.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Very light sweet malt nose. Black with hints of red. Roasted malt and dark chocolate taste, but like by all the others very light. Only the brewpub by itself is really worth a visit, as it is a nice buildung.

Flip-top 65cl brown bottle, picked up during a beer raid into Europe at a Channel port booze warehouse (Pidou in Dunkirk actually, donâ€™t you know?). Best before Aug 2009, drank Aug 2008. Poured most into a Duvel glass and the rest (for the wife) into a Veltins Pilsner stemmed tulip glass. Looked good in both glasses, large white head, which stayed for a while before fading to a clingy covering until the end. Mid amber body with good carbonisation rising through the beer. Yeast, straw and hops vie for a place in the aroma, none of them winning, so a mixed bag for a smell. Very dry and bitter taste, not what I was expecting at all. I had been cutting logs and generally getting sweaty before I had this and wanted something refreshing, wrong choice. Not sure what to add, without slanging it off, which would be a bit unfair. Strange beer, looks good and is well packaged. It just doesnâ€™t deliver what it appears to promise. Nothing wrong with it, but it didnâ€™t Rock my Boat.

500ml bottle I drank probably 5 or 6 years ago, I got it from the ANBL location in Fredericton. A little sad to see they went out of business, but given the $5/bottle price tag and the poor reviews on here itâ€™s not shocking. Despite the negativity here, I rather liked this beer, although it seemed rather odd for a blonde. The colour was a fair bit darker than Iâ€™d have expected and it had a bit of a hops and alcohol bite to it.
Canned (Carrafour version). Yellow coloured. Cleaer. Off white fluffy head. Straw and alcohol in the nose. Sweet, malty and dense alcohol in the flavour. Thin bodied. Sweets and alcohol in the end.
Canned. Golden colour, minimal head. Aroma of corn and alcohol. Sweet, boring and only just drinkable.

Weak malt aroma, rubbery hops, straw. White foamy lacing head over yellow clear liquid. Med-hi card & watery body. Weak malt & hops. Stale watery corn & industrial bitter with astringent after. Alcohol.
clear golden colour, fine head, nice lacing, caramel and orange with a touch of alcohol in the nose, very sweet and quite light-bodied, short neutral finish - hmmm...
Distusting aroma and flavor. Strong alcohol taste. Another horrible french beer :(

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Yellow-orange and greatly topped. Distinctly malty nose. Velvety smooth, strong malt presence with sharp bitter hop complements, but lacked the "right" balance.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Fresh, bright hop nose, reddish amber color and a low head. Clear hop bitterness predominates the flavor profile. Turns slightly unpleasant in the end. Amateurish beer, but one of the better ones at Harvest Moon.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Apple and hops nose. Amber golden color. Hops dold taste, very intense, medium bitter aftertaste.
A norwegian, copper Amber Lager / Vienna witj light head. Aroma is malt, caramel, yeast, tea, light raisin. Taste is bitter sweet.

Can 330ml. @ home. [ As Mack God Jul - Godt Nytt Ã…r ]. ABV: 4.5%, Clear medium to dark orange amber colour with a average to large, frothy - creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, hay, straw, caramel, sweet malt, light grain, light bread - sweet bread. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, sweet malt, hay - straw, caramel. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20181227] 5-3-5-3-9
Et helt OK Ã¸l. MellommÃ¸rkt i farge. Smakfullt, passer godt som bÃ¥de matÃ¸l og til Ã¥ nytes alene. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Can.Dark golden colour with medium white head.Aroma of malt and caramel medium bitter and bready sweet bor thin overall.
Ganske god og velsmagende juleÃ¸l. Tilpas med julekrydderier. Lidt for let. Savner aroma
Kastanjefarget med lavt skum. Lukter karamell, hÃ¸y og noe nÃ¸tter, Smaken godt balansert mellom malt og gjÃ¦rsmaker. Litt over gjennomsnittet til Ã¥ vÃ¦re norsk makro jul. rene smaker.
RÃ¸dbrun farge med tynt hvit skum. Lukter karamellmalt og svakt av krydder. Litt vannete i munnfÃ¸lelse. Lettdrikkelig.

Appearance Pours a clear deep red, with a cream coloured dense head, that quickly dissipates to a ring, leaving some lacing Aroma Burnt sugar, freshly roasted coffee, nuts, forest fruits Taste Sweet, with a subtle and mild bitterness Palate Mild carbonation, medium body
Red with white head. Cardboard, corn and some caramel. Slick, dry and floral. Not bad.

(Flasche, 2016) Es hat eine hellbraune Farbe mit einem leichten bernstein Einstich, ist filtriert mit einer fast weiÃŸen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist dominiert von bretanomyces, phenolen, leichte Kirschnote und etwas Malz. Der Geschmack ist schlank, trocken eitwas matt und einer leichten Kellernote

Aroma has some hay, dough and basement aromas. Cloudy and pale color, minimal head. Yasty and sweet taste, not very typical witbier. Palate is sticky, and this is not a compliment. This was just a horrible experience.
330ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours clear golden with a thin white persistent head. Aromas of light spice, light yeast. Taste is light sweet malt, bread, spice. Clean finish.
25cl Flasche mit skurilem Esel-Comic-Etikett. Noch mit 5,8%. Hell und trÃ¼bes Bier mit schÃ¶nem Schaum. Frischer und leicht herber Duft. Hefe und Citrus Geschmack. KrÃ¤uter im Abgang.
Ligeramente anaranjada y turbia con poca espuma. Aroma algo dulce y citrico. Carbonatacion media, no mucho cuerpo ni destaca por nada en especial, algo plana, aunque definitivamente entra bien.
TrÃ¼bes orange goldenes Bier mit einer geringen weiÃŸen schaumkrone. Geruch sÃ¼ÃŸ, oxidiert, leicht hefig. Geschmack sÃ¼ÃŸ, alkoholisch, oxidiert, reife FrÃ¼chte,trocken.
Oxidiert krÃ¤utriger Antrunk, herb, etwas malzig. Quasi nicht hefig, passend milder Alkohol. SÃ¼ffig, gut trinkbar. 8/9/8/9/8/9

Bottle from de Bierschuur in Poppel. The beer is hazy and deep golden colored, has a small and unstable white head, the carbonation is a little too low. In the aroma are tones noticable of apricots, flowers, spices and in the background some malts and wheat. The taste is fresh and medium bodied and some alcohol is noticable. The finish is light bitter with tones of coriander. Not a typical white, but itâ€™s ok.

Robe blonde, reflets ambrÃ©s, belle mousse. Nez houblonnÃ© et fruitÃ©, Ã©volue vers le citron. Bouche Ã  lâ€™attaque ample, une belle mousse, une note Ã©picÃ©e, une finale amÃ¨re assez raffraÃ®chissante. Belle biÃ¨re mais pas trÃ¨s typÃ©e blanche.
Lichtbruin troebel bier zonder schuim. Smaak is licht zoet en lichtbitter met een kruidige smaak. Vreemd om dit een witbier te noemen. Etiket is inmiddels gewijzigd.
"poured pretty yellow for a white. average at best - the yeast, coriander and/or citrus just isnâ€™t very assertive, but thereâ€™s really nothing that takes away from it either. falls just short

column1: Michelob Seasonal Brew All Malt Lager
column5: Pours a clear golden yellow from the bottle with bubbly white head that dissipates to leave light lace. Aroma and taste of mild sweet maltiness and adjunct rice, a hint of floral bs hops. Clean and simple, another mass produced light lager.

column1: Michelob Seasonal Brew All Malt Lager
column5: Bottle. Pours clear yellow with low head. Aroma is wheat, yeast and fruits. Palate is watery. Taste is wheat and hops.

column1: Michelob Seasonal Brew All Malt Lager
column5: Bottle. Pours a clear, light amber with a thin, fizzy head. Easy malt aroma with some grains. Sweet flavor with some sugar and cereal. Light bodied with average carbonation. Finishes malty, basically no bitterness. Nothing too wrong here.

column1: Michelob Seasonal Brew All Malt Lager
column5: Hay, citrus, in the aroma. Not unpleasant. Color a wan yellow with a big head that dissapates quickly. Thin mouth feel with a light, clean, mild taste.Call it a guilty pleasure and drink it really cold.

column1: Michelob Seasonal Brew All Malt Lager
column5: Bottle: Poured a yellow with off white head. Aroma is malt and corn. Taste full malt flavor, light hop and corn blend.

column1: Michelob Seasonal Brew All Malt Lager
column5: Well at least give them an A for effort. They are trying not succeding but trying. Itâ€™s not horrible and it was for free . Coppery pour with a malty and mild citrus aroma. Some hop in their. Itâ€™s an attempt at something here.

column1: Michelob Seasonal Brew All Malt Lager
column5: I was reviewing old family videoâ€™s recently when I saw that I had gotten a Mic variety pack for Christmas â€™01â€™ with this beer in it. I remember enjoying this one. It was similar to a Amber.

column1: Michelob Seasonal Brew All Malt Lager
column5: Appearance: Pours a bright, deep golden body with a medium white head. Smell: Toasted grains and very light caramel with soft musty, floral notes. Taste: Exceedingly mild malt flavor and sweetness. Barely a dash of Noble-esque hops. Finishes relatively sweet. Mouthfeel: Light-bodied. Medium carbonation. Drinkability: Refreshing, inexpensive, and not nearly as bothersome as the vast majority of the other macro beers, so really I canâ€™t complain.

column1: Michelob Seasonal Brew All Malt Lager
column5: I am only rating this because it is a big step in the right direction for BMC beers. Pours a honey gold with a spritzy head that instantly fades. Lots of honey and caramel in the nose, possibly diacetyl as well. Lively carbonation. The body is light and drinkable, with subtle notes of hay and dough. The hops are barely noticable, but do add a slight grassy note to balance things. This isnâ€™t my favorite style by any means, but this easily rises above all the other "adjunct" ridden beers in its class. Hopefully this all-malt idea catches on with the masses.

column1: Michelob Seasonal Brew All Malt Lager
column5: Poured a nice goldish color. Nice and malty, and was great when served ice cold. Should be made more available.
Aug 2019 Rising Sun, Lynmouth, North Devon. Rough like a home brew, but at least not as sweet as other Exmoor beers. OK.

Cask pint on 18th July 2018 at The Thelbridge Cross Inn, just outside Witheridge, Devon. Light amber, clear and bright, the head a thin white blanket of foam. Malty front to the semi-sweet brew in both the nose and taste, mild bitterness creeps in later to give a nicely balanced easy drinking 'Cooking Bitter'.
Tried at the Orchard Inn, Nr Taunton. Pale amber colour with a white head. Aroma is light malty caramel. Taste light sweet to light bitter medium body.

Cask at The Cobblers, Leek. A clear pale amber colour with a thin white head. Aroma of biscuit, some caramel, slight lemon and subtle spicy hops. Taste of biscuit, some caramel, slight lemon, a little butter and subtle spicy hops. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A short, malty, biscuity bitterness in the finish. Started promising with a good balance of malt and hops but very bland, biscuity and buttery after a while. Below average.

tap at the Black Horse in Sidmouth. Golden with a small but creamy white head and promising hopy aromas. Light-bodied, yet full of malty goodness and lots of citrusy, fruity hops. Smooth palate. Perfectly balanced, easy drinking and full of flavour. Good, good stuff!
Cask@the longhorn, walsall. Amber beer with medium foam head. Aroma is malts and a touch of sulphur. Taste is same with some mild hop presence. Drinkable.
Fra cask pÃ¥ The Lamb, Bloomsbury 23 Sep 14. MÃ¸rk gyldenbrun. Lavt tett skum. Smaken har et lite preg av fjÃ¸s. Smaken er litt tynn men en aner tÃ¸rket frukt.

On cask at the Haymarket. Appearance - amber with a decent head. Nose - faint biscuity toffee with an unwelcome sulphur note. Taste - toffee and biscuit. Palate - close to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a fairly good finish. Overall - wonâ€™t return to this one.
Cask at GBBF set up 11/8/14. Pours mid brown with a white head. Aroma of caramel and toffee. Short bitter finish. Quaffable ale that went well with curry.
Bona cervesa molt equilibrada i gustosa. Buena cerveza muy equilibrada y sabrosa.

I had this at the same time as the regular "HvidtÃ¸l" from Thor. I found them very like each other, but this is sweeter and has hints of licorice. Itâ€™s very dark brown with a small head and a sweet aroma with notes of roasted malt. The flavour is sweet with notes of roasted malt, caramel and hints of licorice. Just like the regular "HvidtÃ¸l" from Thor itâ€™s quite OK - but not outstanding in this class.
[Sampled in 2005.] Uhhh, this was a nasty too sweet brew for me even to risengrÃ¸d. Like something from a bubblegum-"factory".

Bottle. Dark brown color with a average frothy good lacing mostly lasting light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, sweet malt, roasted, brown sugar. Flavor is heavy sweet with a average to long duration. body is medium, texture is syrupy / watetery, carbonation is flat.
Bottle. Black colour with a beige head. Aroma is prunes and fruit. Flavour is sweet, malt, prunes.

Bottled. Clear, deep, reddish brown, with a beige head. Caramel, sweetness and fruit-syrup in the aroma. Caramel, fruity-syrup, sugar and hints of mocha in the flavor. Thin and sticky mounthfeel and a sweet finish with some papery notes. The Danish HvidtÃ¸lâ€™s is best enjoyed with a sweet and creamy dessert, and this is no exception. (070104)
Just like the Thor Taffel Ã˜l, just bit sweeter. Also goes under the label of "Urban JulehvidtÃ¸l", still the very same beer.

Bottled - Urban: Dark brown/red colour. Light brown head. Sweet, malty and caramelly nose. Flavour is sweet as other of these julehvidtÃ¸l, but not as cloying as others tend to be. Some brown sugar, spice and caramel notes. Is medium bodied. Ends on a sugary note. Thaks to Ungstrup for this.
Reddish colour with a medium browish mostly lasting head. Sweet sweet aroma of caramel, licorice and sugar. Sweet taste. Watery body

A deep red beer with a huge brown head. The aroma is very sweet with notes of licorice, caramel, and straw. The flavor is also very sweet with strong notes of licorice, caramel, and straw. But ofcourse the body is thin. A nice HvidtÃ¸l. Earlier Rating: 11/27/2002 Total Score: 3 A dark brown beer with an OK light brown head. It has a very sweet aroma with hints of liqurice. The flawor is also very sweet and dominated by liqurice. It's a typical danish hvidtÃ¸l brewed for Christmas - a nice beer, but too sweet to more than one at a time except if You are a child.
A dark brown beer with an OK light brown head. It has a very sweet aroma with hints of liqurice. The flawor is also very sweet but not too sweet
big scratchy hop mired in alcohol soul and some woody malt. not that there is anything wrong with that! smooth body, bitter and some sweet sugar syrup. easy pine and citrus.

Bottle pour. Clear dark golden with a large creamy off white head. Very nice strong aroma of pine, grass, grapefruit, and citrus. Medium silky body. Light sweet, light bitter, followed by a salty finish.

Bottle. Pours bronze with a little head that dissipates. Aroma is mostly cotrus and fresh forest pine. Taste follows particularly grapefruit, with loads of semi sweet caramel. Hoppy bitter finish. Classy dipa, really enjoyable. Not my fav Alpine brew, but a good one nevertheless.

12oz bottle at home (via trade). Pours hazy golden orange with s long lasting creamy off white head. Flavors are grapefruit, tangerine, mango, dank pine, grass, sourdough. Medium carb, medium full body. Moderately dank finish becomes more bitter as it lingers, ends with pepper and some alcohol. Excellent.
Tap @ City Beer SF. Pours deep gold, white head. Citrus, floral, grass, grapefruit, pine, pith. Clean and hoppy guy.
Pours amber with fizzy head. Potent aroma of citrus medley and peel, flowers, biscuits and grass. Citrus flavors with fermented fruit, sourdough bread, dank with a touch of wafer, hops finish.

Draught @ Alpine Beer Pub, Alpine. Pours hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma of malt, rich fruity hops, peach, mango, citrus, grapefruit, pine. Flavor is rather bitter, malt, rich hoppy, grassy, fruit, citrus, mango, grapefruit, pine. Medium to full body, average carbonation, lasting bitter finish. 240718

On tap at World of Beer in Bethesda, MD. Hazy, amber gold with a near-white head and good lacing. Aroma of citrus, pine, biscuit and a touch of tropical fruit. Taste of citrus, tropical fruit and pine. Medium body and medium carbonation. And a previous review: On tap at Carpool in Herdon, VA. Lightly hazy orangish gold with a near-white head and very good lacing. Aroma of apricot, pine, dank forest duff, tangerine and touches of tropical fruit. Taste of pine, tangerine, caramel, pineapple, dankness, bitter grapefruit and touches of tropical fruit. Medium/full body and medium/high carbonation.

Poured from the tap. Hazy yellowish orange with beige head. Pine and grass hops with some mild citrus and even a hint of tropical hops. Great balance and blend despite so many flavours and has a chewy caramel malt underlay.
Amber gold, white head.Lightly funky citrus nose.Fruity palate, good malt & med alcohol heat/bitterness. Big body

Date: February 15, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: opaque dark amber, creamy beige head, bits of lace Aroma: rich malt aroma with lots of earthy hops, touch of fruity character, brown sugar sweetness Body: big body Flavor: rich sweet and fruity flavor, dark caramel sweetness, nice fruits, plenty of balancing earthyness, touch of peppery alcohol disapates upon warming Overall: the perfect answer after a seven hour drive Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.8/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **4
Daft at Brewpub. Poured a ruby reddish dark color. Aroma is sweet flroal with a hop smell. Taste is excellent the floral and malt is mixed well.
Draught at the brewpub, Dallas Dark amber color. Good hop aroma, very good malt flavor, full bodied, with an aggressive hopping and big quality. Iâ€™m impressed!

this was 3 years old...and it was GOOOOD!!! i canâ€™t really put into writing how good this was..it has about 12% but i could not tell, subtle and complex, delicous and magical, dangerously good and sneaky..leaves a very nice aftertaste..good head even..this is why i LOVE english barleywines..sweet and delictable..A+.

Out of the tap at Two Rows in Houston. Dark, ruby colored. Very small head. Rich aroma of malts and fruits. Very rich/strong malt/fruit bitter-sweet taste. Had to drink this one slow. Went great with the steak. This is the second barleywine I have tasted. I was not disapointed, but barleywine really isnâ€™t my favorite.

ruby pour with a ring of grey for a head. sugared caramel like a vaporized caramel square. a delightful experience that starts gently with a vinous taste of caramel, a cherry note that envelopes. a wonderfull oozing alcohol syrup. alcohol lingers with strawberry and cinnamon. a great english style barley wine.
Copper in color with a small white head.Aroma of rich malt and fruit, with moderate amount of alcohol coming through.Bitter-sweet flavor with citus notes,malt sweet with rasin-like charcater.
Rotten raisin and dough mixed with old, bitter yeast. Good thing this was only a sampler size; my stomach could not possibly have tolerated any more of this mess.

A reasonable stab at a world-class west coast barleywine, however it fumbles the ball and just becomes overbearing in the final analysis. Super fruity aroma over a cold water caste, vanilla-esque from the alcohol. Creamy, coating head. Medium, lightly hazy cherrywood color. Lacks the complexity fo the Pacific bruisers, but pretty well done for heavy-handed hopping. Citrus, wood, cream, well-bittered. Finishes a bit too bitter for a bit too long.
Man you can smell the booze in this one. Nice dark brown. Smells of stewed plums and desert sand. Not bad. Taste is excellent. Overall not abd I could dirnk a few of these...and then pass out. G-rat
Average beer, nice flavor, a bit watery. Subtle hoppiness to go with the sweetened malt. Clean, nild finish.
Good beer, nut not really what i would consider a bock. Fruity aroma and fruity taste., Very easy to drink. Just not really a bock.
QUITE undeserving of the bock moniker. At best, a very weak maibock. Mininal aroma, and the flavor was more like a wheat beer. Slight cola in the finish.
Tawny reddish colour, a malty, toasty caramel accent, but is kind of thin and disappears quickly.
(Bottle) Nice color dark with a tan head. Really coffee aroma, Nice malt coffee flavor carries in a bit of smoke alcohol coming through the finish. Pretty decent
Toasty, firm, with a hint of mint. Strong at 7%, and shows it a bit. Big winter warmer of a "London" porter.

Zugegeben, als ich dieses Bie vor einigen jahren getrunken habe, war ich sehr bierdurstig, was wohl etwas Zusatz-Begeisterung hervorrief. Aber ist es ist ein klassisches, solides Helles mit einem wÃ¼rzig-malzigen Kern, der aber doch etwas Platz fÃ¼r den Hopfen lÃ¤sst.

Love a nice little piece of Hell. Fuller, glossier, chunkier than the Dortmunder with deeper rusk and honey malt drifting towards England. Aroma of dried rosemary, honey, blossom and macaroon. A mineral suggestion on the tongue; bit of bicarbonate, honey, toasted white loaf, dewy grass and rusk. Bright and lacy. Good. 500ml from Rugby Rd.
0.5l bottle, thanks Fil! Golden body, white head. Huge grainy, cereally sweetish aroma. In the taste, cereals rule again, honeyish, slightly soapy and flowery. Okay lager.
Clear golden. Aroma is grassy herbs forward a little honey. Taste is harsh sweet and bitter herbs at first. A bit metallic and herbal later. Ok.
Jasna, sÅ‚omkowa barwa. Aromat sÅ‚odki, zboÅ¼owy. W smaku mokre zboÅ¼e, zioÅ‚owa, tÄ™pa goryczka.
Klassisches und sehr angenehmes Helles mit leichter Vanille und Heunote. Durchaus sÃ¼ffig, zum Abschluss wÃ¼rzig, sÃ¼ffig. Gut !

Flasche 0,5l (ABV: 5.0%): Golden, glasklar, mÃ¤ÃŸig stabiler mittelporiger Schaum; fruchtig-frische + leicht sÃ¼ÃŸe Nase, deutlich wÃ¼rzig, Malz, Getreide, leichte fruchtige Hopfennoten, leicht nussig, dezente trockene Bitterkeit; frischer + dezent fruchtiger KÃ¶rper, dezente WÃ¼rze, Malz, Getreide, leichte trockene Hopfennoten, cremig, krÃ¤ftige KohlensÃ¤ure, leichte Zitrusnoten, dezente trockene SÃ¤ure; angenehmer fruchtig-wÃ¼rziger Nachgang
Classic Helles. Pours golden with white head, that dilapidates quickly. Aroma and taste are predominantly grain, rather sweet. Drinkable.

Ar: Sulfer; straw, hay, and dried bouquet of flowers; dry crackers. Ap: Pale gold and clear; large white head with good retention, leaving a cap of airy foam with a waxy-textured cover and bits of lacing. T: Chalk and bitters; sulfur and bitterness is almost bracing; cracker malt; black licorice; finish is chalk and more bitters. P: Light body with very high carbonation; very dry finish. O: Some nice hop and malt flavors here, but the sulfur and bitterness elements are just too bracing, almost astringent.

500ml bottle. Poured a mrky amber with almost no head. Must have gotten an old bottle, the look and taste of this was off. Over ripe dark fruits, very little hop notes. Down the drain with most of it.

This was a quite unique experience. According to the label the beverage has 80 % beer and 20 % "of something else with caffeine" I can''t taste the beer. the drink reminds me most of all of Red Bull. However it is pretty refreshing. It has a strong smell and taste of artificial cherry.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Aroma is malty, a bit spicy with a hint of chocolate. The taste is not what I expected: chocolate and lots of it.A bit of caramel and vanilla as well. Not unpleasant at all.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: This â€˜wasâ€™ a great beer in the past, but this 2018 winter season, my first try of the season, this beer has gone down hill dramatically with the full Port background in past years replaced by what tastes and smells like artificial coffee and fake chocolate flavours and aromas

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: BiÃ¨re dessert qui ne fera pas trop grossir, la Winter Ale est trÃ¨s parfumÃ©e sans pour autant avoir une grande complexitÃ©. La vanille domine tout ici, mÃªme si sucre brun, cacao, gateau Ã©picÃ©e se laisse goutÃ©. Le problÃ¨me c'est que la vanille semble artificielle ce qui la dissocie des saveur de malt et houblons qui semble avalÃ© par la levure. Je la prÃ©fÃ¨re en bouteille qu'en canette car plus caractÃ©riel.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: A sugary sweet aroma, with notes of coffee and malt, pours a clear dark reddish brown color with a thick tan head. Taste is sweet almost has a maple syrup taste, notes of vanilla, coffee and sweet malt. Body is a bit thin and the finish is sweet malt.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Bottle in Canada. Aroma is chocolat much, cocao, overwhelming. Poured dark amber, no head. Taste is chocolat, nuts, heavy sweetness.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Hazy brown with a quick dissipating head. Smell is 90% chocolate, like a hot cocoa powder. Taste is predominately sweet. Again, chocolate with cream. There's some hop presence, but it's drowned in sugar. Not what I would expect a winter ale to be.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: It's a great cold winter evening sipping beer. Malty, dark amber-copper with an off-white head. Coco + flowery hops aroma; sweetvmalt caramel toffee/fudge taste with early notes of vanilla. Smooth, creamy and easy to drink while the snow is coming down. Great on-mountain snowboarding brew. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Pours clear, light cola with a medium sized foamy burned butter head. Big nose of chocolate, with notes of mild leafy hop. Flavour is extremely sweet. Lots of chocolate cookie dough, and vanilla. Traces of wood and earth. Herbal hops. Touches of berry tart. The description is weirdly non descript. "Special" this, and "Premium" that. Not 100% sure this is always consistent. It's definitely tasty for a winter sipper. Don't think I'd want to have more than two in a row. If it weren't for some bitterness, this would be quite cloying. Body is deceptively medium/thin. It actually has the same or more chocolate in there than Rogue's or Young's Chocolate Stout. Caramel/Molasses. Definitely has the Tootsie-Roll flavour many other raters describe. Is that a good thing? Maybe. It would be a good introductory beer in a flavour profile. More of a chocolate porter than an ESA. Chocolate and Crystal malts. Not sure if there is oatmeal in with the malts or not, but more would make it luscious. Finish is quite sticky. Enjoyable.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Can. Tootsie roll aroma. Sort of messy Tootsie roll aroma with fruit... Like a Tootsie Pop I guess. It's drinkable but not my first choice in winter ales.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Best on tap (draught.) If in bottle or can then pour into separate glass. Requires less agitation than a lager of course. Vanilla w caramel. Great beer on a cold day. Garbage beer on a hot day.

column1: Ballast Point Tongue Buckler Imperial Red Ale
column5: 12oz bottle at home. Copper colour, medium tan head, aroma of sweet tobacco, burnt sugar, rye, some orange. Flavour is bitter resin, rye grains, booze, some tobacco notes. Bitter finish

column1: Ballast Point Tongue Buckler Imperial Red Ale
column5: 355ml bottle bought at Owlsome Bottles in New Town Plaza, Sha Tin. Looks: Clear amber brown colour; One and a quarter finger head with crumpety off-white foam which lasts for 2 minutes; Excellent good sticky lacing with quite fizzy slight carbonation. Aroma: Very fragrant Amber malt, with strong toasts. caramel, toffee, strong red fruits, strong citrus, floral, sugar, spices, strong resins, biscuits, lemon and strong grass. Taste: Mid to strong sweet full Amber malt, with strong grapefruits, strong red fruits, strong caramel, toffee, toast, floral, sugar, spice, pine, very strong resins, biscuits, lemon, very strong bitter hops and sharp grass. Body: Close to full body; Slick and very oozy palate. Mouth Feel: Full Amber maltyness in a very solid background. Intensely malty and astringent hoppy with full red fruits, grapefruits, caramel and toast. Flowery with nice strong sweetness. Spicy, very oozy piney with strong lemon to round. Very strong and nice! Hoppiness: Strong citrus, floral, spices, strong resins, lemon and strong grass in nose. Strong grapefruits, floral, spices, pine, very strong resins, lemon and sharp grass in taste; Bitterness is very strong for a lasting, very high astringent bitter sweet Amber malty finish. After taste: Quite dry. Very oozy citrusy and strong bitter to mouth. Comments: What can you do to make it a simple Amber Ale even better? You do it like this one: turn up the volume with full-on toasty red fruit and caramel maltyness, plus massive hopping to the point that astringency not bitterness overtake the palate, with very citrus oozy taste but stopped just short of being uncomfortable. Strong and effective, recommended!

column1: Ballast Point Tongue Buckler Imperial Red Ale
column5: Bottle. BB 16.01.2020. Sweetish, jammy. Iron hints. Bog berry bitterness. Crispish, but relatively easy-drinking. Piney-resinous dry on the palate. Boggy kinda. Medicinal / cough syrup hints, especially in the finish. I like it at points but then again I feel like it's got quite a rough overall character.

column1: Ballast Point Tongue Buckler Imperial Red Ale
column5: Bottle. Red berries, boysenberry, wine and sugar. Bitter with raspberry, boysenberry and plum with some booze. Bitter, sticky and sweet. Very wine-y. Quite nice.

column1: Ballast Point Tongue Buckler Imperial Red Ale
column5: Bottle. Amber color with quite thick off-white head. Aroma has caramel, hay, nuts and dark fruits. Taste is malty with long quite sweet and bitter aftertaste. Flavors of caramel, dark fruits, resin, wood and vanilla.

column1: Ballast Point Tongue Buckler Imperial Red Ale
column5: Kuparia ja mahonkia oluen vÃ¤rissÃ¤. Tuoksu aluksi makean maltainen, hieman keksimÃ¤inen, mutta tÃ¤mÃ¤n jÃ¤lkeen kuvioihin tulee humalan sitruksisuus. Makuprofiili on tÃ¤ytelÃ¤inen. Maltaat tuovat makeutta, mutta humalan puraisu katkaisee sitÃ¤ hyvin. Loistava vahva ale-olut.

column1: Ballast Point Tongue Buckler Imperial Red Ale
column5: Bottle. Amber, hazy, small to average and mostly diminishing head. Moderate, malty and sweetish aroma, light - some caramel and dark fruits, some hoppyness and light alcohol. Body is medium, light - some caramel and dark fruits, some hoppyness and light - some alcohol. Finish is average, malty and lightly sweetish sweetish, light - some caramel and light dark fruits, some hoppyness and light - some alcohol. Caramel sweetish. Decent bitterness though.

column1: Ballast Point Tongue Buckler Imperial Red Ale
column5: bottle, alko. ambery clear. dry caramels, dry butterscotchy malty nose, dusty. dry pines. everything seems dry on nose. full bodied, smooth, clean. well bittered, clean dry bitter piney slight woody finish. lots of flavour, some green herbyness. quite bitter dry asa.

column1: Ballast Point Tongue Buckler Imperial Red Ale
column5: Pullo @ Alko. Kaatuu IPA-lasiin kuparisena ja kirkkaana, noin 2,5 sormen paksuisen muhkean vaahdon suojaamana. column1: Ballast Point Tongue Buckler Imperial Red Ale
column5: Bottle 355ml at home. Bottled 2018-01-16. From Alko web shop. Pours dark amber, off white head. Malts, resin, hops, pine, grapefruit, caramel, alcohol. Full body, oily texture, average carbonation and bitter finnish.

21/12-02. Bottle: Dark clear amber colour, nice head. Aroma of caramel, dark chocolate, and alc. Flavor is almost the same here. dominated of caramel and alcohol. Maybee a bit unbalanced. Medium body, and a medium malty/alc finish.

The last few years Ringnes have, in addition to their normal "klasse F" Christmas beers, brewed a "Juleklassiker" (Christmas classic) which changes every year, and allegedly is based on old recipes from the various breweries that have been engulfed (and in many cases closed) by the Ringnes group. Last year it was Aktiebryggeriet i Oslo, this year it's Ringnes' own recipe. As a gimmick every bottle is numbered, I had number 37089! This beer is not "golden" like the label says, it is reddish brown (the label mentions that Ringnes brewed its first pilsener in 1877 - irrelevant information, as this is definitely not a pils!) - its flavour is very close to the weaker Frydenlund BayerÃ¸l (Munich dunkel) though some may prefer to call it a Vienna (who the hell cares - the term "Vienna" is unknown in Norway, even if our numerous Christmas beers belong to the borderland between dunkels and Viennas). Anyway this is a good beer, but it could use some heavier malts for its strength (6,5%). Not as spicy as the normal "klasse F" Christmas beers. Good with food though.
Minuarust Ã¼le mitme aasta Ã¼ks parimaid jÃµuluportereid alecoqilt. VÃ¤ga kena vÃ¤rvi ja vahuga

Dark brown beer with lots of sticky beige head, stays for long time. Aroma is malt, slight yeast and hops. Taste is mostly roasted malt, also some hops, metal, also some nuts at the end. Drinkable but nothing special.

500 ml bottle. clear dark black brown color with average white head. smell roast malts. taste are soft water roast malts with caramel and brown sugar sweetness. aftertaste are pleasant roast malts with some coffee notes. nice porter

500ml bottle (2017). Pours black, foamy beige head. Aroma of roast, mild smokiness. Taste is sweet, roasty, milky. Watery feel. Milk in aftertaste. Medium bodied, bit below average carbo. Drinkable, but bland. More sweet and less roasty than last year. More like sweet stout that porter this year.
Pours nut brown with medium off-white head. Aroma is empty, some malts, caramel, grass, sourness, cardboard. Taste is light, some sourness, light toast, malts, light caramel. Empty beer.

Looks cola black with a huge creamy head. Roast level is nice and makes a good first impression. Mild bitterness and a little caramel sweetness. Finishes quite dry and it feels a bit stronger than 6.5%. Price and quality ratio right on spot. For less than a euro a bottle, I cannot expect more or compain really. Well worth a try.
50 cl bottle @ SeinÃ¤joki. BBE 14.10.2017. Aroma has berries and coffee. Flavour has berries, licorice, coffee and berry juice. Mild menthol in the finish. A bit unusual with the fruity berry aromas.
Nice, great, smooth, christmas special porter. Easily drinkable, with christmas food.

500ml bottle. Reddish-brown colour. Quite high head. Stays quite long time. Bready, alcocholy, grainy sweet aroma. Caramel, sugar sirup at first. Bready, caramelly notes. Alcocholy, sweet finish. Rather medium bodied, alvocholy, watery palate. Medium carbonated. Too sweet, quite flat taste. Alcocholy and sirupy. Not a goid brew.
