This is a great nut brown. Amber/light brownish in color, good hoppiness, and very malty, with a solid almond/hazlenut taste. Very smooth, with a nice malty/nutty finish. Very nice aroma also. One of the best nut browns I've had.

Brown in color, nice soft lacy head, quite a bit of hops in the aroma as well as a hit of nuts, somewhat of a spicy aftertaste, a little too unbalanced as it seemed like there was a bit too much hops in the flavors, a little hint of nut in the flavor as well

column1: Brew Brothers Antonios Original Garlic Pils
column5: Garlic good, beer good; garlic and beer in the same bottle = bad. At least this came in a nice swing top bottle. From the instant the stopper was popped, yikes!! ....rather a strong garlic smell like a punch to the nose. I was expecting "some" hint of garlic but nothing like this. Onward I ventured, pouring the slightly cloudy medium gold, with the modest white head. Coming from the bottom of the bottle was what I thought might be sediment, but I caught it just before "it" went into the glass, "it" turning out to be two slices of garlic. Nice save, and into the loo they went. Aroma was garlic, and the taste was well, garlic. Mouthfeel was hard to judge, my mouth being overwhelmed by the garlic and the aftertaste was garlic. Mightâ€™ve been an okay pilsner but for the garlic. Would not and could not ever drink this again. ps All this garlic had an extreme laxative effect within the hour. Could this be worse than the infamous Chili Beer?

column1: Brew Brothers Antonios Original Garlic Pils
column5: I want to first note that my review will be biased on Aroma and Flavour, because I ABSOLUTELY ADORE garlic. Now, with that said: A terrific nose! Garlic wears a nice coat over light hops. Not much else but delicious garlic bread in the mouth. I did catch a wisp of the ale and it truly seemed like nothing spectacular. Moderate feel in the mouth, nothing exciting. A taste to suite my palate, but Iâ€™m sure not that of the everyman.

column1: Brew Brothers Antonios Original Garlic Pils
column5: Is this retired now? I had this a while back at the Garlic restaurant near the Royal Alexandra Hospital in Edmonton. A curiosity really-- a pale lager that has been steeped in garlic (indeed, the beer comes with a little garlic clove in the bottom of it). At first it is off-putting because you canâ€™t taste the beer behind the garlic (but once you get your food, which also is made with several pounds of garlic per entree), and your palate becomes absolutely pummeled by garlic, THEN the shitty pale lager component of the beer shines through. As I said, a curiosity more than anything worthwhile.

column1: Brew Brothers Antonios Original Garlic Pils
column5: bottle. thanks to Jesse for sharing this world class beer. pours a yellow-golden body with small specks of presumabley garlic. aroma is pungent as all hell! very garlicy and not much else, it actually fills the room. Well there isnâ€™t much to expect from the flavours either, with garlic itâ€™s pretty much overpowering in all respects and thatâ€™s not entirely a good thing as others have pointed out. Itâ€™s only interesting for about a second and I canâ€™t imagine anyone actually drinking this except for the novelty.

column1: Brew Brothers Antonios Original Garlic Pils
column5: Uhm. Wow. Aroma is garlic bread. Not beerlike at all but it sure smells good. I can kind of taste some beer behind the garlic. An interesting taste - just one I hope to never experience again.

column1: Brew Brothers Antonios Original Garlic Pils
column5: I like garlic. It helped that in transporting back to Toronto, the bottle got a good shaking up, and not too much sediment of garlic taste, and so the creamy head top overflowed the first third of the pour. Points for originality. Too bad this place is finito,

column1: Brew Brothers Antonios Original Garlic Pils
column5: Golden beer with a freakin garlic floating in it. Fresh malty nose with AWFUL garlic sell. The taste of garlic is cloying and needs to be eliminated for any further tasting. Little body or hops in this beer. Interesting maybe to make a nice vinaigrette.

column1: Brew Brothers Antonios Original Garlic Pils
column5: Slight haze, minimal head. It looked a bit like ole root beer. Unclean spice, garlic salt aroma . Highly repulsive . Salt , old oil , garlic , dust . Horrible combination . Thank you

column1: Brew Brothers Antonios Original Garlic Pils
column5: Hazy light golden color. Huge sharp and acidid garlic in the nose, if it was anything else, it probably wouldn't be so dominant, but what do you expect putting a garlic chunk in a pilsner? Some sweet malt in the body, but the garlic barely makes an impression (which is good). Not as bad as one might think.

column1: Brew Brothers Antonios Original Garlic Pils
column5: (5oo ml bottle) Thanks to Kimchee for this fabulous experiment! Pours clear gold with a thin, white head. Garlic butter nose. Flavour is more oily with an overpowering garlic taste. When the clove slid out into Doug's glass I honestly thought someone had spat a loogie in the bottle - I nearly threw-up! Not complex at all and won't likely have again but was fun.
Tap at Port Solana and always a treat to be there. Had this one many times. Dark brown in color with a tan head. Aroma of malt, dark fruit. Flavor is roasted malt, caramel, nutty. Very nice beer.
on draft @ Port Solana beach. Clear, dark amber pour.....light tan head. Nose of some dark fruits, molasses, and caramel malts. Slightly watery but, a good brew overall.

Date: 10/17/1998 Mode: Firkin Source: Brewfest, Real Ale Festival dark brown, strong maut aroma, watery, dry malt flavor, only a hint of bitterness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 4/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.6/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Solana Beach. Aroma of sweet malt, with some underlying plums. Appears a deep red mahogany, with some effervescence, and with a huge head. Flavor is warm, mildly nutty, with underlying red berry. Palate is medium and appropriate. Overall, a very good brew.

On tap@Port Solana: Dark amber brown with a wisp of light tan foam. Aroma is lightly sweet and nutty. Flavor is malty sweet with a hint of cocoa, moderately bitter with a touch of spice. Light to medium bodied and smooth with moderate to lively carbonation. Served way too cold, flavor enhanced as it warmed.

This is a strong brown ale. A very alcohol and nutty aroma. The appearance is a murky brown. The flavor is very sweet and a bit too much so with some nutmeg, caramel, and sour cherries. This does not hide the alcohol well at all. Its ok in small amounts.

Couldnâ€™t quite get into it after drinking Hop15 for 6 hours. Initially it tasted like a dopple bock, then the yeast mad it taste more Belgian. Had a lot of alcahol to it also. Dark sweet, malty and spicy with some bite to it, sums it up for me

Pours a deep brown hue with a slight off-white head with aromas of roasted malt and slight yeast. Mouth feel is meduim to full bodied with the initial mouth taste being belgian-style yeast. The flavor mellows as it warms and other flavors follow suit with brown sugar, roasted malts and a little more yeast.

Pours with a deep amber brown/mohogany body, topped by a medium thick head with little lacing. The aroma is sweet and malty with notes of spice, yeast and brown sugar. The flvor is very similar with more spicy notes. Medium to full bodied, tingly on the tongue and warming.

Coconuts and brown rum smooth off the sweet spicy nutmeg impersonation and biting endâ€¦Vanilla-coated raisins bathing in light soy sauceâ€¦Their friends the figs eagerly share some of their sweetnessâ€¦Absurdity can be entertaining for a whileâ€¦

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: W aromacie kakao, kawa, czekolada, wanilia. W smaku wytrawne, nuty gorzkiej czekolady, kakao, nuty waniliowe. Degustacyjne, aksamitne, smukÅ‚e, goryczka Å›rednia, palona. OgÃ³lnie solidny, klasyczny ris

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Dark brown, almost black, minimal brown head. Aroma is intensive dark chocolate, ash, raisin, molasses, a bit of green hops. Medium sweetness, light bitterness from roasted malt. Medium carbonation, higher than it's usual. Does not feel too heavy. Solid.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle. Aroma- nice, roasted coffee, with some sweet cocoa and a bit spicy notes (something like vanilla and cinnamon). Pleasant and well-balanced composition, but on the other hand- could be a bit more intensive. Black, unclear, with a medium-low, creamy, brown head. Taste- it's better, much stronger, roasted coffee, which brings even some typical, but not very disturbing sourness. Then come cocoa and still clear spiciness, which adds some sweet feeling. Nice, medium-low roasty bitterness in the aftertaste. Medium-high-bodied, quite smooth, with a low carbonation. Very solid Imperial Stout, but it doesn't blow off my mind.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: (~choco-cara, Âµ-cuir-noix, > onctueuse, first-sweet (nice sucre), last-dry, trÃ¨s beau â€˜stoutâ€™ noÃ«l Ã  la russ-hop, rude)

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: 33 cl fles. Helder donker bruin van kleur, fijne romige bruine schuimkraag. De geur is chocolade en gebrande mout. Smaak is zoet, gebrande mout, koffie, vanille en chocolade. Vol lichaam, veel koolzuur.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle. Dark brown black a little beige head. Chocolate milk, cinnamon, licorice aroma. Cocoa, bitter chocolate, creamy milky mouthfeel, thick body. Dark chocolate bitterness, ground cocoa powder remain on the palate. Dont get the coffee so much, but it's really good. I prefer rhis over the bourbon barrel version, it's way more balanced.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Don't know the brewer, don't know the beer but I do like imperial stouts, enough said. Acquired in California, brought home to Texas, the 12 oz bottle will be consumed tonight. I open and pour into my ABGB snifter, black, yes it is black, with a thin light brown crown of foam. Fragrant, I detect strawberry, wheat, something sweet. But the taste will abide. My my, very nice. Baker's chocolate, berry, baked bread, brown sugar and black licorice. Bitter but not a whole new chapter. Wish I had bought two, certainly next time.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle, 2018 vintage. Rich roasted malt aroma with notes of chocolate, coffee, licorice and some vanilla. Pours deep brown with half a finger of mocha brown head that has excellent retention and good lacing. Starts with rich roasted malt, chocolate and licorice flavors as well as having a rich, full body and slick viscous mouthfeel. Finishes smooth with coffee and a little bit of vanilla flavors. Really nice imperial stout.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Aroma: Dark roasted malt with chocolate and notes of vanilla. Flavour: Sweet roasted malt with chocolate, vanilla and slight licorice. Aftertaste is roasted malt. Colour: Black with a tan head.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Santa's Little Helper has a thick, tan head, a very dark brown appearance, and moderate lacing. The aroma is of sweet malt, cream, and coffee. The flavor is similar, with minimal acrid char. Mouthfeel is high medium, and Santa's Little Helper finishes medium sweet. RJT

column1: Pizza Port Double Overhead Abbey Ale
column5: On tap at Toronado SD. Clear reddish auburn with a small off-white head, fading to a ring rather quickly. Smells like New Belgiumâ€™s Abbey with a tinge more toasted malt and light chocolate, slightly more banana. Flavor is much the same with a moderate alcohol presence and bitterness at a 3, dry.moderate prickly carbonation with a medium full body. Just a Tad better than NB. Stupid autocorrect. . .

column1: Pizza Port Double Overhead Abbey Ale
column5: Bottle, courtesy matta. Pours a dark copper hue, thin white head, and sticky lacing. Caramel nose, raisin, some wet wheat. Flavors of caramel, raisin, some chocolate in the distance, some sour tart punch in the finish. Spicy, full body. Has a lot of age on it. Would have been better fresh.

column1: Pizza Port Double Overhead Abbey Ale
column5: Bottled at RBSG thanks to Christian! Poured deep medium caramel with a swirly cap of beige head. The aroma picked up toasted lighter fruits, showing plenty of oxidation.. darker fruit and caramel came on the second wind.. quite sweet overall. The flavor was sweet again with caramel and medium-skinned fruits paired with spicy lighter fruit skins and some raw alcohol.. finished dry and spicy with some tart and yeasty notes. Medium-bodied and a bit more sour than Iâ€™d like.. interesting evolution.

column1: Pizza Port Double Overhead Abbey Ale
column5: Bottle @ RBSG guessing from AlohaC Christian or some one else old school. Pours orange with a bright white ring. Nose is fresh and sweet. Taste is sweet and fruitty and very nice. This is a cool brew.

column1: Pizza Port Double Overhead Abbey Ale
column5: Date: 05/04/2005 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting hazy amber, slightly tart malt aroma, light and very tart flavor, lame -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 06/18/2005 Score: i to ii some sweetness to balance the tartness, bit of fruity character, not lame Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column1: Pizza Port Double Overhead Abbey Ale
column5: Orange-dark amber in colour, off white coloured head, average retention, good lacing. The aroma starts off quite sweet, lots of fruit (apples and some peach), lots of yeast, bready, really fresh. The flavour is yeasty upfront, lots of apple tartness, good fruit sweetness, very light spice, a rather unusual sourness although this is a good thing. Tart mouthfeel, medium body, high carbonation. Finishes long and tart, lots more fruit, dry. This is good, a different take on a double. Iâ€™m liking the angle that they take with this one. 750ml bottle obtained in a trade with DarkElf, thanks Stephen. Opened on February 16, 2007. Bottle #155, Vintage 2004.

column1: Pizza Port Double Overhead Abbey Ale
column5: Bottle. Warm, coppery brown with an off-white head. Medium body with fizzy carbonation. Aroma of fruit, funk and honey. Biscuit, spice and fruit flavor. Dry, nutty finish.

column1: Pizza Port Double Overhead Abbey Ale
column5: Bottle. #155. Pours a bright brown-ruby body with a creamy, medium-size white head. The aroma has a solid fruit constituency (apricot, peach) along with bready yeast. Fruity, funky acidity in an oily body. Interesting profile, as others mentioned this doesnâ€™t appear to be a double, but I still found it to be quite enjoyable. Thanks for sharing, radiomgb.

column1: Pizza Port Double Overhead Abbey Ale
column5: Doesnâ€™t really seem like a double if that was the intent. Tart, doughy, orange citrus aroma. Hazy browned copper coloured body is topped by a decent but diminishing off white head that does leave some sudsy lacing. Tart orange and strong grapefruit citrus hops overwhelm the malt body. Chaotic fruitiness leaves the flavour unfocussed. Somewhat watery texture with gassy strong carbonation. Bottle (trade, May-05) sampled with MartinT and Rastacouere. Thanks, DarkElf!

column1: Pizza Port Double Overhead Abbey Ale
column5: From the bottle. Very fruity spicy cherry with sweet malts and nice spice. The alcohol shows a bit in this beer, but the malts are fantastic, very fruity and great caramel flavor. Beer was a bit light on the palate and lacked carbonation.

column1: Belgian Passions Comics & Beer Triple Blond
column5: Another unique beer dumped on the Australian market. Cloudy light amber with a generous fluffy white head. Strong, sweet belgian yeast aroma. Some spicy plum pudding notes. Strangely underwhelming flavour, but itâ€™s well balanced. Seems fairly sugary, even for a belgian, but it doesnâ€™t seem too sweet on tasting. Pleasant if not challenging.

column1: Belgian Passions Comics & Beer Triple Blond
column5: Another high rating to add to the evidently volatile opinion of the Aussie contingent! This is one good looking beer. Thin head on pouring and excellent visual complexity - cloudy orange glow lightens notably to a dull gold at the edges. Powerful nose, well cooked malts, not roasted (if that makes any sense), a touch sugary. Impressive. palate has power but lacks the smooth, well integrated structure of the nose. Big malts, stewed, some blocky alcohol notes, but settles nicely nicely in the back palate.

column1: Belgian Passions Comics & Beer Triple Blond
column5: 5 Mar 06 - Spiritous spicy malt hop aroma. Cloudy yellow-brown colour, good retaining head and suds lacing. Big spiritous spicy fruit malt flavour. Tangy hoppy malt aftertaste.

column1: Belgian Passions Comics & Beer Triple Blond
column5: 10th Aussie to rate this one! I guess us Aussies must be able to get this one fairly easily. Spice hop malt aroma. Murky yellow colour with great head and lacing. Spice malt hop flavour with spiritus. Smooth palate.

column1: Belgian Passions Comics & Beer Triple Blond
column5: Mystifying name but an interesting tripel. I found this very satisfying. Lemon marmalade colour, with a towering frothing head. Aroma had banana and honey notes. Creamy mouthfeel, smooth and very drinkable for its 9% abv. Flavour palette dominated by wheat, lemons and cedary hops. Very well balanced for its strength. (Bottle, 2003)

column1: Belgian Passions Comics & Beer Triple Blond
column5: Bottled: The lables had fallen off this bottle and I had to work backwards to figure out what it was, quite an amusing exercise. Bottle conditioned judging by the floaties in the glass, horse blanket yeast aroma with some honey and fruit. Somewhat peppery but the alcohol in pretty-in-your-face instead of being a background player. Easily enough identified as a triple, but not a particulary good one. Had to identify the beer using the bottle and cap in the end. Not Sillys best beer.

column1: Belgian Passions Comics & Beer Triple Blond
column5: 8th Aussie rating! I grabbed this one cos it was the only one left that I hadnâ€™t rated! Colour was a murky pale straw with a large frothy head that left an odd shaped egg in the foam. Wheat and yeast on the nose. Alcohol shows in the taste, some pepper, coriander, sweet and not that well balanced.

column1: Belgian Passions Comics & Beer Triple Blond
column5: The 7th rating and the 7th Aussie. Just like some of the other Belgians (Caporal comes to mind) it appears that we are the dumping ground for some of the inferior stuff. The silliest thing about this beer is that I had to hand over a $10 note for this beer and a small handful of loose change. The other silliness is that, as described, it just lacks the presence of other beers of this kind. The most noticeable aspect of the beer is the lack of real integration of alcohol, hops and malty body and mouthfeel. Enough said, except 493, the number of this rating.

column1: Belgian Passions Comics & Beer Triple Blond
column5: Well Silly by name (brewery and Beer) in this case turns out to be silly in just about ever rating category. Medium hazy honey with huge, almost joke-like erectile, craggy icecream sundae style off white head. Mild yeast, wet mown straw and overly fruity aroma. Thinish low carb characterless body. Not well integrated. Big yeast and milder floral honey sweet flavours. Kinda reminds me of an over sweetened Belgian home brew gone wrong. The closest thing I have tasted to it is a Belgian "fruit shandy" - Belgian ale mixed with tropical fruit flavoured soda water - truly silly and not even a beer clown.

column1: Belgian Passions Comics & Beer Triple Blond
column5: This beer just lacked body and persistance of flavour. The picture says a thousand words about this beer, COMIC.

column1: Erve Kots Prins Frederik Hendrik Pilsner
column5: 1l bottle shared. Apperance: A Very bright golden body, mostly clear with a nice white head on top that leaves some lacing. Aroma: is grass, light malts, some hops, some citric tone.and a hint of honey. Taste: Light sour, malty sweetness, a hint of honeyish tones. however tasty refined. and finish is a light bitterness with some hops. Quite a lot of taste, for a pilsener. Thin- medium body, average carbonation. Solid Pilsener. The real problem is that I would prefer slightly smaller bottles.

column1: Erve Kots Prins Frederik Hendrik Pilsner
column5: Van de tap bij erve kots. Tja, tis pils. Wel een met veel smaak. Ziet er prima uit. Niks mis mee.

column1: Erve Kots Prins Frederik Hendrik Pilsner
column5: 1 L bottle, leaking and gushing. Huge white head. Aroma is mild grassy, grainy and slight citric. Mild fruity, light milky. Light sweet, grassy and toasted malt. Medium sweet and light bitter finish.

column1: Erve Kots Prins Frederik Hendrik Pilsner
column5: Draught: Served in a footed Pilsner: Medium sized snowy white foamy head on top a clear yellow colored beer. Aromas of malts, herbs, some dull flowers and a hint of something hay/herbal. Flavours of malts, bitters, chalk, light creamy, some hay and some light honey ish tones while itâ€™s not the typical honey tones thatâ€™s there. Aftertaste is bitter wth the typical pils (malt) tones. Low carbo, light creamy mouthfeel, low bodied and a light creamy texture. Nice beer for itâ€™s style.

column1: Erve Kots Prins Frederik Hendrik Pilsner
column5: Draught @ Museum Erve Kots, Eimersweg 4, Lievelde, Netherlands 7173 HG. Light unclear medium orange yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, butter, butterscotch, light caramel. Flavour is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter with a average to long duration, fruity, spicy butter, perfume, grass - sharp grass, butter - toffee - caramel. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20130926]

column1: Erve Kots Prins Frederik Hendrik Pilsner
column5: Weich getreidiger Beginn, deutlich grasige Herbenoten stoÃŸen hinzu. Die hopfige Grasigkeit stellt sich dann noch deutlicher in den Vordergrund, hopfig, sÃ¼ffig, rund. Absolut gelungen! 12/12/13/12//12

column1: Erve Kots Prins Frederik Hendrik Pilsner
column5: Bottle @ home shared with DutchDrebus. Very clear bright yellow / golden color. Standard, decent pilsener smell and taste.

column1: Erve Kots Prins Frederik Hendrik Pilsner
column5: This beer scored the normal score for Pilsener. Nothing bad or really good about this one. Easy to drink.

column1: Erve Kots Prins Frederik Hendrik Pilsner
column5: Draught at the nice farmhouse museum. Weak dusty aroma. Clear warm golden colour, almost copper. Nice stable white head. The flavour is bready with some slightly rough bitterness. Hint of aroma hops and vegetable. The finish has some yeast and an OK rough, cleansing bitterness. Sounds bad, but works out almost all right in the end.

column1: Erve Kots Prins Frederik Hendrik Pilsner
column5: Perfect tasting beer. The beer I had from the tap had a strong smell of "eau de cologne". I visited the brewery-tour.

Aroma; caramel, juicy malt, strawberries, plums, cinnamon, syrup, muffins. Look; offwhite head on clear amber body. Taste; straw hops, fruity malts, caramel, bread, leaves, grain, and finishes with syrup bread n malts. Feel; good body n natural coÂ². Overall; it`s a good urtyp. [btl@hÃ¶me]

Bottle. Clear dark amber, low, rather ugly but generally stable, off-white head, little lacing. Aroma malty, roasty, bready, caramel, hints of dried fruit, a little nuts. Taste smooth, full, slightly sweet, roasty. Carbonation medium to high, tingling. Bitterness medium, roasty, a little grassy. Aftertaste malty, roasty, bready, fruity. Very good MÃ¤rzen.

500ml bottle; BB Christmas Day 18. Drank at home on 28th Aug 18. Deep golden body, clear and clean looking, white crown on top that hung around for longer than most beers of this type. Light malty aroma and a mild malty sweetness taste wise, minimal hop bitterness. My sweet tooth quite liking the malty brew and it's simplicity. OK for a cheap supermarket beer.
FrÃ¥n JÃ¶rg 3,50 flaskan. DÃ¥ligt skum. Trevlig ljusbrun fÃ¤rg. Lite unken smak. Ohumlad ? Inget vidare men i nivÃ¥ med svensk fulÃ¶l till en fjÃ¤dedel av priset. Dricks nog med fÃ¶rdrl fÃ¶r kall.

Sampled from 0.5 l bottle from local 'toom', best before April 2018. Clear, dark amber with a medium large, frothy, slowly diminishing, off-white head. Sweetish, slightly malty and a little grassy aroma of grains, straw and a touch of caramel. Moderately sweet, slightly bitter, a bit malty and slightly grassy taste of grains, some caramel and hints of straw, followed by a short, moderately bitter, slightly grassy and quite yeasty finish with a metallic touch. Thin to medium body, slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. One of the worst I've had from Oettinger so far, pretty yeasty as if something went wrong here, didn't like it at all!
courtesy of Philipp and Thomas - translucide bright bronze beer with no head retention; aroma paperboard and grain; medium-bodied; harsh, bitter and grainy, papery finish

Pours dark gold from the bottle. The creamy white head soon fades. Aroma is very much that of a Kellerbier or MÃ¤rzen, with dank basement notes set atop caramel and alcohol undertones. Taste is malty sweet with caramel and honey notes. Finish is short and fades off into nothing. Body trends light. Not your usual Helles. It is not a bad beer, but a flawed one.

Aroma: DMS, wort notes, herbs. Appearance: clear golden color and thin white head. Taste: low herbal bitterness, wet socks, malty, wort, semi-dry. Palate: medium body and low carbonation, malty. Overall: Really average.
En klassisk tysk Ã¸l, maltet smag og en nÃ¦sten anonym bitterhed, som dog varer lÃ¦nge.

Pours a medium brown-red color with a slight white head. Aroma is a little hoppy. It seems that there is rye in here somewhere. Flavor is lighter on the hops than expected, but still good. On tap at Uncle Billyâ€™s.

1-3-08 on tap at Uncle Billyâ€™s Unfiltered brown color with okay head and lacing. Nice hoppy smell that would be perfect if it had a bit more kick. Very nice, VERY light hop flavor. A bit thin on the palate but nice overall.

Had on tap at Uncle Billyâ€™s. Was told this was the same recipe as used at the Bitter End by the bartender, so Iâ€™ll put the review under here for now... Poured a very dark crimson color, almost brown with just a small head. Smell was hoppy and zesty and almost rye like. Taste was a balanced hoppiness with again zesty, hearty notes of rye like grain and malt. Very nicely balanced and easy drinking enough for beginners but tasty enough for everyone. Not a traditional Joe Schmoe Amber, and a nicely done beer.

On draught. Amber/orange color with nice lacing. The aroma has nice citrus with a touch of malt coming through. The flavor is so well balanced with the malt and the hop bitterness, flavor and aroma. This is a bit unique being a hoppy amber here in Texas so it is very welcome each time Brian brews it. Look for it.

On Cask @ the Bitter End. Nice murky amber color with some head and lacing. Citrus and malt in the nose. Smooth malt flavor with a medium body. Citrus hop bite and the end for balance. Very drinkable beer.
Nice round about, do the job ale. plenty of malt to let the floral hops take over at the end. bitchin!

One of the better Amber Ales I have come across at a brewpub. Dark orange appearance with a creamy white head, good lacing. Sweet floral aroma with some faint citrus notes. Flavor is bittersweet with a bit of grapefruity sourness. Thick mouthfeel, sits just right.

This beer smells like a well hopped Fat tire. Really sweet smelling. Not as dark as the tire but still amber in color. Palate is average. Amarillo hops really shine through on this one. Sweet...but overcome by the amarillo hops. G-rat
Clear yellow/brown with a nice off white head. Head is nicely retained and there is nice lacing. Aroma is mainly hoppy. Flavor is hoppy and the texture of the beer is grainy.
Nice reddish color; great head with great retention. Pleasent nose. Very nice ale- a winner for sure. Clean maltiness- no body odor for me Patrick!
Brewery brewpub. Golden color with thick white head. Malty aroma. Malt centered beer with light bitter hops. Iâ€™d like more hops inside, otherwise OK.
FÄ¾aÅ¡ka v jednom terasovom podniku. Farba zlatista. VÃ´Åˆa sladova. ChuÅ¥ sladova menej chmelova. JemnÃ¡ horkost s trpkosÅ¥ou na konci.

Clear golden color with a nice durable white lacing head. Well carbonated, I like the tiny bubbles. Has malty, caramel, bit bready aroma. For me, the flavor is too sweet. Nevertheless, it has nice malty, bit bready notes, well balanced.

Unter dem Titel "Prezident" gibt es von der mittelstÃ¤ndischen Brauerei aus Wittingau ein 14-grÃ¤diges, also ein bisschen vollmundigeres und schwereres Bier heraus. Wobei ich finde, dass es auch als 12-grÃ¤diges durchkommen kÃ¶nnte, da es zwar recht bitte ist, aber einen milden Abgang hat. Man kann es gerne probieren, aber ich wÃ¼rde eher das 12-grÃ¤dige empfehlen.
