Az alkohol szÃ©pen el van bÃºjtatva, egyÃ¡ltalÃ¡n nem Ã©rzÅ‘dik.
Bottle @ Louise. Clear yellow. Aroma medium malty (caramel), light hoppy. Flavor medium sweet, light bitter, flowery and spicy. Medium body, light sirupy, light carbonated.
0.5 l bottle from Alko YmpyrÃ¤talo, Helsinki. Appearance is golden, clear and small head. This has the Czech taste of malts, balanced with hops. Great, no taste of ABV.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Draft - Light earthy bitterness and some twig. Deep cloudy brown with a small white head. Malty and woody bitterness with a light bitter finish.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: A hazy amber-yellow, with a frothy white head. The spices are layered and mess well together, the bitter is robust but built in nicely. A good esb ---Rated via Beer Buddy

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Weak aroma with a cloudy golden pour. Pungeant bitter, ginger and lime flavour. Some fizz on the tongue and a nice bite to it.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Had @ the Merchant Ale House in St Catherines, Canada - drinking this beer on draft .. . woah, worst nose ever for a brewpub beer .. some wheat, nice bitterness .. . damn the nose kills this beer, but other than than- good all round .. . Questions? Well, uh, I might take advantage of this rare opportunity even if you children arenâ€™t interested. Ah, which do you think is more important? Hard work or stay-tuneded-ness? Are there any REAL questions?

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Pale golden pour with a little bit of white head. The aroma has a nice fresh bite. A bright spicy hop aroma with a bit of light malt. A nice bright UK hop flavour along with a touch of light minerally bitterness. Really solid bitter. Lingering bitterness. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: For an ESB this one was quite sweet and it was bitter but not as bitter as other ESB in a good way. I really enjoyed this beer, good offering

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: [1541-20080719] Tap. Mild grains aroma. Clear, amber orange body with a long-lasting creamy white head. Bitter lemon rind grains flavour is a little hoppy. Medium body is tangy. Average. (@ Merchant Ale House; St. Catherines, ON)

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: On tap at the brewery- Deep copper/amber with a frothy white cap. Nose is of muted earthy malts and wet hay, alongside some vague fruitiness and butterscotch. Flavour profile is weak sweet malts with a dank fruity component. Very weak. Something says this isnâ€™t right. Itâ€™s sorta of muddled and doesnâ€™t resemble much. Itâ€™s a sweet, dank, strange muddy concoction. Not offensive, but confused.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: hoppy aroma, initial hop bite and flavour, and then notice much carbonationaand water. Citrus. White crown hhead with lace on medium grapefruit colour. Some creaminess in the mouthfeel.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Draught at the Merchant Ale House. Hazy golden-amber with a tight white head. Muted aroma, but what I could find seemed stale to me. Flavour was pretty standard for the style, but again, somewhat muted and stale. This staleness seemed to appear in a lot of their beers - maybe they just havenâ€™t had a lot of turnover through the holidays? Whatever the case, thereâ€™s no excuse for serving stale product at a brewpub, and my ratings reflect that.

A dark reddish copper ale with a thin dark mocha head. In aroma, sweet caramel malt with fruity notes, dark fruits, light molasses, pine trees, interesting. In mouth, a sweet dark fruity malt with plums, molasses, light woody notes, burned caramel, licorice in finale, nice. On tap at brewery.
On tap at Piece. Poured brown with light beige head. Aroma of dried fruits and spice. Med bod and carb. Similar taste to aroma.
Reddish pour with a head that hangs around for a while. Lots of lace. Taste has some sugar, roast & a little banana. Aroma is earthy with some banana & clove. Smooth mouth.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a dark hazy mahogany brown with a small off white head. Aroma is sweet, candyish in a way, dark fruits and some spice notes. Flavor has some dark fruit, prune and plum notes along with a light spice, touch of roast, oddly not much alcohol noticeable which makes me wonder if this is truly 9% as they say. Considering itâ€™s moderate body and complexity I was amazed that I wasnâ€™t tasting some hint of booziness. Not too bad.

On tap at the brewpub. Poured a cloudy dark brown with a red hue and a light brown head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma had sweet grain, some nuttiness, a nice spice note and a bit of light fruit. Flavor was similar complex with some sweet grains joined by light fruit and spices with a bit of nuttiness in the finish.
I thought this was fairly tasty but a bit thin. It was darker in color than in flavor. But that being said I still liked it. Serving: Tap

Growler. Poured a slightly hazy dark brown color with orange light shining through. The head was light tan. Medium bodied and slightly sweet with a hint of warming alcohol. There were elements of brown sugar, clove, and subdued chocolate accented by a dash of cinnamon and a splash of red wine. Nice.

Draft at Piece. Pours a ruddy, hazy brown with reddish tinges. Nose is muted, though I do get pleasant cloviness and stone fruit, mild roastiness as well. On taste, pretty pleasant with a very dubbel type character, roasted and dark crystal malts at the forefront with a nice soft body. plums are in there as well. Pretty tasty stuff.
On Tap on saturday. Dirty dark brown with some dirty head. Aroma of carmel, roastyness,and earthy tones. Taste is similar with a nice malt backbone. Just an alright ale.

tap at piece... dark brown, almost porter-like in appearance with a thin light brown head... aroma of dark fruit, fig, dates, and even some black licorice and brown sugar... dark fruit, rather sweet without much of any assertive spices. pretty drinkable with low carbonation and a nice creamy mouthfeel.

Keg @ Cittie of Yorke, London. Pours clear gold. Fruity medium-sweet nose. Pleasant medium character, stewed fruit, some unexpected smoky notes, light skin. Not bad, just unsure about the smoky elements.
Crisp apple cider with a very light citric pressence wich makes it rather enjoable. Fizzy. OK cider

Keg at Ye Olde Swiss Cottage. It pours clear golden with with a small fizzy white head. The aroma is sweet, sugary, cheap apple juice, earthy, light barnyard and apple pie. The taste is initially crisp, plenty of sugary sweetness, apple juice from concentrate, appletiser and candy with a touch of dryness through the finish. Light - medium body and fine, effervescent carbonation. A bit sweet and one - dimensional. Fair at best.

On tap in Fitzroy Tavern. Amber to orange clear fizzy colour with no head. Nose is apple skins, brown apple flesh, sweetness, apple skin tannins. Taste is sweet, moderate dryness, slight tartness, slightly dry, brown oxidised apple flesh. Decent moderately balanced carbonated cider.
On tap at the Red Lion, Conisbrough. Thin white head. Clear golden pour. Slight tart aftertaste. Ok

Pale golden color with a bubbly head. Pleasant mild apples and in both aroma and flavor. Balanced sweetness and acidity. Semi dry texture. Quite flat carbonation. Medium body. Ok plain cider. [On tap at Olde Cheshire Cheese (Sam Smithâ€™s) (Fleet Street) in London, England]
Keg at the Golden Ball, Scarborough. Pours clear pale gold with a thin white head. Aromas of cooked apples. Taste is sparkling apple juice. Watery finish.
Pint at princess Louise, holborn. Clear piss yellow with no bubbles at all. Aroma is Apples... Not particularly sweet or sharp. Taste is much the same. Quite an average cider.

Keg at Fitzroy Tavern. Very pale yellow, lightly sparkling, decent foamy white head (not used to that on a cider). Aroma is gluey, apple juice, alcohol. Body is medium to light, soft carbonation, pretty smooth. Taste is apple-forward, minerally, not overly sweet, dry finish. Very drinkable. The commercial description shows that itâ€™s made in a pretty artificial way...but I enjoyed my half pint.

Tap at Swan and Three Cygnets, Sam Smiths, Durham. Clear yellow colour, short lived white foam head and sugary apple aroma. Sweet apple flavour with straw, dry sour, and woody notes. Syrupy mouthfeel, light bodied, medium to spritzy carbonation, lingering sweet tangy woody finish. OK.

Not impressed. Tony Prins of Hopdaemon Brewery wins the contract to brew the house beer for The British Museum, and he produces a product which tastes like your worse nightmare out of a tin. Stale, flat and metallic. Being as positive as possible the taste could be described as iron fruit, and the tinny dry twang at the end could be called a gentle citric hoppiness, but when I consider that tourists from around the world are going to drink this as an example of British beer, I don''t think I should be that kind. This is revolting! This is not British beer!

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Nice amber coulour with a white foamy head. not a complex flavour, some hops, roast malts and wheat. Decent beer though.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: as i write this, one week ago exactly, i was sitting in the Merchant Ale House in St Catherines, Canada drinking this beer on draft .. . light mud and fresh wheat .. some mud aftertaste .. . muddled and not that enjoyable .. . . When you tell on someone, youâ€™re not only telling on them. Youâ€™re telling on yourself

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: I really enjoyed this one, it had a dark colour and it is bitter at the front and smooth taste all the way through, it had a sweet finish and good beer, I would have again

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Dark yellow, medium white head. Decent wheat and malt aroma. Taste is quite bland but there is is wheat and malt notes here as well. Some hops in finish. Nothing wrong here, I just found it boring.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Draught at the Merchant Ale House. Hazy golden-orange colour - not very "dark", really. Aroma is odd - a bit candyish, some funk (maybe thatâ€™s the "vomit" that jerc found?), some chemical/plastic notes - like I said, odd. Flavour is quite dead to start, developed into some stale fruit (peach, orange) and hop notes, and got unpleasantly bitter in the finish. I really didnâ€™t care much for this.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Hazy golden amber, with a very small white head and half decent lacing. Citrusy aroma, bit of stale hop/lemon/vomit (but not actually)/and grass notes. Light lemon citrus hoppy bitterness. Light tart wheat bite, but other than that it is not very wheaty. Average to light palate. Tasted more like an american style wheat than a dunkelweizen. Meh.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Draught. At Merchant Ale House, shared with jerc and GregClow. Poured cloudy deep amber with a thin white head. Mild aroma of thin caramel malt, light tea hops, hint of sour fruit. Taste was surprisingly citrus hoppy, if somewhat stale, with toasty grain, tea, and as it warmed something sour that wanted to resolve into chocolate, or chlorine or something unpleasant. Mouthfeel bitter, sourish, average body. We felt this one had been on too long, probably would have been quite decent if fresh, as it was, somewhat disappointing.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Cloudy, orange hue typical to darker wheats. Just average crown. Spicy nose with biscuit character, clove. Neat mouth feel, good texture, well rounded malts; noticeable hopinnes makes decent session ale.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: a different take on a wheat, to give it more depth. Drinkable with the slice of lemon not on its one. Little lace. Darker colour, watery, aggressively carbonated.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: (Draught) Thin, almond head with a copper doy. Citrus and slight hop nose. Caramel, citrus and hop tongue with a nice bitter finish.
Clear copper color with no head. Aroma of caramel and fruit. Flavor of fruit with some caramel. Not too sweet. Decent beer, but weak for the style.
Although not an outstanding dubbel, I think it is quite average and drinkable for the style
Amber with a short, small head. Weak flavor, a slight tingly malt flavor. No discernable fruits, not sweet, very empty... Extremely disappointing beer.
I thought it had a pretty good flavor, but it was kinda watery. Just a slightly punchy version of their normal wheat, darker in color of course too.

Not very dark in color or flavor for something calling itself a dunkel. Creamy head. Sweet, banana flavor, somewhat candylike. Reminds me of the Rockin Rogger served down the street at the Copper Tank. Simple flavor but I like it. Nice clean finish.
Seasonal offering... Lemony hints, but slightly watery, growing more watery as it warmed. Hazy amber, retaining a ring of head. Lacking interest, overall.
(Bottle 33 cl) Neatly pale brown (unfortunately with added colourant). Notes of roasted malt and caramel. Soft and well rounded. 050204
Nice creamy head, clear amber body. Malty aroma with caramel and nut tones. Roasted malt flavor with brown sugar and a dry/bitter finish. A nice lager.
A nice lager brewed to honour Vesterbro (a part of Copenhagen). Well balanced.
Nice lager. The best beer from Maribo.......................................

(bottle) pours a clear golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of apple pie and yeast, slightly green, with notes of straw, brown sugar and pepper. flavour is mostly powdered sugar and light green apple, quite leafy, with a hint of vanilla and cardboard. medium-bodied with lively carbonation.

Bottle. Golden, small to average and fully diminishing head. Moderate, malty and sweetish aroma, some caramel, faint hoppyness. Body is medium, malty and sweetish flavor, some caramel and light bread. Finish is average, malty - lightly grainy and lightly sweetish, light caramel and faint hoppyness. Sweetish kellerbier - almost totally lacks bitterness, too sweet for me.

(screw cap bottle) Clear, pale golden colour with a blond mid-sized foamy head. Strawy pale malty aroma with hints of dough, traces of honey and herbal hops in the background. Moderately sweet and slightly bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a rather calm carbonation. Pale malt-character with shy hoppy spice; sweet and delicately bitter hoppy finish with delicately grainy notes in the aftertaste. Clean but not very exciting Helles. 02.VII.13
bottle from Bierzwerg. Hazy golden yellow, white head. Nice grassy hop aroma and flavour, well combined with a robust malty base. Good.

Bottle looks simple but good, dont like that twist-off cap. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts mild, fine malty-spicy, more and more wheaty. Modest grasy. Not very dry. Mild finish, spicy aftertaste. Nice!
Hazed golden,white head. Some nice fruity aromas. Similar flavours with a nice bite at the end.
Light yellow of color with a white head. An aroma of butter, vegetables and weak bitter. A flavor of flour, bread and grainy.

Bottle, courtesy of fonefan. A clear, golden beer with a small, off-white head. Pale malts and fruits on the nose, some grassy hops. Dry, medium body. The flavor has pale malts, some fruityness and bitterness and a touch of lemon. Dry, bitter finish. Not super exiting, but tasteful and quenching. 110129

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium yellow color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, hay, straw, toasted, light to moderate hoppy, grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, sweet malt, light grassy hops. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20110129]
Bottle 500ml @ fonefan Pours clear pale yellow with a white head. Aroma has notes of hay, malt and light cabbage. Taste is light sweet. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.
Redelijk krachtige smaak. Gebrouwen door De Bassus. Beetje zoet, bittertje na (10 jaar over datum variant (07 in 17) zoet, chocola, caramel, zacht, warm 7). (9-2011).
Backlog rating. Hazy brown, low head. Light sugary sweet aroma. Light sparkly body. On the sweet, sticky and not very interesting side.

Bottle from Kisjes Slijterijen, Meppel. Aroma is strong dark malt, caramel, dried fruits, raisins, with some strange vegetable off-flavour in the finish. Flavour is sweet and moderate bitter. Body is medium. Unfortunately, the off-flavour ruins a potentially decent Doppelbock.
Drinking from tab at BBF Amsterdam. A hoppy aroma. The clear, copper beer has a small off-white head. Honey and caramel in the ttaste. Medium carbonated.

Ins Glas ergieÃŸt sich ein leicht trÃ¼bes bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit schÃ¶ner Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr malzig fruchtig, sÃ¼ÃŸ karamellig, fruchtig. Geschmack rÃ¶stmalzig sÃ¼ÃŸ, fruchtig, Karamell, leicht wÃ¼rzig.
Decent winterbock beer. Malty, sweet and yeasty, with some herbs. Not bad actually.
The best type of Huttenkloas beers yet. Mainly light sweet with a touch of bitter. It could have been a bit thicker to my taste. Some very light nutty and chocolate tones.
Fles gedeeld met rikmeister. Licht bruine kleur. Kleine schuimlaag. Lichte chocolade geur. Iets bitter, met een zoetzurige afdronk.
Gedronken @ aaclubavond. Helder robijnrood bier. Aroma is honing, droppig en licht hoppig. Smaak voornamelijk zoet met klein bittertje. Body wat waterig.
Helder amberkleurig bier. Smaak zoet met een bittertje aan het einde. Gedronken met aa zuipclub ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at Tempe. Pours a clear golden color with a white head. Aroma is of spicy earthy saaz hops and malt. Flavor is crisp, spicy hops, caramel malt, finish is very clean and refreshing. Great summer brew.
A quality brew from Four Peaks and another excellent brew for the beginner.

On draught at Tempe brewpub: Clear golden yellow with a thin white head that does hav nice retention. The aroma is spicy, earthy, and floral hops (but not very assertive), light fruits, along with a hint of dusty malt. The taste is very crisp, clean, and yet round, creamy and full. The carbonation is moderate, yet sprizty and lively on the tongue, while the body is light. Flavors of spicy/grassy/floral hops come through, but by no means are anything like an IPa, along with sweet fruit, light earthy bread, and doughy malts. Very approachable for the average drinker, and not the imperial/harvest/double barrel-aged type thatâ€™s going to get talked up on ratebeer, but a very solidly brewed beer all around.

Draught at the brewpub. Clear golden color with thin white head. Sprucy noble hop aroma with a hint of cereal grains. Grains dominate the flavor with a touch of sweetness. The finish is somewhat bitter. Nice beer.

This beer has a nice creamy, pale colored head. The beer itself is a full gold color and is quite clear. The aroma is fruity with notes of apricot and peaches. This beer is quite smooth and creamy on the palate up front. There is a light bitterness in the finish, which definitely matches the dominant hoppy fruit notes quite well. I get notes of apricots, and sweet citrus fruits like grapefruit. This is nice and light on the palate and it goes down so fast, and I still want there to be more in my glass. This is so nice, refreshingly hoppy and light, perfect as a summer quaffer.

tap at the brewpub-pours a golden yellow hue with a nice white head. big grainy/spicy german hop aroma. flavors were haygrass, lemon and big spicy german hops. pretty decent for a light beer from this brewery!

Complex is right. No aroma to speak of except a little bitter. Gold color to it. Had a bland flavor to it may have to go back and have one more to get a better sense of this beer Tap. Had a full glass this time rather than sampler glass. Aroma something was there but hard to explain maybe some fresh sent of hand soap. Staw body with white head. Flavor had a mild bitterness to it like most swill. But if this was served in cans like Miller or Bud maybe more people would drink it.
Golden yellow with small head and lacing. Light hops and citrus aroma. This is a is very good, easy drinking beerwith a crisp light hops and citrus flavor.
Summery lager nose - floralish hops, toasted malt. Hoppier than the nose suggests, earthy bready malt, tingly bready finish.
Light golden color. Aroma is nicely balanced with the malt and hops, faint earth tones. Medium bodied, not complex though but smooth with a little bite. A good summer starter beer.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Winter Tipple
column5: Cask at Birerria Paradiso. Red-amber color with a big, lasting sparkler head. Spices, caramel, and light dough aromas. The flavor is upfront with cinnamon and nutmeg spicing. Malty as well, with caramel, toasted bread. These combine with moderate citric hops to give a dark orange spice-cake flavor. Pretty full bodied and smooth for 4.4%, but the lack of any alcohol presence reminds you of its lightness. Pretty cool sessionable winter ale that might not really be a warmer, but gets interesting and balanced spiced-cake flavors in, which are often not my thing.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Winter Tipple
column5: (cask @ The Old Toad - Rochester, NY) Copper color with a nice tan head. Light aroma of malts and toffee with a light hop base. Taste is very smooth and malty with a hint of fruits, toffee, brown sugar and some hoppy bitterness. Smooth finish and very creamy. Definitely a great session beer.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Winter Tipple
column5: 1. Cask Handpump at the Ship & Mitre, Liverpool 05/12/2002 Copper amber coloured with some fruit aroma. Full malt finish. 2. Cask Stillage at the New Century Hall, Manchester 21/01/2006 Amber golden coloured and slightly hoppy with a floral aroma. Wheaty and crisp on the palate with some bitterness and dryness in a malt finish.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Winter Tipple
column5: Cask Conditioned @ CAMRA National Winter Ales Festival, New Century Hall, Manchester.4.7%. Russett coloured winter ale with a sweet, malty flavour balanced by a bitter finish, although a little syrupy overall. A really pleasant winter ale that drinks to itâ€™s strength.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Winter Tipple
column5: Burton Winter Fest. Golden brown with a small head. Aromas are caramel malts with hints of grapefruit. Flavours are fruity and quite malty with grapefruit bitterness on the finish. Also has some residual sweetness and sulphur. Like Oakham JHB but a bit more wintery. This version was at 4.7%

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Winter Tipple
column5: Anyone expecting a winter warmer might be disappointed, as this is, in fact, a rather nice best bitter. Sure, it is a quite malty one, but that is undepinned by a a quite austere flinty hop bitterness. Finishes clean and slightly sharp. Not at all thick or sticky. A pleasant drop. Handpump, The Speaker, Westminster, London SW1.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Winter Tipple
column5: [Cask at Gullivers, Copenhagen] An amber beer with a fine light brown head. The aroma is sweet and fruity while the flavor is cask flat, sweet malty with notes of caramel. It is a nice beer.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Winter Tipple
column5: Served from a firkin. Aside from the attractive amber appearance, there's not much to recommend. Flavor is bland and lacks any complexity. Finish is mild and slightly bitter. Maybe it did not travel well across the pond.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Winter Tipple
column5: Cask Conditiones at The Stag's Head, Swalcliffe, Oxon. A dark brown bronze beer with thick white head. This is a bitter but fruity beer homing into Stout territory. Hard coffee, smokey bitterness initially which warms and fills into a blackberry fruitiness on the tongue. Not a strong as other winter beers and no alcohol glow, but nevertheless a pretty decent pint.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Winter Tipple
column5: [cask] Watery texture. Bitter. Unremarkable. I wouldn't call this a winter beer.

The best offering from this brewer gives the drinker a caramel malt flavor that is sweet and smooth throughout the drink. Hints of roasted malt add an extra punch. Got this one in a "jug" and Iâ€™m glad I did.

On tap at the the brewpub. Pours a medium to dark amber, white, light but frothy head. Aroma has some hints of caramel, pleasant. The flavor has a unique blend of Christmas spices, caramel and nuts. Reminds me somewhat of a Sam Adams, Mouthfeel is decently thick for a lager. Would go good with food.
Served way too cold! Decent malt flavor with a slightly hoppy finish....just a beer.
Light amber, clear. Served slightly above freezing temperature. As it warmed the malts were kind of nice but there really could be some more strength to this. I''m sure it sells well.

Their weakest offering, intended for the macro drinkers. Not much aroma, some honey, but tasted mostly like water, seemed thin. Most people reading this would probably be happier with one of their other brews.
I might have been sitting next to kaggie and pounder? Honey cream was not a good effort. Some hint of honey, but itâ€™s an ok beer to walk around with on a hot day.

On tap at the brewpub - pours a dark orange with a light white head. Aroma has some faint fresh lake accents. The flavor has some slight sweet honey notes, but not much else. Very smooth drinking, nut nothing to get excited about. Mouthfeel is not very creamy, in fact it turns a bit metallic near the end. Probably the weakest of the five I had on my visit.
A nice, tasty little brew that is best enjoyed after a day at E Rock. Sweet, slippery, and satisfying- the honey is just noticeable enough, with the hops holding it back nicely.
One of the better beers from FBC. No idea wh they bill it as a light beer drinkers beer; It is not light at all but does have a sweet flavour taht any drinker can enjoy

This beer is billed as one that light beer drinkers would like....that made me expect some watery, adjunct crap. On the contrary, this beer actually had a decent, sweet flavor with an excellent hop finish.

I have to admit that I wasn''t expecting much based on the last line of the commercial description. But I found the slight hoppy-honey taste pretty decent, with just enough flavor to keep things interesting. Being 4.7%, it''s not really a light beer by anyone''s definition, but I''d drink it again.

This is not the first terrible thing to come out of Minnesota, and Iâ€™m sure it wonâ€™t be the last. Seriously though, you knew what this beer was all about just like you knew what that fat girl was all about before you brought her home that night in college. Anyone surprised by how terrible this beer is that actually takes the time top complain about it should be beaten severely about the face and perhaps also the head. This is the beer you buy to torture your friends or enemies and I have to believe the brewers of Panther Ice understand and embrace that. Celebrate it for what it is.
It should be called sex panther. Nothing special whatsoever. The cheapness may dazzle the eyes but be weary, itâ€™s a trap!
60% of the time it gets you drunk everytime. Fairly good ice beer much better than some Gluek offerings

Good golden color,small white head that disappeared almost as soon as it hit the glass.Nasty corny sickeningly sweet aroma,some faint whimpy hints at hops but it might just be wishful thinking by my nose.The flavor was mildly sweet and cerealish cornflakes or total in taste,some faint hops in the end and a slight metallic taste as well in the very end.It will definately get you there if thats what your looking for but as far as taste goes this is not it......but it is better then some.
RRRRAAARRRRR. THis panther has a bite! Try a 6 pack, and weâ€™ll see you tomorrow afternoon.

Pale gold. Nose very corny. Flavor is sweet and corny, but at least it doesnâ€™t taste like napalm. The lack of a vile chemical burn is both surprising and pleasant, meaning this beer is actually drinkable. Comparably, itâ€™s nicely non-horrific, exponentially more not-awful than it should be. It even keeps a decent head and has some lacing. Amazingly near to somewhat average, instead of horrid.

Surprisinging in its lack of offensivness. Maybe it is just that this was sampled side-by-side with Rockman High Gravity Lager, but I found this one to be palatable. This is especially surprising given the brewer. Thanks for the experience Dan.

This didnâ€™t taste bad to me. It was cold and cheap. I was tired and thirsty and had been bicycling 15 miles. At times like that you can be grateful for just about anything, so it hit the spot, and had a nice alcohol content to relax me. Iâ€™ve tasted worse, trust me. I was curious about this cheap stuff, because I had tried Gluekâ€™s regular beer, which was also cheap but reasonably good for the price. This stuffâ€™s about the same quality and same low price, and has some pretty potent buzz potential to go wth it.But my next beer will be the other stuff I bought, i.e., Octoberfest. I only want one of these for now. .

This was the best beer I have ever had. I first had it in Rochester Minnesota. And I have been hoping to get it out here in Illinois anytime soon.. If you like strong bottom of the barrell beers this one is definately for you. Thanks Melissa

This was a tailgating gift from JMerritt. It had a malty taste that was a bit strong until you got used to it. I didnâ€™t have a glass so donâ€™t really know much else about it. Hope I never have it again - thanks JM :)

Draft: Pale straw. Compact, but lapsing, white head. Cleanly minerally, Pilsner malt aroma with honeyed apple hints. Fluffy, semi-fuzzy carbonation. Skillfully balanced display of crispy, doughy malt and poignant hop spice. Nice integration of muted melon fruitiness and lengthy fresh baked bread flavors. Restrained apple acidity. Off-dry, invigoratingly hoppy finish shows a flash of mineral astringency which heightens the dryness and curtails the lush doughy malt remnants. A respectable attempt at a difficult style to brew.

This beer is a brilliantly clear, pale gold color and is topped by a frothy white head that is quite creamy in texture. There is a light aroma of spicy hops, and a hint of clean grain. This beer has a nice soft sweet grain character to it, but that is not all. A subtle spiciness, plus a bit of herbal character, runs throughout, and it finishes with a nice complimenting bitterness that is a bit more than I was expecting in a KÃ¶lsch. This is quite quaffable, and quite clean too, thought there is a hint of creamy fruitiness here. This is a really nice example of a KÃ¶lsch, and is certainly the best commercial one I have ever had.

Had a stange aroma to startout with. Second sample tried strange odor not there. Oh well, nonetheless flavor was slightly bitter. Gold body with white head and some lacing. Refreshing but not much different from common swill.
Light yellow with small head and lacing. Aroma is clean and crisp malt. Flavor is light malts with a light body. Light,easy drinking beer.

Draught @ Papago The beer pours a lightly hazed gold with a modest and bright white head that is semi-creamy in texture, and the resultant lace a thin covering upon the glass. Nose is sweet malt; fresh and pleasing, start is sweet, malt profile adequate and the top thin. Finish is mildly acidic, the hops personable in their spicy bite, quite dry and a drinkable beer.
Straw colored, clear. Aroma is medium grassy. Taste is medium grassy hoppy, decent bitterness, medium carbonation.
About as good as a lawnmower beer can get. Flowery hop aroma with hints of malt and a tiny bit of fruit. Crisp, clean malt flavor with some pleasant hops in the finish. Very refreshing beer.
Clear, malty nose. Heady malt-flavor for a Koelsch, and airier too. Slight bitter finish. Quite good.

The Cowboy is out of business but I have to get my props in for this beer. This was the best hefe Iâ€™ve had, bar none. The banana / clove was perfect and this beer had a spiciness that was so complemantary that it nearly rendered the beer perfect. Great body, greath mouth feel. Itâ€™s just a shame most people canâ€™t appreciate good beer because losing this Gem was a tragedy for Scottsdale.

This beer is a pale, hazy straw color and it is topped by a creamy white head. The aroma is dominated by clove at first, but I quickly am able to get notes of banana as well. There is perhaps a hint of spicy/ tart wheat in the nose as well. The taste is soft and fruity up front, it then moves to notes of banana and spicy clove. The finish is lightly tart, with a slight bite from the hops. This beer is soft and creamy, yet it has a sharp spiciness to it all at the same time. This is really quite nice. There is a nice wheat character that is a bit tart. This is really a quintessential example of a Bavarian Hefeweizen

Wow one of the first hefeâ€™s Iâ€™ve had on tap lately without a lemon for carbination. Hazy yellow body with white head and some lacing. Aroma you could smell the banana here. Flavor was also banana and also creamy. Easy drinking beer.
Hazy yellow with a nice white head and thick lacing. Aroma is all banana with flavors of banana, malt, hops with a tangy spicy finish. Good refreshing Arizona beer.

Draft: Foggy lemon. Tall, tightly packed white head is slow to recede. Soapy yeast, clove, white grapes, bananas, and airy phenols comprise the aroma. Soft body but equally firm and minerally. Rich banana and bright clove esters temper the immediate quenching lemony acidity. Husky malt base with fresh bready dustings sliced with plump lemon pulp flavors add more juiciness. Lack of dryness fails to highlight the spicy esters and subtler hop elements. Doughy yeast pervades with a partially gritty accent. Mashed plantains uphold the thinnish body. Straightforward, but delicious, clove-dusted doughy malt finish. Carbonation is low/soft for the style and lacks the crunchiness-turns-creamy texture. The body could stand to be yeastier and the estery flavors are a tad understated. Quite a polished example, though.

Light clove and bananas. More subtle flavors than most, largely wheat. Doesnâ€™t knock you off your feet with sweetness. Fairly dry finish. Very creamy and not especially crisp. Apple abounds, not a lot of herbal bite. Light yeast and pepper as well.

The beer pours to a slightly hazy deep amber color; the head is portly in size and the consistency creamy with the color an off white, as it slowly dissolves the resultant lace a fine covering upon the glass. Nose is slightly sweet, mostly malt with a slight hint of the wheat and a touch of banana, start is sweet, light malt profile, the top thin to light in its feel to the palate. Finish is perky in its acidity, the hops mellow and the aftertaste quite dry. A drinkable beer, but I think a bit "Thin Waisted", but it would make a good "Arizona 118 degree Dry Heat" Beer, and "NO" I don't any "lemon" in or on my beer!
Typical golden hazy color. Nice yeasty aroma. Crisp and clean on the palate. Rrefreshing just not quite there yet to a good standard hefe.
Slightly hazy straw colored. Aroma is banana and clove, fairly strong. Taste is mild banana, fairly smooth with decent body.

I am not a wheat beer-drinker, but I thought this beer was outstanding. Aroma of bubblegum, yeast and clove. Brilliant banana and clove flavors, supported by a backbone of malt and wheat. Perfect balance and blending of flavors and aroma. I can say, without a doubt, that this is the only wheat beer I've ever tasted that I would drink again.
Clear golden body with medium head. Medium Saaz aroma. Taste is mildly malty that finishes very dry and Saaz bitter. Slight skunkiness.

The brewer at this small, unpublicized brewery in Scotsdale is truly talented. Hardly anyone has heard of this place, even though the brewer has won multiple gold and silver medals in the largest national and international competitions. No I don't work there. This beer is clean and crisp, balance is slightly more bitter than most pilsners I've tried. Dry finish. Yet another beer style that this brewery has convinced me is worth drinking.
Nice bubbly straw look. Sharp malted flavor, reminiscent of some of the best European pilsners.
Hazy light orange with medium beige head. Aroma is moderaqtely sweet, mild grapefruit hoppy, slight skunk. Taste is medium floral hops, moderate malts, fairly smooth. Finishes nicely dry and bitter.
Light yellow orange, with a nice head. Citrusy hoppy aroma. Excellent lightly grapefruited bite. Smooth, understated, with an IPA character.
Red with caramel nose. Nutty, roasted flavors. Very good in the classical style.
Good golden color. Highly carbonated and easy to drink. Good finish. Some fruity smell.
A hugely nondescript beer. So bland I don't have any good adjectives to use. Stay Away!!
Light orange with little aroma at all. Low key maltiness with a hint of sugars. Light and not what you''d expect from ''strong ale.''

Retired, wow. Took a bet on this 12oz bottle when I bought it from Super Liquor III, it must have been much older than I thought it was. Shared with robotopera. Hazy amber color. Thin off-white head. Decent bits of lace. A lot of caramel, spicy malt. Just a very light old hoppy citrusy spicy earthy taste. Tastes like itâ€™s got an unfortunate amount of age on it. Medium-plus body. Light carbonation. More dry texture, with a spicy bite in the finish. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter, and a big spiciness. This tastes like it might have been a solid IPA fresh, but thereâ€™s no way to tell at this point. If only there was a date stamp!
Weak and underwhelming. The bitterness and hop quality of this beer is less than good. Light aroma of bread and grass.

I believe this beer was my introduction to microbrewed beer. I think they listed it at 6.4% ABV at the BrewPub. Itâ€™s been forever since I had it, but I remember it had a golden hue and a fair amount of bitterness for a rookie hophead. Lots of fun sharing pitchers of this after class with friends. Sadly, Mishawaka BrewCo is no more, so beware if you see this on shelves at your bottle shop, as it is no doubt well past its prime. At least grab it for the label and the memories, if you can get a deal.

Iâ€™m pretty sure we got a six pack that had gone bad because this resembled nothing that a pale ale brings to the table. If this was what the brewer intended to give us then this was the worst beer Iâ€™ve ever had.
Bottle: Poured a doodoo brown with off white head. Light hops aroma. Taste was butterscotch, light hops, a bit unstable and possible infected.
12 oz bottle. Pours bright golden in colour with very small white head. Decent floral hop aroma and taste. Very drinkable IPA, not super hoppy.

Poured a syrupy deep amber, not so much of a head. Excited to get this as an extra, but not really my kind of IPA. The nose was dominated by a malty-booze, coupled with the syrupy mouthfeel just wasnâ€™t my jam, almost thick in a way. Got to take my review with a grain of salt, iâ€™m completeley swayed by the west coast IPA, and it ruins me on other IPAâ€™s, i tried to rate with that in mind.

Bottle with thanks to coyotehunter. Pours copper/brown with little head and aromas of sweet sugary malt and herbal hops. Flavor is horrid. Sweet brown sugar collides with a herbal and medicinal hops presence to produce an absolute trainwreck. Thereâ€™s not much here that works.

Found this one bottled at a liquor store in St. John, Indiana, as part of a mix 12 pack of various beers from Indiana brewers. Hazy, medium reddish-brown pour, a thick, tan head, a nice balanced aroma with sweet malts and rosy hoppiness, balanced flavor, bitter but not offputting finish. Excellent.

Copper-amber pour from a 12 oz bottle. Three fingers of solid, long lasting head. Lacing â€“ it almost coats the glass as the beer goes down. Aroma of sweet malt â€“ caramel and butterscotch â€“ with a notable hoppiness. Solid IPA flavor â€“ slightly sweetish start with a pleasant bitter hoppy finish. Not an extreme IPA but a damn good one.
Slightly musty odor--not sure what this is initially. Drinkable nevertheless. PsychProf was right in saying that these beers have a tangy sourness to them. Interesting.

Bottle: Not quite sure what style this is. Golden amber color with small white head. Aroma of yeast, wheat, and sugar. The body is light with an enjoyable sweetness with a sticky bitter finish. Pretty smooth overall. Still have no idea what this is, but I must say it was my least favorite beer I tried from Kraftbrau.

"A novel beer" - label. "A lager that''s not as flavorful as some of our others." - the barmaid. So, I had the sampler tray of 5 lagers and 1 ale. I was bummed because my absolute fav from the brewery is the Helles and they were out. The barmaid assured me they didn''t have any bottles either. So I saunter over to the brewery''s fridge (as you only can after a sampler tray in 30 minutes) and found 1 remaining Helles (treasure) and this concoction. It is an interesting blend of flavors, that''s for sure! Definite American Wheat components (tart/sweet) - chill haze plus some unfilteredness makes it look nice - Saaz aroma, but not the body to go along with it...in fact it was thin and watery. Yet...unusual in flavor. Yes, it''s a lager, but not one I''ve ever experienced! What the hell are these guys using that imparts that characteristic sourness? I am sure it turns some folks off.
Black and filtered. No head. Nose is minimal. Taste-a bit of roasted malt and not much else. This is brewed at JJJ Chophouse.

Brewery is now Triple Js but the beers are the same. Pours out a clear brown color with a small tan head. aroma is malty and somewhat sweet. flavor was a little bit malty but not much else going on there.

Surely by now, everyone knows that Porter is not one of my fave styles, but htis one had several redeeming qualities- the biggest being the wonderfull mouthfeel. It was like velvet in the mouth. Wasnâ€™t too ashy.
Dark, coffee-chocolate aroma, fairly typical porter but still decent. Nice smooth mouthfeel, best beer in the house.
Not a bad beer, but not GABF award winning IMHO. Very smooth, with a sweet mocha taste.

Black body that is opaque. Some lacing and a small light brown head. Nose is chocolate, roasted malt and some sort of stale grain. Taste is sweet and smooth, with chocolate and a little bit of coffee. Much sweeter than the porter but lots of water in the taste and mouthfeel.

GABF â€™05. Listed as the "Double Chocolate Stout". Black body. Chocolate malt (strong), some coffee, and a hint of fruit in the aroma. Fermented fruit and tart chocolate malt in the flavor finishing w/ roasty dryness.

(Gaylord Location) This is one of the better beers I''ve tried at this very commercial brewery. Thick, oily, black appearance with a thick, almost nitrogen, looking head. Chocolate is noticable in the aroma but the roasted malts predominate. Wonderfully sweet flavors of cocoa and traditional stout bitterness. A must try if its available.
Brewery is now Triple Js but the beers are the same. another run of the mill wheat beer. nothing great here, but not too bad at all. cloudy yellow with a wheat beer aroma.
Decent wheat and yeast profile, though they are definitely not going for the Bavarian style wheat. Good effervesence.

tap at brewpub-pours a cloudy yellow hue with a small white head. subtle citrus on the aroma. decent palate for this style. flavors of haygrass, orange ,banana and some malt grain husks that add positive things to the flavor i must say. This would make a good quaffer during a TT game at the brewpub.
Pretty good for a hefe....these beers typically get butchered by American brewpubs, but this one was in no way offensive. Had a nice citrus flavor, banana finish.
-1 on appearance for the uninvited lemon, which distorted the aroma. Cirtic, floral, and soapy. Nice mouthfeel, mild flavor but rather well-balanced. Not bad.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Rude Elf's Reserve
column5: Keg at Bethlehem Brew Works. Clear amber, large creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of toffee, soy, cherries, clove, ginger. Taste is gingerbread, caramel, toffee, hints of cherry. Medium bodied, oily, a bit of booze. Medium bodied.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Rude Elf's Reserve
column5: Crisp copper and amber coloured body with a ruby glow and a thinnish tan head. Aroma of candy sugar, apricots, pit fruits, nice earth, caramel, toffee, rich fruits and a dose of floral hops, all with a good deal of alcohol as well. Medium to Full-bodied; Rich pit fruit flavour with a lot of sugars, some caster sugar, a lot of earthy and caramel malts and some light alcohol at the end that finishes fairly nice and smooth. Aftertaste has a mellow sweetness with a touch of grain, a lot of light sugars, a smooth alcohol burn and a touch of complexity near the end. Overall, a nice rich and fairly smooth beer for the style that shows nicely and has a good fruity sweetness with alcohol that is well hidden! I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Liqour Outlet in Boonton, New Jersey exactly a year ago on 22-December-2015 for US$2,42 sampled at home in Washington a year later on 22-December-2016.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Rude Elf's Reserve
column5: I poured it from the bottle into a glass. It pours dark red with almost no head. The aroma is spice and dark fruit. The taste is spice, plum, other dark fruit, and booze. It had a strong, boozy taste to it. This was pretty good. I was expecting more though.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Rude Elf's Reserve
column5: Draft pour at the Bethlehem location. Poured a clear copper color with a small off-white head. Aroma was lots of holiday spices. Coriander, nutmeg. Flavor was candi, brown sugar. Booze, but subtle. Nice!

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Rude Elf's Reserve
column5: aroma is of faint malt and holiday spices. amber and clear in color with little head. taste is entirely of holiday spices; clove, nutmeg, cinnamon.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Rude Elf's Reserve
column5: Had this awhile ago poured reddish amber with off white head. aroma cinnamon, nutmeg and the cloves. flavor got all of the spices with some alcohol

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Rude Elf's Reserve
column5: Draft at the Irish Pol. Clear dark orange brown pour with off-white foam. Runny lace mostly disappeared over time. Spicy malt brew with some dark amber fruit and vegetables. Brandy-soaked sugared pears. Clear candy toys. Nutmeg. Cinnamon. Clove. Peat. Celery. Ginger. Apricot cordials. Started off tasting sugary and simple but developed nicely as it warmed. Eventually feels surprisingly similar to many better Belgium Christmas brews albeit a bit rougher. Would have again.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Rude Elf's Reserve
column5: Dark reddish tint, nice spice notes but not overwhelming. A bit of an aftertaste, but overall not bad for such a high abv. Will buy again.

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Rude Elf's Reserve
column5: Not my favorite Xmas style beer. A bit of an aftertaste that made it off putting. Deep red and hazy. Spices and ok and not overboard. Heavy abv, but not worth the drink if you can get a better drink for your drunk! Tap

column1: Fegley's Brew Works Rude Elf's Reserve
column5: Damn, so much spice. Too much spice? Certainly is a Christmas inspired ale. Belgian yeast comes through, sweetness of the malts and possibly Belgian candied sugar.

Gekocht bij drankencentrale Verhelst in Dendermonde eind 2013 en thuis geproefd op 14-12-2013. Zeer goed, lijkt wat op champagne, het ideale bier om niet-bierdrinkers te overtuigen. Ã©Ã©n van mijn lievelingsbieren. Info en foto's: http://www.beersfrombelgium.eu/nl/Deus_Brut_des_Flanders-b-175.html

Bottle. A birthday gift off Hydes. Drunk at the local byo kebab place. Pale, green tinged gold. No head. Nose has cardboard. Some fusty lemon. Bit of a leathery thing. Weird shit this. Taste has some bready sweetness. Pretty dry. Medium body. Fine, massaging carbonation. Drinks easy at the ABV. Light bitter finish. Weirdly underwhelming.

From a corked bottle. Pours light gold with small head. Aroma of light grain, ginger, pear, apple. Significant carbonation and mouthfeel. Flavors of sparkling apple juice, honey, pear, ginger, love. I've had this brew many times over the last 20 years and this time it really stands out as more than just a champagne type beer, but at the Seattle International Beerfest it was the best beer for me, refreshing, sophisticated, smooth and delicious.

From 0,75l bottle at Sanders place. Yellow golden color, small white head. Smells herbal, elder flowers, nice smell. Full body, soft carbonation. Tastes of elder flowers, flowery, light sweetness, Belgian yeast, grassy. Finishes lightly sweet with notes of elder flower, Belgian yeast and grassy notes. Nice one, good to drink
Helder geel bier met ruime witte schuimkraag. Citrus, bloemig, zoet, met niet te. Blijft lang hangen. Beter dan dame Jeanne

Was tending to some homebrew in my basement and stumbled upon a long-forgotten bottle of Deus I had squÃ¬rreled away, vintage 2005. Was a bit worried, to be honest, that it had gone off after all that time, but the 14 or so years didn't seem to adversely affect the golden elixir whatsoever. Chilled to the recommended 2Â°C and it poured a very fizzy, white head that quickly and completely disappeared in the champagne flute. Pronounced ginger note up front and a bit of mellow Belgian funkiness made for a very enjoyable evening sipper with the better half. Will definitely be looking for another bottle in the near future for comparison's sake (and not waiting 14 years to drink it this time, haha).

Copenhagen 30/3 2019. 75 cl bottle from Meny, Borups AllÃ©, Frb F. Corked with metal keeping everything in place. Brown label made out to look hand drawn with a couple of Hippogriffs. CuvÃ©e Prestige 2017. Pours clear pale yellow with a medium-sized white head. Bubbly. Settles as flimsy thin layer of foam. Patchy and unable to cover the surface of the beer. Resembles a Champagne or Cremant. No Lacing. Aroma is spicy, citric and quite yeasty. Cardamom, ginger, coriander. Acerbic citrus. Hints of banana, humid basement and yeast. Strong carbonation. Wildly prickly, tingling, slightly thick texture. Flavor is medium sweet followed by a slightly stronger citric sour bitterness. Aftertaste is bitter sweet and lingers for a short while. Very Champagne-like and vineous in character. Kind of camouflages the fairly High ABV of 11,5. A bit too heavy on the herbal stuff but well made and an amusing concept.

Aroma: light lemon, touch of stone fruit & hop Appearance: nicely yellow with a touch of haze, big head with patching lacing and lots of fine bubbles Flavour: hit of citrus, floral and stone fruit blended with sweet malt and noticeable spiritous, reminiscent of lemon cello Palate: nicely carbonated, good medium mouthfeel, finishes a touch herbal

24 February 2019. Wieze Bierfestival - cheers to Meeki, Ama Deke & the lovely Anke! In a suitable champagne glass, pours clear pale golden with a lasting, thin, frothy, off-white head; pleasantly fizzing at the edge. Aroma of apple cider, dried banana, wheat, white grape, white pepper, breadcrust, melon, flowers, perfume. Taste is light fruity sweet, notes of banana, apple, pear, and weirdly, melon, almost cider-like, next to faint honey & bread & perfumey accents; medium spicy bitter middle has white grape, pepper, aniseed, vague grain & yeast. Just a tad wheaty sour before finishing dryish, bit floral hoppy, lingering banana, bread, spices, and warming champagne-like alcohol. Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation. Definitely a succesful brew, agreeable too, although I'm glad I got to taste one glass at the festival, not having to buy a whole bottle of it...
Ocena uzupeÅ‚niana na podstawie wspomnieÅ„ z degustacji. Wyglada jak szampan, smakuje bardziej jak wino jabÅ‚kowe. IntrygujÄ…ce

column1: Triple J Stauss & Braun Oatmeal Stout
column5: Otis Oatmeal. Pours an espresso color with a light brown head. Nose is milk chocolate, vanilla, meat. Taste is meat smoke, pepper mint, and dark chocolate. Thinner mouthfeel. You give me meat, mint, and chocolate and Iâ€™m happy.

column1: Triple J Stauss & Braun Oatmeal Stout
column5: [Tap] This beer is now being sold by Triple Jâ€™s as Otisâ€™ Oatmeal Stout. I was sure to ask the waiter just to make verify that. The beer is an opaque black color with only a slight film of brown head. Aroma of smoky and burnt caramel. Taste is of chocolate and smooth molasses. Creamy mouthfeel, yet still kind of cloying. Definitely one of their more flavorful beers.

column1: Triple J Stauss & Braun Oatmeal Stout
column5: This beer can be very different after every vat. Smokey, malty aroma. rich, coffe brown color, absorbs most visability. The head goes from Zeigen Bock-weak to as thick, lasting, and frothy as swiss hot chocolate. Usually, itâ€™s pretty frothy and stays in the glass untl youâ€™re done. Palate is smokey, coffe, and malt and very thick texture. Two of these, while not posessing a high alcohol content, will dehydrate you - presumably from the caffeine and tannic acid and can give you a serious headache after one tall. Itâ€™s weird. I never have more than one before witching to a their pale ale or lager.

column1: Triple J Stauss & Braun Oatmeal Stout
column5: black pour thick tan well laced head. Roasted malt and light grass aroma.. avg pal. Flavor is a dry choclate and a grassy bitter swallow. a very blah stout.

column1: Triple J Stauss & Braun Oatmeal Stout
column5: Very decent beer, but doesnâ€™t kick you in the face like a stout should. One of my standbys when I go to Hub City however. Sweet flavor, milky texture, not super bitter.

column1: Triple J Stauss & Braun Oatmeal Stout
column5: I have to say, I was expecting a "stout".... what you get is a nice tasting beer, that is pretty smooth, and sweet, but not stout! I will drink it again.

Bottiglia. Il gusto al naso propende per coriandolo e frumento. L'intensitÃ  olfattiva Ã¨ normale e il modo in cui permane Ã¨ sufficiente. Il mantello birroso superiore resiste abbastanza. La grandezza delle bollicine Ã¨ medio-fine. Il liquido Ã¨ di aspetto trasparente e anche qui la grandezza delle bollicine Ã¨ medio-fine, con carbonazione allegra e vivace. Il colore Ã¨ giallo dorato. Il corpo Ã¨ leggero e scorrevole. L'amaro Ã¨ contenuto. La forza gustativa Ã¨ normale e la permanenza Ã¨ sufficiente. Le sensazioni boccali finali risultano di facile beva. Il finale Ã¨ semplice e dissetante. Il retrogusto Ã¨ di media intensitÃ . Il tetto della bocca riconosce impressioni di miele, frumento, agrumi e arancia amara.
Birra particolarmente gasata, dal colore giallo paglierino e aroma di grano

Bottle from Drankenhandel Leiden. Aroma is sourish wheat, coriander, spicy yeast, pale malt, dough, light orange peel. Flavour is moderate sweet with a mild wheaty sourness that doesn't work for me. Body is medium. Not a fan.

0.25 l bottle from 'Speciaalbierpakket.nl', best before August 2020. Hazy, pale golden with a thin, frothy, almost stable, white head. A little sweetish, floral, spicy and slightly fruity aroma of coriander, orange peel, some banana and a touch of clove. Slightly sweet, moderately bitter, gently yeasty-spicy, moderately floral and a bit fruity taste of clove, banana, hay, wheat and a touch of banana, followed by a short, moderately bitter, rather dry, gently yeasty-spicy finish. Thin to medium body, gently effervescent mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Interesting beer, pretty much a Wit/Saison hybrid, a little too thin for my liking.
Bottle from Jumbo. Pale straw, clear with fine white head. Decent carb. Pretty dry with wheat, lime and a little baking soda. Fair

Robe blonde trÃ¨s pale, assez limpide pour une blanche, belle fontaine de bulles mais zero mousse, on dirait du cidre. La coriandre domine le nez, ensuite classiquement blÃ© et levure, rÃ©glisse?. En bouche toujours la coriandre, les zests d'orange apportent une petite fraicheur, lÃ©ger acide, blÃ© et son. Bonne carbo, longueur limite, corps lÃ©ger. Blanche belge fort classique mais parfaitement rÃ©alisÃ©e si ce n'est la mousse qui gÃ¢che un peu l'aspect de la biÃ¨re...
Une blanche bonne assez classique. Les Ã©pices se sentent bien, le dupont n'est pas caractÃ©ristique.

Colo amarillo palido, ligera turbidez. Escasos milÃ­metros de espuma sin retenciÃ³n. Aroma floral y a especias. Gusto a trigo, naranja, limÃ³n, levadura y algo de heno, carbonataciÃ³n alta. Cuerpo acuoso. Cerveza blanca que carece de cuerpo y tiene un aire de Saison.
Bottle 0,25ltr: Hazy golden colored brew with an nicely dry-like taste, hints of coriander, orange peel and some green apples.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: 12 oz can, red amber clear. Medium body. Powerful cinnamon aroma, with nutmeg and cloves to a lesser degree. Believe there is some beer snuck in there, but the spice is overwhelming in the taste. Bitter unpleasant finish. Pretty bad.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Very heavy on the spices, cinnamon, clove, etc - Christmasy spices, the ones you'd expect. A bit of bitterness at the beginning, either from hops or excessive spicing, can't tell which. If they laid off the bitterness just a bit, and toned the spices down slightly, this might be very good. It's acceptable as is, but nothing to write home about.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: light amber beer modest head nice egg nog spices and a fair beer underneath, pretty clean finish on tap at Stokes

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: 12 oz. can. Canned early November. Deeper brown appearance with the typical Christmas spice hints. Good amount spice in aroma and flavor. Lots of nutmeg, cinnamon, toffee malt body and clove in the finish. The ginger and clove are really starting to take this beer over. Is it any better real fresh? Not sure, overall a bit heavy in the spice department.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Can from Total Wine, Gainesville. Pours clear amber-brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of cinnamon, sugar, nutmeg. Flavor is cinnamon, nutmeg, metal, and little else. It could be spiced iced tea for all I know. Itâ€™s OK, but could be better. Just because you put those "chirstmas" spices into a beer doesnâ€™t make it a winter beer.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Pours a clear amber. Has a nutmeg, cinnamon and light spice aroma. A sweet cinnamon and nutmeg taste with sweet malts and caramel aftertaste.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Drank from a 500ml pint glass, poured from a twelve ounce can. Strong aromas of cinamon. Subtle tastes of both cinamon and ginger. A really awesome winter brew! Thank you Bjorn!

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Nice red color with a beige head. Strong aroma of cloves and cinnamon. Dry and earthy. Would not drink again.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: DATE TASTED: January 29, 2016... GLASSWARE: Mad Elf snifter... OCCASION: celebrating another Friday night with Shan and the Tank... APPEARANCE: dense, burnt sienna body that releases little effervescence...the thin white line forms the head, with a smear of an island in the middle... AROMA: the canâ€™s claims are tangible in the aroma--cinnamon and ginger are the most dominant scents; nutmeg and clove are present...the addition of maple syrup to the olfactory is surprising, as are the wet, toasty malts... PALATE: fizzy early and flat at the finish, with a warming, syrupy draw--not the flourish that I hoped for in a Christmas beer, nor is it as full-bodied as it could be... TASTE: nutmeg, ginger and cinnamon definitely evoke the Christmas spirit--even a month after its exit... the syrupy kickback detracts from the overall flavor--it runs akin to cough medicine, with some malt return to add balance--possibly a brown ale base is in here... OVERALL: This beer gets a bit of a boost from the nostalgia spawned from last weekâ€™s Lamb of God/Anthrax concert in Philly...however, the beer on its own does its job but does not demand a second purchase--a reasonable holiday drink that doesnâ€™t distinguish itself...at 5.5%, a favorable drink to combo...

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: red to deep amber color with a thick head; lots of cinnamon and pie spices in the aroma; smooth with lots of spices in the flavor - mainly cinnamon; medium bodied, bready malt base; I am not usually a fan of spiced Christmas ales, but for all the spices here, it is a pretty smooth and drinkable beer;

Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy pale yellow with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has sweet grains and bread with a hint of honey. Flavor has more of an earthy straw note with some honey and a bit of plastic.
Had it on tap at Northwoods BrewPub. Poured a clear golden hue with no aroma, no lacing or head and a tangy bitter weak hop taste.
Tasted at Northwoods Brewpub. Clear golden color with a thin white head. You can taste a hint of honey. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle from the brewpub. Hazy orange-tan. Thin, patchy white head. Odd sour aroma, quite bad. I donâ€™t really get much honey in it. Really quite a cheap, unprofessional feel to it. Maybe the most boring honey ale imaginable..though Ill bet the honey smooths out the rough edges a bit. Avoid.

Bottle from Skyview, thanks! Bubba shot the jukeBox last night, because he drank a bad beer, that made him cryâ€¦ Golden yellow with a 50/50 airy white head to beer ratio. Aroma of heavy grains, malt, bad brewpub beer and very light honey. Taste of honey, grains, malt and mild lemon. Thin and over-carbonated with a prickly finish.
Tap at Northwoods in Eau Claire, WI on Nov. 18, 2011. Pale yellow pour with a small clingy white head. Grain and corn, quite watery. Bleh.
Could they make more of a generic beer? It tastes like malt extract but with carbonation.
Tap at the brewpub. Medium gold pour with a white head. Very light aroma, some maltiness and a little honey sweetness. Flavor was light as well a touch of sweetness, but not much else.

Appearance: Pours a clear, bright yellow body with a thin, wispy white head. Smell: A light aroma of corn niblets, discount honey, and lemon wedges. Taste: While corn and honey can come together to create candy corn, a Halloween delight, they donâ€™t go well together in a beer. Light, tart citrus flavor and faint spicy hops on the finish. Mouthfeel: Light-bodied. Medium carbonation. Drinkability: This is one bee that needs to die off.

Name: Bumblâ€™n Bubbaâ€™s Buzzâ€™n Brew Date: September 29, 2007 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting, Cellar Party Appearance: hazy pale yellow, wispy white head Aroma: light malty aroma with a hint of spicyness and subtle tartness Flavor: bitter malt flavor, touch of sweetness breaks through the astrengent bitterness, bit of funk, long bitter finish Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 4/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 4/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.5/5.0 Drinkability: 4/10 Score: * /4
(Tap) clear, bright, very dark brown colour with a small brown head; aroma of roast, chocolate liqueur; balanced flavour with a long, light bitter finish
Tap at the pub. Black color. Opaque. Brown head. Roasted aroma. Dark malts. Flavor is roasty, dark malt, bitter grains.
On tap @ GI - Clybourn. Pour is black with a small tan head. Notes of roasted grain, chocolate candy, semi-sweet caramel, and slight bitterness.

7/3/18: $5 draft pour, 16 oz into nonic glass at Goose Island Clybourn. Black liquorice pour, thin tan lacing. Strong pleasant roast coffee aroma, balanced by chocolate. Light tasting, coffee and malt, Creamy texture, light carbonation. Overall good offering.

On tap at Goose Island Brewhouse Chicago. Black beer lasting tan head. Big heavy dark chocolate aroma in a good foreign stout way. Nicely lower carbonation. Some lovely dark chocolate with a little dark cherry. Dry finish. Best beer here so far. Still lacks a little body but the dark chocolate flavour is lovely.

A deep dark stout with a thin dark brown head. In aroma, sweet chocolate malt with light coffee notes, light vanilla, light powdery character, nice and smooth. In mouth, a nice sweet chocolate malt with light coffee, powdery character, light mineral notes, pleasant. On tap at Clybourn location.
Draft at source. Nose is dark cocoa and light coffee. Nearly pitch black pour. Creamy lacing tan head. Taste is bitter chocolate and light coffee. Decent enough stout.
Black pour from draft at goose island on clybourn. Nitro and loose mouthfeel. Off white head. Notes of coffee, and earth. Roasty. Not bad.
very nutty and roasted malt flavor. slightly smokey finish. had a draft pour at GI tap room. pours deep brown with a tan head. aroma of roasted malt.

On tap, poured into a nonic glass. The aroma is fresh coffee and dark fruit with an emerging baking chocolate. The beer is dark and rich with a near opaque, caramel brown hue and a tan, creamy-doughy head that has moderate retention, and good, snowy lace. The taste is medium high sweet and medium bitter. The creamy texture has a thin creamy fuzz for carbonation, and a medium full body. The palate profile is brownies and oatmeal with a roasty finish that cleans quickly leaving an aftertaste that has a mild hoppy cleanse followed by lightly cloying baker chocolate that lingers.

0.5 l draught @ Vltava, Helsinki as Unfiltered Staropramen. Apperance is golden, very cloudy (like some juice) and big head, which dies very fast, lively and bubbly. Aroma has barley. Taste has barley, bit of sweetness from alcohol, which makes this smooth, but also a bit too heavy for a traditional Czech evening session with beer. Ending has enough hops to make this a balanced experience unless you drink too many of these. Not for those who like hoppier Pilsners.
June 28, 2017 - on tap at the Swan. Nicely balanced with malt and hops, palate was smooth and creamy.

Tap. Malty aroma, significant yeasty notes, soft bread notes. Hazy yellow color, white head. Malty and yeasty taste, light sour, light bitter. Light body, watery texture, soft carbonation and soft bitter finish with soft soury notes. Ok.

Big off white head, rich lacing, hazy amberish deep golden body. Aroma has hops, meadow, saaz notes, caramel, malts and bread. Tastes malts, sweet hops, fruity honey notes, caramel, sweet grass, sweet brown bread - ends malty gently. Good body and natural carbonation. Easy fully svetly.

#26 In der Staropramen-Brauerei-GaststÃ¤tte "Na Verandach" in Prag-Smichov getrunken als Kwasnicova-Yeast Beer-Hefebier; also ein sog. KrÃ¤usenbier. Im 0,4L Krug, tiefes bernstein mit viel brÃ¤unlichem Schaum. Im Aroma sehr wÃ¼rzig und fruchtig nach Trockenobst, etwas hefe, wunderbar komponiert. Im Antrunk dann sehr vollmundig und ultra-weich. Es beginnt malzig sÃ¼ÃŸ, wird aber dann stets wÃ¼rziger und im Abgang auch hopfig. Kann man geradezu wegsÃ¼ffeln. Ein wahrlich hervorragendes Bier! *Danke an quack-duck fÃ¼r Deine Prag/Tschechien-Empfehlungen. Es hat uns wunderbar gefallen! Test vom 29.11.2009, Gebinde: Fass Noten: 12,13,14,14,-,14 - 13,63

Draught@SBWF2012. Hazy yellowish orange colour, small white head. Aroma is fruity, wooden, sweet malty along with quite big yeastyness. Flavour is yeasty, fruity, wooden with mild herbal, grassy and toffeeish notes. Thin palate though.
Draught at SBWF. Pours golden with a big white head. Bready, smooth and light bitterness.

Draught sample @ SBWF 2012. Pours golden with a big white head. The aroma has got the fresh notes of hay and bread that one are looking for. Taste is however quite dull and tastes a bit like old white bread.
Very light beer, no noticeable aroma, a boring beer, pilsner urquell is a better choice for this style of beer

I have to assume this is what I had at the shitty little rock bar in kutna hora, labeled Staropramen Nefiltrovany, because whatâ€™s listed here as that name has coriander and wheat and other stuff in it and this certainly did not. Body was deeply cloudy and pale gold with a tall fine-bubbled creamy white head. Nose is extremely pale and neutral with only light touches of pilsner malt and semi-sweet egg white yeast - no discernable hop aromatics, itâ€™s just too muddled. Flavor is pale and quiet wet crackers with sludgy yeast, masking any hop flavor, though their bitterness is present in small amounts. Dense, frothy and rotund body. A strange one, altogether not bad but I greatly prefer the regular Staropramen 12Â°, even if it isnâ€™t a superb bohemian pilsner, itâ€™s at least clean and crisp.

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: Clear gold color and a lacey head. Light aroma that is a little yeasty. Tangy spiciness within a medium bodied brew. Great balance and delicious served fresh.

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: Malt, alcohol and plum aroma. Golden body, brussels lace. Malty, alcohol and raisons taste. But also short hoppy aftertaste. Alcohol comes also trough, but not unlikley
Sampled at gabf. A little haze in this amber golden beer. So light glaor. Hops? Kind of. Sweet malts are watery, too. Swing and a miss.
On tap at brewery. Pours a clear dark gold, white head. Aroma is bread and caramel. Sweet and a decent amount of hops. Thin and dry but full bodied.

Extremely pale color, close to water. No color, no aroma, no flavor, it helped clear my palate for the next beer. Poor excuse for an IPA. My first instinct was that the taps must have been mixed up and he accidentally poured me a coors light, but no... he poured it straight out of the bottle. Unless your dehydrated and looking for some water do NOT waste your time.
Sparkling amber with large off white head. Large bead. Good hop nose. Well hopped throughout
Sparkling gold with large white head. Large bead.Interesting carmel nose. Carmel malt taste with long hop finish
TroszkÄ™ utlenione jak na "mocne" jest nawet Ok, ale ja takich piw nie pijam zazwyczaj trochÄ™ sÅ‚odkie. WiÄ™cej nie kupiÄ™ ðŸ™‚
ZÅ‚ociste wchodzÄ…ce w bursztyn piwo ze Å›redniÄ… pianÄ… ktÃ³ra szybko znika. Aromat sÅ‚odowy nijaki, w smaku gÅ‚Ã³wnie akcenty sÅ‚odowe i karmelu. Czy lepsze od typowych koncerniakow?
Jasny bursztyn. Chleb, mokry karton, diacetyl. W smaku bardzo pusto, goryczki nie stwierdzono.

Butelka. Jak ktoÅ› lubi to do zaakceptowania. Te 7% w miarÄ™ poprawnie ukryte pod tonÄ… karmelu. WÅ‚aÅ›ciwie poza karmelem niewiele czuÄ‡. + za butelkÄ™ 0,33l, bo ciÄ™Å¼ko by siÄ™ piÅ‚o wiÄ™cej - tyle jest w sam raz. SÅ‚odkie i mdÅ‚e, choÄ‡ paradoksalnie doÅ›Ä‡ wodniste.

Barwa zÅ‚oto-sÅ‚omkowa, klarowne. Piana obfita, od drobnych do duÅ¼ych pÄ™cherzykÃ³w, szybko siÄ™ redukuje. W aromacie sÅ‚odowoÅ›Ä‡ i niestety estry przez co piwo trochÄ™ Å›mierdzi. W smaku trochÄ™ lepiej, sÅ‚odowe, trochÄ™ alkoholowe, raczej treÅ›ciwe. Goryczka niska, a wÅ‚aÅ›ciwie znikoma. Mimo wszystko lubiÄ™ to piwo, bo kojarzy mi siÄ™ z wakacjami, zresztÄ… nadal w wakacje je pijam. Butelka 330 ml idealna na plaÅ¼Ä™, jak i przy ognisku.

Not exaclty Red but golden, relatively mild given its strength. Thus I do think the focus on malty and sweetish flavors would go well with a more complex composition which this beer is lacking. Drinkable.
CaÅ‚kiem spoko. MyÅ›laÅ‚em, Å¼e to bÄ™dzie jakieÅ› typowe mocne piwo dla meneli, a tymczasem alkohol jest raczej schowany. Fajne butelki 330 ml.

Etykieta gÅ‚osi, Å¼e piwo Å‚Ä…czy moc z Å‚agodnym charakterem. Z polskiego na nasze - klepie ale wchodzi. Piwo bardzo sÅ‚abe. Zapach alkoholowy, kefirowaty, zgniÅ‚y. Goryczka niska i raczej alkoholowa niÅ¼ chmielowa. Nie do picia.

Barwa zÅ‚ota, klarowne, piana biaÅ‚a, umiarkowanie obfita, jako tako siÄ™ trzyma. W aromacie sÅ‚odowe, nieco estrowe. W smaku sÅ‚odowe, nieco chlebowe, takie misiowate - alkohol nie wyczuwalny, niska goryczka, fajnie sÅ‚odowe, chociaÅ¼ nie jest jakoÅ› szczegÃ³lnie peÅ‚ne. Wysycenie w normie, nieÅºle siÄ™ pije. Przyjemny strong, daje radÄ™.
Aus der Flasche getrunken (Mitbringsel aus Polen). Eher bernsteinfarben mit mÃ¤chtiger Schaumkrone. SÃ¼ÃŸliche Malzigkeit dominiert.
Eastern europe flavours of corn and cheap malts. Water and dull and notes of card board. Not great.

Iâ€™m a bit alarmed to see this as a retired beer... with no new ratings in over a year. I just bought mine a week ago at the CT Beverage Mart in Newington, CT. Anyway, I think this beerâ€™s low rating is deserved. It is overly sweet, with very little of the hop bitterness that I expect from a pils. Tastes a bit skunky, like an old Heineken or Beckâ€™s that was left out in the sun. Bleh.
Bottled@Kahdet Kasvot, Tampere. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma and flavour are both hayish, grassy, bready malts as well as some slight grainy and rubbery notes.

Bottle: Pours a clear gold color with a white head. The nose is lightly fruity with some husk and pale malt notes. Clean light flavor with a touch of grain and apple. Not bad, needs a little more hop bitterness.

Tap at company gathering in Gdansk. Light yellow colour, wiyh a thin white head. The aroma is sweetish, with notes of malt, hops, caramel and yeast. The flawor is also moderatly sweet, with notes of malt, caramel, hops and metal. Nice party beeer, but nothing great.

Sample from 500 ml can, as Amber Classic, Westerheim stand at Smak 09. ABV is 5.2%. Golden colour, moderate head. Moderate malty aroma. The flavour is clean and fairly malty for a pilsener, with moderate hops in the finish.

No 306 Rated: 23.01.2008 Can, 500 ml, 11P Appearance: Pours bright shiny, perfectly filtered, golden colur typicall of a Pilsener type beer colour. Head is medium to big in size, frothy, white with decent lacing, slowly decreasing to small, than lasting for quite a long time, carbonation of the body is initially medium , but quickly decreasing to gentle in intensity, 3/5 for a good lacing and well filtered body with a natural gass, again sediment flaoting in the body. Aroma: Very faint and gentle, a bit milky, some hint of chalk and lemon, very simple, not much but positive, denoting quite high standard of lemon lager beer being Pilsener in type. Very mild and gentle floral aroma of hops when the beer gets warmer. Alcohol is not felt being very well hidden. Flavour: Front is grainy and balanced between bitterness and sweetness, than what comes is a distinct grainy taste, flour, malted barley, chalk and a bit accidic - aromatic nose from hops and carbonation. Some notes of lemon and citrus in general. Very good balance between sweetness&bitterness. Finish duration is average. Palate: Body is light, texture is rather wattery, not dry as Bohemian Pilsener, but still well balanced between bitterness and sweetness, carbonation is soft on palate. Finish feel is grainy and chalky.

Bottle and marked with an ABV of 5.5% versus the 5.2% listed on this site. Poured a small white head that mostly diminished, minimal lacing, visible carbonation, transparent, and a yellow hue. Nose was malty, some hops and corn. Flavor was malty, corn, hops, and somewhat crisp tasting. Tingly mouthfeel. Medium body. No desire to have this one again. Just didnâ€™t like the taste of this one.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop marked lot 80 poured a small sized head of foamy white colored bubbles that were and left behind a slightly hazy typically carbonated light yellow-white colored body and a fair lacing. The mild aroma was floral and malty. The crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a mild malt hop aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of malt hops and floral. An OK brew just nothing special.
Canned. Pale golden with a brief, white head. Dry, papery nose with loads of sour vegetables. Sweet flavour with some notes of raisins. Ash-like bitterness.

From memory, This was a favorite. Used to drive up to New Hampshire couple times a year for it. Remember a good nose Carmel, pine, orange. Nice reddish brown color, always clean. Flavor has the same as the aroma. Very easy drinkin, clean bittersweet finish. I miss this one!

I had many pints of this at the Barley Pub in Dover NH. I'll definitely have to look up Trout Brook. As for the beer, it was quite decent, with a strong hoppiness, as a good IPA should have, but it didn't have the over-bitter, sometimes metallic aftertaste that can make an IPA bad. The aroma was fruity and hoppy with a hint of bread.
One of the best IPA''s Ive ever had. Hope Paul starts making the same at Trout Brook
A very unique tasting Oktoberfest, and certainly one of the better I have had in the last 5 autumns.
reddish amber color, minimal off-white head. not much nose, mild malt and spicy carbonated flavor, faint hop.
Sparkling amber with tiny bead. Malt nose and antiseptic malt taste.........

Bit messy and unpredictable, the Bootleg range. You canâ€™t accuse their beers of being carbon copies of the styles they emulate, but the results are at least interesting. This one was clear brown with a fair head and reeked of coffee beans. Very intense for a 4%abv brown ale. Also in the mix were drinking chocolate powder and some mint. The aroma raised expectations of something full flavoured and robust. Alas no. Milky coffee notes dominated but it went AWOL in the mid-palate and finished abruptly. The carbonation was soft, verging on flat, which seems to be a feature of the bottled range. Drinkable but a bit muddled. (Cozâ€™s Ashfield RB get-together 07. Thanks Coz for this one.)
Bottle. Rusty caramel and some stoutish nutty flavours. KInd of wanted to like it but it just muddled its way to a rather unpleasant finish.

330 ml bottle - Dark reddish brown with a tan head. Thin to medium bodied with light to medium carbonation. Dark roasted malts with a slight nutty/coffee taste, and a faint hint of molasses and charcoal/ash. A low to medium bitterness throughout.

Bottle -- A deep brown brew with a huge tan head and lots of cabonation. Caramel/Chocolate aroma. Watery mouthfeel. Roasted maltiness. Strangely sharp bitter aftertaste. Itâ€™s OK but I probably wonâ€™t buy it again.

Nicely made porter style. Cola-like in appearance but poor head retention. Sweet chocolate nose, feels grainy. Less heavy in the mouth as the chocolate and roast notes are subtle but probably in keeping with the style. In line with most Oz peers but overpriced at $4.
Roasted malt hop aroma. Black coca-cola colour with foamy head. Malt bitter flavour. Fizzy palate
11 Apr 2006 - Sweet fruit malt hop aroma. Dark brown colour, good head and good suds lacing. Simple roasted malt flavour. Thick, bitter finish and roasted malt aftertaste.

pours with a great white head over the malty brown beer. Beer is quite well balance with a predominance of chocolate grains leadin the initial taste with a slight sour/bitter aftertaste. Is perhaps a little thin, but at the same time is true to itâ€™s aim of emulating the british way of making beer.

Dark crimson with a light brown head. Aroma is sweet and fresh with some chocolate malt. The beer is great up to this stage.. but thats where it ends.
