The mouthful is thin, and the roasted malts are far too strong in the palate, leaving an aftertaste similar to eating chocolate malt straight out of the sack. The hops are subtle, and bitterness is low. Unimpressive

Maybe my trouble is that I had this from a bottle and not from the keg, but I was very disappointed. I cannot believe that this won any awards based on my tasting experience. Poured very over-carbonated, fizzy with a big head that sunk to nothing quickly. Dark brown and clear, some roasted malt aromas. Sweet palate, but very watery with too much caronation, some nutty chocolate notes, but I had to really search for these traits among the malt. I must have had a bad bottle because nobody else seems to have had a similar experience.

column1: Dogfish Head Snow Blower Belgian Ale
column5: The brewpub brought this one out of retirement in Feb 2015. This time around the beer is 6.5% and brewed with two Belgian yeast strains. Pours a cloudy amber orange with a medium bubbly white head. Aroma of spicy and fruity belgian yeast, sugary notes and some dark fruits. Flavor of spicy/fruity belgian yeast character, citrus, dark fruits and light toasted malt.

column1: Dogfish Head Snow Blower Belgian Ale
column5: Growler courtesy of mday. Served in a tulip. Pours a moderate brownish color with a white head that sticks around for a bit with a decent amount of retention. The nose brings forward a moderate amount of sweetness and yeasty esters as well as a light spiciness throughout. The flavor is moderately sweet without too much going on. Thereâ€™s a bit of yeast and fruit, but nothing standing out too much on its own. The mouthfeel is decent enough with moderate carbonation and a good body. Drinkability is pretty decent but thereâ€™s nothing really pulling me back for more. Serving type: growler Reviewed on: 01-20-2011

column1: Dogfish Head Snow Blower Belgian Ale
column5: 12 oz draft at dogfish head served in a snifter; retention is not great on this one, but it leaves an attractive show of lacing. Pour is murky gold with two fingers of thick White head. Nose is cantaloupe, pears, Belgian yeast, and various spices. Taste is on par, but the fruit is actually a dominant factor. This is a much appreciated turn, especially outside of the world of lambics. Although not my style of choice, this is one tasty brew!

column1: Dogfish Head Snow Blower Belgian Ale
column5: On tap at the dogfish head new years eve event served in snifter pour was cloudy orange with one finger of off whit head.nose was light fruits and belgian yeast. Taste was Yeast,spices and nice fruity Finnish.

column1: Dogfish Head Snow Blower Belgian Ale
column5: Donâ€™t know how else to describe this one except to say "weird and weak". I wasnâ€™t impressed. Might try it again but I doubt it.

column1: Dogfish Head Snow Blower Belgian Ale
column5: On tap at the Gaithersburg location on 1/19/07: Pours a transparent copper orange with a wispy-lacing white head. Aroma of lightly sweet crystal malt along with a hint of piny hops. Body starts fairly full and malty with a good flavor hop balance and earthy caramel notes. A good brew, but I didnâ€™t get much Belgian ale character out of it.

column1: Dogfish Head Snow Blower Belgian Ale
column5: Wow. What a huge dissapointment. I expect so much more from DFH and this was just so pedestrian, that it was embarassing, No identifying characterstics what so ever from this one.

column1: Dogfish Head Snow Blower Belgian Ale
column5: Pours orange fading to tan with a decent sized head of fairly large bubbles. Very mellow aroma, but interesting cheese notes, some grass, and dark fruits. Taste of light O-fest style malts, white grapes and a light sugar sweetness. Mellow flavor. Thereâ€™s a light spicy finish where the yeast makes itself known (without overdoing it), and a surprising earthy hop bitterness. Fairly light body and a medium to high carbonation. This is a pretty mellow beer, but it certainly doesnâ€™t offend and itâ€™s probably intended to be drank fast and in large quantities.

column1: Dogfish Head Snow Blower Belgian Ale
column5: DFH tasting in Houston at Flying Saucer with KAggie97. Looks more like a filter Belgian Ale. Light cherry nose. Taste is sweetness that reminds me of Muscat Canelli , but not that viscous. Honey notes as well. Not sure what this beer is, but itâ€™s not a Belgian.

column1: Dogfish Head Snow Blower Belgian Ale
column5: Dogfish Head tasting, Flying Saucer, Houston. Pours thin for a Belgian, with an aroma of sweet berry and muscat wine. Dull grapefruit and orange flavors. Iâ€™m having trouble identifying this beer as a "Belgian;" it seems to have more in common with an IPA. Average mouthfeel. This is about as Belgian as a Guinness.

column1: Lonesome Pine Red River Red Ale
column2: Red River, New Mexico, United States
column5: Sudzy, lasting head. Somewhat watery mouthfeel. Sweet and roasty, candy-coated flavors in the malts. Sugary, slightly bitter finish. Easy to drink; maybe too easy.
Spicy malt hop aroma with an ashtray thrown in for good heasure. Slight murky yellow colour with poor head and lacing. Bitter malt flavour with chemical aftertaste. Flat palate.

An amber light is supposed to tell you to slow down before it goes red. At 2.7% you donâ€™t have to at all. Silly really. I guess if you down a thin beer you become what you drink, but you also wouldnâ€™t want to become insipid, unimpressive or tasteless.
bottle, beertopia â€™06. darker than most lights, faint syrup and pride of ringwood with a little detergent and pond scum

A bit hesitant to taste any beer light in alcohol, most Aussie macroâ€™s have stooped to low levels in their quest to brew a full flavoured light beer, but most micro-breweries tend to bring out the best in care when it comes to all their beers and this seemed no exception. Tasted from the bottle after a visit to the brewery and poured into a pilsner glass. Clear deep amber with a short lived bubbly white head that manged a little lace. Sweet caramel and nutty aroma, very subtle, with a little grassy hops. Thin watery palate, light in carbonation and and little length in the swallow. Light malty flavours, nutty and woody, a little sweet and only a hint of bitterness in the back (malt more than hops). Not too bad a light beer and a decent effort from this nice brewery in W.A.â€™s south.
Pours clear amber with medium fading to small white head. Hoppy aroma with hints of caramel. Thin, though smooth. Nutty with a slightly hoppy finish. Toffee in flavour too. Suprisingly good.
Yellow in colouring with a thick cloudy off-white head. HInt of floral, woody aroma. Smokey, malty taste. A bit too watery for my liking.
Awful. They told me at the brewery that the batch I was drinking had something wrong with it. Good for advertising donâ€™t you think?

Didn't think much of this one from the bootleg mob. Thought it was a little bit similar to the settlers pale but mainly lacking in flavours and colour. No carbonation and no head grassy metallic taste.
At AIBA 2003. Not really amber in colour at all. However it actually does have quite a strong and agreeable flavour (for a light) Still a little watery though.
ABIA 2003: Not bad for a light, pretty watery, but you can actually taste hops and malt in this one.
Great on the nose, fresh & hoppy and looks slick once you've poured it into the glass. This one lacks the weight on the palate which is a bit of a let down for me.
Got a grassy edge on the nose. Bit hoppy. Definitely IPA but bitterness might be a bit high. Got ground coffee. Has fruit with touch of chocolate. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap from Mane Liquor. Pours a golden brown with 2cm of off-white head. Sweet caramel biscuit and grassy nose. Flavour is well balanced, nice easy drinking carbonation and body. Lingering bitter-sweet hoppiness. Great for a WA beer!

Bottle At mane liquor. Pours a golden with a nice white head. Aromas of citrus , honey and malts. More bready honey malts in the taste. Not as fruity up front. Sweet bitterness. Tasty ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Light gold pour with little head. Aroma is largely malt, but with some tropical fruit and biscuit. Taste predominantly malty, a little citrus, some bread.
Had on tap at the brewery. A very nice american pale ale. Lovely hop aromas and bitterness.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Not sure why this isnâ€™t getting higher raps. Great looking orange amber with a big, fluffy white head leaving great lacing. Nose is a little one dimensional but what is there works well - caramel, biscuit, grapefruit, citrus. Quite malt driven but the hops arent at all subdued. Great grapefruit finish. Tasty stuff

330mL bottle, pours a light golden almost straw colour with a grassey/citrus, slightly doughy/wheat aroma. Nice bitterness upfront with a light lemon zest and smooth finish. Decent lacing and creamy head, nice beer.
Pours golden color, not much head and didnâ€™t laste. Bit citrus and bready taste but not too special. Another one i will need to try from the tap

Nose is somewhat fruity with citrus and floral hops plus a significant amount of grass as well. Lightly dusty, a some bread and crackery malts as well. Pours light golden with a short lived frothy head and lace - the picture to the right looks way better. Grassy, floral, citrusy, light bread and cracker malts. Dry and crisp with a decent hoppy finish. Drinks well. Well carbonated.
Tap. Hazy amber with a laced white head. Lots of hops but a good malty balance.

Tap. Moderate roasted grain and dark bread for the malt, light herbs for the hops, light dough for the yeast, with notes of clove, nutmeg, ginger and dark dried fruits in the background. Head is small, frothy turning wispy, off-white, with some slippery lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is dark reddish brown. Flavor starts slightly sweet and lightly to moderately acidic, then finishes slightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, dry, with a lively carbonation and a lightly astringent finish. A really unique winter warmer type Spiced Beer with a dry and bitter finish.

On tap at madMex in cranberry. cola color, no head but some lacing, i liked the malty and mellow flavors. the Ale is a little thin and the spices come across quite bitter at end, but still very pleasant.

Dark beer with some mahogany hints around the edge. Foamy beige head. Malty nose with some sour funk. This beer tastes like something unwanted took over. There is some spice flavors and a dark sugar sweetness, but the sour tang over powers the other flavors. I wonder if it is supposed to taste like this.

22oz traded bottle from 2009. Pours a very murky, dark brown with a thin, khaki head. Light aroma with a little spice, banana and a hint of sour fruit. Nice flavor of roasted malt and just enough spice to make it interesting. Pleasant.
Reddish dark brown with a fizzy head. Cinnamon nutmeg and clove aroma and taste with an almost tart spicy finish.

Welp, this vaults me into the top 5 raters for 21st Amendment, which is a decent honor to have since they are an underrated brewery. Yes, I realize that nobody cares about this in the slightest. No, I donâ€™t care that you donâ€™t care. Yes, I know you donâ€™t care that I donâ€™t care that you donâ€™t care. And so on. Had this on tap at 21st Amendment on New Years Eve. The description is wrong - this beer is not a copper color, itâ€™s dark brown with reddish hues to it. A small off-white head sits on top but fades pretty quickly. Aroma is heavily spiced with some caramel and roast. Flavor is lots of winter spices (cinnamon, allspice, and nutmeg), caramel, roasted malt, and molasses. Medium body and just a little booze in there, but not more than youâ€™d expect for an 8% beer (which is how it was listed on the menu, although RB has it at 7%). Overall an above-average holiday beer.

On tap at 21A Appearance: Dark brown with a off white head, some lacing Aroma: Holiday spices, cinnamon, nutmeg, etc..... Taste: Tastes like it smells. Alot of spice, but not over the top. A nice balanced beer for the holidays.
22oz bottle. Clear reddish brown. Lots of ginger and spice and everything nice. A bit too bitter on the finish. Solid.
Draught at pub. This is a great holiday ale. Just the right amount of spice, not overdone like so many others. Allspice, nutmeg, cinnamon, and clove with a little fig. Good warmer.

Draught at the brewpub. Clear dark ruby, small head. Distinct spicy nose with nutmeg, chocolate and spruce. Medium bodied with clean mouthfeel. Lightly roasty and richly spicy with orangey notes. Low-medium bitterness. Like most beers from this brewer the flavours are really good, but the mouthfeel is too clean and hard.

Draft flight 3/23/05 (Brewery had as Baren Marzen)-Pours a medium amber with a small head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, malt, and slight hops. Taste of the same. This medium bodied brew is hoppier than most oktoberfests but I think it adds to it.

Draft. Rich amber beer with an off-white head. caramel aroma with mineral notes. Rich caramel/toffee flavor with a light earthiness. Medium body. Toffee and light earth linger with some light hopiness that keeps it interesting.
A hoppy, amber drink, with alcohol hidden by the mats and flowery aromatic hops. A nice drink on a warm festival day.

Draught, Thirsty Bear. Head is mostly diminishing. Body is medium to dark amber. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain, cookie, caramel), lightly to moderately hoppy (flowers, herbs, apricot), with notes of peach, honey, and black tea. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation. Excellent beer, this. Malty, fruit, hoppy, itâ€™s got it all in the nose. And a terrific flavor balance. Yummy stuff.

Draught at the brewery. Beer is clear, medium/dark brown. Head is small, white, frothy, quickly diminishing but mostly lasting.The aroma is dominated by malty goodness redolent with fantastic, toothy, full breadyness. Moderate notes of caramel, biscuit, toasted grain; Hoppy with light notes of herb, alfalfa, honeysuckle flowers; Yeasty with a trace of basement.The flavor is moderately/heavily sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter with a long, lightly bittersweet, trace acidic finishThe body is medium, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.Stunning.

On tap at the brewpub. This was being called the "BÃ¤ren MÃ¤rzen" when I had it, but the bartender said it was essentially the same recipe as the Oktoberfest. Amber/copper in color with a white head. Extreme sweetness. Lots of berry flavors (blueberry and raspberry) from all the hops present here. Seems super strong at 6.5% ABV. Aroma is candy sweet. Mild carbonation, medium body, poor lacing. A very unusual beer in my opinion. Not bad, but definitely does not fit the style. Odd little beer.
Medium amber. Off white head. Malt aroma. Flavor of malt, but a lot more hops than Iâ€™d expect in an Oktoberfest.
Tap. Copper color with a foamy white head. Light malts with an air of spice. Nice and smooth.

column2: San Francisco, San Jose, California, United States
column5: Tap. Dark brwon. Minimal aroma. Malty body but rather light and watery...
Draft at the brewery, served with lemon. Hazy orangish yellow with a small white head. Standard banana/clove/wheat aroma, average sweetness with no hop character. Medium-light body. Meh.
Overall: Honey, orange. Refreshing. Note: Steelhead Brewing Company Reviewed 2014-03-16.
Not bad. On draft in Burlingame. Fruity citrus aroma and palate, soft round and easy for summer

On tap at Steelhead Burlingame poured a cloudy yellow with a small lasting white head. Aromas of wheat, yeast and a hint of citrus. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of wheat, yeast and a hint of citrus with a crisp finish.
On tap in Burlingame. Hazy orange with a small white head and some lacing. Aroma and taste of wheat, lemon, honey and citrus. A nice mild, easy drinking hefe.
A decent enough beer though slightly lighter than a good hefeweizen in my mind. Nice and wheaty.
A brilliant Hefeweizen, probably the best I have ever tried. After you swallow the beer a delicious aftertaste will develop in your mouth. "Two thumbs way up!" -Roger Ebert

Tasted on 1/23/11 on draft at Steelhead Irvine. Pours cloudy orange amber with a thin white head that leaves a thin collar of lace. The nose is nutty with wheat, spicy yeast, light citrus, and biscuit. The flavor is wheat with light citrus, lightly spicy hops, and biscuit. The body is medium with lively carbonation and a short finish that has flavors of yeast, lemon, and light hops bitterness.

A: The pour is a turbid/hazy pale golden color with a fingerâ€™s worth of white head. Served with a slice of lemon, unfortunately. S: The nose, surprisingly, starts off with clove and banana notes. Thereâ€™s a definite wheat character, too, almost a raw wheat thing going on. Not a very good nose, but not horrendous. T: This is probably too bitter for a hefeweizen, but itâ€™s not overwhelming. Thereâ€™s a decent clove flavor, but not really any banana, and not really too sweet. Lightly tart at points and a definite straw flavor on the finish. M: The body is medium and so is the carbonation. D: I guess Iâ€™ve had worse brewpub hefeweizens, but this wasnâ€™t all that great either.
Hazy light golden color/ fleeting white head. Lemon slice and mild tart pale wheat aromas. frothy light mouthfeel. Grainy bready pale wheat flavor with very mild banana.
(Tap) clear, bright orange amber colour with a small white head; aroma of honey, jam; balanced, simple flavour with a long, medium bitter finish
Nice red ale. Slight maltiness and nice level of fizz. Nicely drinkable beer. (K)

Couple of pints at Game Over arcade in Lincoln City OR $4.50 Typical darker amber colour with a small tan head. Malty aromas..caramel and toffee. Malt forward amber ale here..although there is a wee bit of the floral hop going on in the end. Mouth feel was pretty nice..smooth drinker. A good malty amber for drinking not thinking.

Draft at the brewery. Reddish amber color with a white head. The aroma is weak but nice, caramel but not many hops. Caramel malt flavor, medium sweet, slight bitterness. Not bad. The mouthfeel is very standard. Overall an OK, malt-forward red.
on tap at the brewpub; clear, deep amber color; caramel,toffee aroma with floral hops; nicely balanced; floral hops on a medium bodied caramel malt base

Part of a flight at the brewery with Dadbra. Amber pour. I donâ€™t know if it was the smell of the kitchen, or if it was a dirty tap line, but I was getting a weird, unpleasant smoked aroma. Smoked or fishy.
On tap - dark rust color with a small head and lacing. Sweet toffee aroma and taste. Slick mouthfeel. Not bad and not spectacular.
Pours light red. Sweet red caramel malt smell and taste. Pretty balanced flavor and not too sweet or hoppy. Decent red ale, but unremarkable.

On tap at the brewery in Burlingame, California, pours an amber red color. Nose is a bit malty. Taste is caramel and malty with some flavor. Finishes on some hoppy notes. Drinkable. Quaff Score 6 / 10

On tap at Steelhead brewing co in Burlingame station. Pours a red amber with a white head and hoppy aroma. Taste is light and subtle, with hoppy, malty, and caramel flavors coming through to the slight bitter finish.
Smells floral and fruity. Taste is the same. Pretty good for a standard issue pale ale

On tap at the brewery in Burlingame, California, pours a clear golden color. Nose slightly hoppy. Taste is flat without any real flavor, rather dull and boring. This was the last of the right samplers, which rarely do, all in all a rather mediocre and below average brewery . quaff score 4 / 10
On tap at Steelhead brewing co in Burlingame station. Pours a clear golden with a white head and aroma of Malta and hops. Taste is light, of malty, caramel, and bread notes with a malty finish

On tap @ Steelhead Burlingame. Hazy straw colored pour with a white head. Nice floral hops, some grapefruit, grass, and orange peel on the nose. A bit of bready sweetness. Light pine. Flavor is lightly sweet with a heavy bitterness. Very piney and grassy. Light citrus flavor. Some bready malt. Not great.
Golden straw hazy body. White foamy head. Little to no aroma. Pretty nice palate, too hoppy for a pale ale thoigh
On tap; perhaps my favorite of the day. Color was ruddy gold. Aroma was quite floral. Flavor was balanced with creamy, toasted mlat with some fruit, flowers and citrus. Much better than expected.
pretty average apa, nothing special, decent small with small head, had on tap at steelhead burlingame

Sample at the Irvine brewpub. Lightly hazed bronze color with a thin white head that diminishes steadily, and small patches of lacing. Citrus hops aroma. The flavor is sweet at first with malt, followed by moderately bitter hops and citrus. The finish is moderately bitter hops with lingering orange peel and hops aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

Tap @ the brewpub. Poured a hazy amber color with an off-white head. Citrus and orange hop notes, although mild, make up the aroma and flavor. Fairly dry finish. Mild-moderate bitterness that grows. Orange peel on the finish. Long bitterness with a light-medium body. Bigger than their IPA.

Date: 12/02/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy burnt orange, fine beige head, bits of lace, sweet crystal malt aroma with citrus hops, sweet crystal malt flavor, lots of citrus and floral hops for balance, touch of orange sweetness, nice lasting bitter finish, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4
Pours amber with no head. Aromas of caramel malt, no hops. Flavor ends with a pretty huge bitterness, but still nice and smooth.
on tap at burlingame. ruby brownish color, bitter malty flavor. stronger than most others at the same site.
Tap in Burlingame, CA. Wow! I did not expect this treat. Great floral aroma. Minty malt flavors with tons of hops and a full body.
On tap in Burlingame. Clear dark brown with a small tan head and spotty lacing. Roasted malts, roast coffee and grainy. OK, lots of roast.
on tap in burlingame. dark brown color, foamy dark tan head. roasted malt nose and flavor, with mild dry bitterness and aftertaste. lots of carbonation and spicy zing too.
Almost black - dark ruby. Lasting head. Good porter with bitter chocolate flavor.
Deep brown with light brown head. Faintly nutty coffee nose. Lightly roasted dry malt flavor.
Tap in Burlingame, CA. Dark brown color with a light brown head. Dry malts and coffee in the aroma and flavors.

Draft at the Bâ€™game brewery. Black in color with a well-formed khaki head. Smooth roast, chocolate, sweet malt aroma. Medium sweet flavor with good roasty notes and dryness. Smooth mouthfeel with medium body. One of the better beers I had at Steelhead, but really only average.

On tap at Steelhead poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lasting tan head. Aromas of roastiness, bakers cocoa, earthiness and light vanilla. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of roastiness, bakers cocoa, and light earthiness with a smooth lingering bakers cocoa finish.
Very nicely done, but seriously, how could this one have gone wrong at all?

Draught pint at Redbones on 12/5/06 Unfortunately, the tan-beige colored head immediately fizzles to nothing, leaving a rather still-looking glass of opaque or near-opaque black liquid. Iâ€™ll chalk it up to pressurization at the bar or the glass (though this is almost never the case at Redbones), as this beer was anything but problematic and I see no point in taking off points from an otherwise wonderful beer. Furthermore, I see plenty of scores showing quite the opposite experience of mine. Sticky, vanilla flavored marshmallows rise up sweetly, dotted with sweet dates, light black cherries and the most subtle, yet noticeable, roastiness. Vinousness, bordering on liqueur-like flavors with anise and maybe some cocoa? Rich, unrelenting aroma (though it must be sniffed close to the glass). No off-flavors and quite the rollercoaster of sweet and dry flavors. Fruity and sweet at times, to spicy and roasty with a broad range of complexities. The flavor takes the aroma and personifies it tenfold. Especially upon warming, itâ€™s just a wealth of rich flavors in the mouth. But as all good beers, itâ€™s balanced as well. Lightly dry char and roast notes balance the sweet choco-caramel and vanilla notes. Dark fruits are perky on the edges and the body is soft, with a sticky, and at times, velvet-like texture. A very lovely anise note is well-placed and balances some fudginess. Coffee flavors are light and stay mostly out of the way, just adding a light complexity. The flavor is so strong and full, it coats the palate and lingers long, with no loose sections. Even undercarbonated, it hardly comes off loose, the malt just adding so much depth and texture. Chocolate-cherry-cola finish with balancing roastiness is phenomenal.

Dark brown, rootbeer-like coloring with a roasted beige head. Some red glint is noticable in the light as well. Roasted malts sport a very caramely aroma. I actually smell the oats as well. Creamy texture and tons of roasted coffee crowds the tongue. Iâ€™m also picking up a smidgen of dark fruit as well - maybe prune. Long finish with a black cherry smack and mild oakiness.

A pretty dark brown pour, and it was dark and cloudy today, so I could not really see any other hints of anything coming through. The aroma was strongly medicinal and very roasty, to me there was nothing sweet about this stout. It seemed to me like the balance was off in the nitro,or the carbonation almost had a gassy, medicinal roastiness. The flavor has lots of chocolate and coffee, but there was just something off here, and I had to pass on ordering a full pint.
(GABF05) Clear red-black body with tan head. Aroma is medium sweet, rich, cocoa, light roast, faint cherry. Taste is moderately sweet, milk chocolate, some caramel, roast. Light-medium body.
Bitter coffe taste, light light on carbonation, smooth start to finish, good winter brew or for desert.

Pours a very dark brown, almost but not quite black with a nice tan head. Aroma was filled with chocolate and coffee tones. Taste was sweet at first then ended a bit bitter when the hops kicked in. Chocolate and coffee tastes really made this sweet stout, and the oatmeal made it nice and creamy.

Huge rich roasted oatmeal aorma that's just incredable. Everlasting light brown head throughout. I hear the Lord Stanley Stout won Gold at GABF in '02, this isn't it. This is just awesome. The rich flavor just emvelops your mind and soul with fantastic coffee and a dark delectable dry sweetness. I would put this against any of the very good one's.

Tasted this in The Esquire House, Glasgow (JDW) in November 2007. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear pale copper red in colour with a thin white head. Hint of sweet shortbread biscuit in the short aroma. Thin mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt delivers a sweet pomegranate fruit flavour which is long in intensity. Slight prickle of hop resins give a dry aftertaste. Finish is rather short with malt just edging it. An ok session bitter but not my favourite from the portfolio.

Bottle 50cl. Light unclear light amber yellow color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, roasted, nutty notes, light hoppy, light yeasty burnt rubber. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20081122]
Clear golden with tiny white head. Chemical and sourish notes in the nose. Flavour has hints of peated malt, turf and malty notes.
Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Slightly hazy deep golden with a small, off-white head. Lightly nutty aroma. Light body, dry malts, nutty accents and a dry, bitter finish. Very Britih. 221108
Bottle, 3.8%. Hazy orange colour. No head. The flavour is nicely malty with some smoke. The smoke is distinct but mild, making it quite nice.

50 cL bottle. Pours hazy golden orange with a diminished white head. Mild cornish and mild fruity hops aroma. Bitter and mild roasted malty flavoured. Light caramel malty into the finish. Lasting and medium dry into the far finish.

500ml bottle from Westholme Stores, Goring. Bright gold with a thick cream head; earthy caramel aroma; rather watery and soft, with a slightly sour grain flavour, some herbal bitterness, and a dry and chalky finish. Looked good, but it went downhill from there.
Cask at The Briar Rose, Birmingham for the Wetherspoons Beer Festival. Straw with a short head. Slight caramel scent but not much. Bitter and dry. Hoppy, lots of cereal malts. Smooth. Quite good.

Cask in counting house for wetherspoon beers fest. Aroma gives some slight applyy sweetness and grassy hop. Taste is quite sweet from the malts, though not too much appleness, floural aswell as grassy hop and a good bitterness makes for easy drinking, though its not in the best nick i dont recon.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Racehorse - Northampton. A mid brown coloured beer wih a whitish head and lacing. The aroma is pretty dull and standard. The taste though is quite complex. Great fruitiness with cherries and strawberries. Nicely bitter , but with good malt flavours also. Very decent.

Bottled (backlog). Goldeny orange colour with a small white head. Aroma is malts, some wood and resin along with mild floral notes. Flavour is nectar, bready, crisp malts along with some wooden and mild bitter notes toward the finish.

First tasted this at the Mossend Beer Festival, Lochwinnoch in August 1995. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear orange amber in colour with a thin white head. Slight hint of digestive malt in the short aroma. Thin but resiny mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt gives a robust digestive biscuit base with strong orange peel notes. Strong prickle of citrusy hops combine well with the fruity malt notes to give a slightly floral note to the long aftertaste. Finish is fruity with malt edging through and has a taste of thick cut marmalade to it.. A decent session bitter.
Bottle. Pours a medium golden colour with a medium white head. Aroma is malty with a hint of some fruit. The taste is very citrus fruit which give it a bitter taste.

Bottle 50cl. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, resin, moderate yeasty, plastic. Flavor is just bad bad with a long duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20081122]
Cloudy golden with medium white head. Chemical aroma and flavour that finished sourish. Pasteurise your beers god dammit...

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Slightly hazy yellow with a gigantic and very lively head. Some fruit in the nose but also with some unpleasant sulphur notes. Light body, pale malts, a little fruit and a dry finish. 221108
Bottle, 4.5%. Plasticky aroma. Clear yellow colour. Big stable white head. Bad plastic flavour. High carbonation. Infected and undrinkable.

50 cL bottle. Pours cloudy yellow with a huge white head. Yeasty and fruity aroma. Light phenolic and slight chemical aroma. Sweet malty and light spiced flavoured. Light and crisp flavoured into the finish. Has a vague off-note yet also sweet and mild yeasty, pleasant.
Nice golden yellow on the pour with a frothy white head. nose is light and sherberty. flavour is lemon sherbert and surprisingly smoky. pleasent surprise.
Cask gravity at SIBA BF, Paddock Wood. Gold, appley, earthy. Too earthy for my palate.

Bottle. Deep Amber in colour. Lively carbonation; frothy head. Very Malty; caramel, toffee, toasty malt. Fruity; citrus-orange, apple Slightly spicy. Nice malt/fruit/hop balance. Sweetish malty fruity with a lightly bitter finish. (2008)

Clear dark copper, the thick head is a bit too big bubbled for my liking, looks a bit detergenty...my glass was, as always, rinsed and dried before use! Light nose of malt & spice, good body and well flavoured, fairly malty with rounded hop bitters, finish lasts well. Sainsburys, Ponteland.

bottle from sainsbury. dark amber colour, not much head to talk about. very earthy, slightly sour malt nose. sweet yeasty taste, still earthy with a bit of chalk and horse. quite decent, but forgetable.

Oops. Nearly entered this into the database under its full title (Arthur Pendragon S.A). Budget bottle from Sainsburyâ€™s. Weâ€™ve got a real gusher on our hands here. Well, an oozer anyway. Beige worm of froth wriggling from the bottle a good 10 minutes after most if it had been (very carefully) decanted. Froths insanely without provocation. At least you know theyâ€™ve stuck some yeast in there. Impressive from a BCA seeing as so many of them are stone dead and pour like cordial. Apple strudel yeastiness, earthy jammy hop (with a musty squeeze of green), and enticing caramel aroma really makes me want to tuck right in. Earthy chocolate apple hop flavour sprinkled with ash. Yep, loads of pretty standard BC acidity, earthy applepeel and yeasty sparkle, but it didnâ€™t detract from my enjoyment of the beer. Clean but dirty. Well conditioned but badly behaved. Naughty one.

Bottle from Sainsbury. Deep amber, rocky off white head. Nice yeast, decent ESB. Itâ€™s got a bit of that earthy BCA quality to it. Yeast character is good. Fruit berry is good. But the BCA earthiness ruins it for me.

Bottle from Sainsburyâ€™s Cannock. Big head upon pouring with a very definite and unusual flavour. Full bodied and quite bitter with som hops present. a malt finnish makes for a very interesting bitter.Unusual, quite complex and interesting.

Bottle, from Sainsburys, Grimsby. Copper bronze, thin shortlived off white head, low condition. Gentle sweet toffee and caramel in the nose with a slight burnt roastiness, quite sweet initially in the mouth with a hefty yeast bitterness developing and a faint suggestion of barnyard, remaining yeast bitterness in the finish with some more retronasal cow shite.

Bottle from Sainsburys. Deep amber with a decent beige head. Sweet caramel aroma and flavour dominates, with some earthiness and a whiff of chocolate powder. The finish was short and bitter with the alcohol fairly prominent. Ok.
500ml bottle from Sainsburys - bottle conditioned. Reddish amber with a thin white head; earthy malt aroma; loads of sweet chewy malts; and a gently bitter finish. A rather good bitter.
Bottle at me dads, think this was one he got from Sainsburys Pours mid/dark brown with an off white head. Earthy malty aroma, some woodiness and even a hint of whisky on the nose, tasty bitter.
Bottle. Orangey Gold colour. Fruity (citrus fruit). Malty (toasty malts, caramel). Hoppy (floral hops). Sweet-bitter fruity malty. Moderately bitter citrus-hoppy finish. Tasty. (2008)

Bottled. A hazy dark golden beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of malt and caramel, as well as lighter notes of straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and alcohol. The body is thin inspite of the alcohol note.

bottle from a shop in Winchester. Hazy golden yellow, large white head. Aroma of cirtus fruit and cheese (?). Full-bodied, solid sweetish malty base with lovely fruity flavours and, again, a hint of cheese. Despite the cheesy flavour, which becomes less and nearly disappears during drinking, a good one. Lively carbonation.

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of Ungstrup. Hazy golden with a dense and retentive off-white head. Aroma of citrusy hops. Quite full-bodied with fruit, nuts and roasted malts before a rather bitter finish. 030608

50 cL bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a lacing white head. Grape hops fruity aroma. Flavour is slight rubber-yeasty but also and moreover with a nice fruity hops and fruity yeasty flavour. Ends with a nice fruity hops flavour and mild bitternes into the finish.

Bottle from BeersOfEurope. A pleasant and drinkable beer. Doesnâ€™t stand out in any way, but does a reasonable enough job. Thereâ€™s some mild hops undercutting the pale malt. It hangs together well enough. A lasting nibble in the finish. The strength isnâ€™t felt in the drinking, but makes itself known in the effects. A decent, soft, mildly buttery and well behaved beer.
Yellow with the haziiness that lots of bottle conditioned beers seem to have. Poured with no head and surprisingly little body considering its strength. Not very exciting.

Cask (gravity dispense), Ealing Beer Festival, May 2006. Pale gold colour. Bags of resinous hops in the aroma. Sweet fruit comes through on the palate, with a decent citric hop rush. Also some slightly green apple/pear that makes for a sharp, but smooth mouthfeel, enhanced by a subtle biscuity malt backdrop. Crisp and refreshing finish with a distinctly bittersweet character. Thereâ€™s some warming alcohol evident, but no burn. The cask Hampshire beers seem noticeably better than the bottled. I like this one.
Bottle conditioned. Golden colour with a thick white head. Fruity and spicey aroma. Flavours are hoppy, fruity and sour. A bit too sour, itâ€™s distracting. Firm bodied. I almost like it.
Draught. Buttery toast malt nose. Looks great in the glass - nice pale amber. Flavour is rich, smooth and well hopped with some caramel. Finishes bittersweet and long.

column1: Trap Rock Ghost Pony Helles Lager
column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: I had it on tap. It pours golden with a white head. The aroma is grass, honey, and fruit. The taste is grass, fruit, and butter. Itâ€™s smooth and drinks easy.

column1: Trap Rock Ghost Pony Helles Lager
column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Even light than the wit, which is odd. It also has a bit too much of a grassy aspect, and then drinks with a slick, buttery popcorn-ish thing. Almost nothing to it. (#8523, 10/11/2014)

column1: Trap Rock Ghost Pony Helles Lager
column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Reviewed from notes. This was on tap and served in a pint glass. The appearance had a hazy light colored brown. The smell had some bready/caramel malts in a roasty sort of way. The taste was somewhat sweet and had a long sweet aftertaste and finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light on the body with a decent sessionable aspect about it. Overall, this was a good Munich Helles Lager worthy of having again.

column1: Trap Rock Ghost Pony Helles Lager
column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Clean pale malty base, with very low bitterness, hints of grain, and a relatively clean finish. Not bad.

column1: Trap Rock Ghost Pony Helles Lager
column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: 3oz flight sampler from the brewpub. Pours a clear light yellow color with no head. Aroma of light citrus and sweet grain. Taste of lemon, grain, and yeast.

column1: Trap Rock Ghost Pony Helles Lager
column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Tap at a bar. Probably a bit flat. Clear golden yellow pour with minimal head. Citrus, white spice, wheat and grass. Light and citrus body.

column1: Trap Rock Ghost Pony Helles Lager
column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Tap at the brewery. Pours clear gold with very little fizzy white head, no retention or lacing. Aroma is Pils and corn malt, spicy hops. Flavor is malt dominant with light hops and bitterness and a clean lager character with a dry finish. Light to medium body and medium carbonation.

column1: Trap Rock Ghost Pony Helles Lager
column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft at the source. Hazy golden yellow color. Aroma of white pepper and citrus. Taste is citrus and straw.

column1: Trap Rock Ghost Pony Helles Lager
column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft at brewery. Pours cloudy gold. Off white head. Nose and taste of lemon, bready malt light spice and peppercorn. Lighter bodied.

column1: Trap Rock Ghost Pony Helles Lager
column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Location: Draft at the Brewpub, 10/5/12 Aroma: This beer has a nose of light grass, some malts, and some yeast Appearance: This one pours a clear almost watery, white wine looking type of color Flavor: The flavor has a clean, light sweetness and some light hops as well for a good balanced flavor Palate: The body is pretty light, it has a smooth feel on the mouth, and average carbonation Overall Impression: I canâ€™t imagine ever really craving this, or wanting to order one again with so many more interesting offerings on the menu, but I thought this was a pretty solid light ale.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Location: Draft at the Brewpub, 10/5/12 Aroma: The aroma has some resin, some citrus, and a little soap Appearance: It pours a clear light orange color, with a white head, and medium lace Flavor: The taste is mild sweet, with a resiny bitterness, and underlying dish soap flavor Palate: The body is light-medium, it feels a touch sticky, and has a lengthy dry finish Overall Impression: This one definitely could have been much better but the dish soap really kills the flavor for me. Still, it is close, and I bet if it wasnâ€™t for that dish soap it would have been great. Itâ€™s a shame because the IPA I sampled that is coming on next is really good, and this one just isnâ€™t quite up-to-par.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Served on draft at the brewpub as Kestrel IPA. Pours a clear copper color with a thin creamy off-white head. Good head retention. Aroma of toffee, citrus and faint resin notes. The taste is bitter resin, herbal and pine hops with a malty finish. Medium bodied.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft. Poured clear dark amber color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Solid complex hop aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture with soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable brew

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Orange pour with creamy off white head and lace. Earthy/citrus hoppiness. Sweet malt with a medium bitter. A medium bodied beer. A nice finishing bitter that just grows on you.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Finally, a beer with flavor from trap rock. Full of hops. Piney. Delicious in many ways.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Clear, nice-coloured golden ale. Excellent, firm white head, fully lasting and leaving massive lacing. Aromatic, slightly yeasty, well aromatic nose. Oranged, earthy, flower petals â€“ well put centennial/cascade blend. Highly supportive bready malts, biscuity, soft and never exaggerating the sweetness. Growing sheets of bitterness follow the dry finish never get extreme. Soft-edged texture. Medium-bodied, soft carbonation, juicy palate. Great IPA.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: taster. Golden/Light orange with medium carbonation. Aroma is citrus and pine with a touch of sweet malt. Taste is well balanced, sweet malt with citrus and pine hop bitterness. Liked this one.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours an offwhite head with yellow/gold color. Aroma is grapefruit, hops. Taste is crisp hops with a strong medium malt presence.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Looks and smells like an IPA. Tastes like one too. A very solid India Pale effort. Spot-on the style. Got the hops (adamskillin correctly called the cascades) and the malt support.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Looks and smells like an IPA, smells like an IPA, plenty of bitterness. I dont understand using Cascade hops in an IPA, but it came out okay, maybe just inauthentic. The hop flavor is that nice citrusey cascade thing. A good effort, but itâ€™s an American Pale Ale, not an IPA.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: I had it on tap. It pours reddish and amber with an off-white head. The aroma is caramel and bread. The taste is caramel, bread, and grass. Itâ€™s sweet and malty. Itâ€™s still very drinkable. Thereâ€™s a nice smoothness to it.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: On tap at Huntley Taverne. Pours amber with tall, long-lasting, fluffy white head and lively carbonation. Aroma is of some herbal hops and caramel malt. Body is medium and slightly crisp. Taste is similar to aroma. Finish is long and dry. OK brew.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft. Pours amber with an off white head. Lightly toasted and sweet malty base, with faint earthy hops and relatively low bitterness. Plain sweet malty finish. Not bad.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: 3oz flight sampler from the brewpub. Pours a clear amber color with a small off white head. Aroma of light citrus and toasted malt. Not much else. Taste of old citrus, grainy toasted malt, and caramel.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Tap. Copper pour with a thin head. Malty, caramel, nuts and coffee bean. Light body with watery and nutty finish.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Pours a light amber. A malty aroma. Taste is malty, roasted, and some caramel. Nothing special.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft at brewpub. Pours reddish amber with off white head. Nose and taste of malt, red fruits and earthy hops. Medium body.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft. Poured clear reddish-brown color with an average fizzy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate toasted sweet malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium balanced flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Basic to style.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: On draft at the Mount Tabor Tavern in Denville. Nice red-amber appearance with thick white head. Mild and well balanced. Not bad but not a standout. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: On tap at Trap Rock as Hathorâ€™s Amber Ale. Poured a clear amber color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas and tastes of lighter earthiness, toasted caramel, and some citrus. Lighter nuttiness.
0,5 litre Can from Alko Vaasa. Golden with little white head, Malty and Hoppy aroma, Caramel and alcoholic taste.

500ml can (Alko, KittilÃ¤). Straight from the can as street tick, but I think it was pale amber. Sweet, malty and caramel in aroma. Sweet, caramel, sugary some glue and paper in taste. Alcohol over everything. Not a disaster, but nothing close to delicatessen too. Boozy macro.
Can (thanks? Marduk). Street tick. Aroma is awful cardboard and booze. Flavor is sweet, corn, cardboard, booze. Overall: a horror.

Pours a clear amber copper color, toppedwith a rather small white head. Malty aroma, grainy with some alcohol notes and a bit of caramel. Taste is sweet, malty with alcohol plain in sight. Metal feel to it. Not too thrilled about this one.
Dark golden, small head Aroma has caramel malts, dried fruits. Flavor is sweet, alcoholy, malty.
Can 50 cl. Copper color with big smooth thick head. Notes of grains, caramel, malts. Slightly better then the lighter stuff Karjala but yet another mass produced lager with just more alcohol in it.
Lovely 50cl can thanks to rosenbergh. Color is dark golden with a medium white head. Body is thin. Taste is medium bitter and sweet. Aroma is caramel, metal, light alcohol. Not bad!
0,5l can from Alko. Pours clear golden with a low head. Aroma and flavor are grassy malts with a hint of metallic alcohol. Surprisingly decent.
50 cl can. Golden clear with a minimal white head. Malt, grass and alcohol. Light bitter with alc. End.
Bottle 0.33l from local Alko. Colour is golden with tiny white head. Aromas and flavours: Alcohol, grain and malts. Horrible.
Pours a nice clear mahogany from a tap, cream colored head has some lacing. Malty, light wheat toast aroma. Slightly bitter but mostly sweet. Good beer.

Cloudy amber. Full body, rich , hot, well carbonated palate, flavorful, good length, tasty finish. Medium bitterness, dry but well balanced. Malty, hoppy, yeasty. Intriguing, each sip invites the next one. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured into an English pint glass, the appearance was a ruddy burnt orange to brown color with a solid sustaining fingerâ€™s worth of off white foamy head. The head must last for a good minute before gently dissipating and creating some light speckled lace. The aroma starts off with some sweet to spicy estery fruit flowing upon rich caramel and toffee malts. Some grassy notes. Clean earthy and spicy hops beat feet upon those malts to add a little bit of zing. Sly herbal notes underneath and then a little bit of chocolate. The flavor balances very nicely between the sweet to spicy to fruity and caramel/toffee blended flow all combining extremely nice and right on into the aftertaste and on into the finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a nice sessionable flow smoothing out on my tongue. The use of the malts in this beer really helped smooth out some of that "zing" I smelled in the aroma as it doesnâ€™t let in any cloying features but just really feels absolutely wonderful. Overall, an English pale ale with a little beef. Feels just a tad heavier than some others of itâ€™s style, perhaps the chocolate in it, but if anything for a medium ABV-ed beer, itâ€™s heartier than expected and definitely could still go with some fish nâ€™chips.
Pale murky amber brown pour. Spicy hops and a heavy malt backbone. Not terribly ruch for a winter ale, but serviceable with a spicy bitter malty finish.

Draught. Pours mahogany with a medium beige head. Aroma is sweet malt, grain, and spice. Taste is muddled caramel and fruit with a little spice. Lightly metallic. Drying, bitter finish. Medium body. Medium carbonation. Oily mouthfeel.
Bottle. Pours a murky brown with malt aroma. Sweet malt up front that lingers. A little spiciness at the end. Pretty pedestrian.
Out of the bomber with fam. Not reall but i digress, slight bitterness washed over by caramel and toffee, hay. Medium body.

A small taste from a bottle @ Bauer Wine & Spirits. Pours clear chestnut with a medium head. Aroma is malts with some spices. Flavor is malts with some pumpkin, some spices and a hint of hops. Lighter than most winter warmers, which suits me just fine.

Draft at Champions in Springfield. Pours a cloudy amber with thin beige head and some spots of lace. Nose of sweat socks, sour cream, some caramel, light grass. Undrinkable. I doubt it is the beer but rather absolutely filthy tap lines since beers my friends ordered on draft were also undrinkable. I wonâ€™t kill them on the rating because Iâ€™m sure it taste better than this at a better establishment.
Draught. This is a boring old EPA without out much to make it worth the up pricing from a macro.

Tap at Callahanâ€™s. Pours clear gold with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is biscuit malt and light earthy hops. Flavor is sweet biscuit malt, light earthy hops and bitterness with a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

A: This is one of the paler beers Iâ€™ve come across in quite some time. The most feeble of yellow hues keep this one from being clear. S: The nose is similarly lifeless, offering not much more than a touch of sweet grain/malt. T: To my surprise, there actually was a flavor to the beer! Though it mostly consists of sweet malts, there is a touch of bitterness and perhaps some floral hops. M: As you might expect, the body is light and the carbonation is plentiful. But, itâ€™s somewhat necessary for this beer. D: One of those beers thatâ€™s made for the Bud Light crowd. I can see how this is a choice for some, but Iâ€™d prefer a beer with a bit more going on.
Draft. Golden beer with a white head. Mineral and malt aroma. malt/cereal flavor with mineral notes and light grass. Medium-light bodied. Easy drinking. Malt, mineral, and light grass lingers.
on tap-pours a thin white head and yellow color. Aroma is sweet grain, light crisp hops. Taste is sweet grain, light crisp/floral hops (saaz).

Date: 12/04/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear dark gold, fine white head, streaks of drippy lace, sweet light grain aroma, sweet grain flavor, light spicy hops for balance, nice light bitter finish, Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 6/20 Rating: 1.8/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: */4
Clear golden with no head. Faint malty aroma, bready malty taste, with a crisp finish.
Draught at the brewput. Very average in every way. Somewhat skunky flavor, bitter hop finish.
Draught at the brewpub: Orange/brown, nose of adjuncty light cheap malt. Tart bitter flavor with a light metallic finish. No body.
Draft at brewery. Yep, thier answer to what the masses want. Not really very exciting. Bready aromas and some slight hop bitterness. Just pretty plain.

Every brewpub has to have one of these to appeal to the Bud drinkers. To Callahanâ€™s credit, it is better at this style than many others. Golden in color with small white head. Same funky aroma that most Bud drinkers crave. Lightly hopped and lacking in malt body.

Sehr schÃ¶ne rotbraune Farbe im Glas. Netraler, leicht dunkelmalziger Geruch. Der Antrunk ist malzig-sÃ¼ÃŸlich, etwas laff. Zum Hauptteil wird das Bier ein Bisschen voller, aber es bleibt immer noch etwas im malzig-sÃ¼ÃŸlich-wÃ¤ssrigen hÃ¤ngen! Hat ein Bisschen was von alkoholischen Malzbier â€“ nicht so sÃ¼ÃŸ, aber der Grundton stimmt Ã¼berein! Zum Nachgeschmack kommt eine ganz leichte herbe Notemit ins Spiel, die aber leider ziemlich schnell wieder verfliegt. Der Nachgeschmack ist ein ganz klein wenig rÃ¶stmalzig-trocken, bleibt aber leider nicht allzulange auf der Zunge. Schade. --> Nettes Winterbier, aber insgesamt etwas Ausdrucksschwach mit leckeren AnsÃ¤tzen! (Test vom 17.2.2009) --> 12,11,12,12,12,11 - 11,45
Clear amber with a medium beige head. Sweet malty aroma with caramel notes. Sweet flavour with caramel and toasted malt. Good malt balance.
Amber color; small creamy head. Light caramel and cereals aroma. Good body strength, it has the classic caramel flavor, with some residual sweetness and cereals. Correct bitterness. Balanced.
Bottle at PapsÃ¸. CXlear orange red coloured with a medium sized white head. Sweet aroma of caramel with notes of bread. Sweet flavour of malts, caramel, bread, cardboard and hops. Sweet finish.

50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is fruity, breadish and slight oxidised. Roasted and fruity flavoured. Light phenolic and solid malty. Lingering breadish and fruity finish.
Bottled. Amber coloured. Clear. Small off white head. Bread, sweetness, light alcohol in the nose. Flavour is sweet, bready, fruity and light. Medium bodied. Dry. Sweetish and fruity end.

Bottled. An amber beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma has notes of caramel, bread, and metal. The flavor is sweet with notes of bread, caramel. metal, and alcohol, leading to a dry and alcoholic finish.

Bottle 50cl. Clear medium to dark orange amber color with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white to light beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, bread, caramel, light alcohol. Flavor is moderate to light light light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090626]
Bottle. Sweet peach malt and alcohol aroma. Clear brown color with small head. Smooth creamy banana and malt flavor with a bitter alcohol finish. Nice flavor but a bit rough in the finish.
Bottle, 6.6%. Good malty aroma, slightly farty. Clear dark brown colour. Small tan head. Good malty flavour, nice malt note, slightly sweet. Well-balanced.
Aroma of caramel, roasty, coffee, barnyard and sweet malts. Very nice balanced flavours. Brown colour with a slightly brown head. Great christmas beer, even though itâ€™s only 4,7 %.

330 ml bottle. Clear, amber body with a medium off-white head. Aroma is quite distinct malty. Flavor is malty with some caramel and a light bitterness. Relatively thin body, closer to a lager than the traditional Norwegian Christmas beer.

Medium brown colour, moderate head, typical Munich dunkel malty and slightly spicy aroma, well balanced malty flavour, very close to the ordinary Frydenlund Bayer. Pleasant aftertaste. Very good for a "klasse D" (low ABV) beer. (Frydenlund was Ringnes'' Oslo competitor, which they bought and closed about 15 years ago. At least they kept the recipes and the yeast - this is one of the beers that Ringnes now brew under the Frydenlund label.)
Heller, mild wÃ¼rziger Antrunk. Getreidig, sÃ¼ÃŸlich karamellig werdend. Spritzig, steigende Herbe, vollmundig, zum Ende etwas trocken. Gelungen. 11/11/10/11/9/11
*Old rating from 2006. Rund und leicht getreidig, nicht zu tief, sÃ¼ffig und moderat neutral herb.

#944 Das Bier als auch die Flasche sehen ja recht ansprechend aus. Leider kann ich das vom Bier selbst nicht sagen. Ein Brotaroma mit leichter Alunote. Im Antrunk dann bissig wÃ¼rzig mit bittersÃ¼ÃŸer Brotnote; der Hopfen im Abgang ist fies blechern. Definitiv nicht mein Geschmack! Test vom 28.3.2011, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 10,8,6,6,10,6 - 6,90

Bottle: Golden, mid-sized - slowly collapsing - lacy white head; sweetish strawy-grainy nose with a bitter touch; light to moderate sweet-bitter flavour, almost medium bodied; sweet grainy finish, bitter aftertaste. Simple, unexciting brew.....

(bottle) Clear, golden colour with a blond and fluffy foam. Sweet and grainy malty aroma with subtle notes of citrus and draff and a touch of herbal hops. Moderately sweet and bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a crisp carbonation. Balanced malty base with grainy notes on a delicately hoppy background; slightly bitter herbal hoppy finish with a mildly sweet malty aftertaste. Solid. 24.II.11
Commercial Description promises a malt-aromatic beer. In reality this light yellow beer is more tasteless and watery, grainy and hoppy

I have to disagree with my neighbor from Eagan, this beer was a pleasant surprise. If you like Corona you will like this one. I sometimes think micro breweries deliberately over-hop their product to give it "character". This beer was made with a good recipe that makes it very drinkable. As an aside, the ladies at my table loved it! Steve K. Apple Valley, MN

Yet another largely forgettable "specialty beer" contracted brewed for a restaurant by a so-so brewery. Served so cold that it had ice chunks floating in it. I''d say it negatively impacted the flavor but once I let it warm up it still didn''t have much flavor. Bit sweet with a mild hop finish, but far too many rice tones in its thinness. A few malts, but in general just another boring pilsner. That being said, if you get to the Nav-A-Gator just north of Punta Gorda, I highly, highly recommend the grouper sandwich, blackened. More than makes up for this forgettable brew.

Tap at Callahanâ€™s. Pours clear brown with a medium, creamy tan head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is toast malt, dates and light earthy hops. Flavor is toast malt, light earthy hops and bitterness with dates and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Cloudy mahogany with a tiny off white short lasting head. Aroma had roasted malt, nuts, chocolate and caramel hints. Flavour had hard roasted malt, caramel, chocolate and nuts. Finished sweet and samewhat watery for the style.

A: The pour is an almost amber brown color with a fairly minimal off-white head. S: There is a fair bit of nuttiness and perhaps a bit of chocolate to the nose. There are some toasty malts and caramel sweetness as well. T: The nuttiness and chocolate flavors are present as you might expect. Unfortunately, there is an almost chalky bitterness (aspirin?) to the beer that really ruins it. M: The body is a bit on the light side with the aforementioned chalkiness and a moderate carbonation. D: Not one of the better offerings from Callahanâ€™s. There are certainly better brown ales available, so I would suggest going with something else.

Draft. Mahogony beer with a dark cream colored head. Nutty malt and light cocoa aroma. Malt and light cocoa flavor with light roast and light nuttiness. Medium bodied. Nutty malt lingers with light chocolate.
On tap at brewpub. Color was darkish brown with red hints. Aroma was pretty light, like alot of there beers. Some nutty caramel. Flavor had a coffee like flavor with caramel and toffee.

Sample at the brewpub. The beer is a brownish-amber color with a medium beige head that dissipates steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. The aroma is nutty with some floral hops and malt. Medium-bodied with a mild nutty flavor along with notes of pale malt and hops. The finish is soft and sweet with a short nutty aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

Dark brown hue with amber highlights, thing amount of head. Nose is very muted, slight nuts, malts, and vinegar. Taste is much better, bit roast and toast, walnuts and pecans, grassy hops. Medium-bodied with a light creamy texture and low carbonation. Flavorful brown ale with good balance and malt profile.
on tap-pours a thin tan head that laces and mahogany color. Aroma is mild medium/dark malt-chocolate, some sharpness. Taste is mild medium/dark malt-chocolate, some sharpness-hops?. Light body.

Date: 12/04/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear brown, fine beige head, streaks of drippy lace, light chocolate aroma with dark caramel sweetness, rich chocolate flavor, nice nutty character, touch of sweetness to enhance the chocolate, light bitterness to keep it balanced, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **/4
Clear reddish brown with creamy white head. Faint malty aroma. Slight roasty taste with a nutty finish.

A: The pour is a pale golden color with some hints of orange and a white head on top. S: The amount of grapefruit and citrus in the nose is quite surprising--in a good way. A touch of bready malt and a bit of sugar as well. T: Unfortunately, the flavors donâ€™t quite live up to the expectations of the nose. A bit on the bready side with some faint grapefruit and orange hops. M: Medium in body, but perhaps a touch watered down. The carbonation also isnâ€™t as aggressive as I usually like in a pale ale. D: For what it is, not a bad beer. I would have liked the hoppiness to translate to the flavor a bit better, but a decent enough pale ale.

Sample at the brewpub. This beer is a clear light orange-amber color with a thin bone white head that recedes quickly. Spotty lacing. Moderately hoppy aroma with touches of citrus. Medium-bodied with citrusy hops and malt flavors. The finish is mostly hops with some grapefruit in the aftertaste. Straightforward and above average overall.
What I had was called Mission Trails Pale Ale, which I assume is a different name for this beer. Clear golden with creamy white head. Grape fruit and pine aroma and taste with a hoppy finish.
Draft at brewery. Decent amber color with an OK head. Fruity citrusy hops. Some bright fruit too. Flavors came off a bit more bitter than the sweet aroma, but overall, not too bad.

On tap@Callahans: Golden amber color with a small (bar pour) white head. Aroma is light and sweet with a hint of hops. Flavor starts malty fading to a light citrus hop finish. A fairly decent pale ale. One of Callahans better house brews.

Draft at brewpub before my first QUAFF meeting. Woohoo! Amber color. Nice small bubble head. Middle of road sweetness. Very nicely done grapefruit hop bitterness. I think this beer is underrated, for whatever reason. Even I dropped it 0.1-0.2 to fit closer to the current ratings.
Draught at the brewpub: Bronze, nose of light cascades and sour malt. The flavor is similar with tart, off-kilter malts. Not good at all. Husky, sour, blech.
Pours amber in color with a little white head. Little bit of caramel malt and lighter on both hop aroma and flavor than expected. Not enough body, and needs more (some) dry hops.

Draft. Deep amber with a white head that lasted pretty long. Nice lacing for the whole glass. Aromas were a little weak, some floral and some citrus. Flavors were better, normal IPA flavors. Pretty good beer.

Took out a jug from the pub: Deep amber color with a small white head. Light sweet nose. Flavor is caramel candy sweet (maybe a tad too sweet) fading to a light hop bitterness and finishing with a tart grapefruit after taste.

Had on tap at Callahan's on March 12, 2003 After trying a few of the other beers on tap, I figured I'd try the one I'd probably like the most, the IPA. Probably the best locally brewed beer on tap, the IPA has a nice hoppiness with a good balance of malt. The beer is a dark brown color with a fair sized head, but what surprised me (and those around me) was the amount of lacing. As I drank, there were rings on down the beer from previous IPA levels - it looked quite beautiful actually when I was done. If you're going to go with a house beer (nice and cheap both during and after happy hour), the IPA is the way to go.
50 cl bottle. at home .Golden color.Small head. Rubber and hay aroma.Hay ,grains and white bread flavor. A bit metallic and acidic.
I drank this in less than 12 parsecs.............pretty decent pils :-)

Flasche (33 cl) vom REWE-GetrÃ¤nkemarkt Marktbreit. - Goldgelb, klar. - In der Nase derb unkrautige Hopfenbittere, AnklÃ¤nge an verbranntes Gummi und Chlor. - Antrunk aromatisch blaÃŸ aber derb bitter mit AnklÃ¤ngen an Chlor und Urin. Malzaromen: Fehlanzeige. Schlank, wÃ¤ÃŸrig. Im Abgang unangenehme schroffe, stumpfe Bittere. - Grauslige BrÃ¼he, billigst gebittert und kaum genieÃŸbar. Wie man sich so etwas freiwillig in den Rachen gieÃŸen kann, wenn rundherum der herrlichste Wein gedeiht?

Bottle from the brewery. Clear gold with a billowy large-bubbled head. Stale malt impression is white bread and saltine cracker with muted lemon hop aromatics and off-notes of dryer sheets and chalk. Light, body, fizzy, astringent, husky and minerallic. No sugar to help push against the high effervescence, so it comes across drier and more bitter than it should. A shame that the bottles doesnâ€™t fare well, we had a zwickel pull of the pilsner directly from the tank and it was in better shape, still didnâ€™t have a great malt character but at least it was bright.
Ins Glas ergieÃŸt sich ein klares goldgelbes Bier mit schÃ¶ner Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig, getreidig, grasig. Geschmack hopfig, grasig, lang anhaltende Bitterkeit.
Small white head. Clear golden coloured hoppy and malty with a crisp and slightly dry finish.
If you havenâ€™t knocked this back for 3 years as I have---in Marksteft where itâ€™s brewed---all her ratings are meaningless.

500ml bottle. Pale gold ruffed with lace. Excellent, fresh herbal hop aroma; basil, mown grass, vanilla, honey, lemon jelly. Crisp, lemony and VERY grassy with plush softening biscuit, light minerality, toasted white bread. Love lager when itâ€™s this good. Bizarrely underrated.
500ml bottle. Clear pale yellowish golden colour with average white head. Bitter hop aroma on grainy basis. Bitter taste, bitter finish, some fizzy grainy malt taste in between.

50 cl bottle @ Timo A. Pours pale clear golden color with medium head. Aroma of grass, mild hoppy fruits, herbal notes and cellar notes. Flavor of grass, mild fruits, yeast, distant malts and mild herbal notes and grain. Dry palate with a dry crisp finish. 3514
[backlog] 08-01-16 // bottle at Heroes Burger, Frankfurt. Pours a cloudy orange. Yeasty, light fruity banana. Average.

Bottle from the brewery. Lightly hazed gold with a medium-sized white head. Impression of the nose is stale banana slices, muted clove esters, yeast with a quier salt and pepper effect. Light bodied and effervescent. Dry, pasty, starchy, tart and turning sour with a rough dose of yeast in the finish. Off balance and unpalatable.
Ins Glas ergieÃŸt sich ein trÃ¼bes goldenes Bier mit schÃ¶ner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig, wÃ¼rzig. Geschmack hefig fruchtig, reife Bananen, leicht wÃ¼rzig.
Bottle courtesy of Yespr. Hazy dark yellow with tiny white head. Aroma is malt, yeast, wheat and a little banana. Flavour is malt, yeast, wheat, little banana, medium sweet and a little bitter.
Bottle courtesy of Yespr. Hazy yellow without head. Aroma is sweet, wheaty, banana and yeasty. Flavor is quite sweet. Sweet finish. 160313
50 cl bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a quickly disappearing head. Aroma is toasted and light estery. Banana and light orange fruity, medium dry estery. Light bitter and medium dry finish.

Draft. Pour was hazy straw colored. Weak lacing. Aroma of fruity banana esters, some doughy elements, spicey phenolic notes low. Flavor followed, grass mixed in there, but again notably lacking phenolic kick that I like balancing out these hefes. I could see why this bombs out in bottles, but from the tap it was decent.

Catch up rating from notes, 2012: Bottle from Bierwelt. Poured into weizen glass, golden, hazy, weak head, haziness increases as bottom of bottle is poured in. Aroma is bready, but the normal weizen scent is rather subdued, other citrus notes. Taste comes in kind of weak as well. Kind of disappointing.
Hazy yellow with a medium white head. Fruity with spicy tones. Malt, hops, banana and spices.

Bottle. Hazy yellow color with a disappearing foamy white head. Aroma of banana and lemon. Thereâ€™s something wrong with the taste. Itâ€™s quite harsh and tang. I donâ€™t know if thatâ€™s because of the date (2 weeks past BB) or does it normally taste like this.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of banana, yeast, spice and wheat.
Bottle. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma of dust, caramel, veggies, fruity, paper. Taste is rather sweet loads caramel, spicey, boozy, loads of corn.
Bocken varer lige til pÃ¥ske. Golden with a lasting white head. Grainy malt aroma with lots of vegetables. Sweet grainy flavour with cabbage and a touch of alcohol.
Bottle @ Dolles Bockstival â€” Bocken varer lige til pÃ¥ske, 5000 Odense C. Pours Amber with a creamy White head. Cooked vegetables. Cauliflower. Dammn. Poor.

Das Bockbier der Privatbrauerei Kesselring aus Marktsteft in Unterfranken. Das Etikett ist voll hÃ¤sslich und schaut nach Assibier aus. Honiggelb im Glas mit schÃ¶ner feinporiger Schaumkrone. Der Antrunk ist pappsÃ¼ss, Alkoholnoten machen sich schnell breit, der verwendete Hopfenextrakt schliesst dieses Bier ab! Wenn ich morgen Kopfschmerzen habe, dann liegt es an diesem Fusel.

50 cl bottle. Clear golden color.Some alcohol aroma.. Fruity . Malt and caramel flavor. Some spices.Grassy hops.Sweet without being annoying. Not too sophisticated but quite enjoyable to drink. The alcohol "warming" sensation is welcomed when is - 3Âº outside.
Klare goldene Farbe, ordentliche weiÃŸe Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr malzig, fruchtig getreidige SchÃ¤rfe. Geschmack krÃ¤ftig malzig, reife FrÃ¼chte, Honig, Getreide.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, a little fruity and grain. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 121013
Bottle, 7.4%. Clear golden with white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, little caramel, grainy and hop. Flavour is malt, fruit, medium sweet, hop, little caramel, little grass and a little bitter.
50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is toasted malty and grassy. Cornish to grassy. Toasted malty, flat, light cornish. Toasted and bitter finish.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, grass, bread and hops.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Scottish Ale
column5: Drank from the taps at the brewery. Pours a hazy amber color. Aroma is of malts and sugar. Taste has a nice fruity maltiness to it. Aftertaste leaves a little bit of roasted nuttiness, clean finish.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Scottish Ale
column5: Orangish-brown in color with little off-white head. Big malty aroma with a bit of nuttiness and alcohol in there. Flavor is more of the same with a sweet creamy mouthfeel that makes this an easy ale to drink. Finish is a little sour and earthy with just a touch of alcohol warming. A pleasant take on a scotch ale.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Scottish Ale
column5: Thanks to Ryan for sharing this at HWOH. Again- this one is 8.5%, not 6%. Pours a deep amber with ruby highlights and a thin head. Aroma is sweet with lots of caramel malts, and hints of burnt wood or peat. Flavor is a bit astringent but sweet upfront and malty. Kind of sour in the end actually- and finished dry and woody.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Scottish Ale
column5: Pours rich amber color with tan head that vanishes in a flash. Aroma is of wet dog ( or dog bathed in wort). Flavor is malty with rich earthy notes. Not bad for one bottle, would not invest in a six pack.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Scottish Ale
column5: A nice brown coloured ale with a malty taste. Nice finish and decent aroma.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Scottish Ale
column5: Pours hazy brown with aroma of roasty malt, chocolate, nuts, scotch. Tastes malty with a chocolate, scotch, slight nutty finish. Pretty good.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Scottish Ale
column5: Roasty and chocolately, This might be the best Cottonwood Brew Iâ€™ve had. Maybe the Scottish Aleâ€™s just hit me in the right spot. This is very very good. Nice malt and hop mix. Great flavor and a smooth drinking beer. Another great Beer courtesy of North Carolinaâ€™s finest, Ross. Traded twice with Ross, #3 Iâ€™m sure wonâ€™t be that far away in the future. I really liked this. I think you will too.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Scottish Ale
column5: Like Beer God, I also had this at the Bier Garten in Portsmouth. Ruddy brown color with nearly non-existant head. Aromas of brown sugar and general sweetness, not complex. Flavor is completely one dimensional - general brown sugar sweetness. Body/mouthfeel is insepid, would be considered thin even for a pale ale, and is totally disappointing. Lingering butterscotch aftertast refused to go away. I found this beer utterly lacking in every quality except appearance.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Scottish Ale
column5: Had this at the Bier Garden in Portsmouth VA on 8-7-04. Reddish brown body with almost no head. Nose is malty and sweet with hints of caramel and brown sugar. Taste is, again, malty and sweet with some hints of chocolate coming out. Mouthfeel is a bit thin for the style but it is pleasant enough to be enjoyable. Not as rich as Iâ€™d hoped for, though. Finish is also sweet but thereâ€™s a weird paper-ish taste coming out in it.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Scottish Ale
column5: dark red color with a head that goes away very quickly. smell is very malty and has a slight hint of chocolate. taste is also very malty, not much hop presence in this one. a very nice scottish ale, but this class is really not something i go for, because i am more of a hop guy than a malty guy. nice brew though.

Poured into a pint glass at the brewpub, the appearance was a brown clear color, sly transparency, and a quickly dissipating head. No lace. The aroma had a fair amount of nutty malts, almost almond character. Sly earthiness, some wood. The flavor was basically the same with a sly woody to nutty sweet balanced aftertaste leading into the finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a super nice sessionably smooth feel rolling about it. Low carbonation. Overall, nice Scottish ale. Could have again with a bacon cheeseburger nicely.

Decent, if uninspired, low-gravity Scotch Ale. Medium body, medium brown clear body with little head, very malty, almost no hops, almond character throughout was nice, piney and woodsy. Easy drinkin''.
Touch of citrus. Clear gold with a decent white head. Touch of bready notes and light bitterness. Grains come through in the finish.

On tap at Jolly Brewery & Restaurant, pours a hazy golden blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out gentle crisp grassy notes, crisp crackery malt, and a hint of cereal grains. Flavour is clean and crisp, with grassy notes, crisp crackery notes, and cereal grains. Crisp and grassy. Well-made.
(Tap) hazy, bright, pale yellow colour with a small white head; aroma of ink; inky, bitter flavour with a long, medium bitter finish, not good
Goldgelb schaum ok im Geruch leicht Hopfen etwas citrus im Geschmack schÃ¶n hopfig citrus angenehm herb gutes pils
Vom Fass. Hellgelb klar, wenig Schaum. Frisch zitroniger Duft. Antrunk aromatischer Hopfen, Apfel, frisches Gras. Lecker.

On draught at the Heng Yang road restaurant, Ximending, Taipei, Taiwan. Another wonderfully crafted beer from this brewer. Produces up a shimmering straw yellow with fine carbonation lifting up a silky, rocky cloud of white that holds and laces well. Nose hints at lemongrass, mint, elderflower and dusty palest malts. Hoppy, well actually itâ€™s as bitter as the gates of hell, but in that pleasant, all smiles way. Delicate, light bodied and racy across the tongue. Spicy, minty and earthy with a fragrant pot pourri perfume late. Light lemon and honey tea blend minces mid-palate whilst a good level of malt grounds it all giving great balance. This is a wonderful quaffer and one of the best Pilseners I have tried. I loved it so much it became the mainstay of the rest of the trip. Delicious draught lager!
Tap @ Jolly BrewPub Restaurant. Clear golden yellow, reasonable head. Vanilla corn grain aroma. Sweet barley sugar flavour with hints of vegetables. Sharp on palate. Good big flavoured pilsener.

This has more in common w/ an American blond or craft brew lager than a traditional pils but that works OK for me. It is clear and yellow w/ a mix of foamy bubbles for a head. Itâ€™s mild and a bit grainy w/ some fruity American hops (menu mentions Liberty). It has crisp carbonation and is medium bodied w/ some grassy, herbal bitterness in the finish. This is a tasty and easy drinking brew even if it is not quite to the reported style.
On tap at the brewpub restaurant in Taipei. Hazy golden colour. Hints of banana and clove, good bitterness. Quite a good pilsener with some weizen character.
Clean and smooth pilsener with some complexity to the flavor. Not overly carbonated. Iâ€™m not a pilsener fan, but I did enjoy this beer. Hoppy and slightly bitter.
Ketchup and wheat. Clearish gold with a small white head. Sweet banana and ketchup with a long finish. Not good.
(Tap) cloudy, pale yellow colour with a small white head; aroma of lilies; light, balanced flavour with a long, light bitter and tart finish; competent
TrÃ¼bes gelb ordentlicher schaum Hefe Getreide etwas banane im Geruch im Geschmack etwas Schal Hefe fruchtig citrus und banane Getreide, nicht Ã¼bel
Vom Fass im Brauhaus. Prost Reto! Gelb und trÃ¼b, heller flÃ¼chtiger Schaum. Gras und Hefe. Frischer Hefe und Getreide Geschmack. SÃ¼ffig.
