Tap @ Jolly BrewPub. Hazy yellow orange, reasonable head. Strong spicy clove aroma. Big banana clove flavour. Sweet aftertaste. A bit unbalanced and too intense.

This was my first from a sampler at the brewpub-like location (no brew on premise allowed in Taiwan or so I understand) and I was surprised to get such a nice hefeweizen. It is cloudy orange w/ a creamy head of fine bubbles. Its nose is banana up front w/ some spicy clove to pin it down. Itâ€™s creamy but not sweet w/ vigorous carbonation that softens its juicy texture with just a touch of earthy bitterness in the finish. This is pretty down-the-middle for the style and very well done.
On tap at the brewpub restaurant in Taipei. Golden with a smallish head. Good banana aroma with hints of clove. Fruity flavours. Nice.
This turned out to be a pretty good wheat beer. The wheat flavor was there, but not too sweet like some weizens. Good color and "cloudiness", too.

Tap. Golden color, pretty clear. Very light wheat aroma that falls apart into a sea of uncoordinated malts and wet cardboard. I was not impressed. Yeah, so I went to the bathroom while drinking this stuff and saw something that looked like a guy in a tux and a girl in a dress on the doors. I took the tux and on the way out was this Asian chick...well, I thought it was a chick, with the feminine face and crazy hair. I doubled back to look at the other door and then realized that I had it right. I must have really insulted the guy, but he really needed to do something about the hair.

Sampled draught at Jolly, Neihu, Taipei, Taiwan. Golden coloured and slightly hazy. Phenolic, fruity, slightly ashy and just a tad estery, this wheat beer is more clean and less lively than the average weizen. It is medium bodied with low bitterness. Probably a sensibly understated wheat beer to be able to find a way into a beer market that not is very adventurous.
Almost golden ale in appearance. Mild hop and malt nose that is almost too well balanced. Clean and soft palate with a very mild hop bitterness. Clean finsh
This ESB almost tastes like an IPA. Very hoppy but at the same time, refined...

I had this labeled as â€™Vintage Christmas Aleâ€™ A mature festive amber glow. Really Christmassy but not too complex. Intense cognac with a range of Christmas pudding aromas. Muscavado sugary, rich comforting flavours Compelling, with the full complement of Christmas flavours. Not too heavy; buoyant. Swollen apetite element and BIG Christmassy booze. Tingly smooth and intensely boozy. Refreshing on the tongue, deep down the throat. Molassesey thickness. Imbued with the delights of the season.

500ml bottle, deep copper with not much head but a pleasing spicy and malty nose. Lots of chewy malt, plenty of hops, citrus and ginger notes, all well balanced by a good alcohol bite. Smooth and drinkable.
Bottled, 500ml many thanks to Sandra. Copper with white head. Very malty beer, lacking character and body. Seemingly spiced, but dry and powdery. not keen at all.

500ml bottle. Not exactly a wonderful appearance is definitely overwhelmed by a really good christmas ale. Fruity orange aroma, smooth palate, final smooth bitter finish. Good drinkability, alcohol well hidden.
Bottle. Aroma is sour. Palate is sour, not in a pleasnt way. Some subtle spice and some dark fruit characters, some orange. Not really pleasant to drink and the alcohol is noticeable.

500 bottle from Cask & Glass, Tonbridge. I saw the previous yearâ€™s offering in the clear glass 660 bottle that Chris_o had in an off licence in Brighton and wished I bought it, so when I saw this I had to buy it. Reddish copper colour with lasting off white head. It does smell of christmas cake, malty with dried fruits. alcohol and hops (ok hops arenâ€™t in christmas cake), Full in mouth, alcohol kick comes through in the end. Lots of tea and tobacco, more dried/burnt fruit too. I love it. More dry malt and dry peppery hop on finish. The hops, the malt, the alcohol all go to make this one of the best UK beers Iâ€™ve had. It is extraordinary. It really does assault the senses.

660 ml bottle. 2005 vintage. In England we usually expect Christmas ales to be dark and rich, so the relatively pale orange/ginger colour (and the clear glass bottle) didnâ€™t look particularly promising. The contents, however, were a pleasant surprise. Poured with no head to speak of and a slight haze (bottle conditioned). Big estery, fruity aroma - bags of orange and tropical fruit - with some yeasty notes. Smooth and spicy on the palate. Lots of sharp, juicy Seville oranges and marmalade. Some late bitterness although the overall mouthfeel is mellow. The alcohol is not too intrusive. A tasty, light but full-flavoured Christmas beer.

<!-- i -->courtesy of fiulijn<!-- /i --> - hazy amber colour with a giant creamy white head; strong fruity hoppy nose with notes of lychees, pear and apricot; solid notes of yeast too; strong malt body and aromatic bitterness; moderately dry finish where the yeast dominates the fruity character - deeply original and a with a strong character
Bottle: Simple tasty english strong ale. Nice malt character. Clear amber with a white lasting head. Warming.

Bottle conditioned Golden to amber color, thin creamy head. Aroma of metallic green hops, some white sugar. Malty body, toffee, strong bitterness (good quality of English hop, partially aromatic), almost extreme at the end, with toffee again. Balanced, warming stuff, not too much complex nor exciting, but the more I drink it the more I like it ;-) Donâ€™t drink it too cold!
0,33 l bottle from Alko YmpyrÃ¤talo, Helsinki. Quite nice blond bier - nothing special but still quite good as most Belgian ales are.

Bottle from de Caigny dranken in Essen, Belgium. The beer is hazy golden colored and has a stable white foam, with very good carbonation. The aroma is malty, yeast and spicy, with notes of citrus, yeast, hay, sweet malts and spices. The taste is medium bodied and starts sweet malty, with notes of caramel and goes to light bitter with belgian yeast and spices. The finish is light bitter and a little watery.

A golden beer, a head is medium and blond. Aroma has fruitness and popcorn, hint of yeast and spicyness. Taste has fruitness, spicyness, quite dry. Medium bodied, high carbonation. Nothing special here but tasteful anyway.

A small taste @ the flagship Alko, press blind tasting. Pours cloudy straw yellow with a medium head. Aroma is fruity malts with some hops and ammonia. Flavor is grainy, sweet malts with some fruits and a hoppy finish. Strange brew. Drinkable.
From old ratings. Hazy golden colour, white foam. Nose is rather sweet, a bit citrussy, notes of peach.Medium carbonatin. Not bad.
33 cl. bottle at home. Drank on November 29th 2018 as St-Martin Blonde (7,0%), bought in Mons.

AchetÃ© Ã  tabacco palais des biÃ¨res dans famiflora Ã  Dottignies. Bouteille de 33cl . Couleur blonde reflet intense dorÃ©e belle brillance. Mousse Ã©paisse aÃ©rÃ© et qui ce tiens bien . Au nez : note florale , cÃ©rÃ©ales et levures , un peu piquante au nez . En bouche : sensation fruitÃ© et florale prÃ©sente . Marque de longueur et de corps . Amertume franche mais disparer rapidement. DÃ©saltÃ©rante

Clear golden beer with small creamy white head. Aroma is yeast, and malty, very little hints of fruits. Taste is slightly yeasty, some sweetness. Alcohol is nicely hidden. Medium body. Easy drinkable strong ale. Overall descent beer, maybe a bit boring though.

Wazig goudblond bier met witte schuimkraag. Geur: gistkarakter, licht kruidig, hooi, mout. Smaak: licht hopbitter, wat moutzoet, gistkarakter, licht kruidig, doet wat denken aan saison. Medium koolzuurprikkel. Afdronk: licht bitter

DorÃ©e voilÃ©e, mÃªle bien petite amertume aux notes fruitÃ©es agrume et lÃ©gÃ¨re douceur maltÃ©e, finale un peu sucrÃ©e mais mesurÃ©e, bonne surprise. Bouteille 33cl version Bio achetÃ©e chez La Vie Claire (enseigne bio), Paris, bue le 22/03/2018.
Deep brown, cloudy appearance, thick as natural apple juice, heady fermented fruit aroma, sediment at the bottom, full-rounded flavor.

Ha, drunken Paul cracked this baby on Friday night of BCTC (7/20/07). Early Friday night was about the only time I was somewhat sober, so Iâ€™m not going to miss out on rating this one. Old bottle, not sure how old, but Iâ€™d guess it was at least 5 years old, if not more. Still poured a one-finger pink-tinged-white head atop a mostly clear (protein chunk in bottom) marmalade colored beer. Head faded fairly rapidly to ring, leaving little lacing. Medicinal phenols and band-aids in the nose are bolstered by vanilla-like oxidation of the malts and hints of cherry pit or cherry juice notes. Light black pepper, some waxiness and a bit of artificial sweetner. Still quite a strong aroma, with nips of fusel alcohol on the finish. An odd citric acidity is still present, assumedly from the cherries. Little/no acetic acid, with lightly oxidized, but still rather enjoyable pale malts producing honey and vanilla. Some brief instances of caramel with a tangy, almost lactic or citrus-rind-like finish. Carbonation is still ample, though not exactly tight or creamy. Not bad though, considering the age.

Bottle: Poured a deep and murky orange/amber with a small diminishing white head. Lots of sour/tart cherries in the nose. Flavor was the same, stayed and finished tart, no syrupy qualities at all, smoothed over by mellower malt. Nicely carbonated mouthfeel.
33 cl bottle. Very cloudy amber brown with a nice head that settled quickly. Aromas of tart cherry, chocolate and alcohol. Taste is nice and sour with some Very crisp and refreshing.

My bottle stated that the contents were a Belgian Golden Ale. My guess is that it's a tripel. Definitely not a cherry fermented lambic... Lightly hazy golden brew. Small, swirling white head. The nose is very fruity and spicey. Yeasty. Yellow apple and pear. Flavors of white fruit and orange blossom honey. Medium-bodied with a thin, watery mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Astringent and lightly sweet finish. For around $10 per bottle (nice looking bottle), what a waste of cash. Overpriced, but not unpleasant in the least.

This beer poured a golden color and formed a nice foamy white head that acted a lot like a float and left circular lace as it slowly subsided. A heavy amount of carbonation is present. An aroma of malt, caramel and citrus. A taste of malt and caramel which gives it a bit of sweetness in the fairly astrigent finish.
An adequate kriekbier. Fairly tart and sourish, as it should be. Another quality product from Sterkens.
Golden, small head, aroma is malt, sweet, grain, taste is the same, bitter, light herbal, not bad
Bottle @ home. Clear yellow w a white head.Aroma medium malty (caramel) and hoppy (citrusy). Flavor medium sweet and bitter. Medium body, average carbonated.
Clear golden with a very thin head. Yeasty, citric smell. Bitter taste with a sour note. Although the taste isn't exceptional, this beer has a decent body. Medium carbonation.

(500ml can, maybe .50 EUR, Berlin) AROMA: more of a fruity, sweet grain/corn nose. touch sour. APPEARANCE: clear, light honey yellow, hint of pale orange, light/thin lager head, a bit of residual, ok for a lager/pils TASTE: taste follow the nose, light grain, light hops, tad sweet but with a soft background of euro pils. the graininess and hops build in presence as I had additional sips. PALATE: light to light medium body, mostly soft and easy. OVERALL: I could see some people not liking this, while others might kinda like it. a tad light and sweet, but just enough pils backbone so you don't totally forget what you are drinking. kind of a baby pils with training wheels. feels lighter than the 4.9% ABV
Ein Klassiker aus dem Norden. dadurch auch mit der Herbe der dortigen Biere, die auch gut gelungen ist. Allerdings vermisse eine gewisse Eigenheit und Frechheit, welche ja beworben wird.
Affordable, hoppy and with a very unique profile. Reminds me of half-term weekend trips south of the border.
Only cool thing about this beer is the marketing. Even for a standard lager beer it is sub standard.
It is actually quite nice for such a light beer. It's not something super duper but nice light beer for summer

L: -pours a clear golden with a small to medium,foamy,white head -medium to high carbonation visible S: -grainy,spicy,earthy,malty,faint acidity T: -Follows the nose + buttery F: -medium carbonation -light to medium body O: Shares a lot of similarities with Holsten, but it's not nearly as grainy and the slight acidic feel is definitely different. Not the kind of Pils i'm into though.
Clear golden with a small foamy head. Aroma: Grass, hay, soap and bread. Taste Sweet, somewhat metallic with a slightly bitter aftertaste
Draft. Dark mahogany beer with dark cream head. Dark fruit and malt aroma. Dark fruit and caramel flavor. Medium bodied. Dark fruit and caramel lingers with light toffee.

Bomber. Dark brown with a good inch of foamy light brown head. The aroma is brown sugar, roasted malt, toffee and butterscotch. The flavor is predominately caramel, bready malt and molasses along with some raisins, lemon citrus and herbal hops toward the end. The body is mildly creamy with strong carbonation and a slightly tangy, roasty finish. Overall, a well-balanced Pacific Northwest style Scottish Ale.

22 oz. from Bottleworks. Smells ever so slightly sour, like lukewarm milk. Pours a deep brownish-red color that is pleasing. Tastes spot on for a Scottish Ale. Is that the same as a Scotch Ale? Not quite as boozy and furry tasting as others.

Skagit River Brewery-Jennyâ€™s Scottish Ale--Skagit Valley Highland Games & Celtic Festival--2009-10 22 oz. Bottle Release. 5.50% ABV--20 IBUâ€™s? (3.5 / 5.0) Scottish Ale--Lacy off white dense mild head. Clear dark cherrywood red color. Rich malty toasted mild smoked peat hop front. Cloying sweet malty toffee biscuit burnt dark fruit light smoke infused full body. Cloying sweet malt mild peat hop end. Thick too sweet Scottish Ale. Sampled 2/15/2010. 2-$4.99 Each.
From notes. Light brown/amber pour, small off white head. Toasty caramel, biscuity malt, cereals, subtle vegetation. Medium body, balanced, easy. Decent.

Name: Jennyâ€™s Scotish Ale Date: September 14, 2009 Mode: Bottle Source: Brewpub Words: second runnings after making the scotch ale Appearance: clear dark amber, frothy beige head Aroma: light sweet malt aroma, light floral hops Flavor: sweet malt flavor, touch of candy sweetness, light smokey peat, well balanced earthyness follows the peat Overall: a full flavored lighter version of the scotch Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **+ /4
Aroma is toasty and roasty with some caramel malts and toffee perhaps. Copper colored beer. Caramel malty sweetness with a light dry roast and some toasted nuts. Nice sweet/dry finish.

On draught at the brewpub in Mt Vernon, Washington. Pours a semi-clear reddish copper brew with a fast dissolving off-white head that quickly dissipates to a clean top and no lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, a touch of candi sugar, toffee and some roasted nuts. Taste is medium to full bodied, light carbonated with a good balanced flavors of caramel malt, toffee and roasted nuts. Finish is quite sweet, fruity with a slow disappearing caramel malt with toffee and candi sugar. One of the sweeter Scottish ales Iâ€™ve tried.

22oz Bomber - Gravity Beer Market - Olympia, WA Aroma â€“ Rich malt with a nice hops backing for aroma. Appearance â€“ Mahogany in color, thin head and clear. Flavor â€“ Nice malt flavor with a good hops balance. Palate â€“ Good Mouthfeel, nice texture with a dry finish. Overall â€“ A very good average Scottish ale. The hops where a tad much but this was a very well brewed beer.
Draught @ WABF 2008. Pours a slightly hazy amber color Has a malty caramel aroma with some earthy hoppy hints. Fruity malty caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Slightly fruity malty caramel finish.
Cloudy gold, no head. Wheat malt nose and taste with faint hop ending.......
Deep amber,with lasting creamy head.Wheaty malt nose.. Smooth and creamy with faint medium length hop finish. Good lace

column1: Watch City I Got Your Dopplebock
column5: Very dark amber pour with minimal head. Aroma is very malty and sweet - flavor follows the same malty sweetness.

column1: Watch City The Gourd & Sheaf Ale
column5: Dark amber pour, creamy tan head with decent lacing. Aroma is sweet and spicy - pumpkin and nutmeg are most prominent. Flavor similar to their Pie-Eyed Pimpkin Ale, but a little lighter on the spices. Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth. Could be a dangerous session beer if it is to your taste, as it goes down incredibly smooth and easy.

column1: Flossmoor Station Train Wreck of Flavor
column5: Dark brown body with no appreciable head. Vary malty aroma with hints of Bourbon. Flavor is a nice mix of malt, chocolate, and Bourbon. Hot in the mouth. Decent beer.

column1: Flossmoor Station Train Wreck of Flavor
column5: Sampled at Schlaflyâ€™s Repeal of Prohibition Fest. This was one of the more interesting at the fest. Pours dark rich hazy brown with a dense tan head. The aroma has vanilla, sour fruit, passion fruit, mild and light spice. Medium / full body with a small amount of sharp carbonation - lush and smooth. The flavor starts with sour fruits, toasted caramel barleywine malt, hints of bourbon and vanilla. The finish has lots of spice, barnyard and pepper. A very unique mix of styles that is not easy categorized and thus falls appropriately under American Strong Ale. Thumbs up for this experimental brew.

column1: Flossmoor Station Train Wreck of Flavor
column5: on tap at the maproom, pours dark brown with off white head. very molasses and bourbon nose with hints of chocolate. flavor has nicely balanced notes of chocolate, nuts, cherries, bourbon, and mild oxidation. mouthfeel is a tad thin but carbination is nice and low. alcohol is extremely well hidden but resulted in a nice buzz. a very drinkable bourbon aged beer.

column1: Flossmoor Station Train Wreck of Flavor
column5: Sampler flight at Flossmoor Station. Dark plum brown pour with a thick head. Hints of bourbon on nose, hits hard. Definately a hint of burboun gowning down, miild malts and nutty flavor, but mainly caramel and a smokey bite. I liked. As a shot.

column1: Flossmoor Station Train Wreck of Flavor
column5: Almost black in color with an abundant tan head. The nose is intense bourbon, toffee, and molasses. The alcohol is pretty prominent throughout. The flavors range from sweet caramel, toffee, molasses, Jim Beam, oak, burnt nuts (and you know painful THAT can be!), dates, figs, and a spicy peppery twist that i attribute to the alcohol punch. Good!

column1: Flossmoor Station Train Wreck of Flavor
column5: Had this on draught at the brewpub in Flossmoor, Illinois. Clear brown pour, with bourbon and carmel in the nose, spicy with burned caramel and butterscotch throughout. Sweet and smooth, alcoholic toward the end. Good!

column1: Flossmoor Station Train Wreck of Flavor
column5: #908On tap at the 4th anual Festival of Wood and barrel Aged Beer festival at GI Wriglyville Nov 4th, 2006. Nearly black, totally opague with a thin rim of tan head. As it has been said that this had to be poured from a pitcher because it exploded from the tap. Nose has lots of pepper and spice. Taste is flat in texture but lots of strong bourbon and alcohol. Spicy with lots of dark fruits here and there.

column1: Flossmoor Station Train Wreck of Flavor
column5: An uncontrollable head warranted pouring this off the jockey box into a pitcher. It remained a frothy tan over a deep mahogany. Clay and earthen notes aling with some chocolaty malts and alot of overpowering whisky. Thin with creeping potency . Dry & chocolaty. Complexities ensue. Wow. (and that, my friends, is where my notes on this one end.) Sampled at FoBAB IV, Nov. 4, 2006

column1: Flossmoor Station Train Wreck of Flavor
column5: sampled at barrel-aged brewfest. pitch black, though red lines edges. elegent head. all bourbon aroma. pretty flat. aroma pure bourbon. palate thin. but good, solid flavor. flavor is a bit muted. a little nutty, but it wouldnâ€™t be there if the description didnâ€™t suggest it. what an awful review.

column1: Flossmoor Station Train Wreck of Flavor
column5: Very dark brown, nearly black in body with only a few bubbles from the pour. Thereâ€™s a goodly amount of Bourbon in the nose along with the sweet malts and slight woodiness. The flavorâ€™s a crafted blending of Bourbon, toffee, hints of chocolate covered nuts, and a burning alcohol. The finish is sweet, sticky, and hot. Very nice. Festival of Barrel Aged Beers, Chicago, IL 11/04/2006
Smooth malty beginning. Very dry grainy with a nice smooth round aftertaste. Caramel, hazelnuts. Very dry with a grainy and moderate bitter dusty dry finish. Nice.
Bottle. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. No tasting notes kept, just rating.

Bottle. Bronze (Reddish-Brown) in colour. Malty (biscuity, buttery caramel, roasty malts, slightly chocolatey). Some hops and some fruit. Sweet malty. Predominately malty throughout. Easy drinking. (2008)
Not much aroma; a hint of dry-roasted peanuts. Medium brown with slightly scummy head. Malty and a bit caramelly at first, then hoppy. Light bodied.
Pours clear, dark amber. Medium tan head. Aroma is darkly malty, roasty, treacle. Light body. Rather watery. Not much flavor.
500 ml sampled in 2009. Amber body with a nice beige head. Good, strong malt aroma with light burnt caramel. Weak flavor of malt, caramel and some bitterness. Pretty one-dimensional and uninspired.
50cl bottle from Tesco. Copper with a loose cream head; light, leafy, hop aroma; soft caramel malt flavour; with a reasonable dry bitterness to finish. Not bad for a bottled bitter.

Bottle 500ml. @ home. Clear medium amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, bread, toasted, caramel, light metalic. Flavour is moderate sweet and light to light moderate bitter with a average to long duration, thin, toffee - caramel. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light metalic. [20111120]
A - Light caramel with fruit A - Light brown with thin head T - Light sweet P - Mid and soft O - Decent
30th May 2009 Clear brown beer. Dry crisp palate. Dry malt and then some pretty bitter hop without any hop flavour. Very dry finish. Hard work!
Clear pale golden body and no head. Sweet apple and some sour aroma. Sweet apple taste, dry and little acidic. Fizzy carbonation. A good cider.
75cl Bottle @ El Corte Ingles, Seville, Spain. Golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma is green apples, sweet, tart. Taste follows the aroma. Medium body, average carbonation.
Botella, 28/12/18 Color amarillo dorado, espuma blanca, aromas a manzana, sidra espumosa.
Recht sÃ¼ÃŸer Beginn. Hohe Karbonisierung, die starke SÃ¼ÃŸe stÃ¶rt. Apfelig, langer Nachhall. 10/8/9/8/9/8
Bottle, dach gathering. Pours golden. Aroma is sour, vinegar, apples. Flavor is sweet, sour, apples, baked apples, bit metallic. Overall: drinkable.
Bottle sample at RBVG 2018, cheers! Clear bright yellow color, tiny bubbles. Apple skin aroma. Taste is dry lightly earthy apple. Not bad
750ml bottle. Clear dark yellow color. Small size, bubbly white head, disappears. Sweet, apples, caramel, sourish in aroma. Sweet, apples, caramel in taste. Too fizzy. Drinkable brew.
Bottle from a supermarket in Spain. Clear golden liquid. Very sweet apple flavour with high carbonation. A little tooth rotting.

750mml bottle. Tasted on the 24/12/2017 at Vegadeo. Clear golden colour with no head and a fizzy body. Aroma of apples, sugar and sweet candy. Taste of sweet apples, and wood. Funky finish. Next one please!

courtesy of Antonio Rey - translucid pale golden beer, no foam; deep aroma of pears and apples; subtle but lively carbonation, moderate body, light sourish but mainly sweet; long juicy aftertaste of apples with notes of cellar and lot of residual sweetness

Possibly the lamest marketing gimimick Iâ€™ve encountered yet in the beer world. Reddish orange collor, no head. Light malty aroma. Watery mouthfeel. Simple crystal malt flavor. Prety basic, but seemed to be the best choice for me when I was at Garfinkleâ€™s in Vail.
Just a watered down version of New Belgium''s. Nothing too exciting, just a well balanced, medium bodied beer.

No joke, it's really called Phlatt Tyre!! New Belgium unavailable for comment. Crystal-amber appearance. Thick malt profile. Crisp peach aroma and peach/nectarine also prominent in the flavor. I liked this better than the real Fat Tire. The hops could have been a bit more assertive though.
From the Can at Chris Oâ€™s, GBBF Week 09/08/2008 Very malty aroma. Amber coloured malty and a little sweet on the palate. Crisp and slightly dry in the finish.
Canned. Ambe5r colour, mediumsized beige fluffy head. Aroma is fruits, caramel malts and some mild notes of toffee. Flavour is caramel malts and some fruits along with plum.
Clear dark amber with tiny off white short lasting head. Sweet malty aroma with caramel and plum notes. Sweet flavor with caramel and roasted malt. Ends sweet.
Can . Red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, malt. Flavour is sweet, caramel, malt.

500 ml can. Light copper and crystal clear. Medium-sized off-white head. Strong refreshing nougat aroma. Light-bodied, but with a little dark caramel. Balanced flavour, but it lacks much character. Could do with a lot more punch. Little bitterness throughout. A bit watery.
Can, 4.5%. Red/dark amber colour. The flavour is malty and a bit bready, probably due to age, 2 months past BB date. Cardboard flavours. Small floaties.
50 cl can, 2006 version. Lovely amber, fine head. Light and easy, but with the proper maltiness and even some bitter hops in the finish. Fine with food, I think.

Can. 2006 Christmas seasonal. Dark amber almost ruby color. Small beige head. Malty nose. Abrupt malt flavor, some sweetness and minimal hops. Sour and slight bitter finish. A decent "klasse D" julÃ¸l.

(Can 50 cl) Pours a clear, orangey brown with a small, off-white head. Distinct caramel in the nose. Medium body with pleasant notes of roasted malt and caramel. A light sweetness but stil ends fairly dry. 210906
Malty and sweet. Feels a bit thin and sharp and also way too carbonated. Other flavours are very mild and has a slightly hoppy finish. Somewhat metallic.

Bottle from Tim. Poured into a nonic pint glass, the appearance was a murky dark orange color with a cap of a little white foamy head that fell off at a mild pace. Some messy lace. The aroma had some caramel/toffee malts up front, then biscuits and bread and then ended with a little bit of orange extract sweetness. The flavor was sweet all of the way through riding on the blend of the orange and the malts. Did I enjoy it? Hmmmm....well, its just super sweet which also lead into the aftertaste and finish. The palate was almost medium bodied, seemed to sit just a touch under with a decent sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine. ABV felt fine. Overall, is this really supposed to be an American pale ale or an English one? I mean, well, I didnt mind this one so much for me, but honestly, arent the American ones supposed to have more hops to them. I thought this was an English pale ale.
12 oz bottle pours amber with an off white head. Aroma of caramel, grain and a little pine. Taste is caramel malts and toffee.
Pours a dark orange/reddish brown, with medium head. Caramel aroma. Flavors of caramel, nuts, smoke.

Pours a clear orange-gold with a thin, larger-bubbled wispy eggshell head that immediately settles to a ring leaving scant lace. Nose involves faint spice notes along with some apple and orange marmalade. Lightly sweet, a touch more bitter, and fairly tart in excess of the other flavors. Lighter bodied, soft, with a cleansing tart and drying bitter finish. An ok brew, light on aromatics and somewhat odd flavor-wise, but the palate saves it. No idea on the age of the bottle. Iâ€™ll have to get over to LaPorte some time and check this place out.
Bottle. Caramel malt and light orange peel aroma. Amber with moderate head. Slightly sweet caramel malt and lightly bitter orange peel flavor. Not bad - pretty standard.
Tap at Back Road Fall Fest. Faint sweet orange caramel malt aroma. Amber with a small off-white head. Orange caramel malt and mild bitter flavor. Medium body.

Pour from a 12 oz bottle. Medium amber brew with with off white head. Aroma of teaberry, caramel, malt, grass. Taste is brady malts at the start with teaberry / grassy hops (light) in the finish. Rather sweet.
Amber, some head and lacing. Taste of malted grain w/caramel. Light bitter finish that lingers. Overall, needs to be a little lighter for the amount of flavor.
12oz bottle acquired in trade. Poured a medium golden color with a very small sized off white head. Aromas of toast, some caramel, and grains. Tastes of the same.

Thanks to hopdog for sharing this. Pours a translucent amber with a smaller bubbly off white head. Aroma of tea, tobacco, light spicy hop notes, some mettalic notes. flavor of tea, hops, light toasted malt some nuts.

column1: Sports City Cafe The Big Sting Honey Rye
column5: Loose fisheye head. Sticky lemony yeasts and rye in the nose.. Swich stance on you and wallops you with honey with a little rye. To one dimentional.

column1: Sports City Cafe The Big Sting Honey Rye
column5: Really good brew. Surprisingly light, refreshing flavor for being so powerful. A good wheat flavor, with some other fruit flavors. Didn't notice ayn rye, but that good, casue rye (at least bread)kind of tastes like ass. Had this on at the strong ale fest

column1: Sports City Cafe The Big Sting Honey Rye
column5: big thick and juicy white head and light golden body..yeast, banana, maybe some citrus..maybe some rye notes, I dont know..but too wheaty and yeasty for me..

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: (Nitro Draft: 2004 Strong Ale Festival, Pizza Port in Carlsbad, CA. Day 1, Beer 7) The flavor is very sweet, perhaps too sweet, dark roasted, moderate coffee, and fairly bitter. Moderate alcohol presence. Medium body for an Imperial Stout, but still fairly full mouthfeel. The sweetness sticks on the palate for ages. Dark roasted, coffee nose with a fairly sweet aroma in the background. Nearly jet black in color. Pours a good size tan head after the cascading ceases, and retains that level fairly well. Leaves fairly dense lacing, not bad for well used festival glass.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: On tap at Pizza Port 8th Strong Ale Festival. Black color, decent tan head, coffee/cocoa aroma. A very well done IS, full mouthfeel, complex with coffee and chocolate, hops contributing. Good stuff.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: i got in good with the bartender so she filled my growler up with this one.very good russian stout.no rasin flavor at all.nothing but barley,smoke and coffe.slo brew knows how to make stouts thats for sure.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Black color, decent head. Complex flavor and aroma with hints of alcohol, chocolate, licorice, roast, sherry and molasses. Creamy mouthfeel.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Coffee nose, coffee color, coffee flavor. Solidly constructed, slightly sweet with a trace of metal.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: blackness with creamy topping..an aroma of coffee and salty peanut skins..smooth moutfeel, bitter backing..with raisins and mocha..yet still lacking in the flavor department..

column1: Rock Bottom San Diego Johnny Rebels Earthquake Ale
column5: On tap from a while back. Orangeish color with a off white head. Aroma was very sweet; bubblegum and yeast, but not much balance. Flavor was very sweet, although the alcohol was not too present. Some wheat, fruit, and banana/gum as well. Solid beer, but a bit one dimensional.

column1: Rock Bottom San Diego Johnny Rebels Earthquake Ale
column5: Date: 12/02/2005 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Strong Ale Fest cloudy yellow, thin white head, sweet bubblegum aroma and flavor, touch of clove, light bitterness Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 4/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

column1: Rock Bottom San Diego Johnny Rebels Earthquake Ale
column5: Cloudy Orange small white head dissipated fast. Big fruity aroma, light body clean finish.

column1: Rock Bottom San Diego Johnny Rebels Earthquake Ale
column5: Draft at PP Strong Ale Fest â€™05. Hazy bittery yellow pour. Lemon and candied yeasty aroma Light malt flavors, with a fair amount of yeast and candied estery fruit like apples and some lemon.

column1: Rock Bottom San Diego Johnny Rebels Earthquake Ale
column5: 9th Annual San Diego Strong Ale Fest: Murky orange with a small off-white head. Aroma of esters, candy, and some spice. Flavor was also estery. Light fruit, apples, and a light spice on the finish. Semi-dry with a medium body.

column1: Rock Bottom San Diego Johnny Rebels Earthquake Ale
column5: spicy yeast, fruit, peppery aroma. Appearance is almost a cloudy pink/brown, minimal head. Yeasty palate, some alcohol. Sweet finish. Reminded me of Unibroue. My favourite of their line up.

column1: Rock Bottom San Diego Johnny Rebels Earthquake Ale
column5: Ctirusy and flowery on the nose w/ hints of light fruit and spice. This beer poured a cloudt brown color w/ golden orange highlights, almost no head and no lacing. The flavor was spicy like coriander and light fruit w/ slight hop and citrus notes. The mouthfeel had minor effervescence and a light body.

column1: Rock Bottom San Diego Johnny Rebels Earthquake Ale
column5: Tasted at the 2004 Pizza Port Strong Ale Fest. Medium orange color, slightly cloudy. Large sized white foamy head. Aroma is fruity and sweet. Mostly apricots and peaches. Medium bodied Belgian Strong Ale. Malts are fruity and sweet. Nice bright yeasts. Very sweet. Lots of fruit esters. Lots of banana and clove flavors. Nice and smooth. Might have been a little young yet, sort of a chaotic mix of ester, carbonation and yeasts. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

column1: Rock Bottom San Diego Johnny Rebels Earthquake Ale
column5: This beer was had on tap at the San Diego Strong Ale Festival 2004. This beer pours a cloudy dark orange color iwth hints of yellows and reds as well and a thin white head which quickly dissipated and left little head. Swirling led to pretty much slight lacing, but nothing all that interesting. The aroma is belgiany with spices, yeasts and lemons being predominant. It was pretty damn cold by now as this was my last sample of the night and it was only 48F out, so warming the beer was very difficult. As it warmed some cloves and lemon yeast became very apparent as it twirled to a tart and fruity finish. Some oranges, apricot, orange peel and lemon in the finish. Not much presence of alcohol, but if you looked closely enough it was there. Full of carbonation here..almost too much so. Would someone PLEASE put this beer away for a while and let it age. This beer needs to calm down a WHOLE bunch, but its got the makings of a nice solid Belgian Strong Ale.

column1: Rock Bottom San Diego Johnny Rebels Earthquake Ale
column5: On tap @ the San Diego Strong Ale Fest. Poured a dark cloudy/hazy/murky amber/orange color with a white head. Aromas and tastes of spices (cloves and pepper) and somewhat fruity. A decent Belgian Strong ale.

Growler from Ken and Omars tasting. Pours a slihgtly hazed copper with a thin lasting white head. Aroma is medium citrus and orange peel, pears, herbal , english fruity ester yeast, peach, earthy and tea-leaves. Flavor is moderate caramel and toasty malts, ligth fruity esters, pine and citrus hops as well as some leafy herbal hops, slightly fragrant floral hops as well- earth and leather in the finish. Good.

Growler, courtesy of Omar. Somewhat hazy copper with an off-white head. Grain, tea and pine in the nose. Very piney flavor, caramel toastiness, grapefruit, moderate bitterness and neutral American ale yeast. Medium full body with moderate carbonation. Solid stuff.

Growler provided by kmweaver via Omar. Hazy amber body with a medium, creamy tan head. The nose is sweet and hoppy with flowers, grapefruit and caramel. The flavor is lightly sweet, lightly bitter with tea, caramel and tangerine. Medium body is very soft with light carbonation and a bitter finish.

Draft from the brewpub. One of my favorite WilliBrews! Pours a cloudy amber with a thin white head. Heavy aromas of hops, grapefruit, orange and pine. Flavor is of bitter hops, grapefruit and pine with a slight, but noticable sweet toffee finish. Has a crisp, refreshing mouthfeel. An excellent IPA. Plan on filling a few growlers on my next visit.

Growler, courtesy of Omar. Pours a hazy, bright orange-amber color; off-white head with fine-bubbled lacing. Resiny, wet hop and chewy oranges in the aroma; very floral and fresh. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: great, chewy orange and resiny hop presence (oranges, juicy fruits, passion fruit); excellent hop character and density; very drinkable, with a slight oiliness in the palate; lengthy, orange and floral hop finish.

(10/18/07, growler, thanks kmweaver and Omar) Creamy beige head atop cloudy amber body. Aroma is medium sweet, pine/grapefruit, light bread, wood. Taste is medium sweet, grapefruit/pine, caramel, light lemon. Resinous medium body.

Growler thanks to Omar and Ken. Nose of pine sap, hop oil, cedar wood and oilives. Juicy flavor of cedar wood, honey, semi-sweet resinous and oily hops. Mild bitterness, smooth overall, and quite nice, with a grassy finish. Good stuff.

Poured from a growler. Thick but fairly transparent tangerine orange color. Brilliantly dank, vinous aroma that reaches to the heart of delicious, farmerâ€™s market freshness; notes of pine, mint leaves, orange rind, and tropical fruit. Kiwi and citrus. Crisp and fruity taste, pure with sparkling newness like a morning dew; grassy and lavender floral tones play prominently, with understated candy sweetness balancing underneath. Texture is a simple hop paste; pine nuts and woods dry out the finish. A lovely, well-bridled example. Cheers to Omar for procuring the goods, and thanks for sharing, Ken!

Yet another IPA from Willimantic and one of the better ones Iâ€™ve tried. Pours amber with a thin white head. Smells of citrus and perfumy with some wintery splashes. Tastes of pine resin with some nice even bitterness as the beer warms. The malt is present in the background and compliments this one nicely.

Hazy orange, left great lacing. Smells strongly of citrus hops, orange peel, and piney hops. Flavor starts sweet caramel malt, sweet citric hops, then turns sharply bitter with a great piney resinous and slightly grassy hop flavor. Excellent stuff, I just canâ€™t get enough of these Willibrew IPAs.
on draft at the brewery, GREAT IPA. These guys have finally entered the top IPA era. Love the stuff they are putting out. Tons of citrus flavors, very impressed.

Fresh growler. Aroma of marzipan, other candy-like notes, citrus, pineapple, grass, toffee. Flavor very fresh and hoppy-fruity with strong toffee malt notes that still remain crisp and never sweet. Just great stuff.

Growler from the brewpub. Pours a cloudy light brown/orange with a thick white head. Aroma of citrus, garlicky hops, nacho cheese Doritoes. Reminds me of Smuttynose IPA. Flavor of rich caramel and bready malts, garlicky, spicy hops. Tons of flavor and spices here that gives this a full-bodied palate. Really reminds me of super fresh Smutty IPA. This is a top-notch IPA. Very enjoyable. 8/4/9/4/17 [4.2/5]

Tap at the brewpub and a later growler as well. Mmm, mmm, now weâ€™re talking. Very, very cloudy deep orange coloured beer. Bright sweet hop aroma. Lots of bright orange/grapefruit peel and a little bit of apricot fruitiness as well. Quite sweet with a low of resinousness. Fruity and tropical with the malts just peeking out from behind. Papaya and mango and a rich creamy body that somehow manages to stay lean and balanced. There is a touch of zesty/herbal quality on the back that really sets off the fruity notes that are up front. No complaints from this hophead!

Thanks to JoeMcPhee for sharing - lightly hazy copper, with a soapy lace - explosive, tangy grapefruit hoppiness in the nose - a lot of pine and herbs - earthy hop character - more of the same in the flavor - not much to say except it is nicely balanced between malt and potent hops - itâ€™s got the ineffable greatness that more awesome ipas have, so I will not even attempt to explain how good it is.

Growler supplied by kmweaver. Poured a hazed orange color with a small off-white head. The aroma was great with fresh hop forward notes. Citrus and sweaty hop aromas with a sweet malt base that pokes out just enough to give balance. Nice citrus hop flavor with hints of pine. Long mild-moderate bitterness on the finish. Medium bodied.

Draft @ Willi. Pours a murky, pulpy, bright orange-amber color; thin off-white head with patchy lacing. Juicy, resiny passion fruit and orange hoppiness in the aroma; very soft edges, but an enormous amount of chewy, fresh hops in the nose: some red fruits and caramel underneath. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: amazingly dense, pulpy, hop-forward character (oranges, tropical fruits); nice levels of carbonation; zesty, tongue-numbing bitterness; very generous hop character, and ridiculously tasty and dense and hoppy for under 7% (listed as 6.8% on the main board). This tastes like a much much larger beer, but without the slightest show of alcoho; complex red fruits and soft sugar lurking underneath. Hugely successful and impressive. Lengthy finish: some lingering tongue-numbing orange and tropical hops, breadiness, and well-toasted malts.
On tap at the brewpub. A cloudy amber with a small white head. Aroma was all hops citrus and piney. Taste those hops with a touch of malt. Great beer.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a cloudy amber color with a thin white head. Aromas of citrus fruit and heavy on hops. Tastes of lemon and citrus with a nice sweet finish. Has a refreshing, crisp mouthfeel that leaves you wanting more! An excellent Willibrew.

On tap at the brewpub. Dark amber with a white head. Fresh, green hop nose, pine and citrus, lots of hop action. Some bready, biscuity notes creep in after you grow accustomed to the hop assault. Rather dry. Tastes just like it smells - a numbingly bitter hop concert. Nice!
Draught @ Brewpub: This one pours a hazy golden color. there was no head or lacing. It has a good nose. Malty, with lots of hops. Tropical, pine and citrus. the taste is similar. Very nice!
On draft at the brewpub it is a clear golden color with a slight head. The aroma is malty and the taste is strong and bitter with hints of caramel. Has a caramel and slight boozy finish.
On draft at the brewpub. Pours a clear copper with an off white head. Grassy nose. Flavors of pine and caramel. Smooth, slightly boozy finish.
On tap at the brewery: Pours clear amber with no head. Aroma of pale malt and booze. Taste is boozy up front and then toasted malt, and dough. Not much going on here.
on tap at brewery, started very boozy but thinned out to a toasty biscuity stronger ale, safe drinkable beer

12 oz glass at the brewery. A cloudy blonde hue, this unfiltered IIPA has a strong flavor and a heavy body with plenty of citrus flavors and lots of brown sugar taste from the residual sugar. A little too sweet for my liking.

Pours amber with a white head. Smells of pine resin, lots of floral hints, touches of biscuits. Tastes of caramel with lots of up front spicy qualities probably coming from the selection of hops. Mouthfeel is oily with a finish that is sugary.

Transparent viscous copper amber pour has a stringy-lacing white head. Aroma has a big resiny piny hop presence with some caramely malty sweetness. Starts rich and caramely sweet with a lot of big bittering and grapefruity flavor hops. Pretty well-balanced and drinkable, a nice IIPA.

On draft at the brewery. Pours a dark amber color with a thin, white head that dissipates quickly. Heavy aromas of grapefruit, hops, and spice with a hint of mint. Flavor is of citrus fruits, hops, and grass with a slightly sweet aftertaste. Mouthfeel is very soft and smooth. Awesome brew!

Growler provided by kmweaver. Clear amber body with a tiny off-white head. The nose is herbal and sweet with cotton candy, grapefruit, tangerine and cat urine. The flavor is lightly sweet, moderately bitter with cotton candy, tea, spicy herbal hops and orange peal. Medium/full body is soft and sticky with low carbonation.
bland coffee flavor. no head. dark boddy. fairly smooth body. all in all i found this beer to be a little boring.

Probably the most disappointing imperial stout i have had to date. Good thick coffee aroma, and a pour of a dark brown with absolutely no head. When held up to the light it almost glowed a ruby red it seemed...anyhow, the taste was practically of pure chocolate and boy was it dry. The taste was very bland though, almost thin and weak for a russian imperial. It finished with a mocha-like aftertaste but it just didnt combine a solid taste with the aroma i was getting off of it. The taste was far too thin for the palate, and the dryness did not balance well at all.

12/06/02: Had on tap at Pizza Port Strong Ale Festival
After the first few stouts I ever tasted, I really wasn''t overly fond of them. Thanks to recent findings (including this beer and Alesmith''s Speedway Stout), stouts have progressed up my list of favorites. This offering is pourted with a light black appearance very little, if any head. A strong coffee aroma eminates from this stout and it goes down quite easily. A sweet, light aftertaste finishes this fine stout. A superb offering by the Ojai Brewing Co.

FÃ¼r ein Fruit ist es gar nicht mal so schlecht. Erfrischend in der SÃ¤ure, leicht bitter und von der Optik her natÃ¼rlich kÃ¼nstlich, aber in Ordnung. Zu meckern bleibt nicht viel, auÃŸer der vollen Chemie, die hier drin stecken mag.

Pours out of the bottle in a light hazy light red colour with no head and thin body. Aroma of light strawberries and dust. Taste of sweet oranges, strawberries and pear. Okay for a fruit beer but just nothing very nice or tasty.

It has a very nice pink color and the adding op some grapefruit is rather original and makes way for a very nice taste. Both the Grolsch-brand and Grapefruit are bitter but the both compliment each other, perhaps because the watery 2.5 redeems them. Very good summer-beer with a nice fruit-taste.
like the lemon one, artificial and chemical. Take 1 liter of generic pilsener, 2 liters of water and half a liter of grapefruitjuice.. enjoy. Color is disgusting.

Oh man, I hate grapefruit! So I probably should have known that this wouldn't be my beer. Although the sun was shining and I was looking out to some refreshing beer, this didn't do it for me. But probably because ... I hate grapefruit.

What can you expect from a beer with 2,5 % alcahol, not much.... To compensate the little taste Pink Grapefruit is added... Not tasty, but if you can't really drink it is a nice alternative. It is a beerry lemonade.. And very watery

Pink golden color. Grapefruit aroma, a bit artificial. Watery thin but fresh, with a strong grapefruit flavor. I can''t understand some low ratings, I''ve had much worse beers, though the aftertaste is a bit annoying.
I have no words for it, it's disgusting.....................................
it was better than expected. quite refreshing and a pleasant shade of pink. there are plenty of worse beers out there - like grolsch het kanon, for example

only bought this cause it used to be the very worst beer in the world as voted by ratebeerers, before florisgaarden chocolat turned up on the scene - and whadayaknow i actually liked it after a good cycle round zeeland in the rain. exactly as skortila says - amstel light with grapefruit. who needs cascade hops?
eher Radler als Bier. riecht nach Spuelmittel. Schmeckt auch nicht viel besser.
Clear yellow color with a small bubbly white head. Lemon aroma. Medium light body. Tad sweet and a mild bitterness. Average carbonation. Quite fresh lemon flavor. [Can from Boni in Odijk, Holland]

Strange take on the low-alcohol concept with trendy bottle, a typical â€™designer beerâ€™. Well, "beer" is perhaps a bit too much here: this product is very unbeery. Dense moussy head, snow white, bit rocky, crackling; pale straw blonde colour with vague greenish hue, clear, strong sparkling. Weak aroma primarily centered around an artificial lemon sourishness, almost reminiscent of air freshener or lemon-aromatized dish soap, some sweetish pale malts, some grassy hops, and, to mask the lemon effect, â€™wet dogâ€™ due to hops deteriorating. Very neutral taste dominated by the artificial lemon, though not too agressive, light sweetness, very late hoppy accent in the finish, very thin and watery mouthfeel. I cannot find anything redeeming in this fake product.

Sweet lemon with still some beer in the background. Color is clear yellow with small head. Very refreshing taste, with still some beer in the background. Great beer in the summer, with not too much alcohol.
Trinkbar. Mehr aber auch nicht. Pappsuess, leicht kuenstlich und in letzter Konsequenz weit entfernt von Bier jeder Art. Naja...

Pours out of the bottle in a clear yellow colour with airy low head and thin body. Aroma of mild lemons and mild beer. Taste of mild citrus fruits, lemonade and mild lager beer. Nothing very special or nice.
Pours yellow with a white head. Aroma is light malt, light grass and lemon peal. Flavour is malt, grass, lemon peal and light soap. Light bitter and watery.
Pours a clear and pale yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is weak with lemon and synthetic notes. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is dry with sweetness. Overall a boring beer.

Bottle 250ml. Clear medium yellow colour with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is light malty, grain, lemon, cardboard. Flavour is light moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light metalic. [20111106]

Bottle. A small, white head sits over a clear, yellowish golden body. Quite weak on the nose, with a touch of pils and a touch of lemon. The flavor has the same problem, or in this case probably the advantage, itâ€™s very weak, both on beer and lemon. Thin on the palate, with some soapy feelings. A ilttle bitterness towards the end. Not horrific in any way this one, but very uninteresting. 111106

Woo! How great example of Weizen beer! Cloudy, yellow, with strong banana notes. Not much of spices. In taste it turns to ripe banana & bit of sweet notes like vanilla and honey a bit maybe. But it's quite dry as well! Overall it's great :)
Tap at the source. Hazy golden color with white head. Aroma is wheat, light esters, peach, cloves. Taste is clove, milky yeast, wheat, bananas. Very smooth mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Nice!

500 ml bottle. Pale cloudy yellow, medium head. Clove, vanilla, banana, yeast, some citrus and dough. Mild dry bitterness, slightly acidic, a bit sweet. Medium bodied, milky texture, lively carbonated, dry finish. Good and very refreshing!
Vycap damian. VÃ´Åˆa kvasinkova. Farba Å¾ltÃ¡ s bielou penou. . ChuÅ¥ kvasinkova.
On tap at Damian. Hazy yellow colour with small white head, aroma of lemon, some banana. Taste of lemon, banana, clove. Pretty average.

0.5l bottle. Only a tiny bit murky pale yellow body with a quickly collapsing white head. Aroma of doughy yeast and lemon zest with some sweet apples. Apples and emon zest show up in the taste too with notes of sugar syrup, yeast and a bit of spicy phenols. The body is quite light. Nothing super bad, just weaker than how I like a weizen.
Tap and bottle later. Milky yellow color, good white foam. Aroma and taste: wheat, a bit clove and fruity sourness, a bit banana, good weizen.

On tap at Kulovy Blesk. Great appearance, cloudy golden with a compact white foam. Aroma and taste is intense, banana and clove, starting sweet and grany, lots of wheat malts, then finish slightly bitter, herbal hops. An amazing Weissbier!

Bottle, 0.50l. Aroma of wheat, banana, yeast and some phenols. Pours pale amber color with medium frothy white head and average sparkling appearance. Taste of classic hefeweizen with refreshing grainy, banana and yeasty note. Medium body, slick texture and average carbonation in palate. Thirst quencher for sure...

#2071 Tap. Hazy, deep gold to light amber, medium white head. Wonderful aroma of clove, touch of cinnamon, wheat, banana, fruits. Taste is neutral, semi-dry, sourish finish. Wheat and spices. Medium body and carbonation. Nice example of Hefeweizen.

It's been a couple of years since we were at the brewery. We went there with some friends and had to wait 45 minutes to get in. Food, beer and service were excellent. Our friends aren't much into beer, but both were impressed by the food and beer. I tried 2 other beers that were also good.
Poured from 1 pint 6 fl oz bottle. Amber brown with off-white head. Sweet citrus and pine hops, sweet light resiny finish with sticky texture, light alcohol.

Draft at the brewery. Orange pour with a sweet, malty aroma. Citrus fruit flavor with an overwhelming amount of malt. Very hop heavy finish as well. A little boozy. Tastes strong. Overall, pretty good.

On tap @ Hudson. Pours dark orange copper with thin white head. Aroma is big boozy caramel malt with faintly spicy hops in the back. Taste is similar up front - heavy sweet caramel malt with bitter earthy floral hops. Rare, tasty beer, lots of anticipation for this unless youâ€™re in Bellingham. Doesnâ€™t quite live up to the hype, but thatâ€™s a tall order. Not bad, all considered.

6.5% on tap at CBB, 700 yen for a half pint. A clear light copper color with a bitter hoppy taste, very clean. A nicely balanced malty Â backbone perfectly matched with a lemony hop flavor. Very nice.

Draught @ Brouwerâ€™s CafÃ©: Â  Vibrant amber, moderate foamy off-white head, nice lacing. Â  A little carbonation too. Â  Resiny nose, citrus side of hoppy, pithy, light alcohol. Â  Bright resiny and citrus peel on the tongue, bitter but not biting, and very warming. Â  Makes my ears warm! Â  Very clean, lingering hoppiness that doesnâ€™t sting. Â  Moderate to full body and mouthfeel. Â  Solid example, lots of flavor, warming, good malt base so the hops arenâ€™t overpowering. Â  I seem to miss this one often, but finally after all these years got to try it officially. Â  One of the better PNW IIPAs.
Had this beer poured from draft at Taphouse Grill in Seattle. Orange pour. Sourish grapefruit taste with vanilla hints very hoppy. Overall very good
Finally an above average beer from BB. Its a well rounded, almost safe DIPA, but it does do it well. No finesse just a nice drinking floral hop forward beer. Does hide 9% well.

Bottle picked up during WA brewer open house. Copper amber color, very little head. Aroma big on caramel, pine as well. Slick texture, full body, soft carbonation. Taste starts pretty sweet but gives way quickly to pine/citrus hop bitterness that lingers nicely. Overall: decent double ipa, but can't help but hope for more. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught at the brewpub Hazy amber color, with medium sized creamy head. Nice aroma, caramel and hop fruitiness, light sweat. The body is quite good; strong flavor of caramel, some malt, good hops, with provide mild resins in the front, and light fruitiness later; strong but not excessive bitterness. Solid, good, a bit sturdy.
This poured a black color with a large white head. The aroma is coffee and charcoal. The flavor is rather bitter with some chocolate showing up. Overall a nice session stout!

Appearance: Appropriate black body with an inch of fizzy, light beige-colored head. Significant amounts of lacing as we progress. Smell: Roastyish nose for the most part with some chocolate and nutty notes. Taste: Sweet, roasty maltiness with a taste of bakerâ€™s chocolate and hints of dark caramel and cola nuts. Minor earthy bitterness. Pinch of licorice powder. Finishes bittersweet. Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Drinkability: A solid, enjoyable Irish Stout. Overall, itâ€™s better than I had expected.

I will take this over most dry stouts out in the trade anyday. Big head that is lightly tan and of little character that fades away rather quickly. A rugged roasted coffee flavor, blends with a bit of dark chocolate and cocoa notes in the aftertaste. Decent.

Tap at brewpub and served with nitro: Near black with a tan creamy nitro pour head and very good lace. The aroma is roasty and charred, chocolate, herbal and flowery hops, walnut and a hint soapy. The taste is dark malts, bittersweet with a mild hop background. Very light smoke and nutty qualities on the finish. The mouth feel is creamy but thin. A very average brewpub paint-by-numbers dry stout.
Tap. Pours black, tan creamy head. Nitro tasting. Aroma is dry. Hints of licorice flavor. Flavor is dry, toasted grain. Finishes very dry and chalky.

From tap at brewpub : Black pour, carbonated, with a big time creamy offwhite head. This baby leaves big thick lacing, like whipped cream thick. Taste is faint, come coffee, but has a big expresso finish. Very smooth with a medium body. Really enjoyed this one.

Very dark blackish color that shows a very tiny hint of ruby red when held up to direct light. Minimal creamy off-white head that lasts and leaves significant lacing. Aroma primarily of coffee and roasted malt. Taste a nice mix of coffee and very dark, bittersweet chocolate. Very smooth on the palate with minimal carbonation. Sampled while on a road trip to the K-State/Auburn game (thanks to the brewery, Iâ€™ll at least be taking home one pleasant memory of that trip).

Name: Dodgreyâ€™s Dry Irish Stout Date: 11/24/2002 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Black, big fine nitro head, very creamy body with a slight oily (oatmeal?) character, rich dry roasted malt flavor, hint of oatmeal, dry finish, only the slightest touch of roasted malt bitterness and then only after warming Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

the highlight of the evening. this was my first trip(long overdue) to 5 seasons. black with a large creamy tan head with excellent retention. aroma is cocoa and smoke. palate is awesome with just the right amount of carbonation(low) and a very creamy, smooth mouthfeel. flavor is chocolate, smoke, cocoa.

From the tap, this brew is a rich deep brown, almost black, with a fine-bubbled and persistent head. Aroma is rich and stouty with strong smoky and coffee hints. Taste is strong and stouty, very smoky, coffee and chocolate undertones. Finish is smooth with some bitterness. Excellent, and highly recommended to all stout/porter fans.

Tap at brewpub. Pours copper/red. Aroma of caramel with faint hoppy presence. Smells a little boozy even. Taste is a bit hoppy with some malt in the back. Kind of syrupy. Finish is astringent and bitter. Not good.
Amber pour with off white head and lace. Caramel malt with a hint of chocolate nose. Sweet caramel malt flavor. Medium bodied but fizzy.
Frothy head; deep burgundy hue. Rich malts; great flavors and a nice crystal sweetness. Hops provided a zingy balance. Bitter aftertaste. Tasty, easy-drinking beer.
Amber body with a quickly dissipated head. Toasty amber body with some candi sugar/cane sugar? notes throughout contributing a sweet and lightness. Bitter sugar finish.
Tap at the brewpub. Typical mediocre amber. I hardly wrote anything down for this. More brown than red. A bit of syrupy caramel balanced out by dull hops.
On draught at the brewery. Labeled 5.9%. Pours a clear dark brown color with amber hues and slight head. Medium-bodied with a caramel flavor and slight hop presence, dry character and clean finish.

Draught at the brewpub. Lovely reddish-orange color similar to the dirt on this part of the island. Bubbly white head that left some lace. Aromatic sprucy hop nose with some bready malt and subdued hop flavor. Pretty tasty.

Pine-hoppy nose, but not super piney...more like tettnanger. Caramel maltiness also noticeable. Dark red with a thin white head. Nice caramel malt flavor, very rich with a nice roasted touch in the finish, hops really stand out about half way through a mouthful. Very well balanced, erroring on the side of more hops...not a bad thing. I can tell they used enough of both malt and hops, no skimping. Medium body, slight mineral-like finish.

Copper coloured, lacy tan head. Sweet caramel and toffee aroma, light toastiness as well. Flavour is sweet with some woody, resiny hoppiness. A bit spicy and yeasty with notes of berry/cherry as well. Just enough bitterness to round off the sweet maltiness. My favourite from the brewery.
Hazy brick coloured. The aroma is metallic and caramelly. Palate has a slight berryish fruitiness. Sweet, sugary malt notes. Lightly toasty, breadcrusty palate. Hints of woody bitterness.

Draught. Body is dark brown to black. Aroma is moderately malty (dark chocolate, coffee), lightly hoppy (grapefruit), with a note of vanilla. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly acidic. Finish is moderately bitter, lightly acidic, lightly sweet. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. The grapefruit eventually comes out in the nose and for me drops the aroma score by a point, sorry. But other than that this is one of Oasis'' more tolerable brews.
Well I love IPA''s so I can''t say I hate this one but definitely not too special. Not bad but pretty bland, nothing especially striking.
Not a bad IPA, though it doesn''t pack a punch but leaves you with a not-so-fantastic lingering bitter that leaves you wanting something defferent. Very flowery and crisp, but nothing special.
Cloudy amber,thin head.Fresh hop nose. Grapefruit hop taste balanced with just enough malt, with med length finish.

Huge explosion upon opening. Tons of floating yeast particles. Orange-brown body initially wears a sticky white head with big bubbles. Intense acetic aroma, extremely yeasty. Sour fruits, vinegar, raw wood chunks, tree leaves. Very sharp and pungent and ultimately it doesnâ€™t work out well. Harsh finish with a long leafy bitterness. Was this an infection? Maybe not, but I canâ€™t imagine a brewer aiming for that result. Lively carbonated.

Sweet candy, brown sugar, sour dough, acetic aroma. Hazy orange-brown with very active off-white head that recedes to persistent cover. Plenty of yeast in suspension. Brown sugar, sour dough-like yeast with a treacly underlying sweetness. Body is still and unexciting. Pressure in the bottle pushed out the cork as soon as the cap was removed. Itâ€™s a shame Martin injured himself for this beer... Bottle #30. Sampled with MartinT and Rastacouere.

(Bottle 030) : In the bottom of the murky pond flocculates muscular, sour yeast and chaotic fruit salad and cocoa powder banks...A harsh and unpleasant weirdness lingers in the back and makes me wonder if this was intentional or not...This is FantÃ´me gone awry, a nightmarish marsh plaguing a possibly good idea...
On tap at the Archer Ale House. Usually in a dubbel the malt far outweighs the yeast?.not so in this case. Not a lot of detectable malt flavor
goldenhazy yellow, light citrus aroma. a very light beer with a mild clove , banana flavor. woulds make a good drink in the arizona summers.
rather insipid bitter. promising aroma of floral hops but the taste is much too mild and rather sweet for a ESB.

Dark brown color, medium head. Roasted malts, medium hopped. Nice nut-brown flavor. Rich smooth malt taste. big malt flavor. Finish is clean. Aftertaste is malty and slightly nutty, not a lot of hop character
Last beer of the tasting day. Dark brown color.no head.thin mouthfeel. Very strong fruity flavor...but nice
winter seasonal. very dark red brown, lot of swet malt in the aroma with a whisky note. very malty, sweet, buttery with a long fruity (apple?) finish

column1: Back Street Magnus Magnus Old Ale
column5: Name: Magnus Old Ale Date: 12/02/2005 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Strong Ale Fest Appearance: amber, headless, Aroma: big sweet carmel candy aroma, Flavor: flavor has lots of candy sweetness, light bitterness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: **/4

column1: Back Street Magnus Magnus Old Ale
column5: On tap at the 10th Annual San Diego Strong Ale Festival: Pours a deep mahogany ruby with a frothy, pillowy tan head. Sweet, sticky caramel malty toffee aroma has some light fruity notes. Body starts full and sweet with some caramel and brown sugar complexity toward a warming, bittersweet earthy finish. Could use more balance.

column1: Back Street Magnus Magnus Old Ale
column5: Draft at PP Strong Ale Fest â€™05. Kinda dark copper pour. Fruity old-ale aroma. Malty flavors, some sweet caramel, fairly fruity still, and maybe a little musty.

column1: Back Street Magnus Magnus Old Ale
column5: 9th Annual San Diego Strong Ale Fest: Slightly amber with no head. Sweet fruity malt. Apricots. Big on the fruit. Malty flavors. Brown sugar and toffee. Light hop background. Creamy and full. Nice mouthfeel.

column1: Back Street Magnus Magnus Old Ale
column5: I also had it at pizza port in san clemente. Nutty and sweet, tastes a bit like cider and caramel. Full bodied, light carbonation, no head.

column1: Back Street Magnus Magnus Old Ale
column5: Sampled@Pizza Port San Clemente: Bourbon color with a wisp of tan head. Nose is sweet and malty with a little alcohol. Flavor is rich with some oak, a hint of whiskey and a light dry spicy finish. Smooth creamy palate.

column1: Back Street Magnus Magnus Old Ale
column5: draft Pizza Port San Clemente (BTW, â€™Back Streetâ€™ is Lampost Pizza in Ladera Ranch) itâ€™s a dirty brown color, dry flavor, but doesnâ€™t have anything notworthy

column1: Back Street Magnus Magnus Old Ale
column5: (Draft: Pizza Port in San Clemente, CA) Boy, I donâ€™t know, this old ale tastes pretty close to a mediocre Belgian Strong Ale to me. Spicy, moderately sweet, wheaty, slightly sour, and the alcohol is readily apparent. The nose is malty and earthy, but Iâ€™m also getting the mild, yet unmistakeable smell of vinegar throughout this tasting session, though itâ€™s not strong enough to ruin the overall nose. Medium in bodiy with a slightly sticky mouthfeel. Murky, ruddy brown color. Small light tan head fades away to nothing. Kind of an odd beer, and Iâ€™m not all that impressed. It is the $2 special at Pizza Port tonight, so maybe itâ€™s the same keg as they had at the Strong Ale Festival last month and they are trying to get rid of it.

column1: Back Street Magnus Magnus Old Ale
column5: Tasted at the 2004 Pizza Port Strong Ale Fest. Dark orange gold color. Small to medium head. Aroma is malty and sweet. A medium bodied Old Ale. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are slightly bitter and grapefruity. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

column1: Back Street Magnus Magnus Old Ale
column5: At the 2004 Strong Ale Festival. Golden pour with red tones. Nose of sweet hops, yeast, spice, mold? Kind of a medicinal flavor brew, but creamy and smooth, with a nice aftertaste.

column1: Deschutes Double Bale Quail Imperial IPA
column5: Deschutes Brewing Company--Double Bale Quail Ale Imperial IPA--Hopvine Bottle--2002 Release--12 oz. Bottle--10.00% ABV. (4.25 / 5.0) IPA--Imperial--Slightly hazy rich amber color. Light lace head. Thick aromatic pour. Malty floral hop front. Smooth thick sweet big caramel body overwhelms hops. Tangy hot rich hop balancing end. Imperial Barleywine IPA. Sampled 5/25/2003.

column1: Deschutes Double Bale Quail Imperial IPA
column5: San Diego Real Ale Festival - This was an interesting beer, I thought it was absolutely wonderful. This beer attacks your nose on several different levels as it does on your palate, which could be somewhat confusing. The hops are very aggressive and so is the yeastiness. This is one of those beers that is great right now, but will be even better in a year or two. This is a bit of a palate killer. I had to wait a few samples before I could really sample anything else, as the aggressive hops really did a number on my palate. who knew this recipe would go on to evolve in to so many later beers at the brewery. Lucky I got to try this one.

column1: Deschutes Double Bale Quail Imperial IPA
column5: 12 oz. bottle pours an amber reddish hue with a two finger white head. Has a sweet caramel and floral hop smell. Medium bodied with a light carbonation. The taste is a faintly sweet caramel which is quickly pushed aside by a tart, hop and alcohol bitterness. This brew tastes more like a Barleywine now than a Ipa . Not nearly as hoppy as it was two years ago when it was " fresh ". 2004

column1: Deschutes Double Bale Quail Imperial IPA
column5: Gold with a white head and small spots of lace. Fruity nose with some bitter hops. Grapefruit and floral as well. Bitter hop flavors with toasted biscuitus and some yeast. Really bitter finish with some fruits.

column1: Deschutes Double Bale Quail Imperial IPA
column5: Orangey-amber colour. Chewy aroma with hint of malt and a big fat chewy character. Rich, resiny hop body with plenty of crystal malts as well.

column1: Deschutes Double Bale Quail Imperial IPA
column5: Sampled bottled at Man Land, PortlandHazy blonde, no head, nose of bright cascades & other floral hops. I canâ€™t believe theyâ€™ve lived up this long! The flavor is nicely bitter & sweet, well aged with a hoppy finish. Yum!

column1: Deschutes Double Bale Quail Imperial IPA
column5: Pours a very clear amber with a big white head that falls fast. Aroma has a nice balance of sweet malts and big citrus hops. Taste is similar with big sweet caramel front thats desperately needed to combat the big wall of citrus hops to balance it out, and trailing with a big grapefruit finish. This very nicely hides the big alcohol making a nice big IIPA.

column1: Deschutes Double Bale Quail Imperial IPA
column5: Bottle pours a light caramel, somewhat cloudy, small fizzly white head, with sparce lacing. Â  Butterscotch nose... slight phenols along with a subtle trace of pine & hops. Â  Certainly smells sweeter than they did 2 years ago. Â  A sharp bite immediately up front, somewhat thick, sweet, with a nice malty finish. Â  Not as harsh with the bitterness as it was when it first came out. Â  Body and mouthfeel are medium to full. Â  Seems to have held up fairly well. Â  Some slight lingering alcohol and apple skin. &nbsp Not bad!

column1: Deschutes Double Bale Quail Imperial IPA
column5: â€™02 bottle at perkeoâ€™s gathering. surprisingly hadnâ€™t lost much of its hop profile over 2 years. pine and lychee aroma. plenty of fruit, some apple turnover, not that bitter but quite mellow and tasty

column1: Deschutes Double Bale Quail Imperial IPA
column5: Appearance: a dark, plummish brown color, and a slight, but solid cream-colored head. "Imperial" IPA, that doubles as a barleywine, eh? Obviously the Imperialism reflects high alcohol, and that alone should catapult it into barleywine status, if Iâ€™m following their thoughts. With this strength, this hoppiness, and this flavor, it does! Aroma: Fantastic! A buzzing hornetâ€™s nest of hoppiness! Every kind of fruit is set ablaze and swolders away in this astounding nose. Dark cherries, berries, grapes, more, unfolding, showing more alcohol, resembling port wine, dark and leathery, fierce, peppery, stinging, occupying every sense orifice, and becoming akin to taking a deep inhalation of cognac. Hops dominate the mouth on first sip, slowly commanding the senses. Alcohol pretty much takes control, and steers the outcome of every consumption from here on in. Malt does itâ€™s part, too, but the hops, and the booze, never stop! Iâ€™m spinning already, under this influence! Perfectly tasty, lip-smacking texture! Very sweet, delicious, full-flavored! Under more ideal circumstances, controlled laboratory tests, perhaps a more thoughtful or scientific discernment might result, but, alas, this was not my first taste of brew of the night, and I feel like Iâ€™m getting a triple whammy out of this bad boy! A small 12 0z. bottle, but a well-affected, and remembered, experience. As tasty as I like my barleywines, much stronger than my favorite IPAs, oh, so over the top, but exquisitely created! Good job, Deschutes, keep it up!
Pours a murky golden brown color with aroma of wheat, banana, and clove. Sweet flavor with banana, clove, wheat, and caramel. Nice beer.
Draft. Hazy deep golden amber color. Aroma of caramel. Taste is tiasted biscuit. OK.

May 2014 on draft. Red brown pour with an ok head and lacing, nothing notable. Aroma of bananas and some cloves, faint roast. Flavors followed with caramel more prominent. Mouthfeel moderate for the style. Not that outstanding, not bad.

Draft at ABC Gettysburg-Gateway brewpub, served in a pint glass. Clear brown color with off-white head. Aroma of wheat malt, faint caramel, some banana and clove. Taste adds notes of fruity yeast and light chocolate. Light body, moderate carbonation, slightly syrupy with light sweet finish. Overall a nice weizenbock IMHO.
A strong banana aroma and taste which I did not like. A smooth texture and medium body but the banana taste was too overwhelming.
A big EH! A lot of people say you can taste banana. Not the best smell. Overall a decent (at best) beer.

Bomber from a trade with jdb288. Dark brown and opaque (after the bottle being rolled.) A beige head is decent. I smell rich sweet malts and berries. The feel is somewhat syrupy. Rich malts are tasted and dominate. Some chocolate that is syrupy. Earth and fruit. There is some bread and a hint of spice. Th syrupy chocolate dominates with fruit in the background and few this and thats. Not great.

Draft at Camp Hill location. Ruby red/orange color with a finger width white head. Nice lacing down the mug. Aroma is primarily caramel with some cereal. Medium body, more the caramel in the taste with some light hops. Sweet finish. Don't notice the 7+ ABV. One of my favorite beers at ABC. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at the brewpub in Gettysburg. Pours hazy medium brown with a thin fizzy off white head. Tastes like malt, cereal, light spice, and a hint of citrus. Light body and low/medium carbonation. Smells like malt, musk, and light alcohol.

Tap at Gettysburg brewpub. Pours clear amber/copper with fizzy off-white head. Aroma is cereal and cookie malts, orange peel and other citrus notes, floral hops, and faint spice. Flavor is chewy bready malts, sweet fruit esters, and light alcohol notes; semisweet finish that gradually dries out. Medium body and carbonation.

guess what... itâ€™s red. Nose is malty, roasted caramel, flowery hops. Flavor is clean neutral roasted caramel, nuts, and a touch of almond extract. Light body and dry finish. lightly bitter. not special. clean but bland.

Pint on tap. Clear copper with a small ring of cream. Mild aroma of toffee, toast, citrus and dry grass. Taste is mild toffee and a hint of citrus and toast, with a grassy-wooden hop bite on the finish. Light-medium body has medium-high carbonation and is pretty well balanced.

Draft @ Hickory Hops 2011, Hickory, NC. Pours a reddish amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy aroma with hints of caramel. Fruity malty weak hoppy flavor with hints of caramel. Has a fruity malty hoppy finish.
Sampled at the 13th Annual Knoxville Brewerâ€™s Jam. Red-brown, off white head. Aroma is caramel, some hops. Taste is grassy, spicy hops, caramel, little else.
Sampled at the Knoxville Brewerâ€™s Jam. Poured a deep brown with a two finger off white head. Aroma of roasted malt. Flavor is caramel with a dry hoppy finish.

Sampled at the 2008 Knoxville Brewersâ€™ Jam. Brown in the glass with a frothy off-white head that leaves light lace. Light aroma of roasty malts. The flavor finds caramel malts with a slight hop background. Light body and bittersweet.
KBjam. Nice rich amber pour with white head and lace. Aroma of medium roasted malt and light hops. Flavor of semi sweet malt and a complimentary pleasant bitter finish. A pretty easy drinking amber.

Draught. Pours red with a small head. The aroma is malty with hints of biscuits, crackers, caramel, yeah this is definitely malt heavy. The flavor is only mildly bitter with little hop essence imparted. Biscuits, toffee, and the faintest of coffee is suggested. Indian Head Red is a straight-forward malty red ale.

On tap at Mellow Mushroom Asheville on 9/21/2007. Pours a reddish amber with no head and a little lace. Nose is slightly hoppy, good malt balance--pleasent enough. This is very traditional amber with nicely balanced malts and hops. No flaws noted and alcohol well hidden. I tend to like Catawba Valleys hoppier beers better.

Draft sample at Knoxville Brew Jam. Poured a clear amber color with an average frothy white head that mostly diminished with fair lacing. Moderate toasted malt aroma. Medium body with a slick texture. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bitter finish of short duration. Flavorful pale ale.

2 month old can A: Deep dark brown color with a short fast falling tan head. S: Chocolate, molasses and faint leafy hops. T: Spicy bitterness with some bark and roast. Fairly dry with only mild sweetness. M: Light and clean. Prickly carbonation plays well with the peppery flavor. O: Pretty tasty with some interesting aspects. I like it.
Dark brown color poured with a tan head. The aroma is roasted malt with notes of cocoa and caramel. It also has a slight burnt sense. The taste is sweet upfront.

This is a backlog rating fromÂ 2014 on draft, fromÂ notes.Â When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time, work and/or family. Words to describe this beer are mild roasted malts, chocolate, earthy, nutty, decent brown ale.

Smell is medium roasted malt with some coffee...taste is smooth, roasted malt but not bitter...light coffee...pretty straightforward....had at polliwogs for women's world cup 2019 USA vs France 2-0 now!

355 ml. can. 211-18. Dark furniture brown going to black, small mocha head. Nose is stale chicory coffee, bay leaf, herbal spices, touch liquorice, herbal coffee & stale coffee grounds, old pantry. Taste is herbal coffee, chicory, bay leaf, low mocha, old chocolate, almost touch BE, dash liquorice,â€¦ Low grainy, chicory & liquorice body. Sweetness is what one wants in a brown ale in general I think and some dullness, not these old kitchen spices with bitterness, chicory coffee & old pantry tasty. Finish is lingering stale cheap coffee grounds. Not where it should be I think.

Bottle @ Malt & Mold sampling. Pours faintly murky brown with small foamy beige head, faint caramel aroma, medium carbonation, medium bitter roasted malt taste, thin smooth body, long bitter finish. Very good.
