column4: TvÃ¥ Bryggare / Ã–sterlenbryggarna / Bryggeriet i Ystad
column5: Clear golden color with a fine white head. Ok lacing. Deep malty and some butter notes in the aroma. Ok body. Tad sweet and a moderate bitterness. Caramel malty, mild butter and herbal hoppy flavor. No intension of trying this again. [Bottle at Skolgatans Ã–lcafe in MalmÃ¶, Sweden]

column4: TvÃ¥ Bryggare / Ã–sterlenbryggarna / Bryggeriet i Ystad
column5: At the old brewpub in Ystad. Golden, low head. Light honeyish nose Good malt base, light honey, mellow chewy body sparkly mouthfeel, fitting grassy counterpoint, light salt. Moreish in the end

column4: TvÃ¥ Bryggare / Ã–sterlenbryggarna / Bryggeriet i Ystad
column5: @ Havregatan. Flaska frÃ¥n Systembolaget (24:-). Maltig med karamelltoner, grÃ¤s, smÃ¶r, medelbesk och medelfyllig. Avslutningen Ã¤r torr och besk med grÃ¤stoner. En hyfsad lager.

column4: TvÃ¥ Bryggare / Ã–sterlenbryggarna / Bryggeriet i Ystad
column5: Bottle from Systembolaget, e-order in March 2014. (rating 4000) Clear golden with a small fluffy white head. Aroma of grass, some bread, caramel and light notes of butter. Similar taste. Nothing to write home about but at least a drinkable one from TvÃ¥ Bryggare.

column4: TvÃ¥ Bryggare / Ã–sterlenbryggarna / Bryggeriet i Ystad
column5: Draught at MalmÃ¶ Ã–l & Whisky Festival. Clear golden coloured with a small white head. Malty aroma of berries, caramel and butter. Malty flavour of berries, caramel and hops. Hoppy finish.

column4: TvÃ¥ Bryggare / Ã–sterlenbryggarna / Bryggeriet i Ystad
column5: From tap. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is grassy and herbal, straw. Bitter, herbal, grassy and mild citrusy. Dry, bitter and herbal finish.

column4: TvÃ¥ Bryggare / Ã–sterlenbryggarna / Bryggeriet i Ystad
column5: Bottle. Cloudy and boring to look at. IÂ´ve seen more action in fruit juice, than in this beer. With only a few bubbles this beer is as dull as Bush, and IÂ´m not referring to the beer! Aroma is...not bad, but really not very interesting either. Mouthfeel is acceptable, but the tart aftertaste doesnÂ´t get me at all, and I usually get quite a kick of out beer with some sourness in them. I expected more out of this beer, particularly knowing what other swedish microbreweries are able to deliver. Maybe this requires 5-10 bottles in a row, before IÂ´ll grow into it, but thatÂ´s not likely to happen.

column4: TvÃ¥ Bryggare / Ã–sterlenbryggarna / Bryggeriet i Ystad
column5: A hazy yellow beer with a huge white head. The aroma is sweet brewmashy combined with slight hints of hops. The flavor is lemony and hoppy with a slight touch of malt, and a dry lemony end. Somewhat like drinking lemonade.

Light golden blond coloured beer with average carbonation and a medium white head. Rather sweet hoppy aroma with light grainy touches. medium palate. Finish is light watttery, sweet grainy hints. Rather typical low-alcohol brew. Nothing special
Pale yellow color. Light vanilla aroma. Watery, dry, with a quite strong bitterness (but maybe too long infusion).
clear golden colour, almost no foam, few hops with notes of paperboard, sweet, medium-bodied, dry and very unpleasant finish - almost drinkable
Sampled at the brewpub . A nice brew. Pretty sweet and citrus. Probably an appropriate mixing given their location but I was hoping for a bit more.

Horrid acidic tropical fruit aroma. Taste of papaya, and water, over hopped, with a gnarly bitterness that sits in the back of your throat like a retch. No body, no bubbles, yet served with a huge detergent like head.
Light golden pils with a thick creamy white head. Wet dough aroma. In mouth, light bodid, with a light biscuitty malt and a bit too much herbal hops. Unbalanced. Not overly bad. On tap May 2006.
Over-carbed, just like the ''Negra''. Unusual tutti-frutti aroma. Over hopped with cascades, but still had a nice biscuity malt flavour and a decent body.
Dark black beer with a lacing thick moka head. Light sulfuric dough aroma. In moputh, light chocolate with roasted coffee notes, and light bodied. The best of the 3 offerings. On tap May 2006.

Okay, firstly this is not negra (black) by any stretch of the imagination. The brewer uses 10% roast malt, to create something barely even pale amber in colour. I think he should think about giving it a name change. Secondly, it was really poorly presented, over carbed in a huge way, it was about 25% head, despite his rather elaborate 2 mug and spatula pouring technique. However, all that aside, it tasted really nice, heaps of caramel malt flavours, smokey and toasty with a nice hop balance.

Dark mahogany with no head, this beer was poured very poorly by a young slip of a lass in a pub in Hammersmith, London on Boxing day evening 2006. Christmas cake/pudding spices attacked my nose, along with sweet malts, very interesting. The aroma carried on into the taste, a thicker mouthfeel than I was expecting from a mild, almost rich. A very nice mild, one I will have again if our paths cross.
Mild bitterness, good fruits, full of taste and almost a full bodied real ale.

Cask (handpump) @ The Lord Moon Of The Mall, Whitehall, Greater London, England SW1A 2DY . Clear medium to dark red brown color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, dark berry, raisin. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20081229]

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Dark red brown with a small beige head. Very little aroma I could perceive beyond a touch of pencil shavings. Taste was delicious: sweet liquorice, nuts and and spiced fruits. A little bitterness. Very nice.
Cask (JDW Pub in London) - Dark brown with red tings. Fruity aroma with malt and raisins. Fruity taste with a sweet and hoppy element with raisins, toffee and some spicy malt notes.
cask at the JDW edinburgh ... deep brown ... sweet light chocolate malts nose... lovely woody chocolate... soft mellow fruits in background... little creamy and caramel

A Mes rate. Gravicask at the Bree Louise. Dark copper with a good beige head. Strong bready malt aroma with a hint of coca cola. Similar flavour with hints of nuts and caramel in the finish. A little better than I expected to be honest.
Handpulled cask at Baker St. Spoons. Red/brown with off white head. Malty with caramel and a dusty hop finish. Nothing special.

[Cask at the Old Manor (JDW), Bracknell.] Tawny brown with a ruby tint and a dense cream head; caramel and treacle aroma; smooth caramel body, rather dry to start, then some roast hazelnuts come through before a warming sweet tracel finish. A very pleasing winter ale.
Fruity malts, backed with some nuttyness and floural hops. Taste is similar, toast coming through sort of missing a bit of character for this % of ale, and not really what id call a mild.

The celtic design on the bottle looked great, but as soon as I opened the bottle and this murky orange stuff spewed forth I reduced my expectations. Over carbonated, rather grim aroma, of bland hops and hessian sacks. Cidery flavour dissappears quickly, in a flurry of bubbles, leaving a minimal sweet aftertaste.

Lightly hazed cider, bubbly and sweet. In mouth, tastes like Allenâ€™s Nectar (our own Quebec soft drink, a fizzy apple juice), a bit too sweet and overcarbonated. Aroma improves as cider warms up, with nice malic notes, like green apples. On tap, May 2006.
Clear, full apple flavour, mildly sweet, low carbonation. No unwelcome fermentation flavours, could be a little drier though.

1/5/2019. Bottle bought at Buenos Aires Airport. 5%. Pours clear palish gold with a short lasting white head. Aroma of sweet malt, toffee, butter and hops. Medium plus sweetness, light bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation. Sweet, hoppy, slightly toasted and heavy buttery finish.
Bottled brought from Argentina. I think that I got a bad one. Like all others in serie that my mom brought to me. No comments..

Draught at the brewpub, a hazy bright yellow gold with a thick foamy head. A lemony citrus hop aroma. A very clean hoppy palate, not too bitter and not too crisp. Lemon again in the flavour with grainy malt characaters.

Bottled, thanks Fukito! Pale golden, rich head. Grassy, buttery nose. Medium sweet and medium bodied. Solidly malty, yet with soft mouthfeel. Lightly buttery and fairly hoppy, finishes with good bitterness. A well made rounded hoppy lager beer.

Drank this one at Cerveceria Blest in Bariloche. Apart from this being an awesome location, the beer is excellent. It is called Rubia overthere and is one of the better pilseners I know. Rather bitter but very pleasing.

Hazy golden body with a thin, diminishing white head. Some mild Saaz hop aroma with nice earthy bitterness and plenty of biscuity malt to provide sweetness. Light tropical fruit as well. Some bandaid type aromas that definitely seems off, but luckily itâ€™s not too strong. The body is light and crisp on the tongue, relatively satisfying. The flavor is mostly sweet with the malt and fruitiness really coming out. The hops are evident, but not too strong and certainly donâ€™t provide enough bitterness for the style. OK, and not exactly good.
Blonde pils with a thin lacing white head. Light caramel aroma, with berry notes. Nice crisp malt in mouth, smooth, lightly hopped. Not bad and very fresh. On tap, May 2006.

On draught at Pilgrim Bar. A hazy straw color with slight head and noticable diacetyl aroma and flavor. Light/medium body with slight early hop bitterness, mellow light malt flavor and citrusy character. Could be a victim of poor handling in distribution. A "pilsner"?

Bottle - July 2005 Pours lively golden with a not so-long lasting white head. The colour is beatifull, although not "cristal clear" enough for a pilsner. Aroma is dry and malty, right online with the style. Taste is bitter, but somewhat sweet, gentle, pleasant. I donÂ´t know why the other ratings where so low, i really like pilsners and i found this one to be smooth. I could sense some slightly sulphur, but not enough to say "rotten egs"

A strange liquid. Bad named like a Pilsen style . Brewed from the wrong hop for a pilsen (Cascade!!!.) Very fruity, cloudy smell bad (rotten eggs). Another waste of time in Argentina Breweries. I dont try the others styles

0,355l bottle, courtesy of Karol, many thanks, Pours clear dark brown liquid, small creamy tan head, Aroma: sweet, gingerbread, caramel, cookie, chocolate, Taste: light to medium sweet, light bitter, light to medium sour, caramel malty, roasty, Palate: light to medium body, average carbonation slick mouthfeel, long caramel aftertaste, Overall: fine.

30/12/2018. Draft at James Beer, Puerto Madryn. Pours copper brown with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of fruit, veg, toffee, molasses and light toasting. Moderate sweetness and medium bitterness. Medium body, oily texture, average carbonation.

Smell has a bit of a roasted barley but the taste only follows through a little bit. There is a little sourness, but not as much as somedarker beers around Bariloche. This oneâ€™s not bad, just average. Had a bottle from the store in Bariloche.
Draught at the brewpub, dark brown with a tan foamy head. Light roasted malt aroma. A very nice roasted malt palate with coffee flavour in abundance. Nicely done.

Bottle at Cossab, BsAs - Sadly this bottle had some infection but I could still taste the good rich chocolatey body underneath with some sweetness and a long, malty, cocoa-laced finish. Not as good as it could have been but certainly has potential.

Drank this one at Cerveceria Blest in Bariloche. Apart from this being an awesome location, the beer is excellent. This negra (as it is called there) is a very rewarding beer, not sweet, good body, and refreshing.

Dark burgundy with a thin, tan head. The aroma is malty and sweet, full of brown sugar, caramel and a light fruitiness. The nose on this is really nice. Fairly full body with nice development on the tongue. The flavor is on the sweet side, but not inherently sweet on its own. Nice malts and a hint of bitterness at the finish. Easily the best beer from this brewery, at least in my experience.

Bottled, thanks Fukito! Dark mahogany with firm off-white head. Aroma mostly of caramelized sugar. Fairly sweet with evident caramel flavour. Medium bodied with soft mouthfeel. Thankfully the flavour of crystalized sugar does not carry over into sticky sweetness, so the beer reminds gentle and drinkable. Mildly herbal finish.

Hazy reddish brown ale with a thin off white head. Caramel aroma, with nice walnuts notes. Bery nice nutty malt in mouth, with roasted coffee notes, veering on a brown ale. Quite good. Medium bodied. On tap, May 2006.

Mahogany brown color. Big off-white frothy head with a lacing that sticks to the walls. Malty aroma of wet wood, smokey and very smoothly alcoholic. Initially acid with a strong grain coffee taste, smooth butterscotch hints. Light to medium body, creamy texture. Thanks to Lubiere for this one Bottle shared with Panzerfaust and Nigredo

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Nice roasted barley on the nose and good dark black brown body and brown head. Good flavour of dark chocolate and coffee, some cake. Nice mouthfeel good balance. Very fine indeed.

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: While vacationing on PEI I went to the Gahan House in Charlottetown where I had this on tap. It poured nearly opaque black with brown highlights with a small spritz of tan head, that quickly dissipates, leaving behind some lacing. Aroma: coffee, chocolate. Flavor: the above with molasses, smoke, oatmeal/lactose (creamy finish). Mouthfeel: medium-bodied. Drinks above its ABV.

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Bottle. Dark brown/black colour with tan head. Chocolate malts, roasted coffee, rich flavour. Could have had a smoother mouthfeel for an oatmeal stout but otherwise quite good

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Appearance: Basically black, nice tan head. Aroma: Dark malt, perfume, some coffee notes, roasted. Taste: Coffee, dark malt, roasted. Bought: Trade with jtclockwork - thanks!, 500 ml Info: 9/11-2016

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: 2016/09/14 - Pours black with a frothy, khaki head that slowly reduces and leaves minimal patchy lacing. Aroma is roasted coffee, smoky notes, light chocolate, toasted cereal and a hint of licorice. Taste is lots of toasted bread with some coffee roast and hints of semi sweet chocolate. Mouthfeel is light to medium and silky with smooth carbonation and a moderately dry, bittersweet finish. Not too shabby. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Draft at the brewery. Black body, small brown head. Aroma toasted, but not burnt. Some spices. The taste is chocolate and coffee. A bit watery but good!

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: On tap at the brewer pub in Halifax. This is a very dark and rich stout with loads of dark roasted malts, a touch of char, and more smoke. The Smokey/burnt aspects, however, are not overdone, instead working well with over flavors of the dark grain load. Medium body with light carbonation.

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Bottle. Dark chocolate and roasted coffee aroma. Pours black with a small brown head. Dark chocolate and coffee flavours. Creamy texture. Nicely balanced finish with a touch of bitterness. Good stout.

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: 500ml bottle bought by parents in pei and shared with father in law. Aroma: caramel, chocolate, coffee that burned on the bottom of the coffee pot. App: pitch black with medium frothy moka head and some good lacing. Taste and palate: full body, creamy, mineral and bitter finish. Overall: that mineral feeling is quite unpleasant, same for the burned coffee. Glad I shared it. Maybe still too cold too.

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Nostalgia and bias are ringing true here. Iâ€™m from PEI and have always stated (but apparently have never rated) that this is my favourite beer of all time. Now on to the rating. 500 ml bottle poured at home. Pours black with a tan head that dies quickly. Smells like smoke and a touch of coffee. Tastes like the same: smoke and coffee. While my opinion of this beer has changed over time slightly (more smoke, less coffee than my first impressions), I still love it.

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: On tap at Gahan House. Pours a clear gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges slowly and laces. Aroma has grass and straw notes with grain backing. Flavor has lots of grass supported by sweet grains and straw.

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Canette de 473 ml achetÃ©e chez ANBL (Caraquet, N-B) au coÃ»t de 3,40$. ArÃ´me: LÃ©gÃ¨re odeur de cÃ©rÃ©ales avec une pointe de caramel. Apparence: La couleur est dorÃ©e avec une faible densitÃ© de bulle. PrÃ©sence dâ€™un mince col mousseux et dâ€™une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: GoÃ»t de cÃ©rÃ©ales avec une pointe de caramel fruitÃ©. DurÃ©e moyenne de lâ€™arriÃ¨re goÃ»t. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture lÃ©gÃ¨rement minÃ©rale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. ArriÃ¨re goÃ»t lÃ©gÃ¨rement fruitÃ©. (Rating #6615)

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: On tap at Gahan - on tap at Gahan - deep gold appearance, has a salty aroma and a buttery taste. Drinkable but nothing special.

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Probably one of Gahanâ€™s better light beers and even a good lager in its own right. Pours a bubbly gold with a small head. Aroma is of cereal, spice, and tropical hops. Tastes of cereal, caramel, herbs, and lemon. Has a light body with high carbonation that is tingly to the tongue. This is a very good refreshing lager. Earlier Rating: 5/22/2014 Total Score: 1.7 A pretty watery brew. Smells of light hay and cereal. The taste is a vague cereal hay combo, with a touch of spice. Has a light sweet body, with a watery mouth feel. I do not notice any hops in this, perhaps to subtle. One of the least popular of their offerings now doubt

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Wayyyyyyyy better than all of their other light beers. A really nice, clean and actually golden colour with a thin white head. Smells is pretty fine, sweet corn, tropical fruits and sweet floral hops, some buttery smells too. Taste is a bit vinous, sweet with some of those buttery notes and some tropical, mellow hops. Sort of a cloying sweetness and oily feel for a lager and something not off but odd about the taste. I would have pegged this as a summer session brew instead. Much better than all of the goofy fruit beers they have been doing. Earlier Rating: 5/26/2014 Total Score: 1.8 Just stop. Please. Is there not enough similar beers from this brewery? I donâ€™t see the need. Make one of the similar beers decent and move on. Itâ€™s watery, light cereal and hay flavours with a hop-be-gone spell cast upon it. It looks better than it tastes.

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Orange golden pour with a very thin lace. Sweet honey flavour. Very thin body. Lacking in character. Earlier Rating: 7/8/2011 Total Score: 2.6 Hazy golden yellow with a thin white lace. Slight citrus aroma. Hints of citrus and malt flavour. Bitter finish.

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Draft at the source. Light clear golden color. Aroma of fresh hay. Taste is white pepper and straw. OK.

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: On tap at The Gahan House as part of the sampler. Pours a clear medium golden color with a smallish white head. Aromas of light sweet bready malt with hints of citrus hop. British yeasty esters and a hint of toffee. Flavor follows the aroma. Decent pale ale, I could drink these.

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: pinte de 500ml de blonde. arome de banane et de cÃ©rÃ©ales. au gout on retrouve des notes de banane au dÃ©but et par le suite de cÃ©rÃ©ale. biÃ¨re plutÃ´t sec

column4: Prince Edward Island Brewing Company (The Gahan House)
column5: Pint draft @ Gahan. Deep, clear gold, moderate white head. Grainy aroma. Taste is not much to start, then big cereal, with a mild bitterness on the finish. Body was a little watery. Overall, I feel like Iâ€™ve been bait-and-switched a little. Name is "Harvest" but it seems to not be seasonal. It is called a pale ale in the description but it is clearly not an EPA or APA. For a blonde or golden it was decent; I kind of like grainy tasting lighter beers and the finish worked, but I feel like this needs to be rebranded.

Strong taste of alcohol. Not as good as the Negra extra in my opinion. A sweet taste that stays with you all the way through. Sweet and a little bit sour at the leave. Had on tap at the Bolson beer garden in El Bolson town center.
Bottled. A dark brown beer with a beige head. Aroma is sweet , roasted and coffee. Taste is malty and sweet, notes of brown sugar and caramel. Not as full body as I would expect for a doppelbock.
Bottled. brown to Black, no head. Sweet caramel with coffee aroma. The malty caramel is hiding the alcohol well othervise is the taste strangeand is definetly lacking some bitterness.
Poured a hazy brown color with a beige head. The aroma is of tart coffee, plums, butterscotch and alcohol. The flavor is tart with plums, figs and cola.

Bottle shared by maxxdaddy. Brown cloudy appearance. Aroma is loaded with cold coffee, dark toasted grain and a bit of chocolate. Strange buttery/butterscotch aroma that comes and goes depending on whether you swirl or not. Flavour is slightly sour but it has an unusual sweetness with lots of coffeeish character. A bit of brown sugar and molasses, but again, a vegetal cold coffee flavour. Itâ€™s not great, but itâ€™s a hell of a lot better than itâ€™s paler brother.

Super toasty aroma, like really toast, more than any beer Iâ€™ve other had. When you swirl this you get a bit of sourness that probably shouldnâ€™t be there. An odd sweetness/sourness in the flavor, behind some espresso and more toast. A little off and odd, though the aroma is quite good. Could be better if it wasnâ€™t likely infected.

Bottle in Buenos Aires in December 2007. A dark brown to black color with a brown head. A wonderfully robust aroma with bitter chocolate, molasseses, and caramel. Sweet bitter chocolate flavors with a smooth and rich body and a great finish.

Draught at El Regional in Sam Martin los de Andes, a cloudy dark brown with a large beige head. A strong malty aroma with plenty of alcohol. An earthy malt flavour at first, then a sweeter alcohol with berry notes. The finish is more sour. Very good.

Bottle - Novmber 2006. Pours a black color with a thin beige head that rapidly disipates. Aroma is caramelly and buttery. Taste is buttery, chalky, rahter sweet and very slightly acid. Mouthfeel is medium to thin.

Deep black with a thick moka head, Chocolate and figs in aroma, with light roasted coffee beans notes. Sweet chocolate taste, light coffee, liight alcohol warmth, medium bodied, Excellent with the Argentine Edam. Bought at Todo, Bariloche, 4.59$AR. May 2006.

Cask, Leicester Fest â€™08 (Thurs afternoon session). The 4th highest rated on the bill. Not that I make obsessive lists of such things. Lacy beige on pitch, tinted with ruby. Scorched leather, heady grain, burnt xmas pudding. Canâ€™t see how this can be listed as anything other than a Stout. Cocoa and Marmite touches, a bit too much alcohol. Smoky, smooth, powerful, and a bit fruity. Dry, roasty and attenuated, but nothing special.

Sampled from cask (gravity dispense) at 6th Chelmsford Winter Beer Festival 2005. Pitch black, small head. Mostly sweet mild malty aroma with chocolate tones. Roasted malt and dry hop in the flavor. Coffee notes and a good long burned finish. I like it.

Newby Wyke tends to concentrate on pale coloured ales but this beer certainly shows they can make damn fine dark stuff as well. OK, itâ€™s one of those beers that hovers between styles, as others have observed, but letâ€™s not worry about that. Very deep colour - almost black, although thereâ€™s a hint of brown when held up to the light. The emphasis is on espresso coffee, dark chocolate and licorice. Coffee certainly dominates the aroma, but the other elements come into play more in the flavour. Roasted malt and some dry bitterness provide good balance. The consistency is slightly oily. And thereâ€™s enough alcohol to provide a bit of a kick. If thereâ€™s any criticism itâ€™s that the flavours fall away slightly on the finish and the mouthfeel is not the biggest, but those are just minor quibbles. A very good beer as long as you donâ€™t approach it expecting a rich stout. Cask (gravity dispense), Chelmsford Winter Beer Festival.

Cask at Chelmsford Winter BeerEx. Gravity in good condition. Black with white head. Lives up to its name, this is like a black hole. Not sure if this is a porter more like an old ale but very good all the same, similar to Dark Star which I had after this.

Cask Conditioned, at the Market Porter, Borough, London . Black with a speckled brown head. Thin looking but as you approached the generous aroma was undeniable. Rich, dry, dark chocolate aroma and flavour. Nothing opulent about this one, just shear honest passion for beer. Another lovely beer from Wykes, although at the time of consumption I didnâ€™t know either of the beers were Wykes.

This is as dark as the depths of the ocean. To be honest I'm not sure if this is a porter or stout. I stand corrected if I'm wrong. Anyhow - this is a hell of a smooth chocolate and coffee tasting beer. The light bitterness suits it perfectly. VERY smooth. Mmmm.
Cask Handpump at the Star Inn, Huddersfield 26/07/2003 Golden coloured and hoppy with some citrus aroma. Lasting finish.

Dark amber with a small beige head. Aromas are gooseberry, spicy hops, yeast and fruit. Flavours consist of pear, light toffee malts with a dry, bitter, spicy finish. I get a lot of pear in this beer. Pear...
Cask Handpump at Wilkieâ€™s Tavern, Warrington 18/07/2004 Black stout which is smooth on the palate. Slightly dry pleasant roast malt finish.

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London. Dark brown with a thin tan head. Unexpectedly lovely. More like an old style, Dave suggests its actually a porter despite the pub-clips claim to being a stout. F-ing lovely in any case.

Very dark, with smoky & chocolatey hints. More bitterness than many stouts. Dry finish. Very drinkable. Unfortunately, the brewery seems to have gone bust for the umpteenth time and, whilst the beers may still be available, they are brewed by Blackpool brewery. Draught on handpump, The Speaker, London SW1, March 2003
pitch black with thick white head. nitrogenated. firm bitterness from roasted malt. some fruitiness from the esters. no real hop flavor. very nice version of the style

On tap at the brewery pours black with tan head. Aroma is mainly malt and coffee. Medium mouthfeel. Flavor is dark roasted malts, with a touch of coffee and finishes dry. This is an easy drinking stout and Iâ€™m glad this one makes it tap often.

On tap at GLBC. Darkest brown/black pour with a huge creamy tan head. Dry malt and coffee aroma that is faint at first (frigginâ€™ nitros!), but comes out more as the beer warms. Creamy malty flavor up front with a bitter coffee finish. Flavor is also more pronounced as the beer warms. Pretty darn good for a nitro stout.

On draft at the brewpub. To me, this is about as fine an example of a dry stout as one can expect. I believe this is my first 5 for appearance. It was just so sumptuous looking - opaque, thick, oily, with a perfect inch of cafe au lait head sitting contentedly on top of the brew. Strong but not overpowering roasted barley in the nose. And the taste lasted forever, with the roasts coming in initially but rounded by a nicely complex malt flavor, thick and chewy oatmeal, and a superbly creamy mouthfeel. Truly enjoyable.

Date: 07/23/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub black, thin fine beige head, dry roasted malt aroma, creamy oily oatmeal body, lots of roasted flavor, well tempered bitterness considering the amount of roasted malts, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **/4

On tap at the brewery. Always worth the trip. The pour is a deep black with a nearly white frothy head. Looks much like a Guiness. The aroma is of deep roasted malts with a hint of sweat coffee. The flavor is not at all like a Guiness, the malts are stronger and the flavor of coffee is fairly pronounced though out the tasting. The finish is quickly, but the malt leaves a bit of an aftertaste. Very good stout. Very good.
on Tap @ GLBC, black beer, looks like guinness, tastes a hell of a lot better... nice smooth mouthfeel perfect for a dry stout, roasty flavors that was great. Really enjoyed trying this one

Black pour, great almond nitro head. Roasted malts in the aroma. Flavors are roasted malts all the way, chocolate, some coffee, almost smokiness to it, maybe some oats in the silky mouthfeel. Dry but not too dry because of the great mouthfeel form the nitro and even lightly hopped. This beer was perfect for itâ€™s style.
Served with nitrogen. Black with a tan head. Aroma and flavor both have a roast coffee presence, along with dark chocolate. Dry finish.

This beer is very black with a very nice tan head. The aroma and taste have a lot of roast, and a bit of chocolate coffe in them. The body is thicker than the other stouts GLBC makes, and the finish is a nice lasting bitter flavor. But overall I think it is the weakest of the GLBC stouts. Also the alcohol content is lower than expected.

Specially brewed by Ales of Kent for the Macknade Farm shop near Faversham. The Macknade shop is a good outlet for the craft brewers of Kent. This is a pale gold bitter with a short lived and sizzling head. A fluffy malt body like bread dough with a nice tangerine tang.
Bottle in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso. regular african lager, just good because of the eat and lak of better beers
Light and regular international styled lager. Sold everywhere in Burkina Faso, so really the national beer. Just a regular lager, costs about 0.7 USD for a 65 cl bottle.

5/II/17 - 65cl bottle @ Brugs Bierfestival - BB: n/a (2017-153) Thanks to bartlebier for sharing the bottle! Clear pale blond beer, small irregular off-white head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: lots and lots of marijuana, weed, then dirty, grains, wet cardboard. MF: soft carbon, medium to light body. Taste: very malty, grains, bit sweet, car board, sourish. Aftertaste: grains, bit dirty, grassy bitterness.
Thnx to Bartlebier. Pours clear blonde, small white head. Smell is intense, sweet, chemical maltyness. Taste is malty, sweet, aromatic. Lager yeast. OK, bit chemical.

65cl by postcolonial supplier idiosynkrafrasie shared at Brugs BF 2017 - ZO. - Remains a drinkable pale adjunct lager despite its swollen body of sweaty cereals and aroma of sun-drenched mud puddle and cardboard...fruity green apple drinkable as "ale" character instead of DMS. Fancied the label!

Thank you for sharing Bartlebier! 650 ml. bottle sampled @ Bruges Beer Festival 2017. 100 % clear golden, industrial lager white head. Nose is pure vegetables in the worst fashion, DMS, just pure awful cooked vegetables. Taste is sparkling, thin, watery, overly metallic, awfully mineral tasting with cooked vegetables. Thin, metallic, watery. Rubbish. Burkina Faso appears to be another poor country where the beer scene is dominated by a western industrial brewery churning out garbage. Indicative of many other things for sure.

VOIR BRAKINA - BIERE DU BURKINA Ã€ 4.2%. Bouteille 65cl. Ouagadougou. Disons le tout de suite...cette biÃ¨re est semblables Ã  nos produits MolBat canadiens. Mais elle est bien faite, froide, sans faille majeure. Et il fait 38 degrÃ©s. Soleil. Chaud. Je suis au Burkina. Pas un gros score mais si on tiens compte des circonstances, câ€™est un 3.2 lol. Jaune paille, mousse blanche. ArÃ´mes de mais, cÃ©rÃ©ales. En bouche, assez mince, leger houblon discret, sans amertume rÃ©elle. Se boit comme de lâ€™eau Ã  38 degrÃ©s. Earlier Rating: 11/27/2016 Total Score: 2.3 Bouteille 65cl. Ouagadougou. Disons le tout de suite...cette biÃ¨re est semblables Ã  nos produits MolBat canadiens. Mais elle est bien faite, froide, sans faille majeure. Et il fait 38 degrÃ©s. Soleil. Chaud. Je suis au Burkina. Pas un gros score mais si on tiens compte des circonstances, câ€™est un 3.2 lol. Jaune paille, mousse blanche. ArÃ´mes de mais, cÃ©rÃ©ales. En bouche, assez mince, leger houblon discret, sans amertume rÃ©elle. Se boit comme de lâ€™eau Ã  38 degrÃ©s.

From a 65 cl bottle, thanks Ruben. Thick, very frothy, moussy, dense and snow white head, very pale golden colour, cristal clear with lively sparkling. Aroma of tinfoil, cardboard, white bread crumbs, some â€™sweatyâ€™ grains, wet paper. Simple grain sweetish flavor, bit sourish as well, thin with a minerally touch, medium carbo, metallic in the middle, very light herbal bitterish touch in the end, lightly bready â€™feelingâ€™ at the back. Very neutral and in that sense inoffensive.
Butelka 0,65l wypite w B.F. kolor jasnozÅ‚oty, kwaskowe, wodniste.Pijalne tylko w upaÅ‚y.

650ml bottle [Thank you very much, Aziz, for the original Brakina!]. Clear, yellow-ish, pale golden colour with average, frothy, diminishing, white head. Expressionless aroma is damn close to water, thereâ€™s just a touch of... what is it? Paper? Cardboard? Straw? Dust? Taste is mineral, watery, slightly grassy, cautiously dry and pale malty; flawless but also expressionless, nice carbo. Refreshing, but oh so thin and watery. Nevertheless I can imagine to be glad to have some of these when being in Burkina.

Alkohol 4,8% Kolor- zÅ‚oty, klarowny. Piana - drobna, Å›rednio wysoka, Å›rednio trwaÅ‚a. Zapach - lekki sÅ‚odowy Smak - lekki sÅ‚Ã³d, lekki chmiel, lekka sÅ‚odycz, lekka goryczka Lekkie piwo, tylko do gaszenia pragnienia. Country 167

Bottle into glass in Abidjan. Pale watery local suds. More malt than hops. Some grain notes and a touch more flavor than some of the Ghanaian macro suds. Ok on a hot night. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from a local West/Central African restaurant. Bright golden with a bubbly head. Aroma is corn and wheat. Taste is corn and super sweet malt.

Can 33cl given by calisky thanks. A clear yellow beer with low head. Nose is on grain and cereals, light barley sugar notes. Aroma is on the same with dusty hops and wet paper thin body, very industrial like, grain and wet paper finish.
Couleur dorÃ©e claire, lÃ©gÃ¨re mousse blanche. Nez leger malt, cÃ©rÃ©ales. Gout doux maltÃ©. Corps moyen. Ca passe

Pours a light straw color with a foamy head that fades quickly to no real lacing. Aroma of malt sweetness, bit of citrus and grainy. Taste of malt sweetness, grain and bit of fruit. Decent bitterness and a fairly clean finish. Light body, crisp and somewhat refreshing. Decent lager that goes well with the tropics.
Noe sursÃ¸tlig duft av humle. Klar lys gyllen farge, lite skum. noe tÃ¸rr smak, litt sÃ¸lig og noe sur. Helt ok drikke Ã¸l i vamen.
Thanks to travlr - tasted at the RBSGII. Pours a pale yellow with a tiny head. The smell is sweet pale malt, grain. The taste is malt and mild honey. It is light bodied with mild carbonation.
Bottle. Pours golden with a white head. Crisp hoppy and pilslike aroma. Clean, hoppy and refreshing taste.
Bottle, thanks David! Pours pale without a head. Light but clean, balanced and pleasant pilsner.
*Old rating, best before 22.04.03. Neutral-herbes, leicht getreidiges Pils. Nicht zu tief mit einer etwas deutlichen neutral-herben Note im Nachgeschmack.
Poured light golden with a frothy white head. Aroma of sweet malt and floral hops. Medium, grainy body, flavour is quite sulphurous over the fizz with a lingering bitter aftertaste.
Golden color with a fizzy soapy head. Light hoppy taste, but very sulphury. Short bitter kick. Boring!

Bottle 33cl. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, corn, cardboard, light hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090626]
Bottle, 4.8%. Clear golden color. Big stable white head. The flavour is a little watery. There is a hint of butter and peach. Perhaps coming from the malt. Slightly grainy finish.

Bottle: Golden, quite persistent white head; delicate pale-malty nose, completed by straw and grassy hops; mild bitter-sweet flavour, light bodied, quite soft; short bitter-sweet finish. Drinkable, but not really good..........

(bottle) Clear, golden colour with a blond foamy white head of medium-size. Sweet malty and slightly grainy aroma with a faint note of honey and delicate herbal hoppy note. Sweet-bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Initially soft malty, slightly strawy and grainy taste with herbal accents, getting slightly stronger towards the moderately dry and bitter finish. Boring but drinkable Pils (18.06.08).
Bottle in GÃ¶ttingen. Nice crisp pilsener, not overwhelming but worth drinking. Clean fresh taste. Canâ€™t comment on appearance because I drank it from the bottle (when in Germany...).

Bottle Frothy to fizzy, off-white head. Lace lacks. The heads disappears almost totally. Pale, yellow colour. Very soapy, weak aroma of faint hops. Lightly bitter flavour with an astringent feel that makes this beer not so good at all.

A pilsener from the place where I live. Yellow color with stable head. Sweet hoppy aroma. Starts nicely malty and spicy and is then overtaken by aromatic hops. Finishes drier without being really bitter. Malty aftertaste with some fruity accents. Overall impression is rustical and raw. Better than many similar local beers.

0,5 l long neck bottle as Edles Premium Pils. Big thank you to my nephew Christoph, itÂ´s never too late. Clear pale golden in the glass, nearly two finger steady off white head. Smells grassy grainy. Taste starts smooth, some grain and caramel, low malt. Increasing dry mid bitterness to the end. Solid standard stuff.

Bottle. Clear yellow/gold with a decent white head. Aroma of grains, grass and spicy hops. Taste is grains, malts, hay and floral and slightly spicy hops. Medium bitterness. Medium carbonation. Refreshing run of the mill German Pils. Nothing to write home about as they already know more than enough about this kind of stuff.

GÃ¶ttinger Edles Premium Pils: goldgelb und klar mit weiÃŸer Schaumkrone. Recht malziges aber nicht sonderlich sÃ¼ÃŸes Pils, grasig. Im Abgang verbindet es sich mit einer leicht herben Bittere. Solides Pils!
*Old rating, best before 14.07.03. WÃ¼rzig-malziges Bier. moderate Herbe, voller KÃ¶rper. Nicht zu tief aber aromatischer als das "GÃ¶ttinger Edel-Pils". WÃ¼rzig-herber Nachgeschmack.

bottle from Heinrichs 3000 Super-GetrÃ¤nkemarkt Kornwestheim. Clear pale yellow with a mid-sized, quickly-collapsing white head. Light and elegant malty base with just the right malty sweetness and a good amount of bitter, grassy-herbal hops with an impressively bitter, long lingering finish. A very pleasant surprise!
Goldgelbes Bier mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, grasig, hopfig. Geschmack grasig, hopfig, malzig.
Bottle. Frothy White good mostly lasting head. Pale yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Grainy notes. Avererage moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Grassy. Oily palate.
Clear golden colour with a grainy malty hoppy aroma. Malty grainy taste with good bitter finish

Bottle 33cl. Clear light to medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, grain, cabbage water. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a averag duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20091021]
Clear golden with a medium white head. Sweet malty aroma with caramel and grainy notes. Flavour was malty with grassy hops and caramel notes.
Newbie. Had this one while on a bar tour. Needless to say, it was the only drink at that bar (John Harvardâ€™s in Cambridge). I liked it but it was too strong to enjoy on a bar tour :)

I drank this beer in Boston, at the original John Harvardâ€™s Brewery in Cambridge. It has a reddish-copper color with a medium-sized head. The flavor of hops is powerful and delicious, especially being double-hopped. This beer is delicious, especially if you like IPAs.

On tap in Harvard Square. Very hoppy aroma. Dark amber color. Piney hop taste. Can definitely taste the alchohol but doesnâ€™t overpower. Slightly medicinal though. Pretty good for its class but i have had better. I would order it again though.

On tap at the brewpub. Nice chewy hop nose in pine resin and citrus rind. Soft and waxy. Lazy. Pours a deepened orange, with a silky, white lace above. Flavor is fresh dense and chewy. Quite a douple pale and not just an IPA. Hops work balanced and in harmony with the malt. Very bready, chewy and with some yeast. A nice malt profile for the beer. Hops a mish-mash of warm citrus and pine. A bit of grassiness. Nicely balanced. Fresh and bubbly. Alcohol is warming, but only adds complexity. Finishes on a long mandarin draw.

Date: 02/10/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Extreme Beer hazy dark yellow, frothy off white head, big sweet fruity citrus aroma with a hint of pine, thick and sweet, lots of tasty fruity citrus hop flavor, light bitterness allows the hop flavor be the star of the show, a benchmark double IPA Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 17/20 Rating: 4.1/5.0 Drinkability: 9/10 Score: ***+/4

Tap at Boston EBF 2007. Cloudy golden body topped by an off-white ring. Balance clearly leaning towards the hops. Light roasted malt flavour dominated by substantial amount of hops with a taste lying somewhere between citrus fruits and pine-tree. Above average and very pleasant Pale Ale on steroids. Recommended to hopheads. I now do reverse exorcism, I help people who possess a Demon get rid of it.

EBF 2007: Clear copper color with a white head. Aroma, citrusy hops, some pale and caramel malts. Flavor, caramel up front, floral and citrus on the finish, nice bit of bitterness. Pretty solid stuff.

22 oz bottle from Weeare. Thanks Mike. Pours a light hazy amber with a thin lasting head. Aroma is of solvents and pineapple, mango and other tropical fruits- amarillo and simcoe? Light citrusy flavor with some pine, and cedary notes. Light crystal malt backgrounnd and a lighter than expeceted bitterness for an 8% hoppy beer. Smooth and tasty finish.

Thanks to warriorsoul for this! Appears a transparent, golden amber with a small, 1/2" creamy, off-white head that doesnâ€™t want to fade out. Lots of streaky, spotty lacing is left around the glass. Smell is of citrus, pine, light caramel, toasted malts, and toffee. Taste is of a bitter, balanced version of the mentioned aromas with a caramel, & toffee flavor highlighted in the mix. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, along with a slightly dulled grapefruit hoppiness and yeast resounding on the back of the tongue during the swallow.

22oz bottle shared courtesy of weeare138 (thanks!). Poured a deep orange color (with kind of a red tint) and a small sized off white head. Aromas of pine, citrus, light caramel, and grass. Tastes of caramel (stronger than the aromas), light citrus, and pine.
Can. Pours clear gold with an off-white head. Tropical fruit, caramel, pine. Good.

12 oz can. Canned on 07/20/17. Courtesy of Euphemos! Enjoyed on Nov 24 2017. Clear amber color with a small white head. Sweet marmalade, sweet fruity hops, mild bitterness, sweet caramel malt and biscuits in the aroma. Strong resiny hops, strong bitterness and caramel malt in the flavor.

355ml can, thanks Vesa! Canned 07/20/17. Pours dark orange with a small head. Aroma of caramely malts, toffee, pine, resin and citrus. Taste is sweet, caramely and malty with some toffee, pine, grass and resin. Finish is sweet, malty and caramely with some crisp hops, pine, citrus and resin. Sweet and caramely.

355ml can. Canned 07/2017. Big thanks to Euphemos for this one! Pours amber in color with a thick white head. Caramel malty nose, canned fruity with strong piny notes. Flavor has caramel sweetness, malts, hops, pine, massive bitterness in finish. Not very fresh anymore. My first from Idaho!

12 oz can poured into a pint glass. A well balanced IPA that serves the purpose. Doesn't taste like the 100 IBU suggests it might. This is to say, it's not an IPA that burns your tonsils right out of your mouth. It's a great thing that I have have a case of this beer!

Picked up a 6-pack in Boise, ID. Pours amber with head and lace. Aroma of grains, pale malt, grassy hops. Significant carbonation and mouthfeel. Flavors of bitter hops, pale malt, bitter roots. Overall rich and bitter, but not especially smooth or tasty.

Can from World Beer Market. Big fat tropical fruit nose, with biscuits, citrus, and some piney hop. Clear amber/orange color. Moderately sweet initial flavor, with caramel, resin, grapefruit, and mild but long bitter tracks. Medium body, with some hop texture. Very nice IPA.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear orange amber with a thin white head. Soft citrus, a bit of pine and a bit of pineapple. Medium bodied, toast, crisp malt, toast, a bit of fruit. Slow toast, crisp slow bitterness with a bit of pine.

Draught at Bar Gernika. Pours clear copper with a medium, bubbly white head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is heavy citrus and pine hops with medium toast and nutty malt. Flavor is moderate citrus and pine hops and bitterness, toast malt with a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Light aromas of cereal and lemon. Nice and bitter, finishes dry, oranges, lemon, tangerine, some scrubby pine and a plain backing malt.

Special Edition brew, they ran out of porter tonight and substituted this. Made me happy, this was very tasty. Picture Old Rasputin Imperial Stout with 7.5% ABV, and that's what this would be. Very smooth palate with a mild, yet very refreshing flavor. Coffee and chocolate malts are detectable and it goes down very smooth. Overall a very good beer I really enjoyed.
o,33 l. bottle. yellow color with white head. sweet, watery, fresh, fruit. easy to drink
I remember this one from my childhood. Mile drank 10 bottles at Evaâ€™s 18â€™th birthday in 2005. It was supposed to be a Croatian version of Corona. What a fail! Very light and tasteless.
This was piss like that Mexican Corona. Smart move they moved it! Like we donâ€™t have enough shit to introduce new, worser beers.
refreshing beer , for girls.... i don`t drink this one.... great bottle...............................................................................anusually for my country...

Rerate: So, I didnâ€™t rerate it this summer, but, itâ€™s not because I didnâ€™t care to, itâ€™s because itâ€™s very rare on the coast even then. And itâ€™s supposed to be a "party" beer. Well, itâ€™s a good thing actually, cos we donâ€™t need more bad beers. Anyway, I found it when I moved to Zagreb. Itâ€™s quite common here (not popular though). To the beer. It poured a pale yellow colour, and it had a medium sized fluffy white head. Extremely (f)izzy (bad pun alert). The nose was... malt and olive oil. Ugly. Taste... a bit better than last time, but still not too good, basically, weak generic malt. Sorted kinds ? No. Maybe some very weak hops thrown in, but not enough to make a difference, or more than a faint "bleep" on the taste radar. Oily aftertaste. -1 on palate overall. I was too generous back then. Old Review: When I joined Ratebeer, I kinda ignored this, mostly because I knew that this was not one of the best I could get. So, when I finally decided to go look for this, it was nowhere to be found. The reason ? While itâ€™s not really a summer-only brew as far as I know, they donâ€™t ship it to the coast in the other seasons. Iâ€™m not certain, but itâ€™s possible. Anyway, I decided to go to I store that was a bit out of my way to see what it was carrying, and it had a suprisingly big variety of beers. Unfortunately (for me), Iâ€™ve tried everything they had, and was ready to leave, when I spotted a couple of bottles of this. My "trip" was worth it. Or was it ? People say that this is Croatian Corona. And yes, it is. But itâ€™s far better. Itâ€™s still not good. Golden color, white fluffy head, went away fast. Seemed fizzy while in the bottle, but proved not to be. The "aroma" was a bit offputting, but bearable. Tastes sweet, a bit hoppy and like of all things, eggs. Bitter aftertaste. Itâ€™s probably an old bottle though. Iâ€™ll rerate it this summer. (2/2/4/3/8)
Bottled, gravity 11,4% (BB 08/2004) Golden lager color, white foamy head, mostly diminishing. Sweet corn and hop aroma. Sweet. Low carbonation.
Awful lack of taste. Very high priced (about 2 euro for 0,33). So... Bad beer.
For hard workers... Not tastefull enough. Different in different parts of year
Bottled(330ml). -refreshing, yellow colored, fruty aroma, very good sweet aftertaste, quite good for american standard

Bottle at home. Pours clear reddish copper with off-white head. Aroma of caramel, dark bread, some roasted notes. Tastes slightly sweet with balancing bitterness. Medium bodied, slightly sweet finish.
Et ganske godt Ã¸l, passer til det meste av mat. OgsÃ¥ behagelig som tÃ¸rstedrikk. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Look; rusty cherry clear dark body, fawn head. Aroma; dark malts, bread, caramel, hay. Taste; dark malts, bread, brittle caramel, hops - finish has malts and notes of chocolate. Palate; normal, feels as lower abv. Overall amber-brown-vienna like. [33cl br btl 6.6%abv, bb17.6.16, b@Vinmonopolet]

Bottled@AIH53 (from Vinmonopolet, Kirkenes). Copper colour, small brown head. Aroma is caramel, some slight spices, mild liquorice and some wooden notes. Flavour is quite similar, with some stinging strange spicy/bitter/sour kind of touch under beneath.

Bottle 330ml (ABV 6.5%, AIH53, from Vm Kirkenes) Dark clear ruby color, small beige head. Caramel and harsh maltyness in the nose. Light to medium-bodied. Grassy and harsh. Caramel. Watery finish. Feels less than 6.5%. Very typical industrial Scandinavian Xmas beer.
Amber with an off white head - Caramel malt aroma - Good malt aroma with caramle and olso some bitter notes in the back - Malty finish - This was nice

33cl bottle from Vinmonopolet, Storo. Pours ebony coloured, reddish tint in the edges and a rather small tanned head. Malty aroma with caramel, raisins, hints of roasted malt and herbs. Sweet and malty, but fairly balanced and quite tasty winter warmer with some bitterness. Quite okay.
Aroma av rosiner, mÃ¸rkt malt, brent sukker og litt nÃ¸tter. SÃ¸t med god syre og lett bitterhet. (Havnabakken, 05.05.14)
MÃ¸rk brun med rÃ¸dskjÃ¦r, klar i fargen med tynt beige skum. Malt, karamell og sviskelukt. SÃ¸t smak fra malt og alkohol, bitter smak av bitter brendt karamell. Kort ettersmak, lite kullsyre.
Fin mÃ¸rk amber farge. Duft av rosin, eik, karamell og humle. Lite skum. God smak av rosin og karamell. Nb: Flasken sier 6,5%

column1: La Jamboise de Bister SpÃ©ciale NoÃ«l
column5: This beer has a dark brown body - hue apperance and a fine white scum collar. I have drunk the beer from the bottle and it had a low carbonic acid. The initial flavor taste is bitter.

column1: La Jamboise de Bister SpÃ©ciale NoÃ«l
column5: Dark brown beer with a small head. Light fruity, malty, sweet and spicy taste. It has a nice Christmas taste. Neutral finish.

column1: La Jamboise de Bister SpÃ©ciale NoÃ«l
column5: A quite spicy and very warming Christmas beer. Interesting..................

column1: La Jamboise de Bister SpÃ©ciale NoÃ«l
column5: Quite rare and special brew. Nice coffee notes in the aftertaste. Caramel and choccolate in the floavor. A heavy and nice christmas brew.
Good orange color and nicely balanced. One of the few beers around with orange flavor. Different and worth a try.
amber color; light malt aroma with a touch of hops; light, bready malt flavor with floral hops and light pine notes; well balanced
Draft at Macs. Translucent gold pour with off-white foam. Lemon detergent. Glossy caramel grains. Artificial berries. Jello and soap. Nope.
Bottle from Barracks Road Harris Teeter. Clear gold, tiny white head. Aroma of grass and browning leaves. Flavor is caramel malts, grass, brown leaves. Pretty boring.
Tap at Jack Browns. Dark golden with foamy head. Smells grainy and lemony. Citric flavor. A bit of a sweet aftertaste.
On tap at Joes. Pours straw with a white head. Aroma is malty and light. Mild hop bitterness balanced nicely with the malt. Thin mouthfeel.
On tap at SLL tasting. Poured a golden color with a 1/2 inch head. Smell is mild, some malts and sweetness. Taste is crisp, malts, grains, hops are present, a touch of honey.
Boring!! Nothing happening here whatsoever. Good pour, very mild taste, & weak aroma. Not a fan!
Slightly hoppy aftertaste. Smooth and a bit nutty. Nice appearance. Have one then another : )
Grainy and lightly sweet nose and flavor with hops barely evident. Nice enough for a blonde, but pretty pedestrian at the end of the day.
On tap at Redwood. Murky gold body with medium head. Nose is floral, citrus and bread. Taste is tangy, some tart, quite bitter, with bread. Okay. Not well balanced.
I had this beer a while back and from what I can remember I enjoyed it. Iâ€™ve had this at the pub/brewery so it was fresh. Nothing special about it is popping into my head at the moment.
This beer was the one that got me hooked on Duclaw Brewery in the very beginning I wish they would bring it back!

Excellent example of the Kolsch style. Crisp, light, with excellent body and carbonation. Easily my favorite DuClaw offering... And now I understand it is to be discontinued? DuClaw brewers need to re-think that decision. There is no better example of the style available--bottle or tap--in Maryland.
On tap at Arundel Mills/Hanover brewpub. A good beer, very pale, light on flavor and body. But provides a nice cleansing sensation and overall refreshing ambience to a meal.

On tap at Duclaw, Bowie, Md. location. Poured out a very light golden yellow color, almost clear. Thin white head faded all too quickly. Aromas are of fresh malts, yeasty bread, and sweet hay. Tastes are of a bland nature, with malts and yeast making up the bulk of the flavors. Subdued hops, both in flavors & aromas. Decent beer, but kind of thin bodied for my liking.
Clear, bright appearance, nice lacy head. Slightly fruity nose, tart flavor. Very refreshing. My first experience with a real Kolsch, and I was very pleased with how refreshing this beer was.
Pours a piss gold wiith no head. Hops are very subtle, leaving the flavor profile mostly malty, but this is bland and generally uninteresting. The finish fades quickly.

Clear, pale color; small head with decent lacing. Aroma was not too complex; noticed more malt than anything. Very good taste for a Kolsch style beer, dominated by a floral and fruity quality More flavor than most domestics of this style. Clean finish.

I've always enjoyed this beer.Used to play open mike at duclaw in bel air while they had it there,happy hour lasted all night back then(good times) Great fresh brew.Smells faintly like a becks or somethin'.Looks nice and golden/not much headage/some lace.Smooth drinking! reminds me of the best st. pauli girl(lager)you could ever have.Was my fav back in the day(last year)Now I thank God for the sawtooth(their belgian white)No more open mike at duclaw(boo) but happy hour is well worth a trip(3-7).Nice dry duclaw finish.(signature)the finish that is.

Pale straw, yellowy-gold color. Persistent champagney bubbles. Aroma is mild, difficult to detect. Has some faint, sour yeastiness to it. Definitely has the mild, sour-yeasty character I associate with a kolsch. Pleasant, refreshing flavor. Enjoyable and unobtrusive. Probably would be a good session beer.
Dallas. Spicey, alcohol smell. Medium hopped smell and flavor, a little abrasive, but overall, just mild pine, scotch, and nuts. Thick finish.

Malt, fruit and alcohol armoa. Medium-dark woody tone that matched the light cherrywood bar rail. Medium heavy sweetness, some alt-like grainy cherry flavor. Finish starts with vanilla and ends up in alchohol and bitterness. Sweet on the lips. ABV made me bump up the overall rating by +1 towards the end.
Bottled. A pale yellow beer with a small white head. Aroma is slightly fruity. Taste is sweet and soft. A strong chili taste in the end. Too strong in my opinion. Light body.

Bottle conditioned, hazy amber with a white bubbly head. A sweted fruit aroma. Quite a buttery mouthfeel, flowery at first and it isnâ€™t until the finish that the chilli kick comes through. I surprisingly quite liked this, I thought it might be a little gimmicky.

Appearance: pale yellow color. Not head. Aroma: chili; and others â€œhot-spiceâ€ like black peppers, seed mustard and red paprika. Very soft smoked. Not hoppy. Flavor: intensive red chilies, hot-spicy, pale malts that adding a soft sweetness. Reminiscences of red paprika, peppers and mustard. Persistent hot taste; some touch of salame very spicy and smoked. I remember the â€œmerkÃ©nâ€, this is a Chilean hot-spice-seasoning of Mapuche people, that contain toasty and dries red-chilies (mainly of "cacho de cabra" variety) with salt and others spices like coriander. (Long Live to Chile and Mapuche people!!!). Palate: light body, watery texture. Low carbonation. Very hot-spicy beer, exotic, but the chili-taste is not my favorite. I shared this beer with Panzerfaust

Clear yellow/golden color with a small-fizzy, white fast-diminishing head. It leaves a very small lacing. Aroma is spicy and a little smokey. Notes of chile, pepperoni, smoked ham, salmon, saussages, gherkins and italian salami. Flavor is intense, very hot spicy with lots of chile, pepper, suasages, pepperoni and more spices. Almost no malty sweetness or hop flavors to counterbalance, but really unique. Light to medium body, high stingy carbonation. Finish is very hot and spicy. No alcoholic presence whatsoever. Hot aftertaste. A very different and interesting brew, not for everyone. Thanks to davidpl for sharing this brew!
Bottle. I sware i will not pretend to be a macho man again. Chilli beer is not for me. I think everything that has this kind of vegetables should not be considered as beer.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden color with a longlasting white head. Sweet malty aroma with some hints of chili. Sweet malty flavor. Has some hints of chili. Malty finish with some bitterness and hints of chili.

Bottled. Hazy pale golden, minimal head, contains a small piece of green chili. Tabasco aroma. Initially sweet and rounded, but quickly turning into a burning tabasco sensation. Not as terribly macho as Sunshine Coastâ€™s version, and with more malt to legitimize the chili. A beer that makes you thirst for another beer, but certainbly not another of of the same...
Bottle. Light reddish body. Vitually no foam. Light malty flavour with some hint of spices. Nice chili spicy flavour though some what waterish mouthfeel. to it. Bit flat feeling.

Imbibed in December 2002. Not much aroma. Clear light gold color with a head that fizzed and vanished in 30 seconds. Wow! Pretty amazing flavors. Honey/diacetyl flavor with a slight hoppiness that is quickly overwhelmed by peppery, spicy chili zing. Not much heat but lots of chili flavor. Very original and well done. I gave it a high mark because of the flavor and its uniqueness.

I couldn''t really enjoy this beer, but it is exactly what you''d expect. A nice clean lager, pale amber, full head, decent body, and it tastes of chilli, burns the tongue a little. It''s really pretty well executed, I just don''t like the flavour.
Cask at The White Hart Tap, St. Albans in 2013. Clear copper with a white head. Aroma of caramel, floral hops and a nice peppery hop note. Fairly sweet flavours, but a well served pint.
20.10.2014. Cask. Quite lame with only slight bitterness and some strange sweetness.
Cask@the avion, aldridge. Copper beer with medium head and patchy lacing. Aroma is fainty fruity malts. Taste is malts, caramel and some dry fruit. Ok at best.
Draught @ BeerTemple. Amsterdam. Hazy pale yellow, little head. Milky and sweet, meh...

Cask at Tanners Hall JDW, Darlington. Clear deep golden amber colour, white foam head and malty nutty aroma. Taste is malt, toffee, raisins, fruity and light bitter. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft carbonation, clean finish. Quite OK.
Cask at the Macbeth Moor, Musselburgh. Pours clear amber, thick white head. Aromas of butter and oat biscuits. Taste is more of the same. Sweet finish. Not great.
On cask at Wheatsheaf (JDW), Stoke. Pours copper with white head. Extremely sweet with caramel, itâ€™s Ok but overpowered by toffo!
Cask at JDW Arthur Robertson; hazy amber pour with a frothy beige head, feint citrus aroma, taste has malts with some citrus action, caramel.

Cask at the Columbia press Watford jdw. Aroma is toffee, stale malts, vinegar and cleaning fluid. Mostly clear caramel, amber coloured pour with a fleeting halo of white head. Flavour is sweet caramel and cleaning product citrus, seriously fucked. Some savourly meaty flavours and ammonia. Palate is semi sweet tart, and moderate carbonation. Fucked.
Tried at the royal hop pole Twekesbury. Deep Amber colour, lasting off white head. Aroma has fruity malt with some hops. Flavour started with malts and finish with a lingering bitterness.

Cask at The Roebuck, Leek (Titanic) A clear deep amber colour with a medium white head. Aroma of caramel, some nuts, a little yeast and subtle spicy hops. Taste of caramel, red berries, some nuts, slight bready malt and subtle spicy hops. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A dry, spicy hop bitterness in the finish. Quite similar to tiger at first but more fruitier and spicy. Ok but safe.

23rd Dec 2014: hand-pulled cask pint in The Pheasant, Wellington Shropshire. Mahogany/chestnut body with an off-white crown that produced some good lacing. Malty and semi-sweet with a nutty feel to both the nose and taste. Slight spicy trace within the flavours and an easy drinking Christmas brew.

Cask, handpump at a The White Horse, Banbury Beer Festival Meeting, Monday 13th January 2014 Amber in colour a little murky, malty in the mouth. As Glen correctly noted it is a touch tired perhaps, however it is still quite agreeable. Tangy, fruity and with a few things going on in the mouth, it is fine if somewhat predictable. A6 A3 T6 P3 Ov13 3.1
Cask at JDW Charlie Hall; hazy amber pour with frothy white head, malt and fruit aroma, slight nutty taste with caramel and dried fruits.
Had this on tap at Wetherspoons in Guildford. Pours a dark chestnut brown. Smell is quite malty and the taste was rather nutty.
Casok salutation. Pours dark amber no head. Malty aroma. Malty taste nothing special
Cask @ Ship, Bromham Road, Bedford. A shade lighter tha chestnut brown. Faint aroma, consisting of caramel and toffee malt notes. Bittersweet. Rather bland, but certainly drinkable.

Cask at The Wellington, Birmingham. Poured a clear copper colour with a broken white bubbly head. The aroma is malty but weak leading to a medium bitter flavour, with fruity hoppy dry bitter notes. The dry bitterness hits the palate fairly quickly and stays around for a while. Not quite what I would expect from Everards, but very welcome all the same.
From the tap. Copper in appearance, christmasy taste with berries, barley overtones. Head is sticky.
Mmm nice I like it. Bright copper colour subtle citrus hoppiness with slight hoppy bitterness. I think this is delicious! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at MÃ¤lzer Brauhaus (MÃ¤lzator 2017). Comes with a clear, dark brown color and a tan head. Lots of toated malts aroma, followed by burned caramel and nuts. Taste is rich malty, with nuts and raisins, sweet and medium bitter. Not bad for a Doppelbock.
Cremig malziger Antrunk, starke Karbonisierung. Noten von Schokolade, leicht Espresso, vollmundig. Intensiv malziger Mittelteil, geringe Herbe. Langer weicher Nachhall. Gut! 12/12/12/11//12

Draught @ MÃ¤lzer Brau- und Tafelhaus, Heiligengeiststr. 43, D-21335 LÃ¼neburg, Niedersachsen, Germany. [ As MÃ¤lzer Brauhaus MÃ¤lzator ]. Clear light medium amber red color with a average, frothy - creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, nutty, dark berry, sugar, moderate raisin, prune notes. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20081215] [ Good BEER Guide Germany #745 ]

Light nose of toasted grains - pleasant. Dark, opaque brown color and a lacy head. Caramelly, toffe flavors with a tinge of roasted smokiness. Spicey finish. Big round, warming body and mouth feel. The best of the MÃ¤lzer beers.

Not much aroma, a little bit of semisweet malt. Wonderful dark brown body with a little medium head. A lot of flavors are going on in this beer. Malt, smoked, alcohol - but well, toasted, chocolate and also spices. Fullmouth and thick aftertaste. Comes in wonderful long shaped glasses and the whole brewpub is located at a wonderful place in LÃ¼neburg and has a lot of atmosphere!

Dark chestnut. Fizzy tan head. Steady carbonation. Healthy roasted grains and chocolate aroma with notes of barley and oats. Initially a bit watery but modestly malted with a roasted, dry cocoa base and oat smoothness. Dry aftertaste. Medium light body. Flaked barley taste lingers long after, alongside a toasty grain flavor. Powdered cocoa and an astringent roasted property carry through to the end. Finishes solidly flavored and smooth, albeit on the thin side, with an everlasting toasted chocolate covered oatmeal finesse.
Slightly dark; no head from the cask. A lot more character with the extra alcohol. Good hop bite. Lingers a bit too.
Typische pilsener. Smaken van mout en van hop. Heeft een klein bittertje maar het merendeel is mout zoetigheid. -backlog de BierApp-

50cl swing top bottle. A clear pale golden beer with a mid-sized most good lasting white head. Aroma of straw, grainy malt, mild grassy hops. Taste of mild grainy malt, mild floral hops, straw, medium bitterness.
Bottle @ Bayreuth. Pours clear Pale yellow with a egg white head. Straw, grains, dishwasher and faint dms.

That will teach me to buy an entire case based simply on those lovely keywords, "hopfig pils." In reality itâ€™s not either thing. Itâ€™s a fairly sweet, cakey, flabby, Nilla-wafer-tasting malty helles. Which is fine, really, I can make short work of it when I want to drink a beer and not think about the beer. But I feel misled, nonetheless.

0,5 BÃ¼gel-Flasche aus einem lokalen GetrÃ¤nkemarkt. Helles, klares Pils mit reichlich KohlensÃ¤ure und einer cremigen Schaumkrone. Riecht sehr hopfig, wÃ¼rzig, leicht nach Weizen. SchÃ¤umt im Antrunk, fruchtig-sÃ¼ÃŸe Zitrusnoten. Danach eine leichte ausgewogene bittere.

Bottled, Cesky Brod, CZ, Sweet malt,cereal,toast and light herbal aroma, Sweeter taste, light bitter finish, Clear yellow color, smaller lasting head, Lighter body, average carbon, Quite refreshing and pretty good beer.
Good solid Bavarian Beer. A little too low on hops for a pilsner. Nice light Berr for the summer.
* Old rating, 0,5l bottle, best before 11.12.05. Malzig-sÃ¼ÃŸliches Bier. Leichte Herbe wahrnehmbar, frisch und sÃ¼ffig.

Bottle best by March 2015. Clear gold with a fine white head. Quiet pale malt biscuit / cracker aroma with little to no aroma hop expression. Medium body, silty / chalky rough acidity, lightly sweet with medium bitterness. Thereâ€™s some decent malt body but flavor-wise itâ€™s basically empty. Very dull. Faint lemon noble hops mixed with quiet cauliflower DMS.
a bit disappointing - very pale, minimal foam, malty aroma and taste - not bitter at all. iâ€™ve drunk tons of worse lagers, but a lot of better ones too.

Cask at the Cambridge Blue, Cambridge on 7th March 2015. Pale gold with thinning off-white foam and pattern lacing. Herby hop aroma with yeastiness. Fruity in-mouth with very pungent medicinal kick, unsure if intended by the brewer. Sharp pungent notes in finish indicative of a yeast infection. Zingy texture and light to moderate body. Will re-rate should I find the beer again.

Cask Conditioned Handpump Malt Shovel Northampton. A golden beer with a white rim of head and lacing. A nice citrussy beer both in aroma and taste. Oranges and peaches come through. A bit short in the finish in that it needs more malt but the hops arenâ€™t harsh. Just lacking ooomph. Tasty though.
Cask Stillage at the Swan Inn, Stone 20/07/2001 Golden coloured and very sweet on the palate. Fruity wine like finish.
This has a fresh spicey aroma that perfectly complements this crisp, resfreshing bitter. Floral and fruity notes make this beer a good bitter.

Bottle. Dark beer with a brown light bubbly head. The aroma is fruity, spiced and slightly vinous, the beer has a mulled nature to it. The flavour is mainly sour with a long dry finish. Overall a disappointing beer.

Bottle. Black with a small cream head. Aromas are earthy roast malts with sour berries and hints of chocolate. Prickly on the nose and quite light. Flavours are roast malts with bitter coffee and some chocolate. Has an Ovaltine and oat type maltiness. Dry on the finish. Decent, if a bit thin.

Cask Conditioned at The Gamecock, Harbury, Warks. Black bronze beer with healthy head. Overwhelming cardboard note at first sip with hard roasted malts. A little caramel and a dry hop on the finish. A touch of acidity, but mostly moist card.

Bottle: Pours hazy dark brown with a small beige head. Slightly oaky aroma, but mostly mild caramel with a touch of roast. Sweetish start with a mildly fruity mid and finish. Some acidic notes in aftertaste, almost a little tart. Medium bodied, interesting.
Nice. Real Nice. I would like some more body and bitterness. But a real nice beer.
Bottle 750ml.Very dark brown in colour,small head,wood,coffee,chocolate,many unknown others,the range of flavours made me frown often.A strange ale indeed.De smeggin licious.

Dec, 2002: Bottle Conditioned, There are four different malts and three different hops used in this dark and complex little brew. Deep, creamy, darkly fruity with a roller-coaster ride of assorted flavours. Star! O bright, brilliant star!

Cask at the Ipswich Beer Festival 2004, gravity dispense. Black (= very dark brown) colour. Interesting and unusual aroma: Ensilage, fresh mown grass, candy ("Kongen av Danmark"), hints of old ladies with a questionable personal hygiene. (Bordering on vomit, according to chris_o, but I liked it.) Flavour is grassy, citrussy, green apples. Easy drinking. Fruity finish.

A clear brown beer with a chocolate brown head. The aroma is sweet with light notes of caramel as well as roasted malt. The flavor contains notes of roasted malt and chocolate on a sour background before a very dry end sets in.
Black color, light sweet roasted malty aroma and taste, light body, light dry finish.

column1: Great Waters Minnesota Wild Rice Ale
column5: Dark brown color with a medium head. The aroma and taste are reminicent of a bag of wild rice instead of a well blended and cooked rice. Dusty grains protrude into the taste. Interesting and alright, but not the best wild rice beer.

column1: Great Waters Minnesota Wild Rice Ale
column5: Good Brown Coloring.. Nice Head. Aroma and Taste of Dry Wild Rice.. Nice and Crisp, Clean...Some Grains as Well.. Took a Few Sips to Agree with It, But Nice Wild Rice Brew!

column1: Great Waters Minnesota Wild Rice Ale
column5: Mild aroma of hops. Gold with a head that left a lace. Surprising fruit taste, and another flavor I couldn't nail down. A pleasant surprise. A session beer.

column1: Great Waters Minnesota Wild Rice Ale
column5: Color is a crispy brownish amber with a small cream colored head that sticks around a while and keeps an impressive haze on top the whole glass down to nearly empty. Wow! Smell again is nothing to get excited about, Great Waters brews seem to always have a disappointing nose, with the exception of Shipwreck IPA. This Wild Rice Ale has a little touch of frothy malt grains and wild rice. Taste starts clean and fresh, easy balanced malts and light hops with a very nice wild rice & grainy overlay that really stands out midway and helps with the over all crisp finish. Also has a nice calming herbal touch of hops. Nice subtle brew with good wild rice character and flavor. Feel is close to medium bodied and gains a bit of punch just past the midway point and has a nice crisp finish and some late notes of wild rice sticking late with a touch of herbal grains. A nice finisher, the wild rice seems to linger forever across the palette. A nice drinker as well, would go good with just about anything I imagine - or by itself. I liked it, a pleasant little beer.

column1: Great Waters Minnesota Wild Rice Ale
column5: Tap. Medium golden color with a good head. A little sweet. I can taste the rice. Some hops. A good solid beer.

column1: Great Waters Minnesota Wild Rice Ale
column5: Amber color, interesting. Nothing too exceptional in aroma, but the flavor is interesting--wild rice to be sure, but also fruity. Simultaneously dry and sweet?

column1: Great Waters Sink the Bismarck German Black Ale
column5: Dark brown body, cocoa-colored head. Aroma is mild and creamy, though notes of coffee and cocoa perk up. Taste: nice, smooth, clean, if uncomplex. Just enough depth, though, to keep the tongue happy, medium body, neat texture. Easy drinking, ideal session-style brew. This was a "German black" at the pub, not a nomenclature Iâ€™ve encountered before. No matter, it was a nice enough ale.

column1: Great Waters Sink the Bismarck German Black Ale
column5: Color is a super nice solid deep dark brown and when held up to the light has some beautiful deep russet around the edges and helps eluminate the richer tones or glorious brown within. Thick cream colored head about a finger high which fades slowly to some hazy bubbles on top always present and layered lace in spotty sheets. A beauty of a glass to behold! OK, the smell absolutely is void and null with a fairly non-existent roasty malt and thats it! another disappointing nose form the beers at Great Waters. Aromatic malts need to be beefed up immensely! OK, taste is a step up in the right direction with a very mild and smooth with light roasted malts and dryish chocolate and cocoa with a touch of dried hops showing through in some of the finish. Would like to see some more roastyness and some dark fruity notes but none are found. That said the feel is actually pretty good, a medium body, creamy at first and has a light velvety feel coming through with a cottony late finish of drying, kinda nice, I liked it. A super smooth drinker, sits comfortably on the palette, not demanding much more, but boy it would be nice if it had some more flavor, heft, and body. Still a delightful beer to drink then the other mainstays at GW.

column1: Great Waters Sink the Bismarck German Black Ale
column5: Tap. Dark brown with a reddish tint. Some roasted malts. Rather plain....

column1: Great Waters Sink the Bismarck German Black Ale
column5: Dark mahogany with red peeping through against a light. Thin head, completely dissipating. Malty, but somewhat thin and overcarbonated. Muted flavors.

Draft @ Brewpub: Dark brown, light white head and lacing. Nose of metal and starchy caramel. Spoiled eggs, dust. The flavor is nice at first, nutty, sweet, caramelly, but then it digresses to licking a 10 year old rusted sewer pipe. Finish is sharp, roasty, harsh.

Sample from tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown with little head. Aroma is vaue but has notes of roasted malt. Flavour is mildly roasted malt and a spicy coriander note. A bit odd, but works out okay.

Clear mahogany body with beige head. Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, earthy/dusky, light chocolate. Taste is medium sweet, caramel, some earthy, some chocolate, floral, light infection sourness (not nearly as bad as some of their other beers). Light-medium body, smooth.

Nice deep brown color with a good inch of tan foam. A little bit of lace throughout the pint. I have heard bad things about a sour off-flavor in Oâ€™Garaâ€™s brews. Sad to say, that nasty sourness was faintly noticeable in the aroma (and it was really the only aroma noticeable). Sourness dominated the flavor and mouthfeel of an otherwise thin brown ale. I also tasted a grainy (not roasted) flavor that was out of place. This sourness might be ok in a pseudo lambic or fruitybeer. But a brown ale? Not good stuff.
Dark Brown Coloring with Good Head. It Wins on First Impressions. After That, Itâ€™s a Let Down. Malty...Sweet. Boring.
Looks promising with a dark brown color and towering head. And thatâ€™s about where it stops. Sweet and sour malt with no nuttiness. Sigh... badness.

Solid dark brown of deep varnished oak, ruby highlights, very thin off-white head that fades fast and leaves minimal spotty lace. Smell is lightly roasty malts and nuts, hazelnuts. Taste is quick and roasty sweet with some nutty & fruity notions lightly playing on the palette but ends with some medicinal, metalic tingeyness mixing with a light roasty tang in the finish. Lighter body feel, getting close to medium, more so then any other of the beers so far by this"brewmaster", but overall is stilll a watery mess, much like the rest at O'gara's brew pub. This place beats out Rock Bottom for bad brewpub beers thus far on my list. Stick with the Guiness on-tap while visiting this place.

My first visit to O'Garas was a disappointment from a beer perspective. It is obvious that the beer is not this establishment's #1 priority. Cork Brown Ale is heavily acidic and somewhat vinegary. I tried the Sligo Red that my buddy ordered, and it was almost identical. Not recommended.
Clear, deep red color. Malty sweet and sour. Some beers are unidimensional. This one is nondimensional.
Tap. Brown color. Bubblegum aroma. Melt and caramel flavors. A touch of citrus.

Hazy light yellow in color, thin white head, minimal spotty lace. Smell is light sweetish wheat with a touch of apricot, not very strong but readily discernible. Taste is very light with mostly apricot coming through and some very light hops and malts. Extremely watery feel, light, and tiresome. Somewhat drinkable but nearly unfinishable.
Scent of apricot. Cloudy yellow. taste is a little sweet. Flavor of fruit and a little sourness. A good beer.
Hazy pale yellow (so light in color). Mildly fruity aroma. Watery, but a gentle apricot "twang!" with spicy hefe notes. Decent beer. A bit candy-like and with time, mildly sour.
Tap. A hazy yellow color. Lots of apricot in the aroma and flavor. Tangy fruit body. The fruit and wheat aspects of this beer balance each other well.
