I thought this was one of the more unique, more flavorful beers that I have had in many many moons. Overwhelming vanilla aroma, which impressed me, I figured it was just have a lisght vanilla and I was wrong. A big creamy frothy head that stayed around the glass the whole time I was drinking this. Just when you think the vanilla is fading it just mps right back in at the finish, saying her I am, and you want to drink more of me. All in all very enjoyable. Makes me want to go back and make a special trip to PA.

What an excellent brown ale, lots of vanilla in the nose, flavors & aftertaste, the vanilla was all over the place & it was very enjoyable, brown in color, excellent lacy head that was retained throughout the pint, excellent balance as well, the vanilla flavors were not overpowering at all, just enough in there to make sure that you knew it was there, very excellent beer, they also had this on the handpump, cask conditioned, but surprisingly it wasn''t as good as it was on the regular taps, awesome brown ale
Straw/peach color with a light pink white head. Candied cherry aroma. Lager malt flavors infused with cherry fruit drink. Interesting, but not my type of beer.

Copper color with a rapidly dissipating head and a mild and familiar Christmas spicy aroma. This beer was a bit unbalanced, dry and hoppy with a faint sour note and a bitter finish. Reminds me of a homebrew recipe that needs a little tweaking. That said, a couple years ago I visited their brewpub and the on tap beers we tried were quite tasty. Bottle.
Ruby/chestnut color with a minimalistic light tan head. Dry malt aroma. Dry malt flavor. Dry acidic malt finish. Unremarkable.
Nice amber color. Aroma is rather weak, fruity, some fig?. Has a very sweet flavor, fruity, but far from as good as many other swedish x-mas beers.
Brown colour. Small white head. Weak malty and roasty aroma. Sweet and bready flavour with a poor malt structure. Some chemical notes. Unpleasant.
Bottled. Dark amber with a frothy head. A chemical, band-aid-aroma. Rather dry and thin with some hints of butterscotch.
Bottled. Dark copper colour. Buttery aroma with notes of band-aid and...yes...cucumber. Only slight licoricy but apart from that not much of flavour. Pungent finish.
Taste of ash, still a very fruity sweetness and a rather deep aroma. Unusual beer. Not a favourite, but OK.
Bottled. Nut brown, little head. Light grapefruit aroma. Dry and fruity nose with dominant ashy flavour and notes of plums. Medium bodied with some bitterness.

Copper coloured. Head sinks pretty fast. Slightly sourish aroma with some caramel. Thin taste of roasted malt. Watery mouthfeel. Unpleasant bitterness in the finish. Gets quite hard to swallow after a while.

Draft at Washington Brewerâ€™s Festival. Pours a hazy light orange amber with a short white head. The nose is fresh-squeezed orange juice and the taste is predominated by same. An interesting diversion in the world of beer.

cloudy like hefe/ orange peel taste consumes all/ beer does not taste good. thereâ€™s a summation in haiku. but basically, when I want fruit flavour in my beer, I want the actual fruit. this tasted like the white stuff in an orange peel. you know how you throw away that part? i donâ€™t blame those who do the same here.

Hazy orange with a light brown tinge. Pleasant refreshment of orange in the nose. However, the flavor, is a confusion of orange juice and other elements--rose hips, hibiscus, and lemongrass--which do not distinguish themselves. Sour and bland. The commercial description given sounded better than it tasted.
Tap at Wash. microbrew festival. I would like to try this again. It"s hard to rate in a 4 oz glass poured over a cold plate.
Bottle from bier-kaufen. Clear golden colour, white foam. Decent and typical Helles, weak body, bit malty, light sweet. Easy drinkable.
bottle, Markgrafen-GetrÃ¤nkemarkt Bischberg. Clear golden yellow, mid-sized white head. Grainy malty flavours, shy hoppy hints, slightly grassy. Very pleasant carbonation. Quite ok.
Aroma of malts and DMS. Taste is rather malty. Low bitterness. Not so good.

500 ml bottle. Perfectly clear pale gold body with sizeable white foam leaving sparce lace. Grainy malt nose, bit of honey and floral hops. Reasonable carbonation, slightly thin body and texture. More grainy malt on the body, bit bready and corn-like, bit of spicy hops towards a dry, medium bitter finish.
Above average Helles, a bit more intense in taste including a tender bitterness which makes this an enjoyable refresher.
Tap. Brilliant gold. Moderate dense white head. Average lacing. Malty aroma. Bread, walnut. Light to medium body. Bready taste. Better hopped than you regular helles. Not bad.
50 cl bottle. Golden color. Medium white head. Average retention. Aroma is grains and floral hops. Straightforward straw and sweet grain flavor.
50cl bottle. Pours clear golden colour with a huge good lasting white head. Aroma of floral hops and grains. Taste of grainy malt, mild floral hops, easy to drink!
Bottle looks very simple but okay. Beer in the glass zippy, small head. Starts mild, malty, dry. A bit metallically. Some artificial hoppy notes. Finish still dry. Not my favourite.
Many thanks for this beer to kevnic2008. Piwo o sporej bialo snieznej piance, ale maÅ‚o trwalej niestety, sporym nagazowaniem jak pilsner, umiarkowanie slodowe, goryczkowe tez Å›rednio. Srednie piwo.

Bottle, bought since this was my former partner's favourite beer. Aroma is buttery, bisquit and slightly sulphuric, rather malty. Body is medium, with a present malty sweetness leading into a decently bitter palate. Not trying to be dry though. Lacks roundness, pales on many fronts. Not bad, just a bit boring.

â€œLang Pilsâ€œ, Flasche (50 cl) von Logo, Bischofsheim a.d. RhÃ¶n. - Goldgelb, blank. - In der Nase feines, etwas dÃ¼nnes helles Malz und ein wenig strapaziert wirkender krautig-zitroniger Hopfen. - Antrunk dÃ¼nn hellmalzig mit schwach kÃ¼nstlicher MalzsÃ¼ÃŸe und blasser, etwas schroffer Hopfenherbe - guter Aromahopfen schmeckt anders. Mild rezent, dÃ¼nn bis wÃ¤ÃŸrig. Schwach zitroniger Abgang. UnschÃ¶ner Nachtrunk mit ranzigen ZÃ¼gen. - EnttÃ¤uschend dÃ¼nnes Bier, dem die pilstypische Herbe aber auch feinere Hopfenaromen fehlen.

Herber, etwas hopfiger Beginn. Die Hopfigkeit weicht schnell, die Herbe ist dafÃ¼r weich und aromatisch. Im weiteren Verlauf erfrischend und klar, die Herbe steht klar im Vordergrund, erst im Nachgeschmack auch bitter und etwas hopfig. Einfaches aber gutes Pils. 6/9/10/10/8/10

50 cl bottle. Rated on 2.2.2010. Bright yellow colour, head stays on glass edges. Aroma is stale and grainy with hay and hints of vegetables. Flavout is thin, somewhat malty and slightly bitter with hints of hay. Drinkable, but feels bulky.

Itâ€™s golden with a huge, creamy, white head. The aroma has notes of malt, bread and light butter. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of butter, butterscotch, bread, malt and light citrus in a slightly dry finish.

Bottle: Golden coloured, medium-sized, slowly collapsing white head; grainy and sweet-malty nose with a distinctive aromatic hoppy touch; solid sweet-bitter flavour, medium-bodied, solid malty base; sweet-bitter aromatic short finish. All in all a quite pleasant Bier.......

(bottle) Clear, pale golden colour with a medium-sized foamy white head, leaving some lace. Herbal hops and light sweet pale malt in good balance dominate the aroma, unfortunately with a metallic tinge. Light sweet, even lighter bitter flavour, light to medium body with a rather soft carbonation. Soft malty base, quite bland, malt-accented, light hoppy taste, the latter leaves traces of metal during the slim, vaguely balanced finish. Mediocre and disappointing compared to the good Kupferbier.

Pale yellow color, not really lasting but well looking head. Sweet and spicy aroma. Starts sweet, continues spicier with a bitter touch on the tongue, longer dry and slightly bitter finish which I didn''t really like. Aftertaste lasts also too long, is herbal and sometimes bitter. Crisp impression. Overall characteristics a bit lacking.

Original review from 5/21/03. My God. I figured I had experienced bad beer. However, I had never had a Zhiguly Beer. Now that my eyesight has returned, I can write this review. This "beer" pours a cloudy, dark gold. On the downside &#40one of the many downsides&#41 there are particles of God knows what suspended in the liquid, like hundreds of little stink bombs just waiting to explode in your mouth. I know this is normal for this beer because folks at the Central Market in Plano have posted a sign on their cooler explaining that this is normal. In other words, we donâ€™t want this filth back! The head was incredibly vigorous. This, and the fact my tongue didnâ€™t melt, saves this beer from getting a "1" rating from me. I was mesmerized by the head. At least it was interesting to watch, kind of like a wildebeest being attacked by a lion...itâ€™s a fascinating sight but itâ€™s probably a bad idea to get in the middle of it. The odor is not inviting. Thereâ€™s a strong aroma of caramel and brown sugar. The flavor is not good but not the worst in the world...maybe itâ€™s just the worst in the western world. Roasted malt dominates the flavor...as in I can taste nothing else. There is no balance because thereâ€™s nothing to balance. Itâ€™s easy to juggle one apple. The mouthfeel is disappointing only because the incredible carbonation evident at the pour has dissipated to nearly nothing. Itâ€™s also a bit disconcerting because I expect the mystery particles to get caught between my teeth. I would hate to think I would have to floss after drinking a beer. If this is what I would have to look forward to if I ever visited Lithuania then I think Iâ€™ll go to Latvia instead. From this point on, I shall refer to this travesty as "liquid cancer."

big brown plastic bottle(2000ml). -as Gubernija Zhigulevskoe Svetloe Pivo. Yellow coloured, small white head that went away fast leaving no lace, low carbonation, weak corn nose. Lack of everything here, the closest description would go like this: water with notes of dried vegetables extract mixed withchicken meat or ragout... Hm, my dear American ratebeer friends whatâ€™s wrong here???

Gubernija Zhigulevskoe Svetloe Pivo brewed for the German distributor Monolith. ogivlado picked it up in a Russian store in Graz (thanks for sharing!). Poured an odd dull dark yellow/tan body with almost no head. Weak nose and Iâ€™m grateful that itâ€™s like that... smells of artificial chicken soup. The taste is weak and empty... cardboard, meat, peas, with some extremely weak (hoppy?) bitterness showing up from time to time. Less offensive than the sum of its parts but man this sucks.
Bottled. A golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma is skunky with metallic notes of alcohol. The flavor is metallic and alcoholic, leading to a dry metallic finish. Not good.
Hazy golden colour with a white head. Malty, grainy and sweet aroma with notes of grass. Malty, grainy flavor with some sweetness. Hay notes in a dry finish.
2 L plastic bottle. Pours slight hazy yellow and with a fully diminished white head. Butterish aroma, slight grainy. Grainy dry flavour with a finish of butter. Too much diacetyl for my liking.
Plastic bottle. A pale golden beer with a white head. The aroma and taste is rotten and of wet carboard. Light body, just realy bad!
Plastic bottle. Clear yellow coloured with a white ehad. Aroma of malts and grain with notes of cooked vegetables. Flavour of malts, grain and cooked vegetables.
Plastic bottle Hazy blond color. Common Lager, sweetish, with some hay/honeish character and respectable bitterness.

(Plastic bottle 200 cl) Actually comes as "Gubernija Zhigulevskoe Svetloe Pivo" in cyrillic letters - I reckon itâ€™s this one (although I absolutely donâ€™t understand the high US ratings!). Anyways, this pours slightly hazy golden with a tiny, unclean head. Odd aroma of vegetables, but not completely unpleasant. Medium body, a little flat in the mouthfeel - like most plasticbottled beers. Sweet accents of brewing cereal, a little cardboard and then a rough bitterness. Truly a relic from an ancient Soviet era. 301107

column1: Goose Island Dry Hopped Blonde Ale
column5: on tap from memory. this thin pale clear little beer actually had some decent hop flavor to it from the dry hopping. iâ€™ve never the non-dry hopped version but i think the dry hoping were the only thing this beer had going for it, not that it was over the top dry hopped but just noticible and pleasant. refreshing and decent.

column1: Goose Island Dry Hopped Blonde Ale
column5: Sample at the Clybourn location. Almost no head topping a clear amber body...light piney-bready nose is pleasant without distinction...very juicy with lime, perhaps a bit of melon, hops light and sprucy, more pale malt than anything...fairly dull really.

column1: Goose Island Dry Hopped Blonde Ale
column5: Draught, Clybourn Brewpub (2005 version): clear lemon with a thin starchy white head. Almost brisk hop aroma, that catches the nose, but doesnâ€™t stick â€“ sweet grains, lemon zest and pineapple are close at hand, but then disappear. You know, if I was drinking these all night I donâ€™t think I would mind â€“ mild flavoured with a bit hops and some grainy malt, but it is indistinct and unremarkable. Not bad.

column1: Goose Island Dry Hopped Blonde Ale
column5: At the brewpub. Light gold colored body. The aroma was nic efloral hops with some oranges and herbs. The taste was sweet potatoes with some bread crust. There was also a subtle orange zest at the end.

column1: Goose Island Dry Hopped Blonde Ale
column5: Rather a bland offering from GI. It looks nice, a clear gold with a frothy white head that does some fine lacing. The aroma is dominated by the light resinous hops. This is thin and watery in the mouth. The flavor is negligible, a faint sweet grainy malt with some appreciated hop bitterness. (It added something to the taste.) The finish was a subdued, herbal hop bitterness. Goose Island Beer Company - Clybourn, Chicago, IL

column1: Goose Island Dry Hopped Blonde Ale
column5: Cask. Clear golden orange body with a tight, thick white head. Subtle, hoppy nose of light pine, toasted grains, alcohol, caramel, oranges and a touch of lemon zest. The body is awfully thin, which allows this to go down like water. The flavor is pretty good, a touch of sweet malt before a mildly bitter finish. This isnâ€™t the best Goose offering, but they did take a boring product and make it a little more interesting. A lucky find, in my quest to try them all.

column1: Goose Island Dry Hopped Blonde Ale
column5: Utterly magnificent. Goose Island''s finest achievement. Not to be confused with their generic blonde ale. This brew is cask-conditioned and served about 10 degrees warmer than their other beers. Handpumped, no less. It''s dry hopped for a slight bitterness that''s wonderful. A very mild and creamy brew.
Draft. It was dark in the bar, but a deep amber colored with a creamy head. Bitter and hugely hoppy, like a IIPA without the sweetness. Smooth and crisp, but not balanced. I enjoyed it.

Draft over Christmas. Slightly cloudy dark straw colored with a creamy white head and great lace. Aroma of big hops, malt, slight green tea. Tastes hoppy, malty, with a green tea essence. Medium palate. Crisp and smooth finish, but needs a tad more balance.
On tap at the GLI. Poured a medium hazy orangish color with a smaller off white head. Citric aroma and tastes (oranges). Nice hoppy, bitter finish.
Draft at the brewery. Nice IPA. Had a good dry hop bite to it...............

Second holiday beer this year from the General Lafayette. I wouldn''t call this beer a clone of Celebration Ale, but it''s close in taste and hop bitterness. I had this on draft and cask version, liked the cask version better for the extra bitterness.

On tap at the brewpub. It pours a clear pale golden body under a small, white head. Butterscotch and some grains and fruits on the nose. A bit less butterscotch in the flavor, but itâ€™s still there. Not much bitterness going on, barely dealing with the grains and fruits. Medium to thin on the palate. Short finish. A very forgettable beer, not one Iâ€™d choose again. 130903
Pale, clear yellow. Thin, watery, faint noble hop at the finish. I guess its good for what its supposed to be (something lite to drink when you want to hang out with people drinking beer).
On tap at the brewpub Appearance: Light yellow with a small white head and no lacing Aroma: Light citrus and malts Taste: Citrus, grainy and honey Light and refreshing, a decent light beer.

Sample at the brewpub. Rating #19. Light golden pour with a pretty nice white head. Light grainy aroma with maybe a little butteriness. Getting a little butter in the flavor as well, not too great. (1793)

A: The pour is a pale golden straw with a short lived white head. S: Not surprisingly, there is a lot of corn. In fact, the aroma is mostly corn. There is a little bit of apple juice sweetness, and maybe some grassy hops. Overall, though, not very much going on. T: Like with the aroma, thereâ€™s a very light flavor. Also like the aroma, the flavor is mostly corn. Thereâ€™s some water and apple juice, and maybe even a light tartness. Very mild malt and a hint of yeast. M: Light and watery with a medium carbonation. O: Pretty unimpressive, but thatâ€™s what I was expecting.
Taster at the Anaheim location. Pours light gold with a thin tan head. The nose is grain, malt and light grass. The taste is pretty much the same with some biscuit thrown in. Lighter bodied. OK beer.
Draft. a light golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma has light skunky notes of malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and straw, leading to a lightly bitter finish.
From tap at the brewpub. Pours pale yellow with a small white head. Mild fruity and citrusy aroma. Flavour is light sweet, crisp bitterness. Light lasting fruity flavour into the far finish.
On tap. Clear yellow with a white head. Discreet malty aroma. Medium-bodied, lightly sweet malts and a little sulphur. Finishes dry. Fairly clean and decent for a light. 050709

On tap at the JT Schmids Brew Pub located in Anaheim, CA. Poured a medium yellow color wtih a small sized white head. Aromas of grains, -husky-, and I was getting some floralness. Tastes of the same graininess and just all around sweetness. Thin and watery body with watery tastes.
From backlog. On tap at The Brewpub in Anaheim. Golden with white head. Malts, hops, Tropical fruits and some bitterness.

Deep golden with a white head - Good hop aroma with some tropical fruity tones - Good malt body to support the hops that has tropical fruity flavour with a good bitterness - The hops with bitterness goes into the finish - This was good
Pours a rich orange color with a floral aroma. Taste is floral and slightly bitter. A simple aftertaste, with a minor bitterness. A not so complex beer with decent flavor overall.
Harshly bitter unpleasant flavor. very glad I did not follow my first instinct and order a full pint. After the sample tree I had water and better beer back at the motel.

Tap at the Tustin venue. Pours light amber with a creamy white head. Aroma starts mixed citrus/pine and suddenly goes floral. Med body or nearly. Flavor is rather floral/citrus over light caramel. Finishes decently bitter.

25 June 2014, tap at JT Schmids. Light, dirty orange, a bit hazy. Nose is pine hops with some sweet malt. Med body and mildly fizzy. Sweet granola malt, mild alcohol, sugary, some pine hops but nothing big or lingering. Sweet malt more than anything. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at the brewpub. Great lacing, big chill haze. Amber red color. Sheets of white lace. A bit dark for style. Nose is sticky, nutty, mild acetone/solvent. Taste is dusty, nutty, husky, biting bitterness. Sharply bitter and metallic. Big nut skin. Papery, astringently bitter palate. A bit too harsh with big sweet candy.

On tap at the brewpub. Itâ€™s a dark golden beer, clear, and topped by a small, off-white colored head leaving some lacings. The aroma is pretty nice, citrus peel, pine cones and some tropical fruits, some malty hints in the far back. Thereâ€™s a bit more maltyness in the mouth, with a touch of caramel, but still itâ€™s the hops that run the show. Bitterness, citrus peel and tropical fruits. Nice carbonation level, but it could use a bit more body. Mostly bitter and citrusy finish. Sure, a nice and quite well tasting IPA that I could down a few of. 130903
Faint lemony hop aroma. Slightly sweet malt flavor with pine bitterness. Its an IPA.
Not overpowering... Pretty good hop character. Smooth for an IPA. Pours a deep copper. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a light cola brown with a malty aroma. Taste is nutty, with a slight roast flavor. A refreshing aftertaste that coats the tongue with a light sweetness similar to caramel.
Dark wood amber colour. Thin with a burnt bark finish and a bitter aftertaste. Sampled at Anaheim location.

Tap at the Tustin venue. Pours ruddy amber with a beige head. Aroma of fruit, nuts an mild malt. Med body. Flavor is light caramel with light stone fruits and a hint of nut. Finishes rather crisp and clean, and very slightly bitter.

25 June 2014, tap at JT Schmids. Amber, clear, no bubbles. Nose is a bit medicinal, sweet, weird. Thin/med body and mildly fizzy. Soft blue fruit, medicinal, sweet bread. Something is weird tasting. Not a fan.

Tap at the brewpub. Clear deep amber with weak foam. Good lacing though. Soft maple nose with sweet tea. Clean, malty with flashes of richer DMS style creamed corn. Inoffensive, simple. Richer malt profile. Probably their best.

On tap at the brewpub. A dark amber colored beer, clear, with a small, light beige head on top. Cute curtains. The aroma is a bit on the malty side for an amber I think, lacking on hops. Caramel tending towards butterscotch, some dried apricots too. It could also use a bit more bittering hops, not only aroma hops. Medium body and a nice carbonation level. Mostly malty finish, with some hoppy flavors in the back. A rather boring amber, but at least not foul. 130903
Flight at brewpub. Amber (duh). Malty and slightly sweet. Its pretty basic, but the flavor is nice.

Tap at brewpub. (Why did I go to an Angelâ€™s game two hours early and not bring my own beer?!) Aroma, bland. Appearance, good for the style but how can it not be? Amber with white head that is rather foamy. Taste, slight malt, hay, tiny citrus. Palate, bland. Overall, bland but drinkable compared to the other styles on tap.
On tap at the brewpub Appearance: Clear amber with a small white head and spotty lacing Aroma: Mild caramel and malty Taste: Caramel and citrus Ok but nothing special

Sample at the pub. Rating #19. Nice dark amber pour with a tan head. Toasty caramel aroma, very pleasant. Flavor also has a bit of toast and maybe a little astringentcy as well, but decent overall. (1795)

On tap at the brewpub. It pours an almost black body, topped by a dense, dark beige head. Cute lacings. Roasted, almost burnt aroma with licorice, coffee and some syrup. Not very sweet on the palate, full to medium bodied and very soft, with flavors of roasted malts, black coffee, licorice, dark syrup and some dark chocolate. Decent bitterness all the way. Lasting finish. A quite pleasant one, both tasteful and easy drinkable. 130903
Roasty, with a mix of sweet and bitter. A bit of chocolate comes through at the end with some alcohol burn. Medium body. Not bad.

Pours a dark almost black color and has a nice tan head that laces the glass. Has an aroma of chocolate, malts, coffee and hopps. Taste follows the aroma. Notes of coffee, malts, chocolate and some hopps in the after taste. Not a bad stout, but i thought the bitterness toom away from the other characteristics of the stout. Plus the bitterness lingered around after the swallow.

On tap at the brewpub Appearance: Black with a medium sized tan head and good lacing Aroma: Roasted malts and coffee Taste: Roasted malts, grainy, roasted coffee and chocolate A nice stout, full bodied and well balanced.

Sample. Rating #22. Pretty much pitch black with a really dark brown head. Nice light sweet chocolate aroma with a touch of hops. Roasty dark chocolate, almost smoky and it really lingers for a bit, big and bold. (1796)

A: The pour is almost black with a thick, off-white head. S: Roast is the primary aroma here. A decent amount of char along with some coffee. Thereâ€™s a nice sweetness of licorice and burnt sugar as well as a mild molasses and dark chocolate character. T: Nice coffee notes up front with plenty of roast and dark chocolate. Like with the aroma, thereâ€™s some good licorice and burnt sugar notes. However, this is a bit too sweet overall. M: Iâ€™d call the body medium with a smooth carbonation. O: Up there with the IPA in terms of the house beers. A nice stout, though it could do with a touch less sweetness.

Taster at brew pub. Pours ox blood with a halfer finger tan head. The nose is coffee, oats and burnt malt. The taste is cocoa, charred malt, coffee and some hops in the finish. Medium bodied. Pretty damn good â€“ best of their line-up.

Draft. A pitch black beer with a brown head. The aroma has strong notes of roasted malt and soy sauce as well as some sweet malt. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of roasted malt and soy sauce, as well as lighter notes of coffee, leading to a dry roasted finish.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown to black with a minimal and tan head. Hardroasted malt aroma, light breadish and chocolate note. Acidic roasted flavour with a distinct liqourice hoppy note. Bitter and acidic finish. A bit too overdone on the roasted flavours.

On tap. Pours black with a vague orangey hue and a light brown head leaving laces. Sweetish roasted malt aroma with some hints of licorice. Medium body, sweetish hard roasted malt, licorice and tobacco. Some malt bitterness in the finish. 050709

Clear chestnut. Dense, modest tan foam. Trace carbonation. Deeply caramelled aroma with hints of dates and almonds. Initially dry and lightly astringent with a walnut skin bitterness and burnt caramel aftertaste. Medium body. Not a hefty girth to the brew but a wide array of Brown malt flavors. Very dry, yet smooth and easy to consume. Finishes lighter with an astringent edge to a nutty, toffee mix. Another well made brew.

column1: Abbaye d'Aulne Triple Blonde Sur Lie
column5: Huge frothy head, orange cloudy color. Aroma of bread, a little of sugar, grass, coriander. Medium body, excellent alcohol masking. Medium carbonation. Taste is mildly fruity (banana, apple), smoothly spicy; simple but very well balanced. Finishes with a nicely fruity hint.

column1: Abbaye d'Aulne Triple Blonde Sur Lie
column5: Lekkerste bier van het assortiment van Abbaye dâ€™Aulne. Echt een aanrader. Ik drink graag tripels, maar dit is 1 van de beste.

column1: Abbaye d'Aulne Triple Blonde Sur Lie
column5: The â€™realâ€™, i.e. blonde, triple in the ADA series, with a thick, mousse-like, off-white, sticky head and golden blonde colour with an orange glow, misty. Aroma of cara malts and subdued fruitiness, hints of peach, honey, grass, old cheese, orange peel, yoghurt, bread dough, chamomille; tastes light fruity, malty, a bit citrussy, light carbonisation, smooth mouthfeel with subtle spiciness (coriander?), gentle finish with just enough hops to balance, alcohol well hidden. Nothing out of the ordinary, nothing particularly delicious or exciting, just an average standard abbey triple.

column1: Abbaye d'Aulne Triple Blonde Sur Lie
column5: Bottle @ bandlys blÃ¥lys. Clear yellow body with a small white head. Aroma is yeast, butter. Flavour is yeast, grain and butter.

column1: Abbaye d'Aulne Triple Blonde Sur Lie
column5: Bela Tripel belga. Cor amarelo-ouro, com Ã³tima formacao de espuma, duradoura. Aroma frutado, algo cÃ­trico, lembrando frutas amarelas. Na boca, sobressai o fermento tÃ­pico do estilo, com notas de banana, cravo, pao, frutas amarelas, Ã¡lcool. Final longo, com retrogosto frutado, Ã¡lcool no fim. Excelente breja! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Abbaye d'Aulne Triple Blonde Sur Lie
column5: Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is malt, fruity yeast and grain. Flavour is malt, grain, grass, pine and fruity yeast.

column1: Abbaye d'Aulne Triple Blonde Sur Lie
column5: Pera e temperos dominam o aroma. O sabor se dÃ¡ com frutas cÃ­tricas com um "Q" de pimenta. Final doce e saboroso.

column1: Abbaye d'Aulne Triple Blonde Sur Lie
column5: Very light, gold color and strong and good taste. Very easy to drink. ...... ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Abbaye d'Aulne Triple Blonde Sur Lie
column5: 8/II/13 - 33cl bottle from Willems (Grobbendonk) @ home - BB: 5/X/13 (2013-143) Thanks to Erwin for sharing the bottle! Little cloudy pale yellow beer, irregular fizzy off-white head, unstable, adhesive, nice lacing. Aroma: very sweet, dish washing product, artificial lemon, quite some banana. MF: ok carbon, light to medium body. Taste: pretty bitter, grassy, sugar, caramel, hint of chocolate. Aftertaste: banana, bit yeasty, bitter. Downhill again...

column1: Abbaye d'Aulne Triple Blonde Sur Lie
column5: Bottle @ Bandlys BlÃ¥lys, Odense 2012. Pours clear golden with a frothy white head. Lots of grain and corn. Sweet..

Pours clear blonde, no head obviously. No head. Smell is intense, honey, bit dry. Taste is thick, sweet, bit wattery ( in the aspect you can taste some minerals, not the body ) medium intense ginger. Nice, but not great.
750mL bottle from Vintage Wines. Ginger aromas, floral, honey. Clear deep gold. Flavors of gingery spice balancing sweet honey liqueur. Full bodied.
Everybody shoul try Mead. Very interesting experience, and not for those, who only drinks pilsener.
Hazy amber. Aroma of honey, wood and alcohol. Sweetness is balanced by a slight bitter and alcoholic finish.

I work Ren Fairs and i drink alot (ALOT) of Mead, its not for every one but at the same time dont judge it like its a beer, cause its not one. its a for me its got the right amount of sweet but its not too sweet a problem i find with alot of Meadâ€™s i feel like the hops cut some out and helped tone it back. over all i enjoyed it will continue to enjoy it and will save this nice bottle when im done.
I thought I might dig this hopped one the most, but it ended up my least favorite. Musky and prefumey hops, and still tons of honey, which is nice enough, but a touch cloying here.

Aroma is good with brandy and honey. Color is also good with a clear, burnished brass. Flavor was good at first with a boozy honey, but I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s the ginger, hops or what, but I pick up mold and that kills it for me.

Bottle courtesy of a Vi with the Vuong family for Daddy Vuongs birthday. Pours a clear golden body with no lace. Aroma is honey and perfume. Mouthfeel is slick and sugary with notes of honey, alcohol and lots of perfume.
Small bottle from my man dedollewaitor, thanks buddy. Clear golden body with no head. Floral, herbs, honey, cheesy notes, alcohol notes. Quite good actually.
Golden coloured and clear. Has on head. Sweet, honey aroma, spicy. FLavor is heavy sweet, some herbal notes.

Pours a clear golden amber with a decent eggshell head. Malty aroma has a hoppy overtone. Slightly sweet malty flavor has a firm hoppy tone and a hint of pear. Texture is smooth and pleasing, if not very fizzy. Mark a point of taking a break and try it.

Part of a sampler at brewpub. Rating this from memory because it has been awhile since I was there but tried several of the Trinity offerings over the course of a couple of visits where I ordered sampler flights each time. Overall impression was that they made a decent brew in each of the styles they offeredbut nothing overly spectacular in any of them.
Draft at brewpup, unfiltered. Pours golden amber with a white head. Light bodied. Flavor of toasted and pilsner malts, with a hint of peanut shells. Dry and slightly bitter finish.
Pours copper with a white head. Smells of earthy hops and some malt. Taste is of earthy hops and some nutty undertones.
Amber gold. Small white head. Pine hops aroma. A definite American Pale Ale, fairly aggressively hopped. But well balanced enough.
Draft at the brewery: poured golden with orange notes. Medium white head. Very light flowery hop aroma. Light hop flavor, no malt. Very thin finish. Again, not much to speak of.
Light amber in color with a small white lacing around the rim. Mild toasted malt aroma with a touch of citrus. Toasted malt and citrus flavor,very thin body.

Has a hazy reddish gold color with small off-white head and little carbonation. Smell is of fruity hops. Taste is lightly malted and finishes with a strong hop/grapefruit bitter finish. Overall a pretty good beer.

Hazy caramel with white head. I agree with Argo, it did seem more like an IPA in both aroma and flavor. (Actually I had ordered an IPA and was told that they were out, but that this was quite similar to what I had ordered.) Hop flavor dominates. One of the better beers Iâ€™ve had from Trinity, but Iâ€™m still not that impressed.
Reddish-gold, medium head, nice lacing. Fairly bitter and fruity all the way through, thin-to-medium body. Not bad, not really good, ehhh.
Dark brown with a creamy head. Aroma is sweet and vanilla. Flavor is sweet vanilla with a touch of roastiness. Pretty one-dimensional beer.

(Thanks to Papsoe) 33 cl bottle. Golden colour with a fluffy white head. Yeast aroma with tones of light spice and alcohol. Also yeasty flavour with some spice and wheat, very light and drinkable. Someway too tasty for a blond. Very carbonated.

(Bottle 33 cl) Slightly hazy pilsener golden with a handsome, creamy, white head. Vague aroma of yeast and malt. Rather high carbonation. Malty and excessively sulphurous. Dry finish. A disappointment. 291205
Very pale colored, foamy head. Very soft soapy aroma. Soapy, flowery, alcoholic flavor. Cologne. Nasty by-flavors rule, where hops and malt should go first.
A hazy yellow beer with a huge white head. The aroma is acidic though sweet with notes of alcohol and metal. The flavor is also acidic and weird with the main notes being malt and alcohol.
Golden color, sweet light alcoholic aroma, winy tasta, medium body, dry winy finish.
Bottled. Hazy golden, rich head. Sweet and honeyish with medium body. Malty and very soft. Wonderful mouthfeel, but without the flavours to make it really great.
Malty and maybe a little grainy aroma. Golden color, white head, good lace. Light sweet, malty, light bitter to bitter in the finish, little syrupy.
Blond beer with medium, shiny white head. there is a bit of rubber in the otherwise hoppy aroma. The taste is hop, rubber and alcohol. It is also quite short. It has a bitter dry finish.

Tasted some ten years ago when this brewery was still active. More an abt than a dubbel, this strong dark beer had a yellowish beige, thick creamy, rather unstable head and dark bronze colour with ruby hue, misty. Aroma was dark malts, milk chocolate, hazelnuts, a whiff of coffee grounds, lots of coriander, brown candi sugar, rhum, liquorice, blackcurrant, passion fruit, banana, marzipan, cinnamon, fried eggs. Full and creamy palate, sweet in onset, slick, chocolatey and caramelly with fruity accents (banana, pear), drying coriander effect in the middle, finish with lots of port-like alcohol but not too astringent, aromatically hoppy and ever so lightly roasted bitterish. Well crafted example of the style, too bad this isnâ€™t made anymore.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 3 &nbsp Light Brown(1)->Dark(5) : 4 &nbsp Ruby : XX &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 3 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 3 &nbsp White(1)->Tan(5) : 2 &nbsp Lasting: 2 &nbsp Lacing : 2 Aroma: Intensity : 3 &nbsp Yeast : 2 &nbsp Bread : 3 &nbsp Apple : XX &nbsp Esters : 2 &nbsp Banana : 2 &nbsp Phenols : XX &nbsp Leather : XX &nbsp Perfume : 2 &nbsp DMS : XX &nbsp Diacetyl : XX Malt : 3 &nbsp Biscuity : 4 &nbsp Toast : 3 &nbsp Caramel : 3 &nbsp Toffee : XX &nbsp Maple : XX &nbsp Molasses : XX &nbsp Nuts : 3 &nbsp Candy : XX &nbsp Pumpernickel : XX &nbsp Cereals : XX &nbsp Fruits : XX &nbsp Chocolate : 2 &nbsp Coffee : XX &nbsp Vanilla : XX &nbsp Grapes : XX &nbsp Blackberries : XX &nbsp Dates : XX &nbsp Cherries : XX &nbsp Plums : XX &nbsp Figs : 3 Hops : 1 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : XX &nbsp Floral : XX &nbsp Orange : XX &nbsp Herbal : XX &nbsp Spicy : XX &nbsp Pine/Spruce/Resin : XX Notes : &nbsp Earth : 2 &nbsp Wood : XX &nbsp Cloves : XX &nbsp Smoke : XX &nbsp Pepper : XX &nbsp Ginger : XX &nbsp Peach/Pear/Apricot : 2 &nbsp Candi Sugar : XX &nbsp Anise : XX &nbsp Vinous : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 4 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3 &nbsp Sourness : 1 &nbsp Bitterness : 1 &nbsp Complex : 3 &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 3 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 4 &nbsp Clean : XX &nbsp Sharp : XX &nbsp Watery : XX &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : XX &nbsp Alcohol : 2 &nbsp Mineral : XX &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Metallic : XX Comments: Quite biscuity Belgian ale with a sour bready yeastiness. A bit chaotic, but no oxidation noticed.

Bottled. (thx to papsoe for sharing) Copper, unclear beer with a beige head. Quite malty and sweet nose and flavor. Medium to full body and a sweet and malty finish. A decent beer, but nothing more. (070510=
Bottle. Red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is roasted, malt, alcohol. Flavour is caramel, alcohol, fruit, roasted, malt, herbal hop. Complex beer.
(Bottle 33 cl) Hazy, orangey brown with a dense, beige head. Aroma of roasted malt. Rather full-bodied, sweetish, roasted malt and some fruit - a whiff of metal. Subdued bitterness. Quite OK. 100507
Caramel and flowers in the aroma. Sweet and alcoholic. Just a touch of vegetables and caramel. No specific aftertaste.

33 cl bottle, â€™bbeâ€™ Aug 07. Dark red with a minimal beige head. Aroma of dark malts with chocolate notes. Dark malts, some choco, some herbal hop notes in the taste. Good body, light warming finish. A good yet undistinguished dark beer.

A hazy red-brown beer with a small disappearing orange head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel, malt, and hops. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel leading to a dry end stemming from a good hop-sort.
Red-brown color, light alcoholic sweet caramel aroma and taste, full body, bitter sweet finish.
Bottled. Clear reddish brown. Caramel aroma. Full bodied with lovely, soft maltiness and sparkling mouthfeel. Salt and grassy hops. Well balanced.

Flaske fra 1988 (!) pÃ¥ Cardinaltreff feb-13, stor takk til Ivar for omtanken. En helt spesiell opplevelse Ã¥ Ã¥pne en 25 Ã¥r gammel juleÃ¸l. Uklar oransje farge med snev av skum. Eimen som steg opp av glasset var langt fra behagelig, men den ble nÃ¦rmest portvinsaktig nÃ¥r den hadde fÃ¥tt luftet seg litt. Overraskende god smak med streif av honning og portvin. En Ã¸lopplevelse helt utenom det vanlige!

Bottle ,vintage 1988, kindly shared by Ivar. Poured a light dirty and hazy orange, no head. Aroma is strong caramel, a bit of oxidation can be felt, also in the tasting department, but not as bad as feared. Good malty taste with a sharp edgy bitter aftertaste, probably one of the best beers from a former Ringnes brewery.

Kindly shared by my beerpal, Ivar. Clear 0,33 l shared bottle. Opaque orange with a white rim. Over-ripe plums on the nose. Honey, port, sweet pungent flavors. Medium to full body. Surprisingly good given the age.

This traditional "klasse F" (strong) Christmas beer has the last years been given the lowest or second lowest "klasse F" rating in Norwegian newspapers. I can understand why - it's now too lightbodied for its strength, flavour is slightly metallic, a substantial bitterness is not balanced by an equally substantial malty sweetness like a real "JuleÃ¸l" should have. Colour is reddish brown, low head. I think this beer was considerably better 20 - 30 years ago, before Tou Bryggeri (Stavanger) became part of the Ringnes group.

column1: Castelain Ch'Ti CuvÃ©e de NoÃ«l Blonde
column5: Ins Glas ergieÃŸt sich ein leicht trÃ¼bes dunkelgoldenes Bier mit schÃ¶ner Schaumkrone. Geruch fruchtig malzig, wÃ¼rzig, hefig. Geschmack fruchtig sÃ¼ÃŸ, wÃ¼rzig malzig.

column1: Castelain Ch'Ti CuvÃ©e de NoÃ«l Blonde
column5: Golden with floating corns but white good foam. Mild thick aroma apples. Taste is light fruit, alcohol, light bitter aftertaste that gets magnifired

column1: Castelain Ch'Ti CuvÃ©e de NoÃ«l Blonde
column5: Bottle shared with Deanso. Poured a clear copper colour with a thick white head and broken lace. The aroma is strong and malty. The flavour is pretty much the same. The palate is weak and the aftertaste watery. This beer lacks body and flavour.

column1: Castelain Ch'Ti CuvÃ©e de NoÃ«l Blonde
column5: 75cl bottle shared with jmgreenuk. Thick white head. Clear amber pour. Nice enough brew.

column1: Castelain Ch'Ti CuvÃ©e de NoÃ«l Blonde
column5: Bottle. Pours a dark gold colour with a firm white head, the aroma is malty and with fruity the taste is fruity with a dry finish.

column1: Castelain Ch'Ti CuvÃ©e de NoÃ«l Blonde
column5: spruce, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, amber, hazy, minimal head, white foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, flat, long finish,

column1: Castelain Ch'Ti CuvÃ©e de NoÃ«l Blonde
column5: Botella. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is spiced and sweet like with something maltish. Ok mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet and spiced like with some maltiness,lightly fruity, fair bitterness.

column1: Castelain Ch'Ti CuvÃ©e de NoÃ«l Blonde
column5: Bottle, bought @ LIVA, Kolding. Clear golden with a super-nice, staying, creamy white head. A truly perfect looking blonde. Aroma is sweetish, citric, doughy. Light herbal. High carbonation, lightish mouthfeel. Flavour has some pilsner-feel to it at first, citric and sugary, but redeems itself with an okay malty sweetness with a finish with a light vinious finish. Average, but truly pretty.

column1: Castelain Ch'Ti CuvÃ©e de NoÃ«l Blonde
column5: Bottled. Pours deep golden with a nice off-white head. Nose of caramel, fruit and spicy notes. Sweet flavor of caramel, spices,fruit and brown sugar. Medium bodied, watery to oily texture and average carbonation. Ends up more dryand with a little bitterness.

column1: Castelain Ch'Ti CuvÃ©e de NoÃ«l Blonde
column5: Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. MOderate malty and hoppy aroma. Powerfull fruity esters. Moderate bitter flavor. Some fruity esters. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.

Geruch wie altes Wurstwasser, bernsteinfarbig. Der Antrunk ist mild-wÃ¤ssrig, leicht sÃ¼ÃŸlich-herb. Hat wirklich ein Bisschen was von Wurstwasser. Im Hauptteil mild und aufdringlich sÃ¼ÃŸlich. Der Nachgeschmack ist lang-anhaltend, penetrant sÃ¼ÃŸlich-komisch. 4/10/1/3
Nice blond beer, with good foamy head. Pale yellow color. Slightly watery taste, fruity yeast aromaâ€™s give it some body. Very easy drinkable.

Bottle 75cl. @ The Danish Summer Gathering Tasting, TSODRBSG09. Clear medium orange color with a average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, caramel, wood, moderate yeasty. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090822]
Large bottle (75cl) with champagne cork, gold colour and thin head, not much aroma, slightly malty and sweet taste. It was ok with a BBQ in France

Bottle, 75cl corked, courtesy of MiP. Itâ€™s a clear, golden beer topped by an off-white head. The aroma is a nice blend of grains and fruits with a little spiced touch and some hops. The flavor is a bit too much on the citrusy side, else itâ€™s more or less like the aroma, a pleasant blend of grains and fruityness with the hops giving a little bitterness. The coriander can also be sensed. Medium to full body, quite dry. A decent and easy drinkable beer. 090821
Clear golden colour. Sweet fruity and yeasty aroma. Flavour: fruity and yeasty, soft bitterness, some wheat and spice &#40coriander&#41.
Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of MiP. Clear golden with a white head. Sweetish malty nose, some flower accents and phenols. Medium body with sweet malts and a yeasty note. Quite a phenollic finish. 220809
Bottle, 6.6%. Fruity aroma. Clear golden colour. Small stable white head. The flavour is OK yeasty, a little caramelly. Has a little spicy clove. Quite sweet, but not bad.

Itâ€™s a warm golden beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of coriander, yeast, candy sugar and fruit. The flavor has sweetness and notes of coriander, yeast, wheat, citrus and the finish is slightly dry and spicy. Very smooth and pleasant.
Bottle. Low white and fluffy quickly disappearing head. Clear golden body. Fruity honey mild and sweet aroma. Sweet apple pear flavor with a low carbonation and a long aftertaste.
NIce copper flavour, but i keeping it for a while in the mouth, the taste changes. It has a realy good foam and the dark colour is awesme. Nice malty and bitter aroma. Finally I got it.

shiny amber in color with a wafer thin sheet of froth rising from the sides in levitating glory..the aroma hinted at orange peels and had a nutty atmosphere..the mouthfeel was surprisingly thick..the flavor rang in nutty tones and bitterness was layed across to keep it warm..some scotch & whiskey sang through also..
dough, alcohol, woody, rotten eggs, soy sauce, hay, roasty, floral, amber, cloudy, frothy, light sweetness, very bitter, medium sourness, umami, full body, sticky, soft carbonation, bitter,
Bottled. Amber with white head. Aroma of malt and elderflower. Flavor is malt, spices and elderflower.
Bottle, at home (031225). Amber with a very fine head. Aroma light malty (elderflower) and hoppy. Flavor light sweet and bitter.

(Bottle 50 cl) I believe Elysium was the drink of the Gods in both Greek and Roman mythology. Well, this lacks a bit to achieve just that... Amber in colour with a very fine head. The elderflower is mainly present in the palate, but this beer seems oddly inharmonious in some strange way. Go for the Badgers Golden Champion if you like elderflower. 010104
Drank this beer as Golden Jubilee. The elderflower gives a slightly spicy flavour with only slight and not lasting bitterness. Very pale in colour and not having as much aroma as expected
( on bottle)Actually not that much elderflower in the aroma; more like apple to me. Sweet/fresh taste, IÂ´ll take this for a summer drink, before many others.
Orange colour with elderflower dominating the aroma and flavor. Palate is very thin.
golden orange colour, with clear elderflower nose and taste, will do well with the ladies, and on a hot summersday

Golden to orange color, nice perlage. Simple aroma: sweet, a bit malty, oranges, rubber. Simple taste, with a residual sweetness and a light pleasant fruitness. Nice bitterness, and in the finish finally we find the elderflowers. Easy and interesting drink before a dinner.
Dark with an average head. Subtle roasted character. Light chocolate and coffee throughout and hoppy bitterness in the finish. A pleasant and satisfying porter.

Draft at Clybourn brewpub. Poured hazy dark brown color with medium off-white fizzy head that diminished slowly with good lacing. Medium brown sugar aroma. Medium body with light carbonation. Medium balanced sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Sweet drinkable brew.

On tap at Goose Island - Clybourn. Poured deep, hazy reddish-brown with a short yellowy-beige head. The aroma picked up dark fruits, caramel, and chocolate with a deeply-rooted, clearly evident alcohol presence.. came across quite brash. The flavor had sweet drawn caramel and brown sugar at the core laced with raw grainy alcohol.. the same sweetness found the finish, as did the booziness that marred my enjoyment of the beer. Medium-bodied on the palate with lower carbonation.. too much sharpness.

Date: 10/18/1998 Mode: Firkin Source: Brewpub dark ruby, fine tan head, light chocolate malt aroma, rich malt flavor, lots of chocolate, slightly sweet, rich and chewy chocolate, an excellent chocolate porter disguised as a brown ale Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 17/20 Rating: 3.7/5.0 Score: ****/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

pretty good. red/brown appearance with a decent head. flavors start sweet with nut caramel and toffee. as it finishes the flavors become more grainy/bready. a strong brown ale, but not exceedingly exciting.
Not as rich or complex as the nut brown. A little thin, a little translucent. Taste is initially bitter, but fades fast. a little nutty and sweet. Meh.

I had this at the Clybourne and i got the regular nut brown and this to see if i could tell the difference. truth is no. The regular nut brown was darker and was more creamier. Maybe was more nutty in aroma. Other than the extra alcohol there is no reason to spend the extra dollar on a pint of this.

A small, tan head is very fizzy above a deep mahogany body (that matched the bar), with carbonation equally evident within. There is an initial light touch of hops in the aroma followed by whisky and a sharp lemon bite. Malts take a backseat until the flavor, where they are revealed with a wicked-potency. This fades slowly to simple tea-bitters. With a lively mouthfeel itâ€™s rather sharp & crisp for such a malty brew. On tap at Goose Island Beer Company (Clybourn), Chicago, IL 60614

Maybe if Iâ€™d had the cask version that the others have rated this year, Iâ€™d be more excited about this beer. What I had was a 6.9% sweet, malty brown ale with very few hops to balance it out. Quaffable, but merely "okay." Goose Island Beer Company - Clybourn, Chicago, IL

Sampled on Cask at GI Clybourne This beer is a full brown color, and it is topped by a frothy tan colored head. The aromas is lightly roasty with notes of coffee, caramel, and a hint of burnt fruit. The taste is sweet, with a malty fullness to it that is quite nice. I also get notes of brandy, cherries, alcohol, rum and caramel. This beer is so soft and creamy, with a low carbonation to it. This is definitely a great beer to have on cask, it seems to soften it and make it all that much more quaffable. This is tasty and I am quite enjoying the glass of beer that I was poured.

On cask in Wrigleyville. Reddish brown, largest foamy head--not at all like the creamy head I like to see on cask conditioned ales. Nose is earthy, slightly sour. Smooth mouthfeel, almost flat. Not exactly earthshaking but drinkable.
minimal head sits upon a pale yellow poor. Not much in the way of aroma. A nice crisp taste. Nice enough for a straight up pale ale
330ml Bottle. Just updating my records. A very nice pale ale. Subtle fruit aromas with a crisp refreshing finish

Neat frothy head mild to medium carbonation gold pour aroma floral hoppy fruit earthy bright aromas flavour stone fruit apricot resinous peach earthy mild bitter floral note finish resiny taste sweet mild bitter pleasant pale

didnt have high expectations for this beer so i wasnt let down. an inital smell of skunk soon disapated, the colour and head isnt much to speak of, rather poor. tastes of orange and hoppy citrus flavours, mid to high carbonation, overall quite an average beer. i really dont think it should be in the 48th percentile, i can think of many other beers that rate lower and are much more enjoyable

Pours lively but settles down with haste. Carbonation minute, in fine streams. Head struggles its height retreating back to a thin pad of white with no lacing. Body is orange amber, not quite clear with some floaties of questionable origin. The bottle looks as though clear glass has been spray-painted with cola coloured lacquer, strange!!. Aroma of mango and peach, salted, roasted nuts, rubber and vine clippings. Creamy mouthfeel dulls out quick, light in body. Some bitterness to the back end and into the swallow. Light notes of toasted grain and pine-wood, some freshness of orange flesh and zest. Aftertaste of peanuts, pine and subtle citrus. Pretty unexciting unfortunately. Slam one back with too much ease, nothing here to get the brain ticking. Think Iâ€™ll stick with there Pilsner given the choice!! (33cL, no date stamp, Dan Murphyâ€™s Mandurah)
fantastic pale ale, very drinkable. grassy with some strong fruity flavours

Bottle: Looks pleasantly summery in the glass; all froth and golden highlights. In the nose there is some tart malt and a faint whiff of lemon. Rolled around the mouth, this beer gives a pleasant creamy mouthfeel, with a very restrained but well utilised bitterness. I found myself wishing for more flavour, though. Sure there is plenty of golden malt and a memory of fresh bitey herbs, but I wanted some character and some distinction. Still, this isnâ€™t to take away the good points of what is a solid drinking beer.

Thin white head over a light amber body. Nose of grass and fresh cut lawns, hints of a salty breeze as well. Apricot and hop grass notes, bittier finish. Crisp palate. Actually reminds me of Storm Golden Ale out of Bali. Not bad...

Tap. Nice aroma, but too sweet flavour. Aroma is citrusy, and bubblegum. Flavour is sweet, with average length, and only light bitterness. Palate is oily, and medium-bodied. Yellow colour, with a fizzy head that disappears.

Bottle. Gold with fading white head. Hay malts and floral and citrus hops on the nose. Clean, slightly bitter finish. This is a weird beer. I disliked it the first time I had it because I was expecting some sort of pale ale. I see itâ€™s listed here as gold/ blond. But it comes across as a pils with some wit characteristics. Once my confounded expectations were adjusted, I quite liked it.
one of the best stouts ive ever had in my life, so malty and rich!!!! some very good stuff.
Pretty thin looking. Overly coffee flavored and not much else to say about it. Very bland and not much going for it.

This beer is black and nothing else. Black in appearance and flavor. The flavor and aroma are very, very espresso, too much actually. It is apparently aged in oak barrels but the flavor is too overpowering to notice any oakiness that may have complimented it. This beer could be so much more but it is not.

Nice dark color. Only a thin head but it leaves nice rings of lace with each sip. Pleasant malt flavor balanced by a nice bit of hops in the aroma and the finish. Like other brews by Rock Bottom it's boring but there's nothing really bad about it.

Near black with a light tan head. Dark cherry and roasted malts in the aroma. A touch of acidity noted. Flavors of mocha, bitter dark chocolate and cherries. Perhaps a bit like a lactic stout with some cough medicine. A one and done type brew.

Served as "Cherry Cream Stout". Sweet creamy cherry nose with milk chocolate underneath. Pretty similar flavor - big sweet cherry on top of sweet chocolate. A simplistic but very tasty sweet stout. Coffee in the finish.

On tap at brewery...Was not called "Cherry Isthmus" but Iâ€™ll put it here. An attractive garnet hue in an almost black beer. Not a great head, that detracts. Cherry essence in the nose, with some sweet malt. Cherries are evident and the taste was just a bit on the artificial side, with a bit of an aftertase. I would have preferred a stronger stout character, but it works pretty well for a Holiday brew.

Cherry colored dust head. Deep ruby hues around the edges of an otherwise black brew. Smells like a chocolate covered cherry. Unfortunately the stuot part doesn"t hold up its end of the bargain the way it aught to. Thin and watery. Needs more body and a better malt presence.

The clever name is the only thing worth remembering about this godawful abomination of a stout. Absolutely no cherry aroma or flavor that I could detect, soapy flavor, very weak and watery. I asked the waitress if it could be off, and she said it was her favorite with a look as if to imply that I was crazy. As the other beers were fine and I was in a hurry, I didn''t press her, and so this drain pour. Couldn''t finish my 4 oz sample, first time I''ve ever done that.

Draft at the source, 1/09/2014. Light amber color with lasting head retention. Aroma is a botanical garden, abundance of flowers nothing but a tom of flowers. Flavor is like drinking old ladys perfume with a very subdued hint of peat.only got the peat in the last half oz. Heather flower... A lot of heather flower. Not my thing.
on tap-pours a light tan head that bubbles and copper color. Aroma is sweet medium malt, yeast. Taste is sweet medium malt-bubblegum, yeast, peat. OK/mild carbonation.

Hazy copper, gentle off-white ring. Feeling spicy for a scotch ale. Smells of leatherette more or less, though also of apricot. So itâ€™s a fruity ale, but in a very candied way. And its alcohol vapors are vulgar. Vicks vaporub + mint/cinnamon notes. What did that ever have to do with beer? Flower finish. Very warming and candied. Very thin, yet slightly sticky palate. A mess.

In short: A lazy melted hard-candy trying to pass as a scotch ale How: Tap at brewpub The look: Cloudy dark copper body with a little beige ring of foam In long: Malt profile/sweetness is very much hard-candies, crisp and a little sugary. Not the rich creamy caramel of the good scotch ales. alcohol is way too present with nowhere to hide in that weak crispy malt. Some berries here and there. Got some distant mint and cinnamon flavour too although that may be a residual flavour from the spicy beer I had just before. As a scotch ale that Flower of Edinburgh is about as credible and honest as the flowers I buy when I feel guilty about something.

My Bottom Line: Heaps of alcohol drive through the wayward smokiness of this confusing strong Scotch Ale. Distinctly lacking in caramelization, its body was sadly anemic and its malty profundity was nearly absent. Further Personal Perceptions: -A ring of foam circumspects the orangey red. -A nutmeg-like, perfumy spiciness is found in the nose; with the drying smoke, this is definitely not your typical Scotch Ale nose. -Some caramel sweetness accompanies the pointy earthy smoke in the finish. -Effervescence is soothing. On tap at the brewpub.

Pours brownish red with a thin white head. Served in a snifter at the brewpub. Smells strongly of peat moss at the forefront before giving way to a nice malt base. Tastes very smokey with some caramel and fruity notes.

On draught at brewery with Clarkvv 8/11/2005: Mostly clear copper body with a small white head that quickly dies. The aroma is quite unique as far as scotch ales go. Itâ€™s simply packed with smoke, and it has the peaty/earthy/sulfur qualities that youâ€™d find in Islay whiskey. The nose also has a definite bacon and meat aroma as well. The taste is meaty smoke, spicy earth, sweet caramel, sweet grains, and some phenols. Medium bodied, medium carbonation, gets a bit syrupy and sweet over time. I like the excess smoke here, but it needs more body and base grains to back it up.

16oz draught at the brewery with Bucknaked on 8/11/2005. Amber-copper colored beer with a rapidly fleeting head. Nothing left behind, not even bits of bubbles. Fairly clear, no haziness in this sample. Smoke pours forth from the nose, bacon and pork rinds. Band-aid phenols abound. Smells like smoked band-aids. Tastes like band-aids too, mixed in with some pork bbq. Sweet, caramelly with a very low carbonation. Light acid and some dried black cherries. Thick and syrupy with some notes of plastic and medicine (band-aids more or less) smokiness. Really not that bad, just need to work on bringing forth some other flavors than just pure smoke and caramel. Pretty difficult to finish this much, starts to get cloying on the end, rather candyish. Could use more carbonation to make it more drinkable. I think the Scotch ale designation is a good one. Medium-full body, but somewhat watery. Slick, heavy mouthfeel.

3 Oz sample. Very smoked aroma with a ton of smoked bacon. This is definitely more reminiscent of a Rauchbier. Transparent copper color with small white head. Again, closer to a Rauch than a Scotch in color. Lots of smoke up front. Smoked bacon notes. Finishes slightly sweet and caramelly. This is not a Scotch Ale at all. It is a light Rauchbier, one that is not too shabby.

Draught: The beer is served in a small brandy snifter. It is served pretty much ice cold, which doesn't do it justice. I allowed it to warm up, which definitely brought out the flavors and aroma. The beer is a copper color, and is a bit hazy. No much carbonation or head. There is a distinct peat aroma. The taste is very malty, with a lingering sourness at the end. There was a definite taste here, but I couldn't quite pick out what it was. Still, a fairly good beer.

column1: City Steam Naughty Nurse Amber Ale
column5: Pours hazy amber with a one finger, light tan head. Aroma is roast and light hops. Taste is caramel, moving to pepper and light hops. Finish is caramel. An OK amber.

column1: City Steam Naughty Nurse Amber Ale
column5: Draft at Pig Eye Pub. Pours clear bright amber with a fizzy off white head. Tastes like nutty malt, toffee, dry toast, and light booze. Light/medium body and carbonation. Smells like nutty malt, toffee, dry toast, and light booze.

column1: City Steam Naughty Nurse Amber Ale
column5: Light, bubbly, pretty refreshing. Would be a good choice for a hot summer day if no other good options are available

column1: City Steam Naughty Nurse Amber Ale
column5: Aroma: Crisp aroma, light, soft yeast, very faint from pointy glass. Not detecting much aroma. Appearance: Clear body, Amber in color. Head is white, thins quickly but is retained, little lacing. Texture is small bubbles with medium scattered throughout. Flavor: initially tart apples, slight sweetness from the malts. As it settles the malts have a nice roasted flavor with a touch of caramel. The hops brighten the beer, bringing a low bitterness and balancing the beer without overpowering the flavor. Balance is malty and the finish is sweet. Mouthfeel: Body is thin with high carbonation, no alcohol warmth. No noticable astringency detected. Overall: not a bad amber but while refreshing not overly complex, a straightforward amber beer.

column1: City Steam Naughty Nurse Amber Ale
column5: Pours amber with a thick white head. Pleasant aroma of wheat and malt. Taste is similarly sweet with a strong malt body and an earthy palate. Palate also includes resinous hops. Really good ale. Floral.

column1: City Steam Naughty Nurse Amber Ale
column5: Can shared with my wife. Pours a hazed amber with a medium sized white head. Soft malt and toast on the nose, light toast. Medium bodied, sweet with some malt, a bit of toast. Malt and toast into the finish, with a bit of plum sweetness. Easy and toasty with a bit of sweetness and gentle malt lingering.

column1: City Steam Naughty Nurse Amber Ale
column5: Amber/orange color, clear. Somewhat subdued, bready aroma, with a more vigorous flavor, made of very English malts yet in a recognizable American style. O.k. On tap at Bidwell Tavern, Coventry, Ct.

column1: City Steam Naughty Nurse Amber Ale
column5: Malt smells. Pours orange brown with a thin white head. Tastes of bread and sour hops. Short finish. Balanced and drinkable.

column1: City Steam Naughty Nurse Amber Ale
column5: Sampled the weekend of Streets and Annieâ€™s wedding. Pours a light amber body with soft off white head. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with normal carbonation and notes of bread, fresh dough, caramel malt, soft prickly herbal hop and spice. Pretty plain, but not bad.

column1: City Steam Naughty Nurse Amber Ale
column5: Can poured a clear amber with a small lasting amber head. Aromas of caramel and light earthiness. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a smooth finish. Flavors of caramel and a hint of earthiness with a smooth finish.
I do like Schlappeseppel in general, they produce some good decent beers. This not not an exception, makes a good sip, yet does not exactly stand out.

Bu en cours zythologie . Verre de 12,5cl. Couleur cuivre belle brillance reflet dorÃ©e. Mousse prÃ©sente mais redescend assez vite . Au nez : note de cÃ©rÃ©ales Ã©vident et levure , un peu de pain aussi . En bouche : câ€™est trÃ¨s aqueux ! Sensation de cÃ©rÃ©ales intense , malts et levure ! Un peu de pain Ã©galement. Pas de corps et pas dâ€™Ã©quilibre trop lÃ©gÃ¨re et aqueux .
Pours a clear golden yellow color. Aromas of grass, cheerios, and a touch of flowers. Flavor is kinda sweet to start, citrusy finish
Bottle 33cl / Botella 33cl. @ Carrefour, Sevilla, EspaÃ±a. A: Golden / Dorado. T/S: Malt, sweet / Malta, dulce.

So-called â€™historicalâ€™ beer which was brewed for the king of Sweden in 1631, but we all know beers in those days were never bottom-fermented and pale at the same time. Anyway, this one had a light yellowish, thin and unstable head and deep â€™old goldâ€™ colour, clear. Rather neutral aroma with primarily caramelly malt sweetness and some faint hints of vanilla, iron and aromatic hops. Pure malt sweetish taste, otherwise neutral and even a bit watery, simple, with a brief and floral hint of hop bitterishness in the finish.
Ins Glas ergieÃŸt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit durchschnittlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig, leicht herb. Geschmack malzig wÃ¼rzig, getreidig, minimale Bitterkeit.
Drought. Pale yellow with white foamy small head, doughy aroma, slightly sweet hops taste, fizzy with longish finish. Enjoyed it well.

#162 Die Schlappeseppel Brauerei entwickelt sich fÃ¼r mich zum Geheimtipp! NÃ¶rdlich des Mains kaum bekannt, aber aller Ehren wert! Das Schlappeseppel aus der Ã¤uÃŸerst gelungenen BÃ¼gelflasche verdient mehr Aufmerksamkeit. Es ist kraftvoll-malzig im Antrunk, betonte WÃ¼rzigkeit und geht dann Ã¼ber in einen eher bitteren Abgang. Leider habe ich bei mancher Flasche im Nachgeschmack auch Lakritzaromen geschmeckt, was zur Abwertung fÃ¼hrt. Also fleiÃŸig testen und erst nach nem Kasten ein endgÃ¼ltiges Fazit ziehen ;) Test vom 20.11.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 14,12,12,10,15,12 - 12,05
Gold and very fresh. Bright citrus-tinged pale bright malts aroma. Test of 01.01.2005.

Eins vorweg: Die Flasche gefÃ¤llt mir nicht (miese Form). Goldene Pilsfarbe; hÃ¼bsche Optik. WÃ¼rzig-herber Geruch. Im Geschmack brotartig und herb. Es folgt ein malzig-getreidiger AbschluÃŸ. Kein schlappes Bier, aber irgendwie seltsam. Trinkbar.Test vom 12.5.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche

column1: Hair of the Frog Cheery Day Porter
column5: Good dry maltiness and nice roasted notes. Beef up the body and I think this is a real winner.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: Strong aroma of peated malt and caramel. Pours a murky brown color with a thin white head. The flavor has luscious smoked and caramel malt, but thereâ€™s also an unpleasant feeling that ruins the tasting experience partly. The body is medium with a creamy texture and soft carbonation.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: Hazy pale amber body displays a tiny white ring bearing small lacing. Soft malts procure a well presented leatheryness coming out powdery and expertly earthy. While apple skin nuances attenuate the potential malt sweetness, a developing underlying dryish character kicks in to enhance drinkability greatly. Biting small bubbles, light-medium body. A very pleasant take in which balance is key.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: Verre de 5 oz Ã  la brasserie. ArÃ´me: LÃ©gÃ¨re odeur de fumÃ©. Apparence: La couleur est ambrÃ©e rougeÃ¢tre avec une faible densitÃ© de bulle. PrÃ©sence dâ€™un trÃ¨s mince col crÃ©meux et dâ€™une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: GoÃ»t de cÃ©rÃ©ales grillÃ©es. La durÃ©e de lâ€™arriÃ¨re goÃ»t est courte. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture mince. Lâ€™effervescence en bouche est faible. (Rating #355)

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: (Draught) Pint for $5 at the brewpub on November 20, 2005. Pours a thin, white lasting head with a reddish caramel body. Little carbonation. Nose and flavour is mildly smoked and earthy. Lacking the robust flavours of the Erable and California which were also available - leaving me wanting more depth.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: Lovley. Itâ€™s not a scotch ale, itâ€™s a scotish style ale, ie remenicent of the beer the actualy drink in scotland, and I gota say, Iâ€™m shure all will agree that this one clearly had youngers tartan special as the inspiration. Pours a crystal clear rusty coper with a thin whispy white head, and a fizzy carb level. Palat is fizzy and dry, very refreshing. Taste is overall light and simple. Toasty malt makes a dominatny aperance for just a second, quickly folowed by a significant yet not nearly overpowering hit from some bitter hops, folowed by a nutty smoothness. The aftertaste is lightly bitter, very very dry, and lingers for about 2 mins. I like it alot, but Iâ€™m shure it will be gone soon. Look at other ratings for this brewpub, rarely more than 2 or 3 before the beer is gone. Get it while it lasts, itâ€™s great. Cheers.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: A paternal, butter moustachioed, caramel leads his dark fruit children by the smoke of his peat pipe...His vanilla aftershave secures them as well as demands from them discipline in exuberance...

Cask sample at the source. The beer is a clear gold with a white head of foam. Dry, floral notes. Some nut hulls. Mild bitterness, and a little floral in the taste. Light body and moderate carbonation.

Bomber into a sweet Tiffanyâ€™s crystal glass from Coreyâ€™s wedding. Pours an Amber glazed orange, thin white head, thin lacing, mellow mood. Bottle says "New Englander: Mass HOPS Maine Malt". Name change it must be. Itâ€™s solar brewed, no doubt. Aroma of sleek vanilla, frontal ripe orange, and crystal malt. Taste of slightly bitter candied vanilla orange twists, drinks nicely. Amber highlight prevail but pronounced are the sweeter candied additions of melon, orange peel, white grape, and prestound crystal malts. Not a hop forward beer at all, should skip mentioning the hops at all, but oh well. Nice brew to listen to phish 7/29/15 Texas to. Cheers.

Bottle from at least two years ago, which was an unexpected consequence of buying a house and having bottles sit hidden away for a while. So there. Anyway, without much intention of this beer being good, it pours a clear amber orange gold with an enormously large white head. Sweet floral paper and fruit on the nose. Smells a bit of vinyl Kool-aid with sweet candy and sugar over the top. Again my fault for aging it two years, but thatâ€™s what it is after that length. Sweet wheat and musk leads into a bit of tartness and acidity, definitely has picked up a bit of funk and maybe some infections. Fortunately it turns out well, or at least better than expected. Picks up some tart notes and a bit of a musky sweet note. Finishes with more lingering tartness. Clearly not what was intended, but still interesting to drink.

Oh boy, this one was like eating a batch of Grandmaâ€™s home-baked biscuits. So very...bready. And yeasty. Poured a nice, slightly cloudy golden color. Bready nose, very little head. A pretty tasty brew on the whole.

Bomber. Pours gold with a slight chill haze and a nice white head. Smells nutty and somewhat sweet with some spicy elements and biscuits present. Tastes slightly dry with a very nice complimentary tartness, some toastiness and a nice earthy finish. Great example.

Clearish straight golden lager. A smallish white head initially covers it and procures moderate lace, but slowly fades. Enormously bready, but thatâ€™s unfortunately pretty much all there is. A mild toastiness and a rounder cerealic feel combine into a rather vegetal display, think the blandest brand of rice or plain and wetter flour. Sweet, yet its carbonation unloads a wave of biting small bubbles. Lazy hops are almost absent. No bitterness, just linear malts. Medium bodied and soporific.

My Bottom Line: Simple bready malts form a decent body in which furtive hops tickle the ending for an overly basic and quiet golden Vienna. Further Personal Perceptions: -A sheet of foam tops the hazy hay gold. -The tranquil carbonation and lean body increase drinkability. -Maltiness plays biscuity cracker notes too. -Watery passages get tiresome soon enough. Bottle.

Big malty aroma, medium to medium-heavy diacetyl. Medium dark honey gold, decent bomber, bright foil cap cover. Grain sweetness, lightly bitter, honey flavors. Finishes the same way. Medium body. Thanks to DW for bringing this back from MA.

Medium golden pour, fluffy white head. Yeasty, buttery aroma with hints of caramel - full bodied. Flavor has some sticky sweetness, a hint of caramel and some doughy notes with a hint of butterscotch. Thickish mouthfeel. Brought back from one of Aureliusâ€™s work partners from the brewbub in a bomber. Very decent.

Smells like a wet rabbit hutch - which is not always a bad smell. Clear golden color. Instead of being called "Vienna", it should be called "Golden" because that is what color it is - and also Golden, CO is where they make Coors...which is this beerâ€™s identical twin.

Draft at OF. Opaque black-brown color with an excessively large off-white head. Smooth and chocolate centered, a very nice beer. Lots of creamy chocolate flavor, with a very smooth body. Easy drinking and full of flavor. A great dark session beer.

draft: dark black, frothy white head, aroma of malts, taste is sour, malty with a thin body, donâ€™t care for the lingering sourness from this one...edit: after reading the other ratings here I wonder if I was given the wrong beer or if there was a problem with the keg I was drinking from...

On tap @ The Old Fashioned - Pours deep black with a small tan head. Not quite the total eclipse I was expecting, as you can see some light get through it at the edges of the glass, but dark nonetheless. There wasnâ€™t a ton on the nose, even as I let it sit for a bit. Itâ€™s milky, with some sour malt and a little baking spice. Taste is nutty with some nice dryness. Bready, bitter malt on the finish, and smooth and velvety down the throat. Goes down real easy, but full enough to satisfy. Calumet continues to impress me.
Thanks to skyview for sharing this dark pour. Roasted malt aroma, slightly grainy in character. Light mouthfeel with a roasted/burnt coffee malt flavor.

Beer tasting at Cellars Lex/Larpenteur. Thanks Bob (Skyview) for this treat! Roasty notes and a nice flavor here. Unfortunately the sample was served too cold and from a growler it was undercarbonated, which lessened the experience. I think this would be a nice beer with the right conditions. Glad I was able to sample.
Shared by Skyview. A good schwarzbier. Simple but good roasted aroma. Flavor is like an oatmeal stout, with the roasted flavor the dominant character. Rich malt, and oak in the aftertaste.

A growler courtesy of Skyview. Dark brown color with a medium head. Very complex aroma of dark fruits, smoke and coffee. Bone dry malt flavor with ample chocolate. Slightly floral finish. Friggin delicious.

On draught at the brewpub in Chilton, Wisconsin. Pours a dark, near opaque, clear brown brew with a creamy and thick off-white head that slowly disipates to a fine film and off-white head. Some spotty lacing but still quite thick. Aroma of sweet black malt, toasted multi-grain malt and a touch of sweetened coffee. Taste is medium to full bodied, very light carbonation with a grainy texture. Flavors has mostly dark toasted multi-grain malt with little hop presence. Finish is slightly dry with a dark toasted malt aftertaste along with a short lived mild bitterness.

From the tap at the brewery. Pours very dark brown with a rapidly-dissipating light head and some lace. Aroma and flavor is malts, with nice balance and not overly coffee-flavored. A good Schwarzbier from a brewery Iâ€™ll have to explore more!
light see through black with a minimal head. sweet nose of light roast. a bit of roast and coffee with a sugar sweetness taste. light chocolate in the finish.

Please note that on my older reviews I used a 100 point scale. To make up for any scoring discrepancies, all palate and apearance scored are assigned a neutralized 3/5. Undated 2001 ?: This is a very tasty beer with a lot of earthiness to it. It looks great in the glass and is very full bodied.
The beer has a good head that lasts a long time. The aroma is lightly hopped, but the flavour is like bitter weak water. Generally a poor flavourless watery beer. A gimick for Christmas.
Didnâ€™t fancy this too much. Itâ€™s smooth up front with lots of roasted coffee in the back. I definitely prefer the Pewaukee Porter over this.
Nitro at the brewpub, 8/16/16. Dark brown, large creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts and a lactic twang. The taste is roasted malts and chocolate. Thin.

Pours a chocolatey black. Medium sized beige light brown creamy nitro head. Aroma finds an awesome fresh roasted smooth coffee. Some lactose. Medium body. Hint of sourness. Velvety, then Finishes a bit thin. It all just sort of falls off. Light clean roasty finish. What happened to all that character in the aroma? I was led to expect more... Very easy to tip. Light biscuit. Light chocolate. Minimal bitterness. Not gonna knock your socks off, but Iâ€™d have another.
Nitrogen pour at brewhaus. Super creamy head of course. Very nice brew. Super dark and malty with a nice balance of sweetness and bitter.

On tap at Delafield Brewhouse. Dark brown with a creamy brown head that sticks around. Aroma of roasted barley and dark malt along with faint chocolate. Taste is very roasty with grains, dark malts, light chocolate and cocoa and a mild hop presence that provides a little bitterness on the finish.
5/11/12. On tap. Rich malty aroma with touches of soy, acidic tartness, and plenty of roast. Nice flavor with plenty of roast and lots of dryness. Not too shabby on nitrogen.

Nitrogen pour. Poured very deep brown with a dense, nitro-y tan head. The aroma picked up sweet, milky chocolates, roasted barley, and black patent malts.. a little muted from the nitro, but well presented. The flavor found dark chocolates paired with roasty barley and a little molasses.. a kiss of sweeter malts on the back.. nice earthy bitter complements around. Medium-bodied with dense carbonation on the palate.. creamy feel.. overall very good.

Deep black with a thick nitro brown head. Lightly roasted aroma. Flavor is smooth and chocolatey with some smoke and salt. Great stout body with lots of complexity. Very well-balanced, one of the best stouts I've had in a while.

Sampled from 0.5 l bottle from â€™Rudatâ€™, best before March 2018. Clear, golden yellow with a thin, frothy, almost stable, white head. Sweetish, slightly grassy aroma of grains and some straw. Quite sweet, moderately bitter, slightly grassy taste of mainly grains and some straw, followed by a short, moderately bitter, slightly grassy and a bit metallic finish. Medium body, slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Easily drinkable, not too bad.

0,5 l Flasche. Aroma: Malzig, erdig. Erscheinung: Goldgelbes Bier, recht stabiler, aber flacher, weiÃŸer Schaum. Geschmack: Leicht malzig sÃ¼ÃŸ, leicht herb. Nachgeschmack: Recht weich. Gesamt: Bier ohne groÃŸe StÃ¤rken und SchwÃ¤chen.
