Stereotypical Dortmunder with irregular, snow white, not very stable head and clear golden blonde colour. Malt sweetness, rather delicate, mild aromatic hops; soft and elegant palate, drying in the end with some more hop bitterness than I am used to in this style. Simple but well-balanced and refreshing.

#577 Same Procedure as every Ritter: Flaschen-Layout fÃ¼r die Tonne, im Glas helles strohgelb mit viel Schaum, im Aroma zurÃ¼ckhaltend. Der Antrunk ist export-typisch malzig mit wÃ¼rzigem Abgang. Es fehlt an Charakter, die WÃ¼rze ist nicht ausgeprÃ¤gt genug, der Geschmack eindimensional. Nichtsdestotrotz lÃ¤ÃŸt es sich gut trinken. Fazit: Solides Export-Bier! Wer auch immer bei Brau und Brunnen das Sagen hat, sollte mal schleunigst dieses Billig-Bier-Etikett Ã¤ndern, denn der Inhalt ist weitaus besser! Test vom 9.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,9,12,10,3,9 - 9,60
Bottle shared with MichaelBruch. Golden colour, steady head. Taste of mild citrus fruits combined with herbs. Quite refreshing and a solid Export beer.

Bottle shared with McTapps. A bit above average export with a nice sweetish taste. Malt is there and dominating but very slightly. Definitely an easy to drink beer and when itâ€™s just about refreshment, this one is great.
Yellow color, low head. Sweet malty aroma, some hop notes. Flavor is malty, light to medium sweet, dry hopped. Astringent, light bitter finish. Common and boring.
The head is medium, the body light. It smells a bit hoppy. The taste is malty a bit hoppy, watery and also a bit sour. 5/6/5/5/6/5

Das Ritter Export enthÃ¤lt viel co2, das aber nicht die Schaumkrone fÃ¼ttert. Diese fÃ¤llt rasch in sich zusammen. Geruch hopfig-malzig. Geschmacklich herber Auftakt. Es folgt etwas Malz in der Mitte und ein etwas bitter-schaler Abgang. Nicht so toll.Test vom 12.8.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche

Herb-sÃ¼ÃŸer Antrunk bei mittlerer IntensitÃ¤t. Im Mittelteil scheinen sich alle Aromen zu einem Brei zu vermischen, auÃŸer einer gewissen Getreidigkeit lassen sich die Aromen hier kaum auseinanderhalten. Etwas muffiger und mittelhopfiger Abgang. Massenexport, dass sich nicht von anderen abhebt. Test vom 12.2.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,6,7,5,5,5 - 5,85

Draught at the Porterhouse Restaurant. Deep ruby-brown body with a filmy, light tan head. Aroma is like buttered chocolate popcorn plus some roasty coffee. Mostly dry coffee flavor with chocolate highlights and moderate roast. A fair stout.

On tap at the Porterhouse Brepub. A nice stout, if just a little watery for my taste. Maybe this is intentional to make it a little smoother. Not a big problem though, this was the last beer on my sampler and was an enjoyable way to finish it off.
On tap AT the Porterhouse Brewpub. Poured a dark black with an averaged sized tan head. Aroma and tastes of roasted malts with mild chocolate. Lightly sweet.

Definitely the best the Porterhouse had this day, great stout, basically black in color, nice tan fluffy head that laced around the glass, nose full of malt & chocolate, subtle burnt flavors along with more chocolate & dark malts, a little bit of a hint of hops in the body as well to balance everything out just right, burnt dark chocolate in the finish, excellent stout
Tap at the Porterhouse Brewpub in Lahaska, PA. Nice dark brown with a tan lasting head. Bittersweet chocolate/coffee aroma. Big roasty flavor of chocolate and coffee. Nice and drinkable, satisfying.
A nice rich, satisfying but not overly bitter stout. Broad roasted malt followed by smooth finish
Helder geel bier met weinig schuim. Smaak is bitter hoppig en licht zoet met iets van graan. Heeft een fijne bitterheid die dit een smaakvol bier maken.
Presa in bottiglia diverse volte, posso dirvi che a parer mio, se non debitamente fredda, si sente troppo il retrogusto di alcol.
Puszka 0,33. Aromat sÅ‚odowy. Kolor sÅ‚omkowy. Piana spora, ale szybko opada. W smaku raczej Å›rednie, czuÄ‡ jakieÅ› dziwne nutki, trochÄ™ Å¼elaza. Typowy eurolager, choÄ‡ bez tragedii.

Sorella maggiore della piÃ¹ comune Forst Premium, niente male per essere una commerciale da supermercato, piÃ¹ corposa della premium ma si beve comunque facilmente, dissetante con schiuma media che si dissolve presto. Birra da pasto, ma comunque non banale.
Una birra fantastica, colore, profumo e sapore con un equilibrio tendente alla perfezione

Draft at BeerAttraction 2019, Rimini, Italy. Pours classic gold, transparent, with a good head of white foam, fine. Aroma is cereals and bready. Body and carbonation are average. Taste is moderately sweet, with marked bitterness. Finish is long and bitter.

Ã•lle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi vÃµi pudeli suule tÃµstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sÃµltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mÃµjutavad. Seega piirdun iga Ãµlle juures selle tekstiga.

Dieses Bier gabe es vor einigen Jahren als SpezialitÃ¤t in den Regalen von "Interspar" in Wien. Es ist ein sÃ¼ffiges, helles Lager deren Ausgewogenheit zwischen Malzigkeit und Hopfigkeit seine StÃ¤rke ist.
Typisch pilsner uit blik. Wel een aardige smaak. Iets zoetig. Bitterzoete afdronk.

33cl bottle; BB 20th Dec 18. Drank in my back garden on Sunday 2nd Sep 18. Looked good in the old Veltins stemmed tulip glass, clean and clear golden pour, sadly the snow white crown soon faded to a wisp and collar. Grainy, malty aroma and flavour base, lightly hopped nose and taste wise. Thought it fine and refreshing in the afternoon sun.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: Reviewed from notes. This seemed like the darker version of their ESB. Somewhat of an amber color with a little white foamy cap of a head falling off at a decent pace. Not much lace. The aroma did have a bigger sweeter malt presence of the ESB, more caramel and toffee. And not just the grassy hops come back but some citrusy hops come out in this one. The flavor balanced with a more bittersweet blend of hops and malts. The ratio seemed a bit bolder. Light citrusy to malty aftertaste. Not much of a finish. The feel was just a tad under medium in body with a pretty good sessionable sort of smoothness to it. Hops arenâ€™t too abrasive here. Overall, pretty good amber ale that I could have again.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: Draft Brewery 8/16/04 -Pours a medium amber with a small head. Aroma of caramel, malt, and slight toffee. Taste of the same with more malt. This medium bodied brew is not too shabby.

column1: Sonoran Top Down Kolsch Style Ale
column5: What swanmann said. Light aroma of hop; light gold color with a disappearing white head. Starts lightly fruity; floral notes ending with mild hop. V. nice.

column1: Sonoran Top Down Kolsch Style Ale
column5: Lots of confusing information concerning Sonora and Sonoran Brewing, Papago and Brewersâ€™ Den. This is actually at Brewerâ€™s Den, which is Sonora (note the label), not Sonoran. Draught out of a tasting shot was clear golden with a thin, quickly dissipating off-white head. Mild aroma of pears and grass. Flavor of lemons and hops; full-ish bodied.

column1: Sonoran Top Down Kolsch Style Ale
column5: beer decants a super fizzy, very hazy straw-tinted gold, with a massive white head that retains forever and leaves good lace. aroma shows lightly spiced hop notes, with some grassy/grainy notes mixed in. crisp flavor has a very nice graininess to it, a nice dry snap, and a lightly hoppy finish. drinkability suffers from excessive carbonation - that big carbonic acid bite in the finish really stings.

column1: Sonoran Top Down Kolsch Style Ale
column5: On tap at brewery: Slightly spicy noble hop front end; round palate and not much character.

column1: Sonoran Top Down Kolsch Style Ale
column5: bottle-from what flacoalto told me, this bottle could be over a year old. I was kind of hesitant to even try it, but i did and i must say, i was suprised how well this beer turned out. pours a light orange hue with a small fizzy white head with some good retention. citric aroma mostly, kinda banana in a sense-maybe from the german yeast used? became estery as the bottle got old? maybe so. flavors are malty and some good bitters from light spicy hops. not really a true kolsh again, but still not bad. body is light medium with some roughness around the edges. not bad if you ask me, especially considering the age of this bottle.

column1: Sonoran Top Down Kolsch Style Ale
column5: The aroma stood out for me in this one. I seem to like the beer more when you can smell the malty hops just after the pour. Gold body and thin head stayed on the top of beer till the end. Decent beer would probly have another.

column1: Sonoran Top Down Kolsch Style Ale
column5: Bottle. Pours light golden, with a small bubbly head that quickly diminished. Sweet fruity aroma, with a kick of alcohol. Flavor is crisp and clean, starts with a sweet pale malts, and ends with a light fruity lemon hop bight/tinge. Body was light. "Itâ€™s very refreshing."

column1: Sonoran Top Down Kolsch Style Ale
column5: bottle poured a nice golen color with a thin head. aroma was a little malty/pissy?? metalic taste and bitter finish.cool label though!!

column1: Sonoran Top Down Kolsch Style Ale
column5: Cask @ Papago The beer as it sets in the class a limpid gold, the head is generous and bright white, creamy in texture with a thick cover of lace upon the glass. Nose is sweet malt, lime like in its crispness, fresh and inviting this nose, start is sweet, malt profile perfect and the top light to medium on the feel. Finish is modestly acidic, the hops personable in their spiciness, very dry and a fine drinking beer.

column1: Sonoran Top Down Kolsch Style Ale
column5: Bottle. A flowery sweet candy flavor with a light golden color and white head.
I disagree with most of these reviews. This is a refreshing organic brew. Goes down smooth & clean, no bitter aftertaste, a smidge on the sweet side.
Draft. Pale gold with a white head. Light pale malt aroma with a sweet grainy note and a light floral hoppiness. The taste is slightly sweet. Ok lager.
Draught at Indian place Toronto. A light yellow pour with corn on taste nothing offensive
On tap. Clear golden with a thin foamy white head. Flavors are sweet cereals and butterscotch with fruity notes. Light to medium body, moderate carbonation, thin texture.
Plechovka. BledÅ¡ia zlatÃ¡ farba, bez peny. VÃ´Åˆa sladovÃ¡, Å¾elezitÃ¡, umelÃ¡, kukuriÄnÃ¡. ChuÅ¥ sladovÃ¡, nasladlÃ¡, umelÃ¡. SlabÃ¡ horkosÅ¥. DosÅ¥ zlÃ©.
Draft at Craft Beer Market in Old town Toronto. Pours clear golden with medium sized white head. Bit on the sweeter side with malt. Some notes of fruity and grassy hops. Decent lager.

Draught at Boston Pizza, Thunder Bay. Pours a clear medium gold, with a moderate white head. Grassy and floral hops, white bread in the aroma. Light grassy hops up front, white bread and yeasty notes in the mid-palate. Fairly clean finish with some floral hops. Pretty good for a pale lager.
Pretty good for a light lager. And, itâ€™s ORGANIC! From a buddy who came back from Canada. Prost to Ontario, eh? ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This was not very tasty. A plain lager with a little flavor but quite forgettable. Few options at the saddledome in Calgary.
Unpleasant rubber taste. Reminds me of blowing up balloons. Looks like a lager and smells fine but I wonâ€™t buy it again ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask: Poured a dark brown with reddish edges, head is tan. Aroma is sweet malt. Taste is sweet strong malts.

Bottle @ Grainstore, Oakham. Clear brown with a lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, roasted malt, caramel and chocolate. Flavor is medium sweet and moderae bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 161018
Bottle @ The Grainstore, Rutland. Nice creamy head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are caramel, roast malt, fruits, notes of chocolate and hops. Sweet finish.

Cask at the Hope Tap (JDW), Reading. Wahoo! At last! My 5th Rutland Rate! Have wanted to find this beer for a while now, good on 'Spoons getting this in. Decent condition too. It's a nice-looking beer - glowing mahogany in hue with a decent beige head and a light fizz. There's toffee, caramel, a touch of coffee, some plum and some wood. The mouthfeel is full, but a little slimy from the caramel. There's a hint of rough vodka. As others have noted, it's not a stout; it sits somewhere between an ESB and a strong mild I reckon. It would make a nice autumn or winter warmer, but possibly wasn't the ideal brew for a warm summer's day. Who cares though - it's a RUTLAND RATE!!!

Not too bad. Dark, borderline typical stout flavours but not as heavy and so is a dark mild, not a stout. Some coffee, raisin, fruity flavours to this beer. Smell is typically dried fruit. It's not bad, but it's not the greatest. Good for what it is but nothing stands out to make me think 'wow, I will remember this beer for a while and look out for it again in future'.

Pint at the Crosse Keys. A dark colour in the glass and a very foamy and long-lasting head. The taste and the mouthfeel was all about those malts and they were quite sweet. A definite amped up mild, but not yet an Imperial Mild (that's something to try should anyone decide to brew it). A bit too much for a lunchtime beer and at the end it became a bit cloying.

Pint at the Tilley Stone Gateshead. Deep ruby with a tan head. Cereal and baked apple aroma. Similar flavour with chocolatey malt and dried fruits. Full bodied and slick. Stout, or strong mild? Delicious either way.

Bottle at The Great Northern Hotel, Peterborough. Pours chestnut brown with a maroon tint. Aroma of chocolate, dark fruit, light roasted malt, toffee, rich fruit cake and molasses. Medium plus sweetness, moderate bitterness. Medium body, slight oily texture, average carbonation. Rich chocolatey malty finish. Enjoyable.

Cask at GBBF 2017, Olympia, London, Aug 2017 - Dark brown in colour with reddish tinge. Medium foamy off-white head. Malty; toasty malts, chocolate, caramel. Dried fruit notes. Moderate hop bitterness. Sweet-bitter roast malty fruity throughout. OK, but is it a Stout or a Mild? (2017-08)

Sweet, dark molasses, dark grain malts, rye bread, dark fruits. Clear, dark brown, small, creamy, beige head. Medium sweet. More sweet, dark grain malts, caramel, molasses, dark fruits, prunes, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Nice Stout, rich and well-balanced. Cask at GBBF17, Kensington Olympia.

On cask @ Live and Let Live, Kingâ€™s Lynn - Retired? I think it is back. The near-black reddish body, white head and smoky nose, rich Christmas cake fruit taste - a good one. Glad I found it on here. Good kick off to todayâ€™s session.
Market Porter, London Xmas Crawl. Diacetyl aroma. Tastes like a weak barley wine. Rather crude.

Dark oak colour with a ruby tinge. Malty aroma, slightly underdeveloped. Dry malty flavour with some toffee and caramel notes. Nothing exceptional, but not bad. Cask (handpump), Market Porter, London SE1.
Light caramel aroma. Dark brown with red highlights and no head. Sweet caramel and raisins in taste. Medium bodied, ok.
Cask conditioned - handpump - Market Porter Borough London (RB London Xmas Crawl 2004). A muddy brown coloured beer with a sweetish sulphuric aroma. A sweetish, sticky tasting beer.

Cask conditioned at the Market Porter, Borough Market, London.. Dark red beer. Malty and grainy. Sampled on the Ratebeer London Meetup & Pub Crawl, December 2004. With Silktork, Chris_o, Maeib & Kook.

A mild, semi-spiced beer for the holidays. Can't remember where I drank this in the UK, so it's a good thing I took decent notes at the time. Dark and ruby reddish, this had tons o' malt. Distinctive.
The colour of red wine, this is a smooth malty beer with hints of winter fruits. Easy going.

Date: 07/21/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Indy dark brown, creamy beige head, dry dark chocolate and sweet roasted oatmeal aroma with a hint of tartness, rich chocolate flavor, earthy bitterness keeps it balanced, only a hint of sweetness, light bitter finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

Thanks to Bob, Michelle, and mostly my baby Jana for the 12th annual Indiana Microbrewers Festival today! On tap @ the fest. Nose of oats & cereal, coffee and nectar. The brew is dark walnut with ruby highlights. The slow cascade meanders into a tan creamy head that is mostly lasting with good lace. The beer has a fruity & alcoholic start with a roasted coffee finish. The medium body is creamy and very soft. The finish feels chalky.

Draft sampler at Barley Island. Poured a black color with an average creamy off-white head that lasted and had good lacing. Light sweet roasted malt aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture. Moderate toasted chocolate malt flavor with an average smooth finish. Solid drinkable porter.

Had this one from the tap at the brewery. Poured dark with decent head. Has aroma of dark chocolate and coffee. Flavor is pretty smooth consisting of same dark chocolate/coffee taste. This was first porter so I donâ€™t have much to compare it to. Update- Second trial 07/01/06 For some reason the July batch seemed to have lost some of itâ€™s flavor. Seemed to be watered down

Tap at brewery - Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, and a touch of coffee. Pours black with nice brown lasting head and great lacing. Flavor touches aroma character but doesnâ€™t follow up. Palate is smooth and creamy but too thin. Tasty and easy drinking, but the body is too light for a porter.

A stinker. Hoppiness would be appropriate with some malt present, but unfortunately, this is maybe the lightest porter on the planet, so the hoppiness seems overdone. I have homebrewed for 17 years and have been disappointed with porters better than this. Three cheers for Diet Porter (or not)!!!

Growler shared by Scott. Pours out dark brown with a faint tinge of burgundy. Small tan head left some lacing for as long as it lasted. Aroma was roasted coffee, some notes of chocolate, malt powder. It was a bit thin in the mought and low in alcohol for a porter. The flavor was pleasant. The coffolate combo with a smathering of malted milk balls. Nice drink.
On tap. Very flavorful porter. Definitely better than average. It has the roasty malts flavor that is preferable for a dark variety.

From a sampler: This beer pours a dark brown color with a ruby tint. Medium-thin beige head and sticky lacing at the top of the glass. The aroma consists of coffee and burnt chocolate. Medium-bodied and smooth with a decent mixture of coffee, chocolate and malt flavors. The hops come through pretty well in the finish. Overall this is a well-balanced and fairly well-done Porter.

This brew poured a small head of large light brown mostly lasting bubbles that left behind an excellent lacing and a semi-opaque uncarbonated dark black brown colored body behind. It had a very nice caramel aroma and a strong coffee flavor with some noticible caramel.

Generously given a growled of this by some friends. Pours a light reddish brown with a bit of a tan head. Roasty malt with a hint of hops on the nose. Roasty with a nutty, sweet finish. Sessionable and light. Nothing incredible but not bad.
Chestnut color with light tan head. Light malt aroma. Dark toffee with a decent balance. A standard brown ale. Dark

12 ounce bottle from BwP Liquor Expo, 5/11/19. Dark brown, medium fizzy tan head, good retention. Aroma of toffee, raisin, molasses. Taste is raisin, caramel, toffee, hints of roast. Medium bodied, well balanced but maybe bordering JUST A TOUCH on the sweet side. Overall quite nice.
Tap. Pours clear chestnut, small tan head, some lacing. Aroma is malty, dark breads, molasses and toffee. Flavor is medium sweet, light bitter, heavy dark malts. Medium body, smooth mouthfeel.

Tap at OF. Sweet, sugary, amateur hour experiment. Overly sugary sweet, brown chocolate intensity. Pretty insipid, almost embarrassingly subpar. Taste like malt syrup. No balance, just sweet malt. Not all our bad, just not good. Numbers seem generous.

On tap at the Old Fashioned. Deep brown, mahogany. A little roast, but mostly toasted and Munich malts. Flavor is some mild dark fruits and a hint of roasted malt. A bit of an odd acidic middle/finish. Other than that, just okay.

Listed as 6.1%. I didnâ€™t create a new beer for this, as its pretty likely the recipe didnâ€™t change. This beer was the highlight of the beer drinking day. There were lots of sweet Munich malts that left me wanting more. Robust flavor of caramelized malts, subtle chocolate, and simple light hopping. The palate was clean and "lagery".

An old rating, courtesy of Skyview. Grain aroma. Smooth on the palate, and more flavor unprocessed grain with some carmelized sugar. Black, and just hint of grain sourness. Not as heavy on the palate as some bocks, but good anyway.
Growler courtesy of Skyview. This was delicious. Dark shiny brown pour with a small head. Caramel malt aroma. The sweet caramel malt comes through again in the flavor as well as a light bisquit.

On draught at the brewpub in Wisconsin Dells. Pours a clear dark copper brown brew with a creamy off-white head that quickly dissipates to a fine ring. Aroma of dark caramel malt, some light chocolate, flowery hops, a touch of pumpernickel and dark fruits. Taste is medium to full bodied, light carbonation with fruity flavors of dark pitted fruits, roasted dark malt, a touch of dark chocolate and a light coffee character. Finish is creamy and very malty of dried dark malt along with a semi-sweet fruit aftertaste that slowly disappears after the finish. The three month aging really smoothed out the beer texture and flavor quite well.

i had this beer on tap on a recent trip to the dells ..one of the best beers i had in a while .. the brewmaster had confrimed that the 2005 vintage was measuring consistantly in the 7% on up range ..tastes like moose drool but with more alcolhol
Tap: dark golden/amber with wispy head. Lots of sweet malt up front, in the aroma. Flavor is all sweet caramel malt. Pleasantly surprised.
Tried this in wi dells. Pretty good beer. Label art is amazing. Taste is pleasant with no bad after taste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Keg @ Moose Jaw. Gold pour with a tiny white head. Unbelieveably neutral nose - I feel like Iâ€™m basically smelling a glass of filtered water. Some light honey, to be extremely charitable. Very watery with just a bit of honey and gentle spice. Spritzy, bright carb. Poor stuff.

Tap. Pours clear yellow, medium creamy white head, nice lacing. Aroma is honey, grain, wheat, field grass. Flavor is light plus sweet, light bitter, grainy, definitely wheat notes with a bit of banana and honey. Medium body, soft carbonation. This one ainâ€™t bad.
Bottle. Lactic lemon malt and straw aroma. Pale yellow with nice white head. Sweet creamy lemon malt and mildly bitter herbal hay flavor. Body on the light side. At 4%, this is a nice session beer.
12 oz. bottle. Pours golden with minimal white head. Light honey aroma. Taste was watery, with some faint honey flavor.
Aroma is honey and faint sour/vinegar. The flavor is honey, fruit/citrus, malts and a sweetish finish.

Bottle: Pours hazed, very pale yellow with a foamy white head. â€™Slightly sour grain malt, yeast aroma. Taste is slightly tart barley malt, lemon, honey. Not too bad, just plain......and a bit too sweet-tart overall....a bit boring.
Bottle from Mousehouse Cheesehouse. Pale watery golden pour with a smaller white head. Honey sweetness, grain, a bit bland. Not very good.
bottle. Poured hazy pale yellow with a thin white head. Weak aroma, wheat with a touch of clove. Light body, tight carbonation, clean finish. Grainy malt flavour, sweet with some herbal hop.

On tap at restaurant and brewery, pours a clear yellow gold with white head and some lacing in the glass, the aroma is really sweet with a little bit of corn and grain, the flavor is really boring and watery, ugh.
Amber pour with a foamy white head. Nose is malty. Taste is sweet and mild. Medium body, soft carbonation. Good, solid amber. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Burnt red. Caramel and oaky. Sweet salty. Creamy taste and easy to drink. I just wish it wasnâ€™t as sweet

From sampler at the brewpub, 28/10/13. Lacy beige collar on clear ruby. Good juicy redcurrant nose with grenadine splashes. Earthy base under old cranberry sauce, hints of dankness and rust. good nutty backdrop.

Clear amber colored beer with a small off-white head. Nose is sweet toffee, toasted bread, and caramel. Good floral hoppiness, some mild citrus peel, and earth. Sweet malty flavor with only a mild bitterness. Caramel, toffee, and toasted bread up front with some floral hops, citrus peel, and earth. A very slight grassiness in the background.
Draught at Boulder Creek Brewpub. Faint nose of earth and butterscotch. Sweet caramel flavor, some fruit, bitter finish. Earthy and spritzy. Not so impressive.

Draught at the Surfrider Cafe. Dull dark amber-brown color with a small head. Floral piney hop aroma with some caramel and bread squeaking through as well. The flavor was actually more dry and hoppy than I was expecting and had more hop character than their pale ale, with just a light crystal malt character balancing. Pretty standard cascade profile in the hops overall, and Iâ€™m not the biggest fan of that, though I can see how older drinkers might enjoy it more. Light to medium body. Not really great in its balance, but decent stuff and pleasantly lacking in sticky caramel.

Draught at the brewpub. Pours reddish amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is caramel malt, some fresh orange, and some light hops. Flavor is the same, maybe with a bit of spruce or pine. A malt-heavy amber with some interesting flavors.

I am not a fan of this brewery but this is one of their least offensive beers. Pours a nice reddish color. Has a mild aroma of some caramel and maybe a bit of hops (could be my imagination). Flavor is bland and dry. Finishes clean.
Nice red color with an off whtie head. Found the beer to be a little flat for my taste. Almost like it was missing some hops. Not impressive or really note worthy. It just did not stand out for me.

Nice pour. Good head and decent lacing after three days in a growler. Maybe a teensie bit lighter than I'd like, but nice and clear. The flavor's very well balanced. I'm getting a much longer malt finish than hops but that's not a problem. A very nice drinking beer.

Sample at the brewpub. This beer is a nearly opaque dark brown-black color with a medium light beige head that diminishes steadily. Strings and spots of lacing. Roasty chocolate and malt aroma. Medium body with a creamy mouthfeel and flavors of roasted malt, mild coffee and chocolate. The finish is toasted malt with a chocolate aftertaste. Decent overall.

Draught. Pours an opaque dark brown with a thin creamy light tan head that leaves waves of lacing. Aroma is semi-sweet, roasty. Flavor is quite sweet and chocolatey with a creamy lactic character. Finishes dry, roasty, with a creamy feel.
Tried this one out on tap while up judging the Drunk Monk Challenge but didnâ€™t have time for good notes.

Draft at Americas. Pours a dark, slightly translucent brown with a tan head. Nose is werthers original, chocolate. Tons of diacetyl/butterscotch. This renders the beer virtually undrinkable. Huge Diacetyl character and sweet, cloyingly so. Not good.

On tap at the Roundhouse. Pint served a black/brown color with a quickly diminishing, off white head, and sparse lacing. The aroma gave off roasty notes, coffee, malt and sweetness. The flavor supported these with an even hop bitterness, and a medium dry finish. The wheat didnâ€™t seem to help the head retention, but appeared to give the body some fullness.

On tap at the brewpub on 6/20/07: Pours a barely transparent dark mahogany with a thin, spotty-lacing tan head. Aroma of lightly sweet dark caramel malt. Body starts a little thin for the style with some malt sugars, light soapiness and some lingering roasted bitterness toward the finish. An average stout.

Date: 06/20/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub black with ruby edges, wispy beige head, streaks of lace, light roasted aroma, sweet chocolate and roasted flavor, lots of milky swetness that goes great with the rich chocolate, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

(Tap) Pours a inky black color with not much in the way of head. Sweet, roasted aroma. Flavor is relatively smooth, with coffee and burnt grain notes. Mouthfeel is not particularly strong, with a distinct lactose ending. Body is a little bit too thin for the style.

Big cocoa nose...almost to the point of artificiality. The pour was a flat looking dark brown with a thin residue of a dishwater-type head, The flavor and texture were flat and boring. Cocoa again...artificial tasting and forced, with some nutts, roated grain, and coffee. The texture was very, very watery and insubstantial.
On tap pours a dark brown with a tan ring of a head. Bakers chocolate in the aroma and flavor. Finishes with chocolate. Thatâ€™s about it. Not too bad but nothing special.

On tap at the brewpub bar after the 12th Annual Drunk Monk Competition. The tap handle said Golden Ale, but there was tape blocking some initial wording. Mike described it as a lightly hopped Blonde Ale and told me the ingredients, so Iâ€™m going with the Golden Light label. He also disclosed that this was the base beer for the Chocolate Ale. The pint pour was a clear, golden amber, with modest, white foam to a head that diminished rather quickly to a pencil thin ring and light film, and left some light ribbons of lacing. The aroma was light malt, a touch of yeast, light mid-fruit, and a slight hint of banana. The flavor notes were a lighter version of the aromaâ€™s, and in combination with low carbonation, gave off a somewhat thin and watery nature. But as a light ale, still a refreshing and sessionable brew.

a decent light beer if there is such a thing. i got the sampler at americaâ€™s brewpub and this was one of the five 5 ounce brews that they brought me. i chugged it(all 5 ounces!) because that is the purpose of light beer. and this was far better tasting and fresher than any macro light or lite beer

On draft at Tap 25. It pours clear yellow with a white head. The aroma is very citrusy with lemon, grapefruit and florals with some light notes of pilsner malts. Clean. The flavor is very floral and strongly bitter with clean pilsner maltiness. Lemon peel. Fresh and clean, but a bit too bitter.

This beer had some odd citrus and spice tones which I did not expect. This brewery does something weird with their yeast it seems, as everything has unexpected flavors. Pretty good for a plain old American-style lager.

Golden color with a quick vanishing bright white head. Sweet lemon yeasty and malt aroma. Light lemon hops flavors along with mild malt. Has almost a belgium yeast quality that throws some of the flavors askew.

column1: Adler Brau Fox Classic River Ale
column5: Light, watery body but some decent hop flavors. Probably their hoppiest beer. I enjoyed drinking this beer.

column1: Adler Brau Fox Classic River Ale
column5: Copper colored with a minimal head, a grapefruit aroma with some cinnamon/ginger spiciness. Dry and a bit toasty, hoppy and malt stingy with a decent bitter finish. Bottled version, mediocre, but the restaurant downstairs from the brewery is worth a try if you're in Appleton IMO. Lots on tap.

column1: Adler Brau Fox Classic River Ale
column5: Slightly hazy light amber color with a modest light cream head. Burnt hops aroma. Thin feel. Mild malt flavors with hops flavor and bitterness. Really lacks a malt backbone and body.
Another odd beer, probably due to the yeast. Kinda bland, like a lot of their standard style beers. I donâ€™t have much else to say other than that it was very average and boring.
Light amber with a quickly diminishing fizzy head. Aroma of yeast and light caramel. Flavors of light malt and funky yeast, almost a belgium yeast characteristic. Interesting but weird.

column2: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
column5: Draft at the source. Pours a murky yellow hue with a white head. Aroma of dark berries. Taste is raspberry and blueberry mixed with a blonde ale.

column2: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
column5: A bit more wheat than berry in the aroma. But a lot more berry in the flavor, primarily blueberry. A bit too fruity for my tastes but certainly not a bad beer.

column2: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
column5: Sampler at the brewpub in Lake Havasu, AZ. Cloudy yellow color with a fruity aroma. This is a great summer beer and around these parts summer is almost all year long. Sweet fruity flavor that's well balanced. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
column5: Took a trip with the family and landed here for dinner. I researched the beer scene before leaving so it wasnâ€™t a total surprise for me. This beer was delicious. The fruit aroma was pleasant with rasberries and then cranberries. I picked up the blueberry in my first taste. Well balanced, easy to drink, and a definite stop next time I am in Havasu. Had the Calzone. Outstanding.

column2: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
column5: A: Incredibly cloudy golden brown color with a frothy white head. S: The name is very appropriate. Sweet berry aromas, especially the raspberries and blueberries. There might be a hint of the cranberries with a slight tartness. T: The berries give an almost candy-like blended berry flavor, but I actually find it to be fairly enjoyable. Like the aroma, the raspberries and blueberries are the most pronounced. M: Medium body with fairly moderate carbonation, considering the probably carbonation loss in transit from AZ to CA. D: I found the berry sweetness to be enjoyable, but it is something that is tough to drink a lot of (for me, anyway).

column2: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
column5: Hazed gold with creamy tight white head and lace. Cherries, blueberries, and wheat on the nose. Fruity mix with a decent light to medium bitter. Aggressive carbonation from a good medium bodied beer.

column2: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
column5: on tap-pours a white ring for a head and cloudy straw color. Aroma is fruit. Taste is fruit, some wheat, some spice hops.

column2: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
column5: @brewery. Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head. Aroma of wheat, berries. Flavor is wheat, berries. Not too sweet and the berry flavor is well done. Decent fruit beer.

column2: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
column5: Sample at brewery. Grainy wheat aroma. Hazy yellow body with white head. When they say berries they mean it. Black beery seemed to be most dominant but this one is fulll of beery flavor. Somewhat dry on palate good fruit beer.

column2: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
column5: Personally I feel that this is the best American wheat style fruit beer that I have had. Everytime I go to Havasu I go to Barley Brothers and get a growler of this. Given, I am usually with my lady, and she likes it alot, I still really enjoy it. These guys really make some nice fruit beers. Aroma is like fruit candy. Perhaps a little bit of the Skittles purple pack. Pours cloudy yellowish hefe color with some berry colored hue. Flavor is exactly the same. Though not really artificial tasting. The fruit dominates the wheat. It is smooth and drinkable. Not too sweet. Extremely pleasant.

column1: Beach Chalet Endless Summer Cream Ale
column5: Decently creamy, nothing special on the palate or appearance, but fairly tasty. Nice view of the beach to accompany it. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A clean lager for a hot day or to accompany pub food. Smooth, sharp taste doesnâ€™t over-power food, but still quenches the thirst.
Light bready aroma. Golden in color with a slight white head. Nothing really distinguishable....some slight odd off notes though.
Smells like the lime they put on the glass. Taste is malty with light caramel. Balanced, medium body and quaffable. For a standard brewpub lager, this is well made.

Draft @ Remcon Circle location. In sampler set, is the only one without a head. It was served with a lime wedge. Is amber in color. Smells like lime of course, but the taste is pure malt that is nice and nutty. Good balance with clean finish. Not bad at all, really. 3,6,3,7,13
@Airway[ElPaso TX]â€“on tap-pours an off white head and copper color. Aroma is sweet grain. Taste is sweet grain-caramel, secondary spice hops. Good effervescence.

On-tap- Served a nice amber color with a small head and no lacing. It came with a wedge of lime which I discarded. Has a faint aroma of malt sweetness and a bit fruity, probably from the lime wedge. Taste consists of a mild sweetness and just a faint trace of bitterness. Has a dry finish. Light body, smooth but sort of bland. Decent drinker as it goes down easy. Would make a nice session beer. I guess the lime is to hide a bit of the blandness.

[Tap] Pours a light amber color with no head. Aroma of biscuit malts and lime. The taste was of bread and light crisp hops. Lingering sweet finish. Good palate and mouthfeel. Quite refreshing. Think Dos Equis with more body and flavor. One of their better offerings.

Sample @ Jaxons airway location. Not much to this beer. Gold body with white head and flat. Served witha lime. Even a dash of lime didnâ€™t add carbination to this one. Flavor of lime after lime added, Iâ€™m guessing trying a Corona here.
On draught at the brewpub. Listed as 3.5%. Pours a dense amber with a pefumy aroma. Early maltiness, light body and slightly dry finish.
Golden body with a soft white head. Aroma of caramel and nuts. Moderate sweetness with considerable toasty malt and cookie characters. Smooth palate. A basic but fairly enjoyable Vienna lager.

At the Monroeville, PA location. Part of a large sampler. Hazy orange with white head. Aroma is weak cherry and malt. Flavor is the same; a bit like diluted cherry cough syrup. John Harvardâ€™s beers do not have much complexity.

Sampled on draft at the Monroeville PA location this beer poured an orange-amber color with a small white head. The aroma was light sour cherry. The flavor was sweet cherry with a lightly roasty malt underbody and a long sweet cherry finish.

On tap at JH - Wayne, PA... Appears a semi-transparent haze of pale gold with a small white head of foam that quickly fades away. Tiny speckles of lace quickly slip back down into the average sized collar. Smell is of some tart wheat, lemons, perhaps a tiny dollop of cherry...albeit I wouldâ€™ve never guessed thatâ€™s what it was had I not been shown the beer had 44 lbs of cherries added. Power of suggestion? Smells like a typical American Wheat to me. Taste is of the mentioned aromas with a hay like presence, along with a doughy yeast lingering. Mouthfeel is light bodied, mildly tart and bitter with a lip smacking sweet tartness.

Draught at Monroeville. Very weak aroma. A bit of cherry fruitiness but overall very weak. Light malt sweetness and cherry skin tartness. Hazy orange-amber with thin white lacing head. Light bodied with medium carbonation. Starts with little character, mild carbonic acidity. Has mild cherry notes at first then the hops kick in and Iâ€™m left with a light astringent chalkiness. Watery weak finish and mild wheatiness.
Pours hazy golden pink with aroma of hopcit, wheat, cherries, lemongrass. Tastes of hopcit and cherry, with a half decent complexity.

DC - Draft. Clear pinkish amber, thin white fizzy head. Nice nose on this one with a grassy, cherry pie, wheaty thing going on. Was told it was a 50/50 blend of sour and standard cherry, and that seems to come out nicely in the flavor. Somewhat tart with a very light sweetness up front, but blended nicely with the wheat and light hop notes in the end. Light bodied, prickly carbonation, tart cherry finish. Nice lawnmower session brew for the spring and summer...
A nice light change. A wheat beer with a nice cherry flavor. Definatly a good trip to Harvards!
Very dark brown with a small tan head. Malty with fruity tones. Roasted, malt and fruit. Medium body with a dry, well balanced after taste.
Bottle, thanks to larsniclas. Dark amber color, beige head. Cocoa and chocolate aroma, hoppy with some soap and some fruits. Cocoa and tar flavor, some sourish notes.
Bottled from Kris Wines Dark brown with a small bubbly beige head. Aroma of soapy cocoa. Licorice and tar in the flavour. Slightly sourish with light body and bitterness,

Courtesy of larsniclas. Pours dark brown with a small bubbly tanned head. Aroma is sweet, dark fruits and roasted malts. Thin body. Watery roasted mouthfeel. Tary, acidy, ashy and slightly fruity flavor. Finishes sourly bitter.

(Bottle) Pours dark brown with small head. The aroma is dry roasted with a coffee/cocoa background. Red berries and earthy, spicy and light citric hops. Some cookies and tiny smoke in the background. The flavour is light sweet to dry, light bitter and light sourish. Roast, spicy hops and light smoke. The mouthfeel is light watery and light tart. Light roast and hops lingers in the finish. Light bodied.

Bottle 50cl. Clear medium t odark brown color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, light beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, dusty, smoke - peat, coffee notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, and a dusty finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (220808)

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of fonefan. Almost clear reddish brown with a small, off-white head. Lightly tart aroma of hard roasted malt. Medium body, dominated by hard roasted malts and a whiff of fruit. Finishes dry with an underlying acidity. 220808

Bottled. A hazy deep red beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with primary notes of caramel, but also a burnt edge. The flavor is sweetmlaty with a slight acidicy from hard roaste malt, as well as lighter notes of vegetables and soy sauce, leading to a dry finish with notes of hard roasted malt. Thanks to fonefan and Brugmansia for sharing.

Bottle, thx to fonefan. It pours a dark brown body with a quite small beige head. Toffeish and butterscotchy with notes of coffee-grit. Sweetish in a way, but still very dry, with flavors of toffee, butterscotch, some dried fruits, a little sourness and a distinct coffee-like bitterness. Surely not my cup of tea. I ilke both dry and sweet stouts, but Iâ€™m not very fond of butterscotch in my beers. And a tad more fruityness wouldnâ€™t hurt either. (080822)

50 cL bottle. Pours dark brown with a redish/orange glare and fully diminished tan head. Breadish, chocolate and mild spiced aroma. Flavour is mild citric to a breadish and chocolate malty base flavour. Lingering bitter chocolate and roasted acidic finish. Perhaps a mild infection, but not one that does much harm.

Free sample from tap at the brewery to celebrate the new year. The alcohol percentage is a guess, there was no mention of it at the brewery tap inside the store. Full bodied, fairly yeasty beer. Very malty with lots of cherry fruit and just a hint of roasted malt in the flavor. Upcoming sourness.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Draught at the breweryâ€™s premises in 2007, sold there at the time as Grand Place AmbrÃ©e. Orange blond, pale-ale like beer with caramel and very nutty malt character, dried fruits, thin and almost watery mouthfeel, grassy hops in the finish. More reminiscent of an English bitter than a true Belgian amber ale.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Draught @ The Brewpub. Rated on 19.07.2010 Rather light and somewhat fresh aroma with some fruitiness. Flavour is also very light with some fruits and slight hoppiness. Thin palate. Too thin and light, easy to forget.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Hazy yellow with a tiny white head. Sweet aroma with hints of malt. Flavour malty with grainy and caramel notes. Hints of hops towards the end.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Draught @ Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place. Hazy amber body with a rather small white head. Aroma is fruity, malt and some hops. Flavor is sweet malt and hops, not much more. Rather plain and a bit thin, forgettable.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Tap at brewery. Hazy amber. A total wreck of an off-balance sugarfest. Vague bananas...come on, this is a waste of Belgian water.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: (Draught@brewery) Hazy amber color with a lemonadey head. A bit burned-rubbery, unclean and sourish aroma. Sour-vegetabley quite malty flavor with toffee-caramely hints. Still unclean. Light to medium-bodied with smooth carbonation. Not at its best I guess...

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Draught @brew pub Amber color, a bit tanned head. Same toffee, honey aroma than in their pils. Light bodied with herbs and a bit of smoke. Refreshing, easy to drink but plain.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Draught at the brew pub Creamy, off-white, mostly diminishing head. Excellent lace. Sparkling, amber body. Aroma of straw, maple syrup, sour milk and flowers. Lightly bitter flavour. Lightly to medium bodied. Average carbonation.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: ZBF 2005. Pours a hazy amber, with a white head. Aroma is fresh fruity. Taste is light sweet

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Zythos Beer Festival, Sint-Niklaas, Belgium 2005. Hazy amber colour with a big white head. Light fruity hoppy aroma and a light sweet taste. Medium body and a sweet finish.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: â€™Luxepilsâ€™ (stronger than average) with pale golden blonde colour and thin, loose, quickly dissolving head; very neutral character with some malt sweetness, low carbonation, thin mouthfeel and lightly flowery hops in the finish. Was also sold as Grande Place Blonde, apparently.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Draught @ Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place. Clear golden body with a medium dense white head. Aroma is weak malt and grass with traces of hops. Flavor is a bit weak malt and hop with some yeast. Quite ordinary pilsner from a brewpub.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Lightly hazed blonde ale with a good lacing white head. Nice light malt, fruity esters and honey aroma. Good crisp malts, and german styled hops. Nice light body but quaffable. Surprisingly good. May 2005.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: (Draught@brewery) Clear golden, smallish head with lace. Slightly buttery, mild aroma. Quite crisply, acidic and hoppy flavor with some toffee. Light to medium body with balanced carbonation. Acidic, quite well made, but a bit boring.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Draught @brew pub Golden, not much head. A bit weird aroma of honey. Very malty, carbonated. Hops appear in the finish. Well-balanced.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Clean and innocuous. Good conditioning, Lively carbonation with a bit of late acidity. Lite grassy hop notes with almost no malt character.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Boring standard pils. I guess it is possible to produce megaswill in small quantities too.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Draught at the brew pub Creamy, white diminishing head. Fair lace. Clear, yellow body. Soapy aroma. Lightly bitter flavour and Metallic finish. Lightly bodied. soft carbonation.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Golden colour with no head. Weak sweet grassy hop aroma and taste. Medium body and a bitter sweet finish.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Golden with a small head. Malty and grassy nose. Rtaher lively at first with a late Saaz-bitterness.

Bieckert Africana Negra Premium. Big bottle. Black clear colour with an average beige head. Aroma of sweet caramel, coffee, roasted malt. Mild smooth flavour of sweet caramel, roasted malts, bit chocolate and dry finish. A pretty good brew! CervecerÃ­a Bieckert existed from 1860-1997 and was then closed and taken over by Quilmes.

Nothing memorable about it. A fairly bad try at a comercial bock. For the brown hints in the head, I presume this beer is artificialy colored. Pretty mediocre stuff and now hard to come by. Malty as usual, with no aroma or flavor whatsoever.
Imbibed in December 2002. Clear ruby color with a thick white head with tinges of tan. Color is slightly darker than their Bock. Slightly more malt and caramel flavor also. Low carbonation.
Surprisingly good for a mass produced south american bock. Needs a little more body and complexity of flavour to really set it apart. Mild caramel/choc flavours make it pleasantly easy to drink.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Backlog rating LCRBM/Bruxellensis trip 2006: Cloudy white yellow, blanket head. Light orangezest aroma. Light spicy, orange, minerals - yeast. Light body, welllagered. Milk aftertaste. Perfumed notes the only thing distinguishing it from the Blond.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Pale yellow pour with creamy white head and lace. Aroma is wheaty malt, light spices, and no hops. Sweet wheaty malt, light spices(coriander I think). Almost cloying with no hops to speak of. Medium light body with aggressive carbonation.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Standard witbier, used to be sold as Grand Place Blanche at the brewpub, with a moussy, not very stable head and cloudy straw blonde colour; barley sweetness with sourish wheat and a lot of coriander. Actually not really bad for its style but very clichÃ©.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Can at Casanova Beer Cave festival. Hazy light yellow pour with a white head. Some spice, wheat, and light fruit, but a little funky too. Not that good.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Location: Had this one at some Restaurant in NYC, Late April 2010 Aroma: Lots of yeast on the nose, with some fruitiness as well Appearance: Fairly typical appearance for the style, hazy golden color Flavor: Taste is also rather yeasty, with some spice and fruity sweetness Palate: The body is light-medium, an alright body, drinkable enough Overall Impression: This is a fairly mediocre Belgian White overall. Not a whole lot going on here to make it a stand-out in the style. A boring white.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Draught at bar Clean straw body, white bubbles. Slightly soapy aroma, some spice and orange peel that continues onto the body. Smooth texture, decent balance.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Sample at Buckeye Beer Engine. The beer is a hazy yellow color with a thick and fizzy white head that burns down to a film relatively fast. Stringy lacing on the glass. Spiced aroma with some banana notes. Light body with flavors of sweet fruit and spices, plus a touch of wheat. The finish is mostly banana with a bit of coriander up front, and leaves a short citrus aftertaste. Barely average overall.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Grand Place, Brussels, B. On tap Pale yellow with small head. Aroma of citrus and koriander seed. Flavor is wheat and lemon with high carbonation.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Enjoyed in a bottle at Audobon in Boston. OK for the style. There are other brewers that do a much nicer job here, but this is certainly a drinkable wit. Pours a very pale yellow. Looks very much like a Hoegaarden. Strong citrus aroma, very lemony. Fairly bland on the palate. Decent and thirst-quenching, but not an all-time favorite.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: On tap at Flying Saucer (Charlotte). small white head into cloudy yellow body. aromas of light banana, some soap?, and a touch of ripe fruit. flavor is moderately sweet with a touch of aceticness. moderate finish duration. watery texture. Okay.

Dosenbier aus dem Supermarkt. Billigbier, 39 Cent fÃ¼r die Halbliterdose. Laut Zutatenliste mit Hopfen und ohne Hopfenextrakt. Geschmacklich frisch, etwas herb. Guter DurstlÃ¶scher, aber nichts zum GenieÃŸen. Es gibt einige bessere, aber auch viele schlechtere Biere.

Can @ holiday in Germany. Clear yellow golden color, medium to full sized a bit bubbly white head. Aroma is malts, straw / hayish. Flavor is malts, a bit sweet grainy, lightly hay, light iron / metallic notes, slightly distant bitter in the aftertaste. Average body, decent carbonation. Ok pils. 7-3-6-3-12.
Blik 50cl thuis. WÃ¼rzig, bitterhop, metaalsmaak. (11-2015).---------------.
Can. Pale yellow with medium white head in lager glas. Ok aroma and taste. Pilsner-wise. A bit watery finish. Decent pilsner.
0,5 l Dose. Biliges Pils, dem man hÃ¶chstens etwas leicht erfrischendes abgewinnen kann. Metallischer Nachgeschmack und eine pelzige Zunge.
Bitter metallic and neutral beer. Hints of grain, fresh but neutral grainy plain. Metallic bitter neutral finish with a moderate sweetness and hints of grain.
Das gab es frÃ¼her oft in der Tankstelle und war ob des Preises ab und zu die Wahl. Geschmacklich war es aber stets hinter von Raven - das sagt alles.
Goldig, klar. Geruch malzig und leicht hopfig. Leicht restsÃ¼ÃŸ und malzig, leicht hopfig im Abgang. Ganz nett.
Aus der 0,5l dose fÃ¼r wenig Geld, helles gelb schwacher Schaum, kaum Geruch, wÃ¤ssrig und nach schlechtem Hopfen sowie kaum herb im Geschmack
50 cl. can @ home, bought somewhere in Germany. Lifght golden with a white head. Grainy hoppy aroma. Clean bitter taste with some hops, Above par supermarket pilsener.
Soapy aroma, but the beer comes back with nice hop notes in the flavor. Lemon, tangering. Nice but it was a bit hard to get around the nose.

Lo admito, de las variedades que sacÃ³ Schneider al mercado, esta es sin ninguna duda, la que mÃ¡s me gustÃ³. En mi percepciÃ³n se nota muchÃ­simo el gusto de la malta tostada y un claro gusto a cafÃ©. Al igual que lo que notÃ© con la "variedad" roja, el gusto del lÃºpulo es muy suave. Buena espuma y buena carbonataciÃ³n en este caso. En general, es una buena cerveza para ser industrial
Abundante y sabrosa espuma. Liviana, con toques de cafÃ©. Refrescante y suave.

Bottle 100cl. Dark black brown colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, dark malt, roasted, chocolate, bread. Flavour is moderate sweet to heavy and light bitter with a average to long duration, chocolate, sweet malt, artificial chocolate, moderate dark malt and caramel. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20130621]
Definitely better than Quilmes stout but there isnâ€™t a lot more going on here. Itâ€™s dark, at least in colour, and...nevermind.

Buen aspecto, con espuma marrÃ³n, muy negra y opaca. El gusto es suave, dulce y refrescante, no parece una cerveza negra y menos para su aspecto, muy recomendable para quienes no les gusta la cerveza negra o para los que si les gusta pero quieren algo refrescante y liviano.

Poured this beer from a litro into a beer mug. The beer had a dark brown color with a slight dark red hue and a big bubbly, creamy dark tan head that had good retention and some cling. The aroma featured chocolate and caramel malt, along with some earthy and grainy hops. The taste was sweet with a bit of chocolate and some grainy bitterness following. It had a fairly wet but not too thick body with average to low carbonation and a dry finish. My girlfriend begged me to write that she thinks it "smells like vomit."

average light brown frothy head. mostly diminishing. good lacing. flat thin dark brown body. aroma: strong toasted malt, coffee, chocolate. if and ff: moderate sweet light bitter; short duration. palate: medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation metallic finish. sabor maltado, caprichado atÃ©. 12s
Bottle, black with a foamy beige head. The only thing I can say about that aroma is that it was metallic. Metallic again on the palate, syrupy malty flavours. Not good.
VEry nice to drink, it was a little easy but the sweetness was interesting. Black body and yellowish head.

Not bad for an industrial beer. Dark colour, nice head. The typical carbonatation of these beers. No aroma. Taste is caramel malt. No hops presence. If thereÂ´s nothing better to drink, IÂ´ll prove it.
At the Lombard brewpub. Just a hint of Raspberry. This sort of beer is not really my thing but strangely it worked better than I thought. Serving: Tap

On tap at Taylor Brewing. Poured crystal-clear lighter golden with very little white head.. some sticky lacing. The aroma was quite sweet with raspberry seeds and light vegetal mash.. a little warmth brought about a whole bunch of almost unbearable fruity sweetness. In the flavor department, raspberries made themselves inconvenient in almost every way possible.. tart where they shouldnâ€™t have been, lingering on the finish, and sweeter than need be.. tart wheat and vegetal notes stuck with the misplaced seeds on the finish. Light-bodied, highly-carbonated, and poorly balanced on the palate.. very hard to drink.
Pour is clear golden yellow with a thin white head...smells like raspberry syrup...taste is syrupy sweet raspberry...blech.

Clear raspberries in the aroma. Cloudy gold color without much head. What is there is thin and off-white. Streak lace. Some bubbles. Initial mouthfeel is favorable. Wheat and raspberry are evident. A little sour. Sometimes fruit beers are overly sweet and usually it isnâ€™t intended. This isnâ€™t a bad beer, and is closer to good than most of the brews in the 6-beer sampler.

Contract brewed by Two Brothers Brewing Company, Warrenville, IL Amber-colored. Intriguing aromas were not only raspberry, but held a defined pumpkin flesh, a touch of melon and a fresh, green-vegetable essence. The flavor, too, was not overwhelmingly fruity, revealing that it sat on a stable, wheat base. Flat presence and rather thin. For a brewpub fruit beer, this wasnâ€™t too bad. On tap at Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL
No notable color for a "berry" beer, golden. Some hint of raspberry on the nose, and in the flavor. No notable beer flavor, finishes fresh and crisp.

Had this one on draught in Lombard, Illinois. Finally, a respectable raspberry wheat! Light orange color, very pronounced raspberries in the nose with some apple. Tart raspberries in the taste -- like berries right off the tree, complete with the sensation that you probably should be getting seeds in your teeth. Tart, not sweet (finally!) and not too sour. Respectable wheaty taste in the finish. Good.

you can really taste the rasberries in this one. but it is a nice flavor and is still quite drinkable. but i could see how the almost artificial tasting raspberry taste could get kind of old in a full pint. i enjoyed this as part of the 6 beer sampler.
Iâ€™m not usually a fruit beer fan, and this is why. The raspberry totally overpowers any hint that thereâ€™s a wheat bear beneath it. Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL

i noticed more of a raspberry taste then previous raters of this brew. but there really wasnâ€™t much else to it but the hints of rapsberry. better served as, say, a raspberry tea than a beer. not horrid, but definitly nothing to pine after.

On tap at Taylor Brewing. Poured clear, garnety-amber with a short cap of whitish head. The aroma picked up sweeter, lightly-roasted dark fruity and caramel notes with too much sweetness.. blocked out what hoppage may have been there. The flavor was sweet with darker, in-your-face chocolate and fruity sweetness.. light, prickly fruit and something I couldnâ€™t identify for dark bitterness.. long impression on the finish.. kind of unnerving. Slightly less than medium-bodied on the palate with higher carbonation.. tacky, ugly impression on the finish.
Pour is clear amber brown with a thin tan head...smell is lightly toasty and sweet...taste is lightly nutty and sweet...also grainy and thin...

Draft sampler. By sticking to the stuff made by Capital or Two Brothers, Iâ€™m finding some godd beers at this placeâ€¦ regrettably, their own brews keep running out. This does have a dark roast malt to it, just a touch of porter to keep it going, with a large set of English hops, maybe more than a Brown should have. Actually feels best at the aftertaste.

Contract brewed by Capital Brewery, Middleton, WI A weakly-hazed sepia without much of a head. Vinegared aroma with a touch of roast. Medium-bodied with a sweet malted flavor that moved to a bittersweet, nutty ending with a touch of salt. An average beer. Keep moving... On tap at Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL

Pours a clear, light brown color with a slight tan head. Not a bad aroma, roasted malts, some nuttiness, and a dash of grassy hops. Nice sweet malts on the toffee side with a good balance on the hops. Clean finish. Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL
Pour is black with a thin tan head...smell is lightly roasty...very thin and sweet mouthfeel and flavor...surprise: blech...
Sweet roasted malt aroma with coffee notes. Opaque black color with a tan head the color of Guinness. Immediately detected something off in the flavor. Detergent, thin, tainted.

This had a deep brown, thick pour with very little of a tan head. The aroma was smoky and sweet, roasty, a touch of maple and a daub of chocolate. Watery, to be sure. Light roasted malt flavor with a slightly sour nip in the finish. The brewer mustâ€™ve been angry with his papa. Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL

Pours deep ruby/black with a thin, tan skin & halo. Possesses the requisite Taylor butterscotch/diacetyl aromas along with some mild cocoa notes. Flavor finds roasty, almost smoky malts with an annoying presence of vinegar. Weak & thin. My "papa" wouldâ€™ve boxed my ears if I served him one of these. On tap at Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL 60148
Thick, dark, and sweet. One of my favorite local-brew stout/porters. Not much nose to it, though.
This my favorite of the 8 samples I tried. Black in color. Small tan head. Aroma and taste is strong in maple. Very low roasted character for a porter. A little on the sweet side, but a decent beer.

Brewed On Premesis Clear, golden and headless. I sent this back because it tasted like bleach and I thought it was the glass. No... customers have been complaining about this one... itâ€™s the beer!!!! A responsible brewer would kill the batch rather than serve it out, but who am I to comment? Also held a hint of nuts and slight grains. Bleachy flavor. A real palate cleanser (or maybe a kitchen cleanser?) I would re-rate this at another time, but Iâ€™m pissed that they both served this to me and charged me for it if they knew it was off. Irresponsible. On tap at Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL

not a whole lot here. this seems to be an attempt to please the crowds at this brewpub. i must say that it is probably the most macro friendly brew pub i have ever been to. they have bud and bud light on tap for some reason??? but this would be an excellent substitute for a light beer drinker, but not really recommmended for a craft beer enthusiast.

This poured a straw-yellow color with a modest head. The aroma is sweet and fruity. Itâ€™s a watery drink, not much flavor but some sweet malts. I really didnâ€™t detect much in the way of hops. Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL
poured a light golden color. nose was bit yeasty with slight fruits also. taste was light but nice and crisp. really enjoyed this brew.
Draft. Dark yellow color. Small head. Aroma of grains and grass. Lite flavor. Lite body. Grainy flavors. Drinkable but missing flavor. Blahh.
At the Lombard brewpub. I was surprised by this one. It was on the sweet side. More Heineken than crisp like other pilsners but it kind of worked. Serving: Tap

On tap at Taylor Brewing. Poured clear, not-much-more-than-watery golden with rising carbonation and zero head. The aroma picked up very soft grainy and bready notes with light lemon zest and hay.. OK, but very weak. The flavor had just a touch more substance than the nose.. grassy notes over a honey and sweet bready core.. the back found dry lemon zest.. not much going on. Watery, dry, and grainy on the palate with a short finish.. unsubstantial.
Pour is clear golden yellow with a thin white head...smell is lightly sweet and grassy and grainy...thin sweet flavor...cloyingly sweet...

Actually has an aroma which is not something many of Taylorâ€™s beers have. Sweet banana aroma; candied like those youâ€™ll find in Brazil. Very slightly hazy light gold with a white, frothy head and some lace. Very light flavor, with none of the candied banana coming through at all. Perhaps as good as or sligthly better than the average brewpub pils, but basically devoid of flavor.

Draught during my Great Lakes region brew tour. After browsing the menu and seeing nothing at all that grabs my attention, I make some illogical decision to order, consume, then pay money for this. Pours yellow with a large white head. The faint aroma is malty with corn husk and paper notes. A little hoppiness comes out in the mouth which is mostly just flat and predictable. I think I detect some mulch flavor. Pretty lame brew.

Contract brewed by Capital Brewery, Middleton, WI Medium-golden and headless with a fairly flat body. Weak aroma was herbal bitter. Flavor was crisp and true to style, finishing on a nice, bitter note. Aftertaste lasted and was pleasant. One of the better beers here. On tap at Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL
Another Taylor without much of an aroma (or have I just blown out my olfacotory sense on IPAs and Stouts?). Unlike most Pils, no aftertaste, very mild. Clear golden color.

Had this one on draught in Lombard, Illinois. Perhaps the best pils Iâ€™ve had, which isnâ€™t saying a lot, but this still wasnâ€™t too bad. Medium yellow and clear appearance, hoppy nose, clean finish, very similar taste to a pale ale.
I enjoyed this one. not a bad choice if looking for something on the lighter side. i liked this better than their golden ale.
Had at the brewpub in Lombard. Not very exciting Golden Ale. Rather sweet a little watery. Serving: Tap

Pint draft. In its shaker, it looks like any other ordinary beer; something light to go with my Poblano burger. Light amber color with a thin layer of foam. Malty and fruity smell. Taste is at least okay, like a decent homebrew. Some basic hop balance, probably Cascades. Shows rather a lack of brewing ambition, even in their contract brews from Capital. Standard.

On tap at Taylor Brewing. Poured clear, bright golden with a short-lived sticky cap of white head. The aroma picked up artificially-sweetened honey and spicy fruit.. quite sweet overall and not very interesting. The flavor found sweeter honey and floral notes with a grainy, very sweet finish.. some toffee and more fruit with warmth.. meh. Sticky and sweet on the palate with a lighter body.. long, non-offensive but non-enjoyable finish.

Contract brewed by Capital Brewery, Middleton, WI Middle-of-the-road golden with a creamy white and holding head. No distinctive aromas save a touch of grain and grassy hop. Light bitterness in flavor with a thin mouthfeel. Sub par. On tap at Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL

This poured a golden color with good carbonation and a fizzy white head. It smells very sweet, almost candy-like. Itâ€™s watery in the mouth, but delivers a sweet malt taste with a dash of bitterness in the finish. Not too bad. Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL
This beer has a very nice balance. The first taste is very sweet, then a slight was of hops across the middles of the tongue, then the sweet returns. Definitely a nicely drinkable beer.

On tap at Taylor Brewing. Poured clear bright golden with a short, sticky cap of white head. The aroma was sweet with toffee, caramel, and butterscotch represented.. spritzy, vegetal undertones. The flavor found sweet honey, toffee, and butterscotch with light herbal and piney accents.. too sweet, and not a tasty sweetness.. I did not like the components. Creamy and buttery on the palate.. paired with my notes above, made this very difficult to swallow.

Draft. Still made by Two Brothers. Golden lagery body under a thin head. A nice light malty smell. Light ale taste with smoothed over malts. No more than a basic hop balance with some spice poking out of the bitterness. Pleasing enough session beer; a not-thrilling example of a not-thrilling style., but good with Taylorâ€™s happy hour bowl of popcorn.

Contract brewed by Two Brothers Brewing Company, Warrenville, IL Pure golden with a slight head and a hint of carbonation. A touch of vinegar in aroma that is otherwise nutty buttercream... all in all, rather like a sour cream soda (not offensive, though). Flavor was bitter and nutty, hearty & roasted. Not bad. On tap at Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL

Sooo bad. Not creamy, very acidic - almost sour, is it a lambic? Skunk! Maybe theyâ€™ve got a bad tap or something. Was sitting at a table of 5 other beer fans - everyone tasted it and said the same thing - we sent it back. Guess I should try it again just to see if we had a bad batch - but Iâ€™m too scared to. Yuck!
Best thing about this one is the smooth creamy mouthfeel...almost buttery. But, as everyone else pointed out, this has a lot more spritz to it than advertised. Decent enough cream ale.
A nice drink, having more carbonation than they advertize... enough to tickle the throat going down. Good taste after a nice mouth fill. Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL
Easily drinkable faint citrus flavour, kind of creamy as well, but almost acidic. Very carbonated which ads to the acidic kind of feel.
Nose like a stale sock. Burnt melting plastic heaped on an extinguished campfire. Artificial. Sort of tastes like an Oreo/Twinkie type of thing going on. Smooth.
Orangey/tan with thin head and very lively carbonation. Not much at all in the nose. Carbonation added to the grainy taste and effect on my tonue. Tastes as if from a can, metallic and strange.

On tap at the brewpub: Not sure why this is listed as a Bitter. Not sure what else to call it. The well trained staff member said it was "kinda like a lager." It had a clear copper body with a respectable head and evenly coated the glass with lace. The aroma was a nondescript, worty scent, quite sweet and unchecked. The flavor is a maltose sweetness with a candy apple finish.
Pour clear amber with a thin white head...smell is faintly toasty and sweet...taste is thin and sweet...slightly metallic...

Draft Sampler. Contact brewed by Capital (Wisconsin). Yes, a nice orange, with a light head. Really does have a pile of malts to it as advertised. Hops manage to balance it and keep the whole thing from being too sweet, but without much hop character of their own. Rounded out toasty caramel malt, with a good alcohol burn going down.

Brewed On Premesis Orange/brown in color, very clear with a honey glow. Weak aroma was light bitters with rye & grain. Sweet malts and bitters combine nicely in flavor. Enjoyable. On tap at Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL

Very deep copper with a white, thick head that does some serious lacing as one drinks. Rich malty aroma with a creamy mouthfeel, this leans a bit too much towards the malt side of the equation. Tasty hops, but a little light. Good drink. Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL
one of the better offerings of the sampler at taylors. smooth and balanced with more body than the other taylor brews i tried. nice.

Draft. Dark copper color. Ave head. Grainy malt aroma. Lite bitter and lite sweetness. Lite bodied. Kind of light and abrupt. Slite caramel flavor. Easy drinking. Not much at all going on here. Very slight hop kick at end. Boring.
At the Lombard brewpub. Not great but liked it better than some other offerings. Caramel flavors a bit unbalanced. Serving: Tap

This draft brew from a restaurant poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized bubbles that were and left behind a transparent softly carbonated red brown colored body and an excellent lacing. The mild aroma was malty and toffee. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish with a mellow hoppy aftertaste. The thin flavor contained notes of brown malt toffee and softly acidic. An OK brew just nothing special.

On tap at Taylor Brewing. Poured not-too-dark coppery-brown with a creamy cap of beige head. The aroma was sweeter with medium-to-darker skinned fruits, caramel, and light nuttiness.. supa-sweet chocolate, pine, and earthy undertones.. OK. The flavor found sweeter, aged caramel with excellent smoked nutty undertones that built as the drink progressed.. light earthy bitterness surrounded.. sticky-sweet finish with some warmth. Medium-bodied and well-carbonated with a drier, grainy feel on the back.. nicely-integrated light sour and smoky notes. Good one.
No aroma. Dark, reddish amber. Beautiful, artistic, net lace. Nice color. Astringent mouthfeel. Some roasted malt aspect but overall this brew wants to be more than it is. Flawed.

Contract brewed by Capital Brewery, Middleton, WI Brown-colored with a honey-gold aura. Aroma was vinegar with red wine. Flavor was straight malt-vinegar when warm, with slight grain and candy when it was colder. Slightly nutty with an oily finish. I warmed up to this one after awhile, but Iâ€™d recommend it as a salad dressing or condiment rather than a beer. On tap at Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL

Draft. Iâ€™m celebrating my birthday today by checking out a new-to-me pub, about half a mile from work. This beer is a nice dark brown color under a light-colored stoutie head, and with pinprick bubbles up the side of the glass. Has a nice chewy dark beer texture, almost like thereâ€™s some oatmeal in it. The smell and taste resolve to a more familiar wheat beer character. There is some roastiness, too, but itâ€™s relative mild. Then it follows with a slight banana aftertaste. Intersting combination of Guinness and a weizen, perhaps, thatâ€™s just a little short of displaying the very best characterisitcs if either.

This is a nice smooth dunkel, pouring a deep brown with reddish tints and a light tan head. Sweet malty, candy-like aroma. Smooth mouthfeel with the multiple malt complexity coming through nicely, toffee & caramal & roasted malt. Nice mildly bitter finish to balance it out. Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL
This is a tasty example of a dunkel. It has some nicely complex flavors, with the darker roasted malts being highly dominant. It doesn't quite have the chocolate or burnt flavors one might expect.
Dark brown color. Sweet malt, caramel, toffee flavors. The nose oddly reminds me of an inflatable pool device.

Draft at the brewpub, 7/15/14. Pours a clear copper color with a thin creamy tan head. Decent head retention. Aroma of peat smoke and caramel.. The taste is toffee, peat, mild smoke and a fruity finish. Medium bodied, slight lingering smoke.

On tap at the brewpub alongside one of their signature burgers. The smell consisted of malty, caramel-ness, with a slight chocolaty whiskey. The color brown like a glass of sweet tea would be but with a half inch off white head. The taste is where you really notice the caramel and malt and the after taste only re-enforces it. Overall, I would recommend that anybody traveling through the area to stop by this brewpub and grab one of these great brews. You will not regret it.

Day old growler from my last visit at the brewery. This is much better than their Bourbon Barrel offering, a lot more complexity and multi-dimensional. Pours a mottled, amber-brown color with a diminishing, creamy tan head and spotty lacing. Inviting aroma of plums, raisins, earthy mulch and grainy-sweet malts. Malty and smooth, this is a filling brew although not too heavy. Prominent flavors of burnt/roasted malts, toasted bread and organic peat. There is a light smoke quality coupled with mixed berries. Minor hints of chocolate and coffee are present. A heavily malt forward beer with no trace of hops. The best offering I had from MBC during my visit.

decent scotch, very thick, doesnt seem to have a ton of alcohol, but i cant tell through the thinkness. Good stuff, my only hometown brewery now, so i must love it. I have also had the barrel aged version, but i dont see that up for rating yet.

This was a pleasing scotch. Aromas of smoke, butterscotch, whiskey, and chocolate and carmel malts. Had a good head on its shoulders and nice, if not cloudy appearance. Reminded me a lot of Vinoâ€™s scotch ale. Flavors followed aroma adding a hint of funk to it as well.

On draught at the brewpub. This beer pours a murky reddish-amber color with a thin off-white head that has no staying power. Spotty lacing. The aroma is smoked malt, fruit and sherry. Medium-bodied with toasted malt, fruit (red grapes) and liqueur. Alcohol is evident all the while as well. The finish is smokey and earthy malt, leaving behind a slight alcohol and hops burn. Overall this is a pretty good Scotch Ale, it is just a little uneven at times.

On tap. Pours a dark brown color with a soapy beige colored head. Aroma is sweet malts, hint of smoke. Flavor is sweet malts, hint of smoke, perhaps some dried fruits. Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finishes on the sweet side. Pretty decent.

7/20/2007: Marietta Scotch Ale is a murky, dark amber color. The aroma is malty and a bit on the sweet side. The flavor is lightly smoky, dry, malty with a little fruitiness, and some peat. Iâ€™m not sure what the alcohol is on this one, but it isnâ€™t evident in the flavor. This beer has a medium body, but slightly thin/watery on the palate for my tastes. Not bad overall, but it seemed to be needing more malt and depth. Draught at Skipperâ€™s in Athens, Ohio during the Ohio Brew Week 2007. Rating #5 for this beer...
Dark brown, without much head. Nutty and malty with a sour off flavor. This beer may have gone south on them.

Sample at the brewpub. Dark, muddy opaque brown..big molasses, whiskey and brown sugar in the aroma...smooth, peaty, with a nice late alcohol burn; sweet but very scotch-like throughout, bit of oregano and tarragon herbal goodness, with hints of blueberries and pie spice. Excellent scotch ale, and the best from this interesting little brewpub.
Very nice full bodied golden pilsener. Could be a whole lot closer to perfect if it didn''t taste so damn fruity. The mouthfeel was excellent until it started tasting tropical.
Tasted almost exactly the same as the Rubia of the same brewery. Fruity flavour with a mild hint of burnt sugar. Nowhere near the flavour I had expected for such a dark beer.

Bottle - BCA - Dark Brown in colour; Red against light. Malty; roasty malts, liquorice, coffee. Hoppy; earthy hops. Fruity; sour fruits. Roast malty throughout with a pronounced sour hop/fruit edge. Decent.

Cask at the Le Gothiqueâ€™s Halloween Beer Festival 2013. Poured a dark brown colour with a medium beige head. Aroma of dark fruit, caramel and banana essence. A slightly sharp acidic flavour first off followed by apples and brown sugar. Finish was nutty with some cinnamon and roasted malt.

Cask Gravity at the Green Dragon, Croydon. It pours deep brown with a small off-white head. The nose is earth, roasty, toast, cola, dark fruit, blackcurrant and strawberry jam. The taste is bitter-sweet, dark fruit, berry, treacle, liquorice, wood and light bitterness with a dry finish. Medium body and soft carbonation. Nice fruity character. Tasty.
