0,5l bottle @ Migration 2013. Pours very dark brown with a medium tan head. Aroma is rich sweet malts. Flavor is sweet malts and dark fruits. Quite nice.

[Bottle from Pallants of Arundel] Pours a deep ruby-brown with a moderate cream head. Medium carbonation - rather fizzy for the style. Plenty of smoke up front, then a good coffee base with slight liquorice hints and a light earthy bitterness. Decent flavor, but the mouthfeel is too thin and fizzy and the finish is on the short side.
Not quite black, but very dark red with a small bubbly head. It could easily be mistaken as a porter with its roasted malts which ooze of chocolate and coffee in both aroma and taste.

Cask conditioned at Merton Winter Beer Fest â€™13. Dark brown to chestnut with cream head. There is a sharp, fruitiness to this beer, quite tangy with an additional nutty flavour. Some dark roasted malt notes, coffee, chocolate in addition to liquorice. Later a slight tartness comes through. Reasonable.
Bottle conditioned - Aroma quite sour with some wine notes and yeast. Flavour has some full and fruity malts but also some light sourness.

Gravity @ Wandsworth Common Halloween Beer Festival. The pourâ€™s deep brown with a tiny off-white head. The nose is deep nutty earthiness, some chocolate and sweet syrup. Toasted brown bread and caramel. The taste is toasted leafy tobacco, some prune and dark fruits. A bit of spiced pumpkin cake and runny toffee. Chocolate malts. Medium body, smooth. Overall, a fairly flavorful effort. Solid stuff.

Dark brown verging on black with a tan head. Roasted malt, smokiness and coffee with a slight, but not unpleasant, hint of sour fruitiness peeking through. Really enjoyable beer and a good example of the style.

Gravity Dispense at Pigâ€™s Ear BF, London - 05/12/12. Lightly hazed dark amber, head soon clears to nothing. Nose is light roast malt, booze, dark toffee, light vinegar and wood. Taste follows on, dark malt, toffee, a little sugars, touch better flavours than nose. Medium bodied with soft carbonation leading to a dry finish. Pretty average.

Cask at Pigs Ear BF 2012, London. Pours clear, ruby-gold with almost no head. Tangy fruit nose - almost sour. Mediocre flavor, medium sweet, lots of tangy, semi-ripe fruits, berries, a bit of bread. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Sweet, tangy finish, big tangy berries, sugary toasted malts. Erm...OK...meh. Seems like a very average beer not in top shape.

From cask at Bishops Arms. Pours clear and golden amber with a fully gone head. Aroma is smooth fruity and caramelish. Sweet, overripe fruity and light caramelish. Sweet and lingering overripe fruity finish. Plums and prunes. Cinnamon and almost nutmeg spiced.
Cask at Bishops Arms, Copenhagen. Amber beer, small head. Malty fruity aroma, some lingonberries and hops. Malty flavor, chocolate notes, some grassy hops.

cask at charlies bar, clear brown, almost no head. 2 aroma is malty, nutty, raisins, slightly spicy. 7 flavor is extremely strong for an english beer, raisins quite hoppy, tasty seasonal, faint fruity sour touch

Cask conditioned @ Please One Pint, Hobro Dark amber with a small white head. Fruity aromas of berries, hops and caramel. Taste is moderately sweet and moderately bitter with a slightly caramel flavor and a dry finish

Cask (gravity dispense) at the Pigs Ear Beer Festival, London on 6 December 2006. Quite attractive bright copper colour but rather low on condition. Fruity aroma. More fruit on the palate, slightly estery, with perhaps a faint tang of licorice. Some light bitterness produces a relatively firm mouthfeel. Pleasant enough but I expected a bit more imposing from a 6.5% strong ale - a bit too undemanding and easygoing.
21st December 2007 Unusual. Immediate smoky note but with a zesty fruit crisp bite as well. Smooth malt and a sweet finish with a hint of spice. Lots going on here.

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium amber color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, light to moderate hoppy, earthy, cigarette smoke, dusty spices. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, berry - dark fruit. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100813] 5-3-6-3-12 Cask (handpump) @ The Cleveland Arms, 28 Chilworth Street, London, Greater London, England W2 6DT. Clear medium to dark red amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, fruity - berry, light hoppy. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration, berry - dark fruit, caramel, dried fruit. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20111227] 6-3-6-3-13

Bottle, 6.5%. Very spicy aroma, also some roasted malts. Cloudy light brown colour. Small tan head. The flavour starts off roasted, turning rather sweet and spicy. Seems to have a bit of smoke in the finish, which might not be intended. Promising, but not so balanced.
Golden with a very small head and slight fruity orange aroma. Has a mild fruitiness in its flavour and sips down easily.
Real cask. Pours pale golden with a high head. Aroma is sour malts. Flavor is also slightly sour malts. Donâ€™t know if itâ€™s supposed to be like this but itâ€™s pretty decent anyway.
Cask (Kittyâ€™s, Helsinki) Sour. Nice malt finish. Shame. Not supposed to be like this, I hope.

(Cask at Kittyâ€™s, 20120606) The beer poured deep amber and clear. Its head was small, dense, long lasting and white. Aroma had grass, mildly sourness, malts and toffee. Palate was medium bodied with low carbonation. Flavours were malts, toffee, sweetness, grass, sourness and bitterness. Aftertaste was sweet and bitter. Etiher the cask had gone bad or the this beer is just not good.

Cask at the Crosse Keys, JDW. Clear gold with a foamy head. Wimpy aroma, some wood, fruit and plastic. Lightly sweet, toast, cigarettes, mild bitters. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Messy finish, bit more toast, subtle caramel, ashes. Meeeh.

Cask conditioned handpump Thomas Kemp Brighton. A dark copper coloured beer with an off-white head and lacing. Citrus in the nose with good hops. An interesting hop/malt balance and leafy as well as citrussy hops. I liked this. Better this year??
Cask conditioned @ Hole in The Wall,Portsmouth. Musty malts with a little fruit. On the whole unimpressive and not particularly drinkable.

Cask @ Oliver Twist, Stockholm. 7 June 2005. Amber and nutty aroma with a touch of old cold weak coffee. Slightly old ale/sour character. Wolly taste. Missing in hops for a spring ale, in my oppinion. Kind of artificial milky aftertaste.
Enjoyed on tap at small english inn. Good amber color. Some decent malt presense. Not a bad brew but not memorable either. Still, quite drinkable.
Reading Beer Festival. Suprisngly dark for a spring ale. Not great but a drinkable, malty beer.

Bottle. Gold pour with fizzy white head. Corn and hops in the nose, mild cardboard. Tastes corny malty somewhat cloying, with hops and an off-putting finish. Reminds me of MGD but not quite as cloying.
40oz bottle a few years ago. Tasted pretty cheap but wasnâ€™t terrible. Label is a blatant st. Ides rip off.

Thanks to TheAlum! Schooly-D once told me Coqui 900 was a B-boys drink, and I have been searching for some for many years. TheAlum came through in the clutch, risking his life in the slums of Chicago to get the goods. Seriously, it isnâ€™t nearly as horrible as I had hoped. In fact, it is a pretty good malt liquor. A little corn, but overall pretty mild and unoffensive. Drinks easy, and good. If I had access to this, I would drink it fairly regularly. It is still for b-boys only. No whack ass marks like Breau.

great crack on this one. Consumed right from the 40. Lots of grape, some dough, some grass, and just a touch of acidity. Great carbonation for the style, just a bit of bitterness. Perfect 90 degree summer porch 40.
Nearly no aroma at all. Maybe a light amount of grain. Light clear yellow color with no head. Bitter flavor not in a good way. Light palate.

Coqui 900 Premium Malt Liquor has a thick, white head and a clear, yellow appearance, with lots of bubbles streaming up. A very good amount of lacing is left behind. Aroma is a a pleasant combination of clean water and light grain (not skunked- clear bottle). The taste has a strong malt/grain/carbonation-sting backbone, with a hop kiss at the back end to balance it. The unappealing cloying sweetness once encounters with many malt liquors (especially the high gravity ones) is, thankfully, not associated with this beer. Mouthfeel is light and watery, and Coqui 900 finishes crisp and refreshing. This turned out to be much better than I expected. Itâ€™s bold and rich. Iâ€™m enjoying this 40 oz. party bottle, poured into a tasting glass. RJT

purchased at F&G liquors, 63rd and western, chicago. even previous to this sample, i was aware that this is one of the most aromatic malt liquors ever poured to a bottle. i have seen previous samples that smelled downright like flatulence, this one did not but the initial open (a few feet from my nose) REEKED of marijuana and light sewer gas...and this is without pouring to a glass or actually trying to detect aroma. very strong. that said, once the initial blast dissipated the typical corny aroma pushes through but still with a wink of something more funky, even by malt liquor standards. even at less then absolute zero freezing (the desired serving temp for a malt of this quality) the flavor on the other hand remains somewhat crisp when you elbow the corn sludge aside but again the strange infection or whatever it is comes through and your mouth is filled with farts to varying extents. unpleasant no doubt but a roller coaster ride of a beer. potency of obnoxiousness trumps pale yellow neutral piss any day in my book.
Coqui 900 is one of the best malts around, I got this from my boy djoe800 in Philly. Minor buzz but great taste from this 40oz legend. Also known as frog piss I belive this tastes better by a mile.
40 ounce bottle. I am slogging through this beer regretting ever having purchased even if it was just for the sole purpose of getting drunk on the cheap. NO PURCHASE ever again

has cheap written all over it. disgusting flavor, as if it were left to sit in the sun for twenty years, which is probably what happened. Aroma smelled like someone opened King Tuts tomb. palate was left with a slimy feel.
Copper Coloring with Sandy Off White Head. Dry Hops and Grains Aroma. Fresh and Somewhat Dry Grain on the Tongue. Cereal...Lightly Carbonated..Smooth with a Dry Ending. Overall Pretty Decent.

Amber color with a thin head. Slight cherry aroma that is quite nice. It has a grainy taste, but more like fresh grain from the field, not something thatâ€™s been in a silo for 8 months. More berries too. This is actually pretty okay.

I found this to be incredibly tasty. A very good amber that was slightly overhopped but that is the way I like it. Pours ... guess what amber in the color with a nice frothy head, and some great lacing. Flavor is balanced , but really hopped up with a delciate balancing act by the malts. This is without a doubt the best thing to come out of Hops.

Good malt/hop mix in the nose. Creamy, off-white head producing excellent lace. Moderately bitter and medium bodied. Good strong ESB-like flavor. A good session brew. This may be Hops' best or perhaps it just tasted that much better than the Nut Brown I had right before it.

Its a pretty looking beer and overall probably one of your best bet when going to Hops. It reminds me a bit of the sam smith pale ale but with some more body actually. Had 4 plates of bbq with a 20 oz serving of this beer. One characteristic hops has is that so far 3 of its beer has this pure grain taste...like wheat germ in it...like youre biting into a handful of fresh malt. Not much aroma, reminds me of my home brew. simple, pleasing, not terribly complex but its A OK.

Hazy chestnut appearance, retaining traces of a dense head. Gentle aroma, mildly fruity, not suggesting any great burst of anything, although the Golding hops come out plainly in the tasting. A bit heavily carbonated for the style. The taste diminishes into a rather hollow "post-beer" blasÃ©, with only bitterness to remind you from whence it came. (at Eden Prairie, MN location)
On tap@ Mort Subite. Sanft trÃ¼bes Bier. Sieht aus wie Apfelmost. Apfelduft. Etwas Holz. Im Antrunk fruchtige SÃ¤ure, dann macht sich der Kandis bemerkbar. SchÃ¶n ausgewogen.

On tap at Mort Subite Cafe. Pours golden yellow colour with thin white head. Sourness, tart notes, caramel, slight sourness in the aroma. Sweet, bit sugary, bit watery, slightly caramelly taste. Sour finish. Rather flat and watery brew, but drinkable.

Tap at A La Mort Subite. Clear dark golden colour, small white head. Aroma is sour, fruity, some caramel. Taste is soursweet, apples, caramelly, watery. Light body, average carbonation. On sour side, which I like, but feels bit too light and watery
Tap. Hazy golden with small white head. Aroma is malt, lemon, candy and a little funk. Flavour is malt, lemon, candy, sweet, little funk and a little citric.
Rami Rami is drinking a Faro by Brouwerij Mort Subite at Ã€ la Mort Subite No bez przykrosci ale bez zadowolenia. Slodkawe, kwaskowate, zbozowe, aromatyzowane.
30-04-18 // tap at Mort Subite in Brussels. Clear golden. Foamy white head. Sour-sweet malty. Some candis sugar. Quite nice.

Color ambar cobrizo y ligera copa con poca retenciÃ³n, de aspecto parece casi un Nestea. Aroma a caramelo y grano, gusto dulce, azucar moreno, caramelo y madera, regusto final ligeramente Ã¡cido y agrio. Un birra diferente de un estilo poco comÃºn, pega para refrescar, degustar y para postres.
Red with a thin white head. Aroma of cherry, bubblegum and fruit. Taste is sweet and sour.
Quite sharp and sour. Almost a wine-like taste. Aroma of sugar. Caramelly finish

Tap at A La Mort Subite. Bit hazy light brown with almost no head. Light funk, dank hay, soft bready and sugary, apricot, old wood, soft lemon. Medium sweet and sour. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Way better than I expected, there's some actual lambic taste in here.
Bottle in Wimeroux. Aroma of citrus, Wheat, hay, mild spicy. Dry and mild sour. Refreshing.
Medium carbonation and a light body. Fruity citrus aroma. Flavor is of sweet malts, gumballs and citrus. Easy to drink but a bit too much like a lemonade. Not like any witbeer I had before.

On tap - cloudy yellow with large thick head. High carbonation. Peachy aroma, ok mouthfeel. Peachy, mango like tasting. Quite thirst quenching but maybe a bit too fruity. Still went down well on a hot day.
From tap. A hazy yellow coloured beer with a white head. Aroma and flavour of yeast, fruit, spice, wheat and with a mild sour finish.
Geprobeerd met LiekevdV op de camping in Uden. Het is een goudgeel bier met een volle witte schuimkraag. Het heeft een moutige wat gistachtige geur. De smaak is moutig en wat vlak.
(paille, nez sucrÃ©, (poire-groseille), bouche sucrÃ©e, back vomi, une "blanche (a)lambiquÃ©e", mal faite, arÃ´mes ad)
bistrot Montmartre / Vernon. Ressemble trop Ã  Hoegaarden pour Ãªtre honnÃªte. Vite bue , pas dÃ©sagrÃ©able mais vite oubliÃ©e malheureusement.
Legacy rating from trip to Brussels last year. Enjoyed on tap at the Mort Subite bar. Lashings of juicy peaches with good spiciness.

Odeur de bonbon pas trÃ¨s invitant pour une biÃ¨re. Robe jaune-orangÃ©e avec faible mousse blanche. En bouche, les craintes se confirment: un mÃ©li-mÃ©lo dâ€™amertume, aciditÃ©, sucrositÃ© bien balancÃ© mais sans identitÃ©.
VÃ½Äap La Mort Subtite. ZlatÃ¡ farba, biela pena. VÃ´Åˆa banÃ¡novÃ¡, sladkÃ¡. ChuÅ¥ veÄ¾mi sladkÃ¡, banÃ¡novÃ¡, ovocnÃ¡, jemne ostrÃ¡ na jazyku.
Nice yellow color. A bit too carbonated. A little foam. Hoppy, soury , sweet aroma. Mildly sweet and mildly bitter, a bit watery, but I can feel both hops and malt.
Bottle. Clear straw, white head. Pils malt, corn, hay. Not one of my favorite Austrian beers.

getrunken im Sommer 2017 Das normale "Hubertus Pils" ist nicht zu verwechseln mit dem "Hubertus Herrenpils". Das normale Pils bekommt man normalerweise nur um Umkreis der Brauerei vom Fass. Es ist kein typisches Pils, sondern ist an den Ã¶sterreichischen Geschmack angepasst, eher ein MÃ¤rzen -zumindest geschmacklich; farblich ist es strohgelb und entwickelt eine schÃ¶ne Blume. Der recht vollmundige Geschmack lÃ¤sst ein wenig die Spritzigkeit und Frische eines Pils vermissen. Aber es bleibt ganz gut trinkbar, wenn es auch kein highlight ist.

Tap. Aroma of malt, some corn, honey, minimal hoppy touch. Clear golden in the glass with a minimal head, but bubbles are up in air. Taste is semi dry-ish with malty scratches, bit corn with some hoppy herbal bites in the background. Bit soapy, but refreshing.

Aroma is medium malty and grainy. Clear golden color with a medium sized, frothy, white head. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. It tastes like malt, grain, bread, corn. Mouthfeel is thin, body is medium. Finish is first light sweet then light bitter and quite short. Interesting: there's hardly any difference to their MÃ¤rzen. 0,5l from Ammersin Vienna.
Bottle, 500 ml from Ammersin, Wien. shared with JFK10000 and Miro B. Pours clear golden with white head. Corny, malts, grainy, sweet. Watery. Not good.

Piwo pite przeze mnie w latach 90-tych. Wtedy mocno rÃ³Å¼niÅ‚o siÄ™ od polskich lagerÃ³w. ByÅ‚o "czystsze", mniej sÅ‚odowe. jakaÅ› tam goryczka na niezÅ‚ym poziomie. KaÅ¼dy Å‚yk sprawiaÅ‚ duÅ¼Ä… przyjemnoÅ›Ä‡. PachniaÅ‚o mi kunsztem.

Look; white fluffy head with bubbles, pale straw body and some bubbles inside glassware. Aroma; faint floral spicy impression. Taste; straw, bread, malts, syrup note, grass - leading to a strawy finish. On palate average. Overall; should subtract some alcohol and add some taste. [50cl btl 5.4% BB02.12.2015, B@Spar in La an der Thaya AUT, shared with Rune]
Draught at Restaurant Klinglhuber / Krems. Yeasty aroma and taste. Just lightly bitter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500ml bottle thanks to djoeye for sharing. White bubbly head leaving crocheted lacing behind. Crocheted lainge. Mid-sweet pale malts on the nose. Modest dusty hops and grainy flavours. Vague bitter endnotes. Soft in the moth. Anonymous (TromsÃ¸ 09.10.2015).

Aroma is malty. It smells like grain, white bread, caramel. Clear reddish dark brown color with a medium sized, frothy, off-white head. Flavor is heavy sweet. It tastes like sugar, caramel, honey. Body is medium to light, mouthfeel is thin. Finish is sweet. Too sweet for me. 0,5l bottle.
Piwo piÅ‚em w latach 90-tych; nie do koÅ„ca pamiÄ™tam smak, ale na pewno byÅ‚o dla mnie za sÅ‚odkie. WolaÅ‚em pilsa.

F: brownish, average, not long lasting. C: brown with reddish tones against the light, clear. A: weak malty, light caramel, hint of metallic, hint of fruits. T: very sweet, malty, caramel, brown sugar but quite watery, light thin body, average carbonation, nothing special, 0,5l bottle @ horna stanica lanovky Kamzik near Bratislava.

Bottle. Clear brown colour with a very small slightly tan head, aroma is grainy and roasty and malty sweet with dried fruits and some earthy notes, taste is very sweet with almost no roastiness, body is thin with a quite weak carbonation.
0,33l bottle out of Beer Advent Calendar. Watery and too sweet. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I love craft beer and and travel the world in search for something different. I rarely give a low rating but this is the exception. It reminded me of a flat coca cola. Overly sweet, nearly no head, just not a good brew. Look elsewhere. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice clear dark brown colour with tan head. Aroma: caramel, honey, bread, some nuts, plums. Tastes really sweet, lots of caramel, some nuts, plums. Medium bodied, watery mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Sweet aftertaste lasts but it gives an artificial sugar taste. Easy to drink but too easy, the taste is not satisfactory.

0,33l bottle at home shared with Simay. BB 03/2016. redish brown clear color, quite small tan head. smells malty sweet, acidic, citric, bread, some tobacco notes, light plums. OK smell. light to medium body, medium carbonation, oily / sticky mouthfeel. tastes malty sweet, a lot of it, some honey notes, molasses, a bit flowery, plums, also some citric notes. finishes sticky sweet with brown sugar and molasses. has a bit of depth to it, but it all gets drowned in the sticky sugary notes. I am not totally opposed to some sweetness in beers, but this one is just too much.

Look; beige head, dark clear ruby bloody body. Aroma; sweet malts, dark nutty fruits. Taste; floral perfumed malts, light liquorice wrapped in dusty sugar, leading to a sweet soft finish. On palate soft. Overall; easy dark, maybe too easy. [50cl btl 4.1% BB02.12.2015 B@Spar in La an der Thaya AUT, shared with Rune]

500ml bottle shared by djoeye. Stable bubbly, fawn-coloured head. Deep red-brown body. Lacing rings down the glass. Perfumed dark malty aroma, sweet. Taste of dark fruits and dark malts, perfumed and sweet. Medium to thin bodied. Relatively smooth. Drinkable (TromsÃ¸ 09.10.2015).

Aroma is moderately malty, light hoppy. It smells like hay and grain with a slightly grassy note. Clear golden color with a medium sized, fast collapsing head. Flavor is moderately sweet, light bitter. It tastes like it smells: grain, hay, bread. Body is medium, mouthfeel is thin to oily. Finish is short, slightly bitter and a bit alcoholic. Nothing special. 0,33l bottle.

bottle from Meinl am Graben, VÃ­deÅˆ. Clear golden colour, mid-sized white head. Floral hop aroma. Full-bodied, malty and slightly sweet with a warming touch of alcohol. Lingering hoppy finish, floral and grassy.
Advent calendar #8. Oh man Iâ€™m the runt! This beer sucked. Boozy nose and taste, with some grassiness. Very rough malt. Hard to drink. Reminded me of Holsten.
Aroma is lightly fruity, bread, citrus, a little funk as well. Flavour is unpleasant - a little tart, funk, a sharp metallic/boozey edge. Weird. Not good.

Bottle, Dec 8th Beer Advent Calendar. Bright yellow gold, slightly hazy, average white cap. Light popcorn cereal malts and a light green grape sweet fruit note. Finishes dry and clean. Refreshing, which I cannot usually say about heller bocks in general.
(0,33cl bottle) 2012 Advent Calendar. Pours a thin white head atop a gold body. Pure corn mash with a bread yeast base. Very bland and boring.

330ml green bottle from Craft Beer Advent Calendar. Light golden coloured brew with some light haze. Head is short lasting, fades out completely, no signs of lacing anywhere. Nose has white bread, grain, some caramel sweetness and trace of alcohol. Taste has grains, bready malt, faint toast notes, trace of grassy hops. Aftertaste is bready, grainy, light alcohol and some hay notes. Medium bodied, carbonation is on the light side. Overall - the beer tastes decent and has the typical grain and grass notes I would expect to find in a heller, ok alcohol notes. A bit disappointed in the carbonation level and the appearance also suffers because of it.
Pours a clear yellow with small white head that completely disappears quickly. Aromas of grass, fruity and maltiness. Tastes of some grassy bitterness and sweet malt. Great balance and great flavour.

Pours a clear golden color with very lite head or lace. The color of this beer throws me off as the aroma and taste is more than you think from the color. Aroma is a malty tangerine with a hi t of grass. Taste is sweet grains a d a hint of fruit up front with a smooth grassy bitterness on the finish. We balanced for a 7.5% beer.

Dec 8 CBAC. Gold with decent carbonation but no head. Working on the Christmas list for the kids. Dark tangerine scent with a trace of alcohol. Very drinkable and smooth. Dark tangerine flavour, light sweetness, hint of woodiness and a bit of alcohol in the finish.

Kalea Bier-Adventkalender 17.12.2016 (Ã–sterreich-Edition) Ich weiÃŸ nicht ob es als solches geplant war, aber das ist ein Bier dessen Geschmack mich an viele leichte Balkan-Helle erinnert. Es hat einen kÃ¼nstlich sÃ¼ÃŸlichen Geschmack und ist auch sehr blass. NIx fÃ¼r mich.

Clear golden beer with a small, white, medium to short lasting head. Unpleasant aroma, very worty, card board, some hops, bread. Taste is like aroma, pale malt in light to medium sweetish finish. Light body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Trinkable though.
0,33l bottle out of Beer Advent Calendar. Flat and thin, unpleasant aftertaste. Not good. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled: Golden color, frothy head. Quite unspectacular, fresh aroma with few hop notes. Malty and grainy taste, light bitter aftertaste. Quite drinkable for this kind of Austrian alcohol reduced lager, but all in all overall.

Bottled (backlog, thanks Kim N!). Golden colour, mediumsized creamy head, which leaves good lace. Aroma is floral, some caramel, mild bready and grainy notes along with a nice grassy and herbal bitter finish. The bitter finish is nice and lingering, just making you go for another sip. Very drinkable.

Color is a dark golden-orange, darker than other pilsners I have sampled. Aroma is strong and very malty with some sharpness. Flavor is malty but not sweet, and it has a good hoppy edge but not any real bitterness. This pils is smooth but tingly, and the aftertaste has hoppy overtones. Tasty.

My Bottom Line: A somewhat fruity and dusty yeast presence roams with the prevalent maple/honey sweetness of this rather malty bohemian pilsner. If you expect a crisp and beautifully hoppy Czech pils, this might not be it. Further Personal Perceptions: -A sheet of foam fades into the dull, hazy blond. -The finishing hop bitterness is quite dry and muddled, a little wooden. -This has the usual, bready sweet flavor profile of 14-degree svetlÃ©s. -Is this controlled diacetyl I perceive, or is the maltâ€™s sweetness leaking into butterscotch territory? Bottle; no date.

The aroma is sweet with caramel malt, yeast, and light herbal hops. The appearance is light amber gold with a thin head. The palate this thin. This is a sweet caramel interpretation of a Bohemian Pilsner light on the hops. The aftertaste has sugar and a little bit of chemical bitterness.
Pours cloudy amber with very little head that dissapates quickly. Leaves little to no lacing. Sweet malty aroma and a slightly hoppy finish. The longer I drink it the more I like it.
Pours a dark gold, but not too pretty. Grain malts and bread lace about both in nose and taste. No bitter, just easy and smoothe. Very drinkable as an opener.

Aroma is very hearty with grain and bread notes. Clear golden body with a lazy white head. Fore is again bready and grainy with a bit of yeasty dough sweetness. It gives it an almost ale like feel in the regard. Very mild hop bitterness in the finish and even a mild toastyness. Much better than I expected it to be.

Thanks to Degarth for this one! The Stork pours with a dark yellow body that holds up a long lasting, creamy, bone-colored head. Rich bready, doughy malt aroma that is supported by a flowery hops. Slight sweetness that is balanced by a good hop bitterness underneath. A bit soapy, but there is lots of body for the style here that make this quite enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy honey gold with 3/4â€ white head. Smells like caramel apples, flat out. Green Granny Smith apples. Flavor of pear juice, and...man, not much else. Little bit of malt, hint of corn. After taste like green red apple skin and just a touch of hop bitterness. Body is on the thin side, but appropriate for the light flavor of the beer. Is this even beer? This flat out the most drinkable lager Iâ€™ve ever had. Iâ€™m impressed.

One of the best lagers I have had the pleasure to drink. My brother in law bought it for me in the bottle and it set in my refrig for a while before drinking it. The flavor is subtle but long lasting and almost nutty in resonance. The appearance is a dark golden hue.
A: Clear gold with a small white head. N: Hints of sweet malts and light hops. T: Same as the nose P: Thin O: Standard lager

With Bavarian influence, brewed in South Africa by the Funk Family. The techniques used by Mr Funk Senior, had everyone tasting this beer wanting another. Regardless of which and how, a lager beer that would leave your pallet with an interesting aftertaste, pleasing to many, but also often deemed as undesirable by many as it was believed to be imported.
From can. Light yellow pour in a can with diminishing white head leaving very little lacing. Some malt in the aroma with very little hops or bitterness. Very watery with short finish.

Smells like tin, water, and alcohol. I really canâ€™t pick up anything else with my nose. Has that below average piss-yellow colour, and not a bad head. Itâ€™s got a smooth taste though, with plenty of maltiness and some hint of hops. Nonetheless itâ€™s kind of a below average brew and firmly in the "meh" category of beers.

(Can 45 cl) Clear, pale golden with a tall, dense, white head leaving some laces. Aroma of malt and metal. Light and a little watery body with sweet brewing cereal and notes of cardboard. Basically no bitterness. Poor. 110508
Can. A light yellow beer with no head. Both the aroma and flavor are sweet and lightly malty - boring.
Can, 4.8%. Yellow color, fizzy white head. Standard, really boring lager....
Can at Jacobs. Clear yellow - no head. Citrus, lime, egg, white bread, a weak thin beer. Boring. - A new country !!
Golden coloured beer with a nice white head. Not much aroma, weak sweet flavour. Probably not bad unther the south-african sun. (Bottle 34cl)
nice can in a way....still crappy on tap....big foam head at the pour....back bitterness is subtle....pale yellow.like dying straw....some ok sweetness,muddled bitterness mix

Very very very bitter. Huge cascade aroma, with other hops I''m not familiar with. My friend got their IPA, whatever the name was, and this was far and away more bitter. It almost makes your mouth pucker. Good malts, a touch of fruitiness. I was a little disappointed, because i was hoping for a rich english bitter, but this worked just the same.
Great taste for the price. Great memories as a 16 year old drinking this great beer. Personally however I would not drink this on a night out anymore
This put before us is the greatest beer to ever touch the planet. The sense of excitement that you get losing your virginity is relived everytime you open a can of this golden nectar.

Probably the best beer. Markets itself. Despite the rating this beer is quite good, better than tui or speights or anything else youâ€™d pay twice as much for. Flavour: Tui but with way less sugar Head: None but who actually likes froth Colour: The same colour as the average river in New Zealand
In 2004 Double Brown won the prestigious BrewNZ New Zealand Draft Beer of the Year Award. That's brown!
Beer with light color, light body, average carbonized, easy drinkable, (bought a 33cl can at FreshChoice supermarket, Te Anau, NZ #650)(#8 NZ).

Double brown a gift bestowed to us from the gods hence its nickname the nectar of the gods. As soon as you open a car of this malty nectar a tingle shivers down your body as you are about to have your first sip. Double brown is cheap not due to the quality but a want for everybody to be able to enjoy what is a fundamental human right. Thank you double Brown you are a true gift to us all

Cheap, Classic NZ Beer that has stood the test of time, They should bring back the 745ml quart bottle version of these just like Jake The Muss drank out of in Once where Warriors....you cant go wrong with double brown
Perfect beer for smashing back a few fuckin tins and havin a good fuckin time with the lads.
From old tasting notes. Clear Amber orange color. Foamy beige head. Faint Apple peel aroma. Light sweet malt flavor, like iced tea. Faint tart midtaste. Light sweet fruit finish. Fairly inept.

This is the story of how New Zealand as we know changed forever. So the story goes, one day the godâ€™s way up in the clouds were playing a game of footy. Zeus had funnelled a few too many beers and was running it straight up the guts like a true team player. But Zeus got bunced hard as, by one of the big taniwha fullas, Zeus went flying through the air and smashed into the crates of beers. One of the crates flue off the clouds falling straight down towards the mighty New Zealand. This sacred gods beer flew straight into the pool of an unsuspecting hard working man who was wearing his New Zealand summer tuxedo which consisted of jandals, stubbies and a singlet, hats and sunnies are optional. This bloke fished out this crate of beers and inspected the excellent craftmanship of the wooden crate. The huge 745ml bottles had a logo stamped on them which read DoubleBrown. He cracked on open and took a good hard swig, this was the best beer he had ever tasted. From that day on he vowed to brew this beer so the whole of New Zealand could taste its beauty. The End

Winter edition of Sinpalsken Donker, used to be called Sinpalsken Kerstbier. Bottled in 75 cl bottles with paper wrapped around them and only made in very limited quantities (and not every winter, I assume); found this through friends who are acquainted with the brewer. Dark brown beer with thin off-white head; low carbonation and therefore smooth and very soft, almost buttery mouthfeel; malty and dried fruits, caramel, coriander, light roasted bitterishness in the finish. Interesting but more so because of its rarity than because of its actual taste.

Bottle @ Kerstbierfestival 2006 in Essen, BE. Brown color with a small white head. Aroma is harsh malty, caramel, fruit, stabel. Flavor is sweet and very acidic, with a long duration. Not a beer for me. (det er en ommer !)

Mild, sweet and malty aroma. Caramel start. Citric finish. Some raisin notes. Unclear brown (muddy) colour. Nice mild and spicy palate. Aftertaste of diabetic-medicine (thanx Theresa Miszourkewich...)
Cloudy brown amber coloured beer. Weak, medium malty aroma. Sweet yeasty, malty taste. A slightly bitter finish. A good beer without special characteristics.

Sampled at the gorgeous brewpub in Salmon Idaho where this was paired with some outstanding food. In my glass a dark and clear amber with a dark sandy head. Nose of medium-dark roasted malts, and some nuts. The body is a medium plus and the flavor is rich malts, some earthiness, light nuttiness, and even cacao. Finishes with light bitterness. Very nice brown.
On tap at the brewery pours crisp amber copper topped with a small sand head. Nose is light grain some earthy hops. Taste is more of the light grain notes earthy tones and some nuts.
Taster at brewery. Dark amber pour, small ring of head. Aroma us light, roast malts. Taste brings a hint of sweetness, some nutty character too. Solid brown.
On draft. Pours a clear amber with a thick ecru head. Malty nose. Flavors of toffee. Crisp finish.

Tap @ BP. Medium depth brown pour and a thick finger of beige head. Nose is roast and light nuts. Some earthy bitters, nuts, and roast in the taste. Good balance... it actually could be blended with the hazelnut and raise some eyebrows I think. Still, enjoyable as is.
Had at MBBF 2013 Clear brown with a small off-white head Toasted malts, bready, nutty and caramel OK

On tap at the Mountain Brewers Festival 2013. Pours a light brown color with a medium white head. A sweet nose of biscuit and some coffee. The flavor is light, sweet malts, caramel, some coffee. Clean.
Deep amber color with a white top. Scent is light malts some toastiness and coffee. Taste is same.
Draft. Hazy brown color, small tan head. Aroma of brown bread and brown sugar. Taste is sweet caramel and light spice.

Draft at the Hilton Garden Inn, Idaho Falls. Brown with a lasting ring of bubbles. Nose is earthy cocoa and caramel. Flavor is cocoa, molasses and just a touch of grass and citrus. Medium body is to the sweet side, with just enough carbonation and acidity to sweep the sticky malt away at the finish.

Draft at Hilltop. Copper colored. No head. No is faint with mild malts and light hops. It seems wtaered down as I can barely smell any of it. Taste is earthy hops and some light spice and malt. Not very flavorful either. Avergae. Body is a bit thin and watery. Finishes with very faint echoes of the flavor. Needs work.
Huge head and dark red. Hardly any aroma. Smooth, but there's little character. Ultimately, it's a little boring.

The color is right lightish copper, but not much head to speak of. Minimal aroma and taste. Neither are bad, just not much there. Minimal bitterness on the finish. Very light bodied, should be a wee bit heavier. Dissapointing.

Copper in color with minimal head, which seems to be a trait common to all their beers. Nice earthy hop nose. Earthy hop bite through the middle and finish with no malt profile to complement. Body is thin and watery. Finish is bitter. This beer could really go places with some malt content and a little attention to mouthfeel/body.

(64 oz growler - I live right around the corner from the brew pub) aroma of medium floral hops with a malty sweetness (very pleasant)- Golden color (slightly amber)medium to light head diminishing quickly; nice lace; medium after-pour carbo; balance of hops (primary) and malt flavor excellent. Slight bitterness on finish. Smooth palate. I am impressed :) 8+ ABV (well hidden) - I will get the exact ABV tomorrow (from the brewer) and attempt to add it via "Send Corrections"

Pint on tap. Gold color, clear. Medium head, off-white, decent lacing. Nice herb-y IPA, full mouthfeel and aftertaste, grassy aroma, good taste, not too strong, middle of the road as far as IPAs go, not particularly remarkable.

Draught at Devils Canyon paringlot beer festival. Lingering beige head. Clowdy orange color. Citrus aroma with some new cut grass from over dry hopping. Huge hop taste and then long bitterness and dry finnish.
head is thinner and quickly dissipating. good floral and citrus notes in the aroma. a bit thin in mouthfeel.
Bottle... poured amberish-orange with a white head. aroma of dirt and rust. thick dry palate. really sweet and not enough bitterness. fruity and lots of caramel malts.
Crisp. Hints of lemon, but not that citrus-y. very sharp metallic cutting through everything. Disappointing, not that great.
Sampled at West Coast Brew Fest â€™08 ~Pours a light golden colour ~Light floral hop scent. ~Mild sweet hop taste. Very pleasant. ~this was an enjoyable IPA. One I wouldnâ€™t mind having again.
Draft, This IPA is very different, not your everyday California IPA. This one actually has some malt flavor. A very English IPA. Great w/a burger. I hear bottle are coming soon!

12 ounce sample at the Squaw Valley Brews, Blues, and Funk Festival. Grainy and lightly funked out aroma. Almost smells like there is a little sour Brett going on. I also get a dash of lemony citrus aromas. Moderately hazy orange-honey colored body with a small light yellow head. Sweet, fruity, citrus weird apricot/orange/pear-like flavors to start. Lightly grainy malty middle. Becomes a bit sour and astringent later on. This is way off. Definitely not reminscent of an IPA.

At NorCal Brewers Guild Festival at Raley Field. Light floral aroma. Clear coppery amber color with a white head (no lacing). Thinnish mouthfeel. Malt is balanced by floral hop. Itâ€™s not all that bitter. A bit English. Maybe a lot English. Nice finish flavor.

On draught at HopYard. Poured a dense dark gold color with a slight head. Medium-bodied with a big hoppy flavor and medium bitterness. A full mouthfeel. Slight citrus character matched to an underlying pale malt flavor. The hops were more noticable than the malt or alcohol. Maybe a "pale" IPA.

Cask at the White Lion, St. Albans in 2012. Dark, bright ruby with an offwhite head. Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, tinned prunes and malt. Malty, fairy sweet and quite fruity flavour with a hint of roastiness.

Bottle courtesy of SimonTomlinson via the RB EU 2019-3 trade. Deep auburn with a creamy, light beige head. Mild caramel and ash aroma. Dry and mildly bitter with lingering woodsmoke at the end. Faint berry tartness. Medium body, balanced carbonation. A nice one.
Sampled at Hakets Cask Festival, GÃ¶teborg, Sweden. Clear ruby to chestnut. Nutty, fruity, caramelly. Semi dry, medium bitterness.
Cask at Cask Festival Haket 2019-10-19 GÃ¶teborg AR: sweet toffee, AP: darkest ruby, wee cream beige lid F: smooth, sweet toffee, semi sweet mouthfeeling, sponge, nice
Cask at Wetherspoons Ruislip Manor. A dark ruby/brown coloured pour with a medium off white head on top. Sweet, fruity, malty, caramel aroma and taste. Not bad actually.

Cask at Herbert Wells Spoons in Woking. Low key malty chocolate aroma. Dark brown. Creamy beige head. Light bitter. A hint of berry sourness but predominantly malty. Light-medium bodied. Slick. Flat carbonation. Abrupt finish. Serviceable mild.
Dark and malty brew. Marzipan sweetness with toffee aromas. Big hazelnut flavours and lovely smooth finish. Seen loads of times in the co-op but never bothered with it before. Will buy again.

Bottle. Black with a small head. Excellent malty, nutty flavour. Quite distinctive in a world that seems to be dominated by IPA's. The label says that it is an award winning beer-and you can see why. Great to see this style in a bottle-long may it continue. Well worth trying.

Bottle from Booths, Keswick. Clear ruby/brown body with a thin beige head that holds well. Steady carbonation. Faint lacing. Aroma of raisin, wood and milk chocolate. Flavour of stewed tea and cigar. Thin body with a sticky mouthfeel. Soft fizz. Really tasty - Iâ€™m surprised itâ€™s not been scored higher.
Sample at the Bluecoat. Thin creamy beige head. Hazy amber pour. Smooth and easy drinking.
From old tasting notes. Brassy gold color. Brief white head. Light grainy malt aroma. Tangy malt flavor is fruity. Mild hop finish is grassy in finish.

I thought this was a great attempt from Miller. It did pour pretty nice with a decent white head. Golden color. There was a light but good barley malt flavor. Hopping was pretty tame. Crystal, cascade combo maybe?? Iâ€™m sure they didnâ€™t want to scare the High-Life crowd away. Drinkable, expensive...but they should have stuck with the "special edition" market. It helps sell the cheap beer

5.9% - I had this beer many years ago at one time when I was only giving ratings to the beers but was too lazy and stupid to write down my thoughts. I will update this as soon as I get my hands on this beer again.
Is this stuff still produced? I drank this in college because of the cool fluted bottle. I liked it a lot then, but then again I thought Mickeyâ€™s was good too.
A-B world select is even better than this........ this is ....... utter swill.......... i dont like it
woah. special reserve? they should have kept it reserved! this was supposed to be a good beer?!

This was an effort to come out with a super premium. Slightly darker than the typical straw color with a off white dense head. Light malt and floral hops aroma. Flavors align with the aromas. Miller's "World Select" only sever years ahead of A-B.

Nice dark brown-ruby body, modest head. Aroma is tin, brown sugar, molasses. Flavour is sweet dark bread, hints of hazelnut nutella but not too strong. Medium mouthfeel, balanced. An okay drinker but does not rise out of the pack.

From a 355 ml can purchased in Revelstoke. Pours a clear mahogany with a quickly receding tan head. Aroma is nutty with toasted malts. Flavor is moderately sweet caramel and toffee. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Dark brown colour with beige head. Aroma is malty and caramel. Taste of candy sugar and malt.
Opaque brown hue with a large frothy brown/beige head. Light bodied and watery texture. Mild roast, nuts, and toast with a slightly bitter finish. Epitome of mediocrity.
Amber brown colour with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate and with a hint of caramel. Taste of chocolate, caramel and a smoaky wood aftertaste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours see through brown, like a cola. Has a cloudy head that stayed till the bottom, but no lace. Tastes of roasted malt, chocolate malt with a nuttiness. A tinge a sweetness makes a nice balance.
Bottle. Dark amber brown pour without much head. Very malty, a bit sweet without much bitterness. Slightly nutty. Not bad for the style.

Bottle shared with northropfrye. Aroma, pretty nutty and delicious. And flavour wise, this doesnâ€™t disappoint -- even nuttier and more delicious in taste. I usually donâ€™t like nut brown ales, but this one I could just guzzle. Yum!
Brown slightly red body some lacing not much head. Bready dried fruit malty aroma. Taste is malty with a touch of roast, some lactose. Okay brown ale.

ENG: 650ml bottle from Liquor Mart in Winnipeg, poured into the Teku glass. Dark red, clear color, medium, white head and a bit of lacing. Aromas of roasted malts, roasted caramel. Tastes malty, roasty with nutty finish. Unfortunately these nuts are very subtle... Cocoa, coffee popping out after a bit warm-up. Malty aftertaste. Low to medium carbonation, medium body. Overall easy drinking, refreshing malty character beer, but very subtle, smooth. Not bad. PL: Butelka 650ml kupiona w Liquor Mart w Winnipeg, przelana do Teku. Barwa ciemno-czerwona, klarowna, piana jasna, Å›redniej wielkoÅ›ci, nieco lejsingu. Aromaty palonych sÅ‚odÃ³w, palonego karmelu. W smaku sÅ‚odowe, palone, lekko orzechowe pod koniec. Niestety orzechy sÄ… bardzo sÅ‚abo wyczuwalne... Po lekkim ogrzaniu wychodzi kakao, kawa. SÅ‚odowe w posmaku. Niskie do Å›redniego wysycenie, Å›rednie odczucie w ustach. PodsumowujÄ…c Å‚atwo pijalne, orzeÅ¼wiajÄ…ce piwo o sÅ‚odowym (ale delikatnym, gÅ‚adkim) charakterze. NiezÅ‚e.
From a 355 ml can. Pours a clear gold with an off white head. Malty aroma. Flavors are moderately sweet honey.

355ml can. (5.0% ABV) Pours a slightly hazy gold with a medium, creamy, short lived, off-white head that laces. Mild aroma of grainy malt, caramel and honey. Sweet flavour of grainy malt, caramel, honey and bitter grass with a dry, metallic finish. Light body with a thin texture and soft carbonation. Bee(!)low average.
Draft - Sweet dark raw honey. Clear gold with a rich white head. Light nice raw honey and some biscuit. Actually OK.

Pours a clear golden yellow with a frothy white head. Aroma of sweet honey, toasted malts, light hop esthers and grainy. Taste is toasted malts, honey, grainy and a bit of hop bitterness on the finish. Nice golden ale thatâ€™s very sessionable.

Pours clear yellow with fluffy white head. Aroma is malty, honey, and some grassy notes. Taste is bitter, flavors of honey and straw. Medium mouthfeel, bitterness throughout and a lingering dry finish. Refreshing, but nothing stands out.

355 ml can. Clear golden yellow, creamy white foam head settles and lasts. Mild sweet malt aroma. Sweet honey saves an otherwise bland, lightly toasted malt taste, a hint of grassy lemon citrus. Softer than average carbonation, light bodied, low hopped. Sâ€™okay. MLF (More Lagerboy Friendly)
Can. Pours pale amber with fizzy white head. Have to say I was disappointed in this beer. Being organic I thought it was going to be magical for some reason but it was quite bland, dry and sweet.
can. Poured clear gold with a bleach white head. Aroma is sweet and grainy. Mouthfeel is light with smooth carbonation. Flavour is light bready malt with some herbal hops.

355ml can pours a pale amber color with a surprising amount of white head and some rather nice lacing left on the glass. Aroma is light malts and mild citrus. Taste is malty sweet with a light citrus hop bitterness in the finish. Light bodied with decent carbonation providing a nice mouthfeel. Easy drinking and somewhat refreshing, but overall this is not up to par with some of the other offerings from this brewery.

The pour is a light gold with a thin off white head. Some nice carbonation and spotty lacing. The nose is light hopped, grassy, slight metallic hint, lots of grain. A light honey sweetnessand a light caramel grain. The taste is similar with a sweet grainy malt, nice honey sweetness, light grassy hop. A light citrus note and a light skunk. Overall, a light sweet and crisp beer.

355ml can. (6.0% ABV) Pours a clear copper-brown with a medium, foamy, long lasting, beige head that leaves curtains of lace. Mild, sweet aroma of toasted malt, caramel, toffee and brown sugar. Sweet flavour of toasted malt, caramel, brown sugar, molasses, chocolate and light spice in a dry finish. Medium body with a watery texture and average carbonation. A little mild, but ok.

Wasnâ€™t sure what to think of this beer. Itâ€™s sessionable and easy to sip on for a beer brewed with molasses and brown sugar. Has a nutty character like an English brown and is too dry for a beer that claims itself to be big.

Pours a clear dark brown with light head and lacing. No bubbles coming coming up. Taste is sweet malty, chocolate and light coffee and vanilla. Nothing stand out so itâ€™s smooth and sessionable, but maybe boring as well. Depend on what youâ€™re looking for on any given day. Above average but not exceptional.
Somewhat complex brown ale type of winter ale. Molasses is subtle. Some toffee and roasted notes -- rated via 'Find A Beer' for Blackberry 10
Pours amber with a large frothy head. Aroma is sweet and slightly malty. Taste is slightly malty, metallic. Itâ€™s alright......

Rating #938 - January 25, 2014 - $8.49 CAD +dep/tax for 6 355mL cans at Coop on ad - . Amber brown pour with a minimal tan head that fades quickly to a ring. Aroma is toffee, chocolate, vanilla, Strong malty notes predominant, slight roasty bitterness. Light bodied, balanced sweet winter ale that is beyond crushable. Nice.
355 ml can, Calgary, AB, Canada. 6% ABV as per can. Clear copper colour. Somewhat sweet metallic mint aroma. Sweet flavour, some xmas spice. Weaker flavour than Iâ€™d hoped for.

Canned: unk Dark brown with some nice fine light cream foam. Smells of bread, toasted rye, some graham and a little bit of herbal hops. Taste is biscuit, cocoa, coffee grounds, some soil, itâ€™s a dry porter like beer with a little more body and a little less dry. Medium bodied with low carb and a wet finish. Good drinker.
can. Poured clear reddish-brown with an off white head. Sugary malty nose. Average carbonation, medium mouthfeel, a touch sticky finish. Roasted malt flavour, raisin and brown sugar notes.
Poured from a 355mL can. Deep mahogany brown colour with nice beige head. Roasted malts, brown sugar, slight hops. Would I buy it again? Probably.
Thick oily pour, just like guineas. The rest of the beer differs from the hallmark. Watered down, more carbonation, and less robust flavor.

Poured into a mug, the appearance was a black color with a thin wisp of a white head that dissipated into oblivion leaving no lace. The aroma triggers dark chocolate, light coffee bean, roasted nuts, and a touch of cream. The flavor blends all of these previously mentioned aromas to boot. Dry rugged roasty aftertaste to finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Mild carbonation. ABV feels fine. Dry in the feel. Overall, good Irish dry stout that I could have again.

Bottle: The aroma consists of light-moderate dark chocolate, black coffee, and roasted nuts. Itâ€™s a dark brown with some orange highlights and a two finger creamy nitro beige head that has decent retention. The flavor starts with light-moderate dark chocolate. The finish has light-moderate roast, mild black coffee, and a touch of roasted nuts. Itâ€™s light-medium bodied with mild carbonation and a somewhat soft mouthfeel.
On tap at the brewery. Comes dark brown with a decent beige head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee. Somewhat dry. Decent.

Very dark with a thick long lasting head. Chocolate and caramel roasted malt on the nose but cocoa and dry hops in the mouth. Had this on tap in the airport in Boston. F Avey---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
(Tap) clear, bright reddish amber colour with a small brown head; aroma of coffee , fruit; balanced flavour with a long, light bitter finish

Sampled at The brewery during the Boston Brew tour. Apparently on nitro. Aroma: roasted malt, smokey, grass. App: light dark, small beige, good lacing. Taste and palate: lots of grass again, medium body, a bit watery, smokey, light bitter finish. Overall: another so so beer from this place. Thank god itâ€™s my last one!

Pours a good black with a creamy cream-colored head that leaves nice lacing. Nose offers a nice rich roastiness and slight ash. Taste is dry and roasty, hey, itâ€™s a dry stout! Medium body and carbonation. A good irish dry stout, Iâ€™d get that again!

On tap on the premise [Canal St] Pours very dark mahogany/black with low beige head. Minimal lacing. Aroma is of metal, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee. Taste is of chocolate, acidity, some bitterness, coffee. Palate: Medium body, creamy texture. Nitro carbonation. Overall: Good.

on tap on the premises - canal st. boston. almost clear medium dark brown, bright purple tint, with a very creamy light beige head, sticky lacing. roasted red maltiness, complex burnt caramel without being ashy; woodsy earthiness, some spices, tasty minerals. low carbonation, light to medium body - oily and smooth; drying woodsy-spicy finish. good standard dry stout.
0,5 l Flasche. Oranges, trÃ¼bes Bier, stabiler Schaum mit schÃ¶ner Gardine. Riecht leicht bananig, schmeckt dann recht laff und wÃ¤ssrig.

NRW-Flasche: Golden, cloudy, medium-sized and slowly collapsing loose off-white head, moderate sweetish fruity-yeasty and wheaty nose; nearly moderate sweet flavour, mild bitterness, mild acidity, soft MF, nearly medium bodied; slightly lingering sweet wheaty-fruity finish with a slight tartness in the aftertaste. Not a demanding, but a well drinkable Weizen...

Super milky cloudy ripe banana yellow. Wheaty and malty aroma with the usual banana and clove. Taste follows the aroma. Watery finish unfortunately. Decent enough, but light on taste. Appearance is also far from perfect.
0.5l bottle. Looks like a golden milkshake with a white head. Aroma and taste of ripe banana, peach and some medicinal hops. A bit watery but an enjoyable fruity weizen.

(Flasche) Es hat eine orangene Farbe, ist trÃ¼b mit einer weiÃŸen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist hefig, Haferflocken, Banane und Weizenmalz. Der Geschmack ist schlank, hefig, ein klein bisschen nelkig mit einem eher schlanken Abgang.

(bottle) murky deep golden colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of cheesecake and yeast, with a light touch of clove, some light banana and oatmeal. flavour is mostly clove and wheat, with a hint of cinnamon, some barnyard and a semi-dry chalky finish. medium-bodied with lively carbonation.
0,5l Flasche. Dunkelgelbes Bier mit toller Schaumkrone. Typischer Geruch nach Banane, im Geschmack keine Ãœberraschungen.

Colour is between yellow and orange, opaque.Much, much foam, itâ€™s very soft and bubbly. Aroma is clove, cereal, yeast. The taste is very soft, sweet. The palate is also sweet, very thin. Better than average.
Bottle from Hol Ab, SÃ¼dstadt, Hannover. Hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, wheaty and banana. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. 110417

Aroma: cloves and weak banana notes. Appearance: hazy golden color and white head. Taste: cloves, weak banana notes, yeasts, dry. Palate: low body and high carbonation. Overall: Average weizenbier, quite empty.
Lata. Unclear deep golden, medium white head. Malty and fruity aroma with yeasty notes. Good palate. Pleasant malty flavour, fruity, soft, mild to medium bitterness. Nice fruity KÃ¶lsch style.

Can. Nose of grass, bread, yeast, and a sliver of citrus. Hazy light yellow color. Grain, bread, citrus, and very gentle bitterness through mid palate and final. Thin body, soft carbonation. Decent, refreshing stuff.

Pours almost clear yellow, a bit of white foam. Aroma is fresh and grassy, some biscuits and a bit of grain. Taste is crisp, fresh bread dominates, clean and completely malt-forward. Simple session beer - but much better than I expected.

On tap at the GJBF in Osaka 2014. Clear light gold with a thin filmy head. Malty, a bit rough and too fruity in my opinion for a KÃ¶lsch. Light bodied, kind of watery. Horrible skunky hoppy flavor, yuck. Not my thing it reminds me of a light struck grolsch. Not sure what was going on here but this beer was subpar.
Bready and slightly sour. Doesnâ€™t leave too much of an impression with some sour apple and a hint of banana, but itâ€™s a decent background beer when food is at the fore.

330 ml bottle. Golden and crystal clear. Medium-sized white fine-laced head that clings to the glass. Clean and fruity aroma with hints of lemon. Refreshing citrusy, mostly lemon, flavours upfront. Watery texture. Very refreshing. Clean malt balanced by quite a bit of acidity. Hops are there but hides well. Easy-drinking golden ale. Not exactly a kÃ¶lsch though.
Can. Hazy, pale golden with a huge white head. Fruity aroma with hints of grass. Sweet flavours that still end up well-balanced. Refreshing and spomewhat complex.

From the can, bought right across from the brewpub, Nov 2007. A rather dark gold color for a Koelsch, quite cloudy with a medium, fine and foamy head. Moderately fragrant, aroma of yeast, malt, a touch of fruit, and some hops. Taste: Very light malt character. Slightly fruity, with a bit of yeast character, not what I would call full-flavored, though either is your average Koelsch. Hops are barely noticeable. A rather uninteresting beer, though a relatively straightforward interpretation of the style, I think. Fruity finish with just enough hops to make it pleasant. No where near worth this ridiculous price.

Glowing, hazy yellow with a very crisp, white head. Grassy, light wheat, yeast, and slight citrus in the nose. Bubbly, medium body. Extremely refreshing. Grassy, some fruit, a touch of lemon, and a bit of biscuit malts. Would love to sit on my porch on a warm summer evening with a few bottles of this.

Can @ Hakodate Station: Gold color, nose of light wheat, clean and light esters and some nice apricot and vanilla notes. Sweet malty body, balanced finish and a pleasant fruity tail that really draws out.
A lagerish aroma from this beer with a thickish hoppish quality to its flavour. A smooth but plain English ale.
A basic hopped English ale, which is hardly warming in the winter. Very plain indeed.

It was a deep amber color with a small clinging head. Its initial taste was sweet caramel malts then immediately very bitter, slightly hoppy aftertaste. It tasted like a Strong Ale to me with very prominent high alcohol content indicative of the doppelbock.

It had a yeast aroma and a taste that was similar to warm fresh sourdough bread, but not as good. It finished with a fruity flavor. None of the flavors were very strong and left something to be desired.
Previous visit - hazy golden with a spicy yeasty nose. Some banana in the flavor as well. Solid.
Pours to a hazy brown body with chestnut highlights. Thin white ring of a head. The flavor is wheat, bubblegum, light cloves. The aroma is light wheat. The palate is creamy and lightly tart.

Draft at brewpub, early Dec â€™05. Buttery yellow and hazy with small head. Good lemony citrus aroma, some clove spiciness. Lemony grassy malt flavors, with a sweeter finish, and more clove notes. Decent.

@ SM Brewpub: Hazy yellow color with a minimal white head. Banana in the flavor and aroma. Also included is some clove and light spice. Light to medium bodied. Not too bad on this one at least no diacetyl.

(Draft: San Marcos Brewery & Grill in San Diego, CA) Starts off with a fairly spicy nose like a Belgian; The flavor features a nice spiciness, banana, bubble gum, and a moderate sweetness, and once again, is strongly suggestive of a Belgian; Palate is medium bodied, a little sticky from the sweetness, but not heavy or cloying; Banana yellow in color and fully cloudy as expected from an unfiltered wheat; Off-white head fades fast and leaves no lacing whatsoever
Instantly noticeable pear candy aroma and sweet canned pear flavor. Banana character comes through in latter half along with a little grainy dryness.
On tap at the Avalon Brewpub. A good effort at a hefeweizen and better than average for a Mark James Group beer. Also above average for a brewpub British Columbian wheat beer.
This is the standout beer from Avalon for sure. Deep, cloudy, yellow colour. Banana aroma and mellow banana flavour to match. Lightly sprtizy, yet fuller-bodied for a hefe.
Cloudy amber,thin head. Yeasty nose. Yeasty citrus flavor...................

Cloudy beige; crisp, wheaty, citric aroma (though they did serve it with lemon before I could stop them). Toned down banana compared to other Mark James hefes. Drier all round as well, with a decent bit of hop in the finish, and lacking the malty sweetness that Yaletown''s hefe in particular has. Not a bad wheat, but a little different from what I expected at a Mark James brewpub.

Aroma is soft malts and nothing else. Has a good lighter copper body and minimal head. Flavour is soft sweet grains. Mouthfeel is weak and semi-watery. This is too sweet and no crispness, not my kind of beer.

On June 19, 2015. At Dockside Brewing Co., in Vancouver, British Columbia. Clear deep golden color, white head. Malty, crisp taste. Malty aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness. Malty, a bit sweet scent.
Draft - Light grains and some earthy hops. Clear gold with a thin white head. Apple and some bitterness with some cooked cabbage in the finish.

On tap at Dockside, pours a hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma is very bland, with subtle notes biscuity malt. Flavour doesnâ€™t strike me as much of a pale ale - there are some subtle fruity notes and not a whole lot else. Lifeless beer with not much character. Bad.

Draft@Dockside Brewery and Restaurant, Vancouver. Dark amber brown beer with a good head. The aroma is lightly malty and hopped, and the flavour is malty with some gentle hopped bitterness. Overall a very nice mildly malty and reasonably hopped beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pint on tap at the brewpub pours a pale amber color with a small white head that leaves only small traces of lacing on the glass. Aroma is mild hops and caramel. Taste is a caramel malty sweetness with a mild hop bitterness. Light to medium body with soft carbonation. Very light in body and flavor compared to some of the northwest American pale ales from Washington and Oregon.
At the bar on Granville Island. Interesting beer. good pale ale taste, but nothing very special...

Draught@brewpub, Vancouver Dark amber color, small off-white head. Light caramelly malty aroma. Light-bodied. Light caramel malty flavor and too little of Centennial hops. Kind of Newcaste Brown Ale imitation.

Glass, 6-ounce, draught, on the premise, savoured on May 1 2009; eye: golden with a copper hue, clear, slight effervescence, tiny ring of white head, slight lacing; nose: malt, light hops, light grapefruit, light dusty; mouth: malt, light hops, light grapefruit, thin finale in malt with presence of hops, slightly bitter, light-medium body, rather carbonated, slightly grainy texture; overall: ordinary FRANÃ‡AIS Verre, 6 onces, en fÃ»t, bue sur place, savourÃ©e le 1er mai 2009; Å“il : dorÃ©e avec une teinte cuivrÃ©e, claire, trÃ¨s lÃ©gÃ¨re effervescence, petit anneau de mousse blanche, trÃ¨s lÃ©gÃ¨re dentelle; nez : malt, lÃ©ger houblon, lÃ©ger pamplemousse, lÃ©ger poussiÃ¨re; bouche : malt, lÃ©ger houblon, lÃ©ger pamplemousse, finale mince en malt avec une petite prÃ©sence de houblon, trÃ¨s lÃ©gÃ¨rement amÃ¨re, corps lÃ©ger-moyen, plutÃ´t carbonatÃ©e, texture trÃ¨s lÃ©gÃ¨rement rugueuse, un peu aqueuse; en rÃ©sumÃ© : ordinaire

Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear light orange color with a thin white head. Not much in the way of aroma other than some subdued steeping barley. Imagine your neighbor brewing a batch of beer in his/her kitchen with the window open. Light bodied, watery actually, and delicately sweet with minimal bitterness. tasted of white paper, poorly made caramel, a bit of stale grain, and subdued grass. Bad news.
Dark amber; light nose; light palate. If the brewer is only going to make me a half-assed beer, then all they get is a half-assed rating.
Braun gelb schÃ¶ner schaum, im Geruch und Geschmack malzig getreidig mit sÃ¼ÃŸer Honig Note, naja
0,5l Flasche. Bernsteinfarben und klar. Hoher feiner fester Schaum. Sanfter Honigduft. Malz, Karamell. Langweilger Geschmack. Getreide, etwas Honig. Zucker.

"Ritter 1645", Flasche aus dem Landbierparadies, NÃ¼rnberg. - Kupferbraun, klar. - In der Nase tiefes gebranntes Malz, Karamel, leicht weinige ZÃ¼ge; milde hintergrÃ¼ndige Hopfenherbe. - Antrunk stark karamelmalzig (Blockmalz) mit kerniger KaramelsÃ¼ÃŸe und zarten weinig-fruchtigen ZÃ¼gen (Weinstein). Dezente, leicht krÃ¤uterige Hopfung mit etwas Orange. Milder rezent, vollmundig; leichte mineralische HÃ¤rte. Im Abgang angenehme Malzbittere aber nur knappe Hopfenherbe. - Kernig malziges MÃ¤rzen, etwas unterhopft aber originell, kantig und auf seine Art sÃ¼ffig. SchÃ¶n.

Many thanks for this beer to Mariusz. piwo ma gigantyczna piane i bardzo trwala. piwo ma kolor jasno bursztynowy. nadmiar karmelowej slodowosci i nieco tosotwej nuty mnie denerwowalo, nie zbyt to smaczne bylo. Ale piana ratuje to piwo przed przepascia., fajna tez jest etykieta.
SchÃ¶ne Shaumkrone. Dunkle wie Cola Farbe. In die Nase gehen Getreide, Schaschlik, Rauch. Guten Geschmack: voll, malzig und bishen wÃ¼rzig. Abgang ist auch malzig, wÃ¼rzig, sÃ¼ssig.
Klares Bernstein mit relativ wenig Schaum. Malzig, etwas Karamell, leicht getreidig, wÃ¼rzig, sÃ¼ffig.
500ml Bottle - Amber with a foamy head. Sultanas, bread and caramel in the aroma. Nutty and slightly sweet taste with bready malt, caramel, sultanas and apricot.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Floral aroma - sugary sap to be precise - with an underlying maltyness. Dark Amber. Off-white head; initially very impressive but soon shrinks away. Ever so slightly bitter, with a sweet and sour finish. Thereâ€™s a maltyness in there and some fruit. I rarely eat fruit so am struggling to place it. Something thatâ€™s been tinned in syrup no doubt. However itâ€™s not overdone, more sweetness would have been offputting for me. Light bodied. Thereâ€™s a lot of carbonation - itâ€™s really at the forefront. A slick mouthfeel in to the relatively abrupt finish. Would down a few of these and then hope no-one notices my burping and farting.
Bottle - copper color with a nice head. Taste is malty, some toffee, slightly sour. Some hops. Not too sweet, which i like here. Very well balanced. Carbo is low to medium. Well done.
Cobrizo limpio y espuma beis. Aromas de cereal, pan y caramelo. Sabor cono en aroma y final seco.

Keg at The brewpub. It pours deep red with a small off-white head. The nose is sweet, juicy, oily, candied peel, red berry and jam. The taste is bitter-sweet, oily, juicy, red berry, strawberry, earthy roast, grass and jam with a short, dry finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Errs towards being too sweet, but drinkable enough. Standard brewpub red.

A very drinkable drink but none too special. Rusty amber, off-white head with smell of brown toast, nuts and honey. A bittersweet, malt-forward bevvie with mid-low carbonation and lightly oily body. Bitter finish on her. Not bad.

Not one of their better beers. Pours a nice clear amber. Smells like beer, maybe a bit of nuttiness. Taste however is not good, a bit skunked. Slightly fruity to start, and a weird bitter aftertaste that lingers. To be avoided. Had on tap at the brewpub.
Smooth on the palate, good tasting beer, tastes lighter than it actually is, nice dark red colour.
Tap. Reddish pour with a nice head. Pretty easy to drink but not a lot of rogue flavor.
Bottle at flemings ...reddish brown pour.. white head... biyter hoppy gir a red...not bad at all..would do agaib

Clear, light red and muted aroma. malts and sweet caramel notes with a slight hint of roast.Light beer with caramel and sweet malts and a weird apple note in the mid palate. Molasses like finish. boring beer but not as bland as the other ones.

On tap at brewpub (as Marzen [Red Ale]). Pours a clear amber/copper with modest off-white head; some retention. Light fruity, caramel malt aroma. Taste is caramel and stale grains; somewhat acidic. A little bitterness in finish. Light carbonation. Pretty weak.

Hazy, and oddly less red than the IPA, which is very red. Decent beige head and nice lacing. Caramel malt, almost a hint of ringwood in the aroma as well as grassy hop. Nice low carbonation and soft mouthfeel. Nutty aftertaste, sweet entry and middle. Bordering on tasting juicy and is then rescued by a roasty, nutty, slightly hopped aftertaste. Ends up nice, balanced, and sessionable.

Draught. Light malt notes of cereal and grain, moderate hop aroma of herbs, and wine, cooked vegetables and paper in the background. Head is thin, creamy white, with fair lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is clear red. Flavor starts lightyl acidic and finishes moderately bitter. Palate is light, watery and has a lively carbonation. An average tasting beer with one off quality in the aroma.
Massive bottle in salta Argentina. Very generic boring lager. Still, pleasant on a hot day.
Salta, Argentina El Carril, Salta - puntos 2 2015 Tomada con Z Diciembre 2015 ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a clear yellow with a small yellow head. Both aroma and taste are the usual pale lager stuff. Donâ€™t expect the world and you wonâ€™t be disappointed.
This Beer is called a Munich style lager and I think that is insulting all the beers of Munich... ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle, a clear gold with a white frothy head. A strong grassy hop aroma. Very dry and bitter with a sweet malty flavour. Typical lager.
In Can. Yellowish, very clear color. Almost without head, only it skims off that it goes out. It is very watery and without body. Really a beer water, I cannot say any more.

Can. Thin yellowish colour. Hardly any head, or rather foam. Some strange malty aroma.Thin flavour of what I believe is in the category of malt. Very waterish brew indeed! Drank it in the desert in Bolivia. Only beer available....
Another "regional" beer from one of Argentinas largest brewerys. Bland flavour, kind of like slightly soapy water.

column1: Flying Pig Curly Tails Golden Ale
column5: Crystal clear apple juice with white head. Aroma is medium sweet, bready. Taste is medium sweet, bready, light lemon. Light body, a bit high in carbonation.

column1: Flying Pig Curly Tails Golden Ale
column5: Deep gold color. Decently hopped for the style but slightly flat............
Hazy amber body with white head. Aroma is medium sweet, grapefruit, some lemon, light bready. Taste is medium sweet, grapefruit (somewhat subdued), caramel. Medium body. Nicely balanced.
Light brown with lasting off white head. Easy drinking beer, but far too few hops for IPA or even a pale
Gorgeous orange-bronze color with a deep, musky clove and wheat in the nose, and a taste that accurately follows this.
Opaque golden body with off-white head. Aroma is medium sweet, clove, light banana, wheat. Taste is medium sweet, clove, banana, wheat. Crisp light-medium body, a bit fizzy. Nice beer!
Not a bad imitation of a german hefe. Light yeast nose, tart yeasty palate..

on tap at the Roost. two finger head with a nice dark black colour. Muted aroma but there is some roast, sweet malts and chocolate. it is a medium bodied brew, considering the style, and fairly sweet as well with cocoa powder flavour. it is surprisingly decent.

En fÃ»t au pub: VersÃ© dans un verre Ã  lait(?). Moyen mince en bouche avec une Ã©trange prÃ©sence fruitÃ© artificielle de framboise(?) alors quâ€™il en est aucunement mention sur la carte des biÃ¨res. Avec les notes chocolatÃ©s, on obtient quand mÃªme une biÃ¨re acceptable.

Draught. Malt has a heavy smell of toasted and molasses, moderate perfumey hop note, light earth for the yeast, with licorice, cola raisin and alcohol in the background. Head is small, light brown, creamy, has good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is black. Flavor starts lightly sweet and acidic, then finishes moderately acidic and lightly bitter. Palate is medium to full, syrupy and has a soft carbonation. A unique Imperial Stout with some remarkable tastes.

On tap in the Rogues. Wake up and smell the coffee. Good appearance, Looks like a strong coffee, but cold obviously. Smooth, smoked texture, goes down well. not sure what the alcohol % is but seems strong. Its snowing outside, its cold and this is going down a treat.
dark as sin, some beige head, coffee on the nose, lotsa roatyness, kinda bitter, has some good choc notes kinda odd on the palate

Tap at the brewpub. Pitch black beer with a thin white head. Aroma is moderately sweet, some chewy maltiness, brown sugar, fairly assertive roastiness, light cherry fruitiness, molasses, toast. Some lingering sweetness. A decent, if somewhat understated impy.
black with small tan head, nice lace. Nice aroma with chocolate, burnt toast, and molasses and bitter hops. Flavor not bad, goes down very smoothly, but body is not what was expected.

Draft, 2005. Black body, with a small chocolate brown coloured head. Mild muted roast in the aroma is coffee beans and dark chocolate but lacks cohesion. Flavour has a big initial roasty acoidity in the introduction but this fades as the glass goes on. Bitter muted chocolate, mild roast acidity throughout. Dry chalky cocoa in the finish. Average to medium palate has an almost oily mouthfeel but it is too thin for the beer in my opinion. Pleasantly enjoyable, but lacks the depth of character for transcendance.

Black colour; thin light brown head. Aroma of roasted barley, tempered by light molasses, plus raisins, and faint esters (red currant?). Slightly oily, slightly creamy body. Mellow fruity-toffee maltiness predominates with just a hint of roasty tang. A little bit of lemony, peachy hop comes in late.

2004: 7.8% abv. Black in colour with a thin diminishing frothy tan head. Milk chocolate and roasty aroma. Chocolate, roasted coffee flavour with a lingering licorice and alcohol finish. Full bodied but thin mouthfeel with a light alcohol burn. Good for here in NS, hell itâ€™s the only Imperial anything available around here, but disappointing up against the big boys of Imperial Stout. (6/4/7/3/13) 2003: 9% abv. Black with some glints of ruby. Almost no head, just some traces of off-white foam. Coffee, slight chocolate, and alcohol aroma. Coffee and some licorice flavours with a heavy alcohol finish. Big thick, rich and smooth mouthfeel. (6/4/7/4/14)
Quite good. Red in several features but strong in most of them. Well made and excellent in taste.
A very nice no n malty barleywine. Super easy to drink. Slightly malty and sweet and bitter. Pours a deep red with a light tan head ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. Aroma- Malt and fruit, has a sweet smell. Appearance- This is an amber colored beer with medium sized off-white head. Taste- Malt, toffee and alcohol; not a bad mix. Palate- A medium to heavy bodied beer with moderate carbonation. Has a strong alcohol aftertaste. Overall- Not a bad barleywine, my first beer from Boulder Beer. I will drink this again and try their other labels.

DATE TASTED: January 26, 2015... GLASSWARE: Duvel oversized snifter... OCCASION: still waiting for Superstorm Iola to hit... APPEARANCE: starts well with an imposing label; intimidating dark garnet body that sports a frothy off-white head that laces with a brazen two-finger strength; lacing is spectral and substantial... AROMA: BIG apple, pear and sour fruit; powerful cherries--a nice mix of a beefy malty base and a kriek... PALATE: full-bodied, warming and hearty--yet smoothly sippable; a balanced barleywine, though it lacks a dry finish...TASTE: cherries are front and center; soft brown ale elements play on the sugary fruits; oddly not as winy as a barley purports to be...OVERALL:as I recalled from years past, a beer worthy of a blizzard watch; the price is about right for its heft; within its genre, not a standout, with enough imperfections to seek out better-rated beers...

A nice barelywine, smooth but not the most interesting. Pours a beautiful clear red with a tan head. Smells of bourbon, caramel and apple cinnamon. Taste is creamy, with a lot of maltiness, more caramel and cinnamon, and some green apple and booziness in the finish. Paired with Mac & Cheese Balls, a booziness and spiciness is brought out that lingers. Happy 998.
Pour at the Coney Island beer festival at mcu park. Dark brown barley wine style with a sweet bready taste

Had this beer on 4/2/2003. Aroma is a sweet malt scent like you would expect from a Scottish Ale. Color is a rich clear amber with very good carbonation and a nice head. Taste is malty and bitter. Starting with a full body that goes down with a mellow sharpness. Finish is a sweet rich malt flavor backed by quick bitterness. In the end it leaves you with a warm alcohol feel.

Date: 11/29/2004 Mode: Bottle Source: Trade clear dark red, nice fine light brown head, sweet citrus aroma, creamy body, big sweet carmel malt flavor with lots of hop character, low bitterness, good in a me-too imperial ipa kind of way, -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 02/01/2007 Mode: bottle Source: aa Vintage: 2006 Score: 3.8 to 3.0 thining out with muted hops but the fruity malt is not kicking in yet, a muddy middle age mess Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: **/4

rating from memory, had this around 11/06, 22oz bomber, purchased at Chuckâ€™s wine and spirits outside of cleveland. pours dark amber, nose sorta old ale like, sweet caramel and fruits. taste was pretty enjoyable, sweet malts, fruits, chocolate, and subtle vegetable notes. pretty tasty and aged fine.

11-Sep-06 (22 oz bottle: Obtained 30-Jul-04 in trade with Eyedrinkale, thanks Mike!) Lots of age under this one, so the characteristics arenâ€™t surprising; it tastes and smells malty, earthy (the aroma is almost pungently so), chocolaty and moderately sweet. Brown sugar and dark fruits, but itâ€™s moderately sweet, staying far away from anything remotely cloying. Bitterness, either from roastiness or hops is very mild if it ever existed in the first place. Whatever spice might have been in this winter-warmer-gone-wild is tough to pick out at this stage over the earthiness and dark fruits. Really coming across as an aged old ale to me. As mentioned, the aroma is earthy, but unmistakable sweet fruits come out even more. Body is medium-full and medium carbonation has held up perfectly after two-plus years in the bottle. Light brown in color, the beer is cloudy out of the bottle, but it pretty much clears up completely over time. Small, light-tan head shows more life on the second (and thus warmer) pour, but either way, it settles to a filmy layer after not too long. Only a few wisps of lace stick to the glass. Very enjoyable to drink, but this has almost certainly transformed into quite a different beer from when it was fresh. And with the aging, it has followed a pretty standard transition toward earth and dark fruits, but the chocolate overtones give it a nice note of distinction.
