On tap at Founders. According to the sign on the wall, this is 8% ABV, and more reminiscent of a Tripel than a Blond Ale. Poured yellow-orange colored, with a creamy medium off-white head. Banana and perhaps a touch of clove in the aroma, which developed vinous characteristics as the beer warmed. Flavor was very fruity, like a cross between bananas and white wine. Lemon characteristics were nicely developed as well. In fact, this beer had a candy-like flavor that reminded me of the candy coating on lemon "Crybaby" sour gumballs. Alcohol shows up in the aftertaste but is nicely subdued in the body. Spritzy and tasty, this is probably a different recipe than last year's batch.
Alcohol well hidden. Quite fruity but bland and quite plain. Not sure exactly what this style entails.

Poured into a pint glass, the appearance was a clear light amber color, thin white cap of a head. Sly lace. The aroma had some light grassy hop elements. Light lingering toast/biscuits. Sweet butter (not diacetyl). The flavor leaned towards the malty side but with that British bitter edge to it. Sly biscuit malt aftertaste and finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Moderate carbonation. ABV felt fine. Overall, decent to me, and seemingly decent as an ESB.

Draught in a flight at the MLT brewpub. Pours a clear light amber color. Nose has some light grassy elements to it, and seems a bit bitter. Taste is only slightly bitter, but has some hints of malty sweetness to it. OK.
Draft at Mountlake Terrace brewpub. Darker sweet orange-brown, soapy head. Malty caramel. Medium syrup body, dry bitter. bready yeast. Solid, if a little boring, ESB.
Draught at the brewpub, 6.1% ABV Dark amber color. Light aroma of caramel. Good body strength; quite good caramel flavor, correct bitterness. Not complex, but fine ESB.
Nice english style bitter that had a good malt balance and nice mouthfeel although it may have been a little carbonated and not totally my thing.
Clear caramel color/ lasting white head; nice lacing. Toasted, spicy caramel aromas with a whiff of pit fruit. Smooth medium body. Spicy sweet toasted caramel, marshmallow, grainy malt flavors--good.

My Bottom Line: Toasted malts and their caramelized counterparts are bothered by dusty minerals before bitter hop resins conclude an otherwise drinkable Extra Special Bitter. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam tops the hazy dark amber, lacing well. -That dusty impression, present in all of their brews that day, was akin to hard tap water. -The flavor profile was a tad too generic to be memorable. -This remains balanced throughout. On tap at the Front St. brewpub

Tap at the brewpub. Pours ruddy amber with a creamy beige head. Floral aroma over a caramel backdrop. Med body. Nice mild roast caramel backbone with a lot of earthy/flroal hop. Died and gone to England.

2010-07-01. Crisp golden amber body with a small off-white head and lace. 3+ Flavour is mild, pleasant light bitterness throughout, hints at citrus in the finish but a vegetal hop character spoils the effect. Aroma is mild, grainy malt, brief caramel and mild hops. Average palate, on the light side. Meh. On tap at Diamond Knot, Mukilteo

[3052-20100701] Tap. Toasted malt aroma has a hint of maple. Clear, orange amber body with a medium-lasting foamy off-white head and some lacing. Toasted bread malt flavour is fairly grainy. Medium body. Good, could stand even more malt. (@ brewpub, Mukilteo, WA)

Maybe the best beer they have...but donâ€™t get excited by that! Very mild hop bitterness, and I do mean mild...Weird detergent aftertaste...maybe they just cleaned their tap lines....but thatâ€™s OK, because it had SOME flavor...
This doesnâ€™t really seem like an APA to me. All I really tasted was a soap-like quality and lots of malt. Little carbonation.

Light orangy amber hue with faded fizzy head and no lace or body. The aroma hints of floral hops and citrus, caramel malts, but also displays a soapy and vegetable nose. The taste has a buttery biscuit, grainy and twangy hops taste, but again an off-taste of veggies and dirty lines ruin the palate. Mouthfeel is watery and bland, fizzy, no depth. Avoid this an ALL Duneland beers until under new ownership or till the day it closes.
Light copper color. Tastes like rubber and yeast. Sparkling mouthfeel. Phenol. Some type of inner-tube taste. Some cereal tastes. Needs more hop and malt flavors to make this have more character.
RateBeer Summer 2003: Clear light orange color, stale hops aroma with a bit of malts. Flat mouthfeel. Unimpressive.

RBSG2003 Crystal clear amber brew. Small, creamy white head. The aroma is Malt Heaven! Caramel Popcorn! Butterscotch, toffee... everything malt! Original Ovaltine. Vanilla. Smells great! The flavor is rich and malty! Abundance of tart hop flavor to balance things out. Slightly vineous as well. Medium-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and pillow-soft carbonation. Lengthy, dry, astringent finish.
Slightly sweet, some malt and a bit of hops. This doesnâ€™t automatically good beer. Average.

OHHHH!!!! The slightest hint of hops lets them call this a Pae Ale. Obviously the brewer has never had a pale ale... They aren't supposed to smell like bubblegum and soap, They aren't supposed to be flat and lifeless, and they are supposed to have somewhat of a balance between malt and hops. This place has been close to my house for years and I've never heard of it...now I know why. RE-RATE: Much closer to a pale ale in the bottle, just don't get one from the tap!!
Hugely syrupy, like an intense version of their amber, but a deeper, darker color and some interesting roasty and hoppy bitters.
Really dark brown. Once again a rubber, phenol, new shoes smell. Bland, not offensive, but really, really bland.

I don't know what to say except I truly sorry for anyone who has had this crap. Embarrassed by the fact this is brewed (if that is the right word) in my home county. Flat lifeless brown water with a hint of roasted malt thrown in. No body or taste. At least the wheat was not offensive.
Void of life, this brown water ale had a nose of bubblegum and wet cardboard. Almost completely absent of flavor, with just a pinch of sweet malts. Very poor quality. Hardly a brown ale.
A poor excuse for a brown. This is a brewpub for people who don''t like beer.
The amber is really dark and the brown is really light, so they come out with the same color, basically. It has body, malt, and hops, but all weak and somewhat at war with each other.
Another disappointment from this place. They seem to be completely clueless about what theyâ€™re trying to create. I also was served this at just above freezing.

Clear black stout with an off-white big bubbled head. Licorice aroma transforming into ashtray as beer warms up. Coffee and ashes in mouth, with lots of bitterness in finale. Decent body. Flawed. (July 31 at Indiana Microbrewers Festival)

Regular roasted coffee smell and taste. Milky and creamy, light hop presence, but too thin. Basic sweet stout. Presentation points take a hit when they served this STOUT to me in a PILSENER glass, frosted, with ice floaties in it. I didn't even realize there were floaties until my first drink, when I felt something solid hit my lips and tongue, and my immediate reaction was to spit it back into the glass, as if I'd just sucked in a bug. Pissed me off. To be honest, the stout was not bad, it was just average. Mike and Joe later told me about the brown ale, and so now I'm curiously wanting to try it in a Cave Creek Chili Beer way.

Served in an overly chilled glass. Perhaps their most flavorful beer. Dark, with a chocolate head. Creamy, smooth nose like chococolate candy, which carries through into the flavor. Some hops and a melted candy bar. Tasted more like an ImpStout than a sweet stout.

Dark brown with reddish tones around the adges. Okay tan head and good lacing. Faint coffee/chocolate aroma. Hints of roasted grains, smoke and prune. Thin bodied for a stout, good bitter and sweet balance, bitter aftertaste. Dry and creamy mouthfeel. While drinkable compared to their other offerings, still way below average for the style.
I echo Hennes rating. I purchased a growler for the Summer gathering, so everyone can taste this one. Very light all around stout, identical to the one you would brew with a Mr Beer Kit.

Really the only Duneland brew worth drinking. It has a subtle smoked fish tone to its roast, some solid oaty notes, and a creamy mouthfeel. I might be overating it out of relief that I found a real beer in the joint, but I did appreciate coming to this one at the end of the session.
Very weak attempt at an American Wheat...flat, tasteless, boring, and completely out of character for the style.
There was a lemon stuck in there. Semi-clear look. Strong Pledge type of nose -- fake lemon. Muted hops and absolutely no wheat flavors. Some yeast flavors, but overall a poor representation.

It was listed as a unfiltered hefe, what I got sure looked like a darker Krystall, almost no head either.Faint aroma with hints of grain, lemongrass, banana and some spices. What flavor? Just a light hint of malt and spices. VERY BLAND! A very bad wheat, lacks any characteristics of a hefe. Boring. Water would have been as good. Stuff like this is why many hate American Wheats. Avoid like the plague!

Nothing in this beer, but an old dried out lemon wedge. Absolutely flat, not a hint of cloudiness, barely an aroma, barely a flavor to be identified. Light golden colored water with an old piece of lemon on the rim. Piss poor quality.
Well, it does have a bit of a body, but it''s absolutely amazing how little flavor it has. I mean, you have to really work to get so unobtrusive a brew.
Add a marichino cherry to the IceMaster and you have this brew. Not much more than a kiddie cocktail.
Pale straw color with a smaller white head. Neutral aroma. Light grain sweetness with little esle to report.
Very, very light. Beyond yellow and into a tinged water. Clean. Some hops, but corn offers an odd taste. Smooth, refreshing type beer.

column1: Brewmasters South Kenosha Gold Brewmasters Pilsner
column5: Festival tap: Clear yellow with tiny head. Lager yeast and graininess. Light all around. some faint grassiness at finish.

column1: Brewmasters South Kenosha Gold Brewmasters Pilsner
column5: Protein hazed golden color with a small white cover of bubbles. Light malt and lager yeast aromas. Light pale malt, sweet start that leads to scads of floral hops and mild acidic bitterness. Actually served way too cold, but flavors still come out. Very malty finish.

column1: Brewmasters South Kenosha Gold Brewmasters Pilsner
column5: Slightly hazy look. Bit better than the average pilsner. Very smooth almost like there's nothing there. However, that is a detriment to the overall appeal with no real flavors or tastes coming through. Some hops or malt would have been nice.

column1: Brewmasters South Kenosha Gold Brewmasters Pilsner
column5: The commercial description is adequate with these caveats: To me this brew lacks the hoppy bitter bite of a good true Pilsner and as a lager leans too much toward the standard American style of insipid body, head, and flavor. I would prefer it over most of the American standards, with the understanding that none of them are my preference. Its finish is mildly sweet. The bottles of Kenosha Gold that I acquired were brewed by Gray Brewing Co. of Janesville under authority of Brewmasters' Pub, Ltd. of Kenosha, WI
Named after Saint Brendan. Dark brown color with a smaller taupe head. Light roasted malt flavors. Fairly light and body so the oatmeal almost seems wasted. Seems more like a brown porter.
Dark. Smoke, bacon flavors. No oatmeal. Tastes really similar to a ham and cheese sandwich, lightly grilled with a drop of butter.

HAHAHAHA I laughed my ass off at how little taste this crap has. This is one of their more popular offerings, probabally because it is one of the more boring ones, how do you expect to SELL people on drinking beer if this is the sort of crap you come up with.

This beer tastes only slightly better than Coors or Budweiser. Iâ€™d take a Miller Lite over this beer any day... High carbonation, even for a lager, and weak taste. I can see why this is their most popular beer - itâ€™s the best beer they have. Even so, you can see the other ratings. Itâ€™s just plain bleh.
Grainy stale aroma, sticky sweet crackers/wet toast, finish odd, long, and...papery. Cereal aftertaste.
Iâ€™d say this tasted really clean. I guess that means that there wasnâ€™t any noticable good or bad tastes. Just a slightly bitter ale. Some breadcrumb flavors. Decent.
Draught at the brewpub. Clear golden color with thin white head. Flowery hop aroma balanced well with the malt. This is one of their better offerings.

On tap at the brewpub. Light yellow with fizzy big bubbles to its white head. Slight malty, hay-like aroma, but very slight. Watery harsh palate. Slight metallic finish. Sodium bicarbonate is the dominant flavor! No hops.

One of the best this place has to offer. But that isnâ€™t saying much. Dark amber with a trace of a white head. Aroma of hay, bananas and some cocoa. A very weird combo for a pale ale. The taste is surpisingly sweet with dark bread and a toasted finish.
Sample at the brewpub. Medium clear amber, full-looking for a light; ok fresh grassy nose; light flavor, a hint of grainy hops, some biscuit in the background, not bad.
I was not terribly impressed with Bricktown in Dubuque. I am not totally surprised they went out of business. This was not well balanced. Serving: Tap
Pretty dark, too sweet, fairly detestable. But if youâ€™re there in the winter, and you gotta get a beer... this one is probabally what you ought to go with.

Pint at the brewery. Winter 2006 version. Red and brown colored body. Clear/filtered appearance. Has a light spiced nose with notes of peppermint, nutmeg and candy sugar. Flavor is similar - lght on the palate, nothing too complex or interesting, with a tasty mild spiced cherry, wood and candy sugar flavor. Reminds me of a very tame version of Troegs Mad Elf. I could probably have written a review of this beer just from sticking my head in the brewpub - nothing too fancy, nothing too â€™flavorfulâ€™ - brewed to not offend the Iowan palate.

Draught at the brewpub. Clear light orange color without much head. Smells distinctly of brown sugar. Brown sugar comes out again in the flavor along with some cinnamon and possibly nutmeg. Flavor is also somewhat reminiscent of malt extract.
Aroma of light mint and some malts. The taste is toast with some burnt sugar. Maybe a hint of mint. This poured a darker gold color. Not sure what was the goal with this beer.

This was quite bad. Tasted like light beer plus artificial vanilla flavoring. I would have never tried this at all but I fell for the classic trick: very attractive bartender plus "Here, this is my favorite, try this", and she puts sample glass in my hand. Serving: Tap

Watery, crappy, tastes like chemicals and bud light. I know itâ€™s a chick beer and everything, but the artfical flavoring added after fermentation dosenâ€™t even make it all that sweet or tasty. Furthermore, shouldnâ€™t we have a little more respect for the "chick" beer drinkers, I know they can handle a little more flavor than this. WITH VANILLA ADDED!

Thereâ€™s a fake vanilla flavor to this terrible beer. Only one sip was all I needed to know I wasnâ€™t going to be drinking any more of that beer. I think I could get better results adding imitation vanilla to a budweiser.

Well, at least this wasnâ€™t a vanilla porter. Too tired of vanilla porters. With that said, there needs to be some type of end to vanilla beers. There is a nice authentic bean flavor to this. Overall, the flavors are very faint, but at least theyâ€™re not too fake. Sort of tasted like a vanilla shake sort of bitter.
Draught at the brewpub. Clear golden color with fleeting white head. Cloying vanilla flavor and aroma. Slightly sweet. No trace of hop as far as I could tell. Odd at best.
Light gold body with a trace of head. Overwhelming vanilla aroma. The taste is like a light lager with the vanilla only in the finish. Underwhelming and one dimensional.
Dark brown appearance and a dark brown effervesence makes this a bland beer. Weak malts, vanilla doesnâ€™t penetrate like it should. Not a great effort, a little too blatantly sweet as well.

Brown in color. Weak malt content prevents vanilla flavoring from tasting synthetic. Poor head retention. Little or no hop content. If you like flat dark water with a slight chemical taste, this oneâ€™s for you. UPDATE: The brewer now calls this Gorilla Vanilla. It still sucks. Itâ€™s now yellow and fizzy with overcarbonation. Smells like a cream soda. Sodium burn on the tongue hurts the palate. No hops. A little metallic.
Just read my notes from our vacation and realilized that I didn't rate this one. As I read my notes it says it was more of a wheat taste and a crisp aftertaste. More of a brown appearence.

Aroma is decent with floral attributes, apperance is a deep, hazy copper body with average carbonation and a small white cap. Flavor was a little disappointing in that there was only bitterness, (like old hops) the aftertaste softened a little with some hop and sweet malt tones at the very end. Overall it was o.k. but not great, i will try it again. Originally rated on 10/29/08
Rated based on notes taken 3 Nov 2012 -- I think I was in a really good mood when I rated this beer, cuz I rated it much higher than I recall it being.
Clear amber with a nice white head and great lacing. Aroma has some sweet citrus citrus, tea, and grains. Taste is citrus rind, grass, and faint toffee. Soft carbonation. Easy to drink.

On tap at the Bottle Shop. Orange with a white head. The aroma and flavor are full of light biscuit malt, with some light citrus and grain notes. Low bitterness. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Bottle poured a clear gold with a lasting off white head. Aromas of biscuit, earthiness and light citrus. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of biscuit, earthiness and a hint of citrus with a smooth dry moderatly bitter finish.
a very soft pale ale. like an imperial english pale. has a great aroma though.
Draft 4/14/10 (Opal Divineâ€™s Freehouse)-Pours a light amber with a full white head. Aroma of hops. Taste of the same with some citrus. This medium bodied pale was not too shabby.
Not a bad little Pale Ale. Nice overall flavor from a solid Austin brewing company. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Good pour with a thick, foamy head. Body is amber in color. Overall a decent beer. Nice amount of hops for a pale ale. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap. Hazy gold pour. Hoppy aroma, not much else. Rather bland except for some bitterness and a metallic aftertaste. If I was harsh, Iâ€™d say it tasted like someone added hops to a budweiser.
It pours deep brown with an off white head. It has a medium body with soft carbonation. There taste has toasted malt and lightly earthy hops, but had a heavy mineral aspect and fairly astringent.

Pours a cola colored brown with a small white head which dissipates quickly......aroma typical of browns with a slight mineral, light touch of coffee.......taste is nice mouthfeel and slight toasted grain, touch of mineral and pulpwood. A fair english brown.
caramel, roasty, dough, tan foam, brown, clear, light sweetness, light body, thin feel, average carbonation,
Dark brown color creamy head. Aromas caramel, toffee, toasted malt medium. Flavors medium caramel, toffee, light toasted malt, nutty. Light to medium sweet. Has decent body.
Sampled at GABF 2015. In the tasting glass amber brown with an off white head. Nose is roasted chocolate malts. Nuts maybe. Medium body. Flavor malty with a little hops. Light biter finish. OK.
Ugh. Pours black with minimal head. Flavor is just a combination of hop and roasted malt bitterness. Light bodied. Not a fan.
Tasting room tap. Aromas of chocolate, caramel, coffee, licorice. Looks more porter than brown ale. Tastes of chocolate, caramel, coffee, roast. Balance palate. Medium finish.

Bootlegger Brown Ale has a rather thin, cream-colored head, a semi-clear, red-brown appearance, and a bit of lacing left behind. The aroma is of brown bread crust, some chocolate, and even a hint of coffee. Taste is of sweet bread crust, chocolate, bitter coffee, and a char. Mouthfeel is light, and Bootlegger Brown Ale finishes semi-dry and easy drinking (as described on the brewery website). RJT

Bottle @ Yespr. Pours near clear brown with a off-white big frothy head. Aroma is very mild with berries, nut, sweet dark fruit, candy. Taste is moderate sweet and light bitter. Body is light, texture is oily. carbonation is lively. Finishes dry with lingering herbal bitterness.
Bottle at Yesprâ€™s - Thanks. Clear brown - offwhite head. Toasted, light licorice, fruity, chocolate, nutty, light cocoa, light bitterness, a bit plain.

En tant qu'habitant de l'Oise, c'est un grand classique. Et toujours aussi agrÃ©able ! Une belle robe orangÃ©e, une carbonation maÃ®trisÃ©e, une amertume parfaitement Ã©quilibrÃ©e, des saveurs fruitÃ©es et d'agrumes. Un rÃ©gal !
Bottle at home, as Bernache, hazy golden beer, small/medium head. Aroma is fruit, citrus, lemon. Taste is the same, bitter, some sweetness, very nice.

DorÃ©e orangÃ©e trouble, nez fruitÃ©, attaque sur le fruit, agrumes, oranges, bonne amertume. TrÃ¨s agrÃ©able. Bouteille 33cl, sous le nom Bernache (lorsquâ€™une fiche pour celle-ci sera crÃ©Ã©e, je changerai cette note de place), bue au parc du Marquenterre, France, le 17/08/2016.

75 cl bottle from a French supermarket. The ABV on mine says 6%, I assume it is the same beer. Pours slightly hazy blond with a thin white head. Pleasant aroma of peppery hop, lemony and slightly herbal (lovage?). Sweet to start, with a gentle bitterness. Grain base evident, some sweet fruit and more herbal bitterness. Dry finish. Well carbonated, well-balanced, refreshing and drinkable.
Bouteille 33 cl - couleur or, belle mousse blanche, arÃ´me fruitÃ©, sur la cÃ©rÃ©ale, goÃ»t sur le malt, fruitÃ© avec un final fruitÃ©, agrÃ©able
Clear golden colour, white head. Fruity aroma, yeast, dried meadow flowers, apricot. Light bitter, fruity flavour, hops, malts. Fruity finish. Nice one! (from 75cL bottle @ Miloâ€™s place)

Bottle from Terre de Boissons Calais and drunk at home. Clear gold thin white head. Some hop and orange flavour on the aroma. Itâ€™s a bit like a spicy Belgian blond ale but lacks the esters on the aroma. Strong blond biere de garde with plenty of orange fruit and decent hop. Pretty good I thought. A bit of floral orange.

bottle, Hyperboissons Dijon-ChÃªnove. Hazy golden colour, white head. Incredibly lovely hop aroma. So promising. Full-bodied, delicious malty base supporting the arimatoc hops so well. The flavour is as god as the promising aroma. Bitter-sweet, malty, intensely hoppy. Delicious, delicious, delicious. I want more of it! Much more!
Bottled@HBF. Fruity, slightly woody, berryish, pear in the aroma. Medium-bodied. Belgian yeast, pear, sweetish fruityness. Some alcohol bite. Nice.
Paille trouble petit col. Aromes pain epices. Corps rond lÃ©gÃ¨re amertume en final. Saveur douce. Excellente biere de garde.
Biere de soif, au nez lÃ©gÃ¨rement floral et citronnÃ©, qui mÃ©riterait plus de corps et une gazÃ©ification moins agressive au palais.

On tap at Express de Lyon Paris. Hazy pale gold colour lasting white head. Lemon aroma. Spicy orange in the mouth. Not too soapy. Some bitterness. Pretty competent wit bier with good spicy orange finish. Good.
Robe or pÃ¢le, mousse peu persistante. Nez sur les cÃ©rÃ©ales et les agrumes, peu complexe. Bouche acidulÃ©e et amÃ¨re, simple et courte. Blanche basique.
Bottle. Straw beer with a cream head. Floral aroma. Floral and yeast flavor with light fruitiness. Medium bodied. Floral and yeast notes linger.
Bottle, name was Spatule Blanche, hazy yellow beer, small head. Aroma is wheat, lemon, spice, tart. Taste is the same, not bad, drinkable beer.
Bottle - citrus, spices aroma. Pale yellow, very small white head - medium carbonation. Ting on tongue and in mouth. Bit watery tasting - not great depth. Nothing special, bit too gassy overall.

Jaune claire voilÃ©e, nez fruitÃ©, attaque sur le fruit, agrumes, oranges, lÃ©gÃ¨rement acidulÃ©e, bonne amertume. TrÃ¨s agrÃ©able, bien Ã©quilibrÃ©e et goÃ»teuse. Bouteille 33cl, sous le nom Spatule blanche (lorsquâ€™une fiche pour celle-ci sera crÃ©Ã©e, je changerai cette note de place), achetÃ©e au parc du Marquenterre, France, bue le 20/08/2016.
Clear light yellow liquid, hardly any head. Aroma of hops. Light body, strong carbonation. Taste is bitter, fruity.

Bottled (backlog). Hazy yellow colour, small white head. Aroma is citrus, spices, yeast, some herbs and mild wheaty notes. Flavour is citrus, herbs, malts and some mild fruity notes. A bit watery, but otherwise ok.
Cloudy pale golden color with a white head. Aroma has notes of grassy hops and light yeast. Light citrus and yeast on palate with a creamy mouthfeel.
Bottle, old review, trip to Bavaria ages ago. I gave this a good score back then, warming sweet wheaty malt and a correct balance to keep drinkability.

Dunkler Weizenbock mit 7,2 % Alkohol und 16,5 % StammwÃ¼rze. Angelehnt an die Geschichte vom bayerischen Engel Aloysios, durchaus ein Bier bei dem man Frohlocken und Hosianna singen kann. Viel Hefe, viel schÃ¶n cremiger, fester Schaum. In Nuancen erinnert es an die Turm WeiÃŸe von Kuchlbauer, allerdings im Vergleich weit weniger fruchtig und sehr deutlich malziger. Recht sÃ¼ÃŸ, aber wohlschmeckend, da auch deutliche sÃ¤uerliche und bittere Noten vorhanden sind. Der hohe Alkoholgehalt ist immer zu schmecken, ist aber nie unangenehm. Sehr gut. Zusammen mit der Turmweisse, die Referenzbiere von Kuchelbauer. ErwÃ¤hnentswert: Viel, wirklich extrem feinperlige KohlensÃ¤ure. Trotzdem nicht zu scharf. Allerdings sehr viel Volumen und man ist sehr schnell pappsatt. Die KohlensÃ¤ure ist so feinperlig, dass sie sich zu keinem Zeitpunkt (auch nicht im Magen) vom Bier trennt. Kein mir bekanntes Bier ist dermaÃŸen sÃ¤ttigend. Das ideale Bockbier zur Fastenzeit. Mit dem Aloysius im Glas kann man mal ne Mahlzeit auslassen. Wer allerdings vorhat sich mal so richtig schÃ¶n anzusaufen, den stellt dieses Bier vor eine nahezu unlÃ¶sbare Aufgabe.
500ml bottle from RusBeerShop in Moscow. Pours hazy dark brown with a tall beige head. Aroma is caramel, bananas, a little earthy. Taste is medium sweet, bananas, wheat, toasted malt.

Bottle picked up from the brewery on Saturday and consumed at home Attenkirchen, Tuesday 13th August 2019, cooking a Spag' Bol' listening to Marc Riley 6Music. Pours dark brown with an off white head. The aroma has wheat and a little caramel, soft carbonation, a little chewy soft overipe banana, a nice warm boozy hit. Very nice.

Hier hat man wirklich ein tolles Produkt vor sich. Nicht nur, dass das Bier mit einer weiten Palette mit Aromen von hefig Ã¼ber frÃ¼chtig bis sÃ¤uerlich-malzig kommt, sondern, dass diese wunderbar miteinander verknÃ¼pft sind und ein weicher Ãœbergang zwischen den fruchtigen und herben Phasen Ã¼berzeugt. Ein wirklich schÃ¶nes, ausgewogenes Bier.
Bottle from kappldav. Many thanks! Brown colour, creamy beige foam. Lots of banana, some citrus. Light sweet, bit bready. Well balanced, nice!

Bottle from Bierwinkel Hop, Amersfoort. Aroma is spicy yeast with banana, wheat, caramel, clove, dark bread. Flavour is medium sweet with low bitterness. Body is medium. Pretty solid Weizenbock, wholesome.

In ordentlich, satt dunkelbrauner, trÃ¼ber Farbe zeigt sich das Bier im WeiÃŸbierglas, falls man die betonierte Hefe gut aus der Flasche herausgeschÃ¼ttelt hat. Die grobporige Schaumkrone baut sich dann doch recht bald ab. Der Antrunk ist recht alkoholisch, wÃ¼rzig, malzig-sÃ¼sslich und hefig. Der Mittelteil ist ausgeprÃ¤gt wÃ¼rzig mit angenehmen dunkel malzigen Aromen. Der Abgang dann leicht hopfig herb werdend, mit malzigen und hefigen Charakter. Bei diesem WeiÃŸbierbock kommt alles zusammen, SÃ¼ÃŸe, SÃ¼ffigkeit, Geschmack, dunkle Aromen, Alkoholgehalt etc. Toll! Einzigstes Manko: Die Schaumkrone. Sie ist zwar schnell weg, das Bier ist aber glÃ¼cklicherweise noch eine ganze Weile erfrischend. Empfehlenswert!
Brown beer. The aroma is caramel, banana, chocolate. Birra colore marrone. L'aroma Ã¨ caramello, banana, cioccolato

500 ml bottle. Cloudy chocolate brown, creamy head. A lot of earthy notes, chocolate, yeast, dough, caramel. Light malty sweetness, some drynessFull bodied, oily texture, lively carbonated, light dry boozy finish. Decent.

column1: Issaquah Cougar Mountain Dark Brown Ale
column5: Tap at brewhouse: Very seldom does rogue make anything bad; I''m hoping this was just a bad keg. Started off with a light malt nose. Flavor is malty but has a cigar butt type finish

04-02-2019; bottle; at home (bought somewhere in Sweden). The beer has a nice ruby red colour, with an amber touch. It has a lovely bright glow. The beer is crystal clear. On top, some greyish foam is formed. Foam retention is a bit low. The bulk collapses quickly, to leave only a thin drape. The aroma of the beer is alright. It is not too special to be honest, but it is nice. There are some nice aromas of malts, that give some caramel and raisin. There is some bubblegum here to somehow. Hops are herbal, but not to aromatic. There is also a fruity note, some berry I think. The taste of the beer is fine. The beer is quite sweet, but has a lovely strong hop bitterness to balance it. The result is a very well balanced beer. Nice. The palate of the beer is fine. The body is medium and the texture a tiny bit rough. Carbonation is average. The finish of the beer has some spicy hop notes, a touch of alcohol and some nice malty notes. In the end, a nice lingering dry bitterness is present. Not a bad beer at all; it is a nice one. Just not mega special.
Brown. Aroma is very sweet melasses and dark honey banana. Taste is very sweet with some toffee banana. A bit strange sourness. Ok.
Bottle, light straw with a decent head. Light sweetness over grains with moderate background bitterness. Not exciting but decent for a drinking session.
Bottle. Clear brown color with white head. Aroma is chocolate, fudge, light raisins. Taste is a bit oxidized, chocolate, fudge. Silky mouthfeel with fine-bubbled carbonation. Just alright.
Flaska pÃ¥ jobbets julbord. MÃ¶rkbrun i fÃ¤rgen med beige krona. SÃ¶tt, maltigt och fylligt med mycket russin och torkad frukt. Funkar helt ok.
Bottle. Clear deep amber color with a medium sized foamy off-white head. Watery aroma with notes of malt. Mild taste, some chocolate in finish. Medium thin body. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone
backlog, can, caramel nose, light coffee, licorice, and caramel malts, taste is lacking body, light caramel, spices, ok
Pours clear brown with medium high tanned head. Aromes malty and syrupy, some roasted maltyness. Taste has sweet lsightly burned malty notes. Some caramel and sweet bread.

33 cl bottle from Systembolaget. Lovely aroma. Coffee, leather, liquorice. Rich and creamy. The arrival is fresh, but the overall flavour is a bit lacking unfortunately. Pretty good finish with a "thickness" that lingers for quite a while. Although mass-produced, it's definitely not bad by any means, especially considering the price.
0,3 litre Bottle from systembolaget Charlottenberg, at home. Black with medium offwhite head. OK christmasbeer.

On tap at the brewery: Opaque brown/orange color with a tan head. The aroma was sweet...malt...cascade hops...grapefruit...sugar. The flavor was very sweet with a noticable alcohol kick. The finish was pure cascade hops bitterness. Slightly thin feel for this big of a brew.

The appearance is very dark opaque brown with an ultra creamy tan head. The aroma and flavor were all about roastiness...coffee, burnt chocolate, roasted nuts. This beer is nitro-ed, so it was very thin, watery feeling and had an overall flatness to it.

column1: Sierra Blanca Roswell Alien Amber Ale
column5: Had this on tap in the city of Roswell .. had to do that. Poured an amber color with a thin sized head. Toasted caramel and grains ... on the sweeter side and plain.

column1: Sierra Blanca Roswell Alien Amber Ale
column5: Sierra Blanca was an unknown brewer to me until dinner the other evening in Santa Fe. Today I try their amber ale in a 12 oz bottle. Chilled well and pouring into a shaker glass, it appears a dark amber in color sporting a thin, light tan head. The nose is caramel, cereal and a bit medicinal. And the taste, malt, some hops, grain and a small sweetness. Not bad. Just uninspiring. It might benefit with a slice of lime.

column1: Sierra Blanca Roswell Alien Amber Ale
column5: 12 ounce bottle from wchesser. Thanks! The beer is a clear amber with a beige head of foam. The aroma has rich caramel and toffee with a strongly earthy sweetness coming through in the taste. Lots of grainy and nutty notes in the taste. Fairly refreshing overall. Medium body and medium carbonation. I liked it.

column1: Sierra Blanca Roswell Alien Amber Ale
column5: 12 ounce bottle from hayduke that we had together via facebook chat. Clearish brownish. Just a little off white foam. Feel is kind of flat. This is malty with a little floral. Neither complex nor exciting. Well, its am amber.

column1: Sierra Blanca Roswell Alien Amber Ale
column5: Clean copper color with a thin head of offwhite colored foam. Light sweet caramel malt with a timid roastiness and soft florals. A bit softcore in its delivery, but I like the marketability and it is an enjoyable sesh beer.

column1: Sierra Blanca Roswell Alien Amber Ale
column5: Pours amber from the bottle. Aroma is caramel, light toast, but in fairness the smell was overwhelmed by the chlorine from the hot tub. Taste is mildly sweet up front with a mild bitterness at the finish. Body is medium. Overall rather dull.

column1: Sierra Blanca Roswell Alien Amber Ale
column5: Nothing to exciting to the taste buds, rather simple amber ale. Extremely cool label. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Sierra Blanca Roswell Alien Amber Ale
column5: Bottle @ Home. Darker amber colored beer with a small khaki head. Smells like chlorine, cardboard, and caramel. Maybe some toast? Flavor is just crappy caramel sauce, cardboard, and prune juice. Super sugary, sweet, and oxidized. Flat, slick mouthfeel isnâ€™t helping anything. Garbage juice.

column1: Sierra Blanca Roswell Alien Amber Ale
column5: Thanks to Joe for the bottle. Musty aroma. Medium body malt sweetness with just a touch of hop bitterness.

column1: Sierra Blanca Roswell Alien Amber Ale
column5: Taste: caramel malt, clean, complex, yeast bread notes. Deep amber color, mild floral hop aroma. Medium body
En klassisk bock. Lys i malten og en en skarp alkoholsmag. Hat ogsÃ¥ den klassiske sÃ¸dme.
Bottle, 50 cl, bought at GetrÃ¤nkeland,Binz. Malt dominates, smooth, yet warming. Small, subtle, accents of honey or caramel. Overall pleasant!

Flasche 0,5l: Bernstein, glasklar, krÃ¤ftiger stabiler feinporiger Schaum; wÃ¼rzige Nase, krÃ¤ftige SÃ¼ÃŸe, Malz, Malzzucker, Karamell, getrocknete FrÃ¼chte, dezente Hopfennoten, angenehme fruchtig-wÃ¼rzige Bitterkeit; frischer + wÃ¼rziger KÃ¶rper, krÃ¤ftige SÃ¼ÃŸe, leichte RÃ¶staromen, Malz, Malzzucker, Karamell, cremig, deutliche KohlensÃ¤ure, dezente Hopfenaromen; angenehmer malzig-wÃ¼rziger Nachgang

â€œRostocker Bock hellâ€œ, Flasche (50 cl) von Edeka, Kyritz. - Kupferrotgold, klar. - In der Nase bocktypisches breites Malz, Karamel, KirschkonfitÃ¼re, Fusel. - Antrunk karamellig-malzwÃ¼rzig mit milder Hintergrundherbe. Recht sÃ¼ÃŸ, aber dank Malzbittere ausgewogen. Vollmundig, breit. Im Abgang matte, etwas derbe Hopfenherbe. - Simpler aber sÃ¼ffiger Bock, fÃ¼r ein Industrieerzeugnis durchaus trinkbar.

Aroma; caramel, malt, fermented apple peel. Look; deep golden clear, thin pearl mat. Taste; caramel, strong malt, brown sweet bread, apple structures, spices n herbs. Finish; malted. Feel; premium. Overall; quite straight bock. [50cl Fl im DDR Supermarkt gekauft]

Clear deep amber-copper color with eggshell head. Aroma is toffee, a hint of chocolate, some fruits, but not the dark ones, rather maybe peach? Taste is overly sweet, malty, nutty, with ethanol noticeable, some honey as well, but itâ€™s a bit unpleasant. The aroma is fine, the taste is not for me. But itâ€™s chewy enough.
18-05-2016-GetrÃ¤nkeland Boltenhagen . Bernsteinfarben, klar, beige Krone. Aroma: M Malzig, Geschmack malzig, hopfig, restsÃ¼ÃŸ. SÃ¼ffig.

-malt,malt and more malt thats literally the only thing this has,its like somebody looked at a description of what a Bock is and started to brew one -sweet malt flavor is so overwhelming that i couldnt make out anything else but malt and alcohol -Finish is very light and water-y Pretty bad
Flaske 0,5 liter, smagt sommeren 2015, ser flot ud i glasset og har en ok aroma, er lidt underlig i smagen.
Itâ€™s a typical bock. Malty, with delicate bitterness. Dark golden color with small head. Rather a bit dull.

Pour from a 12oz bottle, six pack bough 6/17/23013 at King Richardâ€™s in Michigan City. Deep reddish brown brew with small pale head - rich color worthy of a brown ale. Aroma of caramel malt and light grass. Taste is sweet caramel malt with a little toffee, a hint of grass dries up the sweet taste at the end of the swallow. Very tasty.

Amber with nice head and lacing. Balanced between burnt maple caramel and a clean bitter finish. Not a lot going on, but it is refreshing. On tap at Back Road, an interesting place to sip away an afternoon.

Red-amber with good, foamy, tan head / Nose of sour malt and honey / Medium body, fat, sweet and sour, malty with low hopping, and fair finish / Flavors of sour malt and caramel / Overly sweet and malty with insufficient hopping.

12oz bottle, no date. 7.2% for a mÃ¤rzen? Dang. Clear orange brown with a short-lived 1/2 finger beige head that faded to a ring. Nuts, toast, and caramel are the dominant aromas while some hard water mineral notes were in the background. Flavor adds a slightly overbaked sugar cookie and more bitterness than Iâ€™d have guessed from the aroma--peaked at a 3 in the dry earthy finish. Light carbonation with a medium body. Not too bad, but nowhere near my favorite for the style.

bottle - Pours dark amber. The aroma is mostly of caramel malts. The flavor has more of the same with a bit of mild hops for balance. Light to medium bodied, it finishes smooth with a hint of bitterness. This one is alright for a session beer. I see the abv is a little higher than I would have guessed. Itâ€™s not noticeable.

This pours a dark orange body with a moderate fizzy white head. Little lacing. The aroma is that of toast, slightly burnt, with a bit of caramel. The flavor continues with the burnt toast and caramel and the additional of an earthy, nutty bitterness that builds somewhat in the finish. Okay. Kahnâ€™s Fine Wines & Spirits, Indianapolis, IN

Draft sample at Back Road Fest. Poured clear dark amber with an average white fizzy head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate toasted malt and tart citrus aroma. Medium body witha syrupy texture. Medium sweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration.
Bottle. Sweet maple syrup and raspberry malt aroma. Red amber color with slight head. Maple syrup and malt flavor with a moderate hops finish. An unusual beer for the style - hoppier than most.

Poured a clean dark amber boardering on brown with a beige head. Aroma was subtle caramel and spice. The flavor was over the top caramel/buttery. Very full body. Not really lager like. I guess it will do in a pinch, but Back Road makes much better beers than this.

Ah, nothing beats a nice beer after a hard day of mountainbiking. But I guess this will have to do. Actually, I havenâ€™t had a Back Road in some time and found this to be quite pleasant. Had a nice lemon and orange peel taste -- bitter but with some sweetness, perhaps caramel. Amber hued.
Bottle at home. So utterly characterless that I canâ€™t even start to describe it. Not particularly bad, but itâ€™s like drinking slighty flavoured water.
Drank this in Paris. Yellow looking beer with not much in the smell department. Sweet yummy taste.
On tap at the Pont de Seine in Paris. Gold color with a thick, tiny bubble head. Very little aroma, if any at all. Not much flavor other than a mild sweetness and a slight cloudy taste.
Golden colour with a small white head. Light sweet hoppy hay aroma and a sweet barnyard taste. Medium body and a sweet finish.
A hazy orange beer with a white head. The aroma is sweet hoppy combined with notes of straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of straw and a dry hoppy end. Plain boring.
Golden colored with a thin head. Weak unripe fruit aroma plus some brewing mashy notes. Pilsner flavor. Thin, sharp and unbalanced. Not good!!!
Pale golden colour with a white head. Malty aroma with hints of apple. Sweet and thin flavor.
Blond color. Missing aroma. Poor, brewed with poor cereals; quite high bittterness.
Golden color with a white head. The taste is sweet thin and boring. French standard ugly lager.
From A Bottle.Light malt and hops,very thin tasting,run of the mill watery lager.

Sehr hell-trÃ¼be Farbe im Glas, schÃ¶ner, cremiger Schaum. Der Geruch ist schÃ¶n bananig. Im Antrunk ist das Bier schÃ¶n bananig-fruchtig, allerdings gleichzeitig ein Bisschen muffig. Im Hauptteil wird das Bier schÃ¶n mild-vollmundig. Allerdings im Nachgeschmack tritt die muffige Note etwas mehr zu Tage und die schÃ¶ne fruchtige Note verschwindet etwas im Hintergrund. Der Nachgeschmack ist muffig-herb, leicht hefig-sÃ¼ÃŸlich, aber irgendwie komisch. --> komisches, muffig-sÃ¼ÃŸliches Weizen! (Test vom 28.2.2009) --> 12,9,12,8,12,8 - 9,35

Bottle. Very sweet aroma - honey, banana, clove. Yellow-brown color with moderate head. Sweet-sour banana, honey, clove, and wheat malt flavor - less sweet than aroma would lead you to think. Nice standard Weizen.
Bottle, 5.3%. Mildly farty yeast aroma. Cloudy yellow colour. Small stable white head. The flavour has a little clove and caramel. Hint of rough bitterness, tastes a little old.

Bottle 50cl. Unclear medium yellow color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, moderate yeasty, fruity, banana. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is creamy, carbonation is soft. [20090625]

Bottle:Pale golden, cloudy, big and stable white head; yeasty-fruity (lemons, bananas) nose; moderate sweetish-sourish flavour, accompanied by a light bitterness, quite soft MF; sweetish-lemony finish with a wheaty and chalky touch. Uncomplicated, pleasant Weizen.......
I had this one from the tap deep in the forests of ThÃ¼ringen. Yellow hazy color with white lasting head. Fresh aroma and a very (maybe to much) fruity aroma.

(Bottle 50 cl) Almost copper color and a tight, white head on top of the hazy beer. To put it another way: By appearance a completely classic "Hefeweizen". Obvious citric sourness, even more than what is commonly found. But a nice summer refresher. 290603
full vanilla aroma. sour, buttermilk in the taste. quite dry and reasonable
Bottle. Light vanilla and clove aromas. Cloudy yellow, big white lacing head. Medium body, chewy. Vanilla and banana base, a bit candyish. Quick finish. OK
Hellgelbes Pils mit ordentlicher Blume. Grasig-florales Hopfenaroma. Schlanker, blumiger MalzkÃ¶rper. Der Hopfen ist eher wÃ¼rzig als aromatisch mit leichter Bitternote. GefÃ¤llt mir gut.

Sehr schÃ¶ne gold-gelbe Farbe. Der Geruch ist hopfig-frisch und ganz leicht brotig. Im Antrunk ist das Bier nicht wirklich â€žfrischâ€œ. Es macht einen leicht muffigen und brotigen Eindruck. Zum Hauptteil wird diese brotig-muffige, mit ganz leichter Hopfenblumigkeit unterlegte Note, etwas deutlicher. Auf der Zunge bleibt ein wÃ¼rzig-muffiger Ton zurÃ¼ck, den ich eher bei einem Export, als bei einem Pils erwartet hÃ¤tte. --> Schmeckt weder â€žfrischâ€œ noch ist es eindeutig als â€žPilsâ€œ zu erkennen. MittelmÃ¤ÃŸig! (Test vom 7.2.2009) --> 12,8,11,7,12,8 - 8,90

50 cl bottle as â€Meininger Pilsâ€. Rated on 01.06.2010 Bright, yellow colour, disappearing head. Aroma has grassy hops with herbs, some malt and butter. Flavour has stinging herbs, grassy hops and some malt. I find the hop profile here unpleasant.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are sweet malt, herbs, grass and hops.
Bottle. Creamy white good mostlÃ½ lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate bitter nice malty flavor. Average light bitter finish. Oily palate.
Bottled. A golden beer with an off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt and just a touch of hops. The flavor is sweet and very malty with just a touch of hops.

Bottle, bought @ Ambrosetti, Berlin. Pours clear, pale golden with a slight green hue. Fine, medium, frothy, white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, some grass, a little pine. Lowish carbonation, fine mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet, somewhat metallic, bready and cornish malts. A bit of grassy hops with a slight pine or juniper edge to it.

Bottle 50cl. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, grain, toasted, paper. Flavor is light to moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090321]
Bottle, 5.0%. Clear golden colour. Small white head. The flavour is slightly citric. Hint of grain. Medium bitterness, OK clean. Clean and refreshing.

bottle from pivnizub - Danke! Clear pale yellow, large white head. Hoppy nose. Malty background with shy aromatic and intenive bitter hops, grainy flavours are also present. A clean and crisp Pilsener.
Cask @ GBBF 2013. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate aroma. Roasted malty chocolate and caramel flavor. Has a roasted malty chocolate and caramel finish.
cask @ gbbf 13. Black colour, Roasted aroma, rather light bodied, a bit disappointing

Cask at GBBF 2013. Somewhat hazy dark brown beer with a beige bubbly head. Malty toffee aroma, caramel, hay notes, licorice, milk chocolate, some prunes and vanilla. Toffee flavor, vanilla, caramel, soot, prunes, some hoppy bitterness. Pleasant but a bit on the sweet side.
4.5% black with a good head, roast malt aroma, slightly bitter burnt toffee / caramel taste.

Cask gravity, Derby Winter BF, 17/02/12. Half price half. Deep mahogany with a tan halo. Aroma of dead leaves and train smoke. Decent with more burnt vegetation, coal, an undercurrant of blackberry fruitiness. Touch of burnt almond. Cigar linger. Actually not bad.

Cask-conditioned at the Three Kings, Hanley Castle, Worcestershire 27/05/2011. Jet black witha slight tan head. Sweetish aroma of dark fruits and liquorice. Easy drinking, with some blackcurrant, chocolate and more liquorice before a dryish finish. Very good.

[Cask at the Belle Vue, High Wycombe] Black with a small white head. Roasted malt with lots of coffee, liquorice and earthiness comethrough. Great balance, a good mouthfeel, a top notch easy drinking stout that was unusually sessionable for the style.

(Cask at Wenlock Arms, London, 22 May 2010) Black colour with brief, beige head. Malty, roasted nose with notes of coffee, caramel and dark chocolate. Malty, roasted taste with chocolate, coffee, dark bread and a generous coffee bitterness in the finish. Medium body, mainly dry. Well balanced and tasty stout.
Cask,Dark Ale Days 2010 - Edwardstone White Horse.Black with no head,aroma of roasted and dark choc,taste of dark choc,roasted,coffee and malt,liquorice,silky,dry finish.

Bottle from Poachers Off-Licence, Lincoln, tasted in May 2008. Appealing dark colour. Decent condition. Heavily roasted malt aroma. Distinctly dry, with a fair amount of burnt dark bitterness. Just a hint of coffee. Quite astringent aftertaste. Just a little short of presence but very drinkable.
Cask @ GBBF 2015. Pours a dark amber brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel finish.
Cask@GBBF 2015, Olympia, London - pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma and taste is sweet roasted malty, with cocoa, caramel, dark fruits, dark malty finish.

At GBBF. Poachers Trembling Rabbit 3.40% on tap at GBBF it pours a dark reddish brown with a pleasing mild coffee cake aroma. Medium bodied with a bitter tobacco leaf character to it with mild caramel. Ok
From cask. Pours dark brown to black. Dark roasted malty. Breadish, roasted. Bitter and toasted dark malty. Breadish amd roasted finish.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 2012, Great British Beer Festival, London Olympia, Hammersmith Road, London, England W14 8UX. Clear dark brown colour with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, chocolate, light burnt. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, chocolate malt, roasted. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20120808]
8th August 2012 GBBF. Hazy dark brown beer. No real head. Fresh light palate, low carbonation. Fresh mild dark malts, a little tangy. Very mild dark fruits. Dry finish. Malty aftertaste.

Cask@GBBF2012. Amber colour, small white head. Aroma is fruity, wooden, syrupy with some mild floral notes. Flavour is caramel, some herbal notes, earth, fruits, honey and mild syrupy and toffeeish notes.
Cask,Dark Ale Days 2010 - Edwardstone White Horse.Almost black with a small head,aroma of sulphur and wood,taste of choc,farmyard,country air,damp,lovely.
Cask Handpump at the Community Centre, Frodsham 24/05/2003 Dark coloured slighty fruity with an acidic taste. Some bitterness in an earthy finish.
Cask conditioned - Gravity - Derby BF. A muddy brown mild with a sourish aroma. The taste is fruity and pleasant with a hint of blackberries.
Light brown. Great carmel malt nose.Light carmel malt flavor with mild alcohol heat
Like the Koltzh, this beer is quite drinkable... has a very powerful bitter aftertaste, but seems to have a better balance of hops. Not too bad!

column1: Sly Fox Burns Scottish Export Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Tap at Sly Fox. Balanced. Toffee caramel tones. Mild hop balance. Medium bodied. True-ish to style. Kind of simple, a touch of earthy caramel notes.

column1: Sly Fox Burns Scottish Export Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Pours a clear brownish red color with a two finger off white head. Aroma of roasted malts, a faint hint of smoke, and earthiness. Smoke is more prevalent in the taste with sweet roasted malts, pine, grass, and some very light hints of chocolate. Smooth medium body with light prickly carbonation.

column1: Sly Fox Burns Scottish Export Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Pours a mostly clear caramel color with a medium creamy off white head...great lacing and retention. Aroma has nuttiness and notes of mild caramel and a faint bit of chocolate. Flavor follows suit and adds some dry leaves and very mild fruitiness. Mouthfeel is medium and very silky with a dry finish of dry leaves/nuttiness.

column1: Sly Fox Burns Scottish Export Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at the brew pub. Pours hazy copper with no head. The aroma Is all caramel malt. The taste is medium bitter and sweet on the finish.

column1: Sly Fox Burns Scottish Export Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft...not much carbonation...its mahogany with some added red highlights....smoky malt aroma...mild carbonation with a medium to watery body...mild smoky malts throughout....would be better with more smoke throughout or something...mild bitter finish...flavors in general are abrupt

column1: Sly Fox Burns Scottish Export Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: From the tap poured dark amber color with a fair amount of head. Bitter hoppy flavor with a quick finish.

column1: Sly Fox Burns Scottish Export Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Clear ruby color with no head. Aroma of roasted malts and butterscotch. Nice flavor of butterscotch, roasted malts, and some caramel. Seemed unfinished.

column1: Sly Fox Burns Scottish Export Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Cask @ Blind Tiger. Dark amber pour. Flavor is quite subtle, was wishing for a deeper flavored brew.

column1: Sly Fox Burns Scottish Export Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Cask pours an amber body with a bubbly head. Malty with a hint of smoke, butterscotch and toffee. Dry and thin. Decent.

column1: Sly Fox Burns Scottish Export Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: yum yum yum give me some amazing aromas of chocolate molasses and sweet malt lots of head and lacing nicely balanced no complaints here

column2: Old Orchard Beach, Maine, United States
column5: Deep Golden Color with little head. Slightly sweet yeasty aroma with hoppy undertones. Yeasty hoppy flavor, Not very good at all. Fairly smooth and medium bodied.

column2: Old Orchard Beach, Maine, United States
column5: Deep amber gold color with little head. Sweet nutmeg aroma with a hint of citrus. Sweet pumpkin and nutmeg flavor with a hoppy background. Medium bodied and somewhat soda-like.

Ich gebe zu, ich mag Schankbiere. Und dieses hier finde ich recht lecker. Das Bier zeigt sich messingfarben, klar und mit wenig Schaum. Brotige Aromen dominieren den Geruch. Der Antrunk ist erfrischend, leichtfÃ¼ÃŸig und rund. Auch hier Malzaroma. Erst im Abgang kommt eine leichte Bittere die auch etwas nachklingt. Ein gutes Bier fÃ¼r zwischendurch!
Fra Stora Coop Kiruna. Drukket pÃ¥ rom 115 Hotel Bishops Arms. Lys gylden. Filmskum. Maltaroma. Smaken malt & gress. Litt sÃ¸t.
Burk 500 ml frÃ¥n Willys. En helt ok "lillebror" till Falcon 5.2 %. Fungerar att dricka om man vill ha nÃ¥gra Ã¶l till maten och Systembolaget Ã¤r stÃ¤ngt.

Den hÃ¤r Ã¶len Ã¤r vÃ¤ldigt blaskig. Smakar nÃ¤stan bara vatten. Det Ã¤r tur att jag har blivit 20 sÃ¥ slipper jag dricka blaskig Ã¶l. SjÃ¤lv sÃ¥ mÃ¥ste jag dricka 8 sÃ¥na hÃ¤r om jag ska bli full. Vilket leder till att man mÃ¥ste pissa hela tiden.

Canned, 50 cl. Clear deeper golden colour, medium sized creamy white head, which leaves some lace. Sweet, malty nose and aroma with bread and honey underpainted by some dough, mouthfeel is slick. Short, malty, minimal hoppy finish.
@Calmar, Sweden. Yeah, listening to old Pantera and Metallica, what more can you ask for?
Bottled from supermarket in haparanda, sweden. Poured golden coloured with an small white foamy head. Hoppy aroma. Hoppy flavour with weak sweet malty flavuor. Watery.

Third time's a charm for Falcon, this is by far the best of its 3.5 series, even though the other two were nominally Viennas (a style I generally quite like), this PL has more balanced malt/hop character and is not either soapy or watery. Recommended at this category/price point (16.9 oz can, Stockholm)
Can from Ica Maxi. Pours amber with a white head. Malty balanced brew, clean.
Can. Pours clear pale yellow with large white head. Aroma is malt and grain. Taste is sweet. Body is light oily with medium carbonation. Finish is medium long with notes that follow the nose.
*Can from HemkÃ¶p in Stockholm. Smooth grainy beginning. Hints of sweetness, hints of hops. Not too round, refreshing but a bit sweetish-unround.
Beer with light color, light body, average carbonized, (bought a 50cl can in Stockholm supermarket).
500 ml can. Pale clear golden with white head. Smell is grain and carbonated water. Taste is carbonated water with hints of grain and beer. Dry with low bitterness and high carbonation.
50cl can. Pours clear golden with a small wihte head that stays. Malty aroma and taste, with some acidic and hoppy hints. Watery texture with slight carbonation. Not bad, but nothing special.
Clear darker yellow with small white foam head. Aroma is mainly barley. Taste is bit watery. Not bad for what it is, a low alcohol beer. (FarstanÃ¤s 201307) ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A thin but good scent. The taste is really good to have such a low alcohol percentage. The aftertaste is also a moment. I enjoy a little bit of this beer. It will not find every day in this kind of beer.
500 ml can. Aroma malty with a hint of citrus, not much else. Taste of pale malts. Boring.
Not much to say. Just a quite incipit lager and some foam too much major brewery features too.
Typical standard beer that is somewhat watery and characterless. Light on hops and as weak of malt.
Herber, flach getreidiger Beginn. Laff, nur eine minimale WÃ¼rzigkeit ist gegeben, dafÃ¼r immerhin angenehm bitter. Belangloser, minimal getreidiger Abgang. 8/6/8/5/6/6
14. 10. 2017, Pivo & burger fest, Ljubljana. On tap. Not much of aroma, taste is OK but nothing special. I expected some more out of this one.

Draft @ Pivo & Burger Fest Octâ€™16, Ljubljana. CuivrÃ©e, col crÃ©meux blanc-cassÃ©. ArÃ´me maltÃ©, cara pale, touche de baies noires et une petite impression de beurre / dyacetyl. Palais est maltÃ©, pils, caramel finement amer, note de toffee avec encore cette impression de baies noires - mÃ»res. Petite faute en fermentation qui semble Ãªtre trop haute et laisse ce fini de bouche de beurre.

Bottled, thanks MarkoNm! Hazy nut brown, small head. Buttery nose with some toast, red berries and hay. Sweet with light body and well rounded mouthfeel. Some caramel and chocolate, quite heavy on diacetyl. Low bitterness.

Draught at 3. Festival Mikropivovarjev, Koper. Cloudy dark brown color with small creamy tan-like head and average sparkling appearance. Aroma of caramel, roasted malt and grass. Taste starts with sweet caramel and roasted malt, follows nutty and grassy with mild spicy mouthfeel and mild bitter finish. Light to medium body, sticky texture and average carbonation in palate. Not much fuss about it...

on tap at Sokol, Ljubljana. black color, small tan head. smells light sour, spices, some roast aroma. light body, light carbonation, light mouhtfeel. tastes malty roasty, xmas spices, light sour, vegetably taste, some sweetness. spicy / roasty finish. decent.
Dark brown colour with off-white head. Aroma of roasted barley, the same flavour, mild body, low carbonation and bitterness, empty, watery finish. Too low abv.

Pours a dark brown color, topped with a medium sized off-white head. Mild roasty aroma with some notes of caramel and coffee. Grassy notes sitting in the back. A perfect dark lager nose. Sweet start with some roastiness with that needed soury feel, very gentle. Mild bitterness. A bit watery perhaps, light and nicely drinkable. Very likeable.
On tap at brewery. Pour hazy brown with sweet aroma. Low/medium body, malty, sweet finish.
Average aroma, appearance, taste and palate. Decent, somewhat memorable. Rated from the tap.

Cloudy dark bronw beer topped by a thin off-white head. Pretty strange roasty nose reminds me of burnt buckwheat galettes which is not a particularly pleasant smell, but reminds of fond memories and hits the spot. Besides that, it stays focused on rather sweet, biscuit meets toffee sugary malts. Fortunately, the carbonation does the necessary cleansing job to reduce the sugary feel from that surprisingly frail body . Far from perfect, but still one of my favourite Slovenian dunkels from possibly my favourite brewer in the country.

Can, comes as Christian 4 Tal Pils 5,3%. Clear yellow colour, short white bubbly head. Sweet grainy aroma with some caramel and malt/cardboard. Thin mouthfeel. The flavour has a mild bitter.sweetness with grains, caramel and something malty. Cheap "beer" bought at the German-Danish border. Thanks Henrik.

33 cL can. Pours pale yellow with a chalk white head. Aroma is mild sweet cornish and somewhat cardboardish. Flavour is much the same, subdued sweetness and bitterness to a light acidic touch. Rather thin and somewhat watery finish.
Clear golden with tiny white head. Sweet aroma with malty and caramel notes. Sweet flavour with malty and cardboard notes.
Straw, OK head. Lightly malty and metallic aroma and high carbonation. The flavour is typical for a cheap mainstream beer, thin, malty with a hint of hops and a fairly OK bitterness. 1751
Yellow body. Lots of malt in arom and taste. There is a strange sublime taste in this in. I canÂ´t put the finger on it but itÂ´s there and itÂ´s no good.
Heavy malty and bready aroma. Large white head. Fair lacing. Mostly diminishing longevity. Clear yellow body. Moderate bitter initial flavor. Medium palate.
Can. This is in fact a strong lager, it has a fine balance in alcohol and in hopÂ´s. but it wont make you sit up and say ahhhh.
Can. Clear golden with no head what so ever. Slight metallic hintâ€™s of malt and a bit of fruit. Quit pleasent and easy drinkable. Like is because you can actually taste malt.

Can: Golden with little fast disappearing head. first sip has metallic notes. Other than that some sweet malty notes & alcohol. watery with a lively carbonation. Typical cheap 10 cent, messed up lager!
Canned. Medium head with medium duration. Color is pale golden. Aroma is malt and hops. Taste is malt and hops as well. A bit metallic.

column1: Big Buck Copper Penny Scotch Ale
column5: Sampled draught at Big Buck, Grapevine, Texas. Nut brown. Sweey and roasty. Thin for a Scotch ale, near watery. Roasty finish with very low bitterness. Scottish 10/-?

column1: Big Buck Copper Penny Scotch Ale
column5: I typically expect mroe ABV from Scotches. Amber color, very bubbly though the taste was still rather smooth. It had an excellent malt flavor with a slightly thick finish. Very nice, but not overly indicative of the style.

On tap at James Joyce in Baltimore under the name James Joyce Amber. The pour is light amber with a small foamy head and nice lacing. The scent is earth with a slight metallic note. The taste is malt, earthy, subtle hops. A smooth drink with subtle flavor. Not exciting, but better than mass market. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nice pale amber which had a full head when poured for me. Tasty and smooth.
Pours a light amber color. Aromas of roasted malts, and some hint of fruit. Flavor is malty, slightly sweet, with a bitter finish.
Neutral nose. Pale amber, low head. Slightly perfumed, pine, grass. Ok malt balance. Not that exiting.

I did not enter this beer--it was already in existance without ratings. I am not entirely certain this is the correct entry--Clipper City brews (as of 11/03) a beer for the bar Boatyard in Eastport which they call "Chesapeake Ale". The bar serves it too cold. But the beer is very good. A lot of American hops in the nose and flavor. A terribly easy drinker, modeled on the really nice Pacific hoppy ales. Damned fine.
Tap. Light gold color with a light musty bland lager taste. Nothing redeeming about this beer, but I guess business demands they have a beer like this on tap.
Tap. Dark brown with a light brown head. Sweet malts and quite a bit of body and kick to it.

column1: San Diego Red Star Imperial Stout
column5: On tap at Callahans. Poured into a snifter. Very dark pour with a thick chocolaty head. Sweet and smooth flavor with some nice roasty malts, very tasty.

column1: San Diego Red Star Imperial Stout
column5: Name: Ax-Pickin Stout Date: 12/03/2005 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Strong Ale Fest Appearance: muddy brown with ruby edges, thin tan head, Aroma: rich roasted malt aroma, Body: thin body, Flavor: light roasted flavor, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 4/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.9/5.0 Drinkability: 5/10 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 12/02/2006 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Strong Ale Fest Appearance: black with ruby edges, huge creamy tan head Aroma: slightly tart roasted malt aroma Body: creamy body Flavor: light roasted malt flavor, a touch of tartness, big bitter finish, a bit too much astrengent malt bitterness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: **/4

column1: San Diego Red Star Imperial Stout
column5: On tap at the 10th Annual San Diego Strong Ale Festival: Pours a mostly opaque with dark brown edges and a dense, frothy dark tan head. Aroma of roasty caramel and black patent malts with a touch of plum fruitiness. Body starts lightly sweet and roasty drying toward a semi-tart, warming finish.

column1: San Diego Red Star Imperial Stout
column5: a murky brown color with thin eggshell head. coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, and sour cherry. flavor is coffee, chocolate and only hints of the funky cherry/fruity flavor. maybe a little dark belgian candi sugar in there too... ? could have had a better appearance, and stronger characteristics all the way around. seemed watered down.

column1: San Diego Red Star Imperial Stout
column5: Good strong rep. Not too much ABV. Could be a bit heartier and less carbonization. smooth finish.

column1: San Diego Red Star Imperial Stout
column5: Pizza Port Strong Ale Fest 05: Murky brown color with a thin off-white head. Aroma of coffee and roasted sweet malt. Notes of prunes and light chocolate. Roasted coffe flavor with a tart and tangy finish. Semi-dry finish. 7/3/5/3/13 10th Annual SD Strong Ale Fest: Very dark brown almost opaque with a medium tan head. roasty malt aroma with notes of chocolate, dark sweet fruit and candy. Roasty flavor was less complex than the aroma. Estery finish. Nice warmth. Semi-dry bitter finish.

column1: San Diego Red Star Imperial Stout
column5: Aroma: Chocolate, coffee, burn roast, VERY NICE Appearance: Almost black dense Flavor: Very big roasted malt and bitterness slight tang on back of tongue which was a plus in my opinion Palate: dense mouthfeel thick Overall: Great Impy stout!!!!

column1: San Diego Red Star Imperial Stout
column5: Draft at Pizza Port Strong Ale Fest, Dec 05. Moderately dark brown, fairly hazy. Milky roasty aroma, some semi-sweet chocolate. Sweet lightly roasty flavors, some chocolate, and something kinda earhty/funky.

column1: San Diego Red Star Imperial Stout
column5: Draft: Dark brown, nose of fruity light roast and subtle coffee and chocolate. The flavor is more of a baltic porter with almost no astringency or high end hops, just intense chocolate cocoay notes. The finish is good and medium bodied. yum. Mellow, light, balanced.

column1: San Diego Red Star Imperial Stout
column5: Draft at SDBC. Very dark with a brown head. Aromas of chocolate and more roasty malts. Somewhat sour up front. Wasnâ€™t expecting that. Chocolate in the middle and decent hoppiness to finish things off. Alcohol warming if you let it sit on your tounge for a few minutes. Decent, actually... not too bad.

2/19/2011: NABC ConeSmoker Ale... Aroma: Pacific Northwestern-Style aroma - caramel maltiness with pine/resin and sugary grapefruit hoppiness. Appearance: Cloudy amber color; dense ivory to beige-colored crown. Flavor: Smoky with a nice hop profile; caramel malt with a respectable bitterness. Palate: Body is medium-light to medium; average mouthfeel. Overall: I think that this is probably the first hoppy smoked beer that I have had... This beer must be what a Smoked Pacific Northwestern-Style Red IPA would taste like! Draught sample (7% ABV; 60 IBU) at New Albanian Brewing Company in New Albany, IN. Rating #39 for this beer.

Growler courtesy shrubber85. Fruity/sweet smoked ham aroma. Hazy amber with a small off-white head, nice lacing. Sweet malty smoke ham flavor and a light bitterness in the finish. Medium body, light carbonation.
Draft. Hazy amber pour with an off white top. Scent is smoked bar-b-q. Taste is same with even more smoke.
Aroma of citrus, butterscotch, faint smoke and caramel. Appearance is toffee gold with creamy tan head. Flavor matches the nose. The palate is very bubbly. An interesting beer.
Tap. Honey smoked ham and malt aroma. Hazy amber color with nice head. Honey malt and smoked ham flavor. Lightly bitter herbal hops finish. A very sweet smoked beer but works well.
I think these people make great beer, but wow! This beer is all smoke in the nose and flavor. It has a great apperance but the smoke will ruin your palate. Stone only thinks they make ruination.

Pours golden amber with an off white head. Aroma is smoky wood and not much else. Flavor is almost all smoke, with a little bit of light malt. Not bad, but almost cloying, artificial smoke flavor is not my favorite.
Brown-red, off white cover. Aroma is light smoke, sweet. Taste is smoke, ash, bacon.

Draft sample at New Albanian. Poured dark hazy brown color with average off-white fizzy head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate roasted and small smoke aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium smokeybittersweet flavor with a medium roasted smoke finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable brew and standout for smoked style. Very interesting brew.

On tap at Rich Os. Hazy pour that i lighter color than expected. I am still not really into this style. This was good, but I have not grown fully accustomed to the smoked meat quality of smoked beers. Nice and balanced though. All the smokiness is in the flavor. Hardly any in the aroma.
Amber body, minimal head. Aroma is minimal, slightly earthy. Taste is earthy hops, spiked by some skunkiness. Medium body. Attempts an English-style IPA, but definitely falls short.

Amber color, white head. Aroma of earthy hops, light fruit. Well-balanced flavor (slightly bitter) of malt and hops, tastes like a mix of US and UK hops. Medium full mouthfeel. Not as hoppy as some other American versions, but pretty damn good.

Had this on tap while celebrating at the converted â€œVarsity Clubâ€ prior to the Fiesta Bowl in Tempe - GO BUCKS!! Interesting nose of grapefruit and smoke. This brew is a light amber with a white creamy head. The flavor is bitter and robust with moderate acidity. The medium creamy body is lively and smooth and finishes clean and dry. Like my Buckeyes this brew is a winner!
No head, clear dark amber. Aroma is mildly sweet, caramel, roasty, malty. Taste is smoky malty, smooth, not very bitter.

Had this on tap while celebrating at the converted â€œVarsity Clubâ€ prior to the Fiesta Bowl in Tempe - GO BUCKS!! Fresh floral nose. This brew is a medium ruby brown, with a frothy white head. This brew starts sweet with a long toasty finish. Iâ€™m not big on reds, but I really liked this one. The palate is medium dry and lively.
Amber with thin off white head. Light hop nose, lighter hop flavor. Not hoppy enough for an IPA
Strong roasted aroma. At bit thin. The flavor was both strong and week at the same time. Not great or balanced. Serving: Tap

Sample at the brewpub. The beer pours black with a medium tan head that recedes steadily. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Sweet roasted malt aroma along with a touch of chocolate. Medium, smooth body with flavors of malt, cocoa and mild coffee. The finish is short and roasty with a slight malty aftertaste. Just average overall.

On nitro at the BP. Almost opaque black with creamy tan head. Aroma is smoke and roasted malt. Off-dry smokey, roasted malt, bitter bakers chocolate, a little spicey. Light body and watery. Like a watery porter and a little chalky.

Pour is black with a thin dense brown head...smell is rich and roasty chocolate with hints of smoke...what a great nose!!!! rich and roasty flavors of cocoa and lots of coffee...a little too thin...if it was a little more full bodied it would be amazing...

On tap at the Flatlanders Brew Pub. Poured a dark, dark brown color with an averaged sized tan head. Aromas of roast, chocolate, and caramel. Tastes of roast, chocolate, caramel, and some coffee in the finish. Thinner body.

Draught sample at the brewpub, December 28th 2006. Typical nitro pour, nice dark head lasts through my samples of 4 other beers, opaque jet body, bit of dark lacing....nose of chocolate and lots and lots of prunes, deep and fairly well structured though sweeter than I expected....watery body but no off flavors, lightly spicy with cinnamon and perhaps a dash of licorice, grapy, bittersweet chocolate and touches of coffee....prune juice comes in at midpalate and doesnâ€™t go away, dominates far too much....not bad, but too fruity and lacking in roast.

Draught at the brewpub. Pitch black with a creamy off-white, nearly brown, head. Malty sweet roasted aromas. Caramel and burnt flavours. Mouthfeel is surprisingly sweet for an irish stout. I belive there has been used caramel and crystal malts in the beer. Finishes lightly roasted, but not bitter.
Not much going on on any level here. Virtually no nose. Watered down mouthfeel. Weak flavors of roasted malt/chocolate/coffee, but very weak. I wasted 10 minutes on this one!

On tap at Goose Island Stoutfest. Poured a deep brown with only a light ring of toffee head. Nose was of semi-sweet roasted chocolate and a little caramel.. not much more. Flavor picked up the chocolate and some stale coffee.. also just OK. Carbonation was too low resulting in a flat feel to it. Body was light to light-med. This was drinkable, but powerfully mediocre.

Pours an oily black/brown with a thin, non-retaining head. The nose finds a sour chocolate aroma and the flavor matches. Thin and chalky with a decent alcohol hit but a dirty finish. Mediocre. Tasted like an amateur experiment. On tap at Night of the Living Ales II, Goose Island Wrigleyville 03/04/06
Tap @ Brewpub I thought that this was a nice wheat bear, with a classic wheat beer flavor but not one that blows you away.
Cloudy yellow with a light, filmy head and spots of lace. Banana and cloves with some wheat in the nose. Bitter with more tones of bananas. Nicely spiced. Tangy and well spiced.

Tap @ Brewpub in Lewiston, ID
Cloudy yellow, nose of fresh citrusy lemon, clean wheat and lots of yeast esters. The flavor is lightly sweet, nice chewy body. Good hefe!

Traditional gold color with swirls of orange and brown, pours with a nice head. Has elements of citrus, banana, and nutmeg. Best served with a slice of orange, this is a basic hefe with no more than average taste.

Courtesy of Jeff Bottle: The aroma caramel, fruit, citrus, and oxidation. It pours a transparent dark amber with a thin white ring for a head. The flavor starts with caramel and fruit. The finish has some ages citrus hops, oxidation, andlight oxidation. Medium-full bodied with mild carbonation and slight syrupy mouthfeel.
Pours a clear amber. Lots of caramel malts. Thick and oily. Not too bad.

Bottle shared by thickfreakness. Thanks Charles! Pours reddish amber with a short lived beige head. Smell is tart, oxidized caramel. Taste is dark, tart bitter caramel with the slightest tang. So-so, and not terrible, but this bottle was on its way downhill.

Bottle... Pre-C&Pâ€™sLYFO Throwdown... Mostly clear amber ale with a small, creamy, khaki head. Fruity esters and caramel malt comprise the nose. Full-bodied with an oily mouthfeel and mild carbonation. Caramel sweetness flanks moderate bitterness and a whisper of acidity. Crisp, bittersweet, malty finish.
@ GI Clybourn. Pours a reddish brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of sweet dark fruit. Very sweet, caramel and dark fruit. Just a slight bit of hops. A nice barleywine.
On tap at the San Diego strong ale festival. Pours a reddish brown; off-white head. Sweet caramel malts, raisin, spice, and hints of berries and bourbon. Very good,an interesting barleywine.

Tap at Clybourn - RIP. Smells so much like Bourbon County that we checked about 5 times to see if it was aged. Very deep red, thickly sweet and sour at once. Real gritty barley and rye notes. Old Abe is not going quietly...

tap at GI Clybourn... dark reddish amber brown pour, just penetrable by light, with a medium frothy light beige head... aroma has a more assertive dark fruit component to it. very little hops and mostly sweetened malt.... rich, sweet, caramel flavors. the middle keeps the sweeter profile and finishes with an apparent and mild sharp bitterness. nice full body with mild carbonation. slightly warming. a really nice barleywine... also had this side by side with the cask version which had a more transparent color to it. huge difference in tast in that the hop bitterness was hugely pronounced when compared with itâ€™s sibling off the regular tap. less malty and sweet. def. favor the regular version to this one. 7/4/8/4/16

On tap at GI Clybourn. Poured a deep red with a small tan head. Aroma is of malt, sweet hops, spice, and alcohol. Nice malty taste, with a delicious super hoppy backbone. Notes of spice and raisins. Deep warming alcohol presence. Creamy mouthfeel that goes down smooth, without being too intense. Insanely drinkable. My only complaint is that it needed less sweetness and more alcohol face punching.
on tap at goose island clybourn. dark brown color, ruby highlights, small head. aroma of airy perfume. flavor of rich malt, with a hint of coffee, dried fruits, alcohol. oily mouthfeel.

column1: Goose Island Lake Effect Winter Ale (2002-2013)
column5: From old notes. Draft at clybourn. Citrus and pine dominate. Pretty darn good brew right here.

column1: Goose Island Lake Effect Winter Ale (2002-2013)
column5: Very spicey yeast in this one, sweet malt, herbal hops, not my favorite from GI.

column1: Goose Island Lake Effect Winter Ale (2002-2013)
column5: Flight on tap at the Clybourn Brewpub (Chicago, IL). Pours a deeper hazed golden amber hue. Good glow, mellow carbonation. Offwhite cakey head sits atop and laces well, sticks around. Aromas are Citra hops, gentle bready and straw grainy malts. Doughy, touches of spice, mellow citrus, florals and that Citra feel gives some good life. Gentle straw, dryness hit from the yeast, some spice, mellow lemon, bready malts. Initial is lighter bodied, a touch of girth from the malt bill. Firm hoppy presence up front offers florals, grass, lemon, gentle Citra fruity tropical presence. Bready and crisp straw, grainy malts. Some gentle spiciness, Belgian yeast influence starts to float into the middle. Firmer dry middle and hoppy backend, never gets a bit heavy or sweet. The malt body is there and never really changes. The hops glide over it, firmly dry, citrusy, a nice nose and more earthy floral backend and finish. Gentle bready, straw, and grainy malt body as we move through. Gentle spice, yeast, touch of lotion and lemon as we move into backend and finish become more assertive. Firm inviting dry hoppy element finishes, gentle yeasty, gentle fruity elements meld with the hops. Really plays well together. Nice Citra dose on the nose, firmly hopped beer but nothing Iâ€™d call strong. Pretty nice Belgian Ale with a nice American hop spin.

column1: Goose Island Lake Effect Winter Ale (2002-2013)
column5: Draught @ Clybourn Brewpub: Served in a tulip glass. This one pours a Fairly clear amber color. There was about 1 finger of an off-white head onit. There was some lacing. It has a nice hoppy nose. It is pretty well balanced between citrus and pine hops. The taste is very good. Not too bitter at all. It is fairly full bodied. Pine, some citrus, lots of malts, but no real sweetness to it. Some caramel and faint fruits also.

column1: Goose Island Lake Effect Winter Ale (2002-2013)
