(bottle) pours a clear golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of chestnut honey and heavy dandelions, with hints of popcorny wheat, pale malts and fallen leaves. flavour is mostly the same, popcorn and floral hops, with hints of pepper, cardboard and barnyard. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Pours clear golden with a medium white head. Malty and caramelish character in the aroma with light hoppy notes. The flavour is sweet malty and grainy.
Herber, mild sÃ¼ÃŸer Beginn. Trocken malzig, wenig wÃ¼rzig, leicht steigende IntensitÃ¤t. Mittellanger Abgang, eher langweilig. 8/7/8/7/9/7

Had this beer at the canstatter wasen (volksfest) in 2017. Lovely crisp festival beer. Malt and caramel flavours dominate with a light citrus hop tone. Very easy to drink. It may not excite for a one off drink but it's perfect for a beer festival or party
Klassisches MÃ¤rzen mit einer leichten Karamellnote und einem angenehm wÃ¤rmenden alkoholischen Hintergrund. Etwas Vanille, dazu mild malzig und im Abgang durchaus sÃ¼ffig. Vollkommen ok.
Gylden klar skum hvid lang tÃ¦t Malt brÃ¸d korn citrus gÃ¦r Bitter modrate sÃ¸d modrate Oile blÃ¸d @wassen ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Couleur dorÃ©e, forte mousse. Nez maltÃ© avec note cÃ©rÃ©ales et noisettes. Gout trÃ¨s maltÃ© avec notes de houblon, pain, noisettes, douces. Bon corps. Amertume moyenne en fin de bouche

The beer has got a light hazy golden colour with a steady head and medium body. Aroma of malt and hops. Taste of hops, citrus, bread, straw, malt and grass. Refreshing and nice to drink, yet of course nothing special.

Many thanks for this beer to kevnic2008. Piwo z ladna piana choÄ‡ nietrwala, ladnym kolorze jaskrawego zoltka. Smak slomy, wafli pszennych i skorki chleba i gotowanej kukurydzy. Zapach lekko trawiasty, piwo maÅ‚o nachmielone.
Goldgelb Schaum ok, typisches volksfestbier Geruch leicht getreidig Geschmack flach wÃ¤ssrig
0,5l Flasche. Goldgelbes Festbier mit weissem Schaum. SÃ¼sse und Gerste in der Nase. SÃ¼ffiger Geschmack, kaum herb. Etwas langweilig.

50cl bottle from kevnic2008, many thanks! Pours clear deep golden colour with a mid-sized white head. Aroma of pale malt, grain, some sweetness. Taste is intense malty, cornish, spicy, medium bitter finish.
Draft - Light sweet grains. Pale fizzy gold with a nice white head. Light sweet pale malts. Very sweet.

On tap at Big Ridge, pours a cloudy yellow with a small white head. Nose brings out corn, a little wheat, and grass. Flavour is quite clean and refreshing, with grassy hops, citrus and corn. Quite juicy for a lager. Well-balanced and with no off-flavours. Good for the style.
Draught at the brewpub Blond color. Although not offensive, the aroma is mild, the flavor is sweetish for a Lager, and overall itâ€™s quite weak. Very common.

Aroma is faint fruity malts, body is an okay clear gold with little head. Flavour is okay grain notes, with a slightly bitter, fruity, and dry finish. Itâ€™s not a bad lager; simple reliable, but hard to pick out of a crowd.
Blonde with no head. Slightly sweet with a grassy flavour. Seems like a dirtier lager then the Red Truck Lager that I had.
Pale blonde colour with a thin white head. Fairly dusty aroma, a bit of DMS. Flavour is also slightly vegetal with hay/grass notes.
Typical Mark James lager - good dose of hop, well-made but unspectacular....
Hazy gold,thick lasting white head. No noticeable aroma. Can taste nothing but cigar butt (dirty line?) taste.
Draft - Toasted malts and some cocoa. Dirty dark brown with a rich beige head, toasted malts, some light nut and coffee bitterness. Not bad.

Cask at Alibi Room, Vancouver. Pours Dark Brown, almost opaque, no head, nice smoky/roasted aroma. Slightly syrupy and sweet, medium body. Subtle finish reintroduces smoky notes. A very nice traditional English-style porter, glad to have had it on cask.
(Draught) Purchased at the Alibi Room on March 14, 2012, for $6.25. Very smooth, nice ash. Great texture - very good full body. Not gritty but strong palate. Enjoyable.

On nitro tap at The Alibi Room, pours dark orangey brown with a foamy beige head. Aroma of English malt, light treacle and biscuit. Flavour of butterscotch, roasted malt, treacle, light spices and feint chocolate. Great smooth body with rich flavours for a porter. Very enjoyable.

Draught at the brewpub Dark amber-brown color, with a persistent creamy head. Aroma of dark, roasted malts, light bread. Smooth mouthfeel in the front, with a good roasted malt and dark chocolate flavor, getting drier to the end, more ashy, more toasty; there are light hop qualities, but they are hidden by the dark malts. The dryness of the final is also a bit metallic. Quite tasty overall.

Aroma is okay roasted barley with nothing else on the nose, and none of that barley is turning into other fancy flavours you might reasonably expect from roasted barley. Has modest head, and a dark amber-black body. Flavour is barley, roasted; imagine that! Itâ€™s drinkable but missing some serious mastery.

Date: September 06, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: opaque brown, creamy beige head, sheets of lace Aroma: sweet chocolate aroma, caramel sweetness, nice nutty character Flavor: sweet chocolate flavor, dark caramel sweetness, light bitterness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4

Iâ€™ve been driving past this place on a regular basis ever since they opened and at last, yesterday, finally stepped inside for lunch, Oh yes, and also for some beer. This porter looked right but I could sense any sort of aroma at all. Odd, but the taste was what it should be and thatâ€™s what matters the most. Might have been some dark chocolate, might have been some burnt coffee, but if there was I could not discern any of it. However, it DID taste like a porter. Mouthfeel was better than some porters Iâ€™ve had, i.e., not thin, and this one had a nice finish. An okay beer, and Iâ€™d have it again.
Dark brown with a tan creamy nitro head. Aroma is light touch of coffee and some dark malts. A light toasty flavour with a little chocolate. Finishes slightly sticky and thin.

Very pale for a porter... looks like a darkish amber colour. Brown nitro head. Faint caramel and toast, but otherwise quite low. Flavour is chocolatey and roasty with a touch of coffee. Light caramel/cocoa finish with lingering bitterness.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the brewpub bar dispensed to a shaker showing a hazed, yellow/gold color, with a presentable layer of white froth that reduced to a persistent ring & film, with foamy dots & dashes of lacing. The nose was soft grain/wheat, a touch of lemon, with light hefe characteristics of banana & clovey phenols. Light+ bodied, with good effervescence, the taste was similar, adding some modest, earthy bitterness and crisp & somewhat dry finish.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the brewery pours a hazy, dark gold with a ring of white head. Nose is very estery, banana, clove, cakey. Flavor is very sweet, honey, cake, clove. Sweet finish, overdone.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Fonefan 191214. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is citrus, apple, malt, orange, banana. Flavour is dry, citrus, apple, orange, banana, sourness, wheat, yeast. Medium body. Ordinary beer.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Banana spice lemon and orange dominate this guy on both the nose and tongue. Not bad for the style. Had this as part of a flight at Grumpy Troll in Mount Horeb, WI.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Bottle 22fl.oz. [ As Grumpy Troll Trailside Wheat ]. ABV: 5.0%. Clear medium orange yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, wheat, sweet wheat, moderate yeasty, fruity yeast, yeast. Flavour is moderate sweet with a average duration, tart fruit, fruity, yeast, wheat. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20141219]

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: 1 pint 6 fl oz bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with small white head. Aroma is toasted malty and caramelish. Toasted and fruity. Mild citric. dry and toasted malty. Citric and dry finish.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Bottle. A clear one, dark golden in color and with a dense, white head of finger-thick size. Quite fruity aroma with a sourish orange- and banana touch. Some sourish citrus juice in the flavor, with a generic fruityness, some banana and a spiced hint. Medium to thin on the palate, dry and lightly acidic. Lasting finish. Well, sure not my favorite wheat beer, even though thereâ€™s some sweetness going on which I doubt should be there and thatâ€™s probably the most interesting about this beer. 141219

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Clear golden with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, wheaty, banana, lemon and yeasty. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. Surprisingly dry. 191214

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Bottle 650ml @ fonefan Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, wheat, yeast, some tartness and faint hint of banana and clove. Taste is medium sweet, light bitter and light sour. Body is light to medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Tap at brewery. Pours slightly cloudy golden. Lots of clove, a little banana and some pepper. Very good.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours cloudy orange/gold. Virtually no aroma and barely a flavor either. Slight malt and just a hint of hoppiness. Mouthfeel is extremely thin and low carbonation.

Picked up a growler of this at the GTMW thanks to the folks at Illinois Brewing: Poured a bright clear copper colour with really no head. IT had lost some carbonation. Mouthfeel was light and creamy, soft with floral notes abundant. Taste was flavorful- citrusy with soft lime andgrapefruit notes. But not as bold and hoppy as the description said.

(Tap) Pours a light amber color with almost no head. Sweet, fruity aroma. Light hop notes in the taste. The fruity taste almost seems like a flaw. Could have been more hoppy and had a better mouthfeel. Not particularly good.

From the tap this poured a pale amber with a white head that had no desire to do any lacing. The aroma is faint, but it presents some sweet caramel covered by grapefruit anmd pine hop scents. A bit thin, but I can forgive them that because of the hops. The grapefruit gets almost juicy in the flavor, balancing out nicely with the sweet malt. Good crisp, bitter finish. Pretty decent. Illinois Brewing Company, Bloomington, IL

not sure i got a good sample of this one. ill try later to try it again and re rate. it was very sweet and a little watery. a good deal of citrus flavor, but that didnt taste like it came from the hops.

Draft, at IBC. I can definitely find the Cascade hops advertised on its description, but I didnâ€™t find it to be especially hoppy for the style. Still some fruit taste that may be more from hops than esters.

Wonderful pale ale-the aroma was very piney/hoppy with a tad darker appearance than say SNPA-lots of lace and a smooth palate with a strong emphasis on Cascade hops. A good brew from an interesting brewery

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: This was just called Kolsch, but I assume it is the same beer. The body was light gold with a white head. The aroma was fesh bread dough with some whole wheat and some carrots. The taste was sweet potatoes with some dirt. The finish was honey ham.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Little nose, but some lemon-orange comes through as it warms. Nice lacing. Quite bitter, not much malt, far and away the hoppiest beer at this place, just a bit of dry malt at the end.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Clear straw with a white head. Nice lace. Dry/sweet aroma. Dry candy corn flavors. Dry vanilla finish. A weird ale.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: This was a very odd beer, and I had trouble coming up with words for it. Yellow in color, it was both citrusy and a little smoky. Didn''t really care for it. Sorry I can''t be more help on this one folks.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Nice to see this one return after a nine-year absence. On draught at the Grumpy Troll brewpub in Mt. Horeb, Wisconsin. Pours a clear golden amber colored brew with an average off-white head the slowly dissipates and leaves behind some spotty lacing. Aroma of fruity and golden caramel malt with a hint of Scotch Ale character with a hint of melon. Taste is medium bodied, soft carbonation with flavors of toasted caramel malt, floral hops and some Munich and caramel multi-grain. Finish is semi-sweet, Vienna malty some a mild bitterness.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Amber color with little/no head. Sweet malt and vinous aroma. Strong alcohol and malt flavors that are somewhat vinous. With the strengh and flavors, wonder if some strange gnome got into the yeast.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Orangish red color, and an almost flowery aroma. I definately tasted apple in this, and think I noticed orange, caramel and cinnamon as well. Left kind of an acidic mouthfeel afterwards. Seemed to be too thick, almost syrupy. I need to try this again someday.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: From the Jug at the GABF Colorado Convention Center, Denver 09/10/2008 &#40As Sumner Stout&#41 Roast aroma. Black and smooth on the palate with some alcohol present. Crisp dry and slightly bitter burnt roast finish.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Draught at GABF 2008 as Grumpy Troll Summer Stout. Black coloured with a small beige head. Roasted aroma of caramel, chocolate and coffee with notes of hay. Roasted flavour of coffee, hay and dish washer. Roasted finish.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Terribly concocted and not to friendly. I had a sampler at the brewpub and was dissipointed to the fact that the bartender thought this was good stuff. I would recommend that if you visit the Grumpy Troll that you donâ€™t ask the bartenders what they think is the best brews on tap. It lacked the substantial feel of a stout and seemed rather thin. Rated in September of 2006 just to clarify that with the user by the name of grumpy troll.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Draught pint at the brewpub, mid-October 2006. Translucent, near-black body with a decent lasting frothy off-white head and nice thick lacing....milky chocolate at first in a nose that rapidly becomes roastier and sharper and hints of licorice which doesnâ€™t materialize enough for real excitement....some nice roastiness throughout the body, fairly fruity (berries) and slightly tart, dark chocolate touches....body could be fuller but itâ€™s really quite drinkable, definitely the best thing I had on this visit.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: The body was very dark brown with a light ruby color when held ot light. The khaki head was fairly thin on top. The aroma had lots of chocolate with coffee and some sweet oatmeal. The taste was light with some mild coffee and a a little bitof roast. There was also some milk chocolate in the smooth and light body. A lame stout that they describe as dry on their menu.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Dark Brown Coloring with Whisp of a White Ring. Chocolate and Coffee Roasts on the Nose. Very Light Mouthfeel...Certainly Not Robust with the Chocolate and Coffee Flavor but Still a Good Drinking Stout.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Black color with slightly red edges. Aroma of burnt coffee. Very watery body. The coffee is still there with a slight chocolate wrap.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the Brewpub. Dark brown in color with a white head. Roasted and coffee-like aroma. Body is too light. Good lacing. Not an outstanding stout and slightly disappointing for this very good brewpub.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Worst looking stout ever - clear, translucent amber brown with a thin grey/white head. Roasted malt and cocoa powder aroma along with some walnuts. Smells like a potent red. Chocolate dryness attempts to satisfy its claim as a stout. Thatâ€™s pretty much as far as it gets. Dry and thin-bodied. Might be classified as a stout in a blind taste test, but I have serious reservations.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Beautiful looking beer. This beer does excite my tastebuds (mind you it was the last one I had, they were already pretty excited). A very good stout with no crappy aftertaste.

Tap. Pours reddish-brown. The pleasantries end there. Smells of raw hamburger meat, and it tastes like it smells except they bothered to add some peaty malt in the mix. Mouthfeel is unfortunately full. I fear I may have salmonella poisoning.
Slightly odd taste to it, golden brown color. Almost could taste the barley(I know that sound odd but I could). Weak flavor, thin tasting. Not really very good compared to some of their other beers.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Tried this one at the Brewpub in the Monte Carlo Casino on a recent trip to Vegas. Really not a whole lot going on here, but it is what it is. This beer is pretty much their wheat beer with some orange flavor added. They float a orange in the glass when they serve it to you, and the sweet/cirtus orange flavor of this beer makes it refreshing. The beer pours to a slightly hazy, golden color with a tight, white head, and a moderate carbonation. The nose has light citrus notes of orange. The palate is lean, and smooth, with light flavors of tart wheat, and light citrus flavors. This beer finishes quickly with light orange flavors. A nice thirst quencher for hot weather, but a pretty average beer in every way.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Golden orange with good off white head. Lighly spiced citus (orange nose) The flavor was more of orange peel rather than the fruit itself.
From old tasting notes. Orange amber liquid with a creamy beige head. Slightly sweet toasted malt nose. Tangy toasted malt flavor. Hints of citrus and cloves with a dry finish and aftertaste.
not bad, but iâ€™ve had way better. i didnâ€™t think they still made this until i got some the other day. i remember it being way better than it was

Pours thin and lifeless. Taste is like a barnyard, with lots of straw and animal dung. The hops are flat, the malt is raw, and everything else in this screams awful. Iâ€™m reminded of cooked beets while drinking this. Not suitable for anyone... except Will Smith.
Oh No!, they donâ€™t make this muck anymore?! Darn, shucks, crap, holy-cannoli! That is such a shame, if anyone ever liked this beer I feel bad.......GOOD

poured a clear reddish color with a very thin tan head. Aroma was sweet and malty. The was deffinitally a caramel presence in its aroma. Taste was light, almost delicate with a nice hoppy twang in the finish.

Bottle. What an interesting find in a small liquor store in Menlo Park, CA. How this beer ended up here I have no idea. A cloudy amber color with a tan head. Lots of caramel in the malty nose. A little tangy zest on the palate. Pretty good stuff.

A surprise when it came on the market in 2002. It actually tastes really good! Tasted from a bottle. Nice golden colour with weak head. Malty aroma and a hint of corn. The taste is a bit sweet, malty and some good hint of corn. The yeast used for this pilsner is partly the same as used in a Carlsberg pilsner. Maybe thatÂ´s why is has such a good taste.
Bottle. Golden colour with a small white head. Malty, corny aroma and taste, light fruity. Medium body and a sweet finish.
Bottled. Clear yellow coloured with a small white head. Aroma of malts, hops and corn. Flavour of malts and hops with notes of corn. Hoppy finish.

(Bottle 33 cl) Pilsener golden with a very small head. Malty aroma with some odd almost fusel like impressions - and coal (?). Light, slightly watery body with weak notes of malt. Very discreet bitterness. 041005

A yellow beer with a thin disappearing white head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of straw as well as corn. The flavor is sweet and very light with notes of corn and hints of honey on a thin body, and leading to a slightly bitter end. Iâ€™m confused about the corn notes I pick up - the label claims that brewing cereal has been added, but the brewer claims it is an all grain beer - but I have never tasted such a thin all grain beer and I pick up notes from corn. Weird.
The best pilsener of the Faroe Islands. Fantastic fruity and spicy aroma. Nice refreshing flavour with a hoppy finish.
The best pilsener from the Faroe Islands. A funny aroma, different fruit notes, maybe abricot? Quite good pilsener for the mighty people of the Foroe Islands.

column1: Crested Butte White Buffalo Peace Ale
column5: From old tasting notes. Amber orange color. Thick creamy beige head. Fragrant earthy malt nose. Sweet toasted malt flavor hints at butterscotch and clover. Nice dry finish.

column1: Crested Butte White Buffalo Peace Ale
column5: Old rating. 2006 national western stockshpw. We were late for the mutton busting, so we cut through the stockyard. We happened upon a cage with several of the rare white buffalo. On the pen were two bottles of this beer and a snickers bar, possibly an homage to the elusive beast, either way we drank the beer and ate the candy bar. A magical night, I remember almost nothing about the beer except that it was plain and magical,.

column1: Crested Butte White Buffalo Peace Ale
column5: (draft at Peterson Brewfest 2/18/11). Clear gold color. Medium off white head. Moderate bready malt aroma, with light sweetness and light hops. Flavor of the same, with moderate grassy hop character. Avg duration. Light bitter finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

column1: Crested Butte White Buffalo Peace Ale
column5: Taster at a local. This is obviously no longer an Amber, and the breweries web site calls it an American Pale Ale. Pours a thin white head, over a clear, yellow (SRM 3) body....nose is light cereal, grass....taste is cereal, light malts, finishing with a light hop bitterness....mouth feel is light, carbonation medium. While it is nicely balanced it is a light version of a Pale Ale. This would be a pleasant "patio beer". BJCP 6/3/11/4/5

column1: Crested Butte White Buffalo Peace Ale
column5: Bottle. Pours clear tawny with a spare, fizzy, off-white head, diminishing with spare lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (bread, caramel, nutty), average hops (grass), average yeast (dough) with notes of cola. Light bodied, thin texture, soft carbonation, and a chalky finish. Average duration, moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness; lightly sweet finish.

column1: Crested Butte White Buffalo Peace Ale
column5: Light hazy apricot with no head. Hop nose mixed with some citrus. What it does have on the aroma is fleeting in the palette. Low carbonation as well. Only and okay beer.

column1: Crested Butte White Buffalo Peace Ale
column5: Pour is hzed golden yellow with a thin white head...smell is strong with grapefruit....malt sweetness seems the same as the pale...grainy and sweet at first with a light citric bitterness...

column1: Crested Butte White Buffalo Peace Ale
column5: Draft: Clear and light amber. Smooth but light body went down fairly easy. Toasty malts with a faint sweetness. Decent balance, but unexciting. Definitely a session beer for the masses.

column1: Crested Butte White Buffalo Peace Ale
column5: Draught. Body is light amber. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers, grapefruit). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

column1: Crested Butte White Buffalo Peace Ale
column5: i earned my thirst the hard way, toiling up a dusty colorado hillside, sweating enough to irrigate an acre of mojave mangoes. back home after my exertion, and gasping like a fish out of water, i could have drenched that thirst with tap water, but being a major beer geek, i reached for a bomber of local brew-- in this case, a crested butte white buffalo. it was terrifically quenching, owing largely to itâ€™s resemblance to cold water. this beer has some caramelly aspects, mostly in the color, being a shade of golden-orange suitable to caramel corn-- it has visible veins of something i guess to be yeast, so, given the name "white" i was ready to assume it was loosely in the wit style. it isnâ€™t. is "weenie" a style? itâ€™s understated aroma is butterscotch, and dry grassy hops. the head was not disposed to exertion and napped all the while i was taking tastes and notes--and, rather than waking up refreshed, merely lapsed into a coma and died. it quaffs nicely-- with little to either excite approbation or ignite condemnation to the dozing taste buds it glides over. itâ€™s carbonation is mild, itâ€™s body is like water-- only more so. a slight apricot-tort flavor, a touch of yeast and a brief distress signal of bitterness from a lost detatchment of hops. hereâ€™s everything you adore in a cold glass of water, plus a cute beer accent and a pleasant buzz.
Can. Pours clear pale piss yellow with a disappearing white head. Corn, maize, water. Grains.. Poor. But thanks Plovmand!
Can. Pours clear yellow with a white head. Aroma of grainy, slight paper, light banana, grains. Taste is quite sweet, slight citrus, light paper, generic.
Can at Orla leaves the hood for good. Clear golden body with a small white head. Malt, cardboard, corn.
Can. It pours mostly clear yellow with a creamy white head. The aroma is grain and light earthy hops. Clean malty flavor with light fruity hoppy notes.

Bottle at restaurant. Pale golden color, white head. Bitter with citrus, a bit of hops, toast, malts and grass. Bitter finish with citrus, a bit of hops, malts, toast and grass. Drinkable bulk Pilsener.
Beer is relatively common lager but Bolivia is the place where You can drunk beer almost in 5000m from the sealevel

Bottle courtesy of Painy who brought me this one back from his South American travels. Pours pale gold with a small white head. Aroma of grain, caramel, sweet malt, light fruit. Medium plus sweetness, light bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, average carbonation. Certainly not the worst pale lager ever.
When travelling in Bolivia, having one is great, when served chilled. Among the few brews available I rate this to be on of the better. On a global perspective it is no more than an average Lager.

Clear golden with little white head. Aroma is baked peas straw noble hops dms. Taste is harsh hop tartness with sour dish water. Watery but has some tart body. Also drinkable in large quantities. Yeah...

A golden lager with a thick white head. In aroma, classic Latin American lager with light grassy hops, light mineral notes, OK. In mouth, a crisp adjunct malt with light German hops, light mineral notes, OK. Bottle at Paprika, Cochabamba.
Bottle at bar. Pale golden color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, malts, toast, a bit of hops and grass. Bitter finish with citrus, toast, malts and grass. Drinkable bulk lager.

Clear catpiss with little white head. Aroma is musty hops sour dms grassy. Taste is sour grains with herbal tart notes. Good body but somehow ugly in the finish. Still one of the "better" bolivian macros i guess.

From my pre-RB days, I drank this in bottles/cans when in Potosi, Bolivia. It was a typical macro-lager that in essence was inoffensive and unmemorable drunk cold in the city of itâ€™s birth (i.e. fresh). Light bodied, deep gold, fizzy carbonation - refreshing on a bright sunny hot Potosi day. Given as an offering to the gods of the Potosi silver mines along with coca leaves...

My Bottom Line: Rubber soles, erasers and gasoline whiffs waft through this industrial lagerâ€™s hay-like cereals. Further Personal Perceptions: -A thin veil of foam skirts the light straw. -This is so far from a good Pils, itâ€™s scary. -This makes Pacena look like a goddamn masterpiece. -I usually avoid beers that could be awful (or awfully boring) like this. But I admit, once in a while, itâ€™s nice to remind oneself of how low a brewery can go. Can.

A hazed pale blonde lager with a thin white head. In aroma, light skunked malt with adjunct, light mineral notes, boring. In mouth, horrible formaldehyde with light mineral notes, un drinkable. Can from Uyuni convenience store.

fruity hops on the nose and not much else, but it does smell appealing. Lots of bleached white head and a very yellow carbonated body. Flavour is weak malts with a hint of lemon. Ricey finish. An adequate lager, probably, sort of, at best.

500ml bottle in a bar in Uyuni. Poured a clear straw yellow with a good sized, though fading, white head. Grain and grassy hops though little else. Light to medium body, medium carbonation and a short length, soft intensity bitterness in the finish.
NIce, easy to swallow, a little graspy but fine aftertaste and nice fatures in golden body too.

Canned 350ml. -Very pale yellow coloured, small airy white head, sour maize nose. Weak in every way you look. Water with weak notes of butterscotch and maize with hint of metal in the finish. Almost tasteless beer.
Can, a dirty malt aroma with maybe just a touch of fruit. A light bitter palate with a hoppy flavour, though more malty in the finish with some sweetness.

Deep dark appearance of a classic stout. Flavor is just a bit too robust for my liking. Their wasnt one part that stood out as special. The aroma is ok & enjoyable, with notes of chocolate & roasted malt.

Dense black, opaque. Roasted hazelnut, coffee aroma albeit a little subdued. Sweet dark chocolaty flavors, not sure if it"s an oatmeal but has tha kind of feel. Roasted coffee dryness and licorice in the finish that leaves a nice lingering aftertaste. (Tasted @ Babe"s Bar-B-Que & Brewhouse).
Black color with a brown small slightly bubbly head. Aroma of roasted malts. It tastes of unsweetened chocolate and caramel. It also has a burnt malt flavor...not too great..lacking in quite alot.
Dark, although not opaque. Strong roasted flavor with some chocolate in back. Slightly sweet. Not much hop presence. Fairly tasty but a little cloying.

Tap at the brewery. Pale yellow color, not very appetizing really. Nice aroma, really good light malt aroma. Flavor was solid as well, nice malt backbone with some honey sweetness, no off flavors, very good.
Pours a yellow/gold with thin head. Aroma of pale malts and honey. Light malt sweetness with a nice honey aspect as well. Light and crisp with pleasant sweetness.
Clear light yellow with fizzy white head. Sweet malty, honey, and orange aroma. Crisp bready taste with a hint of citrus and honey and a clean finish.
A very pale golden color. A sweet honeyed aroma. The flavor was slightly sweet and very forgettable.
Slight honey aroma. Very clean. Basically yellow fizzy beer. Slightly malty aroma. Grainy. Somewhat bland.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Tap @ Amerisports KC. Pours a clear golden appearance with a white head. Slightly grainy, pils, grassy aroma. Tangy, somewhat dry, lemon flavor. Pass.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: On tap at Amerisports Brewpub. Pours a clear light yellow color with white head. Light, malty, honey, pils flavors. Very light and weak.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Tap - not much head, light straw color, crisp refreshing balanced flavor - better than I expected

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Clear yellow with a fizzy white head. Sweet bread aroma and taste with some caramel taste.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Sampler at the brewpub. Clear gold with a decent white head. Aroma of florals, citrus and grain. Taste is light florals and hops. Decent.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Pours yellow. This beer is very light in both aroma and flavor. Light graininess in both.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Sampler @ brewpub, listed as a kolsch. Color is completely clear macro piss yellow. Has light diacetyl throughout a light sweetness. Buttered popcorn all the way. Worst beer they had.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: I liked this beer, its very drinkable for a lighter style beer. Noble hop nose, with some grassy floral qualities. Biscuity maltiness, and very clean.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: On tap again recently. Still a nice clean pils. The body was a pale gold with a white head. The aroma contained pancakes with flowers and oranges. The taste was light oranges with some flowers and a little hop bite. Nice and smooth.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: On tap at the brewpub 2/20/06: A shade darker than the light with a creamy head and a creamy consistency. Nice floral bouqet and a kolsch-like character. Good.

Pours goldish with little head. Light aroma of sweetness and citrus. The flavor is light caramel malt sweetness with a low citrus bitterness in the finish. Not alot going on here, but at least it is well made.
On tap at PH Woods. Clear yellow amber with a fizzy white head. Faint malty and citrus aroma and taste.
This is a clear brownish colored beer. Kind of sweet for a pale ale, can taste some caramel.

Light caramel color with a very light head. Aroma was floral with a touch of hops. Light carbonation that touched the tongue. Fruity taste with a touch of malts...seems balanced and yummy...my favorite here at PH Woods actually I ordered another pint. Since I am close...I will come back for a pint of this and a B-ball game.

Very fruity aroma with some malt in the nose. Clear copper color. Slight alcohol flavor. Sweet. This isn''t a big beer but it still makes my tongue tingle. Odd English Pale Ale. Nice though. Probably the best beer from PH Woods.

Very light caramel color with no real head. Slight smell of alcohol. I was light in carbonation and medium bodied. Malty a bit of caramel in taste. Not alot of taste in general. A touch bitter...drinkable but, not to write home about.

Golden color with minimal head. Clean, malty flavor and slight aroma. Grainy. Some alcohol apparent. Medium bitterness. Not the best Helles Bock I''ve had but not bad. Would be better with less graininess.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Funnily enough, before I entered this into the database as a spice/herb/vegetable beer, I noted at the brewpub that it seemed to have "vegetable flavors". Dark golden color, creamy with a clinging head. Not a complex concoction.
Gold with short white head.Light malt nose. Light malt flavor with a few finishing hops.Good balance
Smokey blackcurrant aroma and flavour. Chocolate comes though in the end but is too sweet and syrupy to be served at room temp. Unfortunately no-one seems to have a fridge here in Potosi.

Middling brown body, soft head on top. Very vague malt aroma with nothing else coming through. Flavour is a coppery malt, soft sharp hops, sweet mud. An old style craft beer approach, okay carbonation. Works well as a malty brew but also pretty standard.

Pours hazy pale amber with three fingers of rocky white head, excellent retention and heavy, chunky lacing. (4/5) Nose is brett and not much else. (4/10) Taste is moderate sweet, moderate funk, mild bitter. (4/10) Medium body, moderate carbonation, mild bitter and funky finish. (3/5) Utterly dominated by a brett infection. Almost no hops left at all - none in the nose and limited amounts on the tongue. Not a bad drink even in the condition itâ€™s in - almost has a saison character - but thereâ€™s no way itâ€™s supposed to taste like this. And NO DAMN BOTTLE DATE, so no way to know whether this is just a function of it being on a shelf too long. Deeply disappointing, but Iâ€™m gonna have to do what I said Iâ€™d do: if you donâ€™t date your bottle, I assume you meant it to taste this way. Rating this as an E/IPA, itâ€™s a massive fail. (6/20)
Bottle. It's like someone took a dare to make the most jarringly bitter IPA and it accidentally was not terrible. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

My bottle was way over carbonated. He head was twice the size of beer in glass with a carful pour. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel as well as lighter notes of hops. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and citrus hops. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can, very fresh. Pours clear gold with soft head and lace. Aroma is moderate strong hop fruity and earthy, a mix of English and Northwest. Flavor is English earthy lightly bitter and balanced. The feel is alive and chewy. It is a simple but very drinkable and refreshing IPA.
A good steady IPA that can be enjoyed by non IPA drinkers. This beers slightly cloudy, has good aromas and a lasting palate. A good beer to acquire the IPA taste.

My awesome wife always brings me back some treats when she goes home to visit. Poured from a can. A couple of fingers of pillowy white head dies down to a thin film, load of lacing left behind. Nose is sweet malt and a touch of hop. Tastes litely bitter, very sweet malt forward. Very sweet. Nice taste.

Opaque orange with a big rocky off white head that slowly settles. Fresh aroma of citrus floral hops. Moderately bitter citrus floral hop taste backed by mild caramel malts, some spruce and earth. Average carbonation, light-medium body, moderately hopped. Long lightly bitter finish. Nice mild easy drinking IPA. LBW (Lagerboys Be Wary)

Bouteille 660ml, courtoisie dâ€™un contact de Victoria, BC. De couleur ambrÃ©e-dorÃ©e et lÃ©gÃ¨rement voilÃ©e. Nez de houblon citrique (pamplemousse), floral et lÃ©gÃ¨rement herbeux, maltÃ© de caramel sucrÃ© aux notes terreuses avec des notes de butterscotch et de fruits (agrumes sucrÃ©es, traces de pÃªches). Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pÃ©tillement moyen et une texture huileuse. GoÃ»t moyennement amer de houblon floral, citrique (pamplemousse), lÃ©gÃ¨rement terreux et aux petites notes rÃ©sineuses (une amertume qui dure toute la gorgÃ©e) avec un lÃ©ger goÃ»t fruitÃ© sucrÃ© (agrumes sucrÃ©es, petites notes de pÃªches) et Ã©picÃ©es (poivre doux) lors de lâ€™entrÃ©e en bouche auquel se rajoute un goÃ»t maltÃ© de caramel moyennement sucrÃ© avec lÃ©ger de butterscotch et de de miel puis en finale lâ€™on retrouve une amertume de houblon lÃ©gÃ¨rement plus sÃ¨che, plus rÃ©sineuse et aux notes herbeuses. Post-goÃ»t long et lÃ©gÃ¨rement sec, moyennement amer de houblon floral, citrique aux notes rÃ©sineuses et herbeuses avec un lÃ©ger goÃ»t fruitÃ© (zeste dâ€™agrumes). (2006)
650 ml bottle - new label. Pours copper with light head. Aroma of toffee and light citrus hops. Flavors of light toffee, tobacco, light pine and malt. Bitter finish. Good session beer.

Rich, malty aroma combined with huge floral notes. The nose also holds lesser hints of honey and caramel. This beer has a deeply golden hue. Medium-sized white head which is mostly lasting and leaves an excellent lacing. The flavor starts moderately malty, lightly tart and lightly bitter. Interesting hops. The flavor remains lightly tart and lightly bitter on the backside. Perfectly balanced. Medium-bodied with a watery mouthfeel. Lively carbonation. Medium-length, lightly tart and crisp finish. Very good beer. Goes excellently with their wood-fired pizza.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: On tap at Rock Bottom, The Waterfront, Pittsburgh. The ABV is listed as 5.0% on the black board. Black brown color, off white head. Aroma is faint molasses & malt. Flavor is grass, malt, bitter watery coffee.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: On-tap @ Rock Bottom, Pgh, PA. Pours black with thick creamy white head, guinness like. Aroma faint, but of malts. Flavor was of slightly roasted coffee. Some bitterness in the middle, ending with a sweet aftertaste. Mouthfeel was creamy. Full bodied. This had to be a stout, certainly not an ale, but it was good, by far one of the better rock bottom beers.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Pours very black and creamy...think that had it on a nitro. Aroma is soft. Flavor is creamy and a bit chocolately. Definitely not an ale...either a stout or porter. Very reminiscent of a old dominion stout I had on nitro. Mouthfeel was very creamy. Also...the alcohol on the board said 5.2.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Nice black appearance with a full creamy head. Reminiscent of Guiness but with more of a chicory taste. Very nice. Perhaps the best I''ve had from Rock Bottom.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Intresting beer. More like a porter then an Ale. Heavy flavor of Coffeee. Not bad at all...

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: On tap @ 2011 Craft Lager Fest. Clear brilliant gold with a white thin head. Aroma of body odor and light toast. Kinda smells like my dirty hippie friend after he doesnâ€™t shower for a few days (sorry, Josh). Tastes like smoky dry pale malt, bad toast, and stale toffee. A pretty big letdown.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Poured a clear golden-yellow color with a thin white head that faded to a ring. Aroma of of sweet malt, honey, a light spiciness, and a faint grassiness. Smooth, sweet entry with some caramel and honey leads into a spicy, dry yeastiness that lingers into a moderately dry finish where it is paired with a faint grassy hoppiness. Full mouth feel is offset by the dryness on the finish, combining to provide a nice, drinkable beer considering the ABV. Overall, my review really doesnâ€™t do this one justice. There was more going on than I could accurately describe, but it was there. I need to try it again sometime and see if I can do any better.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: On tap at the KoP location and listed as their Goat Toppler Maibock (not Dunkler Bock). 6.5% abv listed on the board. Poured a medium amberish color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of some breadiness, a little earthy, toffeee, and nuts. Tastes of breadiness, lighter earthy, nutty, and caramel.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Tap at KOP location. Pours a mostly translucent golden amber with a medium off white head. Aroma of a handful of Munich malt, nuts, toffee and pretzels. Flavor of the same.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: The folks at my local Rock Bottom in King of Prussia, PA call this a maibock, but I guess a dunkler bock will do. Maibocks used to be one of my favorite styles, before I discovered the joys that are IPAs. This beer pours a brown color with a bit of an orange hue. The head is off-white with good lacing. The nose is full of sweet malts, bread, yeast and earth. The flavors are extremely malty and rich. The finish leaves a smooth, almost creamy-like tone. This bock beer is done very well.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: (on tap at the brewery). Pours a clear yellow color. Sweet malt aroma with light lemon. Sweet malt flavor with light bitterness. Avg duration. Spare lacing. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Draught Colorado Springs Rock Bottom on June 13, 2008. Aroma is a faint malt scent. Color is golden with a touch of orange. Carbonation is good producing a nice head. This brew has a crisp lighter body that goes down with a foamy feel. Taste of malt and bitterness with some hops. After taste has some alcohol tones with a lingering bitterness. Its a nice creamy Bock, but not great.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: (Draft, Rock Bottom, Boston, 8.8% abv version) Pours a lightly hazy copper body with small off-white head. Aroma of nuts, caramel, and light grass. Flavor of sweet maple syrup, light fruit, nuts, and some alcohol.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Draught Colorado Springs Rock Bottom. Pours a deep gold and bronze, clean, foamy and sticky white head, sticky lacing. Aroma is malt (grain, meal, cereal), yeast (sour dough), grassy, and lightly floral hops. Moderately bitter, sour malt and yeast, faint hop character, finish is dry and malty. Full bodied and warm, smooth, dry palate although with some creaminess throughout.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: The Rock Bottom set of reviews is a reflection of my hasty attempt to drink a small quantity of many beers and produce accurate and helpful reviews. Clearly Iâ€™ve failed, but I hope my incoherent and cryptic critiques can help at least a few folks who wander in and want to know what to order. Before the look, nose and taste can even be considered, I have to laud the folks at Rock Bottom for a great name. Even if the Goat Toppler tastes like a Turkish bath house, I could spend hours daydreaming of clumsy, inebriated goats, which is better entertainment than any show on television. The raging booziness of the Goat Toppler glows a semi-cloudy blend of oranges and reds, and reeks of hard liquor like a flavored Bacardi rum. Thankfully the taste is nothing like the smell, showing off a prominent banana flavor with a lace of green apples. Sadly, the high alcohol content cloys an otherwise skillfully concocted brew. At least the name is immutably cool.

Pours gold from the bottle. Frothy white head. Aroma is grains, straw, honey. Taste is mildly sweet, buttery, with just a faint bite at the end, hardly noticeable against a crisp but watery palate. Overall, kind of drab but not offensive.

500ml bottle into shaker. Pours golden amber with a frothy white head. Nose is subdued with notes of metal and malt. Full-bodied and malty. Finish is more malt followed by tin and some grain. Pretty average but drinkable.
50cl swing top bottle. A clear pale golden beer with a mid-sized most good lasting white head. Aroma of spicy hops, pale malt, straw. Taste of straw, pale malt, spicy hops, hints of metallic hops.

Swing top bottle (500ml) from Dan Murphyâ€™s with BB 3/2/18. Clear bright golden appearance, average white head. Nose has honeyish malt grains with grassy and peppery hops. Palate is light-medium bodied and easy drinking with flavours reflecting the nose. Decent grassy/herbal dry hop bitterness. Appears to have survived the long trip from Germany quite well.

Bottle. Pale gold with a white head. Aroma of hay, light biscuit, herbal and grassy hops. Pretty watery for 4.8% - really lacks presence. Tastes as it smells - light, pleasant clean malt, herbal and grassy hops, moderate bitterness. Pleasant, quite refined hops - just a lacks a bit of guts.

Seltsam geformte 0,5l BÃ¼gelflasche. Hellgelbes klares Bier, weisser Schaum. Frisches Aroma. Etwas Honig und Getreide. Zitroniger Antrunk. Gras und Hopfen. Nach einem heissen Sommertag eiskalt nicht schlecht. Zitronenschale auch im Abgang. Hat was von einem Kristallweizen.
Helles Pils mit mÃ¤chtig viel Schaum. Leicht metallisch, wÃ¤ssrig, aber angenehm aromatisch im Geschmack. Mittlere Bitterkeit mit angenehmen Abgang.

Bottle in Stuttgart. Extreme head, unlike other reviewers experienced, that last though the 4 minute drink time. Light duty Pils type bier with low hops. Not much aroma but great finish. I'll have another please. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Golden colour with a medium head. Grass and dough aromas.Grass and malty with medium sweetness. Medium body. Average
This is a great Bavarian beer. Pretty low in hops but a great mild taste especially in the summer time!
Pours yellowish with white head. Smell is hops and grassy grain. Pretty crisp and refreshing bitterness and a solid pilsner.

On tap at the brewpub pours a pale golden color with a small white head that leaves some spotted lacing on the glass. Mild aroma of citrus. Taste is citrus and grass bitterness with a grainy malt sweetness underneath. Light bodied with lots of carbonation. A decent pilsner which is worthy of a sample.
The "fresh hops" brewing process makes the aroma and taste of this beer a real treat to the palate. It presents a light, fresh florel taste thatâ€™s very enjoyable to savor and swallow.

Name: Pilsner Date: September 06, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear yellow, fine white head, lots of lace Aroma: sweet malt aroma, light spicy hops Flavor: sweet malt flavor, touch of cereal sweetness, light spicyness Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 9/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: ** /4

Nice amber colour, but no aroma at first. Even well down into the glass, I could not detect any sort of nose. Taste was also somewhat strange at first - maybe a bit "green"? It got better towards the end. I do prefer this on tap versus bottled.
One of my least favourite Big River brews. Much too watery, and though malty, really indistinctive. Boring and watery.

Bottle... Clear yellow lager with a small, flimsy, white head. The nose is of warm mash, peppery hops and pale malt with a touch of acetaldehyde. Light to medium-bodied with fizzy carbonation. The pale grain and honey flavor leans slightly toward the sweet side of balance. Finishes crisp and thin.

On draught at the Big River Brewpub south of Vancouver, BC. Pours a clear golden straw brew with a fast dissolving white head that leaves behind some spotty lacing. Aroma of crystal grain malt, some grassy hops a touch of apple and very light citrus. Taste is light bodied, some biscuit malt flavor with a hint of grassy hops and apple. Finish is slightly sweet at first and then a dry light bitterness in the aftertaste.
Draught at the brewpub Blond color. Light malt aroma, and quite good malt flavor, unexpected; dryish mouthfeel. Correct bitterness. Pleasant.

A good, hoppy pilsner. Pilsners are uncommon in Vancouver brewpubs so kudos for the effort! Wish more local brewpubs would make lagers and pilsners, as we are really sick of boring Pales and Nut Browns.

On tap at the Alibi Room, pours a hazy copper with a medium beige head. Aroma brings out smooth toffee, light English hops, and biscuity notes. Flavour brings out a mix of toffee, vegetal notes, and biting English hops. Dry, someway spicy and lightly astringent on the finish. Smooth and highly drinkable, despite the smidgeon of vegetal notes. Good stuff.
On Tap. Pours a bronze color with little head. Light aromas of toasted malts, and maybe a bit of caramel. Flavors of malts and quite a bit of UK hop pellets. OK.
Pretty solid overall and leaning hoppy for the style. Nice amber color and bitterness. Enjoyable.

A couple of samples at VCBW 2012 pours a light brown color with a small white head that leaves some nice thin lacing. Aroma is light floral hops and mild caramel. Taste is a pleasant hop bitterness with a caramel malty sweetness. Light to medium body with good carbonation leaving a nice tickle on the tongue. Overall, an enjoyable bitter with a nice balance of flavors.

Draught at Big River Brewpub. Pours dark amber with medium off white head. Sweet and roasted notes in aroma. Medium bodied. Hop flavour leading to lasting bitterness. A little disappointed. I had wanted to like this beer more than I did.

Name: Extra Special Bitter Date: September 06, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear copper, fine dirty white head, sheets of lace Aroma: sweet malt aroma, nice woodsy and earthy hop aroma, touch of citrus Flavor: sweet caramel malt flavor, lots if earthyness for balance, light bitter finish, touch of husky astrengency Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4
Always tastes like more sometimes too many more)! Goes well with most any food (well, at least any pub food at the Big River)and also by itself.

On draught at the Big River Brewpub south of Vancouver, BC. Pours a clear copper amber brew with a creamy white head that has a nice retention and spotty lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, some dry grassy hops and a hint of toffee. Taste is medium bodied, some carbonation with flavors of dry caramel malt, some roasted nuts and mild grassy hops. Finish is slightly dry with a mild bitter aftertaste that quickly disappears.

Draught at the brewpub Amber color, creamy head. The aroma has quite good hops, fruity, mild. Good toffee flavor, medium body structure, strong hopping, well aromatic, oily, a bit fruity and resiny too. Long final, in which the nutty bitterness rises. Finally, a beer in this pub showing some good hops.

Excellent, one of the best brews from Big River. Tried this one at a beer festival and would like to visit the pub and have one there. I will update my notes when I do. At the festival I wrote down that the Big River ESB is strong in both malt and hop arenas, thus creating a lovely taste sensation that is balanced through and through. Iâ€™d like for more local brewpubs to make good ESB.

column1: Big River Sawmill Alley Brown Ale (formerly: Nutbrown)
column5: Nice toasty nutty flavor. Pors brown with beige head. I liked it but nothing too unique. Solid brown ale with a bit more hops than expected.

column1: Big River Sawmill Alley Brown Ale (formerly: Nutbrown)
column5: A couple of samples at VCBW 2012 pours a pale amber brown color with a small white head that leaves some thin spotty lacing. Mild caramel malty aroma with some nuttiness. Taste is light toasted malty sweetness with a moderate hoppy bitterness. Light to medium body with generous carbonation leaving a pleasant sensation on the palate. A decent brown ale, but certainly not one of the best.

column1: Big River Sawmill Alley Brown Ale (formerly: Nutbrown)
column5: Draught at Big River Brewpub. Pours coppery brown with off white head. Faint aroma. Light bodied and watery. Some sweetness and nutty notes. Less distinctive than I had been led to believe.

column1: Big River Sawmill Alley Brown Ale (formerly: Nutbrown)
column5: Name: Nut Brown Ale Date: September 06, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear copper, fine off white head, drippy lace Aroma: light sweet caramel and chocolate aroma, nice nutty character Flavor: sweet malt flavor, light caramel sweetness, touch of chocolate Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4

column1: Big River Sawmill Alley Brown Ale (formerly: Nutbrown)
column5: On draught at the Big River Brewpub south of Vancouver, BC. Pours adark copper brown brew with a creamy beige head that slowly dissipates to a thin off-white ring and some spotty lacing. Aroma of roasted caramel malt, some roasted nuts, a hint of flowery hops and toffee. Taste is medium bodied, with flavors of roasted munich malt, a hint of toffee and roasted nuts. Finish is light in flavor with a crisp finish with hardly no aftertaste.

column1: Big River Sawmill Alley Brown Ale (formerly: Nutbrown)
column5: Draught at the brewpub Dark mahogany color; creamy head. It has mild notes of roasted malt, not too invasive, nutty, with low bitterness. Easy but not bad.

column1: Big River Sawmill Alley Brown Ale (formerly: Nutbrown)
column5: Also had the vanilla/honey cask version of this. All told the many flavours confused the palate, with the sweetness of the honey battling the slightly burnt vanilla for dominance.

column1: Big River Sawmill Alley Brown Ale (formerly: Nutbrown)
column5: Had this in a cask, primed with Honey and Vanilla. Very dark brown, with a molasses nose and the very faintest touch of a head. The vanilla was very overbearing. I found this beer too sweet in general - maybe it was just the cask.

column1: Big River Sawmill Alley Brown Ale (formerly: Nutbrown)
column5: Tried at a beer festival. I believe my notes reflect that because my ratings are much lower than for those who have tried the brew at the brewpub. I should mention also that generally this is not my favorite style. A thin and disappointing texture with a correspondingly light to medium body. Alright. It is fresh beer.

column1: Big River Sawmill Alley Brown Ale (formerly: Nutbrown)
column5: (Draught) Sampled on November 23rd, 2006 at the brewpub. Thin white head with a red-brown body. Nutty roasted malt nose. Toasted flavour has an almost sugarless cocoa powder and marzipan undertone. Nice complex and easy to drink!

column1: Big River Fur Trader Pale Ale
column5: On tap at Big River, pours a hazy amber / copper with a small beige head. Aroma brings out English malt, light spice, and bready notes. Flavour is very malty and somewhat sweet for a pale ale, with bready notes and sweet caramel malt. Not cloying, but not exactly a refined example of an English pale ale. Passable but not too thrilling.

column1: Big River Fur Trader Pale Ale
column5: Orangish color. Smell is hoppy and mild. Taste is your standard pale ale hopped flavor with nothing too crazy. Decent beer but not my favorite of theirs

column1: Big River Fur Trader Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub pours a bright golden color with a finger of white head that leaves some decent lacing on the glass. Aroma is light citrus with some hints of caramel. Taste is a citrus hop bitterness nicely balanced with a caramel malty finish. Light bodied with adequate carbonation. A nicely done pale ale that is worthy of sampling.

column1: Big River Fur Trader Pale Ale
column5: Draught at Big River Brewpub. Pours clear light golden with fast dissipating white head. Faint aroma, sweet and malty. Light bodied. Lingering bitter aftertaste.

column1: Big River Fur Trader Pale Ale
column5: Date: September 06, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear light gold, fine off white head Aroma: light sweet malt aroma, light citrus hops Flavor: sweet malt flavor, combo of crystal and caramel malts, light hop flavor, touch of fruity character, just enough bitterness for balance, light bitter finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: ** /4

column1: Big River Fur Trader Pale Ale
column5: A nice (average) pale ale, and I prefer this one from the bottle to the times Iâ€™ve had it on tap. Serving it a bit "youngâ€™, maybe? However, it poured well, nice colour and nose, with an acceptable taste.

column1: Big River Fur Trader Pale Ale
column5: On draught at the Big River Brewpub south of Vancouver, BC. Pours a clear golden amber brew with a creamy white head that quickly dissipates and leaves behind a white ring and some spotty lacing. Aroma of golden grain malt, some light fruit, a hint of grassy hops and some egg white? Taste is medium bodied, some carbonation with flavors of golden grain malt, some grassy hops and a touch of citrus. Finish is slightly metallic with more malt aftertaste flavor than the ESB but not as bitter.

column1: Big River Fur Trader Pale Ale
column5: Draught at the brewpub Deep blond color, creamy head. Light malt aroma. Some malt flavor, sweetish, turning into a deeper bitterness, nutty. Drinkable, a step beyond the Blond Ale.

column1: Big River Fur Trader Pale Ale
column5: (Draught) Sampled on November 23rd, 2006 at the brewpub. I liked this the least of the bunch I tried - it hardly tasted like a Pale Ale. Pours a foamy, medium white head and a low carbonated orange body. Nose is highly caramel malted with undertones of butterscotch. Astringent, bitter hops donâ€™t meld well with the strong English malt. Was more like an Amber Ale to me.

column1: Big River Fur Trader Pale Ale
column5: Copper coloured beer. Light caramel nose, slightly earthy nose. Slightly musty flavour, a bit earthy but also a touch phenolic. Light fruitiness. Lingering bitterness. A decent effort.
This is by far one of my favorite Rogue beers. Iâ€™ve drank it for many beer over many occasions and I will continue to drink it till the Day I die. And Kaite likes it too,

Bottle at home from backlog notes. Pours a hazy light golden color with a medium sized white head. The aroma and flavor have pale wheat malts, light spices, orange citrus, not much going on with this.
"not bad at all, but itâ€™s a textbook american wheat - ie average. refreshing enough as a summer seasonal. you can taste the wheat, otherwise it was avoidable."

Brilliant, frog emblazoned 650ml bottle from New Beer Distributors, NYC, split with Octo in Barbados on Xmas Eve. Unpromising, soupy pour completely opaque orange with a fleeting attempt at a head. English BC gone wrong aroma; strange, badly behaved yeast, slight pig pen, strawberry and cream Campinos, Twiglets. Tang of sour suggesting things arenâ€™t quite right; rhubarby, redcurranty notes, earthiness, mildew.. stirred with a Twiglet. The dominant note is vomit if Iâ€™m honest. Sloppy to flat condition. Dab of warm hinting at alcohol but who knows? 6%? Gutted. One of the poorest US micros Iâ€™ve had.
Pours a cloudy golden color with small floaties and almost no head. Boring aroma of honey and wheat. Boring flavor of honey, weat and mild hops. I fail too see any interest in this beer.

Pretty standard wheat ale. Had some on tap at Rattle n Hum. Poured a hazy orange with a slight, white head. Aroma of wheat and some citrus. Mild flavor of wheat, lemon, and some yeast. Light-bodied with nice carbonation, this beer is somewhat refreshing but not terribly complex. Decent.

Draft at RnH. Pours a bright hazy orange body with small white head that vanishes quickly, not much lacing. Aroma is sweet candy wheat. The mouthfeel is "tight" carbonation. Sweet flavor is coupled with refreshing wheat, lemon, and maybe some other citrus fruit. A decent session beer.

Location: 22 oz bottle from State Line, 9/21/09 Aroma: Light lemon, a good bit of yeast/bread/grain, light and wheaty Appearance: Hazy golden-orange, thin white head Flavor: Fairly light grainy malt flavor with a short duration Palate: Overly fizzy mouthfeel with a long fizz duration, light-medium body Overall Impression: This beer is decent, but the over-carbonation seems to work against it in my opinion. I really felt that took away from it as it overwhelmed the flavor. Not much of a brew, I gotta say it was just a little dull. Not a typical wheat either. Eh...

Thin head of varying sized bubbles. Moderate carbonation. Light grassy and lemony aroma with some cereal grains and light spice. Color is a light orange. Dry palate with lots of grainy wheat, rice krispies, citrus and some corriander spicyness. Finishes dry and clean. A good easy drinking summertime brew.

22 oz. bottle. pours a thin white head over a cloudy, golden (SRM 8) body....nose is primarily malty with cereal, hay, bit of clove.....taste is very malt forward, with cereal (grapenuts), cardboard dominating, bit of citrus and mild hop bitterness on the finish...mouth feel is light as is carbonation. A fairly typical "American" wheat, which means lacking the spice of a Hefeweizen.

Draught at the brewpub in Brea, California. Clear copper beer with a decent offwhite head. Hoppy caramel aroma, metal notes, floral, some bread. Hoppy berries flavor, caramel, grapes, bready, some roasted notes. Ok.
Earthy dry red Amber ale. Some medium malts some minimal hops very very dry. Ok drinker but not much too it.

Pour on tap at the brewery, clear reddish pour with slightly off white head, aroma brought notes of caramel, toffee, biscuit, bread into a bit of spice, slight earth, slight grassy notes, pretty standard. Taste was a mix of grass, bread, slight caramel, hints of grain into a bit of spice, slight yeasty note, finishing slightly sweet.
Amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is berries, malt, yeast. Flavour is berries, malt, yeast, butter, caramel. Medium body. Boring beer.

[ As Taps Irish Red ]. Clear medium amber orange color with a average, frothy to fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, toffee - fudge. Flavour is moderate sweet and light acidic with a average to long duration, tart, fudge - caramel, fruity. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20140516]

Pours slightly hazy dark amber with small off-white head. Faint aroma of yeast and fruit, with hefty touches of diacethylene. Sour flavour of rotten malt, beautifully enhanced by diacethylene bombs, deafening all other nuances (if they are there at all). Sour aftertaste. Out of balance. Filth!
Clear amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, caramel and butter. Flavour is malt, caramel, butter, toasted, medium sweet and a little bitter.
Decent red ale, on tap at fathers office in santa monica, very light and easy to rink, not bad
Tap at the Brea location. Clear orange amber pour. Spotty white head. Dusty caramel malt. Light yet syrupy palate. Okay.

Draught @ Taps Fish House and Brewery, Brea, CA Pours clear amber/brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, floral, bread and hint of chocolate. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long malty, caramel and bread finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

08-Oct-12 (12-oz sample bottle with a competition label only: Obtained 02-May-12 for stewarding the 2012 World Beer Cup in San Diego, CA) There's nothing like a nice, crisp Pilsener, and this beer hits the spot. It pours a hazy, straw-colored body capped by a creamy, white head that settles to a quarter-inch blanket and hold there for the duration. The nose is mostly hoppy, offering a generally vegetal aroma of cut grass, but also a bit of graininess from the malt. The palate is similar, with minimally sweet, grainy and cereal malt flavors backed by gently bitter, grassy hops. The grassiness lingers quite awhile, but modest toastiness emerges late. There's a hint of medicine and metal far in the background that's mostly noticeable only after a burp. Light in body, dry, medium in carbonation, generally refreshing and easy drinking. Overall, not especially noteworthy as Pilseners go, but still pleasant and enjoyable.
brilliant, smells of floral hops and a touch of sweet malt. Taste is crisp and nice bitterness. The taste of the floral hops is even more noticeable with a touch of citrus.

Tap at Library Alehouse. Pours clear gold with a medium, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is straw, hay and meal malt with spicy hops. Flavor is medium hops and bitterness, malt and a clean lager character with a dry finish. Light body and warmth with medium carbonation.

A: The pour is a clear golden straw color with a couple of fingers of white head. S: Not a terribly fragrant beer. Mild malt aroma with some hints of bread. Floral and citrus hops start to come through a little bit as I stick my nose almost in the beer. Perhaps some fruit esters? T: Not a terribly traditional flavor. Quite a hoppy beer for a Czech style pils, and some definite citrus notes in addition to the floral ones. Sweet pale malts and a hint of corn. Yeast is present and there is a mild bitterness on the back end. M: Light to medium in body with a moderate level of carbonation. O: A fairly good beer, but not exactly what I was expecting to get from this one.

Growler. Rating #5. Medium gold with a nice white head. Nice floral hop aroma, crisp malts. Medium bitterness with a nice malt backbone, hard to describe really, just a really outstanding brew. (1381)
Golden in color, regular lager as lagers go. Taps does a good job with every beer though. This is stronger than most lagers out there.

Pours a gold color with a medium head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is like a lager should be...sweetly pleasant and dry. The taste is perfectly balanced between the malt flavors and the interesting hop notes...I tasted some light citrus notes. The body is what you would expect from the style...a little thin bodied for me.
Yellow color with medium sized head. Flavors were mellow, sweet and malty. Although I usually don't care for pilseners, Victor seems to know his shit. Props.

The best of this trip to Taps. Straw colored brew with a creamy white head. Big floral hop nose which surprised me.First sip revealed a nicely balanced brew with some citrusy notes but a clean saaz hop finish. Very surprised by this one cause I usually dont like the style.
On tap at brewery. Clear golden with a creamy white head. Orange, fruit, and floral aroma and taste with a crisp citrus finish.

On tap poured a hazy golden/orange color with a nice almost white head. The aroma had some fruitiness from the yeast and a nice hoppy nose with a toch of caramel. Taste was full of hop flavor that balanced nicely with the caramel malts. Very well balanced and maybe the best example of the style that I have ever had.
Had it on cask at TAPS. Was not overwhelmingly hoppy at all. Evident malty presence. Aroma was floral-hops and light malt. Flavor was a little bland for my liking and not too complex
Nice and hoppy aroma but not too over the top good balance with malt. Nice clear color and very good maly flavor for the ESB type. A hair thin on the palate but good clean bitter finish
This one was nice and hoppy but still mild and subdued at the same time. Lots of flowery hops. Very well balanced Decent Palate
Nice orange blossom nose with a slightly sweet up front flavor are what this clear amber colored beer greet you with. It finishes finishes dry.
Floral nose coming from this amber brew. Some hop bite up front with a bitter caramel finish.
Sample. Rating #7. Nice dark brown color. Nice beer, rich and malty with some dark fruits. Very enjoyable. (2458)

On tap. Pours with a slightly hazed amber brown body (odd), with a large and lasting tan head. Aromas are lightly leathery, even some smoke (odd again), dark fruits, raisins, dry nuts, malty, bready, munich and some light melanoidins. Flavors are malty, bready, raisiny, caramelized. Dark fruits. Medium bitter balances. Medium bubbles, dry, light smoke note in the finish.

The pour is copper in color with a creamy off-white head. Â Not too much of an aroma to this one. Â Itâ€™s sweet with caramel and toffee, maybe a little bit of toasted malt. Â The sweet caramel is a bit creamy, which is nice. Â Some toasted bread and toffee. Â Sort of one dimensional, but good.

On tap at Taps. Color was dark, reddish brown. Aroma of dark fruit, banana, sweet malt and must. Flavor was a bit strange. Only a slight sweetness. Flavor of earthy, caramel, and fruit. Some sweet malt and toffee.

Tasted at brewery. Mohogany color; nice, lasting head. Aroma and taste of rich, sweet, full body with roasted malts, molassas, caramel, toffee, spices. I was told 7.6%. Decent but more sweet than complex like a Salvator.
(Draft) Pours a medium brown body. Aroma of malt and caramel. Flavor of sweet malts, toffee, and spices.

I was looking forward to this one and I have to say I''m a little disappointed.Dark brown pour. Flavor is a sweet and malty with some kind of spicy (clove/nutmeg) notes. The abv is well hidden and there is a slight hop bite near the finish.
Draught. Slightly hazy gold with white head. Aroma is faint malt and citrus, taste is same. Nothing to get excited about.

Wonderland Ballroom, DC tap ($6): This was advertised as a unfiltered, unpastuerized lager when I was there, but I guess this is an ale. It makes sense looking in retrospect. Pours a copper color with an ok sized head. Citrus hops and light malts. Taste is pretty much the same. A session ale without very much offensive things in there. But, this was and is utterly forgettable.
Draft at Greenleafe tavern. Dark straw color with nose of slight fruit, hopcitrus, and pale malt. Tastes as it smells, with some malt flavor matched by mild hopcitrus and fruity notes.

On draft at the Taphouse-Hampton under the "Pops Golden Hammer" moniker. Very dark yellow/maize color with a thin but gluey head. Light aroma which is hard to distinguish, maybe a lilâ€™ bit oâ€™ malt, but also an almost appley sense. Into the drink this is a very even-keeled malt beer, well made with no offending characteristics. (#2742, 3/10/2007)

On tap at the brewpub, RBSG 2006. An orange beer with no head - from the looks of it - my guess would be a Pale ale not an Amber. The aroma is sweet malty with light hoppy notes. The flavor is sweet hoppy with notes of caramel. An OK beer - but nothing special about it.
On tap at the brewpub, RBSG 2006. Clear gold with almost no head. A pretty standard, blah amber. Meh. Decent maltiness, short on hops.
Draft - This ale was way too creamy for me. Could probably have used more hops to add bitterness. Sweet fruity ale - bummer.
Keg at the Old Dominion Brewing Company, Ashburn, VA. hazy light orange colour with a large white head. Dry, fruity, citrusy, spicey, but needs more hops. Light bodied. OK.
Tap at Clydes in Washington DC. The style name says it all. Itâ€™s an ale. Golden color, light hop nose. A very light taste to it. Dry finish. A good beer but nothing uber special
Hazy orange colour. Quite dry and malty, but I found it a bit short on hop presence. Crisp, dry finish. Pleasant enough. On tap at the Dominion brewery.
Bottle 33 cl. Light golden, clear with a shortlived white head. Aroma of malt and straw. Bitter taste with a not so good malt end.
Pale yellow colour with a white head. Light malty sweet aroma with a fresh touch. Bland malty flavor with soapy notes.
Bottled(330ml). -transparent pale yellow piss coloured, like some carbonated water without taste, same as Efes Light
actually i only taste it once with on glass.Like a water no taste no bitterness.But usually light beers are like that.

Sitting in a splendid hotel with a view over the Dardenelles to Gallipolli. Just back from walking on the walls of Troy at Sun-set - a truly awesome and emotional experience. The beer is better than Efes Light. This is cleaner, crisper and less chemical tasting - though it does have the tang of water scooped from a swimming pool.
Bottled(330ml). -brown with minimal head, light caramel aroma, yeasty, like some slovenian brew pub beer
Why does a dark beer come in a clear bottle? Dont know if this beer have had to much sun, but this was a very thin beer. No aroma, very little taste and a thin palate.
The second dark lager beer in Turkey.You can only find it several markets maybe in big markets like Migros or Tansas.Have a sempatic glass.Reddish colour,not very creamy.Straight taste.

Clear glass bottle with the Trojan horse logo and the name of the beer embossed on the glass. The colour is a smokey amber, like a scarlet tinged tea - quite attractive. Aroma is a mix of faint smokey malt and CO2. Mouthfeel is thin to light medium with some light but harsh carbonation. Taste is of cold stewed weak tea and a vague medicine. Not great. In fact, fairly poor. Troy is not seen around as much as the main Tuborg brands, while Tuborg, although seen in every town, can't compete with the overwhelming popularity (and better quality) of Efes.
Brown coloured. Awful skunky smell of rotten meat and fish. Thin and watery. Very bad.
Decent dark lager beer. copper in color pours in with a white head. Light malty aroma present with a slight bitter finish. refreshing.

This is a superb example for a nice Hefeweizen. So far the best I found from an Austrian brewer. Vanilla, cloves and banana, just the way this style should come with. Good carbonation, solid head. Nice bright amber color. Perfect!
perfect wheat beer, full body, harmony to the bitterness, not to little in hops, but typically for the style interessting fruit flavour not only bananas like all thr rest

330ml bottle (Stockmann, Tallinn) 5+ without yeast, just a few spikes of bananaey esters. With all the yeast, itâ€™s mellowed, but less interesting, and in fact rather dull. 3 You could pour this clear if you wanted to, but if you swirl the bottle, you get a hazy pale orange with quite a bit of sinky chunks, a bit off-puting. 5+ Fairly dull weizen taste. Pre-swirling, it was prety OK estery krystalweizen. After adding the yeast, itâ€™s breadier, and the banana is again more rounded and mellowed. do prefer the latter. 3 Crisp carbonation, a refreshin g but full palate. Finish quite bready, and with an OK bitter bite, but thereâ€™s no fullness to the hops, no aromaticity. But even the biteâ€™s better than nothing. 11 Sounds worse than it was. It was pretty acceptable, but lacking the wow a good hefe can bring.
Fruity. Sweet. Delicious. Excellent! (This beer rating was imported from FB and unfortunately lacks any further comments.)
330ml Bottle - Hazy amber with a foamy head. Banana,yeast and spice in the aroma. Tangy taste with notes of banana,lemon and cloves.
Bottle. Hazy golden body with huge foam. Yeasty aroma. Taste is quite sweet and fruity. After some hoppy tones. Refreshing

Cloudy yellow/orange body. Fine head. Yeasty aroma with some cloves. Rather dry taste. There is some light nuttiness in the finish which is unusual for the style. Nice change from the typical banana/bubblegum hefeweizens.

gold medal straight away at the DLG, the hardest beer test in the world. distinct fruity aroma, particularly bananas and melons. smoothness, achieved through the higher original gravity and the lower carbon dioxide content. multiple and elaborate brew method guarantees rich consistency.
14th December 2007 Draughft in Salzburg, Austria. Very dry and frothy. A lively minerally start leads to a bitter bubblegum. Interesting!

Bottled(500ml). -Weizen by the book. Cloudy dark orange coloured, typical big head for this style, banana nose. Banana is dominant here. Pleasant wheaty and spicy with acidic lemony finish.Very refreshing. My third Trumer and by far the best.
From backlog. On draft at JT Schmids, Anaheim, Ca. Cloudy yellow/Golden with white head. Malts, hops, Wheat, banana and spices.
Lemon wedge takes up a quarter of the sample glass. Cloudy and dark. Lemony. Tastes like citrus juice. Can almost taste the pulp. Nice-ish, but a Hefe?
Tap at the Tustin venue. Pours murky gold with a creamy white head. Clove aroma. Med body or nearly. Flavor is clove, wheat and something fruit that is nice and might be banana. Nice drink.

25 June 2014, tap at JT Schmids. Light, sickly yellow, hazy. Nose is coriander and some faint banana. Med/thin body and mildly fizzy. Slightly tart, banana, some coriander, lemon juice, sweet overall. Ok. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at the brewpub. Hefeweizen. Pours a full haze light golden, great sheets of white lacing. Mild estery nose with light pear. Taste is a bit papery, sharper grain husky. Newspaper like palate. A bit harsh around the edges. Thinner body for style.

On tap at the brewpub. Itâ€™s an unclear, yellow brew topped by a small, white head.
