Irgendwie schmeckt das Ganze ziemlich unausgewogen-komisch. --> Ein ziemlich sÃ¼ffig-wÃ¤ssriges Weizen, dem an KÃ¶rper im Hauptteil fehlt. Und der herb-komische Nachgeschmack ist auch nicht so unbedingt meins. Trotzdem mal interessant zu probieren! (Test vom 12.5.2008) --> 12,9,12,8,12,9 - 9,75

Tap @ brewpub 30/01/13. Pours a dark orangey yellow with a large, off-white head. Aroma is banana and light orange with a touch of cloves. Taste is dry, quite sour with a lot of wheat and cloves, a bit light though.. Palate is light, even a bit watery. Perhaps a bit too much carbonation.
On tap at the brewery. Golden color, slightly hay- good foam. Good fruity aromas, nice yeast- mild banana aromas. Medium body & complexity. Some sweetness, good balance Very enjoyable

BÃ¼gelverschluÃŸflasche: Cloudy, deep golden coloured, average, but stable off-white head, a pretty solid amount of ripe bananas in the wheaty-grainy - sweet and tart - nose; light to moderate sweetish-sourish flavour, light to medium bodied; slightly lingering sweetish-wheaty and sourish finish with the usual tartness in the aftertaste. More than an average Weizen....
bottle with thanks to pivnizub! Cloudy pale golden colour, large and creamy white head. Whetay and yeasty with an intensive touch of ripe banana. Very nice one.
Amber-bronze color. Aroma: plum, fruit, malt, wine. Taste: malt, wine, sweet, esters, warming, dry fruits.

Dark brown color with creamy, light brown head. Aroma is a bit acidic and roasty. Taste has dark sugar and caramel. Finishes bitter and roasty. Heavy bodied with smooth carbonation. Overall this was a nice, heavy and creamy bock, quite different from other beers of the style.
Dunkel orange braunes Bier mit einer mittelgroÃŸen weiÃŸen Schaumkrone. Geruch rÃ¶stmalzig, Karamell, leicht schokoladig. Geschmack schokoladig, rÃ¶stmalzig, Karamell, leicht alkoholisch.
bottle from McTapps - thanks! Brown with a mid-sized beige head. Malty start, some dried fruit and chocolate. Lingering finish of vanilla and dates.
Ein angenehmer Bock mit dem bisschen an Vanille und Spritzigkeit, die mir ganz gut gefallen. Recht einfach zu trinken, mild im Abgang, stellenweise erfrischend und sueffig. Alles ok also.

Flasche von Bier-Hannes GetrÃ¤nkeabholmarkt in Frankfurt, gekauft als "Krolle-Bock". Das Bier hat eine tief dunkelbraune Farbei mit einem geringen Schaum und einem geschmeidigen KÃ¶rper. Aroma von Hopfen, Gerste und milden FrÃ¼chten. Geschmacklich definitiv sehr lecker mit mildem Hopfen, weicher Gerste, Blumen, Stroh, Brot und milden und sÃ¼ÃŸen FrÃ¼chten. Blumig-seifiger Abgang. Lecker.

Rated as Krolle-Bock: Der naturtrÃ¼be dunkle Bock vom Bier-Hannes riecht sehr schÃ¶n malzig-wÃ¼rzig. Der Antrunk ist vollmundig-sÃ¼ÃŸlich und angenehm malzig. Zum Hauptteil kommt ganz leicht dieser muffige Ton auf, der mir bei dem Fassenachtsbier so missfallen ist. Hier passt er aber ziemlich gut hin. Er unterstÃ¼tzt diesen muffig-erdigen Grundton. Hinzu kommt eine hefig-milde Note, zusammen mit ganz leicht rÃ¶stmalzigen AnklÃ¤ngen. Der Nachgeschmack ist lang und hat schon einen rauchigen Touch, wie als wenn Rauchmalz im Spiel ist. Toll (rÃ¶st-)malzig-trocken, erdig. Altes, modriges Laub. Torf. Nur ganz leicht alkoholisch, aber nicht stÃ¶rend. --> Ein klasse erdig-rauchiger Bock. Vollmundig-wÃ¼rzig. Bestimmt nicht jedermanns Sache, aber so stell ich mir einen tollen dunklen (Herbst)bock vor! (Test vom 14.11.2008) --> 12,15,13,15,13,15 - 14,30

Trocken malziger Antrunk mit geradlinig verlaufendem Aroma. Eine leichte Getreidenote und eine ebenso leichte Muffigkeit treten ab dem Mittelteil im Hintergrund auf, das Malz bleibt trocken, wird aber durch eine leicht sÃ¼ÃŸe Note etwas aufgelockert. Fast unbemerkt wird das Malz durch eine auftretende Karamellnote krÃ¤ftiger, wirkt aber weiterhin eher zahm. Passend hefig werdend, so langsam beginnt der Alkohol zu wirken und eine leichte WÃ¤rme zu verbreiten. Hierzu passt auch die herbe Schokolasigkeit im Nachgeschmack. Gelungen! Test vom 28.12.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 13,12,12,12,11,12 - 12,05

courtesy of fiulijn, labelled Krolle-Bock - cloudy dark amber-orange colour with a little foam left; aroma of toffee and cider; a solid carbonation and malt body, a fair sweetness and a long aftertaste of oranges, yeast and caramel

Pours slightly hazy deep amber with thick creamy tanned head leaving nice lacing. Sweet aroma of fruits, malts, caramel, bread. Crispy sweet mouthfeel. Flavor of fruity sweetness, hops, malts, alcohol. Very tasty and drinkable, well carbonated. Lean acidy sweet palate. Finishes with great tart bitter hoppy bite.

500ml bottle at home on 19 June 2011. Vintage bottle, best before November 2005. Lively pour. Dark red colour. Off-white head. Plenty of condition. Fruity and a bit oxidised on the nose. Clean enough on the palate. More berry fruit. A little vinous. Hasnâ€™t been too damaged by age - made it more interesting if anything.

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium to dark brown colour with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, light beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, oxidide, light roasted. Flavour is moderate to light light heavy sweet with a average to long duration, chocolate malt, dark malt. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20110619]
Bottled. Amber colour, small off-white head. Aroma is caramel, some toffee, mild oxidized. Flavour is caramel, toffee, some sweet maltyness as well as some mild syrupy notes.

Deep brown with a big head, almost belgian...tall, thick frothy with a light brown colour. Very nice and inviting aroma of cigar, dark deep malt, chocoalte with a touch of smoke. Big malty flavour of toffee, figs, butter and smoke. Long, smooth, malty aftertaste of toffee and smoke. Very nice Winter Warmer!
Very good dark, ruby and red beer with a head to desire. The aroma is light and malty with a strong alcohol and bitter flavour. Overall a good strong beer.
Bottled. Chestnut brown. Sweet and clean. Mild and syrupy, warming but bold with very low hop rate, but some herbal, medicinal bitterness.

Bottle Conditioned. Deep ruby red, low head and moderate condition. Roasted malt aroma with hints of smoke that become more obvious in the mouth. Stays malty in the finish but with a bitterness developing.
Dark with hints of red. This is a fruity, juicy malty beer with burn''t toffee with warming alcohol. The Xmas pudding like complexity make this a good Winter brew.
Cask at the Grainstore Brewery, Oakham in 2016. Clear, deep amber with an offwhite head. Aroma of bready and biscuity malt, berries and rye bread. Fairly sweet , malty flavour.
Cask @ brewpub. Pours clear amber with a medium white head. Aromas of caramel and butter. Flavours of caramel, fruit and malt. Malty finish. Smooth texture.
Cask: Poured an amber with off white head. Aroma is malty. Taste is light buttery with Maltiness.
Tastes like Stilton has been used in the mix. Would go great with cheese but do not expect a refreshing hoppy pint.

Cask @ Grainstore, Oakham. Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, light fruity and light hoppy. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 161018
Cask @ The Grainstore, Rutland. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, fruits, hops, malt and has a nice bitter finish.

16/10/2018. Cask at the Grainstore brewery tap, Oakham. Pours dark amber with a large creamy off-white head. Aroma of toffee, malt, fruit and hops. Moderate sweetness with medium bitterness. Medium body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation.
Draught (Grainstore, Oakham) (6:4:6:3+:13=3.2+) Simple bitter aroma. Honeyish malts. Gentle twiggy bitter taste. Smoothish palate. Simple, but eminently drinkable.
Cask (Grainstore Brewery, Oakham). Clear yellow color. Medium size, white head, stays. Grainy, floral, grassy and dusty in aroma. Floral, fruity, grassy and herbal in taste. Nice bitter.

Handpull cask at the Fox, North Luffenham, as â€™Cunning Foxâ€™. Light brown with Amber hues, clear. Aroma of tannins, malt, Chardonnay. The taste is quite bitter with fruity vinous qualities. Clean finish with some notable astringency. Thin body. A solid beer, but not exactly my style.
Cask @ the brewpub. Pours clear amber with a white head. Aromas of fruit, malt and caramel. Flavours of horse saddle, caramel and grass. Soft texture. Bitter finish.
Cask: Poured a golden to copper with white head. Aroma is malty and grain. Taste is light bitter malts and grain.

Cask ale, third, at the brewpub in Oakham. Shared with Finn. Rich lacing from a pearl white head. Bright amber coloured body. Hints of herbal hops and mid.-sweet malts on the nose. Flavoured with caramel malts and herbal hops. Bittersweet finish. Okay bitter version. (11.02.2019).
Delt med Rune 11 Feb 19. Varm gylden. Lavt tett skum med litt farge. Ferskenaroma. Smaken plommer. TÃ¸rr lett bitter avslutning.
Cask @ The Grainstore, Rutland. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are fruits, malt, caramel and hops. Fruity finish.

16/10/2018. Cask at the Grainstore brewery tap, Oakham. Pours amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of caramel, malt, fruit, light hops and butter. Medium plus sweetness, light bitterness. Moderate body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Toffee, and hint of chocolate to finish. Fair.
Cask @ Grainstore, Oakham. Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and toffee. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 161018
Cask at the brewery... Deep brown... Small off white head... Soft caramel woody toffee fruit malt... Soft toffee malts.. Light bitter fruits

Draught (Grainstore, Oakham) (6:3:6:3:12=3.0) Compared to the Osprey, this has a watery aroma, even minerally. Thniner palate too, flattish. Twiggy bitter taste. Grapefruity bitter finish. You can drink it.

Cask (Grainstore Brewery, Oakham). Clear amber color. Small size, white head, stays as a ring. Grainy, floral, grassy, leather in aroma. Grainy, floral, nutty and grassy in taste. Weird leather in side-taste too. Medium bitterness. Nice brew.

Cask at the Grainstore Brewery, Oakham in 2016. Clear copper with a white head. Aroma of straw, digestive biscuits, floral hops and hint of peppery hops. Flavour is solid and quite full, with a good balance of sweeter caramel and cakey flavours with some drier, more bitter notes. Just a really good cask bitter.
Cask @ brewpub. Pours clear amber with a white head. Aromas of nut, caramel and fruit. Flavours of nut, caramel, spices and apple. Medium bitterness. Nutty and malty finish.
Cask: Poured an amber with white head. Aroma is light nonexistent. Taste is malty very tasty.

Cask at the Hope Tap (JDW), Reading. Crystal-clear amber chestnut with a thick creamy head. Decent condition. Fruity, malty aroma continues into the flavour. There's blood orange, a floral hint, a touch of chilli, some raisins and a bit of toffee. Sweetish, but full-flavoured and well balanced with a decent body. A very more-ish, tasty traditional English brew. Yum, enjoyed this.
Cask at The Great Northern Hotel, Peterborough. An amber coloured pour with a medium white head on top. Malty, fruity, caramel aroma. Tastes malty, fruity, caramel, hint of spice. Not bad.

Pours slightly hazy coppery color, topped with a minimal tan head. Malty nose, slightly biscuity wit ha bit of wood. A bit boozy. Sweet malty start, minimal bitterness with some alcohol warmth in teh finish. Lighter body. A bit spicy in the end, medium aftertaste.
On cask at Stamford AFC - Deep rusty body, close white top. Nose is malt and caramel forward, lots of fruity berry notes. Taste is toffee, caramel and the fruity malt. Decent beer.

Cask at the Great Northern Hotel, Peterborough. Pours copper to chestnut brown with a small creamy off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, dark fruit. Medium sweetness, light bitterness, touch sour. Medium body, some stickiness to texture, soft carbonation. Finish is fruity, slightly dry.

Cask @ Montgomeryâ€™s Tower, Shrewsbury. Pours clear copper, white head. Aroma is lightly sweet, some honey. Taste is smooth, with a grainy, sweet, lightly bitter character. Some smooth honey / caramel nestled amongst a grainy malt base. Sâ€™alright.

Cask handpull at The Crosse Keys Bishopsgate as â€™Grainstore Ten Fiftyâ€™, 5%. Dark amber, translucent, still with a light brown head which retains quite well and leaves droopy lacing. Aroma is wholemeal bread, some wet wood. Body is smooth with tingly carbonation for cask. Taste is quite sharp initially - some chemical, varnish, quite spicy and drying, astringent. Then a few waves of bready malt. More gluey astringency into the finish with a lasting breathy aftertaste. Maybe even a touch phenolic or smokey. It grew on me.

Cask (gravity) @ NBF 2015 [ The 40th. Nottingham Beer Festival (The 8th Robin Hood Beer and Cider Festival) ], Nottingham Castle, Friar Lane, Nottingham, Nottinghamshire, England NG1 6EB. [ As Grainstore Nip ]. Clear medium red - orange amber colour with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, caramel, sweet malt, dried fruit, sweet fruit. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet with a long duration, sweet fruit, sweet malt, sticky, sugary, dried fruit. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20151009] 7-3-7-4-14
Gravity cask at National Winter Ales Festival. Amber with a small white head. Malty aroma with alcohol and hints of fruit and spice. Sweet malty flavour with caramel, vanilla and a touch of fruit.
Tried at the Nottingham Beer Festival 14. deep ebony coloured beer with a white head. Sweet, spicy, fruity warming from the alcohol.

Cask at The Noel Arms, Oakham on 28 Dec 2012. Poured a bright, clear amber, with a dense off white head. Aroma of sweet fruit, brown bread and dirty socks. Sweet flavours of dates, raisins and biscuity malt. Finish was full caramel, dried fruit and some hop bitterness.

Cask conditioned at Leicester Beer Festival â€™14. Amber with white head. Rich, fruity Barley wine, ripe plum and a slightly sourish cherry character, sweetish later on. There is a great crash of alcohol. Challenging.

Cask the Plantagenet jdw Leicester. Chestnut colour no head. Aroma weak fruity. Taste great sweet fruity caramel toffee no sign of alcohol. Medium full body oily smooth mouthfeel soft carbonated. Really good tasting barley wine easy to drink great stuff.

Gravity cask @ NWAF, Derby. Light chestnut brown. (I am slightly afraid of strong light brown beers as they often lead me astray.) No head. Smells of forest fruit and caramel. Sweet and syrupy with a bitter finish. A big ale from Englandâ€™s tiniest county.
At Rutland Beer Festival... Very well balanced. Oily smooth.. first barley wine I have rated I believed thick. Very good.

On tap at the Derby Beer Festival After finding a quiet table I grabbed a half pint of this to cross off a new county. It was good enough that I seriously would have considered going back for more if there werenâ€™t 25 or so other samples to try in the two days I was visiting. I would certainly pick up bottles of this if it was on a local shelf. Aroma / Appearance - The ruby red base retained a thin white head and mild booziness. Raisins, figs, and Welchâ€™s grape juice sweetened the air along with a handful of dried cherry pits. The total package hung in the air like a fog. Flavor / Palate - Raisins and chewy fig newtons coated the mouth in a sweetness. The boozy aspect appeared next followed by caramel and the remains of whatever hops survived. With a sherry like texture this definitely feels like a dessert beer. Among the higher gravity selections it might be one of the best that was available over the weekend.
Gravity at Battersea beer festival 2012, smooth sweet body, hint of oak, not much aroma.
Amber brown with lasting tan head. Complex malt nose. Rich malt midtaste with medium hop finish. Full bodied and complex
Brown with thin beige head and scarce bead. Toasty carmel malt nose. Good dry malt fore and mid with lingering light hop finish
Old backlog rating, Victoria/Vancouver may 2006: Light pine aroma. Dark amber, low creamy head, fine pearling carbonation. Doughy malt, honeyish, dry grassy aftertaste. Light yet chewy body.

Sampled at the brewpub. MR24/07. App.: Deep golden-pale copper, small, creamy white head. Aroma: Solid hops â€“ peppery, pine, resin, a little dried fruit and toffee behind that. Palate: Medium body, fairly soft carbonation. Flav.: Solid peppery, green hops, a bit of sweet malt behind that (toffee), stone fruits. Almost dry with a fair bitter finish. Tasty stuff.

Caramel and toasty malts are apparent in the aroma along with floral and earthy hops. Clear deep golden coloured body is topped by a decent white head that recedes slowly to a lasting cover. Well-balanced flavour contrasts caramel and toasted malts with the british style floral hops and light to moderate bitterness. Slight diacetyl and mild fruity esters offer accents. Sweetness lingers in the aftertaste. Medium light body with decent effervescence. Enjoyed on tap at the brewpub.

Amber colour, slightly off-white head. Nice malty aroma with earthy/woodsy hops as well. Flavour is well-balanced as well, clean toasty malts, a touch of caramel and biscuit with sweet breadiness on the back. Earthy hop flavour balances the malts perfectly. Light minerally quality in back as well. Perfectly balanced, solid, session beer.

March 30, 2007: Northwest Pale Ale. Golden-amber colour. Fresh aroma has kumquat, orange. Flavour is vague citrus, hints of wood. Moderate bitterness. Finish gets chewier with rich caramel malts, along with lingering resiny, grapefruity hops. Solid if unspectacular. April 19, 2005: Slightly hazy amber brew. Citrusy, slighlty foresty/mossy hop aroma with light toasty malt as a backdrop. Moderately bitter but with a little honeyish sweetness. Light lime, grapefruit and apricot notes. Balanced and refreshing. Ar 7 Ap 4 F 8 P 4 O 15 = 3.8 Oct 17, 2005: Dark amber colour. Fairly earthy aroma. Earthy, spicy hops character with a fairly strong English yeast influence. Light toasty malts in the background. Very English-tasting, and does so without ramming EKGs or Fuggles down your throat. Very drinkable, excellent balance. Nice work. Ar 7 Ap 3 Fl 8 P 4 O 16 = 3.8

Had a fancier name to it than just pale ale. Pale but uninspiring, to be honest. Sadness. After this, I decided to leave. To have street falafel in Vancouver. Why are there so many Lebanese in the Pacific Northwest? Itâ€™s wonderful and amazing.
Light amber brown look with some syrupy malt in the aroma. Light laps of malt and hops touch the palate. Another beer made to not offend.
Amber,lasting white head. Pleasant light hop nose. Smooth,creamy malt start with medium hop finish. Great body.
On tap at the now defunct Avalon brewpub in North Vancouver. Hoppy, crisp, and refreshing. Good for a Mark James pub. Avalon was renamed North Shore Brewing.
Hazy deep gold,lasting white head. Scarce bead. Has a sort of unclean hop flavor.
Klares Pils, getreidig im Aroma und ungewÃ¶hnlich wÃ¼rzig und Herb im Geschmack.

Klassisch entaromatisiertes Schlapperpils. Der Trunk ist aufgrund seiner leichten SÃ¼ÃŸe etwas spezieller als bei andere Hellbiervertretern. Macht das Ganze allerdings nicht charaktervoller. Probierschluck von Enti auf dem Herzberg....im Burghof.
Klare blass goldgelbe Farbe, fingerbreite weiÃŸe Schaumkrone. Der Geruch ist getreidig sÃ¼ÃŸ, etwas oxidiert. Der Geschmack ist sÃ¼ÃŸ malzig, getreidig, kaum hopfig, oxidiert!
330ml Flasche. Klar und golden. Grosse Schaumkrone. Viel KohlensÃ¤ure. Leichtes Hopfenaroma. Geschmacklich eher mild und etwas wÃ¤ssrig.
* Old rating, 0,5l crown-top bottle, best before 08.07.03. Etwa dÃ¼nner als das Rathaus-Pilsner, leicht sÃ¼ÃŸlich-malzig mit leicht herbem Unterton. Irgendwie unrund.

# 3477 ersma: die brauerei gehÃ¶rt neuerdings einem verwandten eines bekannten, daher gabs das groÃŸe probierpaket. eher blass pilsfarben, mittlere verschÃ¤umung, die stabiler sein kÃ¶nnte. der geruch ist dezent sÃ¼ÃŸlich mit etwas hopfen dahinter. der antrunk ist herb, leicht bitter mit malzigem hintergrund und etwas blumigkeit. die mitte bleibt bitter, aber eher von der kratzigen art. der abgang ist noch bitterer, erst sehr spÃ¤t kommt wieder etwas malzsÃ¼ÃŸe hinzu. die flasche will edel sein, ist aber eher austauschbar und einfallslos. fazit: tut nicht not. 9, 8, 7, 7, 7, 7 - 7,35
World Cup Beer. Pale golden with a small white head. Grainy malt aroma with DMS and a dusty cardboard note. Dry malty flavour with plenty DMS, herbal hops and a mild bitter finish
Bottle @ Belarus Takes over the World Cup, 2014. Shared with Christian. Pours clear pale yellow with a off white head. Skunky and insanely DMS all over. Cabbage and leather. Waaauw. Baad!
Brown 0,33 l bottle with an old school labeling. Not real clear in the glass, low carbonated. Starts with mid herb, hay, low citrus. Easy to drink, average and better than expected.

Mittelpilsige Farbe mit ordentlicher Blume. Heu- u. Stroharoma. DÃ¼nner Antrunk. Zu Beginn gleich sÃ¤uerlich herb, kaum malzig. Obwohl im Abgang hopfig-herb ausklingend habe ich eher den Eindruck ein Wiess getrunken zu haben. Geht so.

This arrived at my local 7-11, and honestly this isnâ€™t a bad "game day" beer. I can see myself tailgating or watching football with a bunch of friends and drinking this. Does this satisfy with a meal, or when you want a GOOD beer? Hell no.

Name: Game Day Pilsner Date: September 06, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy gold, frothy off white head, thick lace Aroma: light spicy malt aroma Flavor: sweet malt flavor, nice spicyness, light bitterness Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 9/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: ** /4

On draught at the DIX BBQ & Brewery in downtown Vancouver, BC. Pours a clear golden straw brew with a creamy off-white head that quickly dissipates to a thin white ring. Aroma of golden grain malt, some pear fruit, citrus zest, and a touch of green vegetables. Taste is light bodied, some carbonation with flavors of golden grain malt, citrus zest and some pear character. Finish is light, crisp with a mild bitterness that quickly disappears.
Tap, may 2006. Light apricot aroma. Darker golden, fine bubbles, creamy low head. Light maltyness, good dry hop profile, light citric. Dry bready finish, cracker aftertaste.

20-ounce glass, draught, drank on site on August 3 2008; eye: golden, clear, light effervescence, tiny white head, lacing; nose: refreshing, grainy, malt, malt, and more malt, hops arrive, finale in malt with a good bite of hops, medium body, harsh texture, average carbonation, mildly bitter, lightly sweet, light astringency; overall: correct FRANÃ‡AIS Verre de 20 onces, en fÃ»t, bue sur place le 3 aoÃ»t 2008; oeil : dorÃ©e, claire, lÃ©gÃ¨re effervescence, petite mousse blanche, dentelle; nez : malt granuleux, rafraÃ®chissante, trÃ¨s lÃ©ger caramel, lÃ©ger pin; bouche : rafraÃ®chissante, granuleux, malt, malt, encore du malt, apparition du houblon granuleux, finale en malt avec une bonne mordÃ©e de houblon, corps moyen, texture rugueuse, carbonatation moyenne, moyennement amÃ¨re, lÃ©gÃ¨rement sucrÃ©e, lÃ©gÃ¨re astringence; en rÃ©sumÃ© : correct
Draught at the brewpub Blond color with creamy head. It has a nice crispy malt aroma (6 or 7). Unfortunately this is not repeated by the flavor, being boring as many other common Lagers.

Pours a pale yellow with a light head and some lacing. Aroma is sickly sweet and corny with a light alcohol note. Tastes completely generic and forgettable, just like any old macro pils. Present alcohol - probably the focus of this beverage. Body? Some carbonation. Move on, nothing to see here.

Dix Downtown brewDude knows how to brew. A generous white head, and aroma of creamy maltiness, and spice. Active carbonation.A creamy mouthfeel pile, lots of designer lace. Odd spiciness, with corriander and orange. Like this.
Pint. Thin head. Yellow. Light grain and bread aroma. Cold crisp hop finish. I found it too sweet and too much of a weird vegetable flavour.

Called the Game Day Pilsner now, this beer is straw coloured with a white fluffy head. Aroma is grassy with a touch of hops. Some bready malts and slightly hoppy at the front with a drier citrus hop to the finish. Wel structured.
Black with lasting brown head. Toasty nose. Medium roasted malt flavor. Good body
Easy drinking pils. Creamy, smooth and malty with good body.................

22oz unlabeled bottle acquired in a trade a few years back. Side x Side (regular version & BA version). Poured a black color with a smaller sized off white head. Roast, chocolate, some coffee, and lighter dark fruits.

Bottle from backlog notes 07/08. Pours dark brown to black in color with a small beige head. The aroma and flavor have roasted malt, dark chocolate, caramel, dark fruit, vanilla, molasses with a hint of coffee, some earthy bitterness to the finish, good body to this. Solid imperial stout.

Backlog of ratings. Thanks to someone at one of bu11zeyeâ€™s tastings. The smell is slight teriyaki, smoke, soy sauce, and malts. The look is brown to black in color, thinner head. Taste is malts, roasty, hops, and salty.

Where and how: vintage 2009? bottle Aroma port like, mellow with slight oxidation. Alcohol hints, touch of vanilla, with vinous vibe to it. Appearance: Top: very small with some rings on glass. Base: black . Palate : soft even delicate, medium full bodied with medium walls. Taste: caramel, vanilla, port. Some alcohol with late toasted blend malt chocolate blend. Other notes Tad thin.

Estimate at 4-6 years old. Pours very dark brown and even I could get no significant head. Chocolate and bourbon aroma. Thinnish start and then scotch, vanilla, bourbon and lots of wood.A real sipper and needed 4 of us to get through the bomber. Thanks Steve in Warren.
Rated in 2010 (Backlog) - Deep brown with an average sized beige head. Aroma is of roasted malts, chocolate and prune. Taste is of prune, coffee and roasted malts.

Draft at MBC. apparently they still have some left. No idea how old this is. That said, near black with a dark beige head. Sweet caramel, toffee, plum and raisin aromas. Similar flavors but really heavy on the dried dark fruits. This might even be better now that it's aged.

2007 Vintage 12oz bottle (no label) purchased in winter of 2007 / 2008 by a trade partner at the original Michigan Brewing location! Pours the deepest mahogany to black, opaque, with a 1 finger medium khaki crown that shows moderate retention and lace. The aroma gives off hints of sweet caramel, bread, moderate roast, moderate chocolate, a tiny amount of raisin, and a whisper of oxidation. The sweet malt, sweet raisin, and brown sugar notes take center stage. Moderate roast lays down the foundation. Palate is on the thick side of medium bodied to the thin side of heavy bodied. Overall its aged pretty well and I can tell love went into brewing it 5 years ago. I would have been nice to have tried this one fresh back in the day to establish a reference point.

Growler sample from a friend who brought it to the Smuttynose tasting at Ale Wine & Spirits on 4/27/12. Clear dark brown pour with a thin tan head. Aroma of malt, dark fruit, booze and chocolate. Malty and chocolatey flavor with some dark fruit before a boozy and roasty finish.

Sample from growler at Ale Wine & Spirits in Powell on 04/27/2012. The beer is a brownish-black color with a medium tan head that diminishes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. The aroma consists of dark chocolate, coffee and malt. Full-bodied with a roasty coffee and malt character along with notes of hops and nuts. The finish is rich and malty with a lingering sweetness. Above average overall.

column4: La Voie MaltÃ©e - Microbrasserie du Saguenay
column5: Originally rated October 2006. Sampled at the pub itself, in JonquiÃ¨re, Quebec. Poured a golden-white colour with mild cloudiness, no lace and weak retention. Lots of citrus, lemon dominant nose with slight Belgian white yeast. Very mild tartiness and little waxy. Dry sour taste with lemon and no aftertaste. Not really my favorite here, as this is a weak witbier.

column4: La Voie MaltÃ©e - Microbrasserie du Saguenay
column5: Verre de 12 oz, Ã  la brasserie de Chicoutimi. ArÃ´mes Ã©picÃ©s de coriandre. Robe blonde pÃ¢le et trouble, peu de mousse et effervescence moyenne. TrÃ¨s mince en bouche, les saveurs sont plus discrÃ¨tes que le nez. On retrouve une touche de blÃ© et un petit cÃ´tÃ© Ã©picÃ©. Finale trÃ¨s douce et un peu aqueuse. Rien dâ€™offensant, mais il existe de bien meilleure blanches.

column4: La Voie MaltÃ©e - Microbrasserie du Saguenay
column5: Sampled at the brewpub over the X-mas holidays. Murky Wit-like "white" that was borderline peachy, with a thin, pearly white head. Interesting combination of acidic and spicy nose, sort of like a bastard baby with a Saison father and Gueuze mother. And I donâ€™t think itâ€™s infected, but not entirely sure if this is exactly what the brewer was shooting for. Plenty of yeast, hay and coriander too. Tart and dry, and really refreshing (not very a propos for the cold December evening!), the crans shine through in the sharp aftertaste. Pretty lively effervescence, that tartness in the end makes it dance on that thin line between funky good and funky infected, but it was pretty much thumbs up for me.

column4: La Voie MaltÃ©e - Microbrasserie du Saguenay
column5: Any first impressions? -Ample foam crowns the cloudy pale yellow. -A tantalizing spicy yeast character benefits from some crisp straw, wooden wilderness and subtle herbs. I am reminded of a Jolly Pumpkin witbier! -White grapes, sturdy haystacks, wild yet mellow spiciness all coalesce into this intelligent, well-calculated tartness; this time Iâ€™m reminded of a Russian River delicacy! -The lively effervescence enlivens the vinous, juicy body. What if you dig deeper? -A piney perfume is hiding amidst the aromaâ€™s milky coriander. -Flour is also present in the storytelling nose. -The perfectly-positioned yeasty wilderness is breathtaking in its humility. -Grassy hops dwell in the haystack. -With intricately-linked flavors, this easily approachable yet immensely complex witbier experience was a fine example of this brewerâ€™s talent. -Once again, from reading other ratings, Voie MaltÃ©e beers seem to evolve and shift quite drastically from batch to batch. When they are in fine form, such as my growler of Muse or the snifter of Criminelle I had at the brewpub, they can be mindblowing experiences. From the growler, opened a day after purchase.

column4: La Voie MaltÃ©e - Microbrasserie du Saguenay
column5: Cloudy light yellow. Small white head. It seemed to me like a base beer to which one or 2 ingredients were forgotten. Overwhelming wheat in the nose, a bit lemony with slight honey suggestions on the palate and mostly coriander as far as spices go. Quite yeasty too, bananaish and grainy at that. Crisp mouthfeel, maybe a bit too carbonated for my liking. Just somehow seems incomplete.. This is the only beer I wonâ€™t remember from La Voie MaltÃ©e...

column4: La Voie MaltÃ©e - Microbrasserie du Saguenay
column5: Spicey aroma, cloudy white, nice foamy head. Sweet, lemon bubblegum flavour, spicing comes into taste very well too. Light, bubbly, quite easy to drink lots of I'd imagine. A real treat, Thanks Bill at the Winking Judge!

column4: La Voie MaltÃ©e - Microbrasserie du Saguenay
column5: Cloudy pineapple juice color. Banana and some citrus in the nose. Body is pleasantly sweet with malt with some citrus notes. Spritzy, but not enough to take away from the flavor. Faintly fruity, dries towards the finish with a light hop bitterness. A pleasant, refreshing Witbier.

column4: La Voie MaltÃ©e - Microbrasserie du Saguenay
column5: Opaque yellow; malty, wheaty, slightly honeyish nose. Malty, slight marshmallow, creamed honey, lime. Finishes wheaty, malty.

column4: La Voie MaltÃ©e - Microbrasserie du Saguenay
column5: Light and spritzy with a bitter orange peel presence. Corriander remains in the background. The yeast gives off a presence not altogether pleasant but it"s OK. With a slice of lime in the summer this is a winner to be sure.

Draft: Opaque liquid with light tan retentive foam. Very oaty aroma, complimented by dark grape and wet bread. Rich chocolate flavors with a note of charcoal. Finishes with long bittersweet flavors. This was pretty exciting.

Cloudy hazy copper-brown in color, roasty malty yeasty aroma, nice chocolate and caremel, pretty sweet with the hops noticable in the finish, clean and crisp,very balanced Alt, medium body with a silky soft mouthfeel, another good beer from this brewery.

"Carolus" von Binding; Flasche von Edeka, Volkmarsen. - Tiefdunkles Kupferrotbraun, klar. - In der Nase etwas mattes aber doch tiefes dunkles Malz mit RÃ¶stbrot, gedÃ¤mpfte SÃ¼ÃŸe, Rosinen, herbe und weinige AnklÃ¤nge, leicht fuselig. - Antrunk krÃ¤ftig dunkelmalzig mit RÃ¶stbrot, Bitterschokolade und herber Orangenschale, die bald in eher derbe krautige und Kaffeebittere Ã¼bergeht. Milder rezent, vollmundig, deutliche aber angenehme AlkoholprÃ¤senz. Im Abgang eher derbe aber kernige Bittere von krautigem Hopfen und RÃ¶stmalz. - Positiv ist schon mal, daÃŸ eine GroÃŸbrauerei wie Binding Ã¼berhaupt noch einen echten Doppelbock fÃ¼hrt. Noch dazu fÃ¤llt dieser individueller aus als viele, ist kernig malzig, frisch und trotz etwas ruppiger Hopfung (nur Extrakt kommt zum Einsatz) mehr als trinkbar. Probierenswert!

Draft pour into a mug at the Frankfurt Christmas Market. The beer is a clear copper with a beige head of foam. The beer is a spiced, floral, and very malty. Moderately bitter. Bigger body and medium carbonation.
Une brune Ã  joli petit caractÃ¨re, aux lÃ©gÃ¨res notes cafÃ©, malt grillÃ©, caramel. Pas trop lourde. Sympa. Bouteille 50cl, ramenÃ©e de Francfort, Allemagne, bue le 29/10/2018.

0.5 l bottle from local 'toom', best before June 2019. Clear, ruby with a large, frothy, stable, beige head. Sweetish-malty, slightly fruity aroma of molasses, raisins and prunes. Fairly sweet, malty, slightly fruity taste of molasses, raisins and prunes, followed by a short, moderately bitter, a bit metallic finish. Medium body, slightly creamy mouthfeel, average carbonation. Not a great Doppelbock but still enjoyable.
Black color and high head. Light malty aroma. Taste is toasted with full body.

A decent Bock, probably the best beer you can get in Frankfurt. Focus on malty, sweetish flavors, but with some nice complexity added by some fruity and bitter notes. Always a good time when it's available on tap.

330 ml bottle bought at Great Food Hall in Pacific Place, Admiralty. Looks: Clear copper brown colour; Three-finger head with crumpety light beige foam which lasts for 4 minutes; Very good sticky lacing with quite fizzy carbonation. Aroma: Fragrant full amber malt, with good roastyness, nuts, strong caramel, toffee, strong toast, light dark fruits, light alcohol, Cola, molasses, earth, dark bread, light herbs and thin grass. Taste: Mid to strong sweet full amber malt, with caramel, toffee, strong Cola, black coffee, strong dark chocolates, floral, molasses, herbs, strong dark bread, yeast, lemon, mid to strong bitter hops and grass. Body: Mid to light body. Dry, thin and fairly slick palate. Mouth Feel: Full amber maltyness in a somewhat thinned backed. Very dry dark bread all the way. Caramel and light toffee but no fruityness. Pretty toasty with strong dark chocolate bitterness with some black coffee. Medium sweetness crashed with strong bitter herbal hops. Lemon to round. Too single-mindedâ€¦ Hoppiness: Earth, light herbs and thin grass in nose. Floral, herbs, lemon and grass in taste; Bitterness - toast malt and hop extract - is sharp and strong for a lasting, high astringent sweet-bitter malty finish. After Taste: Very dry. Toasty malty and strong bitter to mouth. Comments: This one is like a very pumped-up Dunkel, and more like the liquid bread for the fasting monks described in history books: dry-ish malt and Cola backbone backed by strong toast and strong (but not pleasant) herbal hoppiness. Looks good but tastes one-dimensional. Drinkable but not top.
Clear dark ruby, big lasting lacing tanned foam head. Little sweet aroma, berries, some roast in taste, toast little sweetness. OK. (Velp 201612)

Flasche 0,5l: Dunkles Mahagoni, Kastanienbraun, glasklar, krÃ¤ftiger fester feinporiger beiger Schaum; in der Nase deutliche SÃ¼ÃŸe, Malzzucker, dunkle Fruchtigkeit, Trauben, sÃ¼ÃŸe WÃ¼rze, Karamell, leichte RÃ¶staromen, Schokolade; im KÃ¶rper deutliche SÃ¼ÃŸe, RÃ¶stmalz, Malzzucker, krÃ¤ftige RÃ¶staromen, cremig, krÃ¤ftige KohlensÃ¤ure, deutliche SÃ¤ure, dunkle Fruchtigkeit, trockene Bitterkeit, Kaffee; angenehmer trocken-wÃ¼rziger Nachgang mit mehr RÃ¶staromen

[backlog] 19-12-15 / bottle at Christmas market Ingelheim. Strong malt, some caramel. I started rating my beers with Untappd and a few basic notes. Now I want to rate them on ratebeer. So my rating sometimes lack some information. Just ignore it, it is for my personal statistics. Untappd-Rating 2.5/5
How: Bottle. Where: Had at home. Appearance: Pale golden colour with a white head. Aroma: Malt, grain, some vegetables. Body: Light body, medium carbonation. Flavour: Malt, grain.

33cl bottle. Medium white head, a bit foamy. Good carbonation, small bubbles. Very light yellow, but no totally clear color. Aroma has malt and moss, flavour is malt, wood, grain. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPad

Bottle from Haus der 131 Biere, Hamburg, as Georgi der Siegende. The label says this is brewed in Germany and not in Belgium. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and corn. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. Watery.
Pale golden, white head that leaves quickly. Sweet aroma, bad sweet flavor. Some bitterness in the finish.

Bottle from the Karstadt in Wedding. Lightly floral, lightly corny nose. Ultra-pale yellow body is more like clear. Taste of dirty malt and dusty metal, relatively dry with a little malt in the aftertaste, and thereâ€™s a somewhat subtle bitterness running through the watery light body. Macro swill, or at least tastes like macro swill.

Bottle 33 cl, Karstadt, Frankfurt. Pours clear pale golden with a big fizzy ehite head. Great carbonation. Malty and spicy aroma with hints of yeast. Crispy refreshing mouthfeel. Flavor is malty, spicy, sweet, watery and fruity. Not bad for a hot summer day by the BBQ. Finishes with a suprisingly nice - similar to flavor - sweet, malty, spicy and bitter aftertaste.

Itâ€™s golden with a creamy, white head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel, and the same goes for the moderately sweet flavour. It has a slightly dry finish, but it rather thin-bodied and boring.

Bottled@Tuulensuu (years ago). Pale orangeish golden colour with small white head. Aroma is grains, mild bready as well as some vegetably notes. Flavour is rather much the same. Not very balanced nor nice.

Bottle 33cl. @ The Danish Summer Gathering Tasting, TSODRBSG09. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, grain, sweet malt. Flavor is light to moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090822]

Bottle. Itâ€™s a clear, pale golden beer with a white head. Thereâ€™s some notes of burnt plastic on the nose, with pale malts and a fruity hints. Grainy and fruity flavor with some bitterness in the end. Medium to thin on the palate. Sure, itâ€™s drinkable, but nothing more. 090822
bottle bb 5/9/19 thanks roman chiara dorata limpida buona schiuma abbastanza persistente discreto erbaceo maltato delicato un filo metallico amaro medio buona secchezza lieve citrico
WÃ¤ssrig herber Beginn. Bitterhopfiger Mittelteil, plump aber fehlerfrei. WÃ¼rzig bitterer Abgang. 9/8/8/8/5/8

Golden clear with medium white head. Aroma : floral hops, not much else. Taste is not much either. Only after swallowing there is the typical hop bitterness. However good to drink. Overall nothing special

Bottle: Unclear, pale greenish-golden, stable and creamy white head with a little lace, papery-grainy nose, a subdued grassy bitterness is detectable; moderate dryish bitter-sweet flavour, light bodied and quite soft; short grassy-bitter finish, some forgotten malt detectable. A cheap brew, still better than Premium Verum Warsteinerâ€¦
bottle, courtesy of pivnizub. Clear pale yellow, mid-sized white head. Hoppy nose. Shy malty base, dursty, dry hops, not very aromatic. No glory.

Bottle from Kris Wines. Standard golden colour with white head. Aroma is usual pils hop in botle form, rich but a little metallic. Body a bit thin, carbonation relatively high, some pils character but finishes quickly and some veggie feel. Does what an average pils does and thatâ€™s it.
Yellow pour with light white head and lace. Light paper and a nice bitter. Medium bodied but a tad thin.

500ml bottle. Brilliant gold with a slender, lacing head. Good, earthy grass sap, honey and vanilla aroma. More of that sappy hop on the tongue partnered with honeyed, bread stick malt. Generous, almost tonic bitter finish. Finally bready, and very bitter. Really sticks around. Nice pils.

Bottle, courtesy of fonefan. Itâ€™s a clear, golden beer with a small, off-white head. Quite grainy on the nose but with a pleasant grassy and piney hop impact. Dry, medium bodied and pleasantly carbonated, slightly metallic in the bitter and grainy finish. Bitterness, grass, some generic fruits as well as pale malts in the flavor. A decent pilsener indeed. 110128

Bottle 500ml. Clear light to medium yellow color with a average, frothy - fizzy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, cereal, toasted, cardboard notes, light hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light light bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20110128]
Roasty caramel aroma. Deep copper with a tan head. Light malty character with hop and roast grain bitterness.
Cask. The Three Legged Mare, York. Medium white head. Dark copper body. Citric, nutty, chocolate malt. Bitter. Dry finish.

Cask (@ Three Legged Mare): Deep amber coloured, stable and lacy off-white head; peppery hoppy nose with fruits and malt, quite light bodied; peppery hops linger in the sweetish-fruity finish, followed by a bitter aftertaste. A pleasant brew.....

Cask (Gallows Bird, Espoo, Real Ale Festival 2003) Deep brown, small beige head. Subtle but full aroma. Soft palate, smooth. Very full taste, itâ€™s basically - in a word - brown. Good roasty malts and plenty of brackeny hops. Finish continues the taste for quite a while. Rating discovered while packing for a move in 2010.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Three Legged Mare, York. A dark brown coloured beer with an off-white coloured head. The aroma has some coffee and berry fruits, which carry through into the warming tasty, predominantly malty mouthfeel. Pretty nice.
Cask at the Three-Legged Mare, York. A well-balanced, flavourful bitter with some roast and fruit flavours. Good but not really a standout from this brewery.

Cask @ 3 Legged Mare, november 07. Nice, shinny ruby color with some orange hues and a small lace leaving white rim. Caramelly, slightly raisiny aroma. Caramel tasting with some earthy hops notes. Medium palate, silky, velvety feeling that keeps it nice and interesting. Tasty, warming amber bitter.

Exclusive to the lovely 3-legged-mare pub in York. Deep copper pour covered by a generous, lasting off-white head with full lacing. A well-brewed, very fruity, figgy even and grapey, boldly caramelly mild ale. Growing coffee-like roastiness. Evolving nutty, toasty notes. Kinda grainy by the finish. Good and tasty stuff.

Aug 07 Cask conditioned @ Three Legged Mare (otherwise known as the Wonky Donky)< York. Lots of dry roastiness which might work well in a fuller bodied beer but I found it a bit out of place here with the slightly sweet malt and gentle hops.
pretty much the same as Dark Knight. same fruity aroma with lots of fruity notes nice malty taste and good balance.
Denne pilsner har et gyldent og klart udseende med et medium skum. Ã˜llen har en meget begrÃ¦nset aroma og smager tyndt af humle med bitterhed. Medium karbonering.

I rate this beer mostly for "historic" reasons. Like in the 90â€™s when people would ask me to say wether I preferred Blur or Oasis I would answer Pulp, in the 80â€™s in Denmark the kids would ask me if I was a Carlsberg or Tuborg drinker, I would answer, Ceres Top. The old 3rd way is big with me, which means Iâ€™d probably waste my vote if I was ever taking part in an election in the US. The beer is very typical industry fare, but tasting it again for the first time in years (it is now near impossible to find outside Aarhus, or in North Jutland anyhow) I found that it is quite refreshing, doesâ€™t have the rotten fruit flavor of Carlsberg, and tastes less than moved grass than Tuborg. So, all in all, somewhat better than others of its kind, or not.

Bottle 330ml. Clear light to medium amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, sweet malt, sugar, rosated notes, light hoppy. Flavor is light moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090507]

good danish vienna beer! it has a soft aroma with some aftertouch. a good beer for getting wasted, semi cheap, and nice body. my overall impression is 4 of 20, because i think there is many better beers, but still, this is a nice vienna :)
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are malt, caramel and hops. Quite ordinary vienna.
Aarhus, DK Bottled A typical classic - Caramel notes and some other malts. Hops are low

Dark golden with an OK head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel and the flavour has a light sweetness, notes of malt (slightly roasted) and caramel. The overall impression is neither worse than better than the average Danish industrial Classic - and itâ€™s easy to drink.
Bottle. Darkish golden with a medium rather short lasting head. Bit weak sweet maltiness in the aroma. Flavour of some roasty maltiness, bit sweet, slight notes of caramel. Short maltish finish.
Bought at a grocery store in Aabyhoj, Aarhus. Copper color with little white head. Very malty -caramel sweetness (munchener) A bit watery body and a short finish!
Aroma/Malty-bread/light, Appearance Head/small, Head/Color-off white, Head/Longevity-mostly diminishing, Body/Hue-brown, Flavor/initial - bitter light Palate Body/medium ok beer
500ml bottle. It is a very average german pilsner with watery body, light aromas. Not a big hit.

SchÃ¶nes Pils. Herb, aber auch aromatisch. SchÃ¶ne stabile cremige Schaumkrone. Leider im Westen Deutschlands nur schwer zu bekommen.
Not very good. Too much sweetness, no sign of bitterness. Poor example of german lager.
Bottle Aroma-grass, bread Appearance-golden, clear, white head Taste-medium bitter, light sweetness and sourness Palate-light body, thin, average carbonation, bitter finish Overall-very drinkable
Aroma of malts and sulphur. Taste is rather watery. Some malty and sulphur notes. Low to medium bitterness. Mediocre
Clear yellow-golden color with a little white head. Malty, grainy, hints of gras, buttery, medium carbonation.
0,5 l Flasche. Goldenes Bier, Schaum baut schnell ab. Riecht wÃ¼rzig, leicht muffig, schmeckt wÃ¼rzig, leicht sÃ¼ÃŸ, angenehm herb, ansonsten Ã¤uÃŸerst durchschnittlich.

9th Aug 2018. 500ml bottle from a Schnell Imbiss in Quedlinburg, drank it on their outside patio area sat in the late afternoon sun. Clear and clean golden body, tight white crown that soon fell away to a wisp and collar. Grainy nose and initial taste, some hop action balances out the malty sweetness and this became a very pleasant and refreshing Pilsner. Nothing made it stand out from the crowd, but it's a fine and what I needed at the time.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: On tap at Buller Pub, Buenos Aires. Pours hazy brown with a medium-sized well lasting head. The aroma features sweet maltiness with some citrusy and tropical fruitiness; orange, mango. Taste is light to medium sweet and malty initially, in the finish a bit drier and lightly bitter. Not a brutally hopped IPA but sweeter and balanced, even malt-driven. Solid hoppy, fruity flavours still. The mouthfeel is smooth and sticky, medium-bodied. Not bad.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Pint opposite the cemetery in Buenos Aires. Needed this after hunting down the tomb of Eva PerÃ³n for a couple of hours. Fairly tasteless and very cold but Iâ€™m not complaining

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Tap at the brewery - clear golden color, white head. actually a very nice IPA: fruity, tropical, with a medium full body. nice bitter finish. very drinkable.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Una IPA de color caramelo con media carbonataciÃ³n. Su aroma es altamente lupulado, en el que resaltan los aromas frutales (durazno Huesillo), pino y eucaliptos. Su sabor es de un alto amargor que se disipa suavemente, destaca el durazno Huesillo y frutos secos. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Honey and malty sweet aroma. Taste is sweet and slightly bitter. Honey and malty again. Must be their thing. Not bad but not an ipa flavor I am used to. Had this as part of a flight at Buller brewing in Buenos Aires.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: uma boa IPA, aroma frutado, amargor moderado. a good IPA, fruit aroma, medium bitterness in a clear glass

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: A pretty average IPA, a touch of hoppy bitterness (moreso than some other Argentine "IPA"s), but nothing too interesting here.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Tap at brewpub. Deep amber color, medium-sized off-white head. Aroma is resiny with some overriped fruits. Medium-bodied. Flavor is too resiny and riped fruity. Gives a bit unfresh feeling.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Hops makes its presence felt but doesnâ€™t fill up the room. Can at least detect it firhg from the first smell. It doesnâ€™t feel like enough hops to preserve a beer from London to Bombay, however.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Drank last year, while I was in Buenos Aires. Maybe my favorite beer from my expedition in Argentina. Hops is something South Americans brewers seems afraid of, maybe because of frightened customers and consumers, maybe because hops are expensive there, I simply donâ€™t know. Well, for the South American standards, I thought that hops (citric hops nonetheless!) had a nice presence in this beer, with a pleasant malt presence. But the feel of the beer was kind of watery, which was a disappointment. Color is amber/orange. More of a Bitter (if not Mild Ale) than an India Pale Ale. Very sessionable though (on cask, this would have been a blow me think). Honest and pleasant. Neostoicism was a syncretic philosophical movement, joining Stoicism and Christianity.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: On tap at Bullers Downtown, Buenos Aires Appearance: Clear yellow with a medium white head and good lacing Aroma: Pale malts and honey Taste: Pale malts, honey and some citrus hops Surprisingly a very nice Lager. Clean, crisp and refreshing.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Buller Pub, Recoleta. Part of 6 beer tasting tray. Not a great beer. Very small traces of malt and hops.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Draft at their brew pub. Light yellow color with a smallish head. Some malts and bitterness for a light lager. Not bad, but wouldnâ€™t order it again.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Draught at the brewpub. A pale yellow beer with a small white head. Aroma is slightly malty with some hops. Taste is malty and sweety. Some bitterness. A simple but good beer

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: ColoraÃ§Ã£o dourada translÃºcida, espuma densa. O aroma Ã© fraco. Bom amargor, lupulado. PresenÃ§a de malte sÃ³ no sabor. CarbonataÃ§Ã£o mÃ©dia/baixa. A consistÃªncia do lÃ­quido Ã© de certa forma cremosa, o que nÃ£o Ã© comum nesse estilo de cerveja. Boa surpresa.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: on tap-pours a thin white head and yellow color with effervescence. Aroma is grain with some sweetness. Taste is nice grain with some sweetness, hint of continental hops. Light body.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Tap at brewpub in Buenos Aires. Yellow color with a white head. Light musty aroma with a clean light citrus flavor.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Recoleta location. Very very pale yellow, almost without color. Mint, iron, and faint foulness of compost on the nose. Taste is mild and quite reasonable. Hay and grasses, some vague malts. Palate is too pungent and violently sharp. Notably more tolerable than most.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Clear pale yellow, small head. Sweet with plenty of orange nectar and rounded mouthfeel. Fairly light bodied with lots of perfumy orange. Low-medium bitterness. Where does all the perfumy orange come from?

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Draft: strong honey flavour?? quite watery, plain and simple, fresh and clean taste. flat.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: On tap at Buller Pub, Buenos Aires. Pours hazy golden with a little white head. The aroma features wheaty maltiness, some banana and a touch of spiciness. Taste is light to medium sweet, wheaty, malty and fruity. Flavours of wheat and banana. Dry and malty finish. The mouthfeel is light to medium-bodied and smooth, average carbonation. Slightly light-bodied but decent flavours.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Had this as part of a flight at Buller brewing in Buenos Aires. Yellowish. Wheat and citrus flavor. Not a bad beer for this style.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Listed as Buller Hefeweizen, Orange body white head. Spicey and sweet, citrus and banana. Tasty hefeweizen.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Tap at brewpub. Hazy yellow color, medium-sized creamy head. Aroma has clove and is a bit earthy. Light-bodied to medium-bodied. Flavor is quite clove spicey with some banana. Subpar weizen, could be more refreshing.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Taste of citrus, even citrus peel for a bit of bitterness. Aroma has some banana. Nothing special,

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Pours cloudy light golden with a fainted white head. Aroma of spices, herbs and hops. Heavy spiced flavour with medium bitterness. Medium body, oily feel, soft carbonation and the same spicy and bitter after taste. Good one.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: On tap at Bullers Downtown in Buenos Aires Appearance: Hazy yellow with a medium white head and good lacing Aroma: Coriander and orange peel Taste: Orange peel, pepper and spices Nice hefe, clean and crisp flavors and taste

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Buller Pub, Recoleta. Part of 6 beer tasting tray. Cloudy yellow colour, with good white head. Light hops bringing a touch of citrus.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Cloudy and yellow, white in color. Nice wheat beer, but I prefer the Belgian style. Citrus notes and is thirst quenching.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Draught at buller Recoleta. A hazy yellow beer with a foam white head. Aroma is citric with notes of banana. Taste is fruity and yeasty. Some spiceness.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Best beer I had here. Orange pour with white head. Had this as part of a flight at Buller brewing in Buenos Aires. Had a strong honey taste. Flavorful and poundable for high ABV

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Tap at brewpub. Clear yellow color, small white head. Light herbal honeyish nose. Light-bodied to medium-bodied. Alcoholic flavor with honey and some bitterness in the finish. Not sweet, kind of odd.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Has virtually no smell, at least that I can detect. Taste is indeed honey, o trace of alcohol in the taset, which is odd considering the high percentage. A little bitter at the end. Alright but not great.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Pours golden clear with a timid head. Almost no aroma, some grass notes there. Spiced taste with some light sweetness and lightly sour flavour. Light body, thin feel, soft carbonation, short finish. Whatever.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: On tap at Bullers Downtown Buenos Aires Appearance: Clear golden with a small head and some lacing Aroma: Honey and pale malts Taste: Honey, malts with some hop bitterness in the finish A good beer, my least favorite beer they had on tap. I was surprised to find out after I drank it that is 8.5% abv.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Buller Pub, Recoleta. Part of 6 beer tasting tray. Probably a little too sweet, even for a honey beer. Golden yellow colour, not cloudy, white head.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Golden color. Sweet malt flavor. Smooth beer with some character, but a little too sweet.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: ColoraÃ§Ã£o dourada translÃºcida, com espuma branca. O alto teor alcoÃ³lico estÃ¡ bem inserido no conjunto. PresenÃ§a de malte, lÃºpulo e um suave adocicado (do mel). Final levemente amargo e doce. Aroma agradÃ¡vel, de malte e mel. Leve floral. CombinaÃ§Ã£o interessante.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: on tap-pours a thin white head and pale yellow/yellow color. Aroma is grain, honey. Taste is sweet light malt/grain, honey, then a short lived sharp bitterness which fades to floral/spicy hops (continental), some yeast. Mild carbonation.

column2: TristÃ¡n SuÃ¡rez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Tap at brewpub in Buenos Aires. Yellow color with a white head. Nice honey and citrus aroma but pleasantly sublte in flavor. Quite and elegant flavor and nicely hopped. A real surprise and a delight.

Nice deep copper color with a thin frothy white head. Aroma is pretty dull with a touch of mild caramel malt and rye, but with the typical lager yeast profile. Body starts crisp and smooth with a decent rye flavor and a touch of European hops. Drinkable, but not all that exciting.

Above average medium-weight fruity lager, with a nice golden-red color, good fruity flavors and a surprisingly sharp actual rye taste. Very quaffable; no nose to speak of in the extreme smokiness of the pub.

Poured from tap to glass amber reddish hue with white head that dissipated quickly. Aroma is pine, cereal, caramel. Mouthfeel is nice with a lighter body and moderate carbonation. Taste is clean and dry with a bitter following and slight CO2 in the finish. Overall this is a nice brew

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a dark red color with a nice tan head. Floral and citrus hop aroma with light malts. Flavor is up front citrus hoppiness with some raisins and plums and a light caramel backbone. Finishes very smoothly, a nice easy drinker.

Another great tap selection at Horse Brass. I selected it just on the name. Thick creamy head on a very dark red beer. Aroma is hops, hops, a hint of toffee, and hops. Flavour is like hop chocolate. Cool a Hop Chocolate IPA!

This stuff is killer. That is all I can say. A very nice strong ale, that is immediately there in your mouth, right off the bat, you know what you are drinking. The malt character is rich and balanced sometimes on the overwhelming side, the hops attack your tastebuds, but nothing ever gets too out of balance.
subtle taste of strawberry jam. smooth and full. sweet fruity taste. Good beer

Tap at Rose and Raindrop. Medium brown color wtih a little bit of haze. Soda pop head, very fizzy and short lived. Grapefruit in aroma. Decent malt nose also. Medium bodied. Fair sweet malt balanced just barely with hop bitterness. Pretty good.

Dark mahogany with a creamy head and spotty lacing. Bitter and citrus hop aromas. Orange maybe. Malts of roast and caramel. Kind of toasty and piney. Hops are muted in the flavor, but the malts come out to play more. Thin body almost, finishes fruity and malty.

Sampled draught at Steelhead Brewing, EugeneTawny color, pellucid. Protein rich head, nose of some hops with some rich malt complexity. The flavor is similar, nicely nutty & malty. Finishes sweet & smooth.

Cask, Rose & Raindrop, Portland. Dark murky red and brown color. Highly hopped sweet plum and wood nose. Roasty, smooth wood and coffee with some dark fruit, dates, plums, black cherries... roasted oak flavor. A little assertive roasty hops in the flavor... nutty, woody overall. An excellent brew.

pours a dark brownish red color, has a very nice beige colored head, creamy and long lasting, very hoppy sweet hop aroma mixed with a slight bit of malt. Tasted very hoppy, aromatic floral hops and decent malt body, not great but decent, some slight spiciness as well. Pretty good winter brew
(Cask, Horse Brass Pub) Pours a lightly cloudy golden body with a small white head. Aroma of mild citus and malt. Falvo rof malt, hops, and candy with a bit of soapiness in the finish.
This was alright, I was expecting more. This had a little bit more of a grassy herbal note and had a bit of a sopay fizzy and watered down malt character.
Cloudy orange and gold appearance. Texture is creamy and more full than the bombay bomber IPA - some soap, sugar and marijuana notes, creamy throughout. Slightly fizzy and light to medium bodied.

(Draft: 2005 Oregon Brewers Festival in Portland, OR) Smells very hoppy, very fresh, and sweet. But well, itâ€™s not all that sweet, but the hops in the nose definitely dominates the flavor. Itâ€™s quite bitter and grapefruity actually, with a mildly sweet English maltiness providing a nice backbone. Medium body with a crisp finish. Very cloudy and amber in color. The off-white head isnâ€™t large or long-lasting, but is very easy to revive with a quick swirl. One of the better beers Iâ€™ve had at this festival.

Tasted on Tap at 2005 OBF. Orange gold color, slightly hazy. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is caramel fruity and sweet. A medium bodied IPA/Pale Ale. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are floral and earthy. Smooth taste, very nice balance. Medium to lighter bitterness. Nice dry crisp finish. Somewhere between an American Pale Ale and an IPA. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean. Crisp and dry. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

On tap in Eugene and unfiltered. Pours a very cloudy bright orange with a smooth white head. Lots of very fresh citrus hops in the aroma, grapefruit and yeast. Well balanced pale with juicy hop presence, lots of grapefruit flavor in the finish without an overwhelming bitterness. Crisp and dry finish with an excellent hop flavor. Really nice brew with a bit of that green hop and yeasty flavor from not filtering.
grapefruit hop aroma, more hoppy than most apas but dry hopped to hell......
Overall: Smooth, borderline boring. Note: Steelhead Brewing Company Reviewed 2014-03-16.

A deep dark reddish to mahoganny ale with a thin lacing creamy moka head. A pleasant aroma of light molasses, raisins, veering on doppelbock. In mouth, a rich nutty malt, with light chocolate notes, raisins, light bananas, almost German. Interesting! On tap at brewpub, Jan. 17 2009.

This was a big rich monster, lots of sweet malts up front, lightly roasted, with a caramel taste that intensifies as it warms on your palate. Pours dark red with a quick falling whtie head. Very soft feeling with a lot of body. The alcohol was hidden very well up front, but showed a bit in the finish.
Burlingame. Very sweet, alcohol aroma. Nice. Ruby red color with tan head. Head is lasting to some degree with nice lace. Strong alcohol mouthfeel. Some off-notes, but still solid.

It looks nice with the dark tan color, the name sounds nice, but this beer doesnâ€™t taste that good. It has an alcohol content of 10.5%, and it tastes like it. Itâ€™s almost like drinking a dark ale with a shot of vodka added to it. The booze ruined this beer for me.

creamy tan head dissipated rather quickly to a clingy tan ring. deep chestnut body. nose of a barleywine! alcohol prevalent among creamy ripe fruits, port wine and flaked barley. Big malty sweetness, velvety and ripe. mature, deep and rich. biting and bitter, but well balanced and follows with a solid malt backbone. this is good. warm and yummy right to the tummy. roastey notes reamin, as well as an emerging chocolatiness.
berry aroma with alcohol notes, flavors of berry alcohol with a hoppy finish, full bodied and the brewer's best effort
Wypite przed kilkoma laty, nie jest juÅ¼ produkowaneâ€¦ Ocena przepisana z notatek.
Koledzy lubili. Mnie nie smakowaÅ‚o. Nie czuÅ‚em w tym piwie chmielu. ByÅ‚o zbyt sÅ‚odowe. Nie wiem, jak jest teraz. Ale nie obchodzi mnie to zbytnio.
Bottle. Clear golden colour with a fine white head. Light -bodied, Slightly sweet but nicely hopped,

PÃ¥ sistone har det gÃ¥tt inflation i uttrycket "bÃ¤ttre Ã¤n sex". Kelt 12% Ã¥terstÃ¤ller balansen genom att vara sÃ¤mre Ã¤n sex, avsevÃ¤rt sÃ¤mre. Allt har sÃ¥ledes ett syfte, till och med det hÃ¤r Ã¶let - om Ã¤n inte ett sÃ¥ Ã¤rofullt.
50 cl bottle. Originally rated on 20090304. Pours golden color with a small head. Aroma of fruits, grass, clove and mild malts. Flavor of butter, hay, malts and mild hoppy fruits.

floral, cereal, spruce, earthy, bubblegum, cooked vegetables, raisin, golden, cloudy, frothy, medium sweetness, very bitter, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, bitter, earthy, clove,
Bottle. Pours golden clear with a decent white head. Good aroma, complex taste of sweetness at first sip, and balanced mild bitterness troghout.
beer with yellow colour, thin head. Average beer nothing to rave about. hoppy aroma. Taste after malt with bitterness;
Appereance golden with white head. Light sweet, with missing flavor. Too much hopy. Nothing special, forgettable beer.
Cask, hand-pulled, Bon Accord (8 Aug 2015), sour lemony aroma, pale golden, thin off-white head, no lacing, slightly sour sweet malt, lacking in hops, peculiar aftertaste
Cask @ Bier Huis, Burnley. Slightly hazy gold, with a creamy head. Has a light berry-sweetness in its nose. A touch more balanced in its taste but still with a sweetness.

Bottled as Santaâ€™s Tipple. A fizzy, lager coloured ale with a grassy aroma. Wheat is obvious and not very appealing for a Christmas beer, quite thin with a floral hop finish. Better on draught in summer.

Draft at the Great British Beer Festival 2014, Day 1 - London. Pours clear yellow-gold with a foamy white head. Sweet, with pale bread, light tangy lemon, straw, grains and hay. Light in body with fine carbonation; good condition. Finishes sweet with light bitter dirty hay, more pale dough. Fine golden ale.
How: Cask. Where: GBBF 2014. Appearance: Clear golden colour with a white head. Aroma: Fruit, citrus, floral, perfume. Body: Medium body, low carbonation. Flavour: Perfume, floral, citrus.

12th August 2014 GBBF Day 1. Cask. Almost clear gold beer, small white head. Palate is very light and dry and has a light crispness. Mild floral notes. Very light hops - whisper of lemon. Light dry finish. Okay.

Cask at GBBF â€™14, day 1, 12/08/14. Lightly hazed golden with a moderately appointed off white head. Nose is pale malt, grain, cereal, light citrics. Taste comprises yeast notes, pale malts, straw, faint lemon rind, bready pangs. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Boring GB.
Sampled @ GBBF day 3. Clear yellow to golden color, decent sized white head. Smell and taste malts, nicely hoppy, lightly tropical fruits, some pineapple, decently bitter. Pretty nice!

Cask @ Lamb, Stoke Goldington. Golden and clear. Thin white head on top. Unconvincing aroma of banana, thin malt and sour fruit. Taste is very well balanced, a bittersweet taste leading to bitter-sour finish. Lingering aftertaste. Goes well with my meal but not so muchÂ on its own. Pretty good for this type of beer.

Cask (Charters, Peterborough) Simple barley aroma. Pale orange, tiny brief head. Slightly leguminous, but not full-on vegetal. Cornflakes? Some toffee. A touch sour later. Has those soapy bitter fertilised female hops in the bitterness - quite agressive. The late finish has lots of barley which is an improvemtent. A barely adequate beer. No real flaws, in theory, but misses the mark in several places when it comes to what reached the glass.
Cask by handpump at Bon Accord, Glasgow - clear deep golden, thin white head, some lacing, no detectable aroma, biscuity, bit of fruit, sweet, easy to drink

500ml Brown bottle (bottle conditioned), best before 31st Aug 2010, drank and reviewed 23rd July 2010. Poured slowly into a vase shaped â€™Old Speckled Henâ€™ badged glass. The beer produced a magnificent foaming head of snow drift size and colour. Below sat a pale amber, dull orange body. Carbonisation was good, you could see bubbles rising through the slightly hazey brew. The aromas were of yeast and hops, no malt content. Pilot being the only hop used (according to the label), Maris Otter, Crystal and Wheat malts added nothing to the smell. The malts and Pilot hops did blend together well in the taste, sharp, refreshing and with a bitter aftertaste as the mouth dried. The 5.0% ABV is nicely placed within the beer and the balance between all the ingrediants seems to sit well. My first beer from this brewery, I have two more bottles of theirs in my stash and Iâ€™ll also look out for any of their beers in cask form in future.

Pours a viciously overactive murky goldish brown (the same colour a stewed apricots). Aromas of basement and a little bit of lemon, a little bit of grapefruit. Actually, if sniffed blind, youâ€™d think it was Belgian. The flavour is a little more mild with good malt, carbonation and gentle hopping coming through. When I opened the bottle and had to rush to fill the glass with foam I wasnâ€™t terribly happy, but I put that down to it being a beer that is alive and has had to travel to the other side of the world. I like this. I like that someone in England regards their beer so highly to send it to me in New Zealand. As I mentioned, this beer has a definite Belgian ale character of greenish white wine and yeasty basement and it endures. Calling it a Golden/Blonde Ale does it a massive disservice. Itâ€™s better than that.
On cask. Pours a dark golden colour with a fair off-white head. Aroma of caramel, barley, yeast and apple. Similar flavours, mild carbonation and a dirty tar-like finish. Not the best.

[cask at Cloisters, Edinburgh] Slightly hazy off-golden beer, quite flat on the pour. Bitter, malty nose. Very biscuity â€“ something in the aftertaste I wasnâ€™t keen on â€“ but it was drinkable if unspectacular [07102011]

Bottle from Duncan Murray Wines, Market Harborough. Orange mist with a sudsy pile of head well at home in Octoâ€™s weizen. (4,4) Bag of mouldy clementines, Pink Lady apples and limes sluiced around in the urinal aroma. Fat and balanced like Beowulf; robust earthy malts, applepeel and orange citrus, pine, gooseberry. Some pineapple emerging as it warms. Impressive from 1 variety of English hop (Pilot). Bracing, hairs-on-your-chest stuff with a dollop of farmyard about it. If it said â€™Belgiumâ€™ and â€™7.5%â€™ on the bottle Octo wouldnâ€™t be whinging and reaching for the Brugs.
Cask @ 3 Judges. Pale yellow colour, white head. Aroma is biscuit malt. Flavour is of biscuit malts, some fruits. Slightly bitter and dry finish.
From the Bottle at Chris Oâ€™s, GBBF Week 09/08/2008 Fruit and hop aromas. Golden coloured and a little hazy in appearance with a crisp and slightly bitter full malt finish.

Bottle 50cl.
[ As Frog Island Frosty Fuel ]. Clear medium orange color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, fusty orange, fusty keller, pineapple. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20081003]

50 cL bottle, courtesy of fonefan. Pours hazy orange with a diminished white head. Pineapple fruity aroma initially but the earthy notes become more dominant later. Earthy flavour with a mild pineapple fruity note. Lasting earthy fruity finish.
Cask. Copper coloured. Malty; toasty malts, caramel. Citrus fruity. Floral hops. Sweet malty leading to dry bitter finish. OK. (2008)
Fra fat pÃ¥ Brunswick Inn i Derby 15 Feb 16. Delt med Rune. Gylden. 0 skum. Lett fruktaroma. 0 kullsyre. Smaken tÃ¸rket frukt. Uvariert.

Half from cask at Brunswick Inn. Shared with Finn. A filmy layer on top of a next to clear golden-brown body. Modest malt accented aromas with hints of fruity hops. Malt-fruity flavours, marmalade impression. Resinous bitterness to the ending. Slightly watered in the mouth. Pretty straightforward (Derby 15.02.2016).

A beautiful sunny afternoon on Friday 7th September 2012 saw my father and I join in R.A.T.2012 (Rail Ale Trail part 2). Split between three bars along the Wolverhampton to Shrewsbury railway line: they had over 50 different beers to try: this was one of them. Half-pint, gravity fed in the fest tent behind Codsall Railway Station. Really liked this: good light amber body; with a good head of off-white foam sat on top. Mixed bag of aromas, floral, semi-sweet molasses and woodyards. The taste was on the maltier side than hoppy although a hop bitterness was never far away. Well balanced and easy to drink, ideal on the day I reviewed it.

Cask (handpump) @ Market Porter, 9 Stoney Street, Southwark, London, Greater London, England SE1 9AA. Clear medium yellow amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, light to moderate hoppy, orange - citrus. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, sour malt notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120115]
tap at bow bar ... red copper ... white head ... soft fruit .. light wood hop ... dull soft toffee fruits

Cask at Thurrock Beer Festival 2011, Grays, England. Clear copper colour with tiny white head. Dark dry hops and malty woody in aroma. Dry dark hoppy bitterness in flavour. Long-lasting bitterness in aftertaste. Not that interesting.

Cask at GBBF, day 3 on 3 August 2006. Amber colour tending towards copper. Some citric, slightly resinous hop accents (I now see it uses Cascade) in the flavour. The hops are less prominent in the aroma. Decent enough. The hops are fine, just used rather too sparingly.

(Cask at Market Porter, Southwark, London, 19 May 2010) Amber colour with frothy, beige head. Malty, fruity nose with dried fruit, earthy hops and hints of sulphur. Fruity, hoppy taste with notes of citrus, a solid malt foundation and lots of earthy hops in the finish. Medium body, balanced sweetness. Tasty and very well balanced bitter.

Cask - The Murderers, Norwich. Pours a clear, dark amber with a thin and loose white head. Red fruits, citrus and some floral notes on the nose. Caramel, vinuous flavours: berry and sharp fruits with delicate hints of alcohol. Medium body, average length finish. Oddly different.
Amberkleurig en redelijke schuimkraag. Zoetig qua smaak. Goede nabitterheid.
Fles 33cl thuis. Bloemig, scherpig, maltig. Licht droog. Wat honingtonen. (11-2016).
Bottle @ Ghent. Clear colour, white foam. Sweet malts, some fruity notes, pretty oxidized, metallic. Not very nice.
Very strong blond beer in a humoristic bottle. Excellent mixture of bitter and sweet taste.
Bottle 33cl at Lars'. Poured yellow blond, large frothy head. Aroma is standard. Some flowers, some grass, hay. Taste has honey, grass, a bit fruit as well.

F: huge, egg-white, good retention. C: gold, light hazy. A: malty, fruity esters, orange peels, coriander, spicy, light grassy, yeasty. T: malty, orange peels, spicy, grassy, light metallic, yeasty, medium body, medium to high carbonation, very ordinary tripel, 33cl bottle from Carrefour market â€“ St. Michel @ Etterbeek, Brussels.
Bottle at home. Dark blonde with a white head. Yeast aroma. Sweet with not much bitterness to balance. Lightly syrup, honeyish flavours. Sweet, sticky finish. OK, but not great.

Voici une biÃ¨re pas du tout hypocrite, Ã  lâ€™inverse de ce "Mordeur de colonne" de Pieter Breughel. Elle assume en effet complÃ¨tement son parti pris pour une biÃ¨re en deux temps, le premier tournÃ© vers des arÃ´mes doux de caramel et de pain avant de voir un alcool sâ€™affirmer peu Ã  peu pour devenir omni-prÃ©sent. Ce parti pris la rend singuliÃ¨re, mais sur le dÃ©sÃ©quilibre de cet alcool intense en bouche, se perd de la richesse aromatique. Le nez est apprÃ©ciable, lÃ©gÃ¨rement floral avec des accents de miel, de caramel et un soupÃ§on de coriandre. A la dÃ©gustation, lâ€™attaque est souple, sur des arÃ´mes principalement de caramel, de pain et un soupÃ§on dâ€™Ã©pices. La deuxiÃ¨me bouche voit lâ€™alcool sâ€™affirmer. Que ce soit sur la ligne principale, tournÃ©e autour du malt avec des arÃ´mes de caramel et de pain, ou sur lâ€™arriÃ¨re bouche davantage tournÃ©e sur une amertume lÃ©gÃ¨rement Ã©picÃ©e.
