Pours clear yellow/orange with a huge, dense, frothy, white head. The aroma contains malt, wheat, yeast, spices, caramel and grass. It tastes light sweet and medium spicy bitter. Medium to light body, bit watery in texture, lively carbonation.
0,33l fles van de deen. Goudoranje met een witte kraag. smaak zoet met appelsap en een overdaad aan alcohol

Shared from bottle at M&M. Courtesy of Michael, wa vor Danke! Dark brown with white head. Sweet malts, caramel, chestnut, rye bread with honey, some dusty cardboard. Moderate sweet and bitter. Medium body and soft carbonation. Juicy mouth, tasty drink.

Cracking beer. I love my dunkels, but this one is slightly different, to its credit. The burnt umber pour gives off a distinct smell of brewyard malts--the smell you get as you walk past a brewery. There's even a farmyard niff, as if cows have been nestling on the malt. So this is proper rustic. The mouthfeel is thicker, more viscous than in the more sophisticated Bavarian dunkels--it's very smooth. The taste is unpretentious--the malts taste of malt, not chocolate, burnt toast, coffee, dark fruits and all that old cobblers--it tastes of roasted malts. My favourite taste. Above that, there's a slightly smoky tone, which is very welcome. I can't taste any hops bitterness ... but there's a metallic note on the end, which reminds me this is a lager and not nectar from the gods. Proper drink, though. HofmÃ¼hl: I shall remember the name.

Well balanced texture, creamy and thick without being too much of either; medium body and the ideal level of sweetness for my palate. Hints of coffee and bread and my only real criticism is that I wished those tastes came through a bit stronger. Big fan of this however and I'll be looking to get more in when possible.

500ml bottle from Beers of Europe; BBD 11th Jul 18. Poured into an old Wolnzacher Brauhaus badged tall glass tankard at home on 15th Feb 18. Clear mahogany body, big beige head that sadly fell away to a wisp and collar far too swiftly. Malty molasses rule the nose and taste of this fairly sweet Dunkel. Bit more body depth than some beers in this style. Liked it.
Trocken malziger Beginn, sowohl rÃ¶stig als auch metallern. Daraus entstehend stumpf, etwas getreidig, sogar wenig fruchtig. Dann wÃ¤ssrig werdend, dabei bitter-metallern. 8/7/5/6/7/6
Brown body, light brown head. Aroma has chocolate, mÃ¤mmi, bready malt. Flavour has lots of bread, some yeast and sweet malts. Bit light, but balanced.

Draft @ FrÃ¤nkisches Bierfest, NÃ¼rnberg. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor with hints of dark fruit. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.
Ins Glas ergieÃŸt sich ein rÃ¶tlich-braunes Bier mit schÃ¶ner Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht rÃ¶stmalzig, Karamell. Geschmack angenehm rÃ¶stmalzig, wÃ¼rzig, trocken.

0,5 l bottle BB 30.08.14 caramel, cereal, coffee, roasty, herbs, brown, clear, frothy, tan foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, oily feel, slick feel, average carbonation,
Bottle. Dark browm lowish head. Light toast aroma. Medium body, dry sparkly mouthfeel. Dry roasted grain and nutty notes with a fresh grassy hop counterpoint, caramel finish. Easy drinkable.
Clear dark red-brown with an off-white head. Aroma is roasted malts. Taste combines malts and a slight roasty flavour with a very gentle bitterness. Quite drinkable.
Fles 50cl in Hirschhorn. Bruin bier, zoet maar niet tÃ©, caramellig. (8-2010).
Pours dark red with minimal head and medium retention, low sweet coffee aroma, light body, sweet flavour.
50 cl. bottle. Low but lasting light brown head. Clear dark brown body. Roasted malt caramel liquorice aroma and flavor with little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a long sweet finish.

Flasche 0,5l: Kastanienbraun, schwarz, glasklar, krÃ¤ftiger feinporiger Schaum; in der Nase krÃ¤ftige RÃ¶staromen, RÃ¶stmalz, Malzzucker, getrocknete FrÃ¼chte, nussig, Haselnussschalen, deutliche Bitterkeit, Kaffee; frischer KÃ¶rper, krÃ¤ftige RÃ¶staromen, nussig, RÃ¶stmalz, cremig, krÃ¤ftige KohlensÃ¤ure, angenehme Bitterkeit, leichte fruchtige SÃ¤ure, Hopfennoten; angenehmer trocken-bitterer Nachgang mit krÃ¤ftigen RÃ¶staromen
Klares dunkelbraun mit durchschnittlicher, weiÃŸer Schaumkrone. Malzig, sÃ¼ÃŸlich, RÃ¶staromen, getreidig, wÃ¼rzig, leicht.

Bottle. Clear dark brown color, fast fading beige head. Weak aroma, slightly roasty malty. Dry taste, high bitterness. Metallic bitter aftertaste, low roast malt portion. Average carbonation, thin texture.

Dark ruby to black colour, small bubbles tan head, fades away quickly. Aroma is sweet and lightly roast, with hints of coffee and wine. Taste is sweet at the beggining and turns to bitter on the end, very soft and smooth. Tastes to me like coffee and licorice, some dried fruits are noticeable. Light body, fizzy carbonation. Itâ€™s ok.

Aroma: caramel and roasted dark malts. Appearance: deep brown color and creamy head. Taste: low bitterness, caramel, roasted dark malts, semi-dry. Palate: medium body and medium carbonation, roasted finish. Overall: Poor stuff.

Pours a dark ruby brown with some white head. Nose is roasted malt, a hint of coffee. Taste is same - roasted malt, milk chocolate, a hint of coffee, slightly sweet dark caramel, but there's very little bitterness here. A pretty clean feel and finish on the palate. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
From the archives: This is a reasonably drinkable pale lager. Close to non alcohol brews. Never seen it outside Russia though.
From the notes. Can. Yellow, fizzy. Aroma of beer, but less aroma than the other Baltikaâ€™s. Less taste than them too (except #0). Not much going on, or point.
Light and fruity. (This beer rating was imported from FB and unfortunately lacks any further comments.)

Hey, not too bad. My wife is Russian/German so she picked this up on a trip back to St.Petersburg. She got me 4 different Baltikas and this one wasnt too bad, minus the aftertaste and it is ok. i wouldnâ€™t go looking for it but again not too bad. Better than a select few of the American light beers. Not at all amzing, just so-so.
50cl can. pale yellow, thin head. not much going on here, bit metallic, malty aroma.

50 cL can from Samâ€™s Quik Shop. Golden yellow pour with a medium quickly dissipating head. Metallic and corny aroma. Taste is grain, corn, grass. Some metallic notes. Medium bodied. Honestly probably the best Baltika pale lager.
This is lawnmower, summer beer. Refreshing and clean at least, but not much of a body. Faint fruitiness, a bit of malt sweetness.
tastless clear watery piss of a beer. has to be one of the mildest experienses in my life.

500ml can. Light yellow, quickly dissipating head. Smells of aroma, but not much else. Taste is a whole mixed bag of things - ranging from a sweet light maltiness, to nothing at all, to cooking apples, to nothing at all, to beer. No, sorry I was lying about that last one. A masterpiece of blandness, but at least it wasnâ€™t nasty. If Iâ€™m being fair, I will own up to a little hint of hop in it. But that might just be the finish of last nightâ€™s 100gram still.

Canned, thanks oh6gdx Pale yellow, rich firm head. Fruity aroma with melon and pineapple Sweet and fairly light bodied with clean mouthfeel and notes of vegetables. Very low bitterness. refreshing (for being a BBH beer).
Goldgelb schaum is ok, Recht gewÃ¶hnliche halbe, ganz nett gehopft fÃ¼r mich etwas zu sÃ¼ÃŸ malzig
0,5l Flasche. Goldgelb klar, schÃ¶ner Schaum. Honig Getreideduft. SÃ¼ffiger Geschmack. Honig und Apfel. Cremig.
Beer with yellow color, light aspect, light bitterness, some foam on top, (drunk a 50cl tap beer at "Cosmos Bowling", Ingolstadt, DE #809)(#102 DE)(#38 Bavaria).

Bottled. Clear yellow colour, moderate white head with average retention. Malty nose with some hay and cereals. Sweet malty taste , bread, biscuit, weak hop bitterness. Light body, average carbonation, dry and malty finish. Average helles.

Bottle from Hopfen und Malz, Berlin. Gold with little head. Aroma of sweet bread, hay, really nice and fresh. Taste is similar sweet like fresh hawaiian bread. Light, enjoyable. Some nice bitterness retained, not like a Dortmunder and more like a pils. Sweet malty with great floral bitterness. Best helles around. No big yeast character like Weihenstephaner original, but very tasty and balanced.

Clear golden color with slightly off-white head. Aroma has fresh malt, bread crust and a light nuttiness. Taste follows with fresh baked bread, crackers, a bit of honey and some nutty bitterness on the finish. Medium body without a medium to light carbonation. Quite nice, tasty helles.
Mild getreidig-herber Beginn. Geringe SÃ¼ÃŸe, monoton. WÃ¤ssriger Mittelteil, noch leicht herb, kaum wÃ¼rzig. 7/8/7/7/9/7
Bottle from Beerbaboon - clear golden color with white head. Taste is pale malts, straw, medium sweetness. crisp and refreshing. Good Helles.

Where and how: Bottle 500ml Aroma: higher pitch in set up. Fresh floral hop feel with softer malty behind. Appearance : Top: creamy, medium top with marked rings on glass. Base: clear, golden. Palate : medium bodied, chewy texture Taste: nice, with slight hop feel up front. Softer mid and dry finish. Slight diacetyl but in this case I did not mind too much.
0,5 l Flasche aus einem kleinen Laden in EichstÃ¤tt. Orangegold, klar mit kleiner Schaumkrone. Riecht sÃ¼ÃŸlich. Im Geschmack Weizen, Cornflakes, Brot, leichte SÃ¼ÃŸe, aber auch leicht salzig

Yeah, so I go to C-Tank looking for some new brews to try, and their head brewer comes out and offers me some of this, their newest beer. He was a pretty cool guy, I think he had been enjoying his new creation :) Anyway I told him about ratebeer, so hopefully he visits the site. 'twas an excellent beer; the yeasty banana-clove flavor went quite well with the vanilla tones that were prominent in the flavor and aroma. Very clean finish with the vanilla coming through and lingering on the palate for a few minutes. The ABV was quite well disguised; I'd have never guessed 8.2%. Reminds me a little but of their Rockin' Rogger. An excellent beer!

Dark amber, small, textured head. Reminds me of my rating of Young's Dirty Dick's; no really prominent flavors, it just tastes like...beer! Malty and drinkable, it would be a good sports-watching drink as the name implies.
A decent maibock interpretation. No diacetyl, rich maltiness, not too much hops.

Draft at CDA at Fizz. Pours a deep bronze, very nice color, good clarity. Fluffy white head. Nose is doughy pils malt, some faint spicy hops and some fruitiness from the malt. On taste, lightly sweet with a balancing bitterness. Bready. Finish is reasonably dry with the fruitiness coming across as well. Hops are also present and clean up the back end nicely. Pretty solid Maibock, really.

Had this one on draught at the brewpub in Libertyville, Illinois. Clear amber pour with a nice, lacy head, candy nose -- Twizzlers? strawberry licorice anyway, nice malty character, finished sweet. Good!

Served under the alias "Fest Beer" because, I was told, it was no longer May. Deep-copper colored with a large, creamy-yet-tight, cream-colored head. Mildly sour grapefruit aromas with some alcohol as it warmed and an annoying touch of cattiness. Held moderate bitterness throughout with a lightly acidic finish. A bit watery... not "full-bodied". BrewFest, Elgin, IL 06/18/05

On tap at the brewpub: Handsome pour, a clear bronze body with a tall bubbly head that does some sweet lacing. The aroma is of hot toast with a honey-like hint of sweetness. Medium-bodied, it delivers a strong, sweet roasty malt flavor and a bit of apple fruitiness. At the finish thereâ€™s a brief smattering of hop bitterness. Not too bad. Mickey Finnâ€™s Brewery, Libertyville, IL

On draft at Finn's. Black in appearance with a good head. Slight smoky aroma. Taste is not very full and a bit watery. It's very similar to Guinness, but not quite as well rounded as that. Not bad. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nearly black with a tight tan head. Aroma is blackened malts with a hint of chocolate. Medium body with a creamy mouthfeel. Decent taste is roasty dry black malts with a dusting of cocoa powder. Not too bad.
Pour is black with ruby brown highlights and a tight bubbled tan head...smell is lightly roasty...taste is sweet and thin with hints of chocolate...lightly bitter coffee finish...

Draft Sampler, as "Hackett." I get a big coffee smell as soon as the glass gets near me. Appearance is black, with a thin layer of tan foam after sitting around whilst I finish the lighter beers in the sampler tray (ainâ€™t that always the way with a brewpubâ€™s stout?). Taste brings up dark roasted malt, with more coffee, and cocoa nibs. Roast malt taste is solid, but itâ€™s dry character adds nicely to the package. I liked it, what can I say?

Had this one on draught at the brewpub in Libertyville, Illinois, under the name "Hackett Stout." Opaque brown pour with a thick tan head, faint nose of cinnamon bread, mild bitter chocolate flavor with some toffee, great looking but bland tasting.

Nitro. Compared to their Stout this is sad. My notes liked the nitro head-effect back in the day but I have since had the Imperial stout on nitro from this place and mark it down for that. Still for a Guinness clone it is a more than accepteable style of that.

What can one say about a nitroâ€™ed Guinness clone except that it tastes alot like nitroâ€™ed Guinness? Perhaps itâ€™s got a little more coffee in the nose. Thatâ€™s about it. An average dry stout. Mickey Finnâ€™s Brewery, Libertyville, IL

On tap at Goose Island Stoutfest. Poured a beautiful black with a solid, long-lasting creamy caramel head. Typical dry stout feel to the aroma (nitroey feel with roasty chocolate and toffee). Dry, chalky chocolate and lighter roast coffee in the flavor with hints of oak. Rather light feel on the palate with a dry finish. Nothing exciting, but an easy-drinkinâ€™, smooth dry stout. â€™tis the season.

On tap at Mickey Finnâ€™s, Libertyville, IL. Black hued stout having a long lasting creamy tan head with good lacing. No discernable aroma and carbonation. Thin bodied with creamy texture that starts with dry/slight sweet malt with hints of chocolate, espresso and tobacco. Finishes dry with light bitterness. Though the beer is on the watery side, it is a good mild drinkable stout.

Very dark clear brown body, fine tan head. Black patent malt malt aroma with a dry, dark chocolate essence. The palate is a bit thin but at least the flavor packs a good amount of sweet chocolate, coffee acidity, and a touch of raspberry tartness.

This is an old rating I found. Tried all 3 versions, cask is best with the nitro version having best head. For me most porters I have trouble finding chocolate traits, this was true for this beer. More of a roasted malt aroma and taste, some grassy hops. Not overly bitter or dry. Good on cask, below average otherwise.

Kind of flat & thin, but manages to deliver a rich malt sweetness along with roasted barley and some milk chocolate in the taste. Some coffee, as well, in the nose. Finishes on a mildly bitter, sugar dusted, nutty note. Not bad, and probably better at the pub. Night of the Living Ales II at Goose Island Wrigleyville, Chicago, IL 03/04/2006

Nitro head holds lasting and creamy over a deep black body with garnet highlights. Coffee roasts and dark chocolate aroma with occasional smokiness. Palate is rather watery, but it doesnâ€™t affect the flavor of smoky chocolate roasts with a gentle, sugar-sweet finish. I decided to have an additional pint to enjoy rather than deconstruct. A really good brew, regardless if youâ€™re a fan of nitrogenation or not. On tap at Mickey Finnâ€™s , Libertyville, IL 60048

(01.16.06) Cask conditioned version available at Mickey Finnâ€™s, Libertyville, IL. Brown black porter with large long-lasting head with good lacing. No discernable carbonation. Faint malt aroma. Medium-bodied with creamy texture that starts with light malt sweetness and chocolate flavor. Finishes dry with light lingering bitterness. Smooth, creamy, like liquid chocolate. Delicious.

Smells burnt, and of roasted malt. Descent taste but is watery. Can pick out the elements of roasted malt and dark chocolate. Nor as full and robust as Iâ€™d like but a welcomed change to the other soft beers I sampled at Mickey Finnâ€™s that same day.

From notes. First reviewed 7/6/2010. On tap at Mickey Finnâ€™s in a pint glass. The beer has a slightly hazy dark golden / copper color with just barely a ring of a head. No lacing, very little visible carbonation. The aroma is hops - they describe the smell in the menu as hoppy and I cannot do better. After my first whiff, I am hoping the flavor does not mimic this flat, one dimensional smell. Unfortunately, it does. The flavor is listed as "very hoppy (citrus)," and I agree, except for the citrus part. Barely any flavor is able to sneak through this palette-destroying hop nuke. It is painfully obvious from the first sip forward that they just throw a ton of bittering hops in, forgetting that adding hops later in the process will add "flavor" and "aroma." After half a glass, the taste is pungent and cloying. Mouthfeel: Medium carbonation, medium body. Some graininess and a fair amount of hop oil. I would never order this again. It is definitely the worst IPA I have ever had. A stark comparison to their Hefe, which I enjoyed. Almost curious enough to try to get the recipe from the brewmaster just to post it as a warning.

Sampled at AleFest Chicago. Poured a fairly clear orange/amber with an average, off white foam and clingy lacing. The aroma was floral, with citrus and some resin following up. The flavor added to these some caramel and a balancing, appropriate hop bitterness. A refreshing, basic IPA.

Cask @ Day of the Living Ales. Pours copper with a thin white head. I had this one right after Lunar Brewingâ€™s Moondance IPA and this one wasnâ€™t as good. Still decent aroma of citrus hops. Bitter finish. Decent IPA.

clear gold, light off white head, no lace of which to speak. aroma is mild grapefruit, hints of pine. more flavorful than the nose suggests, with grapefruit, pine and a hint of pepper, nicely balanced. perhaps a suggestion of creamy caramel. medium bodied, bitter pine finish. quite enjoyably bitter. sampled at day of the living ales, 2009.
Clear amber with a tight head. Nice piney and floral hop aroma. Medium body. Mild flavor is sweet piney hop juice riding a bready malt base. Nicely bitter to finish.

Draught sampler: Clingy head over an enticing copper IPA body. Smell shows a nice bit of hop to it. Taste shows it is not a hop bomb, but itâ€™s very nicely laid out; lemon and pine with some English hops in balance (thatâ€™s what I thought before I saw the description, so Iâ€™m actually improving my palate!). A nice combination of US and UK style. Nitro sampler: Toward the end of my sampler tour, this still shows a star-shaped bit of foam in my glass. Carbonation is a little firm for a nitro, but pinprickly and enjoyable. Nitro gives the caramel malt more room to play

On nitro. Poured a clear medium caramel with a short cap of creamy off-white headâ€¦ creamy lacing followed it down. The aroma was muted by the nitro treatment.. but pine, floral, and some sweet caramel seep through.. picks up steam as it warms. The flavor was really carried by sticky vegetal and pine notes.. did not enjoy that very much.. caramel base.. left rather sharp pine and vegetal notes on a long-ish finish. Slick beginning becomes tacky and ugly feeling the rest of the way across the palate. Not good.

(03.18.06) On tap at Mickey Finnâ€™s, Libertyville, IL. Clear amber hued IPA with a tiny white head. No discernable carbonation. Light hop aroma. Medium bodied that starts with light malt sweetness and light hop flavor. Slight hop bitterness in the mouth. Finishes dry with light hop bitterness. The hop flavor component was underwhelming. This beer is styled closer to a pale ale, than a IPA. Though this is a good drinkable beer, hopheads will be disappointed.

Decent enough APA but too tame to be considered an IPA I think! Some pine and grapefruit hopping over the caramel malt base. I picked up a faint trace of solvent, that thankfully was very transitory. Iâ€™d drink this again, but not if I was in the mood for a real IPA.
Sampled at Night of the Living Ales II. A translucent orange with white frothy head. Pine and floral hops along with citrus and caramel malts. A standard but decent IPA.
Good basic malty bock, along the lines of Spaten Bock and drinkable in quantity. Adheres strictly to style.

25 cL Bottle at home. Pours slightly hazy yellow with a medium white head. Aroma is quite musty and bready, some spices. Taste is grainy with some carton and a soft bitter finish. Medium body and carbo.

25 cl bottle bought at Coop, somewhere in Geneva (there are like a thousand ones.) Pours hazy clear golden, no bubble visible, short lasting super white head. Aroma is quite mild: porridge, bread, vanilla, cilantro. Mouth is fizzy, kinda umami goinâ€™ down, not really fresh. Low bitterness. Short, easy, relieving.
Pale golden color, cloudy liquid and average head. Citric aroma. Taste is sweet with fruity notes. Nice swiss witbieer

I bought this beer at the LÃ©man Center and I drank it today, relax with some friends. The color is yellow, creamy and troubled. The foam is thin and white. The carbonation is regular. The taste is really refreshing, wheat, banana and there is a nice touch of "coriandre". We smell the fruit, some hop.
A pleasant surprise. La Claire has a hint of color and a rounded flavor with a Belgian accent. Quite nice.
Spicy yeasty aroma, on the wit side. Quickly disappearing white fizzy head. Almost clear yellow. A touch of diacetyl. Other than that refreshing, citrusy blonde.
hazy yellow beer, not much head. smells and tasts bittersweet, of clove and hops, some fruit. aftertaste is bittersweet, spicy.
Appearance: No 43. Hazy pale yellow. Basically no head. Aroma: Pleasant citrus fruit, some hops. Taste: Hops and some lemon and yeast. Not much aftertaste. Info: 250ml bottle, 11/11-2009
Bottled. Yellow with coarse airy head. Vinegar aroma. Very rounded, rather sweet. Mild with low bitterness.

apparently brewed with top-fermented yeast, a surprise considering the beer - golden-orange colour, no foam, hoppy and herbal with some fruity notes, sparkling, refreshing, light-bodied with a dry and slightly bitter finish
a cheap beer in a tobacco brand,it seems this beer will destory its brand with such low quality water beer

Light watery and fizzy. The waitress wasnâ€™t kidding when she said lighter than Canadian but boy did she get me good. There is a bit of hop flavor which was a pleasant surprise and the reason I gave taste a 3.

Bottle 355ml. @ The Danish Summer Gathering, TFODRBSG12, Ulfborg. Clear medium orange yellow colour with a small, fizzy, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, oxidide, corn, light honey, light to moderate hoppy. Flavour is moderate sweet with a average duration, malty, oxidide. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120818]
Bottle @ Danish Summer Gathering Ulfborg, 2012. Pours clear golden with a off white head. Corn, bread and maize. Nasty and quite oxidized.
Bottle @ Summer Gathering, Ulfborg. No head. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, butter and hops. Looks a bit old. No carbonation.
Bottle @ TFODRBSG, Ulfborg. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, light malty and light oxidated. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. Watery. 180812
Bottle @ FOneFan, Danish Ratebeer Summer Gathering 2012. Clear golden with tiny white head. Aroma is malt and grainy. Flavour is malt, grainy, sweet, hops, vegetable and a little watery.

Bottle 355ml @ TFODRBSG12 Pours clear golden with no head. Aroma has notes of malt, biscuit, grain, oxidized and caramel. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is thin, carbonation is flat.

Bottle, at TFODRBSG 2012. A clear one, golden in color and with a small, white head. Seems to be a bit old, at least thereâ€™s some oxidation. Then again, itâ€™s Chinese... Fruityness and almost buttery maltyness in the aroma. The flavor is pretty much the same, oxidation, fruityness and popcorn like maltyness. Medium body. Some bitterness and grass in the finish. Not awful in any way, not very interesting either. 120818
Bottle. Pours clear golden with a small white head. The aroma is grain and cereal. The flavour is grany and sweet caramelish.
Cask at RAF '03. Bitter to the point of not being fun anymore. Slight rubber shoe flavor.

Very light, very mild. Nothing bold as the description states. Nice session ale with very low bitterness and alcohol. Very clean, left no aftertaste. Cascade isn't obvious, but the light hoppy tease pleases.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Pour on tap at the brewery, slightly hazy orange yellow pour with thin white head, aroma brought notes of bread, dough, some grain, husk, slight earth, some yeast. Taste was a mix of earth, bread, dough, some yeast into a bit of grain, very slight fruit into some trash, finishing slightly spicy.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Kind of a boring wheat beer. Not a ton of flavor or body. Lacked complexity in my opinion.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On draft at the brewery. The beer has a light copper body with a mid haze and small, off-white head. The aroma is weak, but offers a little wheat, cracker, lemon. Refreshing, but bland. Thin, watery body with only hints of wheat, light spice, biscuity malt. No off flavors, just lacking and unassertive. At >4% abv, this goes down easily on a summer day.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Draft at brewpub. Pours golden with no head. Oily On the tongue. Doesnâ€™t taste or smell like much. Finish really dries out the mouth. Nope!

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Tap. Cloudy yellow with no head. Wheat, corn flakes, cider vinegar, and lemon. Taste is lightly sweet, with a vinegar tartness. Medium body with a bubbly feel.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On draft at the pub. The aroma is very mild. Flavors of big league chew/bubblegum, dough, earthy bitterness. The lemon will help this one.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Growler poured a hazy gold with a lingering ring of white foam. Aromas of wheat, fruittiness and straw. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of wheat, straw and light fruittiness with a crisp dry finish.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: on tap-pours cloudy yellow with a thin layer of white bubbles. Aroma is soft wheat/grain, hint of citrus? Taste is soft wheat/grain, hint of citrus-orange. Towards medium body, not thin, but very soft on taste.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Draft. Served with a lemon. Cloudy light yellow color, no head or lacing. Aroma of lemon. Taste of lemon. Plain.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Drinking from 33cl bottle. A medium bitter aroma, citrus. The clear golden beer has a medium white head. In the taste citrus, a bit sour. High carbonated

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: å¥ˆè‰¯æ¼¬ã‘ã®ã‚ˆã†ãªå¤‰ãªé¦™ã‚Šã€ã»ã‚“ã®ã‚Šé…¸å‘³.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a hazy orange to light brown color. Bar pour doesnâ€™t yield any head. The smell had the normal "soapiness" of English malts extending throughout the beer. Light somewhat spicy hops are underneath. The taste followed the nose. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a decent sessionable aspect about it. Overall, I say this was a good ESB worthy of having again.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On draft at the brewery. The beer has a copper body, mostly clear, with a thin, wispy head. The aroma is mild, offering bready malts, grain, fruits (apple?). Malt forward with a light sweetness and a touch of hop bitterness in the finish. Thin bodied with moderately low carbonation. Easy drinking and refreshing, albeit on the bland side.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Growler poured a clear reddish amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of carmel, toffee and light butterscotch. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, toffee and light butterscotrch with a smooth lingering toffee finish.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: on tap-pours gold with an offwhite head. Aroma is soft medium malt. Taste is sweet medium malt-caramel/bready, some earthy/spice hops.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Draft at brewpub - a fairly lackluster, overly sweet bitter - a lot of residual sugar and adjunct-y (corn syrup-like) sweetness - some toasted/burnt grains and faint earthy hops - not so much bitter at the end as it is acidic - a little metallic on the tail end - boring.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Very nice biscuit taste, supported by a nice hop bitterness. Well brewed.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Draught from the brewpub poured into sampler - Pours red amber; Floral hops and malt to the nose; Lots of floral hops and malt on the initial taste; A little grassy backtaste; Medium palate; Pleasant carbonation; Had a light warming sensation as it went down. Not a bad bitter at all.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Amber color with a small dense head. Fruity hop aroma and taste. Thin body. Good session beer.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Another beer I don't remember too much about other than it was very good. My wife and I were passing through and tried this brew pub and thoroughly enjoyed the experience.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Pours gold with a white head. Smells of citrus, some earthy undertones. Tastes citrussy with an earthy hint on the finish.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Draft at the brewery. Scores low because I do not think this is an ipa at all.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Sweet and fruity aroma, some apple and brown sugar present, along with hints of cola and black cherry, perhaps a very slight amount of bubblegum and lurking far in the background are some leafy hops. Incredibly deep, dark red color, unusual shade for an IPA, with a very slight head, dissipating completely over a short while. Flavor profile is balanced a bit toward the hops, luckily, acting to keep it somewhat in style, also has some brown sugary malts up front, turning fruity and blended with some notable yeast esters midpoint, mingling with the spicy, lightly piney hop notes and yielding a light-moderate amount of bitterness there at the finish and a barely noticeable amount of alcohol. Some Kool-Aid and cotton candyish notes very late. Really more like a Brown/Amber hybrid with a higher degree of hopping than usual. Smooth carbonation prickly mouthfeel regardless, also lightly syrupy and with a medium body. Somewhat interesting but not quite brewed to style, for those expecting a standard IPA.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Draft at the brewery. Not exactly a standard IPA, copper colored light tan head. Citurs and caramel aroma, mild all around. The flavor is a good bit malty though there is plenty of citrus and bitterness from the hops. Medium bodied with a bite of bitterness that lingers. A tad bit slimy with a lingering finish.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On tap at brewpub. Ugh. Ruddy red color with no head. No hop aroma at all. Slight caramel malts aroma and taste some sweetness. Very mild dry finish. I think they missed a brewing step with the hops or were a little short as this was not good at all.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: From Bottle. Great nose, tons of hops, flowers, fruit. Nice bite to the nose. Pours a very nice clystal amber, nice fluffy white head that has good staying power. Attack doesnâ€™t quite live up to the nose, which is too bad because the attack comes off weaker than it is just because the nose is so strong. Nice bitterness to this beer. Finishes very well.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: This is a decent IPA that smelled really good with lots of aroma. The attack was ok with plenty of hops, but it was just decent after that. A sold IPA, but nothing special

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Has a nice amber color and a fruity hop smell. Taste is nicely hopped and finishes with a nice bitterness. Overall this a good IPA, but I prefer the bitter for a good hop beer.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On tap in a flight at the brewery. Nice, brownish, orange color, with some fine, beige remnants of a head. Pine, butterscotch, and some hay and earth. Sweet and malty, with a sharp, nice bitterness. Medium body, sticky, a little acidic, and hard. This is a pretty solid pale ale. Malt forward, with earthy and musty hops.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Pours golden with a white head. Drymalty aroma. Dry malty flavor, with an earthy tannin finish. Notes: on tap at the brew pub, June â€™17

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Drank from tap at the brewhouse/restaurant -- For and American Pale Ale, this was subpar. Just, ok.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Pour on tap at the brewery, clear orange pour with white head, aroma brought notes of bread, dough, slight orange, touch of yeast, slight spice, grass, touch of pine. Taste was a mix of sweet bread, dough, some butter into a bit of grain, husk, some butter, finishing slightly sweet.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: An OK pale ale. Well balanced between the hops and malts but lacks body and complexity. Only ok.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a hazy light brown with some light orange tinges around the sides of the glass. A soft thin white head died within less than a minute. Mild stringy lacing slid into the body. The smell seemed to have had English malts up front with a light bitter grassy hoppiness running underneath. The taste was basically the same. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium in body with a fairly decent sessionable aspect about it. Overall, I say this was a decent English Pale ale to have again.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Pours copper/amber with a think off white head. Smells earthy, dusty, some resiny hints. Tastes lightly earthy and spicy with a tangy finish.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Generally plain beer. Bitter withou much flavour, hops variety is too bitter would be better with a floral hops.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Tap. Resinous, light lemon, rich malts and crackers. Moderately sweet, followed by moderately bitter. Medium body with oily feel. Closest thing to Summit EPA I have tasted.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On drat at the pub. Yet another diacetyl bomb like the other five I have tried so far. Spicy hops and grain malts accompany the diacetyl. Meh.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Though retired, I had this well before it was. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a dark brown color. Bar pour didnâ€™t have any head. The smell had a light nuttiness with a roasty malt. There was some light chocolate in there as well. The taste followed the nose. On the palate, this one sat light for a brown ale, perhaps a little more watery than expected. Pretty sessionable. Overall, no complaints from me, could probably have downed a fair amount of these in a session.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On draft at the brewery. The beer has a dark chestnut body with a small beige ringlet atop. Aromas include malt, earthy hops, nuts. Similar flavor, with a light sweetness. Thin body. Some toasted caramel and biscuit / bread notes as well. This was decent.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Reviewed from notes. On tap in August 2009. Pours a moderate brown color with an off white head and a bit of lacing. Good retention. The nose is some light earthy hops along with some mild roast, chocolate, and nuts. The taste is a bit roasty with some toast and light chocolate. Good medium body and a good all-around brew. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 11-10-2010

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: This has a bit of a porter aroma to it - some coffee notes - some chocolate. Light mocha colored head with decent lacing. Dark red appearance - tastes, looks and feels more lika a porter. Chocolate and coffee notes carry over to the flavor as well.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On tap with Erica, Chris and Patty in Deadwood Saloon #10. poured brown and a light tan head. Aroma is roasty medium malt-caramel. Taste is roasty medium malt-caramel, some earthy hops. Nice and cold on a hot day walking round town.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Growler poured a clear reddish brown with a lingering ring of tan foam. Aromas of carmel, cocoa and light toasted malt. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of cocoa, carmel and chalkiness with a crisp dry finish.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: on tap-pours brown with red tint and a light tan head. Aroma is roasty medium malt-caramel. Taste is roasty medium malt-caramel/peat, some earthy hops.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Easily the best of the Firehouse brews. Still, it doesnâ€™t merit repeat trips when Iâ€™m in SD.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery in Rapid City. Best beer I had at the Firehouse. Medium brown appearance with almost no head. Malty and smoky aroma. Nice roasted malt and nutty taste. Smooth mouthfeel. Satisfying if not the most exciting - sort of like South Dakota (hey, at least itâ€™s not Iowa).

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: If you are at the firehouse this is the beer to get. Nice dark brown appearance with no head.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Dark brown, no head, smooth with a clean aftertaste. I could really taste the hops. Definitely THE best beer at this brewery. This will be the only beer I try if I go in there again.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Dark red with a smoky nose. Highly nut-bittered and hearty. Good American brown ale and the best at this SD brewpub.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Has a dark brown color and a roasted malt/chocolate. Taste is of chocolate malt and finishes with a good crisp bitterness. Overall I am not a big fan of brown ales, but this one was not bad.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Fairly mild aroma, some dark toffee and cocoa, some slight roastiness present here as well. Opaque ebony color, head is almost fully diminishing. Flavor is bittersweet and chocolately to start, but mildly, becoming a bit more roasty and features some mild bitterness towards the finish, both from the lightly spicy hop character and the mildly coffeeish malts, seemingly. Lingering notes of cocoa at the very end. Smooth, thin mouthfeel, low in effervescence, body is light-medium. Less interesting than many Porters Iâ€™ve tried.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Draft at brewpub. Dark brown color with an average creamy brown head that mostly lasted and produced good lacing. Moderate roasted chocolate aroma. Medium body with a dry smooth texture. Medium roasted sweet flavor with a light bitter finish of moderate duration. This beer went well with the taco salad I had.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: This is beer is a strong porter. I thought this was the worst beer at the firehouse. I agree with mr. od40oz about the higher temp. It would taste a lot better cold.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Dark beer with a smooth taste and no head. Had an unusual aftertaste. I could definitely taste the hops. I wish the Firehouse would serve their beer colder but they insist on serving it at 42 degrees.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Light coffee tones in flavor and aroma on this unspectacular porter. Bit too thin with no carbonation.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Has a very dark brown color and a roasted malt/coffee smell. Taste is of roasted malts and finishes with a slight hop bitterness. Overall a great porter.

Enjoyed on tap at Flatlanders Brewery while waiting for some soon-to-be former co-workers (2 weeks left!). Appearance like miller lite, clear pale yellow with small white head. Aroma like miller lite, smells of straw hay, somewhat like an old manâ€™s basement but not as succinct as ml, no hop presence whatsoever. Taste is surprisingly good! Actually has a piney hop flavor that adds to the smoothness, slightly crisp in the flnish, not too malty, actually more hoppy than malty but not an ipa or pale ale by any means. Pleasant surprise and would definitely recommend to any continual lager consumers.
Hazy gold with a white head. Diacetyl aroma. Taste is malt with diacetyl and some light hops.

Sample at the brewpub. This beer is a clear orange-gold color with a thin and creamy white head that recedes to a film eventually. Half rings of lacing on the glass. Mildly spiced hops aroma with notes of bready malt. Light body with flavors of mildly floral hops, grainy malt and a bit of corn. The finish is lightly bitter with a hoppy aftertaste. Okay overall.
Pour is clear golden yellow with a thin white head...smell is lightly grassy and hoppy...taste is lightly sweet with a nice grassy herbal bitterness...
On tap at the Flatlanders Brew Pub. Poured a light and clear yellow color with a small sized white head. Aromas and tastes of general grassiness and a touch of malty sweetness (caramel). Thin body.

Poured a clear bright golden with a short, creamy white head.. nice lacing. Aroma was of sweet, soft biscuity pale malts with mild floral accents.. touch of caramel too. Flavor found a light biscuity base with a citrus twist.. simple, but tasty. Light-bodied but never watery.. dry and refreshing finish. Nice one.

Draught sample at the brewpub, December 28th 2006. Faintly hazy gold with a small ring of head, no lacing....grassy nose seems almost crisp and pleasant but a hint of musty dry yeast kills that and flattens the pleasantness....rather adjuncty (ricey) sour body, very typical cheap-big 3-pale lager profile, watery with low carbonation...some off flavors, spoiled milk and metallic notes...not good at all really.

Pale golden with a thin white skin that leaves wet lace trails. Light cattiness opens up to noble hop bitters. Creamy with a tingle. Gentle bitterness holds above a nutty base. Nothing adjuncty nor "off" about it... which is all you can really hope for from a brewpub Pale Lager. On tap at Flatlanders Restaurant & Brewery, Lincolnshire, IL 60069

Draught at the brewpub. Pale golden. Clear. Small white head. Subdued noble hop aromas. Reminds me very much of a kÃ¶lsch because of the way the hops and the flavours stand out. Really mellow aroma and flavours with a more prominent hop bitterness. Finishes somewhat neutral with only a little dryness from hops.

Fizzy gold with a short foamy head. Dish detergent aroma, Herbal Essence shampoo and pils malt. Hits as astringent but light. Finishes like chomping on a dishwasher tab. Some bready characteristics but paling and tinged overall.
@CBCâ€“on tap-pours a tan head and mahogany color. Aroma is dark fruit, secondary earthy hops. Taste is dark fruit, biting earthy hops, medium/dark malt.

This brew must have sat too long since beervana had it, because what I had looked nice but tasted off. Deep brown with a creamy beige head that soon turns to film, itâ€™s got a roasted malt aroma with some bitter nuts. Thereâ€™s no dopplebock sweetness to it, but a continuation of the roasted malts followed by a sour apple finish. Not quite right at all. Flatlanders Restaurant & Brewery, Lincolnshire, IL

(02.12.06) On tap at Flatlanderâ€™s brewpub, Lincolnshire, IL. Clear dark brown lager having an average size off-white head with good lacing. Soft carbonation. Sweet malt aroma. Full bodied that starts with malt sweetness and butterscotch/caramel flavors. Finishes with sweet malt fade. Smooth, creamy and rich. A very tasty offering from Flatlanderâ€™s.
On tap at portneuf brewing. Pours out golden topped with a white head. Nose is grassy hops some sweet malts. Taste is more of the light grassy hop notes and a touch of cereal malt.

Draft @ Mountain Brewers Beer Fest 2010, Idaho Falls, ID. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty and slighlty buttery aroma. Sweetish malty buttery caramel flavor with hoppy bitter hints. Has a sweetish malty hoppy bitter finish.
Pours a nice orangish color. Aroma is grassy hops. Flavor of a classic pale, big grassy hop flavor.

Draft: Pours a sharp golden orange color with a light beige head. Aroma is faint, but has the similar sweet malty profile as the other PV brews. The taste comes through better, more citrus, floral, and caramel than the aroma suggests. No real bitterness, but flavorful and a nice bodyweight.
on tap-pours a white head and pale yellow color. Aroma is faint medium malt-some sweet. Taste is medium malt-some sweet, musty, secondary hops-some bitterness. OK/mild carbonation.

This was a really decent APA. Huge hop nose, just bursting out of the glass with grapefruit and pine needles. Sweeter malt profile, with some juicy fruits and a very creamy mouthfeel. Extremely well balanced and well done.

PVB is usually pretty hit and miss, but they were on a good batch of Sunshine so I brought home a growler. Pale blonde with moderate carbonation. Lightly sweet, very fruity aroma. Starts sweet and stays smooth and fruity. No real bitterness, but nice flavor. Very smooth, almost creamy. You have to hit a good batch, but when you do, good is GOOD.

column1: Portneuf Valley Twisted Stick Amber Ale
column5: Taster at brewery. Light caramel notes on this amber. Light amber body too. Mildly sweet, caramel, toffee.

column1: Portneuf Valley Twisted Stick Amber Ale
column5: Tap @ brewery: Clear amber color with no head. Buttery, nutty flavors. Pleasant aroma with a thin aftertaste.

column1: Portneuf Valley Twisted Stick Amber Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery in Pocatello, Idaho. This arrived with a good head over a clear, dark amber body. Baked bread and caramel in the aroma with some spicy hops. Flavor follows with about equal bitterness and sweetness. Typical strength and slightly high bitterness and hoppiness for style.

column1: Portneuf Valley Twisted Stick Amber Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery Standard amber. Toasted malts and a barley balanced hop character.

column1: Portneuf Valley Twisted Stick Amber Ale
column5: On tap at portneuf brewing. Pours out amber topped with a small sand head. Nose is rich malts some pine and citrus hops. Taste is more of the pine citrus hops a caramel malt and some sweetness.

column1: Portneuf Valley Twisted Stick Amber Ale
column5: Slight soapy flavor. Okay head. Not very good light hop. Very thin on tongue. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Portneuf Valley Twisted Stick Amber Ale
column5: Draft. Rich amber beer with a cream head. Malt aroma. Grapefruit and light pine flavor with light caramel. Medium bodied. Grapefruit and light pine linger.

column1: Portneuf Valley Twisted Stick Amber Ale
column5: Had on draft at the brewery. There were notes of caramel, some slight astringency, fruity, diacetyl. Great label terrible beer.

column1: Portneuf Valley Twisted Stick Amber Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub Appearance: Slightly cloudy amber with a medium sized off-white head and some lacing Aroma: Caramel, biscuity and citrus Taste: Toasted malts, nutty, caramel and citrus Nice and clean

column1: Portneuf Valley Twisted Stick Amber Ale
column5: Draft. Amber with a small ring of bubbles, not much lace. Nose of caramel, and light grapefruit and resin. Flavor is mild blend of the same. Light-medium body is watery and lightly tingly.
Taster at brewery. Light golden, skin of head. Served with lemon, unnecessary. Adds too much citrus. Hides a bland beer, not too much weizen here, not very clear either.
(En fÃ»t Ã  la source): BlÃ© machable, douceur minÃ©rale et un bouquet d'esters civilisÃ© et en contrÃ´le.
Tap @ brewery: Clear gold with a lot of head. Sweet malt aroma with mild taste. Semi-sweet aftertaste.

On tap at the brewery in Pocatello, Idaho. This arrived with a fine head over a clear amber body. It also had a slice of lemon which I removed. Light spicy bread in the aroma with suggestions of citrus. Flavor follows. Clean. Typical strength and bitterness for style.
On tap at the brewery Hazy light orange. Very light pale malt flavors. A bit slick body . Drinkable and soft.
On tap at portneuf brewing. Pours out a hazy straw topped with a white head. Nose is toast wheat some citrus. Taste is more of the toasted malts some wheat lemon citrus touch.

Draft sample at the brewery solely for a krystal counter. Lightly hazy gold color with a white head. Classic lager yeast aroma with a little banana ester. Crisp, clean flavor with some light, lingering bitterness. Enjoyable and true to style
Lemon light aroma. Pretty good flavor. Malty. Nice fading head. Citrus and grain. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft. Amber beer with a whitish head. Caramel and toasted malt aroma. Wheat and caramel flavor. Medium bodied. Wheat and caramel linger with grain.

On tap at the brewery Appearance: Cloudy golden with a small white head and some lacing Aroma: Bready, butterscotch and wheat Taste: Wheat, buttery, grainy and citrus. Sticky mouthfeel This was ok, light but didnâ€™t taste right.

column1: Portneuf Valley Belligerent Ass Nut Brown Ale
column5: Taster at brewery. Dark brown, as expected, small beige head. Pretty standard brown ale, light roast, nutty character, mild bite.

column1: Portneuf Valley Belligerent Ass Nut Brown Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery in Pocatello, Idaho. This arrived with an excellent head over a nearly opaque, brown-black body. Attractive, malty aroma. Flavor: lightly bitter with hints of roast coffee; semi-sweet chocolate, slightly burnt toast and black bread. Smooth, medium-light body.

column1: Portneuf Valley Belligerent Ass Nut Brown Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery Clear deep reddish brown. Toasted brown malt aroma slightly of maple syrup. Flavor though was a bizzare chemically papery flavor. Just off.

column1: Portneuf Valley Belligerent Ass Nut Brown Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery pours out brown topped with a small tan head. Nose is chocolate nutty roast malts some grain. Taste is more of the sweet chocolate roast malts and a little coffee.

column1: Portneuf Valley Belligerent Ass Nut Brown Ale
column5: Best option here. Thin on tongue but wonderful toasty flavor. Good malt base of grain. Very enjoyable. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Portneuf Valley Belligerent Ass Nut Brown Ale
column5: Draft. Amber-brown beer with a cream head. Caramel and light toasty aroma. Nutty and caramel flavor with light citrus. Medium bodied. Caramel and earth linger with backing PNW hops and light caramel.

column1: Portneuf Valley Belligerent Ass Nut Brown Ale
column5: Had on draft at the brewery. There are notes of chocolate, coffee, fruity, and roasty. A nice enough beer. Nothing really impressive, but it is drinkable.

column1: Portneuf Valley Belligerent Ass Nut Brown Ale
column5: This would make a great gift for a few certain people in my life. Draft. Hazy. Rown color, medium tan head. Aroma of nuts and toast. Taste is nutty brown bread decent.

column1: Portneuf Valley Belligerent Ass Nut Brown Ale
column5: Tap: Clear brown with a frothy light brown head. Vanilla, nutty aroma. Thin bodied brown ale with light flavors of nuts, malts, very mild bananas with a slight bitter aftertaste. Not bad for a Pocatello brewery.

column1: Portneuf Valley Belligerent Ass Nut Brown Ale
column5: Draft pint at the brewpub. Dark brown with a lasting creamy head. Nose is toasted nut, cocoa, light espresso, caramel. Flavor is cocoa, malt, toasted walnut, light char. Near-medium body is smoothly carbonated, easy drinking with a slight chalkiness providing a nice balance to the big malts.
